title: Familiar Rivals in Final Four
description: DENVER  In one semifinal at the N.C.A.A. womens Final Four, Baylor and Stanford will duel for the fourth time in their histories. In the other semifinal, Notre Dame and Connecticut will double that  in just the last two years.

title: The Nourse Auditorium
description: Despite street signs that point out the Nourse Auditorium, few walking past the hulking building at Hayes and Franklin Streets know about the opulent 1,800-seat theater inside. Built in 1927 for the High School of Commerce, it has served as a stage for poets, rock stars, lawyers and, for the last 30 years, as storage space for the San Francisco Unified School District.

title: Wildcats Are Winners in Battle for Kentucky
description: NEW ORLEANS  The faithful flocked from the Commonwealth of Kentucky for their sporting version of a religious experience. The fans of Louisville and Kentucky practically filled the Superdome, with its capacity for 74,000 people, and created an atmosphere that made the stadium feel like a high school bandbox in Paducah or Owensboro.

title: Surprise in Florida Clouds Favorites Path to the Kentucky Derby
description: HALLANDALE BEACH, Fla.  Union Rags was relegated to the role of spectator in Saturdays 63rd running of the Florida Derby at Gulfstream Park as Take Charge Indy led from the start and pulled off the upset.

title: 40-0 in Sight, Baylor Turns Focus to Stanford
description: DENVER  Undefeated seasons in womens basketball have been the exclusive property of Connecticut this century; the Huskies 39-0 seasons of 2001-2, 2009-10 and 2010-11 are the only perfect runs since Pat Summitts Tennessee Volunteers went unblemished in winning the 1998 national championship.

title: The Secret Owners Behind a Prostitution Website
description: My Sunday column tries to pull back the veil on the owners of Village Voice Media, the company that owns (besides the Village Voice newspaper) the website Backpage.com, which is generally regarded as the leading site for trafficking of women and girls in the United States. The big surprise: Goldman Sachs turned out to be a 16 percent owner.

title: A Study in Contrasts
description: DENVER  The coaches in the N.C.A.A. mens and womens Final Fours have similar issues as part of their jobs: waging recruiting battles, balancing players practice time with academics and fighting a culture that emphasizes results in March at the expense of games from November to February.

title: Keith Olbermann: Machine Gun for Hire
description: Given Keith Olbermanns abrupt removal at Current and his typically temperate response  Currents statement are untrue and will be proved so in the legal actions I will be filing against them presently  it seems as if his next stop will be a puppet show shot from a basement somewhere. Hell never work in this town, or any other, again, right?

title: N.C.A.A. Tournament Replay: March 31
description: Kentucky roared past Louisville, 69-61, and Kansas pulled off a comeback victory over Ohio State, 64-62, to advance to the national title game.

title: Romney Predicts a Victory in Wisconsin Primary
description: FITCHBURG, Wis.  At a drop-by stop to help a phone bank for Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, Mitt Romney predicted a victory in Wisconsin on Tuesday.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 31, 2012

title: Corrections: April 1
description: NATIONAL

title: Kansas Tops Ohio State in Tense Stretch Run
description: NEW ORLEANS  Kansas won the other game Saturday, the second N.C.A.A. tournament national semifinal, a contest most notable on the surface for what it lacked: even one team from the Bluegrass State.

title: Subway Free-Ride Suspects
description: Suspects, with their faces showing, after they left the subway station at East 116th Street and Lexington Avenue in East Harlem around 5:15 a.m.

title: Chain Bandits
description: A suspect with a backpack and a white scarf was joined by others to tie open an emergency gate with chains.

title: Recording the Crime
description: The police were also trying to identify a man taking photographs of the suspects as they carried out their mission.

title: Jamie Rosenkrantz, Joshua Spoont
description: Jamie Lauren Rosenkrantz and Joshua Lee Spoont were married Saturday evening. Rabbi Robert Silvers officiated at the Woodfield Country Club in Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Tracey Lomrantz, Eric Lester
description: Tracey Lomrantz and Eric Lester were married Saturday evening at the Angel Orensanz Foundation in New York. Rabbi Matthew A. Reimer officiated.

title: Emily Siguler, Langdon Mitchell
description: Emily Ann Siguler and Langdon Paull Mitchell were married Saturday by the Rev. Steven Zehler at Our Lady Star of the Sea Catholic Church in Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla.

title: Pamela Bookbinder, Ernest Clarke
description: Pamela Morgan Bookbinder and Ernest Richard Clarke were married Saturday evening at the Maplewood Country Club in Maplewood, N.J. Rabbi Stuart Gershon officiated.

title: Eileen Shy, Andrew Ormson
description: Eileen Catherine Shy and Andrew Forrester Ormson were married Saturday at the Liberty Warehouse, an event space in Brooklyn. Carissa Templeton, a minister affiliated with Rose Ministries, led the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Monica Malone, Mark Murphy
description: Monica Jeanne Malone and Mark Daniel Murphy were married Saturday at Holy Rosary Church in Hawthorne, N.Y. The Rev. John Fraser, a Roman Catholic priest and the churchs pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: Shushannah Walshe and Ari Yasgur
description: Shushannah Martina Jane Walshe, a daughter of Estelle and Michael W. Walshe of Delray Beach, Fla., is to be married Sunday evening to Ari Mordechai Yasgur, the son of Barbara C. Yasgur and Rabbi Benjamin S. Yasgur of Woodmere, N.Y. The bridegrooms father is to officiate at the Westin Beach Resort and Spa in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Illa Steen and William Gaunt
description: Ida Louise Larkin Steen, the daughter of Ida Clement Steen and John T. Steen Jr. of San Antonio, was married Saturday evening to William Hartley Gaunt, a son of Nancy Hartley Gaunt of Evansville, Ind., and Philip M. Gaunt of Wichita, Kan. The Rev. Dr. Louis H. Zbinden Jr., a Presbyterian minister, officiated on the main house lawn at the King Ranch in Kingsville, Tex.

title: Leah Raful, Seth Goldberg
description: Leah Ariel Raful, a daughter of Dinah Raful and Lawrence Raful of East Islip, N.Y., is to be married Sunday to Seth Shapiro Goldberg, a son of Dr. Robin Goldberg and Neil Goldberg of Syracuse. Rabbi Charles Sherman is to perform the ceremony at Temple Adath Yeshurun in Syracuse.

title: Margaret Weiss and Joseph Maloney
description: Margaret Elizabeth Weiss, a daughter of Dr. Elizabeth L. Auchincloss and Dr. Richard W. Weiss of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married Saturday to Joseph Edward Maloney, a son of Veronica M. Maloney and Edward C. Maloney of West Simsbury, Conn. The Rev. Bill Cochran, a minister affiliated with the House Church Network, led a nondenominational ceremony at the National Museum of Women in the Arts in Washington.

title: Daniel Evans, Matthew Mazer
description: Daniel Mark Evans and Matthew Scott Mazer were married Saturday at the Wequassett Resort in Chatham, Mass. The Rev. Faith Lavender, an interfaith minister, officiated.

title: Michele Hyndman and Matthew Hodge
description: Michele Hyndman and Matthew Abraham Hodge were married Friday by the Rev. Dr. Harvard W. Stephens Jr., a Lutheran minister, at the St. Thomas Yacht Club on the East End of St. Thomas, United States Virgin Islands.

title: Claire James, Ethan Ravetch
description: Claire Elisabeth James and Ethan Michael Ravetch were married Saturday evening in Manhattan. Rabbi Naomi Levy, an aunt of the bridegroom, officiated at the Pierre.

title: Lisa Olmos and Ronald Koo
description: Dr. Lisa Carol Olmos and Ronald Yim Koo were married Saturday evening at the Congressional Country Club in Bethesda, Md. Judge Youlee Yim You, of the Multnomah County Circuit Court in Portland, Ore., and a cousin of the bridegroom, received permission from Montgomery County in Maryland to officiate.

title: Elizabeth Pultorak, Matthew Walker
description: Elizabeth Lauren Pultorak, the daughter of Diane M. Pultorak and Robert J. Pultorak of Chicago, was married Saturday to Matthew Paul Walker, the son of Dr. Elisabeth A. McKeen and Barry N. Walker of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. The Rev. Robin Renteria, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at the Carolina Inn in Chapel Hill, N.C.

title: Keren Sachs, Landis Kauffman
description: Keren Beth Sachs and John Landis Kauffman are to be married Sunday by Rabbi James M. Bennett at the Coronado Hotel in St. Louis.

title: Laura Rowntree, Andrew Gilman
description: Laura Courtney Rowntree and Andrew Chernow Gilman were married Saturday evening at Bubbys, a restaurant in Brooklyn, where the Rev. Edward T. Falsey, a Congregational minister, led a nondenominational ceremony.

title: Rachel Moquete, Michael Day
description: Rachel Anna Moquete and Dr. Michael Sean Day were married Saturday evening at the Horticulture Center in Philadelphia. The Rev. Peter Klein, a Universal Life minister and an uncle of the bride, officiated.

title: Lindsay Taylor, Jordan Farkas
description: Lindsay Ann Taylor, a daughter of Laurie S. Taylor and Dr. Howard Taylor of North Caldwell, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Jordan Lee Farkas, the son of Karen Farkas Wolff of Oceanside, N.Y., and the late Kerwin Farkas. Rabbi Norman R. Patz officiated at the Pleasantdale Chateau, a party venue in West Orange, N.J.

title: Ashley Cornforth, Evan Geronemus
description: Ashley Brooke Cornforth, a daughter of Pam W. Cornforth and Doug J. Cornforth of Landenberg, Pa., was married Saturday evening to Evan Alexander Geronemus, a son of Gail U. Geronemus and Roy G. Geronemus of New York. Rabbi Nancy Epstein officiated at the Rittenhouse Hotel in Philadelphia.

title: Emily Blout and Michael Signer
description: Emily Lorraine Blout and Michael Signer were married Saturday evening at the Clifton Inn in Charlottesville, Va. The ceremony was led by A. E. Dick Howard, a friend of the couple who received permission to officiate from the Commonwealth of Virginia.

title: Alexis Buryk, Scott Borchert
description: Alexis Frances Buryk and Scott Martin Borchert were married Friday at the Church of the Holy Innocents in New York. Msgr. Joseph F. Ambrosio, a maternal uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony. On Saturday, the couple exchanged vows at Blue Smoke, a New York restaurant. Jack P. Moore, a friend of the couple and a Universal Life minister, led that ceremony, which included readings from contemporary authors.

title: Knee Surgery for Lin, a Title for Marbury
description: HONG KONG  Hes Linjured. There, weve said it.

title: Pasty-gate and a Series of Own Goals Hit Cameron
description: LONDON  It has been one of those weeks for David Cameron, the British prime minister.

title: Insurgents Bombs in Thailand: Bigger and Deadlier
description: HONG KONG  A string of orchestrated explosions rocked southern Thailand during the weekend, killing 14 people, wounding 340 and raising fears of larger and deadlier bombs being used by Muslim insurgents.

title: From Prisoner to Parliament in Myanmar
description: YANGON, Myanmar  Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the democracy advocate silenced for two decades by Myanmars generals with house arrests and overturned elections, assumed a new role in her countrys political transition on Sunday, apparently winning a seat in Parliament to make the remarkable shift from dissident to lawmaker.

title: Giants and Jets, the Same Dynamic
description: From the Fifth Down in 2009:

title: Opening Day? Meh.
description: As the editor of The Meh List, Im tasked with making sure that any given submission isnt too cool or too lame but just, well, meh. Its harder than it sounds.

title: U.S. Joins Effort to Equip and Pay Rebels in Syria
description: ISTANBUL  The United States and dozens of other countries moved closer on Sunday to direct intervention in the fighting in Syria, with Arab nations pledging $100 million to pay opposition fighters and the Obama administration agreeing to send communications equipment to help rebels organize and evade Syrias military, according to participants gathered here.

title: Schrdingers Candidate
description: David Javerbaums quantum theory of Mitt Romney has to be one of the funniest things Ive ever read. Check it out.

title: DirecTV and Tribune Fail to Reach Deal
description: Some DirecTV customers woke up on Sunday without Fox or the CW networks on their television sets, the result of a failed negotiation with Tribune Broadcasting, which owns or operates 23 television stations across the United States.

title: From Relais & Chteaux, a Chef-apalooza
description: Relais & Chteaux, a network of more than 500 luxury hotels and restaurants around the world, will host its second annual Grands Chefs Dinner on April 16 at Gotham Hall in New York City.

title: Why Im O.K. with Pink Slime in Ground Beef
description: This is not an April Fools Day joke. I agree withTexas Gov. Rick Perryon something  the nutritional merits of derided pink slime  the processed last scrapings of meat and connective tissue after cattle are butchered.Dude, it is indeed beefa source of low-fat nutrition.

title: Disruptions: Top 10 Lists Lead to Less Choice on the Web
description: The digital age has us living in a perpetual and pervasive popularity contest.

title: Iraqi Leader Visits Qatar in Defiance of Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs fugitive Sunni vice president left the country on Sunday for a diplomatic trip to the Persian Gulf nation of Qatar, his office announced, a development that threatened to stir new tensions just days after officials in Baghdad hosted a lavish meeting to repair ties with other Arab nations.

title: Senator Johnson Backs Romney as Santorum Vows Fight
description: Senator Ron Johnson, a freshman Republican from Wisconsin, endorsed Mitt Romney for president on Sunday, adding to the list of prominent elected officials who are coalescing around the former Massachusetts governor.

title: Myanmar Elections
description: The party of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Burmese dissident, declared that she had won a seat in Myanmars Parliament on Sunday.

title: Another Big Weekend for The Hunger Games
description: The Hunger Games continued to dominate movie theaters over the weekend, leaving the big-budget sequel Wrath of the Titans and Mirror Mirror with Julia Roberts to make do with box-office scraps. Propelled by strong word of mouth, The Hunger Games (Lionsgate) repeated as the No. 1 movie in North America, taking in an estimated $61.1 million for a two-week total of over $251 million, according to Hollywood.com, which complies box-office data.

title: Miguel de la Madrid, President of Mexico in 1980s, Dies at 77
description: Miguel de la Madrid, a former president of Mexico whose derided handling of the earthquake that devastated Mexico City in 1985 was the beginning of the end for the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party, died Sunday morning in Mexico City. He was 77 .

title: On Amnesty Day, Somber Owners Surrender Pythons and a Snapping Turtle
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.  There was Buck, all 12 green, iridescent feet of him, stretched across the sky. His reptilian tongue lapped the raw air, and a light mist clung to his thick body before a team of handlers managed to coil and stuff him into a small plastic bin. Buck was ready for transport, and, whether or not he or his owners liked it, he was starting a new, possibly healthier life.

title: Santana Will Start for Mets on Opening Day
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Mets on Sunday made the announcement they had been itching to make since the middle of February: Johan Santana will be their starter on opening day.

title: As Foreclosure Problems Persist, Fed Seeks More Fines
description: Federal regulators are poised to crack down on eight financial firms that are not part of the recent government settlement over home foreclosure practices involving sloppy, inaccurate or forged documents.

title: Original Review: The Best Man
description: Brooks Atkinsons original 1960 review in The New York Times of Gore Vidals play The Best Man.

title: Response by Big Men in Physical Game Factors Into Kansas Victory
description: NEW ORLEANS  The Final Four game between Ohio State and Kansas was breathtakingly physical; a game of inches as the big men cleared out space inside the key. That physicality was particularly challenging for the games best players: Ohio States Jared Sullinger and Kansas Thomas Robinson.

title: Complacency a Threat to Romney in Wisconsin
description: Throughout the nomination process, Mitt Romneys campaign has applied a sledgehammer approach to the delicate art of managing expectations. If campaign officials think Mr. Romney is going to win a state, they will find a way to broadcast that to the news media  even when it might not seem to their advantage to do so. If they think Mr. Romney will lose, then they wont.

title: Lifting Voices and Ambitions in a Soaring Sacred Space
description: Kent Tritle established his enviable reputation as a choral conductor during the 22 years he led Sacred Music in a Sacred Space, the magnificent series he founded at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in 1989. These days he is about as busy as a conductor can be, having added to his portfolio the directorships of Musica Sacra and the venerable Oratorio Society of New York as well as teaching commitments at the Juilliard School and the Manhattan School of Music, and organist posts at the New York Philharmonic and the American Symphony Orchestra.

title: Out of Sight in Wartime
description: The backwoods North Carolina cove where Laurel Shelton lives was cursed long before the Sheltons got there. The Cherokee knew to stay away. The first white family to settle there died of smallpox. Laurels mother spoke of this setting as a shadow land and claimed there wasnt a gloamier place in the whole Blue Ridge. She died young, as if to prove it.

title: Something Borrowed, Something Kentucky Blue
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Everyone has one: a story of a wedding they attended that conflicted with a major sporting event. The scene of people looking for a bar with a TV at the reception or listening to a game on the radio in the coat check room, or sneaking peeks at a score on a phone.

title: Unleashing Playful Music
description: The composer David Del Tredici walked to his seat in Zankel Hall on Thursday evening accompanied by a tall, neatly dressed man wearing a leather dog collar bristling with sharp studs. It was a reminder that the spirit of San Francisco  provocative, playful, a little weird  had arrived in the cool, corporate New York of 2012.

title: Private Needs, Public Displays
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  Its no secret why people want to be famous. They want to be loved. They want to live forever.

title: A Sure Blend of Noise and Melody Imported From Wales
description: Ritzy Bryan, the lead singer and guitarist of the Joy Formidable, derives a lot of her power from an artful dissonance of style. On one level shes the picture of angularity, lurching fast across the stage, her strumming hand visible only as a blur: a dust devil in a platinum bob. Shes also the keeper of a high, sweet-tart voice, which communicates girlish softness along with its shiver of hauteur. That contrast isnt really unusual in her chosen field, but Ms. Bryan invests so eagerly in it that she makes it work.

title: As Viewing Habits Change, Political Ads Switch Screens
description: MILWAUKEE  Just because you own a D.V.R. or watch television online does not mean political commercials are not coming soon to a screen near you.

title: When Mom Makes Lunch, the Food Is Secondary
description: Nina Levy is putting mothers everywhere to shame with what she makes for her sons lunches: their napkins.

title: Tobin-Brainard 1963
description: Ah. I see that Nick Rowe has made the same mistake I made a few days ago, that of trying to engage the monetary mystics in a rational discussion, and is already regretting it.

title: Billion Price Update
description: For some reason I seem to be seeing a resurgence of inflation scare stories, despite the fact that  gas prices aside  inflation remains quiescent. And along with the scare stories come assertions that the inflation numbers are faked, that the government is hiding the true rate.

title: Rebellious Tinkerers Dress Up the iPhones Uniform
description: For some, fashion means a wardrobe makeover for spring. Then there are those for whom it means an elaborate neck tattoo.

title: Customized iPhones
description: Customers who want customized iPhones can pay companies to take them apart and rebuild them in bright colors and different materials.

title: Ranks of Working Poor Grow in Europe
description: PARIS  When Melissa Dos Santos leaves her job at the end of each day, she goes home to an unlikely place: a tiny trailer in a campground 30 miles north of Paris, where scores of people who can barely make ends meet are living on a sprawling lot originally designed as a bucolic retreat for vacationers.

title: Romney Target of April Fools Joke
description: MILWAUKEE, Wis.  Aides to Mitt Romney love to talk about his underappreciated sense of humor, and his career as a prankster (juvenile and adult) is storied  there was the time as a teenager he put flashing lights on his car and pretended to pull over two friends who were out with dates, and when as governor he used to short-sheet his state troopers beds.

title: Booking Battle at the Morning Shows
description: Set your alarm clocks for 6:59 a.m., America.

title: In Kentucky-Louisville, Coaching Differences Were on Display
description: NEW ORLEANS  With two and a half minutes left and Kentucky leading Louisville by 60-53, the Wildcats faced a crucial possession. Coach John Calipari, sensing the urgency of the situation, stood on the edge of the court and screamed for Anthony Davis to go get the ball. Davis obliged, flashing to the elbow, then dumping a pass to a cutting Doron Lamb. Lamb missed the layup, but Davis had drawn so much attention on the play that Terrance Jones had time for not one, but two putback attempts. Jones stuffed the second through the basket for a momentum-changing dunk.

title: Clarinet Quintets, From Centuries Old to Brand New
description: The clarinet has inspired chamber music composers ever since Mozart wrote his ethereal Clarinet Quintet in A (K. 581), one of several works resulting from his friendship with the clarinetist Anton Stadler.

title: Well Sing and Well Spiel, but No Sex Till War Ends
description: Before Saturday evenings performance of Schuberts one-act opera Die Verschworenen (The Conspirators) at the Manhattan School of Music Dona Vaughn, the artistic director of the schools opera programs, announced that the performers would be dancing in addition to singing, acting and providing their own costumes.

title: The End of an Affair: Movement Marathon
description: Danspace Projects black dance series Platform 2012: Parallels came to a close on Saturday. Near the end of the final program, the choreographer Ishmael Houston-Jones, who had served as curator for this series and its predecessor in 1982, listed what he could remember from the previous two months of Parallels performances. It was a conventional wrap-up, except that he did his reminiscing while lying sealed in a garbage bag.

title: Do Not Feed or Annoy the Dancers
description: Reputations are hard to keep up, especially when youre still referred to as the bad boy of British dance. Its something of a weakness then that the choreographer Michael Clark, included as part of the Whitney Biennial 2012, cannot fully separate from his brash, younger self. Despite his attraction to provocative, sexual costumes and rock music, he built dances based on structure and form. The fashionable edge he worked so hard to cultivate is tempered by classical training at the Royal Ballet School.

title: In Arizona, Censoring Questions About Race
description: In recent weeks, the state of Arizona has intensified its attack in its schools on an entire branch of study  critical race theory. Books and literature that, in the states view, meet that definition have been said to violate a provision in the states law that prohibits lessons promoting racial resentment. Officials are currently bringing to bear all their influence in the public school curriculum, going so far as to enter classrooms to confiscate books and other materials and to oversee what can be taught. After decades of debate over whether we might be able to curtail ever so slightly the proliferation of violent pornography, the censors have managed a quick and thorough coup over educational materials in ethnic studies.

title: Stepping Out of the Shadows With a Sunnier Sound
description: When M. Ward released his previous album, Hold Time, three years ago, he did much of his recording in his Portland, Ore., home with retro equipment and was so shy onstage that he pulled his ball cap over his eyes. People regarded him as an underground folk-rocker who seemed more comfortable as a sideman than fronting a band.

title: Excerpt: 'Gore Vidal's The Best Man'
description: Eric McCormack in a scene from the Broadway revival of the play at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater. (Video courtesy of the production.)

title: Setback Rebounds at Machlin Womens Swiss Teams
description: The winners of the Machlin Womens Swiss Teams in Memphis last month were Barbara Sonsini of Woodside, Calif.; Judi Radin of New York City; Lynn Deas of Schenectady, N.Y.; Beth Palmer of Chevy Chase, Md.; Irina Levitina of Hackensack, N.J.; and Kerri Sanborn of Stony Point, N.Y.

title: Cherry Blossoms and a Fan Telling Tales
description: Virginia Woolf titled one essay On Not Knowing Greek, which she began, For it is vain and foolish to talk of knowing Greek. In the world of the performing arts the same disclaimer should be applied by Westerners to the Japanese traditional forms of Kabuki and Noh. Though these styles have been repeatedly seen in the West for decades, familiarization does not erode their strangeness. Last weeks performance of Kabuki dance at Japan Society, featuring Bando Kotoji with live music, was not more difficult than several other performances of Kabuki I have seen; its finest passages were picturesque, eloquent and remarkable. Yet challenges remain.

title: An Indie-Rock Memoir From Carrie Brownstein
description: Riverhead Books has acquired a book that is sure to thrill indie-rock fans: the memoir of Carrie Brownstein, a singer, songwriter and guitarist in Sleater-Kinney, a beloved all-female band from Olympia, Wash. Ms. Brownstein, who is on tour with a new band, Wild Flag, will write a book about her life in music, Riverhead said Sunday. She is also a creator and star of Portlandia, the IFC show that satirizes hipster culture. Jynne Martin, a spokeswoman for Riverhead, part of Penguin Group (USA), said no title or publication date had been decided.

title: A Shooting, and Instant Polarization
description: What seemed like a single shooting incident in a midsize Florida city  the killing in February of Trayvon Martin  now threatens to divide a country. How did that happen?

title: Footnote
description: The playwright Yussef El Guindi has won the 2012 Harold and Mimi Steinberg/American Theater Critics Association New Play Award for Pilgrims Musa and Sheri in the New World. The announcement came Saturday during the Humana Festival of New American Plays in Louisville, Ky. The honor, which recognizes a playwright for work that had its premiere outside New York City in the previous year, includes a prize of $25,000. Citations and $7,500 prizes were also awarded to Ken LaZebnik for On the Spectrum and A. Rey Pamatmat for Edith Can Shoot Things and Hit Them.

title: Whitney Houston Items Are Sold at Auction
description: Thirteen items related to the career of Whitney Houston drew a total of more than $80,000 on Saturday as part of a Juliens Hollywood Legends auction in Beverly Hills, Calif. The Associated Press reported that a bustier, below, worn onstage by Ms. Houston, who died in February, garnered the highest winning bid, at $18,750, while a velvet gown from a pre-Grammy party in 1996 brought in $11,250. Other items included a vest and pearl-drop earrings from Ms. Houstons wardrobe for the 1992 film The Bodyguard. Most of the items were provided by her friends and family. Another auction, which is to include 30 more dresses worn by Ms. Houston, is planned for June.

title: Encore at the Met Pleases the Audience
description: The tenor sang a number and the audience loved it, so he sang it again. Such encores at the Metropolitan Opera have become such a rarity in recent decades that aficionados  and press offices  take special note. The repeat performance took place on Saturday, when Juan Diego Flrez was appearing in Donizettis Elisir dAmore. At the end of the aria Una furtiva lagrima the audience responded with so much enthusiasm that Mr. Flrez repeated it. The encore was also heard by millions of listeners because the performance, the last show of the run, was broadcast on radio. Within hours the Met sent out a news release pointing out the encore and mentioning that Mr. Flrez was the last Met performer to offer one (in 2008) and that Luciano Pavarotti was the previous singer to do so (in 1994). The Met had banned encores in recent decades amid a more serious performance atmosphere. But the current general manager, Peter Gelb, has loosened the reins in what he has called an effort to make opera more exciting and entertaining. Encores were common in the 19th century and the early 20th.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: A Filmmaker Chases an Israeli Spy Story
description: LOS ANGELES  You dont want an Israeli Air Force pilot on your tail, especially not the kind who has turned documentary filmmaker.

title: Die Verschworenen
description: Scenes from the Manhattan School of Musics production of Schuberts opera.

title: The Joy Formidable
description: Photos from the bands concert at Terminal 5.

title: With Title, Djokovic Steadies His Slam Path
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.  Since his victory at the Australian Open in January, Novak Djokovic has rarely resembled the unbeatable force that dominated mens tennis in 2011.

title: Much-Anticipated Cry
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  PLAY BALL!

title: Exotic Animal Amnesty Day
description: Officials at the Beardsley Zoo in Bridgeport, Conn., show a few of the illegal exotic pets anonymously turned in by their owners.

title: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include the I.S.M. manufacturing index for March and construction spending for February (Monday); factory orders for February (Tuesday); ADP employment for March and I.S.M. nonmanufacturing for March; weekly jobless claims and unemployment for March and consumer credit for February (Friday).

title: Giorgio Chinaglia, Cosmos and Lazio Star, Dies at 65
description: Giorgio Chinaglia, the Italian striker who found a way to overshadow even the soccer greats Pele and Franz Beckenbauer on some of the famed Cosmos teams of the 1970s and 80s, died Sunday at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 65.

title: Kentucky-Kansas: A Look at the Numbers
description: While the nation has been enamored with Kentucky and its eye-popping talent, a statistical analysis for The Quad maintained throughout the past month that Kansas was also one of the teams most likely to win the mens college basketball championship  identifying the Jayhawks as an impressive No. 2 seed before the N.C.A.A. tournament began and primed to advance through their region after North Carolina point guard Kendall Marshall was injured in the first week.

title: Coast Guard Rescues Sailors Whose Yacht Was Overtaken by Wave
description: Updated | 10:12 p.m. For a sailor on the ocean, there is perhaps nothing more bone-chilling than the sight of a skyscraper-size wave gathering to engulf your boat.

title: Anticipation High for Rangers-Bruins, but Tortorella Doesnt Let On
description: Ahead of Sundays Rangers-Bruins game at Madison Square Garden, in which the Rangers can clinch the No. 1 seed in the Eastern Conference and home ice through at least the first three rounds of the playoffs, Coach John Tortorella was in extreme business-only mode. He was eager to end the mandatory pregame news conference, which occurred around 5 p.m. This is the transcript in its entirety:

title: Mets and Niese Are Said to Be Discussing Long-Term Deal
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Mets have been in discussions about a long-term contract extension with the left-handed starter Jon Niese, according to a person with knowledge of the talks.

title: Pension Funds Have Mixed Results With Alternative Investments
description: Pension funds have had mixed results with alternative investments.

title: Pensions Find Riskier Funds Fail to Pay Off
description: Searching for higher returns to bridge looming shortfalls, public workers pension funds across the country are increasingly turning to riskier investments in private equity, real estate and hedge funds.

title: Israel Frees Palestinian Detainee After Hunger Strike of Weeks
description: JERUSALEM  A Palestinian woman who spent more than 40 days on a hunger strike to protest her detention by Israel without charge or trial was released from an Israeli prison on Sunday and sent into temporary exile in Gaza under a deal reached with the Israeli authorities.

title: On Leaving, and Not Leaving, the Church
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayoral Hopefuls Slow Start Has Some Asking if His Heart Is in It
description: William C. Thompson Jr. has heard all the questions. Is he really running for mayor next year? Can he raise enough money to compete in a crowded primary? Does he have the burning desire that it takes to mount an aggressive campaign?

title: Talk Radio Face-Off Approaches
description: The Mike Huckabee Show, the radio show featuring the former Arkansas governor and onetime presidential hopeful that starts next Monday, is not merely another shot at liberal media elites. Conceived by Cumulus Media, the program is a shot at Clear Channel, the radio giant that distributes Rush Limbaughs show at the same time of day.

title: An Eighth-Grade Sports Encyclopedia Finds Himself Without a High School
description: When Omri Shefet started at East Side Middle School two years ago, as a sixth grader, he felt quite small. He had learning problems and needed special education services, including speech and physical therapy, as well as extra support in math and English.

title: Does It Matter if the Orchestra Isnt in the Pit?
description: To the Editor:

title: Considerate Texting
description: To the Editor:

title: Planning for Parking
description: To the Editor:

title: Magazine Guidelines for Tablets
description: Magazine publishers may have embraced the tablet phenomenon by preparing digital editions, apps and multimedia offerings, but learning about the reader on the other side of the screen has proved more difficult. Terms used to describe content are inconsistent, and the type of data that can be collected on users varies by device.

title: To Enroll More Minority Students, Colleges Work Around the Courts
description: With its decision to take up racial preferences in admissions at public colleges, the Supreme Court has touched off a national guessing game about how far it might move against affirmative action and how profoundly colleges might change as a result.

title: Stars of Hollywood and Madison Avenue
description: HERE is a look at some of the highlights, lowlights and sidelights of the annual Transformation conference of the Four As, which took place last week in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Can Privatization Kill?
description: ON Oct. 12, 2010, Jimmy Mubenga was deported from Britain. The 46-year-old Angolan had come to the country as a refugee 16 years earlier. But after his involvement in a pub brawl and a subsequent criminal conviction, the government ordered his deportation. Three private security guards escorted him through Heathrow Airport and onto British Airways Flight 77 to Luanda, Angola. The exact details of what followed are still unclear and currently subject to criminal investigation.

title: At the University of Texas, Admissions as a Mystery
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Even after 20 years of legal wrangling, admission to the University of Texas  and what role race plays  still has its mysteries.

title: As Smartphones Become Health Aids, Ads May Follow
description: With smartphones changing the culture in so many ways, more and more young people are using their mobile devices to keep track of their health, and the trend is not going unnoticed by advertisers.

title: Your Choice for World Bank President?
description: The nominations for the new president of the World Bank are closed. For the next several weeks the board of directors will be considering three candidates: Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, a Nigerian, has a doctorate in regional economics and development from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. She was the managing director of the World Bank from 2007 to 2011 and is currently the finance minister of Nigeria. Many think shes the natural choice for the next president. Her appointment would mean that a woman would lead the World Bank at the same time that a woman heads the International Monetary Fund Jos Antonio Ocampo, a Colombian, has been the United Nations under-secretary general for Economics & Social Affairs and the finance minister of Colombia. He has a doctorate in economics from Yale University and is currently a professor at Columbia Universitys School of International & Public Affairs in New York. He is known for leading Colombia through Latin Americas financial crisis. Jim Yong Kim, a Korean-American, is a medical doctor and also has a Ph.D. in anthropology from Harvard University. He was a founder of Partners in Health, a nonprofit agency that developed a successful, replicable model to provide health care to the poor. He is president of Dartmouth College and is President Barack Obamas choice for president of the World Bank.

title: Painstakingly Reimagining Citys Cabs, Down to the Floor Mats
description: LA JOLLA, Calif.  The goateed French designer and the bespectacled New York City bureaucrat had been at it for about 20 minutes now, politely arguing about the pros and cons of a particular style of plastic sheet.

title: Britain Sees Chechen Plot to Kill Exile
description: LONDON  The British government and intelligence services have accused a henchman of President Ramzan A. Kadyrov of Chechnya of seeking to assassinate a prominent exiled Chechen politician in London, according to court documents revealed here on Sunday.

title: 2 Channels, and Anchor Who Set Liberal Tone
description: Current TV was co-founded by a former Democratic vice president, but it took Keith Olbermann to give the cable channel its liberal identity.

title: Naked, With Children
description: I walk around my house naked. My partner often does, too. Not gratuitously, just often. We dont bother covering up when walking from bathroom to bedroom. We leave the door open when we get dressed. So far, my 8- and 12-year-old sons remain unfazed. If Im standing nude in the door of the bathroom telling my oldest to clean up the basement, the only thing he finds audacious is the request.

title: Pink Slime Economics
description: The big bad event of last week was, of course, the Supreme Court hearing on health reform. In the course of that hearing it became clear that several of the justices, and possibly a majority, are political creatures pure and simple, willing to embrace any argument, no matter how absurd, that serves the interests of Team Republican.

title: A Die-Hard Conservative, but Not on Immigrants
description: SALT LAKE CITY  He is a Republican and a Mormon. He opposes abortion. Mark L. Shurtleff, the attorney general of Utah, also rejects President Obamas health care law as an assault on states rights and he went to Washington last week to urge the Supreme Court to throw it out.

title: Newly in Business, and Finding a Lifeline
description: Erica Molina was standing where she usually stands at lunchtime, in the middle of her 116 square feet  an irregularly shaped booth in the Essex Street Market on the Lower East Side. She was talking about the $5,000 loan that had allowed her to buy the counter she was leaning on and the used refrigerator behind her when a delivery arrived.

title: For Some New York Shoppers, No More State Sales Tax
description: Many shoppers got a pleasant surprise on Sunday as New York State reinstated its sales-tax exemption on clothing and footwear items costing less than $110.

title: Notre Dame Wins a Taut Game and Returns to the Final
description: DENVER  Eight times they have played in the past two seasons, a Big East womens rivalry so familiar that Connecticut and Notre Dame can finish each others plays, the way a husband and wife finish each others sentences.

title: A Report for the Web, on TV
description: When Stone Phillips, formerly of Dateline NBC, learned of a first-of-its-kind study in 2011 at Virginia Tech about the magnitude of head impacts on youth football players, his journalistic instincts kicked in.

title: Apples Chief Puts Stamp on Labor Issues
description: A day after Timothy D. Cook, Apples chief executive, toured a Chinese factory where the companys products are made, an audit commissioned by Apple criticized the long hours and dangerous working conditions at plants run by Foxconn, the operator of the factory Mr. Cook visited last week.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 1, 2012

title: Tyler and Trayvon
description: IN 2009 President Obama signed a federal bias crimes law named for the victims of two gruesome 1998 atrocities: the young gay man who was tortured, lashed to a fence and left to die; and the black man chained to the back of a pickup by white supremacists and dragged until he was dismembered. The Matthew Shepard and James Byrd Jr. Hate Crimes Prevention Act joined a 40-year accumulation of statutes declaring that crimes committed with a mind full of racial spite or anti-Semitism or homophobic hatred should be punished more severely than identical crimes committed for greed or vengeance.

title: Clients Raise Questions About MF Global Checks
description: MF Global customers who closed their accounts in the brokerage firms final days have been fuming for months about how the firm mailed checks to them, instead of promptly transferring the money electronically as usual. Many of those checks arrived after the bankruptcy filing, and subsequently bounced.

title: Judo Legends Dont Retire
description: William C. Rhoden talks with Yoshihiro Uchida, judo coach at San Jose State for 66 years and of the first United States Olympic judo team, who has no plans to retire.

title: For 66 Years, a Force for Judo in the United States
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.

title: In Egyptian Hard-Liners Surge, New Worries for the Muslim Brotherhood
description: CAIRO  Hazem Salah Abu Ismail is an old-school Islamist.

title: Race, Tragedy and Outrage Collide After a Shot in Florida
description: SANFORD, Fla.  Once again, a river of protest raged through Sanford this weekend to demand justice in the name of an unarmed black teenager shot dead. It gathered strength in front of the historic Crooms Academy, the first high school for black students in Seminole County; surged through the streets; and formed a flood of grief and outrage just outside the Sanford Police Department.

title: A Ballerina Who Wasnt and Other Reader Tales
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Loan Gone Sour Clouds the Future of a Media Activists Haven in TriBeCa
description: In the second-floor room with the green walls, Lenny Charles Labanco pointed to where the news desk sat, and the television cameras once stood. Nearly 10 years ago, he started an organization called International News Net World Report, which from that room produced hundreds of 30-minute programs, which were broadcast on satellite television.

title: Their Contributors Bidding
description: Dont they ever learn? Large bipartisan majorities in the House and Senate have now passed the deeply flawed JOBS Act and President Obama is expected to sign it soon. The full name is equally seductive: Jump-start Our Business Start-ups Act. What it is is an invitation to a fresh round of financial malfeasance. It rolls back important investor safeguards from the post-Enron Sarbanes-Oxley law and the post-financial crisis Dodd-Frank law.

title: Myanmar Elections
description: The party of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Burmese dissident, declared that she had won a seat in Myanmars Parliament on Sunday.

title: A Monsignor Goes on Trial
description: A long overdue step of accountability in the sex abuse of children by wayward Catholic priests  the first-ever trial of a diocesan supervisor for allegedly covering up the scandal  has opened in Philadelphia. The issue of hierarchal responsibility is finally front and center.

title: Encyclopaedia Britannicas Last Print Edition Has a Sales Boom
description: When Encyclopaedia Britannica announced last month that it was discontinuing its print editions after 244 years, company executives noted that there were 4,000 sets of the final 32-volume 2010 edition left in a warehouse, the remnants of an old tradition.

title: The Puzzle of More Autism Cases
description: The latest federal survey suggests that more than 1 percent of all children in the country have been identified as having autism or two related disorders by the age of 8, a far higher percentage than found in previous surveys. But no one knows whether the increase shows that the disorders are more common or whether it simply reflects better detection of cases that would previously have been missed. Either way, the survey by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention suggests that more children and parents may need help in coping with these disorders in their schools and communities.

title: Mr. Chairman, the Great State of Nostalgia ...
description: Yards and yards of patriotic bunting stun the senses as you enter the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater, where a revival of Gore Vidals The Best Man opened on Sunday night. Television monitors displaying black-and-white footage hang from boxes that frame the stage, and the usher handing you your program wears a festive boater with red, white and blue trim. The aim is to give the audience a sense of being present at a presidential nominating convention in Philadelphia in 1960, where the play is set.

title: Census Numbers for City Wont Change, Bureau Says
description: The United States Census Bureau, rebuffing a challenge by the Bloomberg administration, will not change its 2010 population total for New York City, a city official said on Sunday night.

title: Examining Marijuana Arrests
description: The New York State Legislature showed good sense when it exempted people convicted of low-level marijuana possession from having to submit DNA to the state database, unless they have been convicted of a previous crime. Still, the state must do more to curb the arrests of tens of thousands of people each year in New York City for minor possession of marijuana, despite a 1977 state law that decriminalized it.

title: For Santorum, Hope That Voters See Message as Pins Go Flying
description: CHILTON, Wis.  Struggling to match Mitt Romney in momentum in the polls and endorsements from Republican luminaries, Rick Santorum has turned, for at least part of his day, from contrasting political records to playing up cultural differences.

title: Master Runner
description: Kathy Martin, 60, is going after a new set of running records for her age bracket. She is breaking them one by one.

title: After Late Start, Runner Is Speeding Through Records
description: The crowd, small but noisy, fixed eyes on Kathy Martin, the woman in last place. Early on, she was fifth in a pack of 11 runners, calmly moving in heavy traffic. She ran not only efficiently but also beautifully, her classic strides in perfect rhythm, a fluid parting of the empty air, almost balletic.

title: Ryan Seacrest Is Said to Be Close to New Deal With Comcast
description: Ryan Seacrest is on the verge of completing a new contract with NBCUniversal, the company that owns the E! channel, where he is a host and a producer; Bravo, where he is a supplier of programming; and NBC, where he will soon appear sometimes on the Today show.

title: Aides With Candidates Ear, if Not Title or Paycheck
description: WASHINGTON  It is the season of the informal adviser.

title: Rethinking How We Teach Economics
The Events Leading to the Shooting of Trayvon Martin
description: What may have happened on the night George Zimmerman shot and killed Trayvon Martin in Sanford, Fla.

title: Nobody Minds Dyeing the Egg, but the Chicken Is Another Story
description: Cute as they are, they are not made of marshmallow.

title: The Politics of Going to College
description: An unexpected issue in the 2012 election is whether or not rank-and-file Americans should aspire to a college degree. Mitt Romney and Rick Santorum have both made comments about higher education that could come back to haunt them in a general election.

title: Washington Is First State to Take On Escort Sites
description: SEATTLE  For more than three months, she was sold online for sex. She had run away at 15, gone back home, then run away again. Finally, an undercover police officer caught her, and her pimp. This time she went home and stayed, but she was not the same.

title: After a Data Breach, Visa Removes a Service Provider
description: Visa removed Global Payments, an Atlanta company that helps the payment giant process transactions for merchants, from its list of compliant service providers.

title: Corrections: April 2
description: NATIONAL

title: Baylors Depth and Defense Subdue Stanford
description: DENVER  Brittney Griner may be the best player in womens college basketball, but Baylor also has what is so far the best and most complete team.

title: Land Rover Time-Lapse
description: Beneath the High Line, Land Rover builds an off-road jungle gym in this time-lapse video.

title: Citizen Journalist in Syria Is Captured and Tortured, Activists Say
description: A citizen journalist in Syria who has been instrumental in assisting those covering the conflict in Homs, helping evacuate wounded journalists from inside the citys neighborhood of Baba Amr, has been seized and perhaps tortured by the Syrian government, an activist told CNN on Saturday.

title: Can Bicycling Affect a Womans Sexual Health?
description: Spending time on a bicycle seat, which has been linked to erectile dysfunction in men, may also be a hazard to a womans sexual health, a new study shows.

title: Word of the Day | prognosis
description: prognosis \prg-no-ss\ noun

title: Paul and Brenda Babits, 51
description: Most pole-vaulters do not stick with the sport after their youthful heyday. The spirit may be willing, but the humility is weak. They dont want to jump at heights three or four feet less than they used to, Paul Babits said. He is different. An athlete who twice qualified for the United States Olympic trials, he not only has kept up with the sport, he has also turned it into a business, coaching vaulters at a custom-built facility in Fort Wayne, Ind. Among his students was his previously nonathletic wife, Brenda, a graphic artist. She couldnt even run around the block, Paul said. Brenda, pole-vaulting now for five years, has a best of 8  feet. The feeling you get flying over the bar, nothing is better than that, she said.

title: Jeanne Daprano, 75
description: Daprano grew up on a farm in Iowa, played a little basketball in high school and later moved to Long Beach, Calif., where she taught third grade for nearly 40 years. She jogged in the sand to keep fit but did not enter a masters track meet until her late 40s. Now she is quite a serious competitor, coupling her running workouts with weight lifting, lunges, squats and time on the rowing machine. I dont do it for longevity, said Daprano, who resides in Atlanta. I do it to be the best at being alive right now. Five years ago, she became the first woman to run a seven-minute mile (6:47.91) after 70. And last month, running in the 75-79 age bracket, she set world records in the 400 meters (1:21.28), the 800 (3:18.48) and the mile (7:13.51). Though pleased with her performances, she insisted: The only record I want is to be in the Book of Life for eternity.

title: Nolan Shaheed, 62
description: As a high school student in Pasadena, Calif., Shaheed ran track and played the trumpet until his parents decided he should focus on music. It was a prudent choice. Shaheed went on to a fine career playing the horn with many of the greats, among them Duke Ellington, Aretha Franklin, Stevie Wonder and Natalie Cole. But he also kept up with the running, working out on his own. It was good for his wind. Air to a trumpet player is like gas to a car, he said. He sometimes bet his bandmates he could beat them in the mile, running the distance himself while six or seven of them used a relay. I took a lot of their money, he boasted. Shaheed has been running masters events for three decades. In 2010, he became the first 60-year-old to break five minutes in the indoor mile (4:57.06). In February, he broke the world indoor record for the 60-64 age group with a 4:35.07 in the 1,500 meters.

title: Phil McConkey, 55
description: McConkey recalls the butterflies he felt competing in sports in the second grade, and he certainly remembers them from the 1986 Super Bowl season when he caught passes and returned kicks for the Giants. He missed that sensation of excitement, and, with his hair now gray, he wanted to feel it once again. When youre younger, you live to compete, and now, at this age, you compete to live, said McConkey, who works in financial services in San Diego. You cant just get off the couch and compete in masters track; youve got to work out. Last month, he ran at the indoor national championships in Bloomington, Ind. I couldnt sleep, too nervous, he said. He went home with two third-place finishes in the 55-59 age group, running the 60 meters in 7.79 seconds and the 200 in 25.98.

title: Philippa Raschker, 65
description: Raschker had her bone density tested seven years ago, and they told me I was still like a 20-year-old, she said. Surely, her powers of recuperation are extraordinary. Though Phil, as she is widely known, has had three knee operations and recently sustained an ankle injury, she broke the world indoor record in the pentathlon in her new age group, 65-69, last month. The sprints and the hurdles are her best events. She has won more than 70 gold medals in masters world championships and is the best-known competitor in masters track. Raschker has twice been a finalist for the Sullivan Award, which honors Americas top amateur athlete, losing out in 2003 to Michael Phelps and in 2007 to Tim Tebow. These days, she trains only two or three times a week, as she is busy working as an accountant in Marietta, Ga., and traveling to Germany to care for her ailing mother.

title: Bob Lida, 75
description: Lida was the Big Eight champion in the indoor 440-yard dash in 1959. Then a problem with his sciatic nerve forced him to quit track; he thought he was washed up at 22 and turned his attention to a career in advertising. At 40, he decided to start sprinting again. This time, it was a pulled hamstring that spoiled things, so he restricted himself to slower road races. But there is something special about the full-throttle locomotion of the sprints. And at 60, he returned to the dashes, and though his knees lock up every now and again, he is back to being the champion he was at Kansas. In January, he set two indoor world records in the 75-79 age bracket, running the 60 meters in 8.49 seconds and the 200 in 27.03. He credits recent advice from an observant track coach. It turns out all these years Ive been overstriding, Lida said.

title: North Korea Party Calls for Leadership Meeting
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Koreas ruling Workers Party will convene a representatives conference on April 11, the countrys state-ran news agency, K.C.N.A., reported on Monday. Analysts said the rare meeting was expected to anoint the new North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, as the official head of the party.

title: Too Many Small Fish Are Caught, Report Says
description: An international group of marine scientists is calling for cuts in commercial fishing for sardines, herring and other so-called forage fish whose use as food for fish farms is soaring. The catch should be cut in half for some fisheries, the scientists say, to protect populations of both the fish and the natural predators that depend on them.

title: Paul S. Boyer, 76, Dies; Historian Studied A-Bomb and Witches
description: Paul S. Boyer, an intellectual historian who wrote groundbreaking studies of the Salem witch trials, the history of apocalyptic movements and the response of the American public to the nuclear annihilation of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, Japan, died on March 17 in Madison, Wis. He was 76.

title: Now, Will She Kick the Hornets Nest?
description: HONG KONG  The joy in the streets and at polling stations was unmistakable as Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and her political party swept to victory on Sunday in Myanmar. Mother Suu, she carried the day.

title: Bruins Prevent Rangers From Clinching Conference and Top Seeding
description: Rangers fans went to Madison Square Garden on Sunday night ready for a party. Their team needed only a point against the Boston Bruins to clinch the Eastern Conference title and the first seed in the playoffs after Pittsburgh lost earlier Sunday.

title: A Land Rover Obstacle Course
description: As part of its silver-anniversary festivities, Land Rover built an obstacle course, an off-road "urban-jungle adventure," in west Chelsea through Tuesday.

title: Little Cheering Accompanies Bruins Division Title
description: Tim Thomas wore a baseball cap with a Bruins logo stitched underneath the words 2012 Division Champs. Otherwise, you would never know Boston had just clinched the Northeast Division with a 2-1 win over the Rangers on Sunday night.

title: Murray, in Loss to Djokovic, Is His Own Worst Enemy
description: Andy Murray lost the final of the Sony Ericsson Open in Key Biscayne, Fla., on Sunday to the one opponent that gives him the most trouble in a match  himself.

title: Charles Lockwood, Who Wrote the Row-House Bible, Dies at 63
description: Charles Lockwood, whose 1972 book, Bricks and Brownstone: The New York Row House, 1783-1929, both chronicled and furthered the row-house revival that transformed many New York neighborhoods, died on Wednesday at his home in Topanga, Calif. He was 63.

title: Knicks Have Returned to Point of Disarray
description: The room filled, the cameras rolled and the shutters clicked, rapid-fire  one last multimedia salute to Jeremy Lin, one noisy farewell to Linsanity. It was not supposed to end this way.

title: Mad Men Recap: Gloom for Betty and Roger
description: Season 5, Episode 2

title: Meanwhile, Starring in China ....
description: With point guard Jeremy Lin out for the remainder of the regular season (and maybe the playoffs) with a torn meniscus in his left knee, the Knicks once again find themselves thin at point guard. Baron Davis has been slowed by a strained hamstring, and Mike Bibby and Toney Douglas are not inspiring much confidence. Halfway around the globe, a former Knicks point guard, Stephon Marbury, is faring far better.

title: Newswallah: A Brief History of Corruption in the Ministry of Defense
description: Corruption in Indias Ministry of Defense runs deep and wide, judging by the accusations made by defense officials in the past few months. Maybe that shouldnt be a surprise. In the frequent cases of corruption that have surfaced in the ministry over the years, incidents of graft have implicated everyone from from petty officers to the highest ranks in the department.

title: The One Who Stayed Holds Kentucky Together
description: NEW ORLEANS  Darius Miller had a senior moment on Sunday.

title: Marlins Bet on Future in a Florida Theme Park
description: MIAMI

title: No Easy Path to the Rim for Either Tourney Finalist
description: NEW ORLEANS  Kansas, one of college basketballs most storied programs, has improbably been cast as an underdog for the N.C.A.A. mens tournament championship game Monday night. Its opponent, Kentucky, has had a season so dominant that its march to an eighth national title has been perceived as inevitable.

title: Rodriguez Is Feeling at Home in Miami
description: MIAMI  Much has changed in Alex Rodriguezs life, and in Miami, since he was a boy growing up here. So returning to play in a meaningless spring training tuneup actually did have some meaning for him.

title: L.P.G.A.s First Major Ends in Playoff After Stunning Miss on Final Hole
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.  That was not another 40-mile-per-hour gust that sent shivers up and down the 18th hole at Mission Hills Country Club on Sunday. It was the crowds collective gasp when I. K. Kim, the leader by one stroke at the Kraft Nabisco Championship, missed a one-foot par putt on the par-5 finishing hole to fall out of the lead and into a playoff with her South Korean compatriot Sun Young Yoo.

title: Vonn Unruffled by Prospect of Knee Surgery
description: VAIL, Colo.  Lindsey Vonn, the newly crowned overall World Cup champion, could have arthroscopic surgery to repair meniscus cartilage damage in her left knee this week, although she said she did not think the injury would significantly alter her off-season training or affect next winters race season.

title: Indias Industry Helps Open a Door to the World
description: On the day the Indian trade delegation came across the border, Pakistan was having another political crisis, Jim Yardley writes in The New York Times from Lahore, Pakistan.

title: In Tug of War Over San Jose, As and the Giants Remain at a Standoff
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  To some outsiders, the Bay Area can look like one big patchouli party united by high technology, good food and liberal politics. But when it comes to baseball, relations between the Oakland Athletics and the San Francisco Giants have become positively nasty.

title: Photo Replay: April 1
description: The day in sports, including a rodeo in Atlantic City, N.C.A.A. womens basketball in Denver and the Kraft Nabisco Championship in Rancho Mirage, Calif.

title: News Quiz | April 2, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page. Good luck!

title: April 2, 1917 | Woodrow Wilson Asks For Declaration of War Against Germany
description: On April 2, 1917, President Woodrow Wilson asked Congress to declare war against Germany, saying, The world must be made safe for democracy. Four days later, Congress voted overwhelmingly in favor of a war declaration.

title: Test Yourself | Math, April 2, 2012
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article No Dribbling and No Passing, but Free Throws Are Nonstop.

title: Britons Protest Proposal to Widen Surveillance
description: LONDON  British lawmakers and rights activists joined a chorus of protest Monday against plans by the government to give the intelligence and security services the ability to monitor the phone calls, e-mails, text messages and Internet use of every person in the country.

title: Beats, Rhymes and Hard Work
description: When Jared Soares decided to document the hip-hop scene in Roanoke, Va., he had a bumpy start. After failing to connect with several local musicians, he was finally invited to the studio of Terrence Palmer, a graphic artist who designed the covers for many of the do-it-yourself CDs sold at corner stores.

title: Saris and Chuppahs for the Bnei Israel Jews of India
description: Two days before Yamit Talker-Shefers wedding to her husband Elad, in traditional Indian custom her family donned colorful saris and gathered together for the henna ceremony, in which her ring finger was painted red in preparation for the wedding ring to come. Forty-eight hours later, in traditional Jewish custom, she and Elad stood under the chuppah  the Jewish wedding canopy  and recited ancient Hebrew vows before an Israeli rabbi.

title: Vogue of the Veiled Has a Following, and Critics
description: HOW is Ala like other fashion magazines?HOW is it different?HOW many subscriptions has Ala sold?

title: Russian Crash After Takeoff Kills 31
description: MOSCOW  At least 31 people died in a plane crash in Siberia early Monday, Russian officials said, the latest in a string of deadly crashes that have eroded confidence in Russias commitment to air safety.

title: Counselors Calendar | April Checklist for Seniors
description: In March, The Choice introduced an occasional series called Counselors Calendar, which is intended to keep students on track as they go through the admissions process.

title: The Early Word: Free Advice
description: In Todays Times:

title: N.F.C. West Team Needs
description: Thanks to the gluttony of N.F.L. draft hype, many fans have an idea of each teams major needs. This series will take a look at a more hidden weakness for each team. Well make a quick mention of the obvious need just to fend off the how could you ignore such-and-such!? comments. We begin with the N.F.C. West.

title: Fantasy Focus: Late-Breaking Rises and Falls
description: This is the time of the year, right before the start of the regular season, when the fantasy-related news starts coming in droves. Players are placed on the disabled list, others unexpectedly stick on the 25-man roster, and playing-time decisions are made. Lets look at a handful of players whose values have risen or fallen in recent days.

title: Beneath the High Line, Land Rover Builds an Off-Road Jungle Gym
description: Above, a time-lapse video of the courses construction, shot between the night of March 29 and morning of March 31.

title: What Would You Do If You Won the Lottery?
description: Last week, many Americans found themselves in a lottery ticket-buying frenzy. In this record-breaking Mega Millions lottery, ticket sales reached $1.5 billion. Were you, your family or your friends hoping to win?

title: Q&A: Recycling E-Waste by the Book
description: Q.

title: Syria Agrees to Troop Withdrawal, Annan Says
description: UNITED NATIONS  The Syrian government has agreed to withdraw its security forces from in and around major population centers by April 10, ostensibly paving the way for a general cease-fire two days later, the special envoy told the Security Council on Monday.

title: DBS Group to Buy Bank Danamon for $7.2 Billion
description: DBS Group Holdings of Singapore agreed on Monday to buy Bank Danamon of Indonesia for $7.2 billion in one of the largest takeovers in Southeast Asias financial services industry.

title: This Week in Small Business: Meet Your Start-Up Mate
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

title: Head of British Bankers Association to Step Down

title: Judge Clarifies That Bloggers Can Be Journalists (Just Not One in Particular)
description: Back in December, United States District Court Judge Marco A. Hernandez created a stir by seeming to suggest that bloggers are not journalists as defined by Oregons shield law. The ruling came in a case involving a self-described investigative blogger, Crystal L. Cox. She had been sued by Kevin Padrick of the Obsidian Finance Group for defamation because she had written that he and his company had engaged in a wholesale fraud in a bankruptcy case.

title: Easy Does It
description: There may be no better barometer of a designers commercial success than retailers and consumers clamoring for those interim collections known as resort and prefall. So after four seasons of challenging pieces like patterned pajama sets and over-the-top quilted coats, the Northern Irish designer J. W. Anderson (left) has come down to earth  at least a little  for his first prefall collection. Alongside straight-leg pants, pleated skirts and jewel-tone turtlenecks (including one in blue with bright green sleeves), Anderson still offers plenty of quilting: a white A-line skirt, a red-and-white checkerboard print jacket and two puffy bombers, one in black patent leather and another in brown with white sleeves and a shearling collar. I like the idea of storytelling, and for me this collection was the prequel to my fall collection, the designer says. Both collections are for the same woman and for me all the pieces work together, but I definitely aimed to design clothes that were easier and more relatable. That doesnt mean Anderson has lost touch with the avant-garde. For fall expect vinyl suiting, pillow-top apron skirts and a curious take on the deerstalker cap.

title: A March for Those Whose Lives Were Taken, and Others Yet to Be Taken
description: It was Palm Sunday, a celebration of what the Gospels say was Jesuss triumphal entry into Jerusalem. On this Palm Sunday, though, there was no feeling of triumph in a march that wound through three city-run housing complexes in Fort Greene, Brooklyn. If anything, the path followed by this procession could have qualified as a latter-day Via Dolorosa, the sorrowful road that Jesus walked on his way to the cross.

title: Taylor Swift Retains Crown as Entertainer of the Year
description: Taylor Swift, Miranda Lambert and Jason Aldean were the big winners at the 47th annual Academy of Country Music Awards in Las Vegas on Sunday night in a show that provided few surprises. Ms. Swift, who at 22 has become one of the highest-earning singers in any genre, was named entertainer of the year for the second year in a row, beating out Mr. Aldean, Kenny Chesney and Brad Paisley. The award was not unexpected. Her last album, Speak Now, was the second-best-selling LP of 2011, and Billboard recently named her its top moneymaker last year with an estimated $35 million earned. She also won two Grammys earlier this year.

title: Opels Future Weighs Heavily on German Town
description: BOCHUM, GERMANY  Udo Mde steered his Opel compact car slowly over the cracked pavement of the half-empty parking lot at the companys plant in Bochum, Germany, on a recent workday.

title: Think Very Different: Ashton Kutcher to Play Steve Jobs
description: In his best-known roles, Ashton Kutcher has played a young man who came of age in the 1970s and a self-made technology gazillionaire, so why shouldnt his latest gig combine them both? Mr. Kutcher, the sitcom star of That 70s Show and Two and a Half Men, is set to portray Steve Jobs in an independent film about that Apple co-founder, Variety reported. The film, called Jobs, is to be directed by Joshua Michael Stern (Swing Vote) and written by Matt Whiteley, and is expected to chronicle Jobss life from his relatively wayward youth to his involvement in the creation of Apple. Variety said the film is expected to start production in May while Mr. Kutcher is on a hiatus from Two and a Half Men, on which he plays Walden Schmidt, a wealthy Internet entrepreneur.

title: Winfrey on OWN: Had I Known It Was This Difficult, I Might Have Done Something Else
description: Oprah Winfrey said Monday that had she known how difficult it would be to start OWN, her one-year-old cable channel, she might not have tried to start it at all.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: What Olbermann Wrought, and Recalling Apples 1984
description: Keith Olbermann may have left the anchor desk again, but he once again leaves behind a channel thats ready to embrace his edgier progressive persona, even if it doesnt care for Mr. Olbermann himself, writes Brian Stelter. Now, liberal journalists and pundits who were inspired by Mr. Olbermanns invectives against the Iraq war and the Bush administration five years ago have multiple channels to appear on and potentially be paid by  a marketplace, in effect, for liberal talent on television.

title: Seeking Happiness on a Finite and Human-Shaped Planet
description: 12:16 p.m. | Live Updates below |Im at the United Nations today for the Bhutan-led High Level Meeting on Wellbeing and Happiness: Defining a New Economic Paradigm. The details are nicely summarized in a recent Op-Ed article by Timothy W. Ryback, the deputy secretary general of the Acadmie Diplomatique Internationale in Paris. As Ryback explains, the meeting was approved in a U.N. resolution last year recognizing that the pursuit of happiness is a fundamental human goal and the gross domestic product [G.D.P.] does not adequately reflect the happiness and well-being of people.

title: Sephardic Dishes for the Passover Table
description: When I am planning a Passover menu I look to the Sephardic traditions of the Mediterranean. The Sephardim were the Jews of the Iberian Peninsula; they had a rich culture and lived in harmony with Christians and Muslims until the Spanish and Portuguese Inquisitions at the end of the 15th century, when all non-Christians were expelled from Spain and Portugal. The Sephardim were welcomed in Turkey, and many went to Greece, North Africa and the Middle East as well. Ive chosen an assortment of vegetarian dishes from all of these places for this weeks Recipes for Health. Throughout the Mediterranean, springtime is the season for spinach and other greens, artichokes and fava beans, and these vegetables make delicious appearances at Passover meals. Theres much in the way of healthy produce to choose from, and olive oil is the only fat youll find.

title: A Burden Too Heavy to Bear
description: In late December 1861 Northern newspapers buzzed with rumors about a high-ranking Confederate officer who had committed suicide. Within days the victim was identified as Philip St. George Cocke, one of Virginias wealthiest and largest planters. Cocke, a West Point graduate, had been appointed commander of Virginias state forces by Governor John Letcher in the earliest days of hostilities. He lost his coveted rank of brigadier general, however, when Southern state militias were folded into the Confederate Army.

title: Oh My, Steve Keen Edition
description: Update update: Ah, so Keen didnt mean DSGE  a term that refers only to New Keynesian models  when he said DSGE; he meant New Classical, which he somehow regards as the underlying principles for models that arent New Classical at all. OK. Anyway, enough of that. Im all for listening to heretics when they offer insights I can use, but Im not finding that at all in this conversation, just word games and continual insistence that the members of the sect have insights denied to us lesser mortals. Time to move on.

title: Growth Industry | Williams-Sonoma Goes Agrarian
description: Williams-Sonoma, the company that has lured every amateur Thomas Keller and Alice Waters into the kitchen with the promise of gleaming, chef-grade pots and pans and all manner of specialized countertop appliances, not only wants you to prepare your own food but also to grow it. On Thursday, it will introduce Agrarian, a collection offering just about everything one might possibly need to make the leap from seed to table, including cedar garden beds and window boxes, organic soil and fertilizer, heirloom seeds, copper gardening tools, even a chic dark denim gardening apron. For the more adventurous (or for anyone who doesnt live in Manhattan) there is even a backyard beehive (beehive starter kit sold separately) and portable chicken coops (above). Or, for those who dont want to get their hands dirty, there are kits for making cheese and kombucha and all the accouterments for putting up the fruits and vegetables you picked at your local farmers market. Shipping costs aside, in keeping with the locavore spirit, the emphasis is on small producers like Brooklyn Slate, which provides Agrarians slate garden markers, and Fire Escape Farms, a company in Northern California whose leafy greens and rainbow beets seed packets are also part of the Agrarian mix. Its about building community through food, says Daron Joffe (affectionately known as Farmer D), an organic farmer and advocate who produces the raised beds from sustainably harvested cedar in Atlanta. There is a lot of opportunity for growth.
