title: Santorum Says Contested Convention Could Benefit G.O.P.
description: APPLETON, Wis.  Refusing to concede the inevitability of Mitt Romneys candidacy, Rick Santorum said a contested Republican convention in August would be energizing for the party.

title: Trayvon Martin and the Smoking Gun
description: It should be clear to everyone by now that our ability to know exactly what led to the death of Trayvon Martin expired when he did. But thats no excuse for not even making the effort, for taking the killer at his word and calling it a day.

title: Asked & Answered | Tilt
description: The stately htel particulier Au Vieux Panier sits on one of the many labyrinthine cobblestone streets in the hillside district of Le Panier, Marseilles oldest neighborhood and home to a thriving art scene. Formerly a Corsican grocer, this 17th-century building was converted into a boutique hotel in 2010 by the Franco-British entrepreneur Jessica Venediger with a unique focus. Sleep in a work of art is the experience promised there, and because the hotel doubles as an installation art gallery, it delivers exactly that.

title: Vocal Responses on the Issue of Grunting
description: Saturdays story about the Womens Tennis Association cracking down on what it calls excessive grunting elicited a handful of pointed responses from readers.

title: In Turbocharged Porsches, Artist Richard Phillips Finds a New Muse
description: On a balmy March afternoon in Manhattan, the artist Richard Phillips was breaking in the refurbished engine on his 1992 Porsche 965. Mr. Phillips, who is 6-foot-5, just missed scraping his head on the roofline of the white sports car.

title: Projecting Anthony Daviss Career in the N.B.A.
description: NEW ORLEANS  Over the past 20 years there have been 10 clear franchise players taken with the first pick in the N.B.A. draft. The list includes LeBron James and Allen Iverson, Blake Griffin and Dwight Howard  players who immediately became the cornerstones of their franchise, were good pros from Day 1 and gave their team a legitimate chance to win a championship.

title: Good Weekend for CBS
description: A combination of college basketball and country music translated into strong ratings for CBS over the weekend. The networks coverage of the N.C.A.A. mens Final Four on Saturday earned its highest preliminary rating since 2005, according to Nielsen estimates, and averaged 14.9 million total viewers.

title: The Billionaire Family Backing the Avon Bid
description: Behind Cotys $10 billion unsolicited offer for Avon Products is one of Europes wealthiest and most private families: the Reimanns.

title: Channel Surfing: Adventure Time
description: The return of The Killing on Sunday night may have drawn the attention of adult viewers, but their children are likely to be waiting for the resolution of a different cliffhanger: Will 14-year-old Finn the Human hook up with the Flame Princess? The answer comes at 7:30 p.m. on Monday night, when Cartoon Networks popular animated series Adventure Time begins its fourth season. (The Season 3 finale will be shown at 7.)

title: Santorum Bowls a Spare
description: Rick Santorum picked up a spare at a campaign event at Sabre Lanes in Appleton, Wis.

title: Hazards: Mild Sleep Disorders Tied to Depression
description: Snorting and stopping breathing during sleep are associated with depression, even in people whose symptoms do not meet the criteria for a diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnea, a new study has found.

title: In a Fight Between the Flyers and Penguins, Even the Coaches Get Involved
description: This wasnt an April Fools prank or an attempt by Philadelphia Flyers Coach Peter Laviolette to add some dark comedy to the waning moments of Sundays third period. The Flyers were playing the Penguins in Pittsburgh, with the game being NBCs N.H.L. broadcast of the week, when a fight-fueled frenzy broke out.

title: Really? A Longer Allergy Season as Climate Warms
description: THE FACTS

title: Video of Aung San Suu Kyis Remarks After Elections in Myanmar
description: As my colleague Thomas Fuller reports, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the democracy advocate and Nobel Peace laureate who was kept under house arrest for 15 years by Myanmars generals, spoke to supporters on Monday, after a resounding triumph in dozens of parliamentary by-elections.

title: Patterns: Alcohol May Help Heart Attack Survivors
description: Its well established that moderate alcohol consumption may ward off heart disease. But even after a heart attack, an alcoholic drink a day may be good for a mans health, a new study has found.

title: Mets Closer to Have M.R.I. Test on Knee
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Closer Frank Francisco said he planned to have a magnetic resonance imaging test on his left knee Monday night.

title: U.S. Appeals Court Upholds Affirmative Action Ban in California
description: A federal appeals court panel has upheld Californias ban on using affirmative action during the admissions process of public colleges and universities, The Associated Press reports.

title: The View from Kansas: A Team Built on Trust
description: The Quad asked writers at newspapers at the University of Kansas and the University of Kentucky for reports on what to expect on Monday night.

title: Selling America Abroad
description: Time was when just the mention of the Grand Canyon, the Pacific Coast Highway or the New York skyline was enough to entice tourists from around the world. But that was before 9/11 and the rise of security barriers on entering the United States. And it was before Asias economic renaissance drew travelers there.

title: For a Bronx Student, Home Is Poetry
At a Bronx Middle School, Reflections on Trayvon and Lost Dreams
Reading Material at the Strand Does Not Include a Contract
description: The Strand Bookstore has long stood as a beacon in the city for book lovers, tourists and those on lunch break who just want to lose themselves in a foreign world before returning to another corporate meeting.

title: Fashion News Were Reading
description: Guess and Gucci pick up where Christian Louboutin and Yves Saint Laurent left off in the latest designer trademark infringement case.

title: From Strife-Marked Vineyards
description: IN his 72 years, Serge Hochar has produced 53 vintages of Chteau Musar, a wine that has enthralled several generations only partly because of its unusual provenance, the Bekaa Valley in Lebanon.

title: The Joys of Old Potatoes
description: Clotilde Hryshko runs a farm and CSA in a beautiful valley in Brookfield, Vt. She has written some lovely pieces that have appeared on www.markbittman.com.

title: Nokias Lumia Ads Say Your Phone Is No Good
description: Nokias strategy to sell its new Lumia smartphone is to make you feel dumb about what you already have. New video ads from Nokia, the Finnish phone maker, suggest that iPhones and Android phones are flawed, unfinished beta devices, which makes you a sucker for having one.

title: No Misbehaving for This Heiress
description: UNDER the storied stone atrium of the Hearst Building in Midtown, a small pale figure emerged from the elevator the other day. Thin and casually chic with blond hair and young-Mariel Hemingway eyebrows, she could have been any glossy fashion editor in the building preoccupied with getting a byline, boyfriend, bikini wax or blowout.

title: First the Mandate, Then All Tax Incentives
description: Last week the Supreme Court heard a case about whether the Affordable Care Acts health insurance mandate is constitutional. But striking down the mandate could suggest that all sorts of tax incentives are similarly unconstitutional, an economist says.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Twitter Women and Tablet Ratings
description: Here are some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Monday. There are more here.

title: Regulator Accuses R.B.C. of Massive Trading Scheme
description: Regulators on Monday accused the Royal Bank of Canada of orchestrating an elaborate trading scheme and booking bogus trades to generate lucrative tax benefits.

title: Gunman Opens Fire at University in Oakland
description: The Times will post updates as they become available.

title: Talking Baseball With Times Reporters
description: Tyler Kepner, David Waldstein and Andrew Keh discuss the upcoming season with Times readers.

title: Talking Baseball With Times Reporters
description: The Timess sports department started experimenting with Google-plus video hangouts last month, and with opening day coming this week, we thought it was time to get our baseball reporters in front of webcams. So, Tyler Kepner, David Waldstein and Andrew Keh joined a handful Times readers to discuss the 2012 season, with topics ranging from Albert Pujols and Prince Fielder to the new playoff format to whether Mets fans have any hope of enjoying the summer, even if that means rooting for Bobby Valentine against the Yankees.

title: Wearing Waist-Length Hair, and a Sense of Humor
description: IM a bass player in a jam band, and we do a lot of concert tours. So I fly a lot. Flying is so far removed from anything that I would really want to do that I just endure it. But once Im up in the air, I suppose I do like it a little bit better, since Im going someplace to do something that I enjoy.

title: A Brief Therapy Heals Trauma in Children
description: Every year millions of children from all walks of life become victims of, or witnesses to, abusive or violent events that can result in long-lasting symptoms of distress. The events can range from sexual and physical abuse to involvement in a natural disaster, fire or serious motor vehicle accident.

title: Traveling the World,  Bottles Full of Miracles
description: Serge Hochar, the guiding spirit of Chteau Musar, is 72 years old. It only seems as if hes been spreading the gospel of Musar for that long. In fact, Musar, made in Beirut from grapes grown in the Bekaa Valley of Lebanon, is a singular wine that is almost as remarkable as Mr. Hochar himself.

title: Numberplay delayed this week
description: Numberplay is delayed, and will appear later this week. Please check the permanent Numberplay link for the post later in the week. Thank you for your patience.

title: Gunman Kills 7 in a Rampage at a Northern California University
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  A former student opened fire on students and staff at a religious college here on Monday morning, killing seven people and wounding at least three more, the authorities said.

title: Does RIMs Enterprise Plan Herald More Shrinking?
description: During his first quarterly financial results conference call as chief executive last week, Thorsten Heins of Research In Motion said that he was taking the company back to its roots. RIM, he said, would again focus its attention on customers who use BlackBerrys for work.

title: Goldman Announces Changes to Its Board
description: Goldman Sachs announced changes to its board late Monday, appointing a lead director and losing one of its three female board members.

title: A Push for Relocation After Mold Found at Brooklyn School
Evidence Against Moon as Meteoroids Offspring
description: Astronomers have long theorized that the Moon was formed when an object the size of Mars slammed into Earth, sending a huge mass of rock into orbit around it. According to the prevailing model prediction, approximately half of the Moon-forming material should come from the Mars-size impactor, said Junjun Zhang, an isotope geochemist at the University of Chicago and the studys first author.

title: Augustas Flowers Are Wilting, but Bloom Is Still On for Simpson
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Images of bright, verdant blooms and shimmering pastels have forever been associated with Augusta National and the Masters, but this years tournament may have a little less color than usual.

title: Amy Brenneman to Star in New Gina Gionfriddo Play
description: The actress Amy Brenneman will star in the premiere production of Gina Gionfriddos new play Rapture, Blister, Burn at Playwrights Horizons this spring, the theater announced on Monday. Ms. Brenneman, a five-time Emmy Award nominee known for her television roles in Private Practice, Judging Amy and NYPD Blue, will be joined in the cast by Kellie Overbey, Lee Tergesen, Beth Dixon and Virginia Kull.

description: In a previous post on The Quad, Jack Styczynski analyzed the championship matchup between Kentucky and Kansas using statistics that show a strong correlation with success.

title: JetBlue Fracas Highlights Need for Alert Passengers
description: ABOUT 1.7 million people board about 28,000 commercial flights each day in the United States. Occasionally, something unexpected is bound to happen.

title: Willets Point Development Makes Gain With Highway Administrations Approval
description: The Federal Highway Administration has removed a major obstacle to the Bloomberg administrations plan to turn a waterlogged enclave of crumbling shops and sheds near Citi Field into a major development site.

title: How Immersion Helps to Learn a Language
description: Learning a foreign language is never easy, but contrary to common wisdom, it is possible for adults to process a language the same way a native speaker does. And over time, the processing improves even when the skill goes unused, researchers are reporting.

description: Rarely does reality intersect with role playing the way it did two Sundays ago in Bob Woodwards living room.

title: City Withdraws Plans to Close Seven Schools
The Risks and Rewards of a More Intimate Space
description: The life of a singer perpetually involves vast, sudden shifts of scale. The ability to negotiate them  as well as to choose halls and repertory carefully and match them wisely  is as much a quality of a successful career as singing in key. Two budding stars of the Metropolitan Opera (3,800 seats) were put to this test when they sang on Sunday afternoon in Gilder Lehrman Hall at the Morgan Library & Museum (250 seats).

title: At Some Recitals, Its All About the Encore
description: After his recital at the Frick Collection on Sunday afternoon the young Iranian-American harpsichordist Mahan Esfahani said it was an honor to perform on the same stage where, in 1954, the acclaimed harpsichordist Wanda Landowska gave her final public recital.

title: Singing Pageant of Pop, With a Circus Atmosphere
description: NEWARK  The spirit of Michael Jackson may not hover over Michael Jackson The Immortal World Tour, a spectacular that played the Prudential Center here last weekend and heads to Madison Square Garden on Tuesday, but the Jackson estate sure does. It collaborated with Cirque du Soleil, which conceived the Beatles Love show in Las Vegas, to create this galumphing sensory assault, presumably a substitute for the Jackson This Is It run of shows that never was.

title: Excerpt: '4000 Miles'
description: Gabriel Ebert and Mary Louise Wilson in a scene from Amy Herzogs play at Lincoln Center Theater.

description: Photographs from Israel, Bahrain, Syria and Pakistan.

title: Giving Women the Access Code
description: CLAREMONT, Calif.  When Maria Klawe became president of Harvey Mudd College in 2006, she was dismayed  but not surprised  at how few women were majoring in computer science.

title: Solar Energy Inspiration From Butterflies
description: Butterfly wings are not just beautiful. They are also sophisticated collectors of solar energy that help butterflies stay warm, and researchers say that their shinglelike structure could provide valuable clues into developing better solar technology.

title: Pipeline to Programming Jobs Has Leaks
description: When educators speak of women in computer science, they often refer to the pipeline, which tends to start in high school and wind its way through graduate studies. Along the way, the pipeline becomes increasingly porous, losing women at a discouraging rate.

title: Footnote
description: Neil Patrick Harris will return as host of the Tony Awards telecast on June 10, the Broadway League and the American Theater Wing announced. Mr. Harris hosted the awards ceremony last year and in 2009. It will again be at the Beacon Theater in Manhattan and will be broadcast by CBS.

description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  A year ago, Jason Day and Adam Scott each came close to becoming the first Australian winner of the Masters, a drought they say inevitably gains attention in their home country this time of year.

title: Push for the Right to Die Grows in the Netherlands
description: AMSTERDAM  It was 1989, and Dr. Petra de Jong, a Dutch pulmonologist, was asked for help by a terminally ill patient, a man in great pain with a large cancerous tumor in his trachea. He wanted to end his life.

title: Path Improves Security in Mobile App
description: Path, the mobile social network, announced on Monday that it had added a privacy feature to its mobile application. The update comes two months after it was discovered that some app makers, including Path, were copying peoplesaddress book data without permission. In someinstances the data was stored unencrypted on company servers.

title: Why Jos Antonio Ocampo Wants to Run the World Bank
description: Last week, I spoke with two candidates for the presidency of the World Bank for an article on the contested election, the first in the history of the Washington-based development institution. (The White House has nominated Dr. Jim Yong Kim, a global health expert and the president of Dartmouth College.) Both candidates gave detailed answers on how they would lead the bank and why they are running for the presidency.

title: How China Steals Our Secrets
description: Washington

title: Panel Rejects Proposal to Allow Election-Related Trading
description: Wall Street, which buys and sells all types of exotic securities, has found a limit to its financial innovation. It cant trade derivatives tied to the 2012 election.

title: $178,000 Is a Lot for a Pig, but This Pig Is Paying for College
description: HOUSTON  Here in the largest city in Texas, $200,000 still goes a long way. It can buy you a four-bedroom 3,000-square-foot home, a used red 2010 Ferrari or a short tubby pig.

title: F.T.C. Approves Merger of 2 of the Biggest Pharmacy Benefit Managers
description: Despite potential antitrust concerns and vocal opposition by some lawmakers and consumer groups, Express Scripts and Medco Health Solutions, two of the nations largest pharmacy benefit managers, said Monday that federal regulators had approved their $29 billion merger.

title: System, Not Judge, Is Blamed for Nepotism in Court Hiring
description: A state oversight commission has dismissed allegations that the top judge in Manhattans appellate court gave jobs to friends and family members, including a former city councilwoman; lied about where he lived; and improperly allowed his assistant to practice law.

title: Agency Administrator Fires Deputies, Then Resigns, Amid Spending Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  The administrator of the General Services Administration fired her two top deputies, then resigned Monday ahead of an investigation into a conference the agency held in Las Vegas that included commemorative coins, lavish meals, a mind reader and a $75,000 team-building exercise assembling bicycles.

title: Obama Campaigns New Ad Attacks Romney and the Oil Industry
description: 9:49 p.m. | Updated The Obama campaign released a new commercial on Monday that tries to link Mitt Romney to the oil industry, painting them both as hostile to the presidents efforts to raise automobile mileage standards and produce more renewable energy.

title: The Straw That Stirred the Cosmos
description: Giorgio Chinaglia was a goal scorer, period. Watching him as he prowled the penalty area  lanky, hunch-shouldered, barrel-chested  fans saw no feints, no tricks, no shimmies or shakes. There was nothing fancy about his play. It was bullish and direct, like the man himself.

title: Quakers Say Contractors Desecrated a Historic Queens Graveyard
description: The wood-shingled meetinghouse, preserved under a bower of trees on a commercial strip in Flushing, Queens, was once the most influential seat of American Quakerism, a place of worship for those who wrote one of the countrys first declarations of religious freedom in the 1600s.

title: Iran: Hyundai Motor Ends Operations
description: The Hyundai Motor Company, the automaking subsidiary of Hyundai, the South Korean conglomerate, has quietly ended its business dealings with Iran, where it had extensive operations, including a joint venture to make cars. United Against Nuclear Iran, an American group that has advocated economic sanctions to pressure Iran over its disputed nuclear program, has reclassified Hyundai Motor, putting it in the withdrawn category on a list the group has compiled of foreign businesses that deal with Iran. Hyundai Motor officials did not respond to requests for comment. A strict new American law is putting pressure on foreign companies to reduce or eliminate their operations in Iran or risk penalties in the United States market. Hyundai is the second big foreign automaker in a week to pull back from Iran. Last week, General Motors said its French partner, PSA Peugeot Citron, had suspended shipments of components to the Iran Khodro Industrial Group, an Iranian vehicle maker, to comply with American restraints on Iran trade.

title: A Little Device Thats Trying to Read Your Thoughts
description: SAN DIEGO  Already surrounded by machines that allow him, painstakingly, to communicate, the physicist Stephen Hawking last summer donned what looked like a rakish black headband that held a feather-light  device the size of a small matchbox.

title: Suggestions by Union in Bounty Case Are Unlikely
description: Representatives of the N.F.L. and the players union met Monday for the first time to discuss the New Orleans Saints bounty system and the 22 to 27 players the league said its investigation showed were involved.

title: Small Banks Shift Charters to Avoid U.S. as Regulator
description: A small community bank in New Hampshire found a demand from its regulator last month just too much.

title: France: Deportations of Radicals Begin
description: French authorities on Monday deported two foreign citizens they identified as Islamist radicals and said three others would soon be expelled, in keeping with a pledge by President Nicolas Sarkozy to quash Muslim extremism after a series of killings in the Toulouse region by a man who claimed to be a member of Al Qaeda. An Algerian man previously convicted for terrorist ties was deported, the Interior Ministry said, along with a Malian imam accused of preaching anti-Semitism. Imams from Saudi Arabia and Turkey and Tunisia were also expected to be expelled. Last week, the authorities arrested 19 people suspected of ties to Muslim groups calling for violence; 16 remain in custody.

title: Mind Games: Sometimes a White Coat Isnt Just a White Coat
description: If you wear a white coat that you believe belongs to a doctor, your ability to pay attention increases sharply. But if you wear the same white coat believing it belongs to a painter, you will show no such improvement.

title: China: Nobel Winners Urge Tibet Talks
description: Twelve Nobel Peace laureates have written an open letter to President Hu Jintao of China, urging him to engage in meaningful dialogue with the Dalai Lama to ease Tibetans frustrations over Chinese policies. At least 32 people in Tibet have set themselves on fire since March 2011 to protest Chinese policies. The laureates, including Desmond M. Tutu, Jody Williams and Lech Walesa, expressed concern over the drastic expressions of resentment by the people of Tibet. The letter, to be sent Tuesday, calls for Mr. Hu to open up Tibet to journalists and diplomats, stop the arbitrary detention of Tibetans and respect religious freedom.

title: President Confident Health Law Will Stand
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama declared Monday that he was confident the Supreme Court would uphold his health care law, saying it would be an unprecedented, extraordinary step to overturn legislation passed by the strong majority of a democratically elected Congress.

title: Alive, Dead or Otherwise (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Pay for Womens Basketball Coaches Lags Far Behind That of Mens Coaches
description: Womens college sports have changed enormously since the adoption of Title IX in 1972. More teams are being fielded and more athletes are participating, and overall visibility and popularity have increased exponentially.

title: Only Connect (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Why People Hate the Banks
description: A few months ago, I was standing in a crowded elevator when Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, stepped in. When he saw me, he said in a voice loud enough for everyone to hear: Why does The New York Times hate the banks?

title: U.S. Davis Cup Team Adds Harrison to Replace Fish
description: A teenager until next month, Ryan Harrison is unexpectedly a key member of the United States Davis Cup team that will face France in a quarterfinal beginning Friday at Monte Carlo Country Club.

title: Another Hole in the Safety Net
description: Georgia is vying with Florida for the title of stingiest state, when it comes to jobless residents. The Republican-controlled State Legislature passed a bill last week to cut the duration of unemployment benefits from a current maximum of 26 weeks to a range from 14 weeks to 20 weeks, depending on the state unemployment rate. Florida cut its 26-week maximum last year, to a range of 12 weeks to 23 weeks.

title: Senior Season Awaits, but at Potential Cost
description: DENVER

title: Live Updates: N.C.A.A. Mens Tournament Final
description: Kentucky is playing Kansas for the mens basketball national championship. Zach Hillesland, a former player at Notre Dame and frequent contributor to The Quad, will provide live updates and analysis with the help of Stephen Danley, another frequent contributor who played basketball at the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Desperately Seeking Synonyms
description: This is the second in a series of writing lessons by the author.

title: As Riots Boil Over, These Guards Dont Budge
description: ATHENS  It is not easy being a member of Greeces Presidential Guard, the soldiers who, resplendent in old-world uniforms, must stand stock-still at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier here. Frozen feet, sweaty brows and the curiosity of the very young, who poke and kick the guards to see if they are really alive, are just some of the hazards.

title: Where Housing Once Boomed, Recovery Lags
description: CLINTON, Md.  Half a decade has passed since crowds of lunchtime workers regularly packed the Fish Market restaurant, a popular fixture of this southern Maryland crossroads known by the lighthouse on its roof.

title: JOBS Act Jeopardizes Safety Net for Investors
description: Maybe President Obama should have bought shares in Groupons I.P.O.

title: Weighing When Slim Hopes Become G.O.P. Problem
description: OSHKOSH, Wis.  With big-name Republicans and even many Democrats coming to agree that Mitt Romney is destined to be the Republican nominee, there is just one hitch: Someone forgot to tell Rick Santorum.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 2, 2012

title: A Judge Turns on the Light
description: A federal judge took an important step toward ending secret donations to big-spending political groups, striking down regulations that permitted some groups to hide their donors. Unfortunately, the ruling probably came too late to flush this corrupting practice from this years elections  though there is still time for Congress to do so.

title: Treasure of Golfs Sad Past, Black Caddies Vanish in Era of Riches
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  For decades, the black caddies at Augusta National Golf Club  required by the clubs rules and treasured for their nuanced knowledge of the courses topography  stood as a striking symbol of the sports segregated state.

title: Divide and Discriminate
description: When a light is shined into the dark corners of American politics, its never pleasant to see what scurries away. Last week, a federal judge in Maine unsealed memos from the National Organization for Marriage, one of the most prominent groups fighting against same-sex marriage.

title: Regulator Orders Hospitals to Undo a Merger in Ohio
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Trade Commission has blocked an Ohio hospital merger in a closely watched case that could slow the consolidation of health care providers around the country.

title: At Advocates Offices, Confronting an Anti-Liberal Scheme
description: Young, bearded, a bit scruffy, a young man walked into a community organizing office in East Harlem, lugging a heavy bag. A little nervous, he said that his name was Melvin Howting, and that he worked for an environmental company in New Jersey and had a few questions about how to organize a union.

title: A Network Popular With Hispanics Reaches Out to Them
description: ITS been redone nearly 400 times over the last 17 years, but one thing has stayed the same about ESPNs This is SportsCenter advertisement: Its always been in English.

title: Stop and Frisk, Continued
description: The Bloomberg administration and its police commissioner, Raymond Kelly, have been disturbingly dismissive of complaints about the citys program of stops, frisks and arrests that is ensnaring hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers each year.

title: State Public Workers Rushed to Join Pensions Before Cutbacks
description: ALBANY  Thousands of public employees across New York State rushed to sign up for pensions over the last several weeks, seeking to lock in generous retirement benefits before cuts approved by the State Legislature took effect on Sunday.

title: Manhattan State Senator Says Hell Challenge Rangel
description: Adriano Espaillat, a Democratic state senator who represents Washington Heights, announced on Monday that he would run against Representative Charles B. Rangel, ending months of speculation over his potential candidacy and setting the stage for a campaign that could test the strength of Latino influence in the district.

title: Ahead of Passover, Strict Standards Transform a Brooklyn Neighborhood
description: On any ordinary day, yellow school buses with the Hebrew names of yeshivas dominate the ultra-Orthodox landscape of Borough Park, Brooklyn. But in the days before Passover, large trucks parked along many of the sidewalks are far more striking, particularly those bearing signs with a Hebrew word obscure even to most Jews: Sheimos.

title: Swiss Seek Arrest of 3 German Tax Officials Over Stolen Banking Data
description: BERLIN  A long-simmering dispute between Germany and Switzerland over a CD containing stolen data about possible tax evaders has escalated after Swiss authorities issued arrest warrants for three German tax inspectors who paid $3.3 million for the information.

title: End of the Rainbow
description: Scenes from the new Broadway show starring Tracie Bennett as Judy Garland.

title: Small Border City Wins an Israeli Title
description: Hapoel Ironi Kiryat Shmona secured its first Israeli league title Monday after battling out a 0-0 draw against its second-place rival, Hapoel Tel Aviv.

title: The Beauty and the Bluster of Chinaglia
description: Lawrie Mifflin, who covered the Cosmos and soccer from 1977 to 1984 for the Daily News and The Times, wrote an appraisal of Giorgio Chinaglias career for Tuesdays editions, but you can read it here now. The former Times sports columnist George Vecsey, who now blogs at georgevecsey.com, offered his take there.

title: A Star Who Was Born, Sparkled and Fell
description: As befits a play about Judy Garland, a woman known for liberally mixing her pills, Peter Quilters End of the Rainbow is a jolting upper and downer at the same time. After watching Tracie Bennetts electrifying interpretation of Garland in the intense production that opened on Monday night at the Belasco Theater, you feel exhilarated and exhausted, equally ready to dance down the street and crawl under a rock.

title: Generations Collide, Gently, in a Grandmothers Village Apartment
description: Plays as truthful and touching and fine as Amy Herzogs 4000 Miles come along once or maybe twice a season, if were lucky. So let us be grateful that Lincoln Center Theater, which first presented this gently comic drama at the tail end of last season under the auspices of its LCT3 program, has moved the same production uptown to the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater, where it opened on Monday with all its virtues intact.

title: Moving Parts of an Engine
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  A nice, fresh grid from Paula Gamache, and just a hair tougher than I would expect on a Tuesday. Not that theres anything wrong with that.

title: Redrawn Districts Present a Hurdle for Democrats
description: WASHINGTON  As Democrats try to orchestrate a state-by-state drive to retake control of the House of Representatives, an unexpected hurdle has arisen in New York, an overwhelmingly Democratic state that should have been friendly terrain.

title: The Muslim Swing Vote
description: As the 2012 presidential election picks up steam, Republican candidates find it tempting and beneficial to bash Muslims as a way to attract voters. In the wake of the 2010 midterm elections, Americans are learning what Europeans have known for years: Islam-bashing wins votes, the journalist Michael Scott Moore wrote that November. At the time, many of the 85 new Republican House members buoyed by the surging Tea Party movement found the political virtues of anti-Muslim rhetoric an easy way to prove their mettle to the surging conservative base.

title: Mayoral Elections Give Russian Opposition a Boost
description: YAROSLAVL, Russia  Just weeks before Vladimir V. Putin again assumes the presidency in Russia, scattered political insurgencies against local governments have begun to expose cracks in his near monopoly on power.

title: And Now, the Veepstakes
description: I have two words for you: Dick Cheney.

title: Although Still Ailing, Davis Thinks He Is Able
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Baron Davis has the rsum of a former All-Star and the bravado to go with it. But sometimes he still has to convince himself, like Stuart Smalley speaking mantras into the mirror.

title: Respect the Future
description: Last fall I asked readers over 70 to send me Life Reports  essays evaluating their own lives. Charles Darwin Snelling responded with a remarkable 5,000-word reflection.

title: Sampling the Easter Markets of Prague
description: Frisky young lovers, barbecued pork and rows upon rows of colorful hand-painted eggs are all part of Pragues pastel-hued Easter markets. The old tradition of men playfully swatting their paramours with artfully decorated willow sticks in exchange for plum brandy and painted eggs is a beloved part of the seasonal fun. These Easter whips (or pomlazka), along with numerous other unique souvenirs, can be bought from little wooden booths that will line many of the citys public squares through April 15.

title: One Star Torn Between Two Tours
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  In front of a hotel mirror with his father by his side, 17-year-old Ryo Ishikawa rehearsed the lines that would open his first news conference on the PGA Tour: Hello, America. I am Ryo Ishikawa from Japan.

title: Half of Irish Homeowners Join Boycott of New Property Tax
description: DUBLIN  Anti-austerity protesters are claiming victory after the government acknowledged that around 50 percent of Irelands estimated 1.6 million homeowners failed to pay a new, flat-rate $133 property tax by the March 31 deadline.

title: Are the Olympics More Trouble Than Theyre Worth?
Law Could Hamper Drug Tourism in the Netherlands
description: AMSTERDAM  The scene at the 420 Cafe on a recent Friday was typical of what many travelers have come to associate with Amsterdam. Behind the bar, Janne Svensson, 34, a self-described cannabis refugee from Norway, weighed out small quantities of marijuana and hashish for her customers, many from foreign countries. They sat quietly, smoking and sipping coffee, as familiar strains of Jimi Hendrix drifted softly from the stereo and giant manta rays cavorted in a nature video on a big-screen television.

title: White House and the F.D.A. Often at Odds
description: Nancy-Ann DeParle, the whip-smart and sometimes caustic White House deputy chief of staff, picked up The Wall Street Journal one summer day in 2010 and got an unwelcome shock. The Food and Drug Administration was proposing as part of the new health care law to require that movie theaters post calorie counts for popcorn  and this was the first she had heard of it.

title: Professors Salaries Are Graded on the Global Curve
description: How much is a professor worth?

title: Areas of Disagreement
description: Senior officials in the Obama administration and the Food and Drug Administration have quietly disagreed over a range of issues.

title: Colombian Rebels Free 10, Raising Hopes of Peace Talks With Government
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Colombias main rebel group on Monday released four soldiers and six police officers it had held hostage for as long as 14 years. The 10 men were thought to be the last remaining noncivilian captives held by the group, which has used kidnapping and drug trafficking to help finance its nearly five-decade war against the Colombian government.

title: Yankees and Mets Resuming Rivalry Down South
description: MIAMI  The Yankees will take a sparse lineup to Port St. Lucie on Tuesday for the first of two spring training games against the Mets in 16 years. Stars like Derek Jeter, Alex Rodriguez and Mariano Rivera will not make the trip.

title: In Libya, Militias Become a Political Force
description: The militias that have turned Libya into a patchwork of semiautonomous fiefdoms are now plunging into politics, raising fears that they could undermine elections.

title: Libyan Militias Turn to Politics, a Volatile Mix
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  The militia leaders who have turned post-Qaddafi Libya into a patchwork of semiautonomous fiefs are now plunging into politics, raising fears that their armed brigades could undermine elections intended to lay the foundation of a new democracy.

title: Noncitizens Sue Over U.S. Gay Marriage Ban
description: Five legally married same-sex couples filed a lawsuit on Monday to challenge the 1996 law that bars the federal government from recognizing same-sex marriages, arguing that its impact is particularly harsh on couples that include an American citizen and a foreigner.

title: Romney Faults Obama on Energy Costs, but Has Cited Benefits of Rising Prices
description: WASHINGTON  For several weeks, Mitt Romney has seized on the rising cost of gasoline to attack President Obama and his environmental aides for what Mr. Romney calls their misguided desire to see higher energy prices.

title: Immigration Officials Arrest More Than 3,100
description: In a six-day nationwide sweep, federal immigration agents arrested 3,168 immigrants who had been convicted of crimes or had repeatedly violated immigration laws, officials said Monday.

title: Image of the Day: April 2
Ex-Treasurer of Massachusetts Accused of Misusing Lottery Ads
description: BOSTON  A former treasurer of Massachusetts, Timothy P. Cahill, was indicted Monday, accused of misusing advertising for the State Lottery to benefit his campaign for governor in 2010.

title: Corrections: April 3
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Coronation for Kentucky, and for Its Coach
description: NEW ORLEANS  Kentucky Coach John Calipari finally found the right team and the right setting to outrace his tortured N.C.A.A. tournament history. For all the drama, all the investigations and all the late-season heartbreak Calipari has endured, the game that delivered him his first national title came against a program nearly as iconic as his own and in almost anticlimactic fashion.

title: Longevity Up in U.S., but Education Creates Disparity, Study Says
description: Americans are living longer, but the gains in life span are accruing disproportionately among the better educated, according to a new report by researchers from the University of Wisconsin.

title: Bidding Wars Amid Flat Property Prices in Manhattan
description: Prices for Manhattan real estate were relatively flat in the first three months of the year, but brokers anticipate a much stronger spring sales season, saying that many properties had recently prompted bidding wars, indicating a new level of buyer confidence.

title: Wildcats Davis Dominates the Title Game With His Swats, Not His Shots
description: NEW ORLEANS  Early in the second half, Kansas threw the ball inside, to the part of the court the Jayhawks avoided most on Monday night. Thomas Robinson, star forward, all-American, likely N.B.A. draft lottery pick, received the pass. Anthony Davis of Kentucky stood waiting for him.

title: Giorgio Chinaglia, Italian Star and the Cosmos Leader, Dies at 65
description: Giorgio Chinaglia, who came to the New York Cosmos professional soccer team as one of Europes greatest and most charismatic goal scorers, then attracted almost as much attention for his impenitent candor  he even criticized his revered teammate Pel  died on Sunday at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 65.

title: 10-Year-Old Boy Shot by Stray Bullet in Brooklyn
description: A 10-year-old boy was shot by a stray bullet fired during a shootout in Brooklyn on Monday night, the police said.

title: John Arden, British Playwright, Dies at 81
description: John Arden, a major British playwright of the 1950s and 1960s, whose politically engaged, theatrically inventive and conscience-provoking works were often compared to Brechts but have been only intermittently revived and rarely performed in the United States, died on Wednesday. He was 81.

description: Kentucky defeated Kansas, 67-59, to win the N.C.A.A. championship.

title: April 3, 1948 | Truman Signs Marshall Plan, Providing Aid to Europe
description: On April 3, 1948, President Truman signed the Marshall Plan, which allocated more than $5 billion in aid to 16 European countries. In signing the plan, officially called the Economic Recovery Program, Truman declared, This measure is Americas answer to the challenge facing the free world.

title: Whats the Easiest Way to Cheat on Your Taxes?
description: If economists ran the tax system, there would be virtually no exemptions or loopholes. But economists dont run the tax system! Instead, businesses, rich people, Congressmen and attorneys spend a shockingly large amount of time lobbying for tax breaks or exploiting the ones that exist. When the modern income tax was created in 1913, the code was 27 pages long. Last year, it was 5,296 pages. What in the world does it say? After surveying 20 accountants, tax lawyers and policy wonks, weve boiled down their arcane knowledge to this short list of things you might want to know.

description: In the past few years, its gotten easier to put out a book  not with an established publishing house, but to do whats known as self-publishing. And students have gotten in on it, putting out self-published books, often with their parents help. Do you want to write a book?

title: Syrian Leader Accused of Escalating Attacks
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrias political opposition accused President Bashar al-Assad of escalating military assaults on four major urban centers on Tuesday. Such assaults would directly contradict the Syrian governments promise, announced on Monday, that it would immediately begin pulling armed forces back from population centers, in accordance with a special envoys cease-fire plan.

title: Beware of Budget Gimmickry
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

title: Solazyme and Bunge Plan Factory to Make Oil From Algae
description: The promise of using algae to make biofuels  a dream scientists have chased for decades  might seem particularly welcome in a time of stubbornly high gasoline prices. But the path to commercial-scale production has been circuitous.

description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The United States has announced a $10 million reward for information leading to the capture of Hafiz Saeed, a Pakistani militant leader accused of orchestrating the 2008 Mumbai attacks, who in recent months has emerged at the vanguard of a prominent anti-American lobbying group.

title: As Myanmar Changes, So Does Its Leader
description: KYONKU, Myanmar  He is sometimes called the Mikhail Gorbachev of Myanmar, a once-loyal apparatchik of one of the worlds most brutal military dictatorships who is chipping away at some of its worst legacies  freeing political prisoners, partially unshackling the press and allowing the long-persecuted opposition to run for election last Sunday.

One of those projects is a two-hour special called Hunting the Elements (as in the periodic table, not extreme weather). It will be broadcast at 9 p.m. Eastern time on Wednesday on PBS. (Local broadcast times vary.)

description: LONDON  One of the top bankers at JPMorgan Chase in London resigned on Tuesday.

title: James Cameron Is Ready for the Apocalypse
description: You recently made news for taking an incredibly tiny submarine seven miles deep into the Pacific Ocean. Was there a moment inside that thing when you thought, This totally sucks?  Oh, yeah. There are moments when you say, Wow, I really wish I could stretch my legs out. If only I had made this three inches bigger. But I worked hard for years and spent a lot of money to put myself in that situation, so I cant exactly complain.

title: Tech Audit: Two Owners, Two Companies, Lots of I.T. Headaches
description: Scott Lowe had been living in Tokyo with his wife, Rio Miura, for a few years when in 1996 they started selling coffee and tea by catalog. We really wanted to open a coffee shop and then expand, like Starbucks, but we didnt have the money for it, he said. But the catalog started pulling in sales, and then in 1998 they moved back to the United States and started selling here as well, settling in San Francisco.

title: Europes Economy Is Eating Its Young, and Its About to Get Worse

title: On Facebook, Some Friendly Energy Rivalry
description: So, would you stop washing your clothes in warm water if your best friend tried doing it in cold and said her jeans were coming out clean? Would you be more likely to weatherize your house if your college roommate said that it had cut her heating bill by 30 percent? And if your mom got one of those power strips that turn off devices that suck electricity in the middle of the night, would you do the same?

description: The quest for happiness has been the direct or indirect subject of a huge chunk of intellectual endeavor: philosophy, theology, psychology, economics and, of course, literature, which has tended to cast a jaundiced eye on the matter. To be stupid and selfish and to have good health are the three requirements for happiness, Flaubert wrote, though if stupidity is lacking, the others are useless.

description: OAKLAND, Calif.  In the tightly knit Korean-American community here, bound by membership at churches and a striving for academic excellence, One L. Goh had long found himself on the periphery. After leaving an apartment in Virginia without paying his rent two years ago, he returned to the Bay Area, where he had lived earlier and where his ailing father still resided.

title: Dress for Success
description: Whats the secret to a great dress? Sunhee Hwang, a South Korean-born designer whose second collection won her an Ecco Domani prize this year, has this tip: Before thoughts of fine fabrics, look for beautiful colors, she says. Thats what gets us into the dressing rooms in the hopes of finding winsome silhouettes and flattering lines. Hwang certainly has a way with a frock herself: at the 1995 Fashion Institute of Technology graduation show, her tangerine gown attracted the attention of the Lanvin designer Alber Elbaz, then at Geoffrey Beene. He said to me, Your dresses are very beautiful. Why dont you work for me?  recalls Hwang, now 38. After stints at Beene, Anna Sui, Elie Tahari and Anne Klein, Hwang is back in the limelight with knockout Sunhee dresses, like an airy silk confection in maize yellow (above right; $825 at sunheeny.com) and a flirty salsa number in rich cobalt ($395 at sunheeny.com). When you look at beautiful clothes, it doesnt matter who the designer is, she says, citing Narciso Rodriguezs color-blocked sheaths and Jonathan Saunderss vibrant shifts as examples of smart fits in smashing colors. As long as you look gorgeous and feel special, you will buy it. Im just hoping its my dress.

title: Daily Report: A Device to Read Your Thoughts
description: The physicist Stephen Hawking is trying out a device the size of a matchbox that is designed to allow him to communicate by merely thinking, David Ewing Duncan reports in Tuesdays New York Times.

title: James Murdoch Steps Down From British Broadcaster
description: LONDON  BSkyB, the British satellite broadcaster partly owned by the News Corporation, said on Tuesday that James Murdoch had resigned as chairman to shield the company from the phone hacking scandal engulfing his familys British newspaper group.

description: Jonathan Bales is the founder ofTheDCTimes.comand will help analyze draft prospects for The Fifth Down in his Scouting the Draft preview series.

title: Whats Next in Myanmar?
description: It seemed unthinkable only a few months ago. On Sunday, people danced in the streets of Yangon, celebrating that Nobel Peace laureate Daw Aung San Suu Kyi had won a seat in Myanmars Parliament. Her party, the National League for Democracy, has picked up almost every seat contested in the elections. As she spoke of the beginning of a new era, observers around the world were wondering what comes next for Myanmar.

title: A Mecca in London
description: LONDON  As a frequent visitor to the British Museum, I can attest that its vast Great Court has never been as full of Muslims  declaring themselves through headscarves, skull caps and prayer beads  as it is these days. They are swarming the museum to visit Hajj: Journey to the Heart of Islam, the first-ever exhibit about the annual Muslim pilgrimage to Mecca in Saudi Arabia. More than 80,000 people visited the exhibit in its first seven weeks. Moreover, it has fueled a much-needed dialogue about Islam in Britain, and demonstrated that cultural venues are well suited to host the difficult debate about multiculturalism.

title: In Paris, Degas and the Nude
description: Edgar Degass reputation largely rests on his paintings of horse racing and dancers, portraits and genre scenes. Far less celebrated but equally compelling are his nudes, a subject he returned to throughout his career. In collaboration with Bostons Museum of Fine Arts, the Muse dOrsay (1, rue de la Lgion dHonneur) sets out to rectify this oversight with the remarkable exhibition Degas and the Nude, which will be held through July 1, and includes important loans from the Philadelphia Museum of Art and the National Gallery of Art in Washington, among others.

title: A Critics Conversation: Modern Dance Madness
description: ALASTAIR MACAULAY These last few years, hard-pressed critics have spoken of Modern-Dance March Madness. This year was no exception. March 2012 proved to be one of the busiest and richest times for dance lovers in New York. The Paul Taylor Dance Companys three-week season, featuring 22 works at the Koch Theater, ended on Sunday. Meanwhile, we have also seen a multitude of performances from other classic companies, like the Martha Graham Dance Company, and contemporary artists like Sarah Michelson and Ishmael Houston-Jones, who organized the Parallels series at Danspace, which also ended this weekend.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Philadelphia Papers Sold and Redford Returns to Watergate
description: The long history of newspapers in the City of Brotherly Love took another turn Monday with the sale of parent company of The Philadelphia Inquirer and The Daily News to a group of politically connected investors. The price was $55 million, less than half of what the papers sold for just two years earlier. One investor who did not follow through with the deal, writes Amy Chozick, was Ed Rendell, the former Philadelphia mayor and Pennsylvania governor whose participation drew a lot of criticism from inside and outside the papers. There was enough blowback from reporters and editorial people, because Im active politically and support candidates and the president, that I decided to step back, he said, adding the current owners might ask me my opinion every once in a while.

The rappers Tinie Tempah and Lupe Fiasco are also expected to perform.

title: Life, Interrupted: A Video Portrait of Cancer in Young Adulthood
description: Cancer doesnt just put your life on hold, says Suleika Jaouad, Well columnist, in a new video that documents her experiences as a 23-year-old woman with cancer. title: Palin and Couric Have Their Morning Showdown. No Blows Landed.

But no verbal punches were actually thrown on Tuesday, as Ms. Couric co-hosted ABCs Good Morning America and Ms. Palin sort-of-co-hosted NBCs Today show.

title: Between Tibet and China, India Plays Delicate Balancing Act

title: Political Geography: Wisconsin
description: The Republican campaign for president will technically continue into May and June, but the primary in Wisconsin on Tuesday may be the last act of its competitive stage.

title: The True Cost of Breast-feeding  This Milk Isnt Free
description: One of the most powerful myths surrounding breast milk is that its not only the best food for baby, but that its free. Nursing mothers have long known that free in this context requires that we place zero value on our own sleep, time and even dignity. (Remember the study showing that breast-feeding women are viewed as less competent?)

title: The Fighting Second
description: The creation of army corps during the early winter of 1862 represents one of the greatest, if lesser known, organizational accomplishments of the Union Army. The sheer numbers were staggering. By the end of March, the Army of the Potomac, the premier Union military force in the Eastern Theater, alone had swelled to 120,000 men. By comparison, the American army that had captured Mexico City during the Mexican War  the nations last major conflict  had numbered only about 14,000 soldiers.

title: Bookshelf | Will Oldham Speaks
description: Will Oldham does not care for interviews. Theyre often confounding and pointless, he finds, and the media does not seem to think he is good at giving them. Whats more, he does not want to get better. It just feels so wrong most of the time, the singer-songwriter and actor tells his friend Alan Licht, in a new book-length interview. Its just a waste of time, because it doesnt have anything to do with anything, and it demands a lot of time and a lot of thought, and the thought has nothing to do with anything. The book, Will Oldham on Bonnie Prince Billy, which will be published in Britain by Faber & Faber on Thursday and in the United States by Norton this fall, is one very long interview  an interview to end all interviews, the hope seems to be. And it just might work, for within the books 382 pages Oldham answers nearly every question one might wish to ask about his prolific output, which he has recorded and performed variously as Will Oldham, Palace Brothers, Palace Music, Palace Songs, Palace, Bonnie (Prince) Billy, Bonnie Billy, and Bonnie (Prince) Billy and the Cairo Gang. Longtime fans will appreciate the books generous portion of inside baseball. He wrote the song I Am a Cinematographer, for instance, after reading Robert Bressons Notes on the Cinematographer, and initially agreed to play piano on Johnny Cashs cover of his song I See a Darkness despite not knowing how to play piano. (He later fessed up and instead conducted Cash and sang back-up vocals, in a recording session he recalls as surreal: I remember it was as if I was a Colorform or paper doll that had just been pasted into that situation.) Readers may also be amused to learn that he once passed up a possible part on Doogie Howser, M.D.; took classes in the waltz, the cha-cha-cha and scuba diving; and admires the comic timing of Foghorn Leghorn and Bugs Bunny, whom he cites as an influence. Though Oldham declined to be interviewed about the interview, The Moment was delighted to mine an advance copy for some of its choicest quotations.

title: How Bolivia Lost Its Hat
description: In 1867, the British ambassador to Bolivia fell afoul of its dictator, Mariano Melgarejo, by refusing a glass of chicha, a cloudy drink based on fermented maize. Opting for cocoa instead, the ambassador got more than he asked for: Melgarejo, incensed, forced him to drink an entire bowl of liquid chocolate. He then paraded him three times around La Pazs main square, tied up and seated back to front on a donkey [1], before shipping him back to London.

title: Kensington Palace Reopens After Extensive Renovations
description: A palace that was built to keep the commoners out is now an estate open to all. Last week, Kensington Palace reopened after a 12 million renovation that created the space for several new exhibits and revamped nearly every part of the building and grounds  from gardens first created in the 1730s to the interior State Rooms, where royal family members such as Queen Victoria and Princess Margaret once lived. Prince William and Princess Kate plan to continue the royal tradition and make this their home once they leave Wales. (Their quarters wont be open to the public, however.)The new exhibits include an in-depth look at two former residents: Queen Victoria in an exhibit called Victoria Revealed and Princess Diana in a timeline of her evolution as a fashion icon. A small collection of her dresses are on display, some of which have never been exhibited before in the United Kingdom.

title: Havas Buys Majority Stake in Crowdsourcing Ad Agency
description: Whether there is wisdom in crowds, a leading advertising holding group sees opportunity in the idea.

title: Worker Dies When House Collapses in Brooklyn
description: A construction worker died on Tuesday in Brooklyn when part of a house collapsed, the authorities said.

title: Obama, in Talk, Calls House G.O.P. Budget the Work of Rightist Radicals
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama opened a full-frontal assault on Tuesday on the federal budget adopted by House Republicans, condemning it as a Trojan horse that would greatly deepen inequality in the United States, and painting it as the manifesto of a party that has swung radically to the right.

title: A Government Harassment Suit Goes to Court
description: The Obama administration has been disturbingly successful at slamming the courts for any challenges to its excessive use, and abuse, of national security powers. So it is worth noting when a judge demands accountability.

title: Amy Adams Joins Cast of Into the Woods
description: Amy Adams, who has had a string of Academy Award nominations in recent years for The Fighter, Doubt, and Junebug, got her start performing in dinner theater in the 1990s  but the movies made her famous before theater companies could. This summer, however, Ms. Adams will have a shot at a star turn on stage when she makes her New York debut playing the bakers wife in the musical Into the Woods, which will run July 23 to Aug. 25 at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, the shows producers at the Public Theater announced on Tuesday.

title: Is the Tax Break on Your Prius More Trouble Than Its Worth?
description: For this weeks Its the Economy column, Adam Davidson, Jacob Goldstein, Caitlin Kenney and I talked to nearly two dozen accountants, tax lawyers and policy wonks in preparation for the tax seasons crunch time. We learned a few things: 1. Accountants can actually be pretty funny. 2. An actress once tried to write off her thong. And 3. Dont buy a fuel-efficient car for the tax credit alone.

Are policies promoting economic opportunity as important as sex ed?

Sometimes large and scary job loss numbers are attached to the assertion and attributed to a study, most often financed by the affected industry.

Ever since we began this expansion, I have been asked how often we are solicited for bribes in foreign countries. The funny thing is that while bribery is perceived to be relatively commonplace in international business, it may be more common in this country than people like to think. At least thats what a former TerraCycle employee who used to work for a major American consumer products company told me.

description: PHILADELPHIAThe Rangers come into Tuesday evenings game against the Flyers needing a single point to clinch the Eastern Conference title. They can also clinch if the Penguins drop a point Tuesday night at Boston.

title: Research Cut Short in Indian Tiger Preserves
description: Anindya Sinha knows the Bandipur Tiger Reserves 900 bonnet macaques by face. Since 2000 he has worked among the monkey troops in the reserve, trying to understand how individual identity informs behavior and group dynamics, and how tourism is affecting the primates intricate society. But his research, meant to last 20 years, recently came to a grinding halt. Along with those of around 40 other scientists, Dr. Sinhas permit to conduct work within the reserve was revoked by the wildlife manager of Karnataka State.

The American contender, Jim Yong Kim, a global health expert and the president of Dartmouth College, is considered the favorite.

title: Theatrical Parody of Harry Potter Books to Open in New York
description: Potted Potter, the 70-minute unauthorized parody of the seven Harry Potter books, will make its United States debut with an Off Broadway production starting preview performances on May 19 at the Little Shubert Theater, a group of Canadian and British producers announced on Tuesday. As previously reported, the producers plan to hold 10 performances a week at the 499-seat Little Shubert  more than the typical New York performance schedule of eight a week  in hopes of making more money off the relatively brief running time of Potted Potter and the popularity of the Potter characters and stories.

title: Gwynnett St.
description: Sophisticated food in simple surroundings at a new restaurant in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

title: In a Simple Room, Surprises Await
description: THE one-story exterior facing Graham Avenue, in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn, was totally unornamented except for a cryptic pair of stone lions up on the cornice. The dining room was plain, too, harking back to the days when nothing said hip, contemporary and urban better than exposed brick. At the end of the bar was what looked like, and under the previous ownership was, a pizza oven. Now it was baking miniature loaves of whiskey bread. They cost $5, tasted sweet and old-fashioned, and brought me back to those sprawling family restaurants that serve turkey with hot gravy on Sunday afternoons.

title: 100 Years Later: Ways to Teach About the Titanic With The Times
description: April 15 is the centennial anniversary of the Titanic disaster, which took the lives of more than 1,500 people and left just over 700 survivors.

title: Budget Plans Defeat Shows Hurdles to Compromise

title: Three Dishes at Gwynnett St.
description: Welcome to the weekly blog feature formerly known as Five Dishes. We took a week off, and in that time two of the dishes dropped away. Cynics will note that we are delivering less content just as The Times is shutting the window a bit on how many articles readers can see each month without subscribing. The more charitable might say that Diners Journal still gives good value when the three dishes contain as many components as the ones Justin Hilbert prepares at Gwynnett St., which Im reviewing this week.

Facing the N.B.A.s second toughest home-stretch schedule, the Knicks have turned to Baron Davis, who has not exactly inspired confidence of late.

description: The blooms may be off the branches, but there is still plenty left of the monthlong National Cherry Blossom Festival, including a kite-flying extravaganza on Saturday on the grounds of the Washington Monument. Where to eat when you are taking it all in? For those who do not mind more walking, or an inexpensive taxi ride, here are suggestions for meals, snacks or cocktails in the National Mall neighborhood:

description: As the Supreme Court considers repealing all or part of President Obamas health care law, Republican lawmakers are dusting off their own proposals. Jonathan Weisman reports.

title: The President Fumbles the Court Issue
description: Im sure President Obama knows how important the Supreme Courts decision on health care will be to his re-election, not to mention the future of the country. And Im equally sure he knows that the issue of Supreme Court appointments should figure highly in his campaign. If he loses, the nation faces what could be the most right-wing court in history, driven by a highly politicized agenda.

title: In Mogadishu, a Glimpse of Daily Life
description: Sven Torfinn, a Dutch photographer based in Nairobi, Kenya, and I just spent a week in Mogadishu, Somalias capital. It was incredible how much the city has changed in the past year. Not so long ago, so much of Mog, as its called, was off-limits, either Shabab territory or a full-fledged conflict zone. Gunshots rang out every night. Bodies were literally lying in the streets.

title: In Poll, Jewish Voters Overwhelmingly Support Obama
description: A poll of American Jewish voters shows that they overwhelmingly support Barack Obama for president, just as they did four years ago, and that Israel and Iran rank low on their list of priority issues in the presidential election.

title: Fire Kills 17 in Moscow Workers Dormitory
description: MOSCOW  A makeshift workers dormitory here that was cited for fire code violations a month ago caught fire early on Tuesday, killing at least 17 people, officials said, and highlighting Russias worsening problem with the enforcement of basic safety standards.

title: MJs Egg Casserole

title: Straight From the Home Coop
description: FOR newly hatched chicken enthusiasts, the first egg from your own hens is a small miracle. You want to dip it in gold, said the writer Susan Orlean, who keeps nine hens at her home in Columbia County, N.Y.

title: Thinking of Keeping Chickens in Your Yard?
description: A theme quickly emerged as I interviewed home cooks for my article this week: once you get the hang of keeping chickens, the challenge is keeping up with them. Many hatcheries have a minimum order of 25 day-old chicks (they need to huddle together for warmth during shipping), so its not unusual to end up with more than a dozen laying hens by summer. Jennifer Trainer Thompson, who has recently published The Fresh Egg Cookbook, was a hobbyist gardener (with a day job at the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art) before branching out into poultry and bees at her Williamstown home. Her dozen hens produce about five dozen eggs a week.

title: The Get | Miu Mius Starfish Sandals
description: With straps that form sparkly starfish, the latest glitterific Miu Miu shoes are beach sandals at their best. Conical crystals mimic the ocean creatures rough, pumice-y texture; a thick layer of gold glitter beneath them reads like pyrite sand; and the leather piping is the perfect seaside color  coral. Every detail has been meticulously applied and assembled by hand (so walk away from the salt water).

title: In Virginia, Kaine Jumps to Substantial Fund-Raising Lead
description: In the closely watched Senate race in Virginia, former Gov. Tim Kaine, the Democratic candidate, has jumped out to an early and substantial lead.

title: James Joyce and Tendrils of 30s Swing
description: The composer Victoria Bond has never been afraid to experiment with unusual combinations, musical and otherwise, in her Cutting Edge Concerts. The series, now in its 15th season, used to bring together musicians and representatives of other disciplines  chefs or architects, for example  in the hope of finding some sort of philosophical common ground. These days, Ms. Bonds goals are strictly musical, and she has expanded the name of the series to Cutting Edge Concerts New Music Festival.

title: Peter Kareiva, an Inconvenient Environmentalist
description: I encourage you to watch the provocative and important lecture above by Peter Kareiva, the much-lauded chief scientist of the worlds biggest environmental group, the Nature Conservancy. The title is Failed Metaphors and A New Environmentalism for the 21st Century. Its a refreshing call for new approaches from a community stuck on what Ive called a woe is me, shame on you tune for far too long

title: Chicken and Egg
description: Once you get the hang of keeping chickens, the challenge is keeping up with them.

title: From Congress, a Law Befitting a Sausage Factory
description: Whether the Jump-start Our Business Start-ups Act will create jobs or only encourage fraud is open to debate, but one thing is clear: this piece of legislation is a reminder that Congress, both Democrats and Republicans, is completely inept at regulating our financial system.

title: In New Zealand, a Man, a Van, a Plan
description: Early on a chilly March morning, my iPhone alarm clock sounded. I extracted myself from deep within a navy blue comforter, sat up and opened the door. I had momentarily forgotten where I was.

title: Mayor Defends Withholding Report on 911 System
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs administration came under attack on Tuesday for keeping secret what is said to be a sharply critical report on New York Citys much-delayed, wildly over-budget 911 emergency dispatch system, as elected officials accused it of trying to portray a technological debacle in the rosiest possible terms.

title: The Simple Analytics of Soaking the Rich (Wonkish)
description: Update: I see that some people are saying, But taxes discourage work! Um, thats what the supply curve in the figure measures; if taxes didnt have any effect on work, it would be a vertical line.

title: Griner Joins the Greats of the Game
description: DENVER  At the buzzer, Brittney Griner threw a towel in the air, ran to midcourt and held up a finger signaling that Baylor was finally No. 1. With another dominant performance, she made good on a pledge to lift a national championship trophy and to hoist her coach to cut down the nets.

title: The Big Bang
description: In 1990, Japan was at the peak of its prosperity. It seemed an unstoppable force. But the boom turned out to be a bubble. Remember MITI, Japans economic planning agency? Its now defunct, but then it was the envy of competitiveness gurus the world over. MITI, plus public-private cooperation, plus thrifty citizens and dedicated workers, plus demanding schools and diligent students, plus a sheltered domestic economy, plus ferociously competitive exporters  all worked together to create a new variety of capitalism, one destined to eat Americas lunch. Or so it seemed.

title: Updates From Wisconsin, Maryland and D.C. Primaries

title: Wen Calls China Banks Too Powerful
description: SHANGHAI  Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China said on Tuesday that the nations biggest state-run banks have too much power and ought to be broken up because they earn far too much money.

title: A Shakespeare Play Set Where the Buffalo Roam
description: The Wild West makes a suitable setting for the brawling romance at the center of The Taming of the Shrew in the Theater for a New Audience production at the Duke on 42nd Street. Transplanting Shakespeare comedies to the land of gunslingers and tumbleweeds has become something of a commonplace, its true, but this lively production, directed by Arin Arbus (who directed the excellent renditions of Othello and Macbeth for the same company), treads lightly on conceptual gimmickry and features a frisky dustup between Maggie Siff and Andy Grotelueschen as the pecking lovebirds Kate and Petruchio.

title: ABC Has Couric, but NBC Gets a Ratings Win
description: 10:30 p.m. | Updated On the first of five days of an epic morning television duel, the normally top-rated Today show on NBC stayed on top.

title: Happiness May Be Here, but Desperation Is Often Close
description: Existential musings waft up from guitar figures in the songs of Ben Howard, the English musician who performed at the Bowery Ballroom on Monday night. Hes an avowed descendant of a late-1960s school of (mostly) British musicians whose songs were inseparable from their guitar textures: tolling drones and intricate fingerpicking, syncopated strumming and skeins of countermelody, damped or snapped strings, tight little trills and the high ping of plucked harmonics.

title: James Murdoch Steps Down
description: April 3, 2012 - James Murdoch steps down as chairman of the British satellite broadcaster BSkyB, which is partly owned by the Murdoch family.

title: RIM Software Opens Up to Competing Devices
description: Research In Motion, the struggling BlackBerry maker, on Tuesday released an expanded version of its server software that supports not only its own phones but also those made by its competitors.

title: Staying Connected, One Shoe at a Time
description: Platform shoe enthusiasts can rejoice at the latest Jeffrey Campbell collaboration. Black Milk Clothing, the three-year-old brand known for colorful, and sometimes outrageous, printed leggings, has teamed up with Jeffrey Campbell to design a shoe line sold exclusively on Solestruck.com. For some, this three-way marriage is overdue.

title: Relish: An M.V.P. Now Sidelined
description: IN the world of condiments, as in major league baseball, there are heavy favorites and underdogs. Ketchup and mustard are the division leaders, of course. But my allegiance is to pickle relish. Not commonly used by chefs and often relegated to the bottom shelf in supermarkets, relish is like a small-market team that is overlooked and always out of contention  say, the Pittsburgh Pirates of condiments.

title: Pictures of the Day: Wisconsin and Elsewhere

title: Assads Forces Record Brutal Crackdown as They Carry It Out
description: Syrian activists working to show what the government crackdown on dissent looks like in graphic detail have found a rich, if unexpected, source of material: video clips apparently shot as souvenirs by members of President Bashar al-Assads security forces.

description: Now that Miami City Ballet has chosen its new artistic director, it seems hard to imagine someone with a better rsum for the job.

description: Willis Earl Beal  part soul singer, part outsider-art curiosity  is not about deception or deliberate sleights of behavior, but the constructedness of Mr. Beals world, whether by design or happenstance, is extremely tough to ignore. For now when you watch Mr. Beal, as you could have on Sunday night at Mercury Lounge, you are watching a back story as much as a performance, especially because the back story is so much louder.

Things werent coming together for him professionally and so Mr. Walton, a Boston native, began plotting a move to New York for a career change to banking. When NBC ordered a pilot called Heist, he landed a role playing a thief, and the show made it to the airwaves.

So Dee Pelletiers frightening monologue as Brenda Goodsen in The Soap Myth, now at the Black Box Theater at the Harold and Miriam Steinberg Center, was a revelation. Thats the sort of thing these people say?

title: Impact of Iran Sanctions Widens

description: To nonaficionados, Japanese comic books, or manga, typically celebrate vampire-hunting beauties or feisty schoolgirls, tentacled monsters or technology-crazed teenagers. But to the graphic artist Yoshihiro Tatsumi and his peers in the late 1950s, they offered an opportunity to explore darker, more sophisticated stories about postwar Japan  stories so adult that they required a brand-new name: gekiga.

title: Fondue the South American Way
description: They like their cheese warm and gooey in Uruguay, Argentina and Chile, and to get it that way at home, they have a ceramic plate with small cuplike depressions. Pop a square of good melting cheese  provolone is the choice in South America  into each hollow; put the dish in the oven, on a gas burner or even on a grill; and in minutes you have little blobs of molten cheese ready for toothpicks. You can doll up the cheese by wrapping each piece in a strip of prosciutto, bacon or salami, or use the plate to sear seafood  say, scallops topped with pesto or tomato. The plate is also perfect for escargots. Though it can go into a microwave oven, it wont fit every model.

title: Syrup With a New York Accent
description: Robb and Lydia Turner, who own Crown Maple Farm in Dutchess County, N.Y., bought the 800-acre property in Dover Plains five years ago as a country retreat, then discovered that they also owned a forest of sugar maple trees. They have hired Nathan Wooden, a wine consultant who has worked at Per Se, as a syrup sommelier who oversees separation of the syrup into three styles: light amber, which is mild-tasting with a brown butter finish; medium amber, an earthier, spicier syrup hinting of roasted nuts and autumn leaves; and dark amber, which is rich and sweet and suggests chocolate and molasses  excellent for cooking and sauce-making.

Well, Id like to see Paul Weller or Jimmy Jam put that to the test.

title: In Indianapolis, Pickup Games With the Stars Were Worth the Wait

When he was 13, McGinnis crammed into the cozy Douglass Park Family Center gym on the citys east side, where 50 or more players jockeyed for playing time, watched the games from a stage on one side of the gym and cooled off in the doorway.

description: Madonna is No. 1 again.

title: Elizabeth Catlett, Sculptor With Eye on Social Issues, Is Dead at 96

description: WAUKESHA, Wis.  To hear Mitt Romney and his team tell it, Mr. Romney will undoubtedly be the Republican Partys presidential nominee.

title: Jurors Doubts Outweighed Their Empathy
description: The day began as a first step into the marvelous: a 25-year-old woman, who had moved to New York to become a teacher, was leaving home early on an August morning to get her classroom ready for the second-graders she would be teaching when school started. She had been hired just that week, after a long hunt for a job. And her principal, it turned out, lived nearby in the same quiet neighborhood of Upper Manhattan, and had offered the new teacher a ride to work. A few minutes after 6 a.m., the rookie was waiting.

title: Officials Seek Origin of Threat in Al Qaedas Name
description: A picture on the Internet with 3-D imagery, sophisticated graphics and the glare of a Hollywood movie promotion has caught the eye of the New York Police Departments counterterrorism analysts: it shows a jumbled composite of city landmarks along with the words, Al Qaeda Coming Soon Again in New York.
