description: WASHINGTON  The Financial Stability Oversight Council, the countrys top financial regulatory body, moved closer on Tuesday to increasing its oversight of nonbank financial institutions, like hedge funds, private equity firms and insurers.

title: Looking Ahead, Republicans Examine Options in Health Care Fight

title: Seeking U.S. Loans for Plant, Fisker Scrambles to Restore Credibility
description: DETROIT  Fisker Automotives huge assembly plant in Delaware stands vacant, waiting for the money, equipment and workers to make a new plug-in hybrid electric car backed by loans from the federal government.

title: Calling Radicalism by Its Name

He accused his opponents of imposing on the country a radical vision that is antithetical to our entire history as a land of opportunity.

title: Agency Trip to Las Vegas Is the Talk of Washington
description: WASHINGTON  When a vast but little-known government agency spent $822,000 in taxpayer money to fly 300 bureaucrats to a luxurious spa and casino outside Las Vegas for a conference in October 2010, its leaders had a goal: to make it over the top, according to a government report that has set Washington abuzz.

title: McIlroy Takes a Trip Down Misery Lane
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Rory McIlroy was talking Tuesday about how hard it was for him to remember his final round at last years Masters  the bad drive on No. 10, the three-putt on No. 11 and the four-putt on No. 12 that plunged him from the top of the leader board like a bird shot in flight  because the whole day was such a blur.

title: An Insufficient Firewall
description: European credit markets have appeared calm in recent weeks, but none of the underlying issues of the debt crisis have been adequately addressed. Spanish interest rates have again begun creeping up, and a new wave of anxiety could burst forth any time.

title: Liquor-License Fight Moves From Park Ave. to Albany
description: A bill quietly surfaced in Albany last week that would overrule regulators and grant a liquor license to an unnamed establishment on Park Avenue.

title: The Pink Menace
description: Rick Perry  remember him?  was more inspired as a defender of the beef processing industry than he was as a debater. Last week, Perry  along with Iowas governor-for-life Terry Branstad and Gov. Sam Brownback of Kansas  implored the media to end its smear campaign against pink slime, the ammonia-treated burger extender hed rather have us call by the name used by its producers: Lean Finely Textured Beef.

description: The battle between Greece and the vulture investors is about to begin.

description: For more than a year, Roxane West spared few efforts while searching for hundreds of oil paintings by her aunt that were stolen from a building in TriBeCa.

title: Sex Trafficking and the First Amendment
description: For months now, the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops and its allies in the contraception and abortion wars have complained that the Obama administration showed anti-Catholic bias when it declined to renew the conferences contract to aid victims of human trafficking. In fact, the contract was not renewed because the bishops group was unwilling to meet the needs of trafficking victims, many of whom have been sexually abused or forced into prostitution.

title: Group Aims to Counter Influence of Teachers Union in New York
description: Leaders of a national education reform movement, including Joel I. Klein and Michelle Rhee, the former schools chancellors in New York and Washington, have formed a statewide political group in New York with an eye toward being a counterweight to the powerful teachers union in the 2013 mayoral election.

title: They Want to Work
description: It has been more than six months since the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ruled that Redondo Beach, Calif., violated the Constitution with an ordinance making it illegal for day laborers to solicit work from the sidewalk. The city had used the ordinance to crack down on immigrant laborers in 2004, sending police officers posing as employers to pick up workers and take them to jail. The court rightly rejected the citys argument that the law was a narrowly tailored attempt to enhance public safety by keeping men and cars from disrupting traffic. The ordinance restricts significantly more speech than is necessary, the judges wrote.

title: Long Before He Was a Yankee, Swisher Grew Up in the Mets Camp
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Nick Swisher walked briskly through the visitors dugout until he saw Tommy Bowes, the longtime head groundskeeper. Swisher stopped, threw his arms around Bowes and gave him a hug. The men smiled and laughed as they reminisced about a long-ago time, then Bowes turned to a bystander and said: Nick grew up here. He was a great kid.

title: M.T.A. Chief Rules Out Subway Line to New Jersey

Eight other specialty boards are preparing to follow suit with additional lists of procedures their members should perform far less often.

That peculiarly modern question motivated a new study from Finland in which a group of healthy, physically active volunteers donned special shorts that measure muscular activity in the legs. In a New Age of Air Travel, Preferring the Old
description: BERLIN  More than 20 years in the making, Berlins new airport is set to open on June 3. With its 70-acre steel, glass and granite terminal, Berlin Brandenburg Airport will bring the citys passengers into the world of 21st-century air travel. And that, for many, is precisely the problem  they prefer the 20th century.

title: Film Inspired by Abortion Survivor Is Quiet Hit
description: As mass entertainment goes, the abortion debate does not typically count as good Saturday-night date movie fare; the subject rarely makes it to the mainstream multiplex. But at a time when the issue is once again causing agitation in political circles, a small film, October Baby, about a woman who learns she is, as the movie puts it, a survivor of a failed abortion, is making a dent at theaters across the country.

title: Russia: Colonel Is Charged With Spying, Accused of Selling Map to U.S. Agent
description: Russia charged a reserve colonel with espionage on Tuesday for selling what officials said were classified topographical maps to the Pentagon. The officer, Vladimir Lazar, purchased a disk with over 7,000 topographical images of Russian territory from a collector he met on the Internet in 2008, smuggled it into neighboring Belarus and gave it to a Russian citizen working for the United States, the prosecutor generals office said in a statement. An investigation found that the materials could be used for planning military operations, including missile strikes, the statement said. Officials did not disclose when Mr. Lazar was arrested or give his current whereabouts.

title: Venezuela: Airline Banned by Europe
description: Venezuelas state-run airline, Conviasa, has been banned from flying to countries in the European Union because of safety concerns, European transportation regulators said Tuesday. The airlines only European destination was Madrid. Most of its flights are within Venezuela but it also flies to Bogot, Colombia; Buenos Aires; and several Caribbean islands. A report by the European Commission said that the Spanish authorities found numerous serious safety deficiencies during inspections of Conviasa planes. The report also cited two fatal accidents involving Conviasa flights, including one in 2010 that, according to news reports, killed 17 people. It said that Conviasa failed to show it had taken adequate steps to prevent future accidents. The Venezuelan Foreign Ministry rejected the action as disproportionate.

title: Seeing a Future in Tablets, Magazines Unveil the Digital Newsstand
description: Readers have quickly taken to downloading magazines on their tablets. Now publishers are betting that readers will consume even more for an all-you-can-eat price.

description: Irans foreign minister raised new doubts on Wednesday about the resumption of international talks over its disputed nuclear program, saying the location may not be Turkey  as previously agreed  and suggested Iraq and China as possible alternate hosts.

At the same time theres more to Katniss fever than page-screen synergy. Manohla Dargis and A. O. They made frontier faux pas, of course, like misidentifying cowboys as cow-servants. Paul Kasmins photo book Claude and Franois-Xavier Lalanne (Skira Rizzoli, $60) catalogs not only the couples whimsical bronze sculptures but also the sublimely rusticated farmhouse outside of Paris where their creations come to life. Hal Rubensteins The Gentry Man (Harper Design, $20) rediscovers a 1950s mens magazine, which in its brief life excerpted Lao-Tze, championed Paul Klee and taught men how to build their own Finnish baths.

title: More on the Mandate
description: My Sunday column made one point that Id like to slightly amend. Discussing the individual mandate, I wrote: The provision is unpopular enough that its unlikely to survive in the long run even if Anthony Kennedy flips a coin and decides to uphold it. In reality, it depends on what you mean by survive. If Mitt Romney wins the presidency, the mandate will probably be repealed outright. If Barack Obama is re-elected, on the other hand, I would expect it to endure at least for a time, but as a poorly enforced, widely flouted, easily exploited, and generally derided aspect of American law. As it stands, the mandatealready depends on a norm of law-abidingnessto make its provisions work, because the penalty is small enough that people could actually save money over the long haul by paying the fine until they get sick and then taking advantage of guaranteed issue to buy insurance. Over time, I doubt that norm will hold (what worked in Massachusetts, a liberal state with a small uninsured population, is not necessarily going to work in a nation of 300 millions), and I doubt the penalty will ever be raised. So even if the mandate technically survives, the combination of non-enforcement, non-compliance and inflation will gradually make it all-but-meaningless as policy.

title: Leading Off: Swatting Away All Comers

But E:Bar also stocks also peaty Islay Scotches including Lagavulin, Bowmore and Ardbeg; the smooth, triple-distilled Lowlands whiskey Auchentoshan; and two briny specimens from high up in the Orkney Islands, Highland Park and Scapa.

title: Family Businesses Learn to Adapt to Keep Thriving
description: For family-owned businesses, the statistics are daunting. According to the Family Business Institute, only about 30 percent survive beyond the founders generation, and just 12 percent make it to a third.

title: Jaws Will Drop
description: This summer, the seaside has a new version of the little black dress: swimwear by the French label Thapelo Paris. The 33-year-old Australian designer behind the line, Wil Ariyamethe, creates glamorous suits with throwback appeal like sleek but not skimpy bikinis, a Marilyn Monroe-inspired number (above; $400 at nancymeyer.com) and a one-piece that recalls Grace Kelly in High Society. Ariyamethe says she takes cues from vintage European swimsuits from the 50s, 60s and 70s, adding that a woman doesnt need to show everything to have sex appeal. Old World charm and elegance is sexy.

description: The relationship between center Andrew Bynum and the Lakers appears to be heading into murky waters.

title: Obama Signs Bill Banning Insider Trading by Federal Lawmakers
description: President Obama on Wednesday signed an ethics bill that bans insider trading by members of Congress and requires thousands of federal employees to disclose information about their personal finances.

title: Scientists Link Gene Mutation to Autism Risk
description: Teams of scientists working independently have for the first time identified several gene mutations that they agree sharply increase the chances that a child will develop autism. They have found further evidence that the risk increases with the age of the parents, particularly in fathers over age 35.

title: Few Answers in Death of Scholar From France
description: About 7:30 a.m. on Tuesday, a bus carrying an erudite group of passengers departed a Midtown hotel bound for Columbia University. Aboard were university presidents from institutions as far away as Bangkok and Qatar. They had convened in Manhattan for a conference focusing on the global surge in the population of young people.

title: Who Knew? Upcycling the Dog Poo
description: Its been almost three years since a grand experiment began in Ithaca, N.Y., and the results are finally in. Yet theres not much to show for it  and thats what everyone was hoping for.

description: Slap Shot will feature reports from the campuses of colleges and universities playing in the N.C.A.A. Frozen Four tournament this week.

title: A Private Jet With Space for Both the Rolls-Royces
description: SEATTLE  In early March, Boeings biggest jet, the 747-8 Intercontinental, took off from Paine Field near here, its gleaming white livery shrouded in secrecy.

title: Resolving a Problem Like a Boss
description: Wow, I really didnt expect such a big reaction to my last post, about falling on my sword to keep a customer happy. I was glad to read that many of you were convinced I did the right thing. In response to those who wondered, we havent picked up the scratched table yet. My shipping manager, Ben Payne, is arranging that now, and we anticipate going out to get it in two weeks. Well respray it as soon as it arrives, let it sit for another week to cure, and then reship so that it can be installed for a May 12 board meeting.

title: Editor Leaving Virginia Quarterly Review
description: Ted Genoways, the editor of the Virginia Quarterly Review whose tenure was both award-winning and tumultuous, will leave the literary magazine at the end of May. Calling him an outstanding editor, Thomas C. Skalak, the vice president for research at the University of Virginia, announced Mr. Genoways resignation in a statement on Wednesday. Under his direction, VQR built a devoted following and an unparalleled record of recognition.

title: Ackmans Influence on Burger Kings Future
description: Buyout shops have developed a reputation for taking companies private and then quickly selling them to the public again. But a hedge fund manager is behind the fast flip of Burger King.

description: Id always heard that true character is revealed on the golf course. I just didnt know it could be revealed in my living room.

title: Club Chairman Notes Deaths in Golf Family
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Part of the allure of the Masters is its rich sense of history. At the beginning of his sometimes awkward, sometimes defensive news conference Wednesday, which included repeated questionsabout when his club would admit a woman, the chairman of Augusta National Golf Club, Billy Payne, took a moment to acknowledge three significant losses in the golf community.

title: Look of The Moment | Kerry Washington
description: The Look:  Punchy. A twirly skirt and white hot pumps perk up a simple, T-shirt take on the little black dress.

title: Payoff for Efficient Cars Takes Years
description: DETROIT  Ed Morans new Toyota Prius was programmed by the dealer to make him feel good about his gas savings. A dashboard display compares the fuel consumption of the Prius and his 2001 Ford pickup truck.

title: Israel Doesnt Let Eviction Slow Push for Settlements
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli police and border officers swiftly evicted a group of Jewish settlers from a contested house in the volatile West Bank city of Hebron on Wednesday on the orders of the minister of defense, officials said. At the same time, however, the Israeli government signaled strong support for more Jewish settlement in areas captured in the 1967 war.

title: When the Truth is Not Enough
description: A health care legacy that bears striking resemblance to the one Obama is currently defending to the Supreme Court. Views on explosive issues like gay marriage and abortion that are opaque at best. The Etch a Sketch remark. There are still so many legitimate ways that Rick Santorum can attack Mitt Romney. Why would he bother lying?

title: Ai Weiweis Self-Surveillance is Shut Down
description: Ai Weiwei, the rebellious Chinese artist, said on Wednesday that the authorities had shut down a Web site on which he was streaming video from four live surveillance cameras in his home. Mr. Ai, one of the Chinese governments harshest critics, was detained without charge for 81 days last year; he started his camera-surveillance project earlier this week to commemorate the one-year anniversary of the start of his detention. Putting up the cameras was Mr. Ais way of commenting on the fact that he has been under constant surveillance since he was released from detention. Mr. Ai is not allowed to leave Beijing, and plainclothes security officers are stationed on his street around the clock. A security camera is trained on the main entrance of his studio and home in the Caochangdi district of Beijing. On Wednesday, Mr. Ai said over Twitter that his web camera project had been operating for 46 hours before being shut down. Byebye to all the voyeurs, Mr. Ai wrote in English on Twitter four hours after the camera Web site, weiweicam.com, ended operations.

title: Junta Leader in Mali Tries to Shift Focus From Coup
description: The leader of a military junta in Mali denied that its coup had provided an opening for a rapid separatist takeover of a large section of the countrys rebellious north, warning in an interview published on Wednesday that if Islamists succeed in taking over in those areas, then the whole world will be a victim one day.

title: SRT Viper: An Ancient Serpent, Reskinned

title: No Need to Shout. Some Products Whisper Wealth.
description: THERES an easy way to make things expensive: slap some diamonds on them or slather them with platinum. But such items often betray the owner to be gauche, an arriviste or, to use a term more suited to our technophilic times, a newbie. Better to announce your Croesus-like wealth quietly. A low-key camera with an ultra-lightweight body. A bespoke briefcase. A pair of headphones not from a multi-acre plant in Shenzhen, but from a Brooklyn workshop.

title: HBO Sets Debut Dates for The Newsroom and True Blood
description: What do television newscasters and vampires have in common? Well find out in June  leaving you plenty of time to write your own punch line about predatory bloodsuckers  when HBO pairs up its hit supernatural series True Blood with The Newsroom, a new show from Aaron Sorkin.

title: Santorum Shrugs Off Criticism That His Campaign Is Irrelevant
description: CARNEGIE, Pa.  Rick Santorum reacted with equanimity Wednesday to Senator John McCains criticism that his presidential campaign has become irrelevant.

description: Did the Broadway producers of The Gershwins Porgy and Bess want the musicals book  which was the subject of a rare public debate last year about adaptation  to be eligible for a Tony Award for best book of a musical this spring?

title: I Buy, Therefore I Am (Unless I Return It)
description: IF you had $1,000 to splurge, would you buy French doors for the living room or a weekend vacation in France?

title: Leaving Etiquette Behind
description: IMAGINE a college campus where students dont stare at their smartphones. Tweets are what birds do. Vulgarity is considered blasphemous. And the cures for depression arent pills or therapy but old-fashioned bars of soap and tap-dancing.

description: Young actors flock to screening of Whit Stillmans loopy romantic comedy of manners.

title: Answers About Bobby and Rosie, Part 1
description: Bobby and Rosie, the red-tailed hawks of Washington Square Park, are incubating two eggs on a 12th-floor window ledge of New York Universitys Bobst Library. As we wait hopefully for the eggs to hatch, the executive director of New York City Audubon, Glenn Phillips, responds to readers questions about what to expect while hawks are expecting.

title: Republican Candidates Coming to Town
description: ALBANY  The Republican presidential campaign is coming to New York.

title: Nutty Professor Musical Will Have Its Premiere in Nashville
description: Can you make an Alaskan Polar Bear Heater in Tennessee? A musical version of The Nutty Professor, the Jerry Lewis comedy that introduced that stiff alcoholic concoction  along with the Jekyll-and-Hyde-like characters of Julius Kelp and Buddy Love  will have its world premiere in Nashville before a planned Broadway run later this year, the Tennessee Performing Arts Center said on Wednesday.

title: When Setting a Budget Can Backfire
description: Getting ready to buy a new computer, a mattress or big-screen television? New research suggests that heading out to shop with a target price in mind could actually cause you to spend more than you might have if you hadnt zeroed in on a price in the first place.

title: Rich Like Me
description: Kevin Roose Spends a Day Like a Billionaire

title: Finding Literary Inspiration in Porcelain Cats
description: For seven years, Rob Walker, a contributing writer to the magazine, wrote a column called Consumed, in which he explored the cultural, social, economic and or merely bizarre significance of consumable objects. You might think that Rob would be tired of thinking about things, having written about hundreds of objects as diverse as Victorias Secrets Pink brand, Rick Warrens The Purpose-Driven Life and carrots packaged like junk food. But he is not. He is just exploring them in new ways. His latest project, a book called Significant Objects, comes out in June. It is a collection of tiny stories inspired by junk-store purchases. Rob and his co-curator, Joshua Glenn, enlisted writers like Neil LaBute, Colson Whitehead and Lydia Millet to take as their literary inspiration such finds as a rabbit candle, a scratched wooden mallet and what appears to be a porcelain cat with little chilies coming out of its whiskers.

title: Uranium,  Grazing Cattle and Risks Unknown
description: As I reported last weekend in The Times, a cattle rancher stumbled upon an abandoned uranium mine in the summer of 2010 on his grazing land, about 60 miles east of the Grand Canyon on the Navajo reservation, and notified federal officials. They came in with Geiger counters and found levels of radioactivity that were alarmingly high.

title: Now Serving | Spring at Le Bal Caf
description: This is a confusing time of year at the greenmarkets in New York. While the sunny afternoons have the feel of early summer, the farmland in the Northeast is only just easing into spring: you might crave asparagus and shell peas, but all youll find at the markets in Union Square or Grand Army Plaza are root vegetables left over from the fall and the seasons first lettuces.

title: Stage Scenes: Linda Lavin
description: Photos of some of the actresss recent stage performances.

title: SAP and the Data Analytics Speed Race
description: SAP, the staid German software giant, turned 40 this week. But Hasso Plattner, the 68-year-old co-founder, talked about the present and the future in an interview.

title: Melanie Oudin Tries to Get Her Game Back
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  In the time since Melanie Oudins fairy-tale run at the 2009 United States Open, her career has been without a happily ever after.

title: Family Investment Funds Go Hunting for Wall St. Expertise
description: Family offices have quietly handled the financial affairs of the nations wealthiest households for generations, privately playing the role of money manager and life planner to the likes of the Rockefellers and the Mellons.

title: Arthur Tress: San Francisco 1964
description: A look at some of the works on view at the de Young Museum in San Francisco.

title: Lost, Now Found: Visions of 1964
description: IN the 1970s and 80s Arthur Tress became well known for his strikingly surreal photographs. He staged odd situations  a man opening the trunk of his car and finding sleeping children; another man, naked, with his head in a bucket and a boot on his back  and caught them provocatively in the frame.

title: Marimow to Return as Editor of Philadelphia Inquirer
description: William K. Marimow, who served as the top editor at The Philadelphia Inquirer from 2006-10, will rejoin the paper in the same role, the company said on Wednesday.

title: After a Rollicking Primary, a Different Kind of Fight in November
description: WASHINGTON  If anything is stable in this presidential race, it is the idea that 2012 is a volatile campaign year.

title: Indias Leaders Dispute Report of Rift With Military
description: NEW DELHI  Indias top leaders on Wednesday denied a rift between the countrys civilian government and its military brass after an article in a leading national newspaper described a tense episode in January in which civilian leaders became deeply unnerved when two army units advanced on the capital in an unannounced nighttime drill.

title: Pros Perspective: Wednesday Nerves and Thursday Intrigue
description: Mark Calcavecchia won 13 PGA Tour titles, including the 1989 British Open. He almost won the 1988 Masters, but settled for a runner-up finish when Sandy Lyle birdied the 18th hole from a fairway bunker. Calcavecchia, in his third season on the Champions Tour, will provide a daily analysis during the Masters for On Par.

title: Do Patients Want More Care or Less?
description: The womans wheeze was a head-turner, audible from across the emergency department. Along with a hacking cough, the musical, whistling sound prompted her to leave the children asleep with her sister one night and seek relief at the E.R.

title: Gnter Grass Poem Attacking Israel for Threatening Iran Is Condemned in Germany
description: Updated | 4:34 p.m. A new poem by the German Nobel laureate Gnter Grass depicting Israels undeclared nuclear might as a threat to world peace drew wide condemnation from Jewish groups and commentators in Germany on Wednesday, showing the strength of enduring taboos in German public discourse about Israel more than six decades after the Holocaust.

title: Councilman Cleared of Charges in Arrest Near Zuccotti Park
description: A judge on Wednesday dismissed charges against City Councilman Ydanis Rodriguez, who was arrested on Nov. 15 near Zuccotti Park, where the police were clearing the Occupy Wall Street encampment.

title: When Is a Peep Not a Peep?
description: For this weeks Look, the photographer Nikolas Koenig went to the Just Born factory in Bethlehem, Pa., to document how Peeps are made. While there, he photographed barrels of discarded Peeps around the factory. They may be inanimate pieces of marshmallow substance but theres something poignant about these rejected, misfit Peeps.

title: Living Like a Billionaire, if Only for a Day
description: I HAVE a major problem: I just glanced at my $45,000 Chopard watch, and its telling me that my Rolls-Royce may not make it to the airport in time for my private jet flight.

title: BMW Brings Geneva Pony Show to Javits
description: BMW is championing an electric future, but its living in a thirsty present.

title: Red Sox Rivalry Will Make Its Way Into Rejiggered Damn Yankees in Maine
description: When the slugger Joe Hardy steps to the plate this summer in Ogunquit, Maine, hell be wearing a Boston Red Sox uniform instead of his usual Washington Senators garb. In Damn Yankees, one of five shows in the Ogunquit Playhouses 80th-anniversary summer season, the Sox will replace the now-defunct Senators in the 1955 musical about a rabid fan who sells his soul to the devil to become a star hitter who can help his beloved team beat the Yankees.

title: Fire at Macys Prompts Evacuation
description: A smoky fire in the subbasement of Macys flagship store in Herald Square forced an evacuation on Wednesday afternoon, fire and store officials said. The fire broke out around 3:20 p.m. and was still being fought as of 4:25 p.m., though the main body of the fire had been put out, the Fire Department said. No injuries were reported. About 80 firefighters were dispatched to the scene.

description: On Tuesday  the day that the Today show was most worried about losing in the ratings to Good Morning America  Today prevailed.

description: Colors like muddied orange, toxic green and shrieking mauve, rare in the marketplace six months ago, are crowding the shelves.

title: The Cost of Higher Fuel Economy
description: Electric cars, hybrids and high-mileage versions of some vehicles are more efficient but also more expensive than similar offerings from the same brand. Even given high gas prices, it may take years to earn back the additional cost.

description: When she was 18, Ophira Eisenberg drunkenly cheated on her boyfriend with a guy she barely knew. This led to panic, lies, confrontation and, inevitably, a breakup.

title: For Some, Bruised Cuts to the Quick
description: IN a world where nails have gone wild, some still maintain that a manicure is just that: a grooming of the hands and nails. In my opinion, a manicure is really to take care of your nails and cuticles, said Elizabeth Lata, the owner of Elizabeth Lata European Day Spa, an Upper East Side stalwart for more than two decades. It could be buffed and shiny and with white pencil, and that looks absolutely fabulous.

title: U.S. Sees Iran in Bids to Stir Unrest in Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON  Just hours after it was revealed that American soldiers had burned Korans seized at an Afghan detention center in late February, Iran secretly ordered its agents operating inside Afghanistan to exploit the anticipated public outrage by trying to instigate violent protests in the capital, Kabul, and across the western part of the country, according to American officials.

title: Homeless in Nashville: Survival Tips
description: The ramshackle lodgings, the scavenged blankets, the angry confrontations: Tent City U.S.A., a documentary being shown Thursday night on the Oprah Winfrey Network, brings to mind some of the typical images of Occupy Wall Street. Unlike most of the occupiers of Zuccotti Park, however, the residents of Tent City dont have anywhere else to go.

title: Beauty Bar
description: WHEN Beauty Bar, the kitschy salon-themed chain, first ventured into Brooklyn in 2009, it landed on a gnarly patch of Bushwick. Gentrification didnt catch up, and it closed. Since then, outposts have opened in places like Chicago and Denver. Last month, like a young adult trading loft parties for PTA meetings, it returned to Brooklyn, this time to staid Park Slope.

description: Shown on Wednesday, April 4: Mazda Takeri concept.

title: Serbian President Resigns to Force Early Election
description: Apparently gambling that he can translate his personal popularity into a fresh mandate for his party, President Boris Tadic of Serbia resigned on Wednesday to hasten an early election. His term was to have ended in 2013.

title: 5 Ex-Officers Sentenced in Post-Katrina Shootings
description: NEW ORLEANS  Five former police officers were sentenced to prison on Wednesday for the shooting of six unarmed civilians, two of whom died, in the days after Hurricane Katrina and for orchestrating a wide-ranging cover-up afterward.

title: Madonna and Lionel Richie Top the Charts
description: This week on the pop charts, new albums by Madonna and Lionel Richie are hits, and a newfangled chart rule keeps Justin Biebers new single from reaching No. 1.

title: Will Sprints Network Catch Up With Its 4G LTE Phone?
description: The newest phone from HTC on the Sprint network will have the words 4G LTE in its name  even though Sprint hasnt finished building a network that uses 4G LTE technology. This underscores a problem for Sprint: If it doesnt build out that network in a hurry, it risks falling behind AT&T and Verizon.

title: The Make-Your-Own Schoolhouse
description: ON a recent Monday night, a gaggle of 20-somethings crammed into a former Curves fitness center along the industrial edge of Carroll Gardens in Brooklyn. The storefront gym had been carved into two classrooms.

title: The Exodus From Paducah, 1862
description: Jonathan D. Sarnas provocative new book, When General Grant Expelled the Jews, is exactly what it sounds like: an account of how Gen. Ulysses S. Grant issued an order to expel Jews from their homes in the midst of the Civil War. Anyone seeking to rock the Passover Seder with political debate will find the perfect conversation piece in Mr. Sarnas account of this startling American story.

description: When it began in 1999 The West Wing was an anomaly, a series that romanticized the presidency at a time when voter cynicism and distrust were at a high point.

title: Passions Alight in Sacred Season
description: It was a remarkable run of four Bach Passions in New York this week and last, with the St. John overshadowing the St. Matthew, for a change, and with each performance outshining the others in at least some small way.

title: A Strong Return for Adventure Time on Cartoon Network
description: The Season 4 premiere of Adventure Time  an animated program on Cartoon Network depicting the fantastical shenanigans of a 14-year-old boy named Finn and his talking dog, Jake  proved to be a draw for children and adults alike on Monday night. The show was the No. 1 telecast on broadcast or cable for children ages 2-14 and finished with a total of 2.6 million viewers, according to Nielsen data.

title: Discovery to Remake Planet Green Channel
description: Discovery Communications is remaking Planet Green, an underperforming cable channel that has been home to environmental programming for the past four years, into Destination America, a channel that will try to appeal to the heartland.

title: Mets Set to Extend Nieses Contract
description: The Mets made their most significant financial commitment to a player in two years Wednesday by agreeing to five-year, $25.5 million contract extension with the left-hander Jon Niese, according to a person in baseball with knowledge of the deal.

description: OPENINGS

title: Instead of a Parking Lot
description: Dutch Kills Green is not a headline about a crackdown on cannabis-friendly Amsterdam coffee shops. Its the name of a newly opened 1.5-acre swath of open space at Queens Plaza.

title: 100 Years Later, the Titanic Resurfaces, Repeatedly
description: When the Titanic set sail in 1912, the people aboard would have been surprised to hear that there was a 2-in-3 chance they were about to die. They might have been even more surprised to know that a century later the odds would be similarly high that they would stumble upon a Titanic 100th-anniversary special on something called a television.

title: A Sly Twist of Sleek Walnut
description: Instead of a straight shelf, we wanted some geometry, said Carol Egan, an interior and furniture designer in Manhattan, explaining how she came to create the single-twist shelf. The walnut piece is hand-carved, yet it looks sleek and modern. Its twist catches the eye.

title: Rain Shortens Annual Par 3 Tournament
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  The thunderstorms that ripped through the area late Tuesday night returned Wednesday afternoon, suspending the annual Masters Par 3 tournament with a slew of players yet to finish. After a short delay, Padraig Harrington and Jonathan Byrd were declared co-champions of the event with scores of five-under-par 22.

title: 2013 Nissan Altima: Milking Plain Vanilla for Profit
description: Introduced on Wednesday, April 4: 2013 Nissan Altima.

title: A Historic Country Manor With 95 Rooms
description: Kuksu Manor, in the countryside of Latvia, is on the market for $2.8 million. The home sits on 17 acres that include a reservoir and two other old buildings.

title: House Hunting in ... Latvia
description: A HISTORIC COUNTRY MANOR WITH 95 ROOMS

title: New York Fed May Sell More of Its A.I.G. Assets
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York said on Wednesday that it was considering selling pieces of a final special entity created to hold assets once owned by the American International Group. If it is carried out, the move would further unwind the insurers government bailout.

title: Testing Ones Metal
description: IN the Stone Age, Neolithic man prized gold for its luminous color and malleability. By the fifth millennium B.C., the Sumerians mined silver to create ornaments, jewelry and money. Later the ancient Egyptians wore copper jewelry as a status symbol and to ward off evil spirits.

title: Market Ready
description: Q. We have window guards for child safety, but they interrupt the view. Should we remove them before listing our apartment?

description: Scenes from the Broadway musical at the Foxwoods Theater.
