description: About.me, an online profile Web service of AOL that enables people to create public profiles of themselves, announced the release of its first mobile applicationonThursday.

title: Who (Else) Wants to Be a Billionaire?
description: To answer some of the most-asked questions Ive received about my article on living like a billionaire for a day: yes, my editors are very cool for approving my pitch; no, I didnt bankrupt The Times when I filed my expenses; and yes, I did get to keep the suit. (I paid for it myself, because I needed a new one anyway. Now I just have to find other, less rarefied places to wear it.)

title: Pentagon Pushes Crowdsourced Manufacturing
description: Designing and building things for the United States military is a notoriously slow-moving and costly endeavor. The time from idea to manufacturing for a new armored personnel carrier or a tank is typically 10 to 20 years.

description: Yonkers, the fourth-largest city in New York State, could be the next municipality headed for a control board.

title: Administration Concedes Courts Review Power
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration stipulated the incontestable to a disgruntled federal court on Thursday, formally declaring that the power of the courts to review the constitutionality of legislation is beyond dispute.

title: And Now a Word From Charles Dickenss Sponsor
description: Globe-trotting admirers of Charles Dickens can celebrate this years bicentennial of his birth by brushing shoulders with chimney sweeps at a Dickens World theme park in England, taking in lectures and amateur theatricals at a scholarly Dickens camp in California, or attending any of the festivities being held from Bologna, Italy, to Colorado Springs.

title: In Time for the Playoffs, Red Wings Find Some Confidence
description: The Detroit Red Wings, who have been mired in a slump brought on by injuries to key players, may be showing some signs of life as the playoffs draw near. The Wings jumped over the Predators for fourth place in the Western Conference, thanks to a 3-2 win over the Central-leading Blues, to temporarily gain home-ice advantage for a looming first-round series against Nashville. The Predators and Wings both have two games left in the season.

title: Actor Is Said to Be Kicked Out of Co-op. He Says Otherwise.
description: It seemed a tragic if not-unpredictable turn of events: Adrian Grenier  TV star, rocker, filmmaker and part-time Brooklyn resident  had been kicked out of the Park Slope Food Co-op for running afoul of the places famously unforgiving work requirement, wherein a single missed shift requires two make-ups and things get exponentially more unpleasant from there.

title: A Mouse Problem Closes Little Owl

title: Cmon, Get Happy. Or Not.
description: SEEING Tracie Bennett in End of the Rainbow isnt the only way to encounter the spirit and legacy of Judy Garland in the New York region. Garland and her daughter Liza Minnelli have always been ripe for impersonation, and several performers continue that tradition. Judy Garland & Liza Minnelli Live at Mamas!, a long-running show on select weekends at the cabaret Dont Tell Mama, is a night of songs and banter featuring the performers Tommy Femia as Garland and Rick Skye as Ms. Minnelli. (212-757-0788, donttellmamanyc.com.) Phyl Craig plays Ms. Minnelli in Believe: Divas in a Mans World, a female impersonator show at Resorts Atlantic City (resortsac.com).

title: The Road Gets Rougher for Judyisms Faithful
description: LAST Saturday I invited my friend Brodie, a 30ish gay man like myself, to a preview performance of End of the Rainbow, Peter Quilters play about the final days of Judy Garland. In the course of that invitation, I asked him if he was a Judy fan, and he said, No, but she was good in The Wizard of Oz.

title: The Big Bang
description: Last fall, television stations carried a 60-second ad for Audis A6 car. The opening images showed a pitted, potholed American road while the voice-over gloomily intoned, Across the nation, over 100,000 miles of highways and bridges are in disrepair. Fear not, said the voice; Audis smart gizmos would help. The spots message was clear: Roads in the United States are now so bad, you need a foreign car to negotiate them.

title: Birons Milestone: 500 Games

Back on Dec. 26, 1995, he played his first N.H.L. game, across the street at the old Igloo. He was an 18-year-old rookie for the Buffalo Sabres then, called up from the Beauport Harfangs of the Quebec Major Junior Hockey League to face the great Mario Lemieux and the Penguins.

It was here 68 years ago, on a slope descending to the moonlit Hudson River, that Lucien Carr, 19, the Beat Generations charismatic, callow swami, buried a knife in the heart of David Kammerer, 33, his besotted, dauntless hometown stalker.

title: Hang Loose
description: My wonderful mother is in her mid-60s. Since retiring, she has tried to become healthier and lose weight. She has lost 30 pounds so far. But she still has 25 to go, and has hit a plateau. Plus, its hard to tell shes lost weight because she has a lot of excess skin around her chin and neck. I want to suggest a neck lift. I think if more people noticed her weight loss, she would be happier, and it would encourage her to work harder toward her goal. Is there any way to do this tactfully?

title: For Some Artworks, Life Begins at the Dustbin
description: From the department of unsolicited advice for aspiring artists: avoid dust, dirt, ashes, soot, smoke, sand, mud and lint, especially if you want to make a statement about life, death, history and the ephemerality of it all. The dangers are well illustrated by Swept Away: Dust, Ashes and Dirt in Contemporary Art and Design, at the Museum of Arts and Design.

description: The writer and director of Damsels in Distress discusses his film.

title: A New Traveling Show of Lichtenstein Works
description: The world has changed since the last traveling Roy Lichtenstein retrospective, which opened nearly 20 years ago at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York. Pop Art has not only continued to capture the imagination of the public, but it has also flourished, helped in part by social networking, global connectivity and a universal fascination with the media.

title: Finding Outfits That Sing
description: The singer and songwriter Carnie Wilson, 43, is part of the pop trio Wilson Phillips, which released a new album, Dedicated, last week and will have the first episode of its reality show, Wilson Phillips: Still Holding On, on the TV Guide Network this Sunday. Ms. Wilson, a Los Angeles native, is married to the producer and musician Rob Bonfiglio. BEE-SHYUAN CHANG

title: Russian Weapons Trafficker Avoids Getting Life in Prison
description: Viktor Bout, a Russian man known and feared for his leadership role in international weapons trafficking, was sentenced on Thursday to 25 years in prison, sparing him the life sentence that federal prosecutors in Manhattan had sought.

title: Taking Cues From Rodin, Who Took Some From Others
description: There is a longstanding tradition of artists reading other artists work against the grain: viewing or interpreting it in a way that was clearly not intended. A famous example is Auguste Rodin, the French sculptor, who was inspired by Michelangelos unfinished works, specifically sculptural fragments of torsos and limbs and the Slaves originally planned for the tomb of Pope Julius II. Working in the same era as the Impressionists, whose canvases were often criticized as looking like unfinished sketches, Rodin took the idea of figures still partly encased in stone and translated it into sculpture that looked distinctly modern.

title: Stalking the Most Elusive Prey in Tasmanias Wilds
description: The Hunter, filmed in Tasmania, has the faintly surreal look peculiar to Australian movies in which nature pulses with a mysterious, primordial shimmer. Adapted from Julia Leighs novel and directed by Daniel Nettheim from a screenplay by Alice Addison, the film tells the story of a lone hunter from another continent searching for a creature that may not exist in an old-growth forest largely untouched by humans.

title: At Spring Nationals, Right Play in Wrong Deal
description: There are some defensive deals in which many make what appear to be textbook plays, not realizing that they are erring.

title: Family of Iraqi Woman Killed in California Was in Crisis, Records Show
description: EL CAJON, Calif.  When Shaima Alawadi, an Iraqi-born mother of five, was found bludgeoned to death in her home last month with a threatening note beside her, many members of the large Middle Eastern immigrant population here feared a hate crime.

title: You Can Almost Hear Him Sigh
description: This year the joys of spring in New York include the visit of a large, magnificently plainspoken self-portrait by Rembrandt to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Never before exhibited in this country, it comes from the collection of Kenwood House in North London, which is closed for repairs; it will subsequently join other Kenwood paintings at the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, for an exhibition that will open in June and then travel to three other American museums.

title: Album Might Have a Presidential Tie
description: Ian Brabner, an Americana dealer in Delaware, is bringing an 1870s photo album that he says has a presidential connection to the New York Antiquarian Book Fair, opening Thursday at the Park Avenue Armory. Last year at a Maryland estate auction, Mr. Brabner said, he unwittingly bought images of maternal ancestors of Stanley Ann Dunham, President Obamas mother, in Kansas and Ohio.

title: Americas Sex-Trafficking Victims
description: I was born in an affluent suburb of Philadelphia, to two professors. Lisa, a woman my age from a poor neighborhood in Washington, was born to a rapist and an alcoholic. I was my parents first and only child. Lisa was one of 12. Im now working at The New York Times, while Lisa is recovering from brutal mistreatment at the hands of pimps and johns.

The arrival of American Reunion is no doubt partly intended to remedy this alarming cultural deficit and also to remind former teenagers of jokes that used to make them laugh.

The organizers were anticipating a better turnout than last years 7,000 visitors, but if the first day was any indication, the slogan stripped across the cover of the official show guide  Building is Back in Business!  may not tell the whole story.

title: Parting With the Parsonage
description: A GENERATION or so ago, a parsonage was the accepted way to provide members of the clergy with housing, typically in lieu of a higher salary. Particularly for younger pastors on Long Island, the parsonage was often nicer than what they could have otherwise afforded.
