description: To the Editor:

title: Illinois Representative Will Drop Re-election Bid
description: Representative Timothy V. Johnson of Illinois will not continue his re-election bid, despite winning the Republican Party nomination in a primary last month.

title: For the Dearest Departed, Nothing Is Too Good
description: HONG KONG  Hong Kong people like to shop  and they dont stint when it comes to shopping for their departed loved ones.

title: Matt Lauer to Stay With NBCs Today Show
description: NBC News has signed Matt Lauer to a new multiyear contract to remain as the co-host of the Today show, addressing one of the divisions most pressing issues.

title: Q & A
description: A False Impression at a Co-op Building

title: Apollo May Again Face an Unwanted Battle
description: Despite its best efforts, Apollo Global Management may find itself once again in a battle to acquire an amusement park company.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Cloud Competition, and Silicon Valley, the TV Show
description: Here are some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Thursday. There are more here.

title: Happy Meal Lawsuit Dismissed
description: The lawsuit brought by the Center for Science in the Public Interest and a California mother of two that sought to stop McDonalds from including toys in its Happy Meals has been dismissed by California judge Richard Kramer. No legal analysis was provided, but the lawsuit had been widely criticized as frivolous: more about rhetoric than legal issues. Is offering a toy with your junk food predatory marketing? For now, its up to the consumer to decide.

title: Locking In Peace of Mind
description: WITH mortgage rates inching higher, some borrowers might want to consider a lock-in agreement, which freezes the terms of a loan while it is being processed, potentially saving borrowers thousands of dollars over the life of the mortgage.

title: A Gangster Named Ulysses Goes Home and Homeric
description: The muscle and the molls are in the parlor, hunkered down and waiting for the cops. There are ghosts upstairs, rattling their chains. But Keyhole is not really a gangster picture nor a horror movie, though it traffics in some of the visual and verbal conventions of both genres: tough talk, murky shadows, darkened hallways. The simplest way to describe it is as a Guy Maddin film, which is really just a way of gesturing toward its puzzles and complications.

title: Karzai Orders Prosecutor and Tribunal in Scandal Over Kabul Banks Losses
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  With Afghanistans foreign backers set to meet next month in Chicago, President Hamid Karzai ordered the appointment of a special prosecutor and the creation of a special tribunal to try those involved in the near collapse of Kabul Bank, a scandal that laid bare the crony capitalism and corruption that has thrived here in the past decade.

title: Pakistani Lawmakers Criticize U.S. Reward for Militant Leader
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The Pakistani government and opposition on Thursday united in criticism of a newly announced $10 million American bounty for Hafiz Saeed, a militant leader accused of orchestrating the 2008 attacks in Mumbai, India, during a heated session of Parliament in which lawmakers demanded that Washington provide proof of Mr. Saeeds terrorist credentials.

title: When Human Advancement Backfires
description: No one carries a placard scrawled with The end is near in the nonfiction movie Surviving Progress, as people sometimes do in New Yorker cartoons. Its assembly of experts is far too smart and savvy, too heavily armed with facts, figures and the legacy of the Enlightenment to be dismissed as random kooks, well, except by their political and ideological critics. Even so, this 86-minute breeze through civilization, its history and self-made discontents from the Canadian filmmakers Mathieu Roy and Harold Crooks  which concentrates on the present and future costs of familiar environmental and economic catastrophes  is very much a doomsday documentary.

title: Answers About Bobby and Rosie, Part 2
description: As we wait hopefully for baby hawks in a nest overlooking Washington Square Park, the executive director of New York City Audubon, Glenn Phillips, responds to readers questions about behavioral clues that signal the eggs are hatching; the parenting instincts of raptors; and hawk attacks and territories in New York City.

title: Vice President Biden on CBS
description: In an interview, Vice President Joe Biden offers a variety of critiques of Mr. Romney.

title: Quandary Considered: Telling My Daughter About My Abusive Mother
description: Years ago, E. chose not to have any more contact with her verbally abusive mother. Now, as she described for last weeks quandary, her young daughter is approaching the age when shes bound to ask questions. How, E. asked, should I tell my child  at 3, and as she grows older  why she has two grandparents on her fathers side, while her mother has no parents to share at all?

title: Upstairs, Downstairs, Apartment-Style
description: HAVE you heard enough about the $55 million for-sale sign on Huguette Clarks apartments at 907 Fifth Avenue yet? Me, too. But this is about something different, about 907 itself, built in 1916 as a new kind of gentry housing, where the truly rich could feel truly comfortable under a common roof  even if the servants did not.

title: Devils Top Line Regains an Important Piece
description: NEWARK  After tearing his left Achilles tendon last summer, then having surgery, then returning for eight games only to be sore and weak, then sitting out more than two months while waiting for the injury to heal, Travis Zajac is finally the Devils top-line center again.

title: Healthier Eating Starts on the Roof
description: WHEN Yarittzi Estevez and her 8-year-old daughter, Aaliyah Rivers, planted collard greens, zucchini, lettuce and strawberries in their Brooklyn garden last year, they did not quite know what to expect. But one thing they never anticipated was competition from the native fauna.

title: Cant Drive, Cant Vote, but Can Publish a Book
description: To the Editor:

title: Interpreting Raised Hands
description: To the Editor:

title: Cholera Solutions for Haiti
description: To the Editor:

title: A Reluctant Pontiff Escapes to the Streets
description: Like the classic runaway bride, the skittish lead character in Nanni Morettis emotionally generous and moving tragicomedy We Have a Pope wears a sumptuous gown, has the aspect or at least symbolic air of the unsullied and suffers from severe commitment issues. Soon after the film opens, Mr. Morettis runaway, Melville (Michel Piccoli), a French cleric elected pope, dons ceremonial white, sits in the Vatican forcing smiles and rapidly sags under the weight of the billion souls hes charged with leading. Uneasy lies the head that wears the crown and so too the miter. What haunts Mr. Morettis character is whether he can embrace his role as pontiff.

title: A Change of Scene, One Town Over
description: AFTER living in New Canaan, Conn., for nearly two decades, Nicholas Zagoreos would have been happy to remain there. He and his former wife had raised two daughters in a two-story colonial-style house of about 2,300 square feet, with four bedrooms, three bathrooms and an in-ground swimming pool on an acre of land.

title: Microsoft Is Writing Checks to Fill Out Its App Store
description: Nowadays, cellphones are all about apps. And Microsoft is so determined to have lots of brand-name apps for its Windows Phone app store that it is willing to pay for them.

title: Sweating to an African Beat
description: MY love of West African dance far exceeds my capabilities as a practitioner. No matter. Fifteen years had passed since my last class, and I was ready for another try. So one recent afternoon I wrapped a piece of African cloth around my waist and entered a packed studio at the Alvin Ailey extension center in Manhattan.

title: Dekalb Market Kicks Off Season With Live Music
description: The urban dictionary gives several definitions for weekender, including a youth who works a boring weekday job just to pay for raves and drugs on the weekend; a busy significant other who is never around during the workweek; and, the Misers favorite, a person who enjoys life more than most.

title: On the Waterfront
description: LAST December something strange took place at the abandoned Fulton Fish Market on South Street: Fishermen came and sold fish.

title: Living In | Cos Cob, Conn.
description: Cos Cob, a snug enclave in Greenwich about 32 miles from Manhattan, seems a place in perpetual motion.

title: Strolling Through a Sailors Haven
description: COS COB, a snug enclave in Greenwich about 32 miles from Manhattan, seems a place in perpetual motion.

title: Sequel to Kony 2012 Video Addresses Critics and Outlines Call for Action
description: Invisible Children, the nonprofit organization that produced the Kony 2012 video that went viral last month and brought to light the brutal tactics of the African warlord Joseph Kony, released a sequel on Thursday as part of its continuing campaign calling for Mr. Konys arrest and capture.

title: Getting Cash and More Than They Bargained For
description: ATM is as compact a debut feature for its director, David Brooks, as you could imagine, confined pretty much to a killers lair, an office, a party room, two cars and a small, free-standing banking center. And yet it generates a taut frisson within its spare 90 minutes.

title: An Apartment That Ticks All the Boxes
description: ITS not every day that an apartment with two balconies, one terrace and 100 feet fronting on Central Park comes on the market. Nor do you often find one with a 70-foot long-gallery, 12-foot-high ceilings and seven working fireplaces. Rarer still is it to see one at the famed Dakota.

title: Assembling a Frame, Then Referring Beyond It
description: The jazz pianist Craig Taborn opened his early set at the Village Vanguard on Wednesday with American Landscape, or at least you will agree to call it that because some sweet, curious, almost Ellingtonian stuff swimming through it also distinguished a much shorter piece of that name he recorded in 2001, on the album Light Made Lighter.

title: Ferdinand A. Porsche, Designer of 911, Leaves a Legacy Beyond Sports Cars
description: Ferdinand Alexander Porsche, who conceived one of the worlds most recognizable sports cars, died Thursday in Salzburg, Austria, at age 76. The cause of death was not disclosed by Porsche, which issued a statement on Thursday, but he was known to have been ill in recent months.

title: Olbermann Files Suit Against Current Dilettantes
description: Keith Olbermann, fired last week from his show on Current TV, has followed through on his threat to file suit against his former employers. The suit, filed Thursday in Los Angeles Superior Court, seeks damages of $50 million to $70 million.

title: A Rare Apartment Comes on the Market
description: Its not every day that an apartment at the famed Dakota with two balconies, seven fireplaces and 100 feet fronting on Central Park comes on the market.

title: On One Corner of America, the Violent Realities of Thug Life
description: Player Hating, Maggie Hadleigh-Wests volatile documentary, is subtitled A Love Story, but its really a tragedy: a tragedy that the hair-trigger energy and ambition of the young men in front of her camera have so few legal outlets. And a tragedy that almost all of them, most in their early 20s, would not think of stepping outside their homes without life insurance.

title: Yankees Face Top Teams to Begin Their Season
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The stinging disappointment the Yankees felt last October when they lost the American League division series to the Detroit Tigers has not been forgotten. On Friday, a new Yankees campaign begins where last years regular season ended, at Tropicana Field.

title: More Than 130 Vocational Schools Are Operating Without State Approval
description: Job prospects for thousands of California students are being threatened by the failure of state regulators to crack down on unapproved private vocational schools. Despite vowing to strengthen protections for Californians attending vocational nursing, technical and trade schools, and other private colleges, the regulators have allowed more than 130 schools to operate for months without state approval, according to state records.

title: 11 Nationalities Unite at Cannelle Patisserie in Queens
description: Cannelle Patisserie, in East Elmhurst, Queens, offers mainly French pastries. Its co-owners are from France and Sri Lanka, and its staff hail from 11 countries.

title: Real-Life Hijacking as Stylized Mass Entertainment
description: As cold as a gun barrel and almost exactly the same color, the French film The Assault stirs the Muslim-hating pot with impressive technical proficiency. Based on the 1994 hijacking of a French plane in Algiers by four Islamic terrorists, this propulsive thriller, a symphony of stomping boots and spraying bullets, kicks subtlety to the curb and humanity to the margins.

title: A Paradise of Sin, Swank and Sinatra
description: Even pickles are romantic and a little louche on Magic City, which begins by ringing in 1959 at a New Years Eve party. In a dazzling, dreamy opening sequence of a beautiful blonde swimming naked deep down in ice-blue water, a ghostly image flits across the background. Its Wolfies coffee shop and restaurant, now closed but once famous for its pastrami and large portions.

title: Divorce, Oligarch Style
description: THE collateral damage from divorce usually affects the children first. For the Russian billionaire Dmitry Rybolovlev, the breakup with his wife, Elena, is spreading to a couple of his trophy properties.

title: For Artists, a Hand-Held Revolution of Point and Click
description: WASHINGTON  Snapshot: Painters and Photography, Bonnard to Vuillard, at the Phillips Collection, celebrates some early adopters of the handheld camera. The first one, introduced by Kodak in 1888, freed artists to take pictures without worrying about tripods, glass plates or chemicals. And, to judge from the photographs here, it turned skilled painters into bumbling amateurs. That too was liberating.

title: Repeat for Red Sox, Joyous Day for Detroit
description: DETROIT

title: Philosophy Is Not a Science
description: For roughly 98 percent of the last 2,500 years of Western intellectual history, philosophy was considered the mother of all knowledge. It generated most of the fields of research still with us today. This is why we continue to call our highest degrees Ph.D.s, namely, philosophy doctorates. At the same time, we live an age in which many seem no longer sure what philosophy is or is good for anymore. Most seem to see it as a highly abstracted discipline with little if any bearing on objective reality  something more akin to art, literature or religion. All have plenty to say about reality. But the overarching assumption is that none of it actually qualifies as knowledge until proven scientifically.

title: Bully Documentary Gets Rating Change to PG-13 After Edited Version Is Submitted
description: LOS ANGELES  Bully, the anti-bullying documentary, is unrated no longer. The Classification and Rating Administration said it gave the film a PG-13 rating on Thursday, after the Weinstein Company submitted a newly edited version of a film that had earlier been rated R because of strong language.

title: Message to Teenagers: Theres More to Life Than Bling
description: Mario Van Peebles tries awfully hard to disguise the heavy-handed messages he has ladled into We the Party, a high school movie that he wrote and directed and filled with his relatives. Teenagers these days, though, are pretty sophisticated when it comes to being manipulated. And anyway, theyve been hearing these same messages  study hard; dont judge people by appearances; theres more to life than bling  for years on the Disney Channel.

title: In-House Getaways
description: Some in-house libraries in residential buildings double as meeting or playrooms; others are designed to be a peaceful getaway within the building.

title: Buildings with Libraries: A Soft-Spoken Amenity
description: WHEN Martin Semjen first looked at the Stanton, a co-op at Broadway and 94th Street, he was delighted by the sauna and fitness room. His wife, Lynn Schnurnberger, on the other hand, fell hard for an unpretentious basement library that doubles as a meeting room and is lined on three sides with floor-to-ceiling wood bookcases. Residents can choose volumes on law and art, popular novels like The Da Vinci Code and Atonement and, fittingly enough, a biography of the buildings namesake, Elizabeth Cady Stanton.

title: Body as Instrument to Retool Classical Idiom
description: In the ephemeral world of dance its telling to consider what sticks  not only onstage but also in the memory. In mine, from 2006, resides a beaming Sylvie Guillem during curtain calls for Push, a program in which she collaborated with the choreographer Russell Maliphant. Choreographically the evening was bleak, but Ill never forget how she came to life during the bows and how sad it made me feel: this French ballerina, handpicked by Rudolf Nureyev to become an toile at the Paris Opera Ballet, needs the spotlight. In the theater thats just another word for love.

title: String Quartet Classics With Alternative Endings
description: Like a rebellious teenager told to get a more conservative haircut, Beethoven was asked to replace the Grosse Fuge, the spiky final movement to his String Quartet in B flat (Op. 130), with something less radical. He grumbled but eventually agreed, substituting an easygoing finale for the original, whose cacophonous thickets had disturbed 19th-century listeners.

title: Italian Populist Party Leader Who Once Backed Berlusconi Quits, Ending an Era
description: ROME  Umberto Bossi, the colorful leader of a populist party best known for its anti-immigrant rhetoric, resigned on Thursday amid a widening scandal of illegal party financing.

title: Top Dog and Underdog to Meet in Final
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The prohibitive favorite Boston Colleges march to a national championship rolled on Thursday night with a dominating 6-1 victory over Minnesota in the marquee matchup of the N.C.A.A. mens hockey national semifinals at the Tampa Bay Times Forum. The overall top-seeded Eagles will meet upstart Ferris State, a 3-1 winner over Union College, for the title Saturday night.

title: Jean-Claude Van Damme, Their Hero
description: Like a number of men of a certain age, Zachary Oberzan spent much of his youth copping scenes and reciting lines from schlocky Hollywood movies of the 1980s and 90s. Thats not meant as a dig. On the contrary, those habits of fond imitation, during a pre-YouTube era of home video, form the emotional engine of this actor-directors latest DIY foray into pop culture, Your Brother. Remember?, a good-humored exploration of fraternal bonds that is often touching.

title: Seen on the Shelves
description: 1 RECTOR PARK

title: Playing the Violence Card
description: EVER since the culture wars of the 1980s, Americans have been familiar with the race card  an epithet used to discredit real and imagined cries of racism. Less familiar, however, is an equally cynical rhetorical tactic that I call the violence card.

title: Hidden Mission of Japanese-Americans in World War II
description: The execution is a bit clumsy, but the documentary MIS: Human Secret Weapon shines a light on an interesting bit of World War II history: the Japanese-American soldiers who did vital work with the Armys Military Intelligence Service even as their countrymen were being thrown into internment camps.

title: Low Growth in Earnings Is Expected
description: Corporate profits have been among the brightest lights of the economic recovery, helping to lift the stock market more than 25 percent since October.

title: Ferdinand A. Porsche, Designer of the 911, Dies at 76
description: Ferdinand A. Porsche, who designed the original Porsche 911, the snazzy, powerful sports car that became the lasting signature of the German automobile company founded by his grandfather and later run by his father, died on Thursday in Salzburg, Austria. He was 76.

title: School District Lives On, but So Do Its Struggles
description: HOUSTON  In the eight years that Vivek Agarwal has taught science at North Forest Independent School Districts lone high school, he has watched six principals and four superintendents come and go.

title: After Revolutions, Beware of Crocodiles
description: Accra, Ghana

title: The Alamo Drafthouse Cinema Plans a Manhattan Outpost
description: The Alamo Drafthouse Cinema chain, which got its start in Austin, Tex., and became known nationally for its strict no-talking, no-texting policy, has plans to expand to Manhattan next year.

title: For Two Food Giants, Defining Fresh Fruit Is Not Cut and Dried
description: Pineapples and papayas are the weapons of choice in a global fruit fight under way in federal court in Manhattan. The point of the struggle? Deciding whether the fruit in plastic containers on refrigerated shelves in grocery store produce sections is fresh  or processed.

title: Drugstore Quarterback
description: On the prowl for pills, the big man with the shiny black loafers and fancy pickup truck broke into houses on the high plains of Montana. When startled homeowners came upon him, he muttered something about being in the wrong residence, so sorry. And they wondered: Could this intruder really be the former N.F.L. quarterback, the Heisman Trophy finalist, the local kid paid $14 million before he tossed a single ball into opposition hands?

title: In First Round, Trouble Arrives Late
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  On a warm, sun-streaked Thursday at the Masters, players slipped down the leader board as if it were a water slide. Henrik Stenson rode a five-under 31 on the front nine to the lead, only to plunge headfirst into an abyss with a quadruple-bogey 8 at the 18th hole. Stenson, the 2009 Players Championship winner from Sweden, played the last three holes in five over par and finished with a one-under-71.

title: Loyalty to Syrian President Could Isolate Hezbollah
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Mazen, a carpenter who organizes protests against President Bashar al-Assad in a suburb of Damascus, Syria, has torn down the posters of Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of Hezbollah, that once decorated his car and shop.

title: Snapshot
description: A new exhibition at the Phillips Collection in Washington celebrates some early adopters of the handheld camera.

title: Ramp? Mall? Ship? No, a Titans New Tomb
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  The 17-story-tall white-tiled mausoleum being built to hold the remains of the national hero Simn Bolvar looks to many people here like the worlds biggest skateboard ramp. To others, it evokes a parking garage, a shopping mall, a bridal veil, a sailing ship or a drive-in movie screen. Some simply call it an outrage.

title: Evita
description: Photos of the Broadway revival at the Marquis Theater.

title: For Detroit, a Path to Recovery Under State Oversight
description: DETROIT  Other cities and towns have teetered at the edge of financial disaster lately, but Detroit, the capital of Americas auto industry and once the nations fourth-largest city, has just become the most striking test case for a key question: Can a city that has fallen so far be saved?

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 5, 2012

title: Energy Dept. to Revitalize a Loan Guarantee Program
description: WASHINGTON  Six months after the expiration of a federal loan guarantee program that backed $16 billion in loans to solar, wind and geothermal energy projects, the Energy Department has decided to offer a smaller set of similar guarantees by tapping another pot of money appropriated by Congress last year.

title: Coast Guard Fires Cannon on Unmanned Japanese Ship Set Adrift by Tsunami
description: The United States Coast Guard began its operation Thursday afternoon to sink a Japanese vessel that was spotted off the coast of British Columbia last week, one year after an earthquake and tsunami set it on an unmanned path across the Pacific Ocean.

title: Tape Reveals Coach Asking for Injuries
description: By the time New Orleans Saints Coach Sean Payton slipped out a back exit at the N.F.L.s office in Manhattan and silently got into a waiting van, his long-shot appeal of a yearlong suspension already heard, the stain of the Saints bounty scandal had grown worse.

title: An Upgrade for the Show Before the Show
description: AUDIENCES still frequently boo the ads that run in theaters before the movie starts. But that reaction hasnt dimmed the allure of premovie advertising to marketers. Screenvision, a giant in the business, hopes that a new mobile app will entice viewers to get to the theater early enough to sit through a full 20 minutes of ads and interactive games.

title: Corrections: April 6
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: That Other Obama
description: President Obama is an intelligent, judicious man who can see all sides of an issue. But every once in a while he tries to get politically cute, and he puts on his Keith Olbermann mask.

title: For Mets, Whispers to Build From Within
description: Build it and he will come. In so many words, that was Darryl Strawberrys message on the day the 2012 Mets memorialized Gary Carter before launching their era of enforced frugality with a 1-0 victory over the Atlanta Braves at Citi Field.

title: $30,000 Watch Vanishes Up Church Leaders Sleeve
description: MOSCOW  Facing a scandal over photographs of its leader wearing an enormously expensive watch, the Russian Orthodox Church worked a little miracle: It made the offending timepiece disappear.

title: Found to Have Misbehaved With Pupils, but Still Teaching
description: A health teacher at a high school in Manhattan, joking about life for homosexuals in prison, forced a male student to bend over a desk, lined up behind him to simulate a sex act, then quipped, according to an Education Department investigative report, Ill show you whats gay.

title: Filling a Hole on the Block, With Cream
description: THE strip mall north of 31st Avenue in East Elmhurst, Queens, looks like any other. There is the parking lot, cracked and huge. There is the Pearle Vision, the Curves, the Carvel, their signs at once garish and slightly forlorn. Not much would suggest, in other words, a portal to some of New York Citys most ethereal croissants, exquisite napoleons and a ruinously buttery rarity called a gteau Breton.

title: Not Enough Inflation
description: A few days ago, Alan Greenspan, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve, spoke out in defense of his successor. Attacks on Ben Bernanke by Republicans, he told The Financial Times, are wholly inappropriate and destructive. Hes right about that  which makes this one of the very few things the ex-maestro has gotten right in the past few years.

title: In Lawsuits, Long Island Inmates Complain of Squalor
description: The inmates at Suffolk County Correctional Facilities told anyone who would listen that they were being forced to live in squalid conditions, with human waste bubbling up from the drains, brown water running from the tap and mold multiplying on the walls.

title: Titanic Ties in the Race for Mayor
description: So far, Christine C. Quinn is the only likely candidate for mayor known to have an Irish grandmother who was a passenger on the Titanic 100 years ago. To beat next weeks rush on Titanic centennial commemorative news, we met a few days ago in the back of a diner in Chelsea to get the grandmothers story straight. That only sounds easy.

title: City Officials Cite Defects in Hoisting System of Crane That Collapsed, Killing a Worker
description: The crane that collapsed this week at a project on the Far West Side of Manhattan, killing a worker, had a number of defects in its hoisting system, city officials said Thursday.

title: In the Rough and Liking It: Some Golfers Eschew the Cleanshaven Look
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Generally, smooth is the rule at the Masters. After all, the Augusta National Golf Club fairways are slick and shaved; the greens are shimmering carpets; even the pimiento cheese sandwiches spread evenly with no chunks.

title: The Law of the Gun in Florida
description: Florida leads the pack in passing bills written by the gun lobby that block any sensible attempt to control the purchase and use of firearms. The dangerous folly of these laws was on display in the Trayvon Martin shooting, and will again be on display when Republicans gather for their presidential convention in Tampa this August.

title: Women United F.C.: A Launch of Its Own
description: When Kristi Colvin curled up on her living room couch to watch Sporting Kansas Citys 2011 season opener, her expectations were low and her sense of obligation was high. Colvin, the chief executive of the Kansas City, Mo.-based creative services agency Fresh ID, had done some promotional work with the team but had never seen a Major League Soccer match before and did not know what to expect.

title: Requiem for a Kingmaker
description: This just in: Eva Pern is still dead.

title: Why Parsing Matters
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Thank goodness for Frank Longo.

title: Banks Always Win
description: Citing unsafe and unsound foreclosure practices, the Federal Reserve said recently that it plans to penalize eight financial firms  HSBCs United States bank division, SunTrust Bank, MetLife, U.S. Bancorp, PNC Financial Services, EverBank, OneWest and Goldman Sachs. Well believe it when we see it.

title: Emirates Detain Pair From U.S.-Backed Group
description: WASHINGTON  The United Arab Emirates detained two employees of an American-financed pro-democracy organization and barred one of them from leaving the country on Thursday, worsening a diplomatic confrontation with the United States that has embarrassed and puzzled administration officials.

title: Huge Rooftop Farm Is Set for Brooklyn
description: Brooklyn is fast becoming the borough of farms. On Thursday, Bright Farms, a private company that develops greenhouses, announced plans to create a sprawling greenhouse on a roof in Sunset Park that is expected to yield a million pounds of produce a year  without using any dirt.

title: Republican Committee Makes Big Turnaround on Fund-Raising
description: Once teetering on the edge of bankruptcy and irrelevance, the Republican National Committee has raised more than $110 million over the past 15 months and retired more than half its debt, accumulating large cash reserves that could give Mitt Romney a critical boost later this spring as he intensifies his campaign against President Obama.

title: Glimpses of Optimism Atop the New Fence in Left
description: The ball left Jason Bays bat, and for a moment, it looked as if the Mets would benefit from the new smaller dimensions at Citi Field on Thursday. Instead, Bay did what he has done many times in the past two seasons: he failed to clear the wall, no matter the distance.

title: A Good Education With the G.I. Bill
description: Service members and veterans looking to learn more about their educational benefits under the G.I. Bill may be in trouble if they plunge unprepared into the wilds of the Internet. Many reputable private and public universities, trade schools and training programs are committed to helping veterans further their education and careers. But there are also predators itching to pad their enrollments with veterans and get their hands on government billions  nearly 600,000 people are expected to enter classes under the G.I. Bill this year, with the Veterans Affairs Department footing more than $9 billion of the cost.

title: Mexico: Gang Leader Sentenced in U.S.
description: A Mexican drug gang leader pleaded guilty in El Paso on Thursday to federal charges that he was the mastermind behind the killings of three people connected to a United States Consulate in Mexico. The gang leader, Jos Antonio Acosta Hernndez, 34, said that he had an agreement with gang members to commit the killings and that since 2008 he had directed or participated in over 1,500 murders. He was sentenced to life in prison. In March 2010, three people  two Americans, including a consulate employee, and a Mexican  were shot to death after a birthday party in Ciudad Jurez. Officials said it was a case of mistaken identity. Mr. Hernndez was arrested in August and extradited to the United States.

title: Congress Needs to Step Up for AmeriCorps
description: After months of Republican obstructionism, the Senate last week unanimously confirmed Wendy Spencer to lead the Corporation for National and Community Service, which oversees AmeriCorps and other programs that encourage Americans to serve in their communities.

title: Magics Drama Eclipses Knicks Win
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  A disorienting wave of dissension and acrimony washed over an N.B.A. franchise on Thursday, pitting coach against superstar, in a spectacle that threatened to ruin their season. The Knicks were nearby, but for once, happily, they were not the source of the mayhem.

title: Indian Couple Deny Charges of Abusing Servant
description: NEW DELHI  The couple accused of abusing a 13-year-old maid and locking her in their apartment while they went on vacation, a story that has renewed attention on the exploitation of children in India, did no such thing, the couples lawyer said Thursday.

title: Malawi: President Suffers Heart Attack
description: President Bingu wa Mutharika was hospitalized Thursday after suffering a heart attack, medical and government officials said. Mr. Mutharika, 78, who has governed Malawi since 2004, was in serious condition, hospital officials said, but local news reports offered conflicting accounts. Some said he had been airlifted to South Africa for treatment, and at least one report said he had died. His spokesman, Hetherwick Ntaba, said he had no information about the presidents condition. Malawi has been rocked by political and economic turmoil. Security forces fired on protesters last year, killing 19 people, and prompting the United States to suspend a $350 million grant. Mr. Mutharikas critics accuse him of autocratic behavior; last month his office ordered journalists to stop calling him the Big Kahuna.

title: Florida. How Soon We Forget.
description: Last spring, Florida made some changes to its election law. Cloaked as technical tweaks, the new laws have the potential to swing the 2012 election.

title: Sothebys Retains Custody of Cambodian Statue
description: Ruling against the immediate seizure of a 1,000-year-old Cambodian statue the United States and Cambodian governments say was looted from its temple site, a federal judge in Manhattan on Thursday gave Sothebys continued custody of the antiquity and called a conference on the case for April 12.

title: Tortorella Seethes After Penguins Hit
description: PITTSBURGH  The match was supposed to be anticlimactic. The Rangers had clinched the Eastern Conference title and the Penguins were simply playing to secure fourth place. For 55 minutes 21 seconds, it a one-sided, benign game.

title: Joe Scarpa, Who Gained Wrestling Fame as Chief Jay Strongbow, Dies
description: Joe Scarpa, who became one of the best-known professional wrestlers of the 1970s and 80s after he took on the persona of Chief Jay Strongbow, an American Indian whose war dance foretold the downfall of many opponents, died on Tuesday.

title: Should Los Angeles New Yorkify?
Dale Corson, Cornell Administrator Who Helped Quell Protest, Dies at 97
description: Dale R. Corson, a nuclear physicist and Cornell University administrator who was instrumental in defusing a potentially explosive standoff with armed student militants in 1969, then brought relative peace to the campus as the universitys president during the 1970s, died on Sunday in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 97.

title: A Gleaming New Park Near the Home of the Yankees
description: Heritage Field, the last piece of the citys effort to replace the parkland taken by the new Yankee stadium, opened to coincide with the Yankees home opener.

title: At Home, the Mets Pay Tribute to Carter
description: For the Mets, opening day on Thursday marked the first real opportunity for the team and its fans to honor Gary Carter together.

title: Strand Workers Reject Contract Offer
description: Seventeen unionized workers from the Strand Bookstore sat around two long, white tables in the back of Pie, a pizza parlor near Union Square on Thursday night. Between sips of beer they calmly talked about the shop, their pay and what to do next.

title: Gil Noble, Host of Pioneering TV Show Focusing on Black Issues, Dies at 80
description: Gil Noble, a television journalist who hosted Like It Is, an award-winning Sunday morning public affairs program in New York, one of the longest-running in the country dedicated to showcasing black leadership and the African-American experience, died on Thursday in a hospital in Wayne, N.J. He was 80.

title: Doubts Intensify on Resumption of Iran Nuclear Talks
description: Prospects for the scheduled resumption of talks on Irans contentious nuclear energy program next week appeared to recede further Thursday, when the Iranians issued new objections to Turkey as the formerly agreed location for the talks and revealed they had rejected alternate proposals to hold them in at least three European countries.

title: New Treatments to Save a Pet, but Questions About the Costs
description: Two years ago, Mike Otworths 10-year-old chow, Tina, was given a diagnosis of lymphoma. The prospects were grim. Lymphoma, a cancer of the lymph nodes that commonly develops in older dogs, can be put into remission through chemotherapy, but tumors almost inevitably reappear within a year, and death quickly follows.

title: Obama Signs Bill to Promote Start-Up Investments
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, eager to promote his administrations efforts to revive the job market on the eve of another politically significant employment report, signed a bill on Thursday that will roll back restrictions on the way start-up companies can raise money from individual investors.

title: Jim Marshall, Maker of Famed Fuzzy Amplifiers, Dies at 88
description: Jim Marshall, who made rock n roll rawer and noisier by inventing the amplifier that helped define guitarists from Jimi Hendrix to members of countless garage bands, died on Thursday at a hospice in London. He was 88.

title: Delegates Up for Grabs in Primary in New York
description: With a little more than two weeks until New Yorks presidential primary, the outstanding question among Republicans is not whether Mitt Romney will win, but by how much.

title: Age 54 and Among the Leaders (for a Hole)
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  For a moment, early on Thursday, Randal Lewis was on the Masters leader board.

title: Santorum Meets With Conservative Leaders to Consider Possible Next Steps
description: A group of conservative leaders met with Rick Santorum on Thursday to consider various strategies to help his faltering campaign for the Republican presidential nomination, including some discussion of how to persuade Newt Gingrich to drop out of the contest.

title: Were on Spring Break, but While Were Gone
description: The live feed from Hawk Cam 2012 as it chronicles the red-tailed hawks of Washington Square Park, in Manhattan.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,907 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American on Thursday:

title: A Company Gingrich Founded to Offer Health Care Advice Files for Bankruptcy
description: A consulting company founded by Newt Gingrich filed for bankruptcy on Thursday, an apparent casualty of Mr. Gingrichs stepping down from the business to run for the Republican presidential nomination.

title: The Closer: Catchers Go the Distance
description: Thursday was opening day for Major League Baseball. As long as youre willing to ignore the game that was played the night before in Miami. And the two games played the week before in Japan. But according to the logos on the field, the season started today.

title: Bulls Defeat the Celtics
description: Luol Deng scored 26 points and Joakim Noah added 17 points and 9 rebounds as the Bulls beat the Boston Celtics, 93-86, in Chicago. Paul Pierce led the Celtics with 22 points.

title: As French Election Heats Up, So Does Campaigning for French Grand Prix
description: PARIS  As the campaigning for the French presidential election shifts into high gear, so is the campaigning for the French Grand Prix.

title: Stepan Is Hit, and Tortorella Retaliates
description: 6:01 p.m. | Updated Rangers Coach John Tortorella was fined $20,000 by the N.H.L. for his comments on the Penguins.

title: Smaller Parties Refuse to Be Counted Out
description: Texas is not a two-party state in the Constitution, or in the law, but it looks that way when the argument is over elections and political districts.

title: On Idol, a Duet From Two Top Contenders
description: One of the best performances on American Idol this week came when Joshua Ledet, the phenomenal 19-year-old gospel singer from Louisiana, and Jessica Sanchez, the equally phenomenal 16-year-old pop singer from San Diego, teamed up for a duet on I Knew You Were Waiting (for Me), which was made a hit by Aretha Franklin and George Michael.

title: Franke Reaches Out the Old-Fashioned Way. He Calls.
description: Wayne T. Franke never forgets a birthday.

title: A Certain Drag Troupe Returns, Now With Rehearsals
description: At first glance, musicals from the Cockettes would seem to be an unlikely candidate for revival.

title: BARTs New Seats (a Few) Make Debut
description: By midnight Wednesday, Bay Area Rapid Transit workers had removed the filthiest seat cushions from the trains. Stacked in crates at BARTs Hayward maintenance yard, the blue cloth-covered seat bottoms and backs were sticky, splotched with stains and coated with grime.

title: GTT
description: AUSTIN

title: Have Moratti and Inter Found Something Special Again?
description: If Andrea Stramaccioni was in any doubt as to how his new position as Inters coach would require him to deal with the extraordinary on a regular basis, he certainly isnt now.

title: Opening Day in Oakland, With Prospects of Doubleheader of Anguish for As Fans
description: As the As take the field for their home opener Friday against the Seattle Mariners, the teams overachieving glory days depicted in last years Moneyball starring Brad Pitt as General Manager Billy Beane are a warm, if distant glimmer.

title: Connecting Music and Gesture
description: Alan Gilbert, music director of the New York Philharmonic, demonstrates and discusses the role of a conductor.

title: How to Help Durga and Girls Like Her
description: The India Ink article, For Some Adolescent Girls in India, a Struggle to Stay in School, inspired several of our readers to write in, asking what they could do to help Durga, the girl profiled in the story, who lives with her family on a pavement in Mumbai.

title: Mali Rebels Proclaim Independent State in North
description: Tuareg rebels who overran much of northern Mali after disaffected soldiers toppled the government in the south declared an independent state called Azawad on Friday, cementing the division of the former French colony as its neighbors began drawing up plans for military action to tackle the twin crises of the coup and the apparent secession.

title: Can Coffee Kick-Start an Economy?
description: When he set out to wedge his coffee onto supermarket shelves in England and America, Andrew Rugasira didnt start by making phone calls from his home in Kampala, Uganda. He didnt begin by sending e-mails. The distance seemed too great for that. At one end of his business were farmers who, until he came along, thought their beans were purchased and carried off to make gunpowder. At the other were buyers at the corporate headquarters of chains like Waitrose and Sainsburys, Whole Foods and Wal-Mart. If he was going to succeed, he felt he would have to do it physically; it was as if he believed he could stretch himself to span the divide between the two worlds. So he got on a plane to London, without trying any advance contact.

title: Stand Clear of the Closing Doors, Please
description: To navigate New Yorks mass transit is to experience all of this competitive citys struggles, pleasures and pains, only transposed underground, into the subterranean arena otherwise known as a train station. Faced with sprints, crowded staircases and down-to-the-minute departure times, the successful urban traveler must display an agility and athleticism akin to a gladiators.

title: Still Undecided, With Less Than a Month to Choose
description: July 26, 2012 | Updated Rachel Yang has made her final decision. You may find her college choice at the end of this post.

title: The Early Word: In the Black
description: In Todays Times:

title: Fantasy Focus: A Crystal Ball
description: The following are my predictions for the 2012 major league baseball season. After picking how I see each division pans out, I added commentary on some of the relevant fantasy ramifications by taking a look into my crystal ball. Heres my stab at predicting what happens over the next six months:

title: Malawi Leaders Death Is Reported Unofficially, and U.S. Worries About Succession
description: JOHANNESBURG  The United States expressed concern about the future of the impoverished African nation of Malawi on Friday after a swirl of reports that its president, stricken by a heart attack, had died, suggesting that the delay in an official announcement reflected possible succession problems.

title: Child Servants in India: Rare Case or Routine?
description: The recent article by Jim Yardley in The New York Times about a 13-year-old maid who was allegedly locked up by her employers in their New Delhi apartment when they went on vacation generated a huge response from readers.

title: Release of Gregg Williams Tape Was Warning to Parents
description: Every single one of you, before you get off the pile, affect the head. Early, affect the head. Continue, touch and hit the head. Gregg Williams, the former Saints defensive coordinator, caught on tape,  exhorting his players to injure the 49ers a day before their playoff game. (In the video above, Williams was Washingtons defensive coordinator when the Redskins affected Peyton Mannings head and neck.)

title: The Legal vs. the Illegal Arms Trade
description: LONDON  Its hard to summon up much sympathy for Viktor Bout, the notorious Russian arms trafficker jailed for 25 years on Thursday by a U.S. federal court. The illicit arms trade is a global curse that fuels conflicts and inflicts misery on the lives of countless innocents.

title: Pakistani Lawmakers Criticize U.S. Reward for Militant Leader
description: The Pakistani government and opposition on Thursday united in criticism of a newly announced $10 million American bounty for Hafiz Saeed, a militant leader accused of orchestrating the 2008 attacks in Mumbai, Salman Masood writes in The New York Times. During a heated session of Parliament, lawmakers demanded that Washington provide proof of Mr. Saeeds terrorist credentials, Mr. Masood writes.

title: On Our Radar: Google Plans Thermal Storage
description: Google will embrace thermal storage at its new data center in Taiwan, making ice at night, when electricity is cheaper, and using it to cool buildings during the day. [Grist]

title: Republican National Committees Finances Have Improved
description: The Republican National Committee has been raising money and paying down debt

title: The Maestros Mojo
description: ARMS carve the air. A hand closes as if to pull taffy. An index finger shoots out. The torso leans in, leans back. And somehow, music pours forth  precisely coordinated and emotionally expressive  in response to this mysterious podium dance.

title: Opinion Report: Guns in Tampa
description: From the editorial page

title: Russia Denounces U.S. Sentencing of Arms Dealer
description: MOSCOW  Russia lashed out at the United States on Friday over the sentencing of a convicted Russian arms trafficker to 25 years in prison, calling the decision by a New York court baseless and biased and warning that it could hamper relations between Moscow and Washington.

title: After a Winter of Strong Gains, Job Growth Ebbs
description: Although signs pointed to a strengthening economy earlier this year, the jobs report on Friday came with a message: dont get ahead of yourself.

title: Friday Reading: Are Life-Saving Pet Treatments Worth the Cost?
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Three Stooges, Two Farrellys? Soitainly
description: THE new Three Stooges movie, opening Friday, brings the knuckleheaded stalwarts of American comedy back to the big screen and into the present day. Given that the film could just as well be called Dumb, Dumber and Dumbest, it also brings its directors, Peter and Bobby Farrelly, full circle, back to the vaudeville anarchy and blunt slapstick antics of their expulsive debut.

title: Patch Work
description: You know Chagalls canvases, but what of his cottons? Artists Textiles (Antique Collectors Club, $50) amasses works on fabric by 20th-century greats like Braque, Matisse, Calder and Warhol. The book begins in the 1910s with pathbreaking swatches by the British artist Roger Fry, who helped erase what he called the erroneous distinction between fine and applied art. Eventually, these art textiles were turned into commercial clothing: a Joan Mir dress, a Salvador Dal tie. By the 1960s, Picasso was allowing his pictures to be printed on almost any fabric, save upholstery. The sofa was a line he wouldnt cross, the book notes: Picassos may be leaned against, not sat on.

title: The Munchkins Are a Problem: The Sounds of Music
The Art of Slipping in Some Learning
Teachers Accused of Sexual Misconduct Still Teaching
Daily Report: Microsoft Pays for Big-Name Apps
description: Microsoft is so determined to have lots of brand-name apps for its Windows Phone app store that it is willing to pay for them, Jenna Wortham and Nick Wingfield report in Fridays New York Times.

title: China Says Wanted Militants Use Nearby Countries to Stage Attacks
description: BEIJING  Chinese security officials have issued a list of six men suspected of being members of a militant group that they said used Asian nations as staging grounds for terrorist attacks in the western Chinese region of Xinjiang.

title: Beer Authority: A Terminal for Brews, Not Buses
description: Instead of opening just after Thanksgiving, as planned, Joe Donagher and his partners are unlocking the doors on their new venture more than four months later, just before Easter. Called Beer Authority, this vast three-story beer hall and restaurant across 40th Street from the Port Authority Bus Terminal expects to finally wake from its bureaucratic nightmare on Friday.

title: Waist Size Helps Predict Heart Risk in Teenagers
description: Using waist measurements together with body mass index may better predict a teenagers cardiovascular risk than using B.M.I. alone, a new study finds.

title: Romneys Health Care Plan
description: Mitt Romney was roundly mocked on Thursday for seeming to forget he went to Harvard. At a campaign rally in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, Mr. Romney suggested that President Obama was out of touch, perhaps because he had spent too much time at Harvard. Mr. Obama attended Harvard for three years, obtaining a law degree; Mr. Romney was there for four years, obtaining a combined JD/MBA.

title: Swamped
description: Sorry about radio silence  too many personal and professional obligations fell in at the same time. Back later today, maybe.

title: Morning Buzz, April 6: Making Rum in Brooklyn
description: Good morning. Enjoy more sunny skies today, with highs nearing 60 degrees.

title: Hindu Wedding Planners Thrive in the United States
description: When I got married almost 10 years ago, it was my parents and I who orchestrated the week-long affair, a medium-sized Indian affair spread over various venues in Manhattan and New Jersey, involving more than 450 guests from as a far away as Hong Kong, New Delhi and Germany.

title: What Were Reading
description: Reuters: McDonalds gets happy: A San Francisco judge has dismissed a class-action lawsuit claiming that the fast-food chain, by offering toys in Happy Meals, lured children into its restaurants and possibly into obesity. The judge gave no reason for tossing the case.  Glenn Collins

title: Hitting the Right Rhythm to Tell Marleys Story
description: OF all the friends, lovers, relatives and Rastas that the director Kevin Macdonald wrangled into his new documentary, Marley, one of his favorite finds was Dudley Sibley, a onetime recording artist and the janitor at the Jamaican recording studio where Bob Marley cut his musical teeth.

title: Tracing the Money, and the Masterminds, of Illegal Logging
description: Endangered forests and plants dont get quite as much public attention as endangered animals generally do. Last month the World Bank addressed that deficit by issuing a study, titled Justice for Forests, that candidly laid out the problems posed by a global epidemic of illegal logging.

title: Behind the Disappointing Jobs Report
description: The March jobs report released today was disappointing. Economists had expected the nations employers to increase their payrolls by about 205,000 net, but instead payrolls increased by just 120,000.

title: A Voice of Williamsburgs Past, Warning Against Change
description: Growing up in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, in the 1980s, Dennis Farr dreamed of a life that was mythical. His fascination with the murals slathered on the walls of the abandoned buildings on the neighborhoods post-industrial waterfront satisfied his longing for adventure, looking like tags written by phantom giants.

title: The First Tudor
description: Visiting the court of Henry VII in 1497, 12 years after the Battle of Bosworth Field ended his unpleasant predecessors reign, a group of ambassadors from the Continent were impressed, intrigued and, as time wore on, a little apprehensive. Their mission was to report to their various employers on Englands monarch, an upstart seeking to improve his status at the European table by wedding his heir, Prince Arthur, to Catherine of Aragon. The path to the altar was to be smoothed, as the ambassadors were well aware, by the reputed wealth Henry Tudor was willing to bestow on the girls proud but cash-poor parents, the Spanish monarchs Ferdinand and Isabella.

title: The Last Trumpet
description: Many people mistakenly call the last book of the Christian Bible Revelations. It is actually the (one) Revelation to John. Elaine Pagels may be playing on that common error with the title of her latest book, Revelations, though in this case it is accurate: she places the biblical Book of Revelation in the context of other ancient narratives of visions and prophecy. Her account highlights several prophetic works and visionaries, from Ezekiel to Paul to the ancient sect of prophesying Christians called the Montanists, and others. Pagels also discusses the afterlife of Revelation in the Christianity of late antiquity through the fourth century. Her thesis is that apocalyptic literature  visions, prophecies, predictions of cataclysm  has always carried political ramifications, both revolutionary and reactionary, liberal and conservative, from the very beginning up until today, as seen in conservative iterations of millennial dispensationalism and the hugely popular Left Behind series of novels about the end of the world. The apocalyptic is political.

title: Two Rescued After Tugboat Overturns Near Liberty Island
description: Updated, 11:16 a.m. | Two men were pulled from the water near Liberty Island on Friday morning after their tugboat overturned in the harbor around 9:45 a.m., the National Park Police said.

title: Inventing the Future
description: In 1909, top executives at AT&T decided to commit themselves to a challenge: building a transcontinental phone line that could connect a call between New York and San Francisco. The problem was one that required not just engineering skill but advances in pure science. They needed, among other things, to create a repeater or amplifier for the electric signals so that they would not attenuate after a few miles. Thus was the seed planted for a new collaborative industrial organization  teaming up theoreticians, experimentalists, material scientists, metallurgists, engineers and even telephone pole climbers  that eventually became Bell Labs. Jointly owned by AT&T and its affiliated equipment maker, Western Electric, Bell Labs went on to invent the transistor and make major contributions to the field of lasers and cellular telephony.

title: Remaking History
description: Alternate versions of history are like catnip for thriller writers. Think of Robert Harriss Fatherland, which takes place in a victorious Nazi Germany in 1964, on the eve of Adolf Hitlers 75th birthday, or Stephen Kings 11/22/63, in which a time traveler stops the murder of John F. Kennedy. These novels invite readers to suspend disbelief, to engage in a bewitching game of what if.

title: On Air, an Excited Matt Lauer Confirms His Plans
description: 5:25 p.m. | Updated Matt Lauer, the co-host of the Today show, told viewers on Friday that he had decided to stay on the show, putting to rest months of talk in the media industry that he might opt to leave when his contract expires later this year.

title: Future Imperfect
description: The curiosity that inspired Homer and Virgil to follow their heroes after the fall of Troy is doubtless as old as war itself, and apparently undiminished. What happens when the carnage ends? How does the victorious or defeated soldier trade the adrenaline rush of combat for the quieter satisfactions (and the tedium) of peacetime? Any number of books, films and television dramas set against the background of more recent conflicts  The English Patient, The Deer Hunter, the Showtime series Homeland, to name just a few  suggest that Odysseus should have been thankful for the distracting detours on the voyage home, and for a transition to domesticity sharply demarcated and enlivened by the bloody massacre of Penelopes suitors.

title: Side Bet
description: Its postmodern, not to mention a little scary, to write a review for The New York Times about a fictional memoir in which the protagonist, a failed novelist who has never excelled at anything, fantasizes about assassinating the reviewer who shoved his novel through a high-speed shredder in the Sunday Times. But this review is not a shredder, and we all know that fictional characters almost never resemble the authors who invent them, right?

title: Blood in the Sea
description: Picture it: An Art Deco villa on the French Riviera in 1935. A witty crowd of expats caught up in a mad whirl of dinner parties, tennis parties, boating parties and scavenger hunts. Nol Coward might have set a delicious comedy in this sophisticated milieu. Agatha Christie would have executed a discreet murder mystery and dispatched Hercule Poirot to solve it.

title: Off the Hook
description: Ferdinand von Schirach is both a German criminal defense lawyer and an exceptional prose stylist, as evidenced by his devastating new volume of stories, a sequel to a similar and even stronger collection called Crime. That book was a critical and commercial success in Germany and received fine notices when it was published here last year.

title: When Cancer Boomerangs the Adult Child
description: Suleika Jaouad, 23, is chronicling her return to her parents home, and to a life of being cared for, in a post on The Timess Well blog. Her boomerang back toward her childhood house came about as a result of her diagnosis of leukemia last year, and now, waiting for a bone marrow transplant, her life has become, she writes, a slow emergency, her world a waiting room.

title: South of Eden
description: Lauren Groffs second novel, Arcadia, arrives bearing enthusiastic blurbs from Kate Walbert and Richard Russo (who claims its not possible to write any better without showing off). But readers doomed to miss their subway stops will wish the cover also included a warning: This novel will swallow you whole.

title: Repeat After Me
description: Few linguists doubt that natural selection has played a part in humans linguistic ability. We all speak. Our vocal tract is honed to produce the sonic richness and precision of speech. Animals couldnt speak even if they wanted to. In the 1960s, however, Noam Chomsky pushed the envelope with a radical proposal: a theory that humans have an innate mental apparatus specifically devoted to assembling words into sentences  an inborn language organ.

title: Chaos in Mali
description: On March 22, the government of Mali, a country that had been widely seen as a model of democracy in West Africa, was taken over by a military junta.In grabbing power, the coup leader, Capt. Amadou Haya Sanogo, claimed the president wasnt doing enough to fight a rebel insurrection in the north. But the chaos of the coup only helped the insurgents gain ground.

title: Editors Choice
description: CITY OF BOHANE,  by Kevin Barry. (Graywolf, $25.) Somewhere in Ireland in 2053, people are haunted by a lost time, when something calamitous happened, and hope to reclaim the past. Barrys extraordinary, exuberant first novel is full of inventive language.

title: Timely | Big Deal: Guitar Heroes
description: It started as an innocent collaboration with a throwaway name: the Californian KC Underwood, then 26, taught guitar to the 16-year-old Briton Alice Costelloe, a rock singer since she was 13, and they called themselves Big Deal because surely theyd never be one. Three years and an album later (Lights Out), the sound they thought wouldnt make waves outside his London flat  synchronized vocals and two electric guitars  has Britain enthralled (now the States, too: the band is fresh off a splashy debut at South by Southwest). And that moniker? The jokes not so funny now that were stuck with a bad name, Underwood says. At least its better than their first one: Hard Cheese.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE MOST HUMAN HUMAN: What Artificial Intelligence Teaches Us About Being Alive,  by Brian Christian. (Anchor, $15.) Each year a tournament is convened to administer the Turing test, pitting humans against artificial-intelligence programs to determine whether machines can think. In 2009 Christian  a poet with degrees in computer science and philosophy  entered the competition, and this lively account investigates the nature of human interactions, the meaning of language and the essence of what sets us apart from machines.

title: Sink or Swim
description: Its no secret that female friendships are born through the sharing of personal information and feelings. Intimacy is our currency. But as Erin Saldins first novel, The Girls of No Return, and The List, by Siobhan Vivian, show, this also makes us frightfully adept at hurting one another.

title: Facing Up to It
description: Born with several genetic abnormalities, 10-year-old August Pullman, called Auggie, dreams of being ordinary. Inside, he knows hes like every other kid, but even after 27 surgeries, the central character of Wonder bears facial disfigurations so pronounced that people who see him for the first time do that look-away thing  if they manage to hide their shock and horror.

title: Gifted and Talented
description: In the town of Remarkable, the setting of Lizzie K. Foleys first novel, all the remarkable women are strange, all the remarkable men are odd-looking and all the remarkable children attend the School for the Remarkably Gifted. Then there is Jane Doe, a very unremarkable girl, 10 years old, of medium height, with eyes of no particular color, and hair that was not quite brown enough to be called mousy.

title: Nuns Behaving Badly
description: Getting bundled off to a nunnery is rarely a prelude to adventure.

title: Star Struck
description: Remember SpaceCamp, the 1986 movie about a group of kids who are accidentally launched on the space shuttle? Like an after-school-special version of Apollo 13, the film showed how a small crew, stranded with limited resources, MacGyvered together a solution, learning valuable life lessons along the way. The movie didnt fare so well at the box office  it was released just a few months after the Challenger disaster  but 10 years old and indifferent to the critics, I loved it.

title: I.S.S. Sides With Illumina in Proxy Fight Against Roche
description: 2:50 p.m. | Updated with comment

title: Inside the List
description: THE PLOT THICKENS: Wild, Cheryl Strayeds memoir of hiking the Pacific Crest Trail, holds steady at No. 7 in its second week on the hardcover nonfiction list. Strayed is also the author of a novel, Torch, but for the past two years her most widely read work was written anonymously: on Valentines Day, Strayed revealed that she was the voice behind the wise and compassionate advice column Dear Sugar at the Web site The Rumpus. Maybe this whole thing will crumble once who I am is no longer a secret, she reflected in the column a month before spilling the beans. I dont know exactly where we are now. I only know were at the place where the plot thickens. A collection of Strayeds Sugar columns, Tiny Beautiful Things, will be published this summer.

title: The Imaginative Arts
description: As my ideas get bigger, my 6-year-old son once told me, you get smaller. Needless to say, this was a startling assessment for a parent to hear. It also reveals the utter stab in the dark an author makes when writing a childrens book, trying to guess backward at just how knowing young readers might be. It seems, in light of my sons mystical warning, all too easy to underestimate your audience.

title: Fan Mail
description: Thomas Berger and I have never met. Yet I also count Thomas Berger, a veteran of World War II and the (insufficiently) celebrated author of 23 novels, among my best friends on this earth. Can this possibly be true? And if so, might it be pathetic, something better kept to myself? My question has some general currency, since lately some of us befriend, or friend, whole armies of discorporate beings. Yet long before virtuality made this gesture prosaic and compulsive, readers were in the habit of making disembodied friendships with authors. I mean, of course, in the sense that Holden Caulfield, after reading a book, expressed the wish to call its author on the telephone.

title: Why the Old-School Music Snob Is the Least Cool Kid on Twitter
description: My friend Lily and I met in 2004 at a showcase for a record label that bartered cassette tapes in exchange for things like drawings and telling jokes. I was there to perform some songs I had recorded on my dads four-track using chopsticks for drumsticks; Lily was there to support her boyfriend, who was playing in a band led by our mutual friends 13-year-old brother. We hit it off, and after that we often went together to see bands play in local out-of-the-way venues, like the dilapidated shack down an alleyway or the basement nightclub that was perpetually flooded with toilet water. The bands were often lousy, but that didnt matter to us. What mattered to us was that no one else knew anything about them.

title: The Postwar Attitude Adjustment
description: I have P.T.S.D. from a violent sexual assault at the hands of strangers. I spent a long time dismissing the idea that pain can make you a better person. Around 2003, I was involved in a study with the Centre for Addiction and Mental Health in Toronto. I began thinking about rape as if it were an earthquake or a flood: it took away everything I had when I was too young to realize I had anything at all. But what was important was what I built out of the rubble  that was what mattered more than the event itself. Today, I sleep soundly, I have successful long-term friendships and relationships with family and I havent had a panic attack in four years. I hope to see the kind of training in this article make its way to those of us who fought solo wars on different fronts.

title: Who Made Mini-Golf?
description: There are conflicting accounts as to what prompted Garnet Carter, who already owned a real golf course, to open a miniature one in the late 1920s. His wife, Frieda, believed it was meant to distract golf widows  much as the Ladies Putting Club, built in 1867, did at the renowned St. Andrews links in Scotland. But Carter, who owned the Fairyland Inn, a hotel outside Chattanooga, Tenn., created more than a distraction. His course was different from other forays into mini-golf. It had hollowed-out tree trunks and gnomes. It was, write Nina Garfinkel and Maria Reidelbach in Miniature Golf, a way of reinforcing the Never Never Land atmosphere the inn strove to create.

title: Donor Agent Provocateur
description: My wife and I retained a fertility consultant to help us find an egg donor who matched some of my wifes diverse ethnic background, which, as we explained, is part ethnic Hawaiian. After a month of dead ends, we asked the consultant directly whether she had searched any Hawaiian donor agencies. She said no, and that she would not do so in the future. Now she refuses to refund our retainer. Did she behave ethically? NAME WITHHELD, CHICAGO

title: The Best Nanny Money Can Buy
description: How often is it the case that one parent (usually the mother, but there is a small group of fathers in this category) gives up a high-paying job to take care of children, particularly preschool-age children? In those cases, the household is paying for their services in the form of what economists call an opportunity cost. In this case, it is the loss of the salary of the parent staying at home. If that parent would have earned $50,000 to $100,000-plus a year, that means your internal nanny service (i.e., the parent) is as extravagant an expense as an Upper West Side counterpart.

title: Jungleland
description: A triumph at every level  reporting, tone, perspective  I couldnt recommend it more. And though [Nathaniel] Rich doesnt directly address it, beneath the surface looms the bigger issue  the recovery of the land is not going to take good and competent managers but something more transcendent: the big idea that no one has come up with yet. Who knows if that will happen.

title: Pros Perspective: When Mud Is a Factor
description: Mark Calcavecchia won 13 PGA Tour titles, including the 1989 British Open. He almost won the 1988 Masters, but settled for a runner-up finish when Sandy Lyle birdied the 18th hole from a fairway bunker. Calcavecchia, in his third season on the Champions Tour, will provide a daily Masters blog, as well as in-round analysis, for The New York Times.

title: A Failure to Lead
description: NEW DELHI  On March 14, Dinesh Trivedi, the minister in charge of Indian Railways, announced a fare increase the first in almost a decade. Prime Minister Manmohan Singh called it forward-looking. Then, on March 18, Trivedi was forced to resign  with the prime ministers approval.

title: Occupiers Hold a Slumber Party Near Union Square
description: More than two dozen Occupy Wall Street protesters, citing a ruling by a federal judge that they said gave them the right to sleep on sidewalks, held sleep-outs near bank branches at Union Square early Friday morning.

title: Bookshelf: Play Ball
description: Childrens books that celebrate the national pastime.

title: In Defense of Music Snobs
description: Music snobbery, which Alexandra Molotkow writes about in this weeks Riff column, has, like a lot of subcultures, a jingo-laden, elitist downside. But for some reason music snobbery tends to anger people more than, say, comic-book collecting or film snobbery. I think people are doubly hostile to pop-music snobbery because theres something elemental to our lives about music that makes it easier to be defensive if someone knows more about it than you do, particularly if its something you like. Ive definitely felt the anguish of looking like a rube next to someone more knowledgeable about something I like, and the initial reaction can be anger and rejection. But learning new information about pop music is generally worth sucking a little humble pie.

title: Bookshelf: Play Ball
description: RANDY RILEYS REALLY BIG HIT  Written and illustrated by Chris Van Dusen.  32 pp. Candlewick Press. $15.99. (Picture book; ages 4 to 7)

title: A House Is a Home, and a Prison, Too

title: Christians and Jews Rediscover Interracial Haven
description: INDIANAPOLIS  After the summons to worship, the Lords Prayer and the first hymn of the morning, the pastor of the South Calvary Missionary Baptist Church here asked the visitors to stand. Among the several hundred African-Americans in the pews on that Sunday last month, about a dozen elderly guests rose to introduce themselves as former neighbors, all of them Jewish.

But one, Proposition 7, sailed through: expanding the states death penalty law to make it among the toughest and most far-reaching in the country.

title: For All the Furor Over Ryans Plan, Its a Place to Start

description: OUARZAZATE, Morocco  Mohamad Ahansal might be 37 years old or 38 or even 39. Ahansal knows only that he was born in the summer, because his mother remembers it being hot, hotter than usual in the Sahara.

title: Weekend Fare
description: This weekend marks the return of three outdoor markets in Brooklyn. Nearly 400 vendors sell their goods at the Brooklyn Flea, held in Fort Greene, 176 Lafayette Avenue (between Clermont and Vanderbilt Avenues), on Saturdays from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., and in Williamsburg, East River Waterfront (between North Sixth and Seventh Streets), on Sundays from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. The large food market known as Smorgasburg (above) is open 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. on Saturdays, also in Williamsburg. The Dekalb Market, 138 Willoughby Street (Flatbush Avenue), in downtown Brooklyn, starts its 2012 season on Saturday and Sunday from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. with food, music, art, film and parties.

title: Answers About Bobby and Rosie, Part 3
description: For the red-tailed hawks incubating two eggs in a nest overlooking Washington Square Park, hatch day could come at any moment. As we await the blessed event, the executive director of New York City Audubon, Glenn Phillips, responds to readers questions about Bobby and Rosies sleeping and eating habits and the effects of pesticides on raptors.

title: Reading Suggestions for Baseballs Opening Week
description: With two games in Japan last week, one game in Miami on Wednesday night, a smattering of action Thursday and Friday, and a full slate on Saturday, Opening Day isnt what it used to be. But baseball is back, and to celebrate the occasion, I asked books and sports staff members at The Times to recommend their favorite books, fiction or nonfiction, that revolve around the sport.

description: We lived the life of a billionaire (for a day), and found that the chances of up-and-coming financiers joining that club are slim. A look back on our reporting of the last weeks highs and lows in finance.

description: In a column earlier this week, I noted and rued journalists and pundits zest for the vice-presidential guessing game, so Im going to have to be careful between now and convention time about participating in it myself. And when it comes to analyzing the strengths and weaknesses of potential running mates, I figure I have a limited number of bites at the apple. Im not going to be taking any of them today.

Then, just when she was starting to get serious about him, John Jones II, also in his 30s, announced that he was contemplating a do-over  about his choice of career, that is.

This involves plying developers with free phones, offering them cash incentives and advertising deals and, in some cases, directly financing the development of an app for its store.

title: At Masters, Anticipating New I.B.M. Chiefs Arrival
description: In the second round of the Masters on Friday, all attention was on Rory McIlroys surge into contention and Lee Westwoods fight for the lead, while the Tiger Woods watch had to wait until his afternoon tee time. As of midday, there was no sign that Virginia M. Rometty, the chief executive of I.B.M., had yet arrived in Augusta, Ga., a move that is sure to steer some of the focus away from the golf tournament and back onto the subject of Augusta Nationals men-only membership.

Nor will it compare with the unveiling of the Ford Mustang at the Worlds Fair in Queens in 1964, which set off a Beatles-scale national mania for the phenomenon that became the pony car.

title: For Just Over $100, Seat Time in a Supercar
description: Driving a six-figure exotic car for a low-three-figure price is not an everyday opportunity. As part of a promotion running concurrently with the New York auto show, which opens to the public Friday, Gotham Dream Cars, a nationwide exotic-car rental agency, is offering an opportunity to take a Ferrari F430 or Lamborghini Gallardo through three high-speed laps for $99  or $105.93 with tax.

title: Bahrain Activists Hunger Strike Belies Image of Calm Ahead of Formula One Race
description: Two weeks before Bahrain is scheduled to hold a prestigious international motor race, the kingdoms attempts to project an image of calm were shattered on Friday when the police fired tear gas at thousands of protesters in the capital, Manama. As The Associated Press reports, the security forces dispersed marchers demanding the release of a leading rights activist, Abdulhadi al-Khawaja, who has been on hunger strike for 58 days.

title: Art to Occupy Times Square

Chashama, an organization that supports artists, has teamed up with Artists Wanted and the Times Square Alliance to create Art Takes Times Square, which starts with a day of events on June 18.

title: Judgment Days
description: ITS cruel April indeed. Kanye West and Kim Kardashian have reportedly hooked up. Itll be more shocking if the agency, which has a long, rich history of inaction when it comes to animal antibiotics, decides to ban the practice of routinely feeding antibiotics to healthy farm animals, a decision that its being forced to make.

description: Isiah Thomas has been fired as the mens basketball coach at Florida International University after three seasons. His record was 26-65.

title: Ryan in Two Numbers
description: Last year, when Paul Ryan first made a big splash with his budget proposal, many commentators  some of them pretending to be moderates or at any rate only moderate conservatives  lavished praise on its fiscal responsibility. Then people who actually know how to read budget numbers weighed in, revealing it as a piece of mean-spirited junk.
