description: Religion and politics have been frequent topics during the battle over President Obamas health care law and the Republican presidential campaign. Several Sunday news shows, marking Easter and Passover, will feature discussions of the spiritual state of the nation.

title: The Caucus Click: The Week in Pictures
description: A look back at the week on the campaign trail in Pennsylvania and Wisconsin.  Go to the slide show.

title: Gemologist Earns Spot in Kentucky Derby With Win in Wood Memorial
description: They say good stallions stamp their foals, and on Saturday, Gemologist flashed the same resolve that once characterized his sire Tiznow in consecutive victories in the Breeders Cup Classic in 2000 and 2001. Undefeated but not seriously tested in four previous starts, Gemologist emerged as one of the leading Kentucky Derby contenders after he resolutely turned back Alpha down the stretch of the Grade I $1 million Wood Memorial at Aqueduct.

title: Berkeley Group Digs In to Challenge of Making Sense of All That Data
description: It comes in torrents and floods and threatens to engulf everything that stands in its path.

title: Tracy Morgan, the Newest Knick
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  From coaching changes to injured star players to the incomparable rise of an unheralded phenomenon, attention and pressure have never strayed from the Knicks this season, a reality solidified by a schedule that allows little time away from the limelight. On Saturday afternoon, that pressure was lifted for a few minutes when the comedian Tracy Morgan attended practice. Morgan, the co-star of NBCs 30 Rock, was filming a segment for Access Hollywood. He briefly played Carmelo Anthony one on one and talked faux strategy with Coach Mike Woodson.

title: Little Farm
description: When you round a bend in Tilden Nature Area in Berkeley, the sound of bleating day-old lambs is a definite clue that you have left the city. You can smell the manure in the crisp morning air, as well as a whiff of hay. The Little Farm, which opened in 1955, decades before the current homesteading explosion, was built to teach urban children about food production. Most days, the swarms of youngsters now seem more interested in feeding the animals than in the origin of their meals.

title: A Fresh Discovery, Three Decades in the Making
description: The novelist Joe R. Lansdale, of Nacogdoches, has never been one of those authors determined to cultivate a reputation as a serious artist. He is much too busy writing: crime fiction and sci-fi fantasy, pulp tributes and young adult novels, comic books and horror stories.

title: Running for Congress Against Octogenarians
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: U.S. Defines Its Demands for New Round of Talks With Iran
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration and its European allies plan to open new negotiations with Iran by demanding the immediate closing and ultimate dismantling of a recently completed nuclear facility deep under a mountain, according to American and European diplomats.

title: As Large Companies Opt Out, Concerns Grow for Workers Compensation System
description: When Walmart, one of Texas largest private employers, dropped out of the states workers compensation system in March, it was a heavy blow to advocates of the system, who have watched more large companies offer private  and in many cases, less generous  injury benefits.

title: Tuna Again? In Fault-Finding England, Its a Cause for Divorce
description: LONDON  In her 30-odd years as a divorce lawyer, Vanessa Lloyd Platt has heard it all. The woman who sued for divorce because her husband insisted she dress in a Klingon costume and speak to him in Klingon. The man who declared that his wife had maliciously and repeatedly served him his least favorite dish, tuna casserole.

title: Meager Participation Hobbles Drug Oversight
description: Byung Sik Yuh, the owner of Nichols Hill pharmacy in Oakland, filled more than 5,000 online prescriptions for addictive painkillers before the California State Board of Pharmacy moved last year to revoke his license. The patients who picked up the prescriptions at Mr. Yuhs pharmacy had never met their doctors, nor had physical examinations. They filled out a brief online survey and paid an anonymous doctor to write prescriptions over the Internet.

title: The Short-Time Amateur
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  As far as final rounds as an amateur go, Kelly Kraft could certainly do worse: The 23-year-old U.S. Amateur champion will play Augusta National in the fourth round of the Masters on Sunday before officially beginning his professional career on Monday.

title: Hopeful Signs for a Homegrown Mets Roster
description: More and more these days, the Mets are feeling made in New York.

title: God Makes a Comeback
description: My Sunday column is about what seems a new intellectual wave  a measured respect for religion even among some atheists and agnostics. As I note in the column, the trend a few years ago was for best-sellers that denounced God and faith in the most caustic terms, but now  just in time for Easter and Passover  we have a series of books that dont exactly buy into God, but are still admiring of aspects of religion. Im happy with this trend, as a step toward civility and a bridge over the God Gulf  but whats your take? Read the column and post your thoughts, please.

title: Lundqvist Is Also a Sure Thing During the Awards Season
description: The end of the N.H.L. regular season on Saturday also marked the time when voters started casting their ballots for the leagues major awards. Here are the favorites.

title: Flustered Woods Loses Temper and More Ground
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Tiger Woods has heard crowds roar on the back nine at Augusta National for his entire professional life. Birdies at the 11th hole. Eagles on 13 or 15. Glorious championship walks up No. 18, the whistles from the fans cutting through the Sunday evening gloaming.

title: Donald Recalls the Awful Moment
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Luke Donald knows the exact moment he wrote off his chances of winning the Masters: When his second shot at the par-5 13th looked to have plenty of carry but hit the top edge of the bank in front of the green and rolled back into the water.

title: After Trying Stretch, Hughes Is Eager to Get Started on Fresh Season
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  The one good thing Phil Hughes thinks about last season is that it is over. It was a frustrating campaign for Hughes that included a stint on the disabled list from April 15 until July 6 with inflammation of his right shoulder.

title: Edward and the Elephant
description: Among the 67,000 sore, weary, traumatized Federal soldiers in Ulysses S. Grants army that followed the Confederate retreat back toward Corinth, Miss., after the battle of Shiloh was my great-great grandfather, Pvt. Edward D. Willis.

title: Welfare Limits Left Poor Adrift as Recession Hit
description: PHOENIX  Perhaps no law in the past generation has drawn more praise than the drive to end welfare as we know it, which joined the late-90s economic boom to send caseloads plunging, employment rates rising and officials of both parties hailing the virtues of tough love.

title: Rangers, With Eye on Top Spot in League, Fall Flat at the Finish Line
description: The Rangers came into Madison Square Garden for their season finale Saturday with a full lineup, hoping to clinch the Presidents Trophy as the N.H.L.s No. 1 team and enter the playoffs on a high note.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 7, 2012

title: The Puzzle of Measuring Poverty
description: Despite four years of economic distress, the welfare rolls have barely budged, as my article this weekend shows. Many researchers see evidence of growing destitution, but the resources of the very poor have become increasingly hard to measure. Different yardsticks show diverging trends.

title: It Looked Good on Paper
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  The third-round pairing of Sergio Garca and Rory McIlroy, the once and current European prodigies, looked great on paper. Once they teed off, in the third-to-last group, it proved hard to watch.

title: Leading From Behind
description: As the Rangers last man between opposing players shots and the back net, Henrik Lundqvist has led the team to the playoffs with stellar goaltending.

title: On TV, Bored Ex-Champion Turns to Fighting Crime
description: Chess is often a plot element in television dramas, but until Endgame premiered last year on the Canadian network Showcase, the game itself had never had a starring role.

title: Boston College Wins 5th Title, but Underdog Puts Up a Fight
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The expected coronation of Boston College as king of mens college hockey did not come without a struggle. The top-seeded Eagles were pushed to the limit but outlasted the underdog Ferris State, 4-1, in the Frozen Four title game Saturday night at Tampa Bay Times Forum.

title: A Friendship Dating to 1976 Resonates in 2012
description: The two young men had woefully little in common: one was a wealthy Mormon from Michigan, the other a middle-class Jew from Israel.

title: Yanks Rally Cant Offset Kurodas Shaky Start
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  When Hiroki Kuroda pitched for the Los Angeles Dodgers, runs were usually at a premium, and Kuroda pitched accordingly. He was precise and careful, knowing he had to limit damage early on because one run in the first inning might determine the outcome of the game.

title: Despite Deadly Fungus, Frog Imports Continue
description: A clerk serving Cantonese-speaking customers at a cluttered market in San Franciscos Chinatown reached into a tub of American bullfrogs. She drew a one-pound frog from the top of the pile. She whacked its head, sliced its neck and placed its body in a plastic grocery bag.

title: Police Suspect Single Gunman in Attacks in Oklahoma
description: The authorities in Tulsa, Okla., were scrambling on Saturday to find a man who they say opened fire on five people in four apparently random shootings a day before, killing three people and wounding two more.

title: Corrections: April 8
description: ARTS

title: Kira Krieger, Samuel Senders
description: Kira Krieger and Samuel Lawrence Senders were married Wednesday evening at the St. Regis Bal Harbour Resort in Bal Harbour, Fla. Rabbi Dovid Vigler officiated.

title: Courtney Morgan and Andrew Montgomery
description: Courtney McClung Morgan and Andrew William Montgomery are to be married Sunday evening at 632 on Hudson, an event space in New York. Dmitry A. Terekhov, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, is to officiate.

title: Laila Tabatabai and Shaan Raza
description: Dr. Laila Shaheen Tabatabai and Dr. Shaan Mohammed Raza were married Saturday at the Saratoga Hilton in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. Maulana Sakhawat Hussain, a Muslim cleric, performed the Shiite ceremony.

title: Jennifer Lenhart and Andrew Carranza
description: Jennifer Michele Lenhart and Andrew Richard Carranza were married Saturday on the Brooklyn Bridge. Eric Faison, a Universal Life Church minister and a friend of the couple, officiated.

title: Rene Robichaux, Guy Endore-Kaiser
description: Rene Michelle Robichaux, the daughter of Karen Kimbrell Robichaux and John V. Robichaux Jr. of New Orleans, was married there Saturday evening to Guy Endore-Kaiser, the son of Gita Endore and Michael N. Kaiser, both of Los Angeles. Judge Kirk A. Vaughn of Louisianas 34th Judicial District, who presides in Chalmette, La., officiated at the New Orleans Botanical Garden.

title: Shannon Liu, Hayes Shair
description: Shannon Liu and Hayes Shair were married Saturday at the Japanese Tea Garden at Central Park in San Mateo, Calif. The Rev. Donald A. Mulford, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Adria Waldbart, C. Allen Garrett Jr.
description: Adria Gayle Waldbart and C. Allen Garrett Jr. were married Saturday evening at the Old Courthouse on the Square, an event space and museum in Decatur, Ga. The Rev. David L. Bonselaar, a minister of the Reformed Church of America, officiated.

title: Showtime: A Japanese Star Is Ready for His Close-up
description: HONG KONG  Every baseball player who makes it to The Show has stellar credentials. All the pitchers in the major leagues have a zillion strikeouts, and all the hitters have piles of home runs or a great slugging percentage. Theyre also likely to have outstanding stats in categories like DIPS, OPS, BABIP and VORP  the arcane indices made popular by Moneyball.

title: A Chance to Unfreeze the Standoff on the Glacier
description: HONG KONG  The search for 135 people buried under an avalanche in Pakistan resumed at first light on Sunday.

title: U.S. Transfers Control of Night Raids to Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Accelerating the transition of military responsibility to the Afghan government, the United States agreed Sunday to hand control of special operations missions to Afghan forces, including night raids, relegating American troops to a supporting role and bringing the raids under Afghan judicial authority.

title: David Wilson, Fourth-Ranked Running Back in 2012 Draft
description: Matt Waldman is the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, a testament to his obsession with film analysis, now available for download.Examples of his work can be found at his blog. He is helping the Fifth Down rank skill position players before the draft:

title: As Russian Real Estate Money Floods in, Could New York Go the Way of London?
description: LONDON  The real estate market in the United States may still be slumping, but its high end is enjoying a remarkable updraft, propelled by money flowing in from all corners of the globe, including from developing countries like Brazil, China and India, writes our colleague Alexei Barrionuevo in his latest real estate piece. But no group is consistently writing bigger checks than the Russians.

title: Arrests in Shootings End a Terrifying Weekend in Tulsa
description: TULSA, Okla.  Late on Thursday afternoon, Jacob C. England, 19, posted a message on his Facebook page, expressing grief  and anger  over the second anniversary of his fathers death. Mr. Englands father, Carl, was shot on April 5, 2010, at an apartment complex here, and the man who was a person of interest in the case, Pernell Jefferson, is serving time at an Oklahoma state prison.

title: Santorum Takes Monday Off to Be With Daughter
description: Rick Santorum said in a statement issued late Saturday that he will not campaign on Monday so he can stay with his daughter Bella, who was hospitalized on Friday.

title: Unemployment and Inflation
description: I thought it might be useful to provide a bit of data context for my post on central bank mandates. What did we think we knew about unemployment and inflation?

title: Behind the Steering Wheel and Not a Grammarian in Sight
description: It was a dark Sunday evening in early October when Mark Vincent reluctantly set off on a city chore shared by some and lamented by many: moving his car to abide by alternate-side parking rules. Mr. Vincent lives in Park Slope, Brooklyn; his car is a maroon 1992 Honda that he and his wife inherited from her father after her father could no longer drive.

title: Overabundant Bunnies Find Off-Campus Haven
description: Its Easter weekend, so bunnies are in the news. This prompted me to check in on an issue I touched on in 2009, during a visit to the University of Victoria on Canadas Vancouver Island.

title: Indian and Pakistani Leaders Encourage Ties in a Rare Visit
description: NEW DELHI  In the first visit to India by a Pakistani head of state in seven years, President Asif Ali Zardari of Pakistan and Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India on Sunday expressed a mutual desire to improve relations between their rival South Asian nations, and Mr. Singh announced that he would at some point visit Pakistan for the first time since taking office.

title: Reactions to the Death of Mike Wallace, 60 Minutes Pioneer
description: 5:45 p.m. | Updated CBS News on Sunday morning put in motion its plans to honor Mike Wallace, a pioneer of American broadcasting who died on Saturday night. He was 93.

title: Disruptions: Too Much Silence on Working Conditions
description: 9:45 p.m. | Updated  to reflect the version published in the print edition.

title: Mike Wallace, CBS Pioneer of 60 Minutes, Dies at 93
description: Mike Wallace, the CBS reporter who became one of Americas best-known broadcast journalists as an interrogator of the famous and infamous on 60 Minutes, died on Saturday. He was 93.

title: Site Finds Home Hosts, Not Kennels, for Your Dog
description: Couchsurfing.org and Airbnb9.com offer home stays to travelers seeking an alternative to hotels. Now your dog can get a similar service: a home instead of a kennel.

title: Four Officers Are Shot in Brooklyn; Assailant Is Critically Wounded
description: The dispute began as a simple argument on the sidewalk: a couple with a baby stroller found the entrance to their home blocked by some movers. Words were exchanged. A gun was brandished.

title: Last Word: Mike Wallace
description: Mike Wallace, the tough-guy interrogator of 60 Minutes, was the personification of 20th-century television news. He made his name confronting the famous and infamous on camera.

title: Ryan, Obama, and Deficits
description: Hmm. Theres an obvious calculation I havent see done: how does the Ryan proposal scored more or less honestly  that is, without the mystery meat, the assumed revenue from closing loopholes that Ryan refuses to identity  compare with the Obama budget?

title: A Look Back 100 Years To Focus on the Titanic
description: The Titanic exhibition in Belfast opened late last month, promising the worlds largest display of materials on the ship built and launched from the city 100 years ago. But for Titanic buffs who cant make the trip to Ireland, a few exhibitions on our shores promise a look at the now mythic voyage.

title: South Korea Suspects That North May Test Nuclear Device as Well as Rocket
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea appears to be preparing for its third underground nuclear test even as it presses ahead with assembling a long-range rocket for its planned launching of a satellite this month, a South Korean government spokesman said Sunday.

title: Cricket and the Ajmer Sharif Shrine Bolster India Pakistan Relations
description: When Pakistans leaders visit India to try to bolster fragile relations between the two countries, both sides can always count on cricket and the famous shrine of Ajmer Sharif to provide the perfect cover for informal talks.

title: Mike Wallace, 1918-2012
description: Mike Wallace became one of the nations best-known broadcast journalists as an interrogator of the famous and infamous on 60 Minutes.

title: Cardinal Dolan Talks of Role of Religion in Politics
description: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan weighed in on the role of religion in politics in an Easter Sunday appearance on Face the Nation, pledging to fight President Obamas contraception policy and defending Rick Santorum over a comment that reading John F. Kennedys 1960 speech about the separation of church and state almost made him throw up.

title: The Hunger Games Surpasses $300 Million in North America
description: The kids of The Hunger Games, even in their third weekend in theaters, ran laps around the rested adults of American Reunion, selling an estimated $33.5 million in tickets to repeat as the No. 1 movie in North America.

title: Mickelson Has History for Him and Against Him
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  The final pairing Sunday has produced 19 of the past 21 Masters champions, which has many people here rushing to fit Phil Mickelson for his fourth green jacket. Mickelson is in the last group with Peter Hanson, who has his first lead in a major championship.

title: In Europe, Unease Over Bank Debt
description: PARIS  Only a few months ago, banks around the world were scrambling to sell piles of European government bonds that had lost value as the Continents sovereign debt crisis flared.

title: Pros Perspective: Liking Mickelsons Chances
description: Mark Calcavecchia won 13 PGA Tour titles, including the 1989 British Open. He almost won the 1988 Masters but settled for a runner-up finish when Sandy Lyle birdied the 18th hole from a fairway bunker. Calcavecchia is in his third season on the Champions Tour.

title: Measuring Up Citigroup and Bank of America
description: Bank of America used to be the stock Wall Street loved to hate. Citigroup, on the other hand, was supposed to be the troubled bank that had finally gotten its act together.

title: Out of the Woods and Into the Green Jacket
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Bubba Watson is an iconoclast in a sport of conformists, in possession of a swing that defies duplication and a mind so overactive that he has a hard time focusing for more than a few seconds.

title: Rangers First-Round Schedule
description: The Rangers series against Ottawa begins Thursday at Madison Square Garden. The complete first-round schedule:

title: 'Ghost: The Musical'
description: Scenes from the Broadway show at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater.

title: Devils First-Round Schedule
description: The Devils will open their first-round series with the Florida Panthers on Friday at the BankAtlantic Center. The complete first-round schedule:

title: 100 Years Ago, a Disaster Captivated the City
description: New York, the city, knew all about the Titanic before the problem with New York, the ship.

title: On Release Date, Crucial Nokia Phone Is Hard to Buy in New York
description: 4:11 p.m. | UpdatedAdding analyst commentary and details about Nokia party.

title: How It Met Big Ratings 7 Years Into Its Run
description: In what amounts to late middle age in television the CBS comedy How I Met Your Mother suddenly finds itself a hit.

title: A Fresh Look at How Humans Are Loading Climate Dice
description: April 10, 12:28 p.m. | Updated I talk about loaded climate dice and March heat records on The Takeaway:

title: Hole in One Highlights Van Pelts Late Charge
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Bo Van Pelts 5-year-old son, Crew, recently asked his dad if he had ever made a hole in one. Van Pelt told him yes, actually, he had made seven, five of them in professional tour events.

title: German Courts at Epicenter of Global Patent Battles Among Tech Rivals
description: BERLIN  Is Germanys system of litigating disputes over patents bad for business?

title: Work Doesnt Stop for Cink After a Dismal Third Round
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Convention holds that the Masters doesnt begin until the back nine Sunday. For the former Georgia Tech star Stewart Cink, it essentially ended on the front nine Saturday when he shot a five-over 41 on his way to an 81. He rebounded with a closing 69 to finish at eight over.

title: Egyptian Presidential Candidate Carries Banner of the Old Order
description: CAIRO  Former President Hosni Mubaraks intelligence chief and vice president filed papers in Egypt on Sunday declaring himself a presidential candidate. His entry gives Egyptians a chance to cast a vote against the revolution and for the old order.

title: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include wholesale trade inventories for February (Tuesday); import prices for March and the Federal Reserves beige book (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, the Producer Price Index for March and the trade deficit for February (Thursday); the Consumer Price Index for March and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for April (Friday).

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Edoardo Molinari Has Had Enough of the Masters
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Edoardo Molinari signed for his final-round two-over-par 74 a few minutes before his younger brother, Francesco, teed off with his playing partner, Ian Poulter. He said the two were staying in separate residences and hadnt spoken since Saturday night.

title: Foundation Files Reveal Insights on Culture
description: James Baldwin needed some money.

title: Anything You Can Do, I Can Do in a Glowing Squiggle
description: Decadancetheatre, a Brooklyn group started by Jennifer Weber in 2004, has an admirable purpose: to redefine the image of women in hip-hop. Ms. Webers work goes against what is often an unfortunate sight: female dancers feigning toughness in baggy pants and baseball caps. In the past she has taken on Stravinskys Firebird and Jerome Robbinss Cage. She doesnt have a one-note mind.

title: Singing of Beasts and Battle, With Folky Starts and Arena Finishes
description: Iceland could be a British isle or a Canadian province for Of Monsters and Men, the Icelandic band that headlined Webster Hall on Friday night. Of Monsters and Men connects two strains of Celtic-rooted music that spur robust, foot-stamping singalongs: the sea chantey and the arena-rock chorus, the folky and the anthemic. Its songs regularly ascend from guitar-strumming, accordion-tootling openings to brawny rock marches topped by la-las for the crowd to join, a strategy also used by Mumford & Sons, the Decemberists, Arcade Fire and, in decades past, the Scottish band Big Country.

title: Jackson Heights Ambassador of Yoga
description: Muhammad Rashid adopted yoga into his daily routine and has encouraged other Muslims to do so, challenging those who view yoga as a sin against Islam.

title: Seeking to Clear a Path Between Yoga and Islam
description: As a community activist in Queens, Muhammad Rashid has fought for the rights of immigrants held in detention, sought the preservation of local movie theaters and held a street fair to promote diversity.

title: Anthony at His Best Against the Best
description: Carmelo Anthony was dancing, spinning, hopping and hollering, a fountain of bravado and joy, a star on a mission, a force unleashed. The moment suited him.

title: Googles Washington Night
description: LOS ANGELES  The annual White House Correspondents Association dinner is Hollywoods big night in Washington.

title: After Three Games, the Yankees Are Still Looking for a Win
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Of all the openings the Yankees and their fans could have envisioned for the 2012 season, a three-game losing streak was probably one that few entertained.

title: No-Hit Bid Silenced, Mets Still Make Noise
description: There was a familiar clash of emotions creeping through Citi Field on Sunday afternoon, a mixture of Could it be? and Here we go again. The Mets have never had a pitcher throw a no-hitter, and each potential bid now is fraught with the cumulative weight of each previous disappointment.

title: Origin of Speciousness
description: I was unhappy with President Obamas decision to call Republicans social Darwinists  not because I thought it was wrong, but because I wondered how many voters would get his point. How many people know who Herbert Spencer was?

title: Jump, Twirl, Paint, Act!
description: LONDON  Seventy Shakespeare productions from companies around the world, performed in 30 theaters all over Britain. A 33-foot-high puppet of Lady Godiva (wearing undergarments by the fashion designer Zandra Rhodes) moving through the streets of Coventry and into London, powered by 50 people on bicycles. Music from everywhere performed free in choice spots up and down the Thames.

title: Serena Williams Continues Dominance to Win Family Circle Title
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  On what has long been her shakiest surface, Serena Williams looked as solid as she ever had Sunday.

title: Lessons From Ants to Grasp Humanity
description: To the biologist Edward O. Wilson, the Metropolitan Museum of Art encapsulates some of the conflicting impulses natural selection has instilled in humans: the innate drive for expression that spurs some of us to make art, the selfishness that motivates others to earn the riches needed to collect it, and the altruism that compels the donation of collections for the public good  as long as the donors names are inscribed on the walls too.

title: Fifth Avenue, 12:32 P.M.
Care for Romance and Acrobatics With Your Ceviche?
description: CHICAGO  Dinner theater, that derided and mostly moribund genre, is making an unlikely comeback at the Lookingglass Theater here, where one of this citys most renowned chefs, Rick Bayless, is preparing a savory meal onstage, and doing a modest bit of acting in a modest little comedy too.

title: London 2012 Festival
description: A look at some of the works in the eight-week festival of cultural events before, during and after the Olympics.

title: A Diva Dips Into Indie Rock and Musical Theater
description: Not quite two years ago the soprano Rene Fleming released an album that constituted the biggest surprise of a noteworthy career: Dark Hope, a collection of rock songs in plush arrangements, came out on Decca in June 2010. Most of the indie-rock acts represented on the disc, like Arcade Fire and the Mars Volta, were urged upon her by Q Prime, the pop-music management firm that hatched the idea.

title: Seattle Reporter Finds Bubbles of Corruption Under the Space Needle
description: There they are, thick on the ground in Jim Lynchs Truth Like the Sun: setups for familiar plot twists that allow a novel to trudge forward on autopilot, delivering nothing of value to either reader or author. Mr. Lynchs book, very good to begin with, is all the better for not exploiting such cheap tricks.

title: A Puzzle That Makes Sense
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Tasty! And a nice way to start our new solving week.

title: In Verdis Parisian Social Whirl, a Star Shines, Then Plummets in Flames
description: In the opening moments of Willy Deckers striking modern production of Verdis Traviata, the dying courtesan Violetta moves slowly across the stage toward a huge ticking clock that symbolizes her mortality, her bright red dress a solitary splash of color against a barren white wall. Her loneliness amid the bourgeois claustrophobia of the Parisian beau monde is evocatively realized in this alluring staging, which returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Friday evening.

title: As Technology Evolves, AT&T Adjusts a Theme
description: AT&T is rethinking Rethink possible.

title: Surprising Disparity at the Spring Nationals
description: A deal is played in the same strain at both tables in a match. The two opening leads are identical. What has been the greatest disparity in the number of tricks ever won?

title: Arrests in Case of Chinese Artifacts
description: Two men and a woman were arrested on Saturday in connection with a museum theft of two Chinese artifacts with a combined estimated worth of $3.2 million, The Associated Press reported. A large jade water bowl inscribed with a Chinese poem dating to 1769 and a Dehua porcelain sculpture were taken from the Oriental Museum at Durham University in England after thieves broke into a ground-floor gallery on Thursday night. Craig Barclay, the museum curator, confirmed in a statement that both items were from the Qing dynasty, 1644 to 1912, the last imperial dynasty in China. Police officials said that the items had not been recovered, and that they were attempting to locate several other suspects.

title: Supremacy in Jeopardy for Today
description: These days, the effervescent smiles on the Today show, Americas most popular morning television companion, are concealing anxiety.

title: NBCs Today Wins a Ratings Showdown
description: Today removed any doubt that it would win its weeklong showdown against Good Morning America by scoring its biggest ratings win of the week on Thursday morning. Today, long the ratings leader, topped Good Morning America by 435,000 total viewers Thursday and by 227,000 in the age group preferred by advertisers, viewers between 25 and 54. Both totals were the biggest of the week. To try to close the ratings gap of many years between the two programs, Good Morning America brought in the former Today star Katie Couric as a guest host, a move that Today countered with a widely publicized appearance by Sarah Palin as guest host on Tuesday. Today won the first two mornings of the week by totals in the 300,000 range; Good Morning America won Wednesday by 87,000.

title: Newspaper Barons Resurface
description: Is there anything more forlorn than the American metropolitan newspaper? First readers began deserting in droves, then the advertisers followed. Family owners headed for the exits and then hedge funds and other financial players scooped up newspapers thinking they were buying at the bottom of the market. Greater fools came and went, each saying they could cut their way to former glory and renewed profitability. They got a haircut instead.

title: Berkeley Rep Workshop
description: The Berkeley Repertory Theater is set to announce Monday that a group of 40 writers, directors and composers will gather there this summer in an effort to develop 13 new projects for the stage. The four-week creative workshop, the Ground Floor, is designed to provide the artists with the space and resources to hone their work. It will include things like The Food Project, a series of short dining-centric scripts from 20 playwrights including Julia Cho (The Language Archive), David Edgar (Continental Divide) and Amy Freed (Freedomland); and plays from Marcus Gardley (On the Levee) and Dan LeFranc (Sixty Miles to Silver Lake) commissioned by the theater.

title: Leaving Las Vegas: The Telethon
description: The Muscular Dystrophy Association will move its Labor Day telethon this year to the Los Angeles area from Las Vegas, The Associated Press reported. A spokeswoman for the Muscular Dystrophy Association declined to provide details. But an official at the South Point Hotel Casino and Spa, where the telethon has been held for six years, confirmed the move. The organization made another big change last year when it announced that the comedian Jerry Lewis would not host the telethon for the first time since 1966. The 2011 show was six hours long and used several hosts, raising $61.5 million, according to telethon officials.

title: Bands Improvise New Ways to Live-Stream Shows
description: For music fans, more and more consumption these days happens through online streaming services like Pandora, Spotify and TuneIn. But when it comes to live shows theres not much out there: for the most part, only big festivals and promoters have had the resources to send as-it-happens audio over the Internet.

title: North Korea Prepares Rocket Launch
description: North Korea on Sunday continued to prepare for a rocket launch that officials say will carry a weather satellite, a claim the United States doubts.

title: A Caregivers Decision to End Two Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: Lin Is Happy With Recovery So Far
description: Six days removed from surgery, an upbeat Jeremy Lin said Sunday he nearly had full range of motion in his left knee and was biking and walking with ease. Basketball, however, remains a ways off.

title: Returning Migrants
description: To the Editor:

title: Obama and the Budget
description: To the Editor:

title: Apps Take Positions in the Topps Baseball Lineup
description: This baseball season, one of the games most beloved and bygone traditions will try for a comeback: the baseball card.

title: Creating a New Taxi
description: To the Editor:

title: Talking About Gun Control
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel Bars German Laureate Grass Over Poem
description: JERUSALEM  Israels interior minister declared Gnter Grass, one of Germanys best-known authors, unwelcome in Israel on Sunday, barring him from entering the country for a poem that accused Israel of being a threat to world peace.

title: Private Equity Firms Duel Over Water Park Operator
description: It is rare to see private equity firms lock horns in a public bidding war. But a heated auction appears to be brewing for Great Wolf Resorts, the big indoor water park operator.

title: Borrowing Costs Rising for Governments
description: Borrowing Costs Rising for Governments

title: Owner Had Right to Clear Zuccotti Park, Judge Says
description: A judge in Manhattan has ruled that Brookfield Properties, owner of the park used as an encampment by Occupy Wall Street protesters, had the right to clear them to address deteriorating conditions inside the park.

title: Treasury and Bond Auctions Scheduled for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Protecting Face-to-Face Protest
description: Tuscaloosa, Ala.

title: I.B.M. Executive Just Another Face in the Crowd
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  The Masters tournament concluded Sunday, but the most talked-about issue of the last week  the lack of female members at Augusta National Golf Club  seems likely to linger.

title: Eighth Place Is Good for Nostalgia but Little Else
description: As the final seconds of overtime ticked away, as Tyson Chandler twice saved the misfiring Knicks on the offensive glass, as the ball found its way into Carmelo Anthonys hands on the far right wing, the thought had to occur to the returning Larry Johnson sitting at courtside and anyone else who was in the building on a particular tension-filled night in June 1999.

title: Dental Insurance, but No Dentists
description: Atlanta

title: F.C.C. Pushes for Web Site on TV Political Ad Spending
description: The government is moving forward with a plan to make local television stations post information about political advertising on a central Web site.

title: At Texas Schools, Making Do on a Shoestring
description: HUTTO, Tex.  School buses passed by 16-year-old Aubrey Sandifer as he walked home one recent afternoon in this rural town northeast of Austin.

title: Peter Douglas, Sentry of Californias Coast, Dies at 69
description: Peter Douglas, who fought for decades to preserve the California coast  treasured for its vast stretches of pristine beaches, jagged cliffs and delicate wetlands  died on April 1 at his sisters home in La Quinta, Calif. He was 69.

title: Begrudging the Wildcats Success and Opportunities
description: A new baseball season is under way, the N.B.A. is headed toward another exciting finish, and yet the University of Kentuckys success in mens basketball has sparked outrage that lingers a week after the national championship game.

title: Banker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy
description: PRESIDENT OBAMA recently nominated Jim Yong Kim, the president of Dartmouth, to be the next president of the World Bank  a privilege accorded to the United States since the banks founding in 1946. A European, in turn, gets to run the International Monetary Fund.

title: Kenneth Libo, Scholar of Immigrant Life, Dies at 74
description: Kenneth Libo, a historian of Jewish immigration who, as a graduate student working for Irving Howe in the 1960s and 70s, unearthed historical documentation that informed and shaped World of Our Fathers, Mr. Howes landmark 1976 history of the East European Jewish migration to America, died on March 29 in New York. He was 74.

title: Tightening the Lid on Pain Prescriptions
description: SEATTLE  It was the type of conversation that Dr. Claire Trescott dreads: telling physicians that they are not cutting it.

title: How to Fix the World Bank
description: FOR the first time since the World Banks creation at the end of World War II, the United States is facing a real challenge over the banks leadership. Leaders of some developing and emerging economies have refused to support President Obamas unexpected choice of Jim Yong Kim, the president of Dartmouth College, to lead the bank.

title: My Beautiful Cushy Tushy
description: When my younger daughter was about four years old, she stood in our kitchen, pulled up her shirt and popped her tummy straight out. It was impressive, that round little belly. I smiled, and she grinned back. Thats as cute as I can make it, she said proudly.

title: Roger Furst Dies at 78; Equipped Mountaineers in the Northeast
description: Roger Furst, one of two fishing buddies who founded the Eastern Mountain Sports retail chain, which has equipped thousands of people to trek deep into the mountains, ski in the backcountry or scale a peak, died on March 16 in Sherman, Tex., a day after his 78th birthday.

title: The Gullible Center
description: So, can we talk about the Paul Ryan phenomenon?

title: A Gadget Processional and Other Reader Tales
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: What Is a Megabyte?
description: Everyone with a mobile device is going to have to start paying more attention as wireless carriers turn to limited data plans. But how many megabytes are in a movie?

title: For Lindsey Vonn, Professional Triumph and Personal Turmoil
description: VAIL, Colo.  Skiing in the mountains above the Vail resort last week, Lindsey Vonn slowed to a stop at the top of a trail named in her honor after she won the 2010 womens Olympic downhill.

title: Quiz: Do You Know Your Data?
description: What is a megabyte? And how many does it take to watch one movie? With cellphone carriers offering increasingly complex data plans, people are being forced to think about how they are using the Internet on their smartphones.

title: Do You Need That Test?
description: If health care costs are ever to be brought under control, the nations doctors will have to play a leading role in eliminating unnecessary treatments. By some estimates, hundreds of billions of dollars are wasted this way every year. So it is highly encouraging that nine major physicians groups have identified 45 tests and procedures (five for each specialty) that are commonly used but have no proven benefit for many patients and sometimes cause more harm than good.

title: A Ballooning Megabyte Budget
description: Everyone knows how long a minute is. And your cellphone carrier keeps close tabs on how many you have used this month. Now, in the smartphone era, more people are being forced to think about how many megabytes of data they are using.

title: Taking Credit Where None Is Due
description: As Fridays jobless numbers showed, the economic recovery has been listless and fragile, but its upward trajectory has been clear enough that Republicans have been forced to acknowledge it. To avoid giving President Obama the slightest bit of credit for the improvement, however, they have come up with increasingly convoluted explanations that have little relationship to reality.

title: Keeping Students Mental Health Care Out of the E.R.
description: During the 2010-11 school year, Adeline Seises son Gabriel, a second grader, repeatedly disrupted classes at Public School 67 in the Bronx.

title: Volunteers Scramble to Save a School for Immigrants
description: As a result of the economic downturn and a dwindling endowment, the International Center, which has taught English and helped immigrants assimilate for decades, faces dissolution and eviction from its Manhattan home.

title: Children Can Never Be Safe in Adult Prisons
description: After an unconscionable delay of nearly three years, the Justice Department needs to issue the final, mandatory rape-prevention policies for federal prisons and state correctional institutions that receive federal dollars. They must improve on the proposed rules issued last spring.

title: Detour on Fourth Hole Costs Mickelson His Chance
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  As Phil Mickelson stared after his tee shot at Augusta Nationals par-3 fourth hole Sunday, his face was calm, calm and then  suddenly  twisted in despair.

title: In Russia, Charges Are Dropped in Jail Death
description: MOSCOW  Russian investigators have dropped the charges against a former prison doctor who was one of only two people to face punishment in the death of a 37-year-old lawyer whose arrest and maltreatment underscored the selective and sometimes brutal nature of Russias justice system.

title: Financing for Job Programs Has Declined
description: Federal funds for some training and job search programs have fallen even as more people have lost jobs. Figures below are adjusted for inflation.

title: Big Warning on Little Fish
description: There is more to smart fishery management than protecting the big, delicious species, like striped bass, cod, tuna and salmon. A huge and growing portion of the worlds commercial catch  37 percent by weight  is made up of small fish, like herring, sardines, anchovies and menhaden, which are food for larger predators.

title: Federal Funds to Train the Jobless Are Drying Up
description: With the economy slowly reviving, an executive from Atlas Van Lines recently visited Louisville, Ky., with good news: the company wanted to hire more than 100 truck drivers ahead of the summer moving season.

title: Super PAC, Eyeing General Election, Aims Blitz at Obama
description: American Crossroads, the biggest of the Republican super PACs, is planning to begin its first major anti-Obama advertising blitz of the year, a moment the Obama re-election campaign has been girding for and another sign that the general election is starting in earnest.

title: The Taint of Social Darwinism
description: Given the well-known Republican antipathy to evolution, President Obamas recent description of the Republican budget as an example of social Darwinism may be a canny piece of political labeling. In the interests of historical accuracy, however, it should be clearly recognized that social Darwinism has very little to do with the ideas developed by Charles Darwin in On the Origin of Species. Social Darwinism emerged as a movement in the late 19th-century, and has had waves of popularity ever since, but its central ideas owe more to the thought of a luminary of that time, Herbert Spencer, whose writings are (to understate) no longer widely read.

title: Corrections: April 9
description: FRONT PAGE

title: On Easter Sunday, Tebow Is a Headliner
description: GEORGETOWN, Tex.  Tim Tebow fans embraced the opportunity to don their new Jets finery and celebrate Easter with him at an outdoor service that drew thousands of worshipers Sunday.

title: Data Scientists Get Ranked
description: What is the best way to rank statisticians? When you do find the best of a batch, are they, on average, out of the ordinary?

title: Rose Returns, but the Rust Shows
description: Late in the first quarter on Sunday at Madison Square Garden, the Chicago Bulls, the team with the best record in the N.B.A., were shooting 8 percent from the field. The Knicks were shooting 71-percent and had raced to a 22-6 lead.

title: AccentHealth Puts Medical Content on Waiting Room TVs
description: Patients sitting in waiting rooms are often relegated to watching television or reading well-worn magazines to pass the time. But in many doctors offices these days, the standard television offerings like daytime talk shows are giving way to a more focused kind of programming: health content.

title: Tradition and Boat Race Both Upended on the Thames
description: LONDON  It is, in its way, one of Britains great anachronisms: a university boat race steeped in pageantry and tradition with nothing but honor at stake, a moment when old buffers in satin-trimmed blazers can revel in upper-crust camaraderie and pretend that the important things in the world remain much as they were when the race was first run in 1829.

title: Serena Williams Captures First Clay Title Since 2008
description: Serena Williams emphatically defeated Lucie Safarova, 6-0, 6-1, to win the final of the Family Circle Cup in 58 minutes on Sunday in Charleston, S.C. It was her first clay-court title since winning the tournament in 2008; only 4 of her 40 career titles have come on clay.

title: Are Some Buildings Too Ugly to Survive?
Long Waiting Lists Again for Kindergarten Seats
Lottery Numbers
description: April 8, 2012

title: City to Install Smart Screens in Some Public Phone Booths
description: It is an emblem from a bygone era: the outdoor pay phone. For more than a century, in booths along New York Citys sidewalks, public telephones have connected residents, one pocketful of change at a time.

title: M.L.S. Week 6: Henry Simply Sublime
description: At the rate Thierry Henry is going, the Red Bulls might want to consider allowing him free rein to spend the off-season in London, or any other place he pleases.

title: Romney the Centrist Peeks Out
description: It was just one line slipped into the middle of a paragraph of Mitt Romneys speech on April 3 celebrating his primary victories in Wisconsin, Maryland and the District of Columbia: And the most vulnerable have been hurt the most  over 30 percent of single moms are struggling in poverty.

title: California May Close a Home to Its Past
description: WHITTIER, Calif.  Here, in an adobe home now tucked between a freeway and a railroad, once sat the last governor of Alta California, as it was known under Mexican rule. The governor, Po de Jess Pico, was one of the richest men in the area, his ranchito stretching for nearly 9,000 acres.

title: Masters Replay: April 8
description: A look at the final round of the Masters, won by Bubba Watson in a sudden-death playoff against Louis Oosthuizen.

title: Nokia Lumia 900 Advertisement
description: A new commercial from AT&T for the Nokia Lumia 900 smartphone.

title: Ex-K.G.B. Agent Said to Win South Ossetia Presidency
description: MOSCOW  Early results from a fourth round of voting in South Ossetia on Sunday indicated that the former K.G.B. official Leonid Tibilov had been elected president, bringing an end to a long, tumultuous campaign season that proved an embarrassment to Moscow, the regions source of military and financial support.

title: Comedy Timing Is Bad as News and Film Collide
description: LOS ANGELES  In the normal course of things a Hollywood movie about space aliens wouldnt be affected by newspaper headlines.

title: Americas Place in the New World
description: Its election season again, and the main contenders for the Oval Office are knocking themselves out to reassure Americans that their nation remains at the pinnacle of the global pecking order, Charles A. Kupchan writes in Sunday Review of The New York Times. Mitt Romney recently declared that this century must be an American century. Not to be outdone, President Obama insisted in his State of the Union address that anyone who tells you that America is in decline doesnt know what theyre talking about, Mr. Kupchan writes.

title: Mad Men Recap: A Fever Dream and Spooky Reality
description: Season 5, Episode 3

title: Indian and Pakistani Leaders Encourage Ties in a Rare Visit
description: In the first visit to India by a Pakistani head of state in seven years, President Asif Ali Zardari of Pakistan and Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India on Sunday expressed a mutual desire to improve relations between their rival South Asian nations, and Mr. Singh announced that he would at some point visit Pakistan for the first time since taking office, Jim Yardley writes in The New York Times.

title: Still on Red Alert Over Green-on-Blue Attacks
description: HONG KONG  The new agreement that gives Afghan forces more control over controversial night raids against suspected insurgents could also serve to reduce the stress levels between Afghan and American troops. But the strategic corporal in the field is ever more vigilant and wary.

title: Seeking to Clear a Path Between Yoga and Islam
description: As a community activist in Queens, Muhammad Rashid has fought for the rights of immigrants held in detention, sought the preservation of local movie theaters and held a street fair to promote diversity,  Sarah Maslin Nir writes in The New York Times. But few of those causes brought him anywhere near as much grief and controversy as his stance on yoga.

title: U.S. Said to Have Picked an Ambassador to Myanmar
description: HONG KONG  It appears that the United States will soon name Derek J. Mitchell as the new ambassador to Myanmar, according to Josh Rogin on The Cable blog of Foreign Policy magazine. The report was confirmed by The Financial Times.

title: Iranian Officials Send Mixed Signals as Nuclear Talks Near Resumption
description: LONDON  A senior Iranian official hinted on Monday that Iran would consider limits on its home-grown stockpile of enriched uranium, offering what seemed a modest compromise to partly meet Western concerns ahead of the planned resumption this week of nuclear talks with a group of six global powers.

title: Camera in the Net? Might Just Work
description: As a youngster in the late 1950s, Barton Silverman used a discount card to get into New York Rangers games at Madison Square Garden for half price. Fittingly, he could see only half the game. The balcony overrode the ice and the balcony blocked one half of the ice, he said.

title: For Bilawal Bhutto Zardari and Rahul Gandhi, Divergent Public Styles
description: It did not take Bilawal Bhutto Zardari long during his first visit to India to show he is a very different type of political prince than Rahul Gandhi  at least when it comes to public relations. The moment the son of Pakistans president, Asif Ali Zardari, and the late former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto landed Sunday in New Delhi, he launched what became a daylong monologue on Twitter.

title: As I Narrow My College Choices, the Indecision Increases
description: April 1 has come and gone, and unfortunately my indecision has increased tenfold.

title: Syrian Troops Fire Across Turkish Border in Clash Near Refugee Camp
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The deadly confrontation between Syria and opposition groups spilled into Turkey for the first time on Monday as Syrian forces fired across the border near a refugee camp, casting a further pall over prospects for a United Nations peace plan due to be put into effect this week.

title: This Week in Small Business: Meatball or Sausage?
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

description: If youre worried that youre not cool because you dont have a tattoo, and also worried about everything else, here are some stress-free suggestions for getting inked (after youve researched the ink to make sure it isnt carcinogenic).

title: A Reporter, in Iran in 1978, Will Cover F1 in Bahrain in 2012
description: Updated | April 12, 2012  Thanks for these comments, all. I have been traveling most of the time since this went up on the site, so I have not had time to respond. I am now in China, spent the day in the F1 paddock, and of course there has been no final and definitive decision yet about Bahrain, although Bernie Ecclestone says it is up to the Bahrainis to decide. Will post if any major news occurs.Thanks again.Brad

description: The other day, a ninth-grade student e-mailed me to ask about the plight of the bluefin tuna. What, he wanted to know, should the government be doing to help keep those endangered fish alive?

title: AOL Strikes $1.1 Billion Patent Deal With Microsoft
description: 11:15 a.m. | Updated

title: A.F.C. West Team Needs
description: We continue our pre-draft hidden needs series with a look at Tim Tebows old division.

title: Daily Report: How Much Data?
description: More people these days are being forced to think about how many megabytes of data they are using on their smartphones and tablets, unless they want to pay huge, unexpected charges in their monthly bill, reports Brian X. Chen in Mondays New York Times. But there is no intuitive or natural way to figure out how much data you are using.
