description: TOP STORIES

title: How a Photo of Joel Klein Saved a Teacher's Job
Saul Gootnick: 'You Have to Do Baby Steps'
The Empathy Gap
description: In general, Im a numbers and concepts guy, not a feelings guy; when I go after someone like Paul Ryan, I emphasize his irresponsibility and dishonesty, not his evident lack of empathy for the less fortunate.

title: A Protest Movements Second Wind?
description: MOSCOW  Day 24 is over, Oleg Shein wrote in his blog just after midnight on April 8. Tomorrow is Day 25. We are not on a suicide mission. Nor are we on a mission to make me the mayor. We are on a mission to secure fair elections that will put an end to the mafia system of government in Astrakhan.

title: Morning T | Mlanie Laurent
description: The actress Mlanie Laurent talks about her latest film, Les Adopts; her new role as the face of an iconic Dior fragrance; and the benefits of being free.

title: Lets Blame the Unions
description: A good article in the Times about the terrible state of Texas schools  followed by a truly awful comment thread, in which many readers rush to blame, you guessed it, teachers unions.

title: Considering the Victims of a Sexual-Misconduct Nightmare
description: In the sexual-misconduct nightmare that has forced the citys school system to wake up to distasteful realities, there are several models to consider. Two that come to mind are The Childrens Hour and the Roman Catholic Church in America.

title: Do You Know Who Died?
description: Heavy boots woke me. They struck the floor upstairs like mallets on a wooden gong. They paced the room above, paused, then paced back again.

title: Gervais Says New Show Isnt Mocking Disabled People
description: It wouldnt be a new Ricky Gervais project if that British comedian werent pre-emptively defending it against accusations of insensitivity, would it? In this latest instance Mr. Gervais, the veteran Golden Globes host and creator and star of comedies like The Office and Extras, is standing up for a new series, Derek, that has potential viewers concerned that it may be making fun of disabled people, BBC News reported.

title: Weak Jobs Report Sends Shares Lower for 4th Day
description: A disappointing jobs report, the latest sign of an uncertain economic recovery, set off the fourth consecutive daily decline for stocks on Monday.

title: Morning Buzz, April 9: Trying to Save the G Train
description: Good morning. Its a blustery day, with highs in the low 60s. Hold onto your hats.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: News Intrudes on a Summer Comedy, and Recalling Mike Wallace
description: Executives at 20th Century Fox have been quickly rethinking the marketing strategy for its summer comedy Neighborhood Watch in light of the shooting of Trayvon Martin by George Zimmerman, a community watch participant in Sanford, Fla., who has said he acted in self-defense, Michael Cieply writes. Fox last month pre-emptively withdrew its trailers and advertising materials for the movie, which features Ben Stiller and Vince Vaughn as four suburban watch members who fight an invasion by space aliens. The new marketing focus will play up the alien invasion aspect of the story.

title: Monday Reading: The Easiest Way to Cheat on Your Taxes
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Romney Pulls Negative Ad Amid Bella Santorum Illness
description: 9:40 p.m. | Updated The full version of this post is available here.

title: AT&T Sells Majority Stake in Yellow Pages to Cerberus
description: AT&T said on Monday that it had agreed to sell a majority stake in its yellow pages business to Cerberus Capital Management for about $950 million, giving the private equity firm an opportunity to resuscitate a declining operation.

title: The Kindest Cut
description: Until a few weeks ago, the last time I subjected my hair to a major cut was 1989. At 35, I had been spending my summer at the bedside of my mother, who was dying of an inoperable brain tumor.

title: New Herman Wouk Novel, The Lawgiver, Coming From Simon & Schuster
description: Simon & Schuster will release a new novel by Herman Wouk, the 96-year-old Pulitzer Prize-winning author of The Caine Mutiny, the publisher said on Monday.

title: Documentary Is Another Voice in the Underage Model Conversation
description: The documentary Girl Model opens with hundreds of scantily clad adolescent and teenage girls lined up in an auditorium. A model scout calls models one-by-one to the stage and begins commenting on their weight, body shape and signs of acne.

title: Antidepressants Can Raise Blood Pressure During Pregnancy
description: Taking antidepressants during pregnancy raises the risk of high blood pressure in expectant mothers, a new study shows.

title: A Living Autopsy of the Ron Paul Campaign
description: The Republican primary has reached an endgame. Mitt Romney has turned his attention to President Obama and the general election. Rick Santorum is trying to remain relevant. And Newt Gingrich has downsized his campaign.

title: In South Korea Scandal, Echoes of Watergate
description: SEOUL, South Korea  An unfolding political scandal ahead of Wednesdays parliamentary elections has many South Koreans drawing comparisons to Watergate: illicit surveillance, an attempted cover-up, destruction of evidence, arrests of people connected to the president  and questions over what the president himself may have known.

title: Lineup Unveiled for Inaugural Montclair Film Festival
description: A premiere screening of Tiger Eyes, a film adaptation of the novel by the New Jersey native Judy Blume that was directed by her son, Lawrence Blume, is among the Garden State-centric events planned for the first Montclair Film Festival, its organizers announced on Monday. The festival, which will run in Montclair, N.J., from May 1 through 6 (and bills itself with the cheeky slogan Its Sundance. Only Jersier), will open with a gala screening of The Oranges, the Julian Farino comedy set in suburban New Jersey and starring Hugh Laurie, Leighton Meester and Oliver Platt. Other events include a tribute to Kathleen Turner on May 2, which will feature a live interview with that actress; a May 3 screening of Cloudburst that will be attended by its star, Olympia Dukakis; a comedy event called The What-Is-It?, featuring commentary on esoteric film clips by the Daily Show producers Rory Albanese and Adam Lowitt; and conversations with the actor Patrick Wilson, the director Michael Moore, and Michael E. Uslan, a producer of The Dark Knight and The Dark Knight Rises. A complete lineup can be found at montclairfilmfest.org.

title: Business Day Live | April 9, 2012
description: Tightening the lid on pain prescriptions | Sam Grobart on why it is time to think about how much data you use on your smartphone | David Carr looks at the return of newspaper barons.

title: Business Day Live: A Ballooning Megabyte Budget
description: Efforts to curb over-prescribed prescription drugs; Sam Grobart on how much data you use on your smartphone; and David Carr looks at the return of newspaper barons.

title: Tumi Sets I.P.O. Price Range at $15 to $17
description: Tumi said it expected to price its initial public offering at $15 to $17 a share, providing a nice exit for the luggage makers controlling shareholder, Doughty Hanson, a London-based private equity firm that acquired the company in 2004.

title: Its Over. For Balotelli and City, City and Balotelli
description: 3:22 p.m. |Update

title: Ford Recalls 140,000 Focus Models for Potential Wiper-Motor Failure
description: Ford is recalling about 140,000 Focus models from the 2012 model year because the windshield wiper on the passenger side could fail.

title: AOL-Microsoft Deal Shows Patent Frenzy Remains Strong
description: The gold rush for patents continues.

title: What Were Reading
description: Los Angeles Times: A secret dinner in which the star ingredient is an herb associated more with brownies than fine cuisine. Jonathan Gold reports.  Eric Asimov

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: John Anagnost joined XplusOne, New York, in a new post, vice president of sales for the Eastern region. He had been president at Reprise Media, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Notes From the Underground | Hunx and His Punx
description: I learned two things at the recent Hunx and His Punx show at the Echo in Los Angeles. 1. I am too old to mosh. 2. Having a flamboyantly gay lead singer no longer poses any limitations whatsoever on a bands demographic reach. People from every possible walk of life crammed the floor in front of the stage, from gutter punks to frat boys, all of them worshiping at the altar of adorable feyness that is Seth Bogart and his Punx. Looking like a scrawny version of a Tom of Finland drawing, and sporting costumes designed by the one and only Peggy Noland, Hunx steered the crowd into a frenzied surge. The passion very nearly swallowed me whole. With squawking, cheeky lyrics that poked fun at sexuality, crushes and just plain sex, Hunx and His Punx are an irresistibly twisted, fantastical cross between CBGBs punk culture and a 1950s surf pop band.

title: "Historic"
description: A negative ad launched by the Romney campaign focused on Rick Santorum's 2006 loss in the Pennsylvania Senate race.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Sam Anderson on the Religion of Stupid Digital Games
description: Sam Anderson, critic at large for The Times Magazine, wrote this weeks cover story on stupid digital games. He has most recently written for the magazine on Haruki Murakami and on the theme park called Dickens World.

title: Leading Off: Unconventional Wins
description: As much as the Masters would like to stage-manage everything in its leafy-green, mythical utopia where everyone is polite, the world is still segregated according to how the rich power brokers want it and usually even the flowers bloom on cue, it cant stage-manage what happens in the actual tournament, no matter how much it wants to. And so it ended up with Bubba Watson, the man of a million laid-bare emotions, a homemade swing, a pink driver and a hobby restoring a car made famous by The Dukes of Hazzard, crafting the craziest of shots out of the woods in the playoff, then watering the 10th green with tears.

title: Morning Walkabout: Myanmar and More
description: Interesting articles, photos and other links from the staff of The Timess Travel section:

title: No Seizure Risk From Measles Vaccine in Older Children
description: A large new study has ruled out concerns that children over 4 are at greater risk of seizures after getting a common measles-containing vaccine called MMRV. The vaccine  which combines the shot for measles, mumps and rubella, or MMR, with the vaccine for varicella, or chickenpox  is given to children in two steps, first as toddlers and then again between ages 4 and 6.

title: Street Style: Spring Scarves
description: The best of readers photos from the week of April 2.

title: Dear FloFab: No Dessert for Me
description: Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

title: 0-3 Starts and the Lesson of the 2011 Red Sox
description: The Yankees and the Red Sox are both 0-3 for the first time since 1966, but if last season taught baseball fans anything, it is that losing streaks are losing streaks, no matter when they happen.

title: Morning T | Mlanie Laurent
description: The actress Mlanie Laurent talks about her latest film, Les Adopts,; her new role as the face of an iconic Dior fragrance; and the benefits of being free.

title: As Hundreds of Men Perished, One Ignored a Rumor to Survive
description: Had you been a woman traveling in second class on the Titanic a century ago, your chances of survival were quite favorable  86 percent were saved. For the men in second class, one of whom was my grandfather Lawrence Beesley, the odds were the reverse  only 14 percent survived, and the rest were drowned in the freezing waters of the Atlantic.

title: Sixteen Candles Clip
description: Sixteen Candles Clip

title: Really? Constant Stress Makes You Sick
description: THE FACTS

title: Dior Selects Raf Simons to Replace John Galliano
description: The job at Dior has finally been filled.

title: For Boston College, a Blueprint That Works
description: Slap Shot is featuring reports from writers at the colleges and universities playing in the N.C.A.A. Frozen Four tournament.

title: Monday Motorsports: Jorge Lorenzo Surges to Win MotoGP Opener in Qatar
description: Casey Stoners forearms could not have picked a worse time for a pit stop.

title: Its Probably Not Going to Be You Who Beats the Market
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at BAM Advisor Services. His book, The Behavior Gap, was published earlier this year. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog.

title: AOL Shares Soar on Patent Deal With Microsoft
description: Will AOLs patent deal appease shareholders?

title: UBS Banker Joins TAP Advisors
description: A senior technology banker at UBS has left the firm to become vice chairman of TAP Advisors, a boutique investment bank.

title: Like Father, Like Son
description: Most Northerners who fought in the War of the Rebellion declared that they did so to preserve the Union. But many citizen soldiers enlisted for other reasons  some quite personal, discussed privately if at all, and certainly not in polite society.

title: Preparing Children and Teens for a Tough Tick Season
description: A post last week on the Times Green blog encouraged Northeast residents to brace for a hungry tick season. Various environmental factors (specifically, fewer white-footed mice to feed on this year, leaving ticks looking for tasty mammal alternatives) mean that this spring and summer the woods will be filled with poppy-seed-size black-legged ticks in need of a meal.

title: Products Named for Dirty Jobs Try to Clean Up
description: For decades, fans have been able to buy merchandise inspired by their favorite television shows, like posters, T-shirts, records, books, jigsaw puzzles and dolls. But now a TV series has generated products that are meant to be practical rather than trinkets and knickknacks.

title: Documenting the Olympic Dreams of Iraqs Rowers
description: Haider Nozad, an Iraqi oarsman, wants to go back to the Olympics.

title: Raf Simons Takes on the Dior Mantle
description: PARIS  The Belgian designer Raf Simons is expected to be named Tuesday as the next artistic director of Christian Dior. The post has been empty for more than a year since the dramatic departure of John Galliano in March 2011. Mr. Simons, who is 44, began his career in mens wear in 1995 and went on to revitalize mens and womens lines at Jil Sander 10 years later.

title: Out of State Guns
description: Last week, yet another school shooting served as a reminder of how desperately America needs to have a conversation about gunsthough naturally we wont have one due to the lobbying efforts of the National Rifle Association.

title: Image of the Day: April 9
TimesCast | April 9, 2012
description: Turkey accuses Syria of firing across its border | Iran and the United States prepare for nuclear negotiations this week.

title: Facebook to Buy Photo-Sharing Service Instagram for $1 Billion
description: 9:07 p.m. | Updated

title: A Fragile Tourist Attraction on the Ocean Floor
description: Explorers and United States government experts have put together the first comprehensive map of the Titanics resting place, illuminating a square mile of inky seabed as a guide to better understanding the liners death throes and better preserving its remains.

title: Facebook Buys Instagram for $1 Billion
description: 2:02 p.m. | Updated

title: Syrian Reportedly Detained for Bold Protest
description: A 33-year-old Syrian woman was reportedly arrested in Damascus on Sunday as she staged a bold protest outside the Syrian Parliament building, standing in traffic with a banner that read, Stop the killing, so we can build a country for all Syrians.

title: The Iceberg Was Only Part of It
description: What doomed the Titanic is well known, at least in outline. On a moonless night in the North Atlantic, the liner hit an iceberg and disaster ensued, with 1,500 lives lost.

title: Another Strong Fund-Raising Quarter for Warren in Massachusetts
description: BOSTON  Elizabeth Warren raised more than twice as much money as Senator Scott P. Brown last quarter in the high-stakes Massachusetts Senate race, bringing in $6.9 million compared with $3.4 million for Mr. Brown.

title: Asked & Answered | Huger Foote
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Real Estate Brokers First Acts
description: A hand model, an actor and a rapper are among those enjoying a second career in real estate. Watch video of their prior incarnations.

title: Rangers Playoff Report: Notes on Gaborik, Callahan, Kreider and Dubinsky
description: The Rangers were without two key players Monday for the first practice in preparation for their first-round Stanley Cup playoff series with Ottawa. Marian Gaborik, the teams leading goal scorer with 41, was sidelined with the flu. The teams captain, Ryan Callahan, who scored 29 goals, was out for what the team called personal reasons.

title: TimesCast | Author: Frank Langella
description: March 30, 2012  The actor Frank Langella writes about meeting some of the 20th centurys biggest celebrities in his memoir, Dropped Names.

title: After Ship Sank, Fierce Fight to Get Story
description: To newspaper readers, and to the anxious crowds that jammed the streets around newspaper offices, hoping to see giant-letter bulletins be posted on the walls, it was the unforgettable story of the unsinkable ship. Behind the scenes, in the fiercely competitive newsrooms of a city with more than a dozen daily papers, it was the equally unforgettable story of two larger-than-life editors, one brilliantly analytical, the other brilliantly theatrical.

title: The Taste of Spring, by the Bunch or Bag: Indian Tofu With Spinach
description: Its hard for me to resist buying spinach at the farmers market this time of year. The bunches are plush, and the leaves and stems, pale pink at the base, are tender. Id almost forgotten what mature spinach tastes like, since Id gotten into the habit of buying the bagged baby spinach that you dont have to stem; at my Iranian market they sell three-pound bags at a very good price. But fresh, locally grown bunch spinach is definitely worth revisiting, even if it does require more prep time. Ever since reading this article about the loss of nutrients and susceptibility to contamination that can occur when greens and lettuces are bagged, Ive become a little less enamored with bagged baby spinach, despite the convenience.

title: N.F.L. Upholds Suspensions in Saints Scandal
description: The N.F.L. upheld the season-long suspension of New Orleans Saints Coach Sean Payton on Monday, and the shorter suspensions of two other team executives, as the league continued to grapple with thebounty scandal that has overshadowed much of the off-season.

title: On Our Radar: Gas, Gas and More Gas
description: With a mild winter in much of the country having tamped down gas demand and with production of natural gas thriving due to the success of hydraulic fracturing technology, a.k.a. fracking, the country is running out of storage space and as a result some producers are slowing down, the Associated Press reports. But just as the market seems saturated, and the Energy Department reports that prices are extremely low, the Interior Departments Bureau of Land Management has issued new rules that will allow for another 3,600 wells in eastern Utah, the Salt Lake Tribune reports.

title: Once a Rapper, a Ballerina or a Model, Now in Real Estate Sales
description: The music video for Notorious B.I.G.s song Big Poppa has dancing and gambling, a thumping rhythm and a young Sean P. Diddy Combs sitting in a hot tub surrounded by scantily clad women.

title: In Bodrum, Turkey, a Hotel for Art and Artists
description: This spring, guests at Casa DellArte will have access to a white sand beach, Balinese and deep-tissue massage and workshops with the Pakistani experimental video artist and provocateur Basir Mahmood.

title: Grand Jury Wont Be Convened in Florida Teenagers Killing
description: The special prosecutor appointed to investigate the killing of 17-year-old Trayvon Martin said Monday that she had decided not to convene a grand jury in the case, which incited protests nationwide after the local authorities in Sanford, Fla., decided not to pursue charges against the crime watch volunteer who shot the unarmed teenager.

title: Occupy Spring Training
description: Occupy Wall Street protestors gather to practice tactics they say will keep them cohesive and strong when they demonstrate again in May.

title: 2 Tulsa Shooting Suspects Confess, Police Say
description: TULSA, Okla.  The two men accused of killing three black people and wounding two others in shootings that terrified this city over the Easter weekend confessed to the police shortly after their arrest Sunday morning, the authorities said on Monday.

title: Braised Squid With Artichokes
description: Mark Bittman prepares a dish he brought back from Italy: a simple braise with artichokes and squid.

title: Looks as if a Hawk Egg Is Hatching
description: While we cant count hawks until theyve hatched, it sure looks as if there is a hole in one of the eggs in the Hawk Cam nest high outside the New York University presidents office high above Washington Square Park, the kind that is made by a baby hawk pecking its way to daylight. Folks on the chat room noticed it around 1:30 p.m. today  Day 34 after an egg was spotted in the nest and well into the expected hatch window.

title: The Minimalist: Braised Squid With Artichokes
description: I did an artichoke recipe just about every year I wrote the Minimalist column. This one, a simple braise of artichokes and squid, was inspired by a trip to Liguria, a region in northwest Italy. The cooking is absurdly easy, but the prep is not. Artichokes are a nuisance to clean, and there are only two ways around it. One is to use frozen hearts, and that kills the dish, and the other is to move to Europe, where artichokes are sold pre-trimmed. There are men and women who work in the markets in Italy who clean artichokes by the case; they can trim down to the heart in about 10 seconds. Literally.

title: The Campster | Spring Trail Accessories
description: With winter weather relenting and fiddleheads beginning to pop up, it seems spring is officially here. Which, for some of us, means getting back to sleeping under the stars. Yes, it might be a little muddy on the trail, but the rivers are high and the edibles abundant. And with fewer clothing layers to bring along, your pack will have just enough spare room to fit these spring essentials.

title: Rangers Prepare by Looking at Themselves
description: When the Rangers begin their first-round playoff series against the Ottawa Senators on Thursday night, it will be the first time the franchise has had home-ice advantage in the postseason since 1996. Despite finishing the season on a sour note Saturday by losing a game tothe Washington Capitalsand the Presidents Trophy to the Vancouver Canucks, the anticipation was not diminished.

title: At 20, Camden Yards Tries to Keep Up
description: BALTIMORE  At age 20, Oriole Park at Camden Yards is not a relic in disrepair. Yet, as the Yankees will discover during their three-game series against the Orioles that started Monday night, the stadium has undergone a modest face-lift that is partly a response to what newer ballparks have done since 1992.

title: Against Nashville, the Wings Will Rely on Their Experience
description: The Detroit Red Wings are not surprised to be starting the playoffs by facing the Nashville Predators, as that showdown has seemingly been locked in for the last two weeks. The only unknown was who would take the fourth seed, gaining the home ice advantage over the fifth seed.

title: Musical by David Byrne and Fatboy Slim Part of Next Public Theater Season
description: The Public Theater announced on Monday that its 2012-13 season will include two new musicals: A three-hour adaptation of Edna Ferbers novel Giant, with a score by Michael John LaChiusa (Hello Again, Queen of the Mist), and a deconstruction of the rise and fall of Imelda Marcos, the former first lady of the Philippines, by the musicians David Byrne and Fatboy Slim.

title: Owing a Debt to Europes Woes
description: Europe may be in crisis, but that is proving to be a boon for the Continents filmmakers. Economic austerity, social, religious and generational conflict, immigration from the Islamic world  all those concerns and more have helped contribute to a bumper crop of movies for the fourth annual Disappearing Act European film festival in Manhattan that reflect, and reflect upon, current realities.

title: Caucus Click: Easter Tradition at the White House
Brush Fires Across Region Are Spread by High Winds
description: Updated Tuesday April 10 | Driven by high, fast-shifting winds, a five-alarm brush fire swept through the former Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island on Monday and burned until 4 a.m. Tuesday morning, fire official ssaid.

title: With Concepts in Manhattan, Chevrolet Tries to Ignite Design Students Interest
description: Before press previews for the 2012 New York auto show, Nick David, the Chevrolet senior exterior designer credited with the Tru 140S concept car, met with students from the design program at the Pratt Institute. He was joined by marketing manager John McFarland.

title: Caregiving as a Roller-Coaster Ride From Hell
description: More than 40 million women are the primary caregivers for a sick person, very often the man they are married to. Caregiving, after all, is a wifes expected role, and most accept it perforce as a duty that offers precious time to express love and wishes, settle financial and legal matters, and right past wrongs.

title: Instagram Signals Break in Facebooks Deal-Making Style
description: Facebooks $1 billion takeover of Instagram is notable in many ways, including size. But its also the first time the social-networking titan didnt strike a deal almost entirely for the programming talent of its target.

title: Finding a Sitter for Your Dog, via the Web
description: Sites like Airbnb enable people to rent an extra bed in their apartment to travelers. A new site called Rover.com lets you rent your lap to dogs when their owners are out of town.

title: Many More Indie Films Are Released, but Not Very Widely, Study Finds
description: LOS ANGELES  Toward the back of an annual statistical download last month from the Motion Picture Association of America were some numbers that reveal the changing contours of film distribution in the United States.

title: Provenal Spinach Gratin
description: There are a few versions of spinach gratin in Provence (there it is called a tian). This one is all about spinach  no eggs or cheese, just spinach and lots of garlic, a bit of flour to absorb moisture and hold everything together, and bread crumbs to make the top nice and crisp.

title: Allure of Online Browsing Leads Couple to Dalliances
description: Brandt Johnsons Just Sex is set in the present, but perhaps its better to think of it as a comedy of manners from the turn of the century  the 21st century.

title: Protesters Hold Spring Training at Zuccotti Park
description: About 100 people were gathered inside Zuccotti Park on Friday as Zak Solomon stood on a granite bench and offered instruction on protest tactics with names like Melt, Wall, and The Peoples Gong.

title: Rocking and Rolling to 60s Racial Tension in Omaha
description: Youd think a play about riots, race, rape, the late 1960s, murder and jazz would be explosive. That My Occasion of Sin is based on a real-life tragedy should only fan the flames. Instead this play by Monica Bauer about events in her hometown, Omaha, is preachy and slow, clunking with inconsistent characterization and force-fed symbolism.

title: Setting a Budget (Set to a Hip-Hop Beat)
description: Many teenagers do not get excited about topics like money management and investing. But some of them might take notice of a new hip-hop video titled Time Is Money, in which Syretha Shirley, a high school sophomore in Las Vegas, raps about, of all things, her checking account.

title: Years After Acid Horror, Suicide Stirs Pakistan
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  Fakhra Younas went under the surgeons knife 38 times, hoping to repair the gruesome damage inflicted by a vengeful Pakistani man who had doused her face in acid a decade earlier, virtually melting her mouth, nose and ears.

title: Photo Replay: April 9
description: The day in sports included the European weight lifting championships in Turkey; English Premier League soccer matches; and the Phillies home opener in Philadelphia.

title: A Creator Specializes in Getting Close Up
description: The young choreographer Avi Scher likes to say that he has a mission: presenting top-quality ballet dancers in intimate spaces at affordable prices. On Saturday at the Alvin Ailey Citigroup Theater, all elements of that formula were in place, including Herman Cornejo of American Ballet Theater. But so was the final, fatal ingredient: Mr. Schers choreography.

title: Bush-Era Torture: A Dissenting View
description: We know that President George W. Bush, Vice President Dick Cheney and their lieutenants did not like dissenting viewpoints. The justification for the invasion of Iraq depended on the muzzling of anyone who doubted the existence of weapons of mass destruction, and for the most part political appointees fell into line after that point. Jack Goldsmith, who withdrew the Bybee memo justifying torture before resigning from the Office of Legal Counsel, was a notable exception.

title: Diving With Care
description: The first comprehensive map of the Titanics resting place should help prevent further damage by visitors to the site.

title: Setting the Stage for the Titanic Tragedy
description: New research suggests that a series of celestial and atmospheric events may have affected the Titanic disaster and rescue attempts, 100 years ago this week.

title: Live From the Cutting Room Floor
description: I was a guest on Up w/Chris Hayes Saturday, talking, it seemed, about everything: a bit of an ambitious agenda. When I go back, the conversation will continue.

title: Drilling Down: What Small Businesses Should Know About Crowdfunding
description: In this weeks Dashboard roundup of small-business news, we quoted from a blog post in which Ryan Caldbeck gave three reasons why crowdfunding will be good for investors. We went back to Mr. Caldbeck, who helped found crowdfunding site CircleUp, to talk about what small businesses need to know about the sites.

title: Judge Tells Bloomberg to Release 911 Report
description: A state judge ordered Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Monday to release what is said to be a sharply critical report on New Yorks costly, much-delayed emergency dispatch system, but gave the city a week to appeal.

title: The Short, Explosive Rise in Instagrams Valuation
description: Its safe to say that few companies have experienced as rapid a rise in valuation as Instagram.

title: Victory Built on Creativity and One Spectacular Shot
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.

title: Similar Moves, Echoed in Different Dances
description: At Joyce SoHo on Thursday, Sydney Skybetters dancers looked attractive in the grays and blacks of Karen Youngs tasteful costumes. Kate Ashton lighted them dimly from the side and below, casting their shadows on a wall. To music that was liturgical in sound if not in origin, the skilled dancers swirled prettily, stretching a leg behind them at hip level and rotating like turnstiles.

title: A Master of Verse Spreads Bad Cheer
description: Deprivation is for me, Philip Larkin once observed, what daffodils were for Wordsworth. He was right, of course: unhappiness, loss, disappointment, boredom and fear of death are the bread and butter of his verse. Larkin was the Eeyore of poets, the Debbie Downer of modern literature. The familiar T-shirt  Lifes a Bitch and Then You Die  pretty much sums up the central theme of his work.

title: A Sense of Glasnost at a Carnegie Keyboard
description: Judging by his enjoyable concert at Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening, the Russian-American pianist Maxim Anikushin has a genuine affinity for the music of Samuel Barber. In 2010 Mr. Anikushin performed a Barber concert in honor of that composers centennial, and he is working on a disc of his music for Albany Records.

title: Hunger Strike
description: With her severe bob and heavy line of red lipstick, the author Herta Mller looks like she fell out of an Otto Dix painting. After Mller won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 2009, one critic sniped that she should get a new haircut, lest foreigners assume thats how all German women look. Other reactions to the Nobel news were more basic: Herta who?

title: After a Frustrating Season, Dubinsky Is Ready for a New Chapter
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Forward Brandon Dubinsky used the word nightmare here Monday to describe his part of the regular season just past. It was part of a remarkable self-analysis that Dubinsky conducted for reporters after the Rangers first practice ahead of Thursdays playoff opener against Ottawa.

title: 110 in the Shade
description: Q. Will climate change affect the incidence of diseases and medical conditions?

title: Mike Daisey to Develop New Work With Cape Cod Theater Project
description: Despite being found to have fabricated details in his one-man show The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs, Mike Daisey will lead off the season at the Cape Cod Theater Project this summer.

title: Fashion News Were Reading Now
description: Its official: Raf Simons has a new gig.

title: TimesCast | Turkey and Syria Clash
description: April 9, 2012  Turkish officials accused the Syrian military of shooting at refugees inside Turkey for the first time.

title: Rushdie Among Those Who Respond to Israels Ban of Gnter Grass
description: On Sunday Israels interior minister, Eli Yishai, declared the author Gnter Grass unwelcome in Israel. This came after a controversial poem by Mr. Grass was published in the German newspaper Sddeutsche Zeitung. The poem, What Must Be Said, is not being analyzed for its rhyme scheme. In it, Mr. Grass writes: Why do I say only now, / Aged and with my last ink, / That the nuclear power of Israel endangers / The already fragile world peace?

title: Tending a Sick Comrade Has Benefits for Ants
description: When one ant in a colony has an infection, the others dont avoid their sick comrade. Instead, they approach the infected ant and lick it to remove pathogens.

title: Improvisation Mixed, Reflected and Remixed
description: Even when you have an iPod, there are those moments in New York life when you find yourself witnessing uncomfortable private moments: a couple, bickering on a subway platform and going at each other with barely disguised fury  in the form of eye-rolling, crossed arms and furrowed brows. In other stories, Alexandra Beller has created and directed a work about these everyday occurrences, and while Id like to be supportive about giving life experiences meaning through dance, its just painful.

title: Treating Sleep Apnea Without the Mask
description: About 28 million Americans have sleep apnea, which causes repeated awakenings and pauses in breathing during the night, sometimes resulting in loud snoring and gasps for air. For decades, the standard treatment has been continuous positive airway pressure. A mask worn at night pushes air into the nasal passages, enabling easier breathing. C.P.A.P. reduces and in some cases completely prevents episodes of apnea.

title: Spring Vacation Means Hit Broadway Shows Reap the Benefits of Higher Ticket Prices
description: The start of April school vacations led some Broadway producers to charge high premium prices for more seats last week because of family and tourist demand, and as a result several of the shows  Wicked, The Lion King, Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark and The Book of Mormon  brought in huge sums per person on average, according to weekly box office data published on Monday.

title: The Titanic 100 years later; the science of science festivals; and rethinking the value of pets.
description: The Titanic 100 years later; the science of science festivals; and rethinking the value of pets.

title: An Italian Sopranos Salon Songs
description: During the triumphant New York recital debut of the Italian soprano Anna Caterina Antonacci on Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall, it was hard to keep from being a little upset with her. Here was a remarkable artist in her prime at 51, a musically intelligent and vocally splendid singer with a significant career in Europe who has been embraced by discerning maestros like Riccardo Muti.

title: Afghan Killings and an Amnesia Defense
description: In several interviews, the lawyer for Staff Sgt. Robert Bales, the soldier accused of murdering 17 Afghan civilians last month, has said that his client does not remember much from the night of the shootings. He has some memories of before the incident, and he has some memories of after the incident, the lawyer, John Henry Browne, said. In between, very little.

title: Dempsey Does It Again
description: Chelsea may be heading to the first leg in the semifinals of the Champions League next week, but Fulhams American international Clint Dempsey is certainly headed for a prodigious payday sometime soon, real soon.

title: Films That Allow the Elusive to Elude
description: Its safe to say that there never was a choreographer with a greater appetite for performing at different locations than Merce Cunningham. Over the decades his company danced not just in a wide variety of theaters and galleries, but also in the Piazza San Marco in Venice; beside the ocean in Perth, Australia; in the Royal Albert Hall in London; in the ruins at Persepolis; and in  Grand Central Terminal.

title: Impatience to Get Thin Sends Some to Canada
description: Tammy Kwarciak, a 44-year-old nurse whose weight had been creeping up for years, was determined to lose 50 pounds. So in February, she drove from her home in Port Huron, Mich., across the border into Canada and had a small balloonlike device inserted into her stomach.

title: Seeking Robots to Go Where First Responders Cant
description: In the event of another disaster at a nuclear power plant, the first responders may not be humans but robots. They may not even look humanoid.

title: Limbaugh to Leave AM Station in Philadelphia
description: The Rush Limbaugh Show is leaving the dominant conservative talk radio station in Philadelphia, one of the biggest radio markets in the country.

title: TimesCast | Nuclear Talks to Resume
description: April 9, 2012  Iran sends mixed signals days before the planned resumption of nuclear talks with global powers.

title: Let Grannie Go
description: One of the first posts I wrote for this blog was on the Supreme Courts first ruling of this term, Cavazos v. Smith. Shirley Ree Smith was found guilty in a 1997 California trial of shaking her seven-week-old grandson to death, and sentenced to 15 years to life. But the Ninth Circuit overturned the conviction, arguing that there was no demonstrable support for it.

title: Carrie Revival, Now Dead, Has an Autopsy
description: After achieving notoriety as a nightmarishly campy, $8 million flop on Broadway in 1988, the musical Carrie rose from the ashes as a fervently earnest, $1.5 million revival Off Broadway this winter, and ran for 80 performances, or about four times as many as the original production had. But the second coming it wasnt.

title: Regulators Sue Silicon Valley Entrepreneur
description: Benedict Van was trying to make a name for himself in Silicon Valley. For two years, the entrepreneur would crisscross California, paying house visits to investors in hopes of raising cash for a pair of online start-ups he founded.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Humanoid Robots and Unlocking iPhones
description: Here are some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Monday. There are more here.

title: Marriott Says It Stopped Ad Service Hidden in Wi-Fi
description: Last week, the Courtyard by Marriott hotel in Midtown Manhattan was discovered to come with some hidden extras: The free Wi-Fi connection inserted lines of code for serving special ads into every Web page a guest visited.

title: Pictures of the Day: Mexico and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Mexico, Pakistan, Delaware and Tunisia.

title: Socialsecuritymedicareandmedicaid Strikes Again
description: Jared Bernstein and Dean Baker are both mad, understandably, at Robert Samuelson, who pulls out, for the 7 millionth time, the old Social Security bait and switch. Heres how it works: to make the quite mild financial shortfall of Social Security seem apocalyptic, the writer starts out by talking about Social Security, then starts using numbers that combine SS with the health care programs  programs that are very different in conception, financing, and solutions.

title: Despite Good Health, Bank Holds Tight to TARP Funds
description: Its the bank bailout mystery.

title: An Olympian Camera Bag, Now for Mortals
description: Lowepro has built a camera bag of Olympic proportions.

title: The Campaign Shifts to the General Election
description: With Mitt Romney now more than halfway toward the 1,144 delegates needed for the G.O.P. nomination, and President Obama engaging him, the battle lines for the general election are coming into view.

title: A School Lottery That Favors Needy Children
Grassley Assailed for Calling Obama Stupid on Twitter
description: United States Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican from Iowa, started a Twitter argument over the health care overhaul law last weekend when he called President Obama stupid, prompting Mr. Obamas chief strategist, David Axelrod, to suggest a 6-year-old had hijacked the senators account to embarrass him.

title: A Celebration of Science With a Popular Touch
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  With the applause just winding down for a scantily clad all-girl rock band, John Durant climbed onstage, carrying his 2-year-old son.

title: 1000 Fifth Avenue, 3:07 P.M.
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art broke its never-open-on-a-Monday rule this week in honor of spring break at city schools.

title: An iPhone Case Ready for a Dunking
description: Many waterproof iPhone cases turn the sleek device into a oversized lump with all the elegance of a 1950s diving bell.

title: More Brainpower Seen in Soccers Top Scorers
description: Brawny athletes are rarely brainy, or so the stereotype goes. But a new study reports that soccer players actually have superior executive functions, the brain processes responsible for planning and abstract thinking. And the more elite the player, the better these functions.

title: Changes in Social Status Seen in Gene Regulation in Monkeys
description: Social stress is known to have adverse health effects on both humans and primates.

title: Tunisia Cracks Down Again on Protesters Defying a Ban
description: CAIRO  The six-month-old government of Tunisia cracked down with tear gas and batons Monday on thousands of protesters who filled a central artery of the capital in defiance of a new ban on demonstrations there.

title: American Hostages Taken in Iran
description: On November 4, 1979, Iranian students stormed the the American embassy in Tehran starting a hostage crisis that would persist for the next 444 days.

title: Growing the Numbers (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Its Never a Good Time (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Fox Renews Three Shows
description: Fox on Monday gave new season orders to three shows: New Girl, Raising Hope and Glee. The move came a little more than a month before the network sets its next season schedule and shares it with advertisers. Now the producers and writers of those shows can breathe a little easier and make plans for their next seasons. All three of these comedies add a fresh and distinctive flavor to our Tuesday nights, and Im really happy to bring them back, Kevin Reilly, president of entertainment for Fox Broadcasting, said in a statement. New Girl, starring Zooey Deschanel, above, had its premiere last fall and is the No. 1 new scripted series this season among viewers ages 18 to 34. Raising Hope isnt as popular but it held up well when it was moved into an 8 p.m. time slot recently. As for Glee, its future involves following its glee club characters after they graduate from high school at the end of this season.

title: Can Fido and Whiskers Enrich Childrens Lives?
description: In this era of mommy confessionals, I must admit: I am not a pet person. With their allergic father, I have reared three children without benefit of in-house canines, felines or invited rodents.

title: New Songs From Old Materials
description: SPIRITUALIZEDSweet Heart, Sweet Light(Fat Possum)

title: A Health Crisis Strikes. Then What?
description: To the Editor:

title: Is This the Sound of Bubble Ready to Pop?
description: Yes, $1 billion dollars is a lot of money for a company with $0 in revenue.

title: Barney McKenna, Banjo Player in the Dubliners, Dies at 72
description: Barney McKenna, whose racing, raucous and often lyrically haunting banjo playing helped propel the Irish folk band the Dubliners to fame, died on Thursday at his home in Dublin. The last of the original members of the band, he was 72.

title: For Reservas, No Cellar Required
description: ITS accepted wisdom today that most wine drinkers do not have the money, the storage space or the patience to wait years as their bottles age to maturity. Consumers expect wines to be ready, or at least enjoyable, immediately after they buy them.

title: Gnter Grasss Poem, and the Israeli Reaction
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bill to Help Veterans
description: To the Editor:

title: Let the Faculty Teach
description: To the Editor:

title: An Independent Scotland?
description: To the Editor:

title: You Say Tomato, I Say Oosthuizen
description: Spelling Louis Oosthuizens out-of-Afrikaans surname is easier than figuring out how to pronounce it.

title: Tsunami Projections Offer Bleak Fate for Many Japanese Towns
description: KUROSHIO, Japan  The simulations shocked this sleepy community on the tip of Japans Shikoku island: a huge undersea quake could bring a tsunami as high as 112 feet here, a government-appointed expert panel said. The waves could arrive in minutes and engulf most of the town, swallowing up even the foothills that the residents had counted on for high ground.

title: For Mets Bullpen, Too Much of a Good Thing May Not Be So Good
description: Among the many sources of optimism during the Mets three-game winning streak to open the season, the bullpen stood out.

title: The Campaign Shifts to the General Election
description: With Mitt Romney now more than halfway toward the 1,144 delegates needed for the Republican nomination, and President Obama directly engaging him, the battle lines for the general election are coming into view. Graphic

title: Microsofts AOL Deal Intensifies Patent Wars
description: The global gold rush in technology patents gained speed on Monday when Microsoft agreed to pay more than $1 billion for 800 patents held by AOL.

title: AT&Ts Lumia Salespeople Dont Seem So Hot for the Phone
description: AT&T has poured loads of money into advertising Nokias new Lumia 900 phone, but if a visit to four stores in New York is any guide, AT&T store employees dont seem that sold on the device.

title: After Yankees Slow Start, Only Girardi Does the Talking
description: BALTIMORE  Even after the Yankees were swept by Tampa Bay in a season-opening series, Manager Joe Girardi did not hear from Hal Steinbrenner, the clubs managing general partner. Girardi insisted that it was par for the course and that conversations with Steinbrenner usually took place when Steinbrenner attends a Yankees homestand.

title: Brands Cheer Their Virtues With Anniversary Candles
description: IF Madison Avenue had its own hit parade or Hot 100, The Anniversary Waltz might be the top song of 2012.

title: New Chief Selected at Avon
description: Battered by the recession, Johnson & Johnson turned in 2009 to Sherilyn S. McCoy, a longtime executive who had joined the company as a scientist in 1982, to overhaul the companys pharmaceutical division. It was a wrenching process that involved reorganizing the business at a time when patents on important drugs were expiring.

title: Food Stamps Helped Reduce Poverty Rate, Study Finds
description: WASHINGTON  A new study by the Agriculture Department has found that food stamps, one of the countrys largest social safety net programs, reduced the poverty rate substantially during the recent recession. The food stamp program, formally known as the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, or SNAP, reduced the poverty rate by nearly 8 percent in 2009, the most recent year included in the study, a significant impact for a social program whose effects often go unnoticed by policy makers.

title: Toyota, Eschewing Sedate Design, Is Ready for Pizazz
description: TOYOTA CITY, Japan  After decades of emphasizing staid reliability, Toyota wants to start running with the cool kids.

title: Facebook Makes a Play for Mobile With Its Instagram Scoop
description: Why did Facebook just spend about $1 billion on a photo sharing site that is entirely free and has no immediate way to make money?

title: Fans React to Surprising Start
description: After the Mets started the season with a string of wins, fans are cautiously enthusiastic about the teams prospects.

title: Mets Fans Revel, for Now, in an Undefeated Season
description: Enjoy it. Brag about it. Dine out on it.

title: N.E.A. Is Said to Cut Aid to Arts Programs on PBS
description: The National Endowment for the Arts, a major supporter of PBS shows devoted to performing arts and independent documentaries, is proposing substantial cuts in their financing.

title: Anthony, Playing His Way, Is Scorer the Knicks Expected
description: The shots were deep, timely and bold  the kind that alter fates, reshape impressions and restore faith. Carmelo Anthony launched them Sunday afternoon, and when the net swished, there was no doubt in the air at Madison Square Garden, only happy delirium.

title: Some Explaining to Do for Republican Leader
description: WASHINGTON  By definition, the majority leader of the House has the majority of incumbents to protect in an election. So it came as something of a shock when House Republicans learned that a political action committee affiliated with Representative Eric Cantor of Virginia, who currently holds that leadership slot, had donated $25,000 to a group devoted solely to taking out incumbents.

title: E.P.A. Denies an Environmental Groups Request to Ban a Widely Used Weed Killer
description: The Environmental Protection Agency on Monday said that the widely used herbicide 2,4-D would remain on the market, denying a petition from an environmental group that sought to revoke the chemicals approval.

title: Lets Keep Our Hands Off the Emergency Oil Supply
description: AS oil and gasoline prices rise, political pressure to tap the roughly 700 million barrels in the national Strategic Petroleum Reserve is building, including among some in Congress. The global oil market is fundamentally strained and suffering from an array of unwelcome but unremarkable problems. Yet the oil reserve is neither designed nor well equipped to address these chronic weaknesses. Instead it should be preserved to address an emergency disruption in supply.

title: For the Elderly, Emergency Rooms of Their Own
description: Phyllis Spielberger, a retired hat seller at Bendels, picked at a plastic dish of beets and corn as her husband, Jason, sat at the foot of her hospital bed, telling her to eat.

title: Practicing Prudence in Picking Travel Cards
description: WITH all these frantic credit card merchants beseeching me these days, I feel as if Im a tourist wandering the Marrakesh souk. Joseph! Last chance to earn 35,000 bonus miles! implores a new e-mail message from Delta Air Lines for its Gold Delta SkyMiles credit card from American Express.

title: The Indios, Once the Pride of Ciudad Jurez
description: A soccer team that made an improbable rise buoyed a city riven by violence. Now the team is gone, although the violence remains.

title: In the Diamond Business, but Not Wearing Them
description: EVEN as a child, I loved the thought of flying. I remember having a book detailing the logos of almost every airline in the world. Today, nothing breaks up the monotony of a long stay on a tarmac more than finding a new airline logo and trying to figure out its origin.

title: Bring the Justices Back to Earth
description: Durham, N.C.

title: A Costly Toy Subsidized by Others
description: When the numbers dont seem to add up, its worth asking some questions.

title: Team of Hope, Gone in City of Violence
description: CIUDAD JUREZ, Mexico  Returning to the soccer stadium here, I feel like an archaeologist on a dig. Fine brown sand dusts the stadiums concrete steps and concourses. Pigeons roost in the rafters, Pollocking plastic bucket seats that spell out Indios, the name of the team that no longer plays here, that no longer even exists. Worshiped in their time, the Indios lie dead, entombed in Mexican memories like Moctezuma himself.

title: Mobile Card-Processing Machines for Marketers on the Road
description: People do not carry as much cash as they once did, relying instead on debit and credit cards for even a cup of coffee. But until recently, entrepreneurs, trade show exhibitors and other small-business people who sell products on the road had to lug around a bulky machine and a stack of paper slips to process the cards, or risk losing business.

title: Evidence in Science and Religion, Part Two
description: In the post previous to this one, I revisited the question of the place of evidence in the discourses and practices of science and religion. I was prompted by a discussion on the the show Up w/ Chris Hayes (MSNBC, March 25) in which Steven Pinker and Richard Dawkins stated with great force and confidence that a key difference between science and religion is that the conclusions of the former are based on evidence that has emerged in the course of rigorous rational inquiry publicly conducted, while the conclusions of the latter are based on dogma, faith, unexamined authority, subjectivity and mere trust.

title: Fanfare for the Comma Man
description: Is it safe to talk about punctuation again? Eight years ago, Lynne Trusss best-selling Eats, Shoots & Leaves took, in the words of her subtitle, a Zero Tolerance Approach to the subject. Although Trusss focus on errors drew the ire, if not the fire, of grammarians, linguists and other descriptivists, her book was, for the most part, harmless and legitimate. Still, it overlooked a lot. Maybe more than any other element of writing, punctuation combines rules with issues of sound, preference and personal style. And as Truss didnt adequately acknowledge, even the rules change over time.

title: A Work-and-Save Project in Bangladesh: It Makes a Village
description: SOMESHPUR, Bangladesh  The village of Someshpur is a ragged collection of huts made of metal sheeting and thatch. Children scamper among the chickens in the unpaved square. The village, like the rest of Bangladesh, struggles to make ends meet.

title: Major Violations Reported at Baylor
description: The joy ride of the 2011-12 Baylor athletic season appears to have hit a speed bump. A report released Monday revealed violations in the universitys mens and womens basketball programs that the N.C.A.A. deemed major.

title: Former Skeptic Now Embraces Divisive Tactic
description: Twelve years back, a former New York police commissioner spoke with disdain of Mayor Rudolph W. Giulianis get-tough police tactics, particularly the stopping and frisking of thousands of men, most of them black or Latino.

title: Raising the Floor on Pay
description: As the nations economy slowly recovers and income inequality emerges as a crucial issue in the presidential campaign, lawmakers are facing growing pressure to raise the minimum wage, which was last increased at the federal level to $7.25 an hour in July 2009.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 9, 2012

title: A Lie Races Across Twitter Before the Truth Can Boot Up
description: It took only two minutes. An unfounded report on a little-known blog claiming that Gov. Nikki R. Haley was about to be indicted rocketed from South Carolina political circles into national circulation, along the way becoming the latest lesson in the perils of an instantaneous news culture.

title: Release of City Teachers Rankings Prompts Lawmakers to Weigh Limiting Access
description: Ever since New York Citys Education Department released 18,000 public-school teachers performance rankings, generating news coverage about the lowest and highest scorers, there has been talk in Albany of preventing a repeat.

title: A Shift in Strategy in Pennsylvania for Romney
description: Mitt Romneys attempt to pull off a victory in Rick Santorums home state of Pennsylvania was all set to go into overdrive Monday with attack ads highlighting how voters there soundly rejected him in his 2006 Senate race.

title: In French Vote, Sound and Fury From the Left
description: PARIS  They sang The Internationale, carried red flags and shouted Resistance! They booed whenever the word rich was pronounced, and they applauded when their leader, Jean-Luc Mlenchon, called the far right professional racists and the Socialist candidate a pedal-boat captain.

title: The Two Economies
description: The creative dynamism of American business is astounding and a little terrifying. Over the past five years, amid turmoil and uncertainty, American businesses have shed employees, becoming more efficient and more productive. According to The Wall Street Journal on Monday, the revenue per employee at S.&P. 500 companies increased from $378,000 in 2007 to $420,000 in 2011.

title: Obama Candidate Sketches Vision for World Bank
description: WASHINGTON  Dr. Jim Yong Kim, the anthropologist and physician who is President Obamas surprise choice to run the World Bank, does not have a detailed public record laying out his views of economic development, the banks central mission. He is not a development scholar nor, like previous presidents, a banker or foreign policy minence grise.

title: Fed Chief Seeks More Resiliency
description: The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, called on regulators Monday to stem risks from financial institutions operating beyond traditional oversight and favored steps to promote the resiliency of money market funds.

title: Football and Swahili
description: I was at the University of North Carolina when I heard the Swahili anecdote.

title: A Sacred Peak With Rich Ore Deposits
description: The Confederated Salish and Kootenai Tribes in Montana are seeking to have a mountain peak listed on the National Register of Historic Places in the hope of calling attention to a copper and silver mining companys plans to burrow beneath it. The tribe has traditionally used the site, Chicago Peak, for praying, fasting and seeking visions.

title: National Database Planned to Combat Cellphone Theft
description: WASHINGTON  The soaring popularity of smartphones has produced an unwelcome, if predictable, side effect: an epidemic of smartphone thefts.

title: Minayas Imprint Is Seen All Over the Mets Lineup
description: Omar Minaya was vacationing with his family in Florida on Monday, reacquainting himself with his wife and children after the grind of spring training. Even so, he plans to sneak away now and then to see prospects for the coming amateur draft. Scouting is Minayas passion, and now his eyes belong to the San Diego Padres.

title: Killing of Bangladeshi Labor Organizer Signals an Escalation in Violence
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh  A labor activist who was arrested two years ago for his role in protests against low wages in Bangladeshs garment industry was found murdered outside this city last week, labor rights advocates and the police said on Monday.

title: Even as Violent Crime Falls, Killing of Officers Rises
description: WASHINGTON  As violent crime has decreased across the country, a disturbing trend has emerged: rising numbers of police officers are being killed.

title: Contentments Elusive Recipe
description: Long before chefs were made of iron and barefoot brought to mind contessa and a cultured 9-year-old could tell farfalle from fusilli at 10 feet, an anxious Southern man named Craig Claiborne sat on a remote island in the Pacific and plotted to turn the American culinary world on its head.

title: A Rockier Pathway to Work
description: Hundreds of thousands of unemployed people are desperate for new skills to pull them back into the job market, but when they visit a job-training center, they are often turned away. As Motoko Rich reported in The Times on Monday, Seattles seven centers had money to train only 5 percent of the 120,000 people who came in last year seeking new skills, and the numbers are similar elsewhere.

title: Despite Warning, Old Handouts Die Hard for Greek Politicians Facing Voters Soon
description: ATHENS  With the country perched on the edge of a financial abyss and international creditors anxiously awaiting more belt-tightening measures, Greek lawmakers have been working extra hard lately. But not always in the ways one might expect.

title: President Assads Latest Bluff
description: The international communitys latest attempt to stop President Bashar al-Assads reign of terror in Syria is failing. Instead of abiding by a commitment to a cease-fire negotiated with the United Nations, he has kept his killing machine rolling, raising the death toll to an estimated 9,000 Syrians in the year since the start of the uprising.

title: An Exchange of Views
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  We have a very clever debut today by Gregory Philip Butler, and well learn more about him in a bit. Meanwhile, however, I will say that I appreciated the twist of finding the ROLE REVERSAL, or ELOR, in the middle of each of the three theme entries; a little extra something is what distinguishes this from a Monday puzzle.

title: Corrections: April 10
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Bogus Challenge to Cigarette Warnings
description: The tobacco industry has never been bashful about fighting back against attempts to regulate the promotion of its deadly, addictive products. The latest is an effort to derail new regulations requiring large health warnings on cigarette packages by making baseless First Amendment claims. It is the subject of an important case being heard on Tuesday by a federal appeals court in Washington.

title: Prosecutor in Martin Case Will Alone Determine Its Merits
description: MIAMI  Angela B. Corey, a Republican state attorney with a reputation for toughness, has decided not to seek a grand jury review of the Trayvon Martin shooting, keeping the resolution of a case that has transfixed the nation solely in her hands.

title: Pulling Back From the Exurbs
description: The view from a helicopter over the outer edges of Las Vegas in about 2004, at the height of the housing bubble, was of sprawl overtaking desert as fast as builders could throw up framing and lay on the stucco and roofing tiles. People were flooding in. The Clark County School District was hiring 2,000 teachers a year.

title: The President, Gas Prices and the Pipeline
description: Like every president seeking re-election, Barack Obama walks the fine line every day between the discordant goals of motivating his partys strongest loyalists and reaching out to swing voters for their support. A few weeks ago, that pathway took him to a tiny town in Oklahoma, where, caught between the anti-drilling demands of the environmental community and the thirst for more affordable gasoline from unions, business owners and drivers, the president announced his support for building half of an oil pipeline.

title: Minimum Wage or More
description: New York, New Jersey, Massachusetts, Connecticut and Illinois are among the states considering raising the minimum wage.

title: Brazil and U.S. Accentuate the Positive
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Dilma Rousseffs first visit to Washington as Brazils president was certainly cordial enough.

title: Nova Looks Sharp, Offense Clicks and the Yankees Win
description: BALTIMORE  Mark Teixeira waited throughout the winter and spring for the Yankees to line up after a game and shake hands. Most starters depart the ballpark by the ninth inning of spring training games, so the first opportunity for a victorious postgame procession needed to come in the regular season. The Yankees waited three games longer than they hoped, but on Monday they finally secured a 6-2 victory.

title: Lush Walls Rise to Fight a Blanket of Pollution
description: MEXICO CITY  We must cultivate our garden, Voltaire famously wrote at the end of Candide, but even he could not have imagined this: a towering arch of 50,000 plants rising over a traffic-clogged avenue in a metropolis once called Mexsicko City because of its pollution.

title: Pennsylvania: Nun Testifies About Being Fired
description: A Roman Catholic nun testified Monday that she was fired from her job as director of religious education at a Pennsylvania parish after reporting her suspicions about a priest who had been convicted of receiving child pornography. Sister Joan Scary said at the landmark sexual abuse trial of two priests from the Archdiocese of Philadelphia that she reported her suspicions about another priest, Edward M. DePaoli, to Cardinal Anthony J. Bevilacqua in 1996. Father DePaoli, who was convicted on child pornography charges in 1986 and sentenced to probation, had been receiving magazines of a sexual nature at an office where Sister Scary worked. In May 1996, she said she sent one of the magazines to Cardinal Bevilacqua with an anonymous note expressing her concern. She told the court that the Rev. James Gormley, the pastor of the parish where she was working, later fired her. Judge M. Teresa Sarmina said she allowed prosecutors to refer to other abuse cases to allow jurors to understand the churchs pattern of response.

title: Rhode Island: Bill Would Ban Dogs on Drivers Laps
description: A bill in the General Assembly would prohibit motorists from driving with dogs in their laps. A first offense would draw a fine of $85, and a second $100. The State Traffic Tribunal would hear the cases. The bill was introduced by State Representative Peter G. Palumbo and has been referred to the House Judiciary Committee.

title: So-So Start for Pelfrey; Big Finish for Mets
description: The giddiness of unforeseen perfection will continue in Queens for at least another day.

title: One Sick Dog, One Steep Bill
We Have a Baby Hawk!
description: Updated, 8 a.m. Tuesday | There is a new addition to the red-tailed hawks nest overlooking Washington Square Park. At 11:02 p.m. on Monday, almost nine hours after Hawk Cam fans initially reported that one egg had a small beak-sized hole, a fuzzy baby hawk emerged between two broken halves of an eggshell, making its debut on The New York Timess Hawk Cam.

title: Frank H. Strickler, Watergate Defense Lawyer, Dies at 92
description: Frank H. Strickler, a Washington lawyer who represented two of President Richard M. Nixons top aides, H. R. Haldeman and John Ehrlichman, in the tangled legal aftermath of the 1972 Watergate break-in and its cover-up, died March 29 at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 92.

title: Hewlett-Packard: Once More Toward the Cloud
description: Hewlett-Packard says it is again revamping the corporate sales of its servers and software to better take advantage of the growing market for cloud computing by large businesses.

title: Report Disputes Christies Basis for Halting Tunnel
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey exaggerated when he declared that unforeseen costs to the state were forcing him to cancel the new train tunnel planned to relieve congested routes across the Hudson River, according to a long-awaited report by independent Congressional investigators.

title: In Surprise, China Posts Trade Surplus
description: HONG KONG  China ran an unexpected $5.35 billion trade surplus last month, government figures released on Tuesday showed, indicating the country remains a strong exporter despite weak demand in Europe in recent months.

title: On a New Web Site, The Real George Zimmerman Speaks, and Solicits Funds
description: Last Updated | 5:46 p.m. George Zimmerman, the neighborhood watch volunteer who shot and killed an unarmed, black teenager in Florida six weeks ago, broke his public silence over the fatal shooting of Trayvon Martin on a new Web site: TheRealGeorgeZimmerman.com.

title: America Is Eating Its Poor
description: When Rendezvous wrote about Europes lost generation of unemployed young people  and what their lot in life will mean for Europes future  many RDV readers voiced their concerns about the overall decline of The West. Wrote Ian Walthew in France:

title: Christine Brooke-Rose, Inventive Writer, Dies at 89
description: Christine Brooke-Rose, an English experimental writer known for wielding words with the ardor of a philologist, the fingers of a prestidigitator and the appetite of a lexivore, resulting in novels that exhilarated many critics and enervated others, died on March 21. She was 89.

title: Malaysia Weighs End to Indefinite Detention
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  The Malaysian government introduced legislation on Tuesday that would limit the time it could detain people suspected of security-related offenses without formal charges to 28 days. The bill would replace the Internal Security Act, a law enacted decades ago that allows indefinite detention without trial.

title: Burmese Are Wary of Tourisms Dark Side
description: HONG KONG  As dramatic political reforms continue to take shape in Myanmar, a wave of tourists has already started to arrive, eager to explore the countrys magnificent temples, beaches and highlands.

title: Who Deserves Welfare in India?
description: Living on 29 rupees (a little more than 50 U.S. cents) a day may not be such stuff as dreams are made on, in William Shakespeares immortal turn of phrase from The Tempest. But according to Indias Planning Commission, which is charged with measuring such things, anyone spending more than that meager amount is considered to be above the poverty line.

title: At the Varli Food Festival, Andhra Shrimp and Halwa Cupcakes
description: Seafood momos and spicy crab meat stuffed inside papadum cones. Kachori chaat and paneer kati rolls. Gajar ka halwa cupcakes and date rose pistachio chocolate dark truffles.

title: Attacks Attest to Afghan Insurgents Spring Offensive
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In a further sign that the insurgents spring offensive is under way, suicide bombers struck in western and southern Afghanistan on Tuesday, killing 16 people, according to Afghan officials in Herat and Helmand, where the attacks took place.

title: Tensions Mount as Syria Truce Seems Elusive
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Syrian peace plan that was brokered under United Nations auspices appeared to be on life support on Tuesday, with Syria disregarding the initial step of returning its security forces to their barracks and senior diplomats around the world preparing for an ever more unlikely cease-fire set for Thursday.

title: The Amazing Matzo Stimulus
description: When Aron Streit started making matzo in 1916, unleavened bread was a serious growth business, at least on Manhattans Lower East Side. By the late 1920s, Streit could afford to build a special machine that mixed, kneaded and cooked dough. A decade later, his family added the cotton gin of kosher food  an automated conveyor belt with a Rube Goldberg-esque basket system that moved the matzo to a packaging area on a higher floor. They even opened a retail store next door that allowed customers to watch it in action.

title: Death Traps in Dhaka
description: A patriot might not readily describe his native city as a death trap and a beautiful place in the same breath, but for the Bangladeshi photographer Abir Abdullah, theyre not mutually exclusive. Bangladesh and its capital, Dhaka, one of the most populous and dense cities in the world, face complex challenges, as a robust economy frequently beset by natural disasters.

title: North Korea Is Set to Launch Satellite Despite Criticism
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea said on Tuesday that it had completed preparations to launch a satellite into orbit, as South Korea and other Asian nations told their airlines and ships to change their routes to avoid the North Korean rocket.

title: College Admissions Advice for Neurotic Parents
description: J.D. Rothman never thought of herself as a neurotic parent  until her two sons started looking at colleges. As she listened to other students discuss literally out of this world accomplishments, like discovering galaxies, she wondered how her son, without such a hook, would gain admission to a top school.

title: Obama Goes on Offensive Over Taxes on Wealthy
description: BOCA RATON, Fla.  All but certain now that his Republican opponent will be Mitt Romney, President Obama has made his proposed Buffett Rule minimum tax for the wealthiest Americans like Mr. Romney a centerpiece of his re-election campaign, defying the political risk of being seen as a tax-and-spender by wary voters.

title: Fantasy Focus: Chaos Among Closers
description: Its best not to overreact to what happens over a small sample at the beginning of the season, but when performance affects roles, fantasy owners need to pay attention. This is best illustrated with closers, who as a whole are off to a terrible start in 2012. Here are the most tenuous situations:

title: How to Really Simplify the Tax Code
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

title: Doug Martin, Second-Ranked Running Back in 2012 Draft
description: Matt Waldman is the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, a testament to his obsession with film analysis, now available for download.  Examples of his work can be found at his blog. He is helping the Fifth Down rank skill position players before the draft:

title: Dragone Classics, Including Murphy-Bodied Duesenberg, to Be Auctioned in May
description: WESTPORT, Conn.  The Duesenberg I was invited to drive off the lot, a 1931 Model J Custom Beverly, was expected to bring $1.5 to $2 million at the coming sale of Dragone Auctions on May 19. The cars value didnt stop the brothers Manny and George Dragone from letting me take a spin in the Duesenberg, or a 1963 Ferrari 250 GT Lusso, around this seaside Connecticut town.

title: European Court Says Britain Can Send Terror Suspects to U.S.
description: LONDON  The European Court of Human Rights ruled Tuesday that Britain could legally extradite five suspects wanted in the United States on terrorism charges, including Abu Hamza al-Masri, an inflammatory Egyptian-born cleric incarcerated in Britain but accused in a range of anti-American plots that date back 14 years.

title: Why Small Businesses Fail to Grow
description: I have written previously about why small businesses fail. Informed by my own failures as well as those Ive witnessed, that post is a gut-wrenching list of the causes of death for too many companies.

title: For Job Seekers, a Fracking Fair
description: Undeterred by New York States delays in deciding whether to allow fracking for natural gas, Broome County Community College, a business group and a coalition of landowners are holding a career and education expo on Wednesday for residents interested in learning about jobs in the gas industry.

description: ISTANBUL  This might be a good time to dust off the Ankara-Damascus hotline.

title: For Romney and Republican Committee, a Waiting Game
description: On the afternoon of March 5, 2008, John McCain did what Mitt Romney is still unable to do  he officially took hold of the Republican Partys political apparatus as he shifted to the battle against an as-yet unknown Democratic opponent for president.

description: We continue our pre-draft hidden needs series with the A.F.C. South.

title: Trade Gains Put China in Quandary
description: HONG KONG  After months of weakness in overseas demand, especially from Europe, Chinese exports finally seem to be recovering. But now the countrys domestic economy is looking a little less robust.

description: In the wake of National Reviews decision to part ways with its longtime contributor John Derbyshire over a frankly racist provocation published in the far-right website TakiMag, the Atlantics Conor Friedersdorf exhumes a long-ago Derbyshire interview in which he discussed the generational divide in conservative attitudes on race:

title: Sony Revises Expected Loss to $6.4 Billion
description: TOKYO  Sony more than doubled its projected net loss for the past financial year to 520 billion, its worst loss ever, as an additional tax expense hurt a company already battered by heavy losses in its television business, a strong yen and natural disasters in Japan and overseas.

title: Remembering a Massacre
description: MONTREAL  Ten years ago on April 11, I was standing on Baralt Avenue in downtown Caracas amid a chaos of tear gas, waving flags and surging protesters, but it was the crackling explosions that made me fidgety. They sounded like the firecrackers protesters had been setting off all through the seven mile march but, at this point, who could tell?

title: Albany Considering Limiting Release of Teacher Reports
Worst Loss This Year for Wall St.
description: The stock market sank deeper on Tuesday, eroding the first quarters blockbuster gains for a fifth straight day, as fears about the debt crisis in Europe re-emerged.

title: Daily Report: Fighting Cellphone Theft With a Database
description: Police departments, the Federal Communications Commission and the wireless phone industry have devised a plan to fight cellphone theft: the creation of a central database to track stolen phones and prevent them from being used again, Edward Wyatt reports in Tuesdays New York Times.
