title: In Court, Trying to Understand Asperger Syndrome
description: With autism front and center in the public consciousness  a report just out says that one American child in every 88 is diagnosed with an autism spectrum disorder  Darius McCollums frustrating odyssey through the criminal justice system is about to get another look. A court date in Queens awaits him, with the next few years of his life on the line.

title: Image of the Day: April 10
Tuesday Reading: Heading to Canada for Weight Loss Surgery
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

description: BEDFORD, Pa.  Rick Santorums daughter Bella was released from the hospital on Monday night and is back home with her family in Northern Virginia, his campaign said in a statement.

description: Facebooks announcement of its $1 billion acquisition of the mobile photo-sharing service Instagram grabbed the publics attention, and for reasons beyond the curious idea that a company not yet two years old and with about a dozen employees could be worth that kind of money.

title: What Were Reading
description: Bloomberg: The United States has agreed to formally recognize cachaa (above) as a distinctly Brazilian spirit. Since 2000, Brazil has had to label its native liquorwhich is distilled from sugar cane juiceas Brazilian rum, a label that has irked some cachaa producers. The Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau will begin the process by publishing notice of the proposed change and soliciting comment. Should the measure go through, Brazil will also extend official recognition of Americas bourbon and Tennessee whiskey.  Robert Simonson

title: Guillen Era Begins in Earnest
description: Today is, to say the least, an interesting day in Miami.

description: Kevin Drum has some fun, and rightly so, with Rick Warrens apparent belief that Jesus was a supply-sider:

title: St. Jude Is Rebuffed Over Report on Device
description: In a setback for St. Jude Medical, a medical journal late Monday rejected the companys request that it retract a published report that found that 20 deaths were linked to failures of a heart device component made by the company.

title: New Stance on Forgiving Mortgages
description: WASHINGTON  The overseer of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac on Tuesday opened the door to forgiving some mortgage debt of homeowners who owe more than their houses are worth, as the Obama administration has recently urged.

title: Penn Virginia Buys Chief Gathering for $1 Billion
description: Penn Virginia Resource Partners agreed on Tuesday to buy the energy pipeline company Chief Gathering for $1 billion as it expands its foothold in the booming shale gas sector in the United States.

title: Spain Bond Yields Rise, Reviving Fears of a Renewed Euro Crisis
description: MADRID  Spains borrowing costs rose Tuesday to levels not seen since early January, raising concerns that the financial crisis in Europe was heating up again after a lull. Stock markets closed sharply lower across the region.

title: Utah Breach Shows Vulnerability of Health Records
description: Eastern European hackers have stolen personal records for 780,000 people in the breach of a computer server in Utah.

title: Now Showing | Jeffry Mitchells Fantastical Totems

title: For High School Athlete With Down Syndrome, Age Is an Issue
description: Last New Years Eve, Eric Dompierre was at a party with his high school basketball teammates. At 12:30 a.m., he called his father, Dean Dompierre, to see if he could stay out for another hour. By 2 a.m., his father was good-naturedly dragging him home.

title: New Yorks Lucky Rice Festival Is Going to Las Vegas
description: Three years ago, Danielle Chang, who had been the chief executive of the fashion company Vivienne Tam, decided she would try to start a pan-Asian food festival in New York. She named it Lucky Rice, partnered with City Harvest, and got a number of local Asian chefs and restaurants to participate with tastings, dinners and other events over four days in 2010. Last year it expanded to a week-long series of events. Now, she said, Its my full-time job.

title: BAM and IFC Collaborating on New Comedy Showcase
description: Theres no shortage of jokes to be made about Brooklyn, but are there enough places in Brooklyn to make jokes? The Brooklyn Academy of Music and the IFC cable channel are working together on a new opportunity for comedians to perform their material in that borough (whether their bits are about Marty Markowitz or double-wide baby strollers).

title: Cracker Barrel Moves to Thwart Biglari With Poison Pill
description: 11:57 a.m. | Updated

title: Death of a Briton Is Thrust to Center of China Scandal
description: BEIJING  The mysterious death of a 41-year-old British businessman in a Chongqing hotel room late last year was thrust to the center of the biggest political scandal to hit Chinas Communist Party in a generation on Tuesday, as the authorities declared the death a murder and named the wife of one of Chinas most powerful men the leading suspect.

title: Corning to Buy Majority of a Becton Biosciences Division
description: Corning agreed on Tuesday to buy the majority of a Becton Dickinsons biosciences unit for about $730 million in cash, amid continued interest in deals for life sciences and laboratory equipment businesses.

title: Coaxing American Chestnuts Back to Appalachia
description: Old swaths of Appalachian forest land left barren by decades of coal mining may find their past is their future, if efforts to restore the American chestnut tree in reclaimed coal fields are successful.

title: Mortgage Servicers Face New Oversight
description: Financial regulators are planning broad new oversight of the mortgage servicing business in an effort to prevent some of the problems that led to the housing boom and bust.

description: If you wade into my column today about Craig Claibornes life, youll find reference to a 1963 story in The Times with this archaic headline: Growth of Overt Homosexuality in City Provokes Wide Concern.

title: A Graphic, Continuous Tale of the Titanics Voyage
description: The sinking of the Titanic 100 years ago was one of the biggest news stories of the last century. In the days after the luxury liner plunged into the depths of the Atlantic Ocean, the catastrophe dominated the pages of the many newspapers in New York City, which was to have been the Titanics destination.

description: Tyler Cowens book An Economist Gets Lunch arrives on the table like a big, unidentifiable, whey-colored casserole. After 75 pages youre still poking at it, thinking, What is this thing? and Can I order something else?

title: Chris Weitz to Write Young-Adult Novels
description: The writer and director Chris Weitz is trying his hand at young-adult fiction. Mr. Weitz, who directed The Twilight Saga: New Moon, will write a trilogy of post-apocalyptic novels for Little, Brown Books for Young Readers, a division of the Hachette Book Group, his publisher announced. The first book in the series, The Young World, is expected to be released in spring 2014.

description: ALBANY  Public employees are working without contracts in cities and counties across New York State, as labor negotiations stall because local governments say they cannot afford to raise wages.

title: Most Important Game for the Knicks: Against the Celtics
description: New Yorks victory over the Bulls on Sunday gave the Knicks a record of 29-27, which placed them in a tie for the seventh playoff spot in the Eastern Conference with the Sixers. Since New York defeated Philadelphia in 2 of their 3 contests this year, the Knicks would have the advantage in a tie-breaker should the two teams finish the regular season with the same record.

title: In Miami, Winning Clearly Isnt the Only Thing
description: MIAMI  In an effort to revitalize their long-struggling franchise and attract the Latino baseball fans of South Florida, the Miami Marlins built a new $634 million stadium, revamped their uniforms, signed one of the biggest Hispanic stars in the league and hired a brash manager from Venezuela who guided the Chicago White Sox to a World Series title. The team even made sure its electronic concessions menus alternated between English and Spanish.

title: Have an N.H.L. Question? Slap Shot Has Answers
description: 11:59 a.m. | Updated Will the Rangers have any trouble with the Senators? Will the Philadelphia-Pittsburgh series go seven games? How far can the Devils go this year? Jeff Z. Klein, the N.H.L. reporter for The Times, and Christopher Botta, a contributor to The Times and to Slap Shot, will answer questions from readers. Submit questions in the comments field, and answers will appear on Slap Shot later this week.Comments for this feature have been closed.

title: Critic of Conservation Efforts Gets Critiqued
description: Peter Kareiva, the chief scientist of the Nature Conservancy and perhaps the most prominent critic of the conservation movement from within its own ranks, has had his arguments sharply challenged. The pushback has come both in the comment string on Dot Earth following my recent post on him and at Breakthrough Journal, which posted Conservation in the Anthropocene, an essay by Kareiva and two colleagues, followed bya package of rebuttals and, most recently,a response from Kareiva et al.

title: Instagram Users Fail to Welcome Their New Overlord
description: Beast, Mark Zuckerbergs dog, had his moment of fame on Instagram Monday. The Facebook founder shared a picture of the shaggy-haired mutt late in the evening after his company announced it was purchasing Instagram for $1 billion.

title: A Roadblock to Recovering Money for Madoffs Victims
description: Most investors lose almost all of their money once a Ponzi scheme collapses, and the trustees appointed to clean up the mess try to find any deep pocket available to recover something. Unfortunately for the trustees, the legal doctrine of in pari delicto, Latin for in equal fault, may block any recovery.

title: Rolling Stones Heading to Studio to Get the Feel Again
description: With the 50th anniversary of the founding of the Rolling Stones fast approaching, speculation about what the band might or might not do to commemorate the date continues. The guitarist Ronnie Wood offered some tantalizing hints on Monday, saying that the group would go into a recording studio later this month to just bat some ideas around and get the feel again.

description: Brian J. Dunn, chief executive of the electronics retailer Best Buy, resigned unexpectedly Tuesday during an investigation by the board into what it called his personal conduct.

description: I DONT really dream anymore, but when I do, I dream of slow life, barefoot rug rats, sun streaks through windows, unspoken connections, evenings of calm bleeding into mornings of hope, the doors closed to the rest of the world. I dream of hiding, us against everyone else.

title: Want to Place Bets on Facebooks Next Acquisition?
description: As you may have heard, Facebook scooped up the profitless photo-sharing app, Instagram, for a cool $1 billion on Monday.

title: Protecting What Mali Stands For
description: WASHINGTON  I asked my Sudanese cabbie where he was from. China, he replied. In the city that acts like it runs the world, he is fed up that so few people know their Darfur from their Juba. If thats true of Sudan, with so much at stake, pity the rest of a diverse continent that Rick Santorum, a candidate for the Republican Partys nomination for president of the United States, called a single country of Islamic fanatics.

title: All Hail Azawad
description: Heres yet another contentious line drawn in the sand of the Sahara desert: The northern half of Mali has just declared independence, and would henceforth like that you call it Azawad, pretty please. We solemnly proclaim the independence of Azawad as of today, Mossa ag Attaher, a rebel [1] spokesman, told the France 24 TV channel on Friday, April 6.

description: A new study shows that patients are far less likely to undergo screening for colon cancer if their doctors recommend only colonoscopy, rather than offering other screening options.

description: My husband and I call it redefining fun. The weekend at the away hockey tournament. The Family Art Night at the school. The team parties, the time on the sidelines and in the bleachers, the side of the community pool.

title: A Series of Concerts and Films to Honor Cecil Taylor
description: The pianist Cecil Taylor, a fundamental influence in the wilder currents of improvised music since the 1950s, will be the subject of a two-week series of concerts and films in Manhattan and Brooklyn in May, produced jointly by Harlem Stage and Issue Project Room. (Information and tickets for the concerts are available through their Web sites.)

title: TimesCast | April 10, 2012
description: The Miami Marlins suspend Manager Ozzie Guillen over comments praising Fidel Castro | A European court rules that Britain can extradite five terror suspects to the United States.

title: Derby Dreams Ride In on a White Horse
description: For Hansen, the reigning 2-year-old thoroughbred champion, every race is like a work of performance art. Not in the way he runs, which is almost always at the front of the field, but the way he looks as he does it. He is the color of alabaster, a striking white vision set against the bays, browns and chestnuts he has left behind in all but one race.

title: Credit Card Rates Up Slightly, but 0 Percent Offers Get Longer
description: Interest rates on general consumer credit cards ticked up in the first three months of the year, but no-interest offers generally got longer, a new analysis from CardHub.com finds.

title: The Incredible Shrinking Payroll
description: The key to sustained job growth may be helping more start-ups get off the ground.

title: A Goldman Co-Head of Global Mergers to Step Down
description: One of Goldman Sachss co-heads of global mergers and acquisitions, Yol Zaoui, is retiring from the investment bank, the firm said in an internal memorandum obtained by DealBook on Tuesday.

title: HBO Orders a Third Season for Game of Thrones
description: As the saying doesnt quite go but should from now on: a Lannister always gets a third season. HBO said on Tuesday that it was ordering another year of Game of Thrones, its fantasy drama about the warring clans of Starks, Lannisters, Baratheons, Greyjoys and Targaryen (among other unusual permutations of vowels and consonants) on the mythical continent of Westeros. The series, which is adapted from George R. R. Martins best-selling Song of Ice and Fire novels and produced by David Benioff and D.B. Weiss, was a breakout hit in its first season, earning an Emmy nomination for best dramatic series and winning an Emmy and a Golden Globe for its star Peter Dinklage, who plays the manipulative Tyrion Lannister. Season 2, which began on April 1, is already off to a strong start, drawing nearly 4 million viewers for the debut broadcasts of each episode that have been shown so far. Dates for the production and premiere of Season 3 of Game of Thrones were not announced but should occur some time after Daenerys Targaryen crosses the Red Waste.

title: Another Bogus Attack on Health Reform
description: Oh, boy. It turns out that the WaPo featured on its front page a report by Charles Blahous of the (yes, Koch-funded) Mercatus Center  although the Post describes him as a Medicare trustee, giving the impression that this is somehow an official document  claiming that the Affordable Care Act will actually increase the deficit. Jonathan Chait does the honors:

title: The Buffett Rule
description: Few things capture the difference in values between President Obama and his Republican opponents quite as neatly as their positions on the Warren Buffet-inspired Buffett Rule, which would require Americans making over $1 million a year to pay at least 30 percent of their income in taxes.

title: The Body Whisperer
description: One of the West Coasts best-kept beauty secrets, the body contourier Megan Simon uses endermologie, sunless airbrush tanning, electrical currents, pet products and plain old good advice to make her celebrity clientele look slim, trim and cellulite-free.

title: Psychiatry May Also Face Scrutiny at Norway Killers Trial
description: After an earlier psychiatric report declared him to be a paranoid schizophrenic living in a delusional universe, a second evaluation by Norwegian psychiatrists released on Tuesday found Anders Behring Breivik, the anti-Muslim extremist who methodically killed 77 people in Oslo last year, to be legally sane, according to Norwegian officials.

title: European Bank Shares Take a Nosedive
description: LONDON  It was a bad day for European banking stocks.

title: F.A.Q. on Hawk Hatching
description: On Monday night, a baby red-tailed hawk made its broadcast debut in a nest overlooking Washington Square Park.

title: Rights Advocate Given Prison Term in China
description: HONG KONG  Ni Yulan, a rights advocate who was crippled by abuse in prison and was later left homeless on the streets of Beijing, was sentenced by a Chinese court on Tuesday to a new prison term of two years and eight months, an advocacy group said.

title: A Slimmer DreamWorks Gets a New Financing Deal
description: LOS ANGELES  DreamWorks Studios, the film boutique founded four years ago by Steven Spielberg and Stacey Snider, got a new lease on life, as Reliance Entertainment agreed in principle to continue financing the company.

title: Walcott, Turnaround Schools, Teacher Evaluations
Santorum Suspends Presidential Campaign
description: 3:08 p.m. | Updated Rick Santorum suspended his presidential campaign on Tuesday, bowing to the inevitability of Mitt Romneys nomination and ending his improbable, come-from-behind quest to become the partys conservative standard-bearer in the fall.

title: A He-Wax for Him
description: YEARS after the word metrosexual entered the mainstream, theres nothing eyebrow-raising about men getting a manicure or a facial. Lately though, guys grooming has gone one step further, deep into territory that was previously reserved solely for women: bikini waxing.

title: A Brush With Art, and Royalty, in Monaco
description: Its not every day that one dines with Princess Caroline of Monaco.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,913 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American on Monday:

title: Pera Soho
description: 54 Thompson Street (corner of Broome Street), (212) 878-6305, peranyc.com.

title: Slide Show: Pera Soho
description: In a neighborhood more preoccupied with fashion than food, Pera Soho, reviewed this week, is a step in the right direction. (An expensive one, though.) An accomplished Turkish chef is in charge here; his best dishes are revised classics, like minced lamb kebab, smoky eggplant pure and lacy kunefe, shreds of phyllo with butter, honey and clotted cream.

title: In California, a Fast-Charging First
description: A Los Angeles-based firm claims to have installed Californias first public fast-charging station, which opened for business last week. The unit, which can recharge the battery pack of a Nissan Leaf in about 30 minutes, is located at the Stanford Shopping Center in Palo Alto, adjacent to Stanford University and about 30 miles south of San Francisco.

title: Teenage Birthrates at Record Low
description: Despite (or because of?) the popularity of shows like Teen Mom and 16 and Pregnant, teenage birthrates are at record lows in the United States.

title: A Dinner Party With Two Mike Wallaces
description: The telephone rang. It was Sy Presten, an old-school press agent who had been pitching items to columnists in New York since the days of Walter Winchell.

title: Edible Selby | Green Zone
description: Cookbook, a green grocery store in the Echo Park neighborhood of Los Angeles run by the master gardener and chef Marta Teegen, is a monument to the principle of quality over quantity: inside the modest 500-square-foot space is nearly everything a cook with a penchant for natural ingredients could possibly want. The best organic produce, yes. But also Dr. Bobs ice cream, fresh-cut flowers, pasture-raised meats, Mast Brothers chocolate, Creminelli salami, Caf Fanny granola and an ever-changing menu of prepared foods, derived each week from a different cookbook of Teegens choosing. Mediterranean sources, like Moro East by Sam and Sam Clark, are in heavy rotation. We are interested in looking at what new things people are doing with food, Teegen says, but we also like to go back to the classics. More

title: Lost in the G.S.A. Scandal, Confusion About a Small-Business Contract
description: The scandal unfolding at the General Services Administration mostly has to do with outrageous spending. The agency, which essentially serves as the governments back office, managing property, federal purchases and some administrative services, pulled out all the stops when it sent 300 employees to a Las Vegas resort for a conference in 2010  the bill for the five-day affair totaled $823,000 and included extravagances like luxury hotel suites and $7,000 worth of sushi. But one issue raised in the investigation into the boondoggle hasnt gotten very much attention: a government contract for running part of the conference that should have gone to a small business seems to have gone to a large company.

title: Etgar Kerets Stories Read by a Chorus of Voices
description: For his latest collection of stories, Suddenly, a Knock on the Door, the Israeli writer Etgar Keret gathered an all-star cast to read his comic, surrealist, often very brief works. The final roster of participants includes Ira Glass, Neal Stephenson, Miranda July, George Saunders, Aimee Bender, John Sayles and Michael Chabon.

title: Rick Santorum Suspends His Campaign
description: Rick Santorum suspended his presidential campaign on Tuesday, ending his improbable, come-from-behind quest to become the partys conservative standard-bearer in the fall.

description: The federal consumer watchdog agency is proposing new rules to protect borrowers from shoddy practices by mortgage servicers.

title: Rangers Playoff Report: Lundqvist Gets S. I. Cover, Callahan and Gaborik Return
description: 4:23 p.m. | Updated GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Henrik Lundqvist is on the cover of regional editions of this weeks Sports Illustrated, sharing the honor with the Masters winner, Bubba Watson.

title: Scully Misses Dodgers Opener With Illness
description: It might be a new era at Dodger Stadium, but the one thing everybody loves about the old era  play-by-play gem Vin Scully  was noticeably absent from the Dodgers opening day broadcast on Tuesday. The Dodgers announced he was out sick with a bad cold, which meant he would miss the home opener for the first time since 1977. That one wasnt a sick day. He was calling the first round of the Masters.

title: Credit Suisse Hires Veteran Tech Banker From Merrill
description: Credit Suisse has hired Chris Gaertner from Bank of America Merrill Lynch as a high-ranking technology banker, the firm announced in an internal memorandum obtained by DealBook on Tuesday.

title: Business Day Live | Google Glasses
description: April 10, 2012 - Sizing up Google's Internet-connected glasses.

title: Emanuel Azenberg, Neil Simons Favorite Producer, Will Get Special Tony Award
description: Few producers have had as much success backing plays on Broadway as Emanuel Azenberg, who shepherded more than 20 Neil Simon comedies over the last four decades (including hits like Brighton Beach Memoirs and Lost in Yonkers) and won eight Tony Awards out of 25 total nominations. Now the 78-year-old Mr. Azenberg will add another Tony to his shelf this June as the recipient of the 2012 award for lifetime achievement in the theater, the organizers of the annual awards ceremony announced on Tuesday.

title: The Not-So-Raging Middle Class
description: In 2010, when Simon Roberts began photographing protests around England, it was the protesters homemade signs that most intrigued him. He set about creating a visual archive of the individual signs (seen above and below) about 250 of which will appear in his exhibition titled Let This Be a Sign, which opens at the Swiss Cottage Gallery on May 23 as part of the London Festival of Photography.

title: Goodbye, Rick Santorum
description: Rick Santorum never had a chance. The Republican leadership and many Republican primary voters are borderline delusional, but they dont have a death wish.

title: American Hostages Released From Iran
description: After 444 days in captivity, the Americans held hostage in Tehran were released.

title: Remembering Titanic: Where the Passengers Are Buried
description: So youve been Titanic-ing, Susan Olsen, the staff historian at Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx, said when J. Joseph Edgette walked in.

title: In Auckland, Exploring the South Seas Without Setting Sail
description: For some reason, few memories are more indelible for me than when I hear familiar phrases in an unexpectedly foreign language. Like when as a teenager I pulled a Beatles LP off my dads shelf and dropped the needle on I Want to Hold Your Hand  in German. (Komm gib mir deine Hand). Or when, as a student teacher in Los Angeles, I witnessed an assembly of grade-schoolers robotically recite the Pledge of Allegiance  in Spanish (Juro fidelidad a la bandera de los Estados Unidos de Amrica).

title: Two and a Half Men Tumbles to Lowest Audience in Five Years
description: Last fall, Two and a Half Men on CBS was a huge ratings success when it returned to record numbers despite the loss of its star Charlie Sheen. And for the rest of 2011 it consistently finished above the audience totals from previous seasons. But that has not been the case this spring.

title: Some Urge U.S. to Focus on Selling Its Skills Overseas
description: In the drive to double Americas exports, Washington has been focusing on manufacturers. But that may be the wrong target.

title: Two Different Journeys Link a Father and Daughter
description: No one likes the political-correctness police. But its hard not to be a member of this scorned squad when watching From the Same Cloth, an autobiographical play written by and starring Megan Auster-Rosen.

title: Photo Replay: April 10
description: The day in sports included bodybuilding in Mumbai, the first round of the Danish Open tennis tournament in Denmark and opening day at Dodger Stadium.

title: When Test Prep Requires Test Prep
Look of the Moment | Rihanna
description: The Look: Slick. A one-piece gets the black-tie treatment with strappy heels, skinny gold hoop earrings and a clean updo.

title: Digital Diary: Instagram and the Internets Secret Places
description: Are the golden days of Instagram over?

title: Meanwhile, Paul Keeps Campaigning
description: Now that Rick Santorum has suspended his campaign, and Newt Gingrich is focusing his efforts on the convention, Mitt Romney still faces one opponent with money: Representative Ron Paul. And on Tuesday, Mr. Paul was campaigning in Texas, his home state, which votes on May 29, to show that the Republican contest was still registering a slight pulse.

title: Devastating Bat Fungus Invades From Europe
description: A study published this week in the journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences confirms that the fungus Geomyces destructans causes white-nose syndrome, a disease that has killed more than 5.5 million bats in North America since being discovered in a cave near Albany in 2006.

title: What Does Santorums Future Hold?
description: Although Rick Santorum was exceptionally unlikely to win the Republican presidential nomination, his decision to suspend his campaign, which puts an effective end to the Republican nomination process, is obviously good news for Mitt Romney, who can now focus fully on his general election campaign against President Obama.

title: The Probability of a Private Equity Play for Best Buy
description: Is Best Buy a private equity play?

title: Digital Notes: Who Attends South by Southwest? Let Us Draw You a Picture
description: Who was at South by Southwest this year? By one reckoning, the average attendee was a single, 31-year-old man making $83,000 a year who most likely has more Twitter and Facebook friends than you do.

title: Obama to Make Case for Buffett Rule
description: President Obama is taking his argument in favor of a 30 percent minimum tax on millionaires to Florida, where he will tell students at Florida Atlantic University that in this country, prosperity has never trickled down from a wealthy few, reports Jackie Calmes for The New York Times. Read more

title: The Rick Santorum Campaign Ends
description: Jeff Zeleny reports on Mr. Santorum's withdrawal from the race and the turn to the general election for his former rival Mitt Romney.

title: Disney Enters Into Chinese Partnership on Animation
description: The Chinese government and the Walt Disney Company, in partnership with the Internet service provider Tencent, on Tuesday announced a deal to collaborate on animated movies, shorts, TV shows and Web videos.

title: Goodnight, Moon. Goodnight, Math Problem.
description: Ive just become aware that April is Math Awareness Month.

title: Colorado State Recoils After Students Accuse Football Players of Beating
description: So far, criminal charges have not been filed against the Colorado State football players who are accused of beating four freshman students late Friday night in Fort Collins, but not many are rushing to their defense.

title: Rangel Sounds Confident of Re-election While Speaking Well of Challenger
description: 8:53 p.m. | Updated He twirled in a leather office chair with the waistband of his dark slacks pulled up well past his belly button and with a microphone in his hand. The rows of people sitting before him seemed enamored of the slender, silver-haired man who spent most of the morning with them smiling.

title: Speedy Romeo
description: 376 Classon Avenue (Greene Avenue), Bedford-Stuyvesant/Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, (718) 230-0061, speedyromeo.com.

title: Styled to a T | Kati Nescher
description: The Trend

title: Slide Show: Speedy Romeo
description: Speedy Romeo was first the name of a horse, a world-champion harness racer who could never quite make up his mind between the pace and the trot. He won at both. (The late sportswriter Red Smith described him  with admiration  as a schizophrenic steed.)

title: Mets Wright Has Small Fracture in Pinkie
description: Riding high after winning their first four games, the Mets received disturbing news Tuesday when David Wright was scratched from the lineup because of a small fracture at the middle joint of the pinkie of his right hand.

title: Gingrich Says Hes in the Race to the End
description: After Rick Santorum suspended his presidential campaign, speculation turned to Newt Gingrich, whose candidacy continued despite long odds.

title: Chinas Exports Rise, but Imports Lag
description: Chinas exports outstripped imports last month

title: Santorums Future? Return to Fox News Is Unlikely
description: Rick Santorums days as a paid Fox News commentator are long gone.

title: TimesCast | Court Allows Extraditions
description: April 10, 2012  A European court rules that Britain can extradite five terror suspects to the United States.

title: Drug Data Shouldnt Be Secret
description: IN the fall of 2009, at the height of fears over swine flu, our research group discovered that a majority of clinical trial data for the anti-influenza drug Tamiflu  data that proved, according to its manufacturer, that the drug reduced the risk of hospitalization, serious complications and transmission  were missing, unpublished and inaccessible to the research community. From what we could tell from the limited clinical data that had been published in medical journals, the countrys most widely used and heavily stockpiled influenza drug appeared no more effective than aspirin.

title: An iPhone Charger With a Bonus
description: As smartphones become more powerful, they consume more power, keeping users in constant need of a working charger. No one wants a phone to die in the middle of a call or, worse, in the middle of a Facebook update.

title: More on Extreme Weather in a Warming Climate
description: April 11, 9:47 a.m. | Updated with a reaction from Stefan Rahmstorf below |

title: Seasonalitys Master Practitioner
description: SOME facts are beyond the reach of search engines. This is probably lucky for all of us, and it is especially lucky for those who go to eat at Kyo Ya. A Japanese hideaway in the middle of the East Village, Kyo Ya gives up its secrets slowly. Learning them is part of the adventure.

title: Kyo Ya
description: A Japanese hideaway in the middle of the East Village is known for its kaiseki dining.

title: Rocks Dont Melt, Nor Do Their Fans
description: WHEN whiskey stones first showed up on store shelves five years ago, they seemed destined to be another fleeting oddity, perhaps an upscale version of the Pet Rock fad of 1975.

title: Excerpt: 'Tribes'
description: Russell Harvard plays a deaf young man and Susan Pourfar his girlfriend in Nina Raines play at the Barrow Street Theater.

title: Aspiring to Conquer Crossover Acting Path
description: It didnt take much rehearsing for Russell Harvard, who plays the deaf son of a loquacious and argumentative British family in the Off Broadway play Tribes, to get inside his characters skin.

title: One Soloist Takes on Seven Characters
description: As the Odissi dancer Sujata Mohapatra told the story on Monday, the narrative dance she was about to perform for the opening night of the Erasing Borders festival of Indian dance was not originally conceived as a solo.

title: Weaving a Tapestry Between Bits of Prometheus
description: Thomas Crawfords American Classical Orchestra is working hard to be the period-instrument orchestra that survives and thrives in New York, where so many others have foundered. It is, in a way, a stealth contender: counting its earlier incarnation as the Orchestra of the Old Fairfield Academy, the ensemble has been exploring the late-18th- and early-19th-century repertory for 27 seasons. And its roster is full of names familiar from other period-instrument groups that ply the New York-Boston freelance corridor, among them the violinist Linda Quan, the violist David Miller, the cellist Myron Lutzke, the flutist Sandra Miller, the oboist Marc Schachman and the trumpeter John Thiessen.

title: The Summer of 62, at a Vintage Price
description: When the Mets play the Nationals on Wednesday in the final game of their three-game series, fans will not only see a marquee matchup between Johan Santana and Stephen Strasburg, but also get to see a slice of history at a bargain-basement price.

title: Bernanke Quietly Criticizes Lack of Repo Reforms
description: Ben S. Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, doesnt sound very happy with the state of affairs in a crucial part of the financial system.

title: N.Y.U. Agrees to Scale Back Its Expansion in the Village
description: New York University has agreed to reduce the scale of its plans for four tall buildings in Greenwich Village by almost a fifth.

title: Pictures of the Day: Tunisia and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Tunisia, Bahrain, Syria and Afghanistan.

title: Natural Gas Signals a Manufacturing Renaissance
description: AS horizontal drilling and the controversial extraction technique known as fracking have made domestically produced natural gas more available and sharply cheaper, that gas has been widely embraced by industry, electric utilities and trucking fleets.

title: Romance-Minded Troll Borrows Cupids Bow
description: Theres a chuckle every 10 or so minutes in the romantic comedy Out of Iceland, at Walkerspace. Youll know that because youll check your watch often, wondering how much longer the play, with barely 20 minutes worth of plot, will try to stretch its running time. (Answer: an hour and a half.)

title: A Chef Whose Touch Will Last
description: CHICAGO

title: BFFs? No, These Roommates Are Not Friends
description: Pretend that you dont know what the B in the title of Dont Trust the B in Apartment 23, the comedy that begins on Wednesday on ABC, stands for. That the offending phrase wasnt spoken twice in the first episode. That the theme song doesnt rhyme the B-word with Im no snitch. That GCB, also on ABC, hadnt already pioneered the abbreviated-title-as-lazy-titillation ploy.

title: Excerpt: 'Don't Trust the B- in Apt. 23'
description: Krysten Ritter is the titular character in the new ABC comedy.

title: Starting From Scraps
description: LEFTOVERS get short shrift. Relegated to the back of the fridge, abandoned among forgotten condiments and that container of heavy cream stuck to the shelf, they are mostly thought of as late-night snacks, economy dinners or tomorrows lunch. Even the word leftovers carries the negative connotation of the unwanted, the uneaten, the scraps.

title: Beinart Fires Back
description: The day my book, The Crisis of Zionism, hit the shelves I gave a speech at the University of Maryland. During question and answer session, an older Jewish mangrim-faced, teeth-clencheddemanded to know how I could criticize Israel for occupying the West Bank when most West Bank Palestinians effectively govern themselves, and when the Palestinians have shown themselves unwilling to live at peace. I responded that while Palestinians do indeed bear part of the blame for the lack of a Palestinian state, Israels policy of subsidizing Jews to move to settlementsincluding settlements deep in the West Bankonly strengthens the most militant forces in Palestinian society. He rose again in protest, then sat down and glared.

title: Kreider Signs With Rangers, but Is He Playoff-Ready?
description: The Rangers agreed to terms with forward Chris Kreider, a first-round pick in 2009 and a key member of the Boston College team that won the N.C.A.A. championship Saturday, on a three-year contract Tuesday afternoon.

title: A Life and a Nation, Tightly Bound
description: The Lady, Luc Bessons worshipful film about the Myanmar opposition leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, arrives at a propitious moment. In the real world Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi  played by Michelle Yeoh and referred to as Suu in the movie  was elected to Parliament earlier this month, one of the latest signs that Myanmar (formerly known as Burma) may be moving in a democratic direction after a half-century of military dictatorship.

title: The Instagram Deal and the Question of When to Sell
description: 6:26 p.m. | Updated It is a question that every successful start-up faces: When to cash out?

title: Uncertain Fate for Urban Projects in California
description: LOS ANGELES  It is impossible to miss the long-moribund Santa Barbara Plaza, a collection of mostly boarded-up retail buildings in South Los Angeles across the street from a shopping center that just underwent a $30 million overhaul. After some costly missteps that only worsened the blight, plans to transform the ugly 19.2-acre site into a mixed-use development called Marlton Square finally seemed to be gathering steam, and the city redevelopment agency started clearing the land last summer.

title: Mostly Mozart Plans Take Wing
description: The Mostly Mozart Festival, in its persistent search for variety, usually finds other composers to highlight. This summer will be no different: a dozen concerts will include works by Schubert, festival officials said on Tuesday. But rarely has it invoked the animal world. The festival said the other focus would be ornithological, as in the influence of birdsong on composers and visual artists. Programs will include chirp-related works by Messiaen and several contemporary composers. The festival will sponsor bird walks in Central Park and show the 2001 documentary Winged Migration. The Murder of Crows, an art installation by Janet Cardiff and George Bures Miller at the Park Avenue Armory, will be presented and organized by the Armory in association with the festival. Visiting conductors of the festival orchestra include Yannick Nzet-Sguin, Susanna Mlkki and Osmo Vnska. Among the soloists will be Nelson Freire, Lawrence Brownlee, Joshua Bell and Martin Frost. Louis Langre will conduct nine concerts in his 10th year as music director.

title: Brazil, Where Oil and Women Mix Powerfully
description: RIO DE JANEIRO

title: Subtly Selling Green to the Flat-Screen Crowd
description: SEATTLE

title: Real-Time Data to Reduce Electric Use
description: WHEN Max Dunn walks through his kitchen in San Jose, Calif., he often glances at the home energy monitor that sits on the countertop. The monitor resembles a cars GPS device and connects wirelessly to the homes power meter.

title: Renewable Sources of Power Survive, but in a Patchwork
description: JUST a few years ago, the future of renewable energy looked as bright and shiny as a white turbine blade coming out of the mold. The federal government was handing out money under the stimulus package, states were approving clean energy mandates, young companies were racing ahead with promising new technologies and big global developers were planting stakes for ambitious, utility-scale projects.

title: Nuclear Powers Death Somewhat Exaggerated
description: NUCLEAR energy is going through an odd patch. It refuses to die, but it does not prosper.

title: Meccas of Shopping Try Hand at Being Misers of Energy
description: FOR most people, talking about commercial air filters is a great way to end a conversation. To Charlie Brantl and Bob Devine, it is an invitation to an hourlong discussion.

title: Out of Africa (and Elsewhere): More Fossil Fuels
description: THE worlds largest energy companies have big plans for Mozambique.

title: Shaken Lawyer Syndrome
description: Apart from Rick Santorums concession speech in Gettysburg, it seems like all of todays big news stories came out of Florida. President Obama pitched the Buffet Rule in Boca Raton. The Florida Marlins suspended their manager for making stupid remarks about Fidel Castro. And the attorneys representing George Zimmerman, the vigilante who killed Trayvon Martin, announced that they were withdrawing from the case.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Instagrams Direction, and Amazon on Tumblr
description: Here are some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Tuesday. There are more here.

title: Notes From the Recipe Tester: Working With Phyllo
description: Denise Landis has been testing recipes for The New York Times for more than 20 years. She is also the author of Dinner for Eight: 40 Great Dinner Party Menus for Friends and Family. Here, she offers tips for making one of this weeks Dining recipes.

title: Bloomberg Accuses Comcast of Favoring Its Own Channels
description: A dispute between Bloomberg L.P. and Comcast escalated on Tuesday when Bloomberg filed a complaint with the Federal Communications Commission accusing Comcast of favoring its own cable news channels.

title: Fuel to Burn: Now What?
description: THE reversal of fortune in Americas energy supplies in recent years holds the promise of abundant and cheaper fuel, and it could have profound effects on what people drive, domestic manufacturing and Americas foreign policy.

title: Fertilizer Billionaire Buys Buildings His Way, in Cash
description: It is rare when a buyer pays all cash for a real estate property, and even rarer when the dollar figure is in excess of $300 million. But that was the case last week when a fertilizer tycoon, Alex Rovt, acquired a majority stake in 14 Wall Street, the 1-million-square-foot office building across from the New York Stock Exchange in Lower Manhattan.

title: A Quiet File Clerk at the Epicenter of Political Turmoil
description: Pablo Larrans Post Mortem takes place in Chile around the time of the 1973 military coup that overthrew former President Salvador Allende and inaugurated a 17-year dictatorship. There are angry crowds in the streets of the capital, Santiago; gunfire in the distance; and bodies piled up in the morgue where Mario, the main character, works. But the sweep and energy of historical drama are notably missing from this grim, intense, mordantly comic little film, and the sequence of public events matters less to Mr. Larran than their muffled psychological effects and unacknowledged emotional implications.

title: Orchestre Septentrional of Haiti
description: The group, though little known outside Haiti and its diaspora, is enjoying a burst of attention.

title: For 6 Decades, the Sound of Good News in Haiti
description: Since the founding of the Orchestre Septentrional in 1948, the bands homeland, Haiti, has endured the nearly three-decade Duvalier family dictatorship, 26 other governments, a foreign intervention, a devastating earthquake and, most recently, a cholera epidemic.

title: To Heal, First Eat
description: ST. HELENA, Calif.

title: Swapping Stethoscopes for Chefs Toques
description: Medical professionals gather at the Healthy Kitchens/Healthy Lives conference in California, where they take cooking classes and attend lectures.

title: John G. Udell
description: Mr. Udell, 55, is the president of Weichert Commercial Brokerage and Weichert New Home, which focuses on new residential developments like 77 Hudson in Jersey City. This year he celebrated his 20th anniversary at the company.

title: Santorum Suspends Campaign for President
description: Photographs from Rick Santorums run for the Republican presidential nomination.

title: So Riveting You Might Have Heard a Fork Drop
description: The popular Greenwich Village music club Le Poisson Rouge is an informal place where patrons are encouraged to drink and eat during concerts, so there are inevitably some clinking glasses and waiters whooshing by.

title: Two Baby Hawks in the Nest
description: Wednesday, 11:25 a.m. | Updated  A second baby hawk has arrived on the 12th-floor window ledge of New York Universitys Bobst Library, where The New York Times has set up a live-streaming camera to film the lives of a raptor pair, Rosie and Bobby. The couple are now raising two baby chicks in the middle of Manhattan.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Autism Brunch

title: Photographic Bites of Street Eats
description: Think twice about opening this book on an empty stomach. After a few minutes with the fat new volume Take Away, by Jean-Franois Mallet, you are certain to raid the fridge, order in some dumplings or run out to the nearest food truck. The author, a chef and photographer, has filled every page with riveting pictures, mostly color and taken over a span of 10 years, showing people in 25 countries dining, snacking and cooking. The travelogue includes watermelon slices in Mumbai, India; brochettes of cheese and thyme on the beach in Bahia, Brazil; snails in Marrakesh, Morocco and Barcelona, Spain; pickles at the Carnegie Deli; huge Shanghai soup dumplings served with a straw, and crisp coriander-spiced duck in thin pastry from Vietnam. Only a few places are identified beyond a country or city, making it a bit frustrating. And I did wonder why, for England, Mr. Millet showed only fish and chips, and nothing from the dense foodscape at Borough Market.

title: AOL Patent Deal Does Not Appease Starboard
description: AOL will need more than a billion-dollar patent sale to quell the ire of one of its largest shareholders.

title: Pancakes for Any Meal, Maple Syrup Not Included
description: Tossing together wheat, oats, sunflower seeds and millet for morning pancakes requires a very well-stocked pantry. Or simply a mix from the Bunnery, a cafe that Grard Yvernault, a former wine executive and consultant, owns in Jackson, Wyo. The home cook simply adds eggs, milk and melted butter to produce pancakes and waffles that are flavorful and hearty. Wheat bran, oat bran and cracked wheat are also in the formula. Now the company has introduced new flavors: double chocolate, coconut vanilla and wild blueberry. Im not so sure about chocolate pancakes in the morning, but they are another story at dessert, served warm with ice cream and fudge sauce. The coconut variety also shines at meals end, topped with sauted bananas. None of the mixes are too sweet. Thin the batter with extra milk and you have crepes.

title: Off the Menu
description: OPENING

title: Antiques, and Japanese Fare, to Savor
description: At first, the place appears to be a shop. Alongside a red-carpeted marble ramp leading to the dining room at Mihokos 21 Grams, a restaurant that will open on Tuesday in the Flatiron district, are shelves that display teapots, glasses and dishes  many rare, some more utilitarian, and all for sale ($20 to $1,000). Most were collected by Mihoko, a former ballerina who uses one name and is dipping her toe in New York with a French-Japanese restaurant; she has 10 restaurants in Japan and a degree in nutrition. Other pieces that she has collected, including etched mirrors from a Cartier house on the Upper East Side, decorate the space designed by Bruno Borrione, who has worked with Philippe Starck. The dining room seats 58 at well-spaced tables, some semi-enclosed by grisaille screens, left.

title: For Some Corporate Chiefs, Private Security Is a Tax Break
description: Most people would think that Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg of the Supreme Court would need more security than Alan R. Mulally, the chief executive of Ford Motor Company.

title: Carlyle Seeks Valuation of Up to $8 Billion in I.P.O.
description: The Carlyle Group plans to seek a valuation of up to $8 billion in its forthcoming initial public offering, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Tuesday, as the private equity firm marches toward a stock market listing.

title: Fox News Is Said to Have a Mole
description: Fox News apparently has a leak.

title: I.B.M. Aims to Sharply Simplify Corporate Data Center Technology
description: Corporate data centers are the slowpoke laggards of information technology. But major suppliers of hardware systems are working on new ways to speed things up.

title: New State Office to Review Questionable Convictions
description: Eric T. Schneiderman, the New York State attorney general, is creating a bureau to investigate criminal cases across the state in which convictions have been called into question.

title: No Second Chances in the N.H.L.s Second Season
description: The Stanley Cup playoffs are a second season, utterly new. Nothing that happened in the long regular season matters, and so great teams fall to poor teams, heroes stumble and the unsung become champions who lift the old silver chalice come June.

title: From Tiffanys to Tinsel Town
description: The clothes in The Hunger Games may have been a bummer to some fashion insiders, but one accessory in the film has gotten a warmer welcome among online shoppers. Copies of the mockingjay pin Katniss Everdeen (played by Jennifer Lawrence) wore in the film have become a hot item on eBay and Amazon.com. Dana Schneider, the jewelry designer who interpreted the pin (and its stunt double) from the book cover, has gotten requests to recreate the pin on Etsy, but she doesnt own the rights.

title: Sleep Is Vulnerability, for a Victim and a Thief
description: First the subway rider fell asleep, and a thief took his iPhone. Then the thief fell asleep, and soon he was under arrest, the police said.

title: Promising First Start for Pettitte
description: BALTIMORE  Yankees Manager Joe Girardi called Andy Pettitte late Monday night to see how the first minor league start of his comeback had gone, and Pettitte showed his age.

title: Court Flips Egypts Timetable: Election, Then Constitution
description: CAIRO  An administrative court on Tuesday suspended a committee appointed to draft a new constitution, all but guaranteeing that Egypt will elect a president before it ratifies a new charter, and raising the stakes in the race.

title: Yankees-Red Sox, on Ice
description: VOORHEES, N.J.  The current state of the rivalry between the Pittsburgh Penguins and the Philadelphia Flyers is exhibited by an oft-shown highlight. It is not of a goal or even a big hit, but an outraged coach.

title: Denmark Presses Bahrain to Release Activist Amid Doubts Over Formula One Race
description: Denmarks prime minister pressed Bahrain to release a jailed rights activist on Tuesday, 62 days into his hunger strike, as the kingdom continued to dismiss claims that its crackdown on dissent made it unfit to host an international motor race scheduled for next week.

title: For City Hall, 2 Standards on the Publics Right to Know
description: As a champion of open government, leader in reform through transparency and all-around tribune of the people, the administration of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has given full support to a campaign to make public the evaluations of about 18,000 teachers.

title: A Tax Code of Politics, Not Reason
description: The deadline for filing tax returns is almost upon us. If you are like me, you must be pondering how such a rich, high-technology democracy as the United States could endure what must be the most inefficient, mind-bogglingly complex tax system known to man.

title: Parcells Appears Out, and Vitt In Atop Saints
description: It seemed such an intriguing idea at the time: Bill Parcells, the coaching icon, taking over the New Orleans Saints while his protg, Sean Payton, served a full-season suspension for his role in the teams bounty system.

title: Owner Says the Nets and a New Arena Remain Hard-Hat Zones
description: Mikhail D. Prokhorov said he could not discuss contract talks with Deron Williams.

title: Basketball Tournament Chief Is Out
description: The N.C.A.A. announced Tuesday that one of its most important executives, Greg Shaheen, would not return as the executive vice president for championships and alliances.

title: Santorum Quits Race, Clearing a Path for Romney
description: GETTYSBURG, Pa.  Rick Santorum, with an abrupt decision to end his campaign Tuesday, cleared the way for Mitt Romney to claim the Republican nomination while dashing the hopes of social conservatives who had propelled Mr. Santorums surprisingly successful challenge to the Republican establishment.

title: Diving Back Into Risky Loans
description: Bank issuance of credit cards to subprime borrowers has grown in recent months.

title: Lenders Again Dealing Credit to Risky Clients
description: Annette Alejandro just emerged from bankruptcy and doesnt have a job, and her car was repossessed last year. Still, after spending her days job hunting, she returns to her apartment in Brooklyn where, in disbelief, she sorts through the piles of credit card and auto loan offers that have come in the mail.

title: Arkansas Fires Petrino, Citing Misleading and Manipulative Behavior
description: Once every generation or so, everything falls into place and allows a team outside one of college footballs traditional powers to compete for a national title. For the Arkansas Razorbacks, the 2012 football season appeared to be shaping up that way. Quarterback Tyler Wilson, a Heisman candidate, returns for his senior year, eight defensive starters are back and two Southeastern Conference West giants, Alabama and L.S.U., will each play in Fayetteville next season.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 10, 2012

title: Dennys Uses Web Series to Speak to Young Adults
description: THE commercials showing now for Dennys depict homey restaurants where waitresses call customers Hon and feature the slogan Americas Diner Is Always Open. The campaign, by Gotham, New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, is humorous but far from edgy, befitting a family restaurant.

title: A Russian City Always on the Watch Against Being Sucked Into the Earth
description: BEREZNIKI, Russia  Dmitry Rybolovlev, the Russian fertilizer tycoon who in February bought the most expensive apartment ever sold in New York City  the $88 million penthouse at 15 Central Park West  may have done a lot for real estate values there. But here in this old mining city in the Ural Mountains, where he made his fortune, not just property values, but properties too, have been plunging.

title: In Martin Case, Tough Choice Looms for Prosecutor
description: Announcing late Tuesday that she would release new information within 72 hours, Angela B. Corey, the Florida state attorney in the Trayvon Martin case, faces one of the toughest tests in the art of prosecution.

title: Wisconsin G.O.P. Sees Insurance in Placeholder Candidates
description: A year ago, when word emerged that Republicans in Wisconsin were encouraging less-than-genuine candidates to run in Democratic primary elections as a strategy, some Wisconsin residents voiced shock. This was not the way politics traditionally had been done around here, they said.

title: Moscow Protesters Try to Expand Movement
description: ASTRAKHAN, Russia  Prominent organizers of the big antigovernment protests in Moscow descended on this regional capital in southern Russia on Tuesday to take up the cause of an opposition mayoral candidate who is in the fourth week of a hunger strike to protest alleged ballot fraud.

title: A Billion-Dollar Turning Point for Mobile Apps
description: The path for Internet start-ups used to be quite clear: establish a presence on the Web first, then come up with a version of your service for mobile devices.

title: Saying Court Win Helps, Nail Salon Workers Rally
description: For legions of New Yorks glossiest women, for whom a trip to the nail salon is a weekly must, square shape or round? is often the most they will ever hear from their manicurist.

title: Judge Orders Reebok to Recall Tebow Jerseys
description: All those Jets Tim Tebow jerseys made by Reebok may now become collectors items. A federal judge ordered Reebok to buy back all the jerseys it made after Tebow was traded to the Jets from Denver last month.

title: Edward Harbert II, Who Led Times Productions, Dies at 88
description: Edward Harbert II, who in the 1980s led an early venture into television by The New York Times as executive producer of NYT Productions, died on Sunday at his home in Westwood, Calif. He was 88.

title: Selling Prostitution, and the Book and Film Rights, Too
description: Outside a Manhattan courthouse, a throng of women, presumably of a flattering appearance, crowd in tightly for the benefit of a video camera. They shake their fists and loudly chant the phrase on their T-shirts.

title: Rick Santorums Race
description: The trajectory of Mr. Santorums campaign, illustrated with charts of primaries and caucuses, delegates, polls and other recent Republican candidates.

title: Facebook Plays Offense and Defense in a Single Deal
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Is it crazy for Facebook, a start-up that has not yet even gone public, to be throwing $1 billion at Instagram, an even younger start-up?

title: Video That City Destroyed Is Cited in Inmates Lawsuit
description: When Kadeem John, an 18-year-old inmate at Rikers Island, was beaten severely by another prisoner in 2010, the attack was captured by a digital surveillance camera, correction officials have said.

title: Christie Stands by His Decision to Cancel Train Tunnel
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey defended on Tuesday his decision to cancel a train tunnel long planned to relieve increasing congestion across the Hudson River, saying it was a matter of principle.

title: Jack Tramiel, a Pioneer in Computers, Dies at 83
description: Jack Tramiel, a hard-charging, cigar-chomping tycoon whose inexpensive, immensely popular Commodore computers helped ignite the personal computer industry the way Henry Fords Model T kick-started the mass production of automobiles, died on Sunday in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 83.

title: Where Trip Began, Remembering Titanics Lost
description: LONDON  A hundred years to the minute after the Titanic slipped its moorings in Southampton, England, for its maiden voyage, a recording of the ships whistle broke a minutes silence at the dockside on Tuesday as the city remembered the liner and the 1,500 passengers and crew members who perished in her sinking off Newfoundland on April 15, 1912.

title: Swing Batter Batter Swing
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  The outlook wasnt brilliant for the Mudville Nine that day; The score stood four to two, with but one inning more to play,

title: Nerves Are Rattled After Bomb Threats at Pitt
description: Dozens of bomb threats at the University of Pittsburgh since mid-February have disrupted classes and dormitory life and prompted some students to find housing off campus just weeks before the semester ends.

title: Iranian President Says Oil Embargo Wont Hurt
description: Faced with diminished demand for Iranian oil because of economic sanctions, Irans president proclaimed defiantly on Tuesday that the country had such plentiful reserves of money that it could survive for years without exporting any oil.

title: Reed Whittemore, Former Poet Laureate, Dies at 92
description: Reed Whittemore, a former poet laureate of the United States whose works calm, unruffled surface belied deep subversion below, died on Friday in Kensington, Md. He was 92.

title: Afghan Force Will Be Cut After Taking Leading Role
description: WASHINGTON  Afghanistans defense minister said Tuesday that his government and the international coalition paying for the war effort had agreed in principle that Afghan security forces would undergo a significant reduction to about 230,000 personnel after the NATO mission ends in 2014.

title: Romney Turns Attention to Obama, Focusing on Womens Job Losses
description: WILMINGTON, Del.  On the day that Rick Santorum withdrew from the race, Mitt Romneys turn toward the general election addressed one of his biggest vulnerabilities according to polls: a gender gap that shows women currently prefer President Obama by large margins.

title: No Charges in Killing at Staten Island Engagement Party
description: A man accused of fatally stabbing a groom-to-be last month during his engagement party on Staten Island will not face charges.

title: Corrections: April 11
description: FRONT PAGE

title: To Stop the Killing, Deal With Assad
description: IN the wake of the recent Friends of Syria conference, the United States and Middle Eastern powers that include Turkey, Qatar and Saudi Arabia are stepping up aid to armed resistance groups in Syria. Under American leadership, the conference pledged $100 million to provide salary payments to rebel fighters.

title: The High Cost of Gambling on Oil
description: Boston

title: Knicks Rookie Hears Plenty of Praise, Little of His Name
description: CHICAGO  When he talks about Iman Shumpert, Coach Mike Woodson uses lots of adjectives, a few superlatives and a wide variety of monikers, none of which include the words Iman or Shumpert.

title: The Marlins Punish Political Speech
description: For the crime of expressing a strange support for an unpopular Communist dictator, Ozzie Guillen, the manager of the Miami Marlins, has been banished from the dugout for five games. It may be the first time that baseball has punished political speech, and it would be considered an over-the-top reaction anywhere but South Florida.

title: Double Dose of Harm
description: House Republicans combined two ill-conceived health care measures into a single bill and passed it on a largely party-line vote last month. One measure repealed an independent board that is one of the major cost-control measures in the health care reform law. The other imposed restrictions on medical malpractice awards that would limit the ability of patients who have been grievously harmed to receive fair compensation for their injuries.

title: An End to a Divisive Campaign
description: Rick Santorums exit from the Republican presidential race deprives it of its most divisive and most sincere candidate. Where Newt Gingrich has sought new and increasingly cynical ways to pander, and Mitt Romney has desperately tried to swim away from his centrist past, Mr. Santorum seemed to believe what he was saying.

title: State of Cool
description: WASHINGTON

title: Im Not Mitt Romney
description: Last week Politico reported that, ever since announcing his re-election bid, President Obamas campaign has been struggling to find a slogan to sum up his reason for running. Hes cycled through Winning the Future, We Cant Wait, An America Built to Last, A Fair Shot. Bruce Newman, Bill Clintons message adviser, was quoted as saying of Obama: Hes all over the place. So far, the most accurate slogan for Obamas campaign would have to be: Im not Mitt Romney. And when you consider that Romney  a former liberal Republican governor  has spent the whole campaign disavowing his past, for the first time in history both candidates could legitimately run on the same slogan: Im not Mitt Romney.

title: Mr. Obama and the Buffett Rule
description: President Obama accomplished two things when he made the case on Tuesday for the so-called Buffett Rule, which would require millionaires to pay at least 30 percent of their income in taxes. He persuasively argued that it would be a step toward fairness in a tax code tilted in favor of the wealthiest Americans. Not incidentally, it allowed him to take an implicit shot at his virtually certain opponent, Mitt Romney, both personally and politically.

title: Norway: Mass Killer Found to Be Sane
description: A new psychiatric evaluation of Anders Behring Breivik, who confessed to killing 77 people in Norway last year, concluded Tuesday that he was not psychotic when he carried out the attacks. The report, submitted to a district court in Oslo less than a week before Mr. Breiviks scheduled trial, contradicted an evaluation last year in which psychiatrists said he had paranoid schizophrenia and was psychotic when he detonated a bomb in central Oslo that killed eight people, then drove to the island of Utoya, where he shot and killed 69 people, mostly teenagers at a summer camp run by the governing Labor Partys youth organization. The new report could give judges grounds to sentence Mr. Breivik, 33, to prison instead of a psychiatric hospital. The court must determine whether Mr. Breivik, who has said he was punishing pro-immigration traitors, was sane or mentally ill at the time, based on the two reports.

title: The Liberalism of Fear
description: American liberalism has two faces. One is the face that Democratic politicians wear when theyre on a political upswing, laying out big plans and sketching grand ambitions, with the wind in their sails and the country behind them. Its an optimists face, a dreamers visage  think F.D.R. beaming with the cigarette holder between his teeth, Bobby Kennedy in shirtsleeves on the 68 campaign trail. Its a face thats in favor of a lot of thingsand against mighty few, as Lyndon Johnson put it while coasting to re-election in 1964. Its a face with nothing to fear but fear itself.

description: Having opened the year with four wins, the Mets were looking to match the best start to a season in the franchises 50-year history with a victory Tuesday night. Only in 1985 had the Mets compiled a flawless record through their first five games.

title: In Massachusetts Senate Race, Testing the Politics of Likability
description: BOSTON  Senator Scott P. Brown posed for pictures with President Obama two days in a row last week, smiling as Mr. Obama signed two bills that Mr. Brown co-sponsored. Never mind that he is a Republican seeking re-election in a season of strident partisanship. Mr. Brown is on a mission to persuade the voters of Massachusetts that he is as independent as politicians come.

title: TimesCast | Marlins' Manager Suspended
description: The Miami Marlins suspend manager Ozzie Guillen for five games over his comments in praise of Fidel Castro.

title: Collecting From Consumers
description: Some states advocate that a federal consumption tax could help balance the budget.

title: Reunited and It Feels So Good: Lollapalooza 2012 Lineup Unveiled
description: The 2012 Lollapalooza lineup is a veritable union of reunions, with a roster that includes reconstituted acts like the heavy-metal iron men of Black Sabbath, the alternative rockers Afghan Whigs and the rejuvenated post-hardcore band At the Drive-In, its organizers announced on Wednesday. This long-running summer music festival, founded by the Janes Addiction front man Perry Farrell, will be held Aug. 3-5 at Grant Park in Chicago, and will also feature headliners like Red Hot Chili Peppers, the Black Keys, the Shins, Florence + the Machine and Jack White, the recently solo White Stripes singer and guitarist, who isnt reuniting with anyone on this outing as far as we know. Other acts on the bill include the Swedish DJ Avicii, Passion Pit, Sigur Ros, The Weeknd, Franz Ferdinand, J. Cole, Frank Ocean, Metric, and tUnE-yArDs, along with no fewer than 100 additional acts. A complete lineup and ticket information can be found online at lollapalooza.com.

title: To Replace Bin Laden on Most Wanted List, a Teacher in a Pornography Case
description: WASHINGTON  Shortly after Osama bin Laden was killed last May, the Federal Bureau of Investigation sent out a request to field offices across the country: Nominate fugitives who could fill bin Ladens place on the bureaus 10 Most Wanted list.

title: A Macabre Tussle Over a Historic Slab
description: ROSCOE, Ill.  The original tombstone of Lee Harvey Oswald may not rest here in peace much longer.

title: How Exercise Can Prime the Brain for Addiction
description: Statistically, people who exercise are much less likely than inactive people to abuse drugs or alcohol. But can exercise help curb addictions? Some research shows that exercise may stimulate reward centers in the brain, helping to ease cravings for drugs or other substances. But according to an eye-opening new study of cocaine-addicted mice, dedicated exercise may in some cases make it even harder to break an addiction.

title: Long After Garcias Five Wild Pitches, the Yankees Pull Out a Victory
description: BALTIMORE  About two hours before Yankees pitcher Freddy Garcia took the mound against the Orioles at Camden Yards on Tuesday night, he sat at his locker and snapped a picture of the lineups with his smartphone.

title: Rock Guitarists Death Ruled a Suicide
description: When Ronnie Montrose, an influential rock guitarist of the 1970s, died last month at age 64, his agent said the cause was complications of prostate cancer.

title: Anthony Leads Knicks Attack, but This Time Its Not Enough
description: CHICAGO  The Knicks were in transition and in need, the floor was open and Carmelo Anthony had that feeling again late Tuesday evening. As if replaying his own highlight reel, he stopped, elevated and launched a 3-point shot that carried the Knicks hopes with it.

title: U.S. Visa Rules Deprive Stages of Performers
description: Everything seemed set for the American debut last month of Pitingo, the rising young flamenco singing star: the Grand Ballroom at Manhattan Center had been booked, tickets and program prepared, a publicity budget spent, nonrefundable airline tickets purchased. But when he went to the United States Embassy in Madrid to pick up his visa, he learned that his name was on the no fly list.

title: Leaked Outtake Video Offers Glimpse of Relaxed Romney
description: Mitt Romneys aides insist that their boss is a warm, self-deprecating guy when the cameras are off. On Tuesday, a leaked video of Mr. Romney bantering in what he thought was an off-camera moment offered a glimpse of his more relaxed self.

description: In the drive to double Americas exports, Washington has been focusing on manufacturers, Catherine Rampell writes in The New York Times. But that may be the wrong target.

description: NEWARK  As New Jersey prepares to lose its N.B.A. team, the Nets will try to play spoiler in the Atlantic Division.

description: HONG KONG  As North Korea enters what appears to be the final countdown to the ominous launch of a long-range missile, South Korea is debating Lady Gaga. Her fans  her little monsters, as she calls them  are not happy.

title: Kraftwerk Keeps Catching Up With Its Past
description: As manifestos go, The Robots  the first song Kraftwerk played on Tuesday to start its eight-night series of retrospective concerts at the Museum of Modern Art  is adroitly misleading. Were programmed to do/anything you want us to, Ralf Hutter sang.

title: All Eyes on Russia as Syria Cease-Fire Deadline Passes
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Many major players in the Syrian crisis consider the peace plan that reached its deadline Thursday as the final speed bump in figuring out how to get Russia to accept enough pressure on President Bashar al-Assad to stop the violence.

title: Indias Heavy Metal Scene: From Underground to Mainstream
description: I knew a lot of friends who were using brown sugar back then, Vehrnon Ibrahim recalls in a warm, Anglo-Indian accent, referring to uncut heroin. For the lead singer of Millennium and his band, metal meant touring tiny venues at regional engineering colleges in small towns in South India. It meant the students would pack the place, high on cocaine, heroin, marijuana  metal was an underground movement back then, he says.

title: Ornery in the Morning
description: When I told my wife I was interviewing you, she said, I like Mika because shes ornery, and all the other women on TV in the morning are so damn chipper.  I proudly own that. I spent 20 years trying to be perky like the beauty queens on TV, and none of it ever worked. It was bad television, because it wasnt real. So, yeah, Im kind of like the bitter housewife.

title: When Is a Flip Not a Flop?
description: At the end of January, New Yorks Conservative Party, the most influential of the minor parties that complicate the states politics, celebrated its 50th anniversary at a Holiday Inn near the Albany airport, a vast and dingy venue that reminded me of athlete housing left over from the 1980 Moscow Olympics. Politicians like former Gov. George Pataki, who owed his election to the Conservatives, came to pay homage to the party for its record of steering the states politics to the right.

title: A Mirror on Growing Up in America
description: Ilona Szwarc couldnt help but notice a curious trend while wandering Fifth Avenue with her camera. Everywhere she looked, little girls were clutching miniature, and often well-dressed, versions of themselves.

description: Constellation Energy keeps a list of buildings that would benefit from energy efficiency improvements, and it has identified an unusual candidate near the top: prisons.

title: With Help From Hertz, BYD E6 Makes Inroads in New York and Shenzhen
description: On the Hertz stand at the New York auto show, next to a Chevrolet Volt equipped for wireless charging, was a BYD E6 battery car from China. Two of the electric crossovers are on the road in a Hertz rental program in Shenzhen, China, and theyre also being readied for fleets in the United States, according to Jack Hidary, the global E.V. leader for Hertz.

title: The Early Word: Farewell
description: Todays Times

title: High-Design Fans Come Primed for a Retro Future
description: Sell-out rock shows usually mean a lot of shouting, some sweating, maybe a few drunken pass-outs. Kraftwerk inspired none of that on Tuesday night. The first of its eight consecutive sold-out performances at the Museum of Modern Art had reverence and stylistic weight; even for a New York museum crowd there was a lot of black. Artfully swept hair, uncomfortable-looking shoes, architectural glasses: check, check and check. The high-design audience was rewarded with an equally aesthetically tuned concert, with the band, a foursome in graphic black-and-white unitards, playing neon-lighted synths. Behind them a video screen offered a parade of simple 3-D images, like stick figure robots and spinning numbers, a retro future in an MS-DOS font.

title: A Start-Up Rethinks the Process of Getting a Trademark
description: Trademarkia is an online search engine that helps small-business owners sift through the more than six million names, slogans and logos that have been trademarked in America since 1870. The Web site, which went live in September 2009, grafts a user-friendly interface onto a colossal database, built with free information provided by the United States Patent and Trademark Office. It also serves as a lure, steering visitors who want to apply for their own trademarks to the law firm of Trademarkias co-founder, Raj Abhyanker, and offering other fee-based services such as domain registration, logo design and automated alerts that notify trademark holders when marks similar to their own are filed.

title: Hardaway and Rock in a Lil Penny Reunion
description: It is hard to explain to younger basketball fans, but from 1994 to 1998, Penny Hardaway was a star so famous and so talented that he was rivaling Michael Jordan in popularity. Even harder is explaining that Hardaways Nike ads featured a rude puppet alter ego voiced by Chris Rock, one of the biggest names in comedy.

title: Takeda of Japan Buys URL Pharma for $800 Million
description: The Takeda Pharmaceutical Company of Japan agreed on Wednesday to buy URL Pharma for $800 million, plus potential further payments based on the companys performance.

title: Governing Party Retains Edge in South Korean Vote
description: SEOUL, South Korea  President Lee Myung-baks governing party managed to keep its majority in Parliament after South Koreans voted Wednesday, a result that is likely to bolster the position of its expected presidential nominee.

description: In the competition between top Web-based e-mail providers, spam filtering has emerged as a crucial battlefield.

title: Putting the Gini Back in the Bottle

As part of class prep, Ive been looking at a story that has received very little discussion here, as far as I can tell, but is very interesting, to say the least: the remarkable decline in inequality that has taken place in Latin America.
