title: Study Finds Higher Charter School Spending on Administration
Last Nights Makeup
description: I have a confession to make. It isnt necessarily pretty, but it can be pretty sexy. I frequently sleep with an inappropriate partner  my makeup. Just like tously bedhead can increase a womans hot factor, so can last nights makeup. Not only because of the way it looks, but also for the narrative it implies. (Provided youre not too puffy from last nights martini, of course.) I love the way loose pigment from M.A.C. or Make Up For Ever melts into the creases of my lids and creeps down the corners of my eyes while I sleep, and how Lip Tar from Obsessive Compulsive Cosmetics leaves a telling stain on my lips. A slightly smudgy cat eye in the morning reminds me of the sex kitten I was the night before. Mascara should be a strictly cumulative affair, if you ask me; its so much better after two or three days worth of top coats.

title: Morning Buzz, April 11: Reviewing Stop-and-Frisk
description: Good morning. Its likely to rain this afternoon, with todays highs in the upper 50s.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Instagram and the Triumph of Mobile, and Kraftwerks Return
description: The Facebook-Instagram deal feels like a turning point in the tech world, Jenna Wortham writes, as even Web giants like Facebook recognize that they need to become mobile friendly, and quickly. For many people, the smartphone has become, for all practical purposes, the primary way to interact with friends and the Internet.

title: Tsunami Threat Ends for Indias Andaman Islands
description: The Indian Ocean-wide Tsunami Watch set in motion by a powerful earthquake off of Indonesia on Wednesday put the tiny Andaman and Nicobar Islands, as well as the eastern coast of India, on alert. While the earthquake itself had not triggered a tsunami by Wednesday afternoon, weather experts remain concerned because of a massive aftershock.

title: Treasure Hunters
description: ISTANBUL  Hajj: journey to the heart of Islam, the British Museums recreation of Islams holy pilgrimage, has attracted much praise and a dash of controversy, as Huma Yusuf recently wrote on Latitude. title: A Films Superheroes Include the Director
description: LOS ANGELES JOSS WHEDON does not consider himself an assertive person. Im not fierce, he said. Im grouchy as hell. But one subject that evokes the passion he has self-diagnosed as crabbiness is the decadent state of contemporary Hollywood entertainment.

title: Joss Whedon on Assembling The Avengers
description: As you may have gleaned from his fantasy TV shows like Buffy the Vampire Slayer and Angel, or his work on comic books like Astonishing X-Men, Buffy and Fray, the director and screenwriter Joss Whedon is a comic-book guy through and through. That might make him the ideal filmmaker for a project like The Avengers, the Marvel Studios movie (opening May 4) that brings together Iron Man (played by Robert Downey Jr.), Nick Fury (Samuel L. Jackson), Captain America (Chris Evans), Black Widow (Scarlett Johansson) and many others.

title: 5 Female Players I Want(ed) on My Team
description: A while ago, I made a mental list of players I would like to call teammates at some point in my career. You can watch a player play many times, you can play against that player, but there are things you cannot know or learn about them until you train and play with that player day in and day out. I want to know what makes all of the female soccer greats special. I want to know the nuances they have mastered, what their weaknesses are and what their mind-set is for training and games. Here is my Top 5 (in no particular order):

title: Santorum Out, Evangelicals Edge Closer to Romney, but Warily

Now, facing the abrupt end of Mr. Santorums presidential bid, some evangelical leaders have begun to rally behind Mr. Romney, saying their shared hostility toward President Obama will be a powerful force for uniting the party in November.

description: WHEN is the best time to book that flight? Its one of the most fraught decisions travelers face, as ticket prices often fluctuate right up to departure time.

title: High Off the Hog
description: The idea began in my kitchen when the cast of Shameless came over to watch our series premiere. Steve Howey, who plays Kevin, and Justin Chatwin, who confusingly plays a character named Steve, both ride motorcycles, and I suggested we take a road trip from Los Angeles to San Francisco. Justin pointed out that it was wintertime. I said, No, man, its California. Its perfect riding weather. We all agreed on a date and then Justin added, Not to put too fine a point on it, but San Francisco is northern California. Whatever.

title: The Season of the Unmanageable Coach
description: Although its only April, this may now officially be considered the Year of the Wayward Coach. Because even by the very low standards for decency set by the modern coaching profession, this one has been a doozy already. The Saints Mr. Bounty, Gregg Williams, and his enabler Sean Payton might have accomplished this all on their own, mind you, but they have Bobby Petrino, now Arkansass former football coach, and Marlins Manager Ozzie Guillen turning their trend into a full-fledged movement.

title: Sarkozy Praises Magic of the New Palais de Tokyo, Opening Thursday
description: PARIS  Oh, I am not an intellectual, I am someone concrete, Nicolas Sarkozy once told an interviewer, and when he ran for president in 2007, he sold competence and a belief in hard work over elegance and erudition. Running hard for re-election, he is presenting himself as the candidate of experience and eclectic tastes. On Wednesday, 11 days before the first round of the election, he spent an hour touring the newly renovated Palais de Tokyo, a museum here dedicated to contemporary and mostly French art.

title: Barney McKenna, Banjo Player in the Dubliners, Dies at 72
description: Barney McKenna, whose racing, raucous and often lyrically haunting banjo playing helped propel the Irish folk band the Dubliners to fame, died on Thursday at his home in Dublin. The last of the original members of the band, he was 72.

title: Faced With Endless Telematics Updates, Automakers Have Their Aha Moment
description: Though Web-connected infotainment systems have become important selling points for automakers, endlessly vetting and serving apps to those systems after making the sale may not be how companies want to use their resources. Outside firms have stepped into the void, acting as middlemen between content providers and a cars telematics system.

title: Nokia Lowers Its Estimate for Profit in First Quarter
description: Nokia lowered its first-quarter profit forecast on Wednesday as demand for its Symbian-based smartphones, which the company is phasing out, weakened sharply amid the transition to phones using Microsofts Windows Phone software.

title: Swiss Court Ruling Hampers a Tax Deal
description: In a setback for efforts to end a tax dispute between the United States and Switzerland, a Swiss court announced on Wednesday that Credit Suisse could not turn over account data of its American clients to the United States tax authorities because doing so would violate the terms of a 1996 tax treaty between the two countries.

title: The Lowdown | JD Samson
description: I remember well the moment I learned that the cute boy in the bow tie on the Le Tigre posters wasnt a boy at all. It was my first time being truly duped by a woman. Contrary to common wisdom, JD Samson is not in the process of becoming a man; rather she is a self-defined gender outlaw who is just really good at blurring the lines. In recent years Samson has revealed herself to be a powerful force at the intersection of lesbian, feminist culture and popular music. A staple presence both as a D.J., and as the lead singer of MEN, the band she has fronted since the dissolution of Le Tigre, Samson arguably keeps the term feminist electro-punk artist on the map. MEN, who are known for their playfully political dance music, appear in a new costume every show, handmade by Samson. Recently she put forth a brave first-person article on The Huffington Post that addresses the financial pitfalls of being a queer, semi-underground rock star with such head-on honesty that it provoked a 600-comment hailstorm of discussion.

title: Greek Crisis Leaves Cyprus Mired in Debt
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus  Michalis Sarris is not the only European banker working seven days a week, trying to scrape together enough capital to satisfy regulators and keep his institution afloat. But he may be the only one with the financial fate of his nation potentially hanging in the balance.

title: Throughout the City, Finding Traces of the Titanic
description: Yes, this was it, the park officer said when a man with a rather bulky camera asked if he had found the right place. Our famous pier, she said.

title: Times Readers Recommend Their Favorite Baseball Books
description: Times staffers recently shared some of their favorite books about baseball, and we put the call out on Twitter for readers to play along using the tag #baseballreads. Below is a selection from the many responses we received. Some books picked by those at The Times were heartily seconded, including Chad Harbachs The Art of Fielding, Jim Boutons Ball Four and David James Duncans The Brothers K. The replies below were chosen, in part, to expand the list and give us more to read than we could possibly squeeze into even the long, leisurely baseball season.

title: Muhammad Ali Meets His Wife
description: The photograph of Muhammad Ali with his future wife, Lonnie, which ran in Sundays magazine, has a fascinating back story. Although Steve Schapiro, the photographer, is the one who found Lonnie that day in 1963, she is the one who tracked him down almost 50 years later. Heres the e-mail that she sent to him:

title: Crane Operators and New York Spar Over Licensing Rules
description: As investigators seek the reason for a catastrophic crane accident on the West Side of Manhattan last week, a battle is raging over efforts to change the licensing of crane operators who labor high above the streets.

title: Lincolns Abolitionist Wedge
description: On April 10, 1862, Congress passed a potentially momentous piece of legislation, a joint resolution offering financial assistance to any slave state that would embark upon the course of phasing out slavery. Congress acted at the suggestion of President Abraham Lincoln, who had outlined the measure in a message he sent to Capitol Hill a month before.

title: Vital Signs by Phone, Then, With a Click, a Doctors Appointment
description: If ever an industry were ready for disruption, it is the American health care industry. Americans spend about $7,600 a year per person on health care, one in two adults lives with a chronic disease and the average wait time to see a doctor in a metropolitan area is 20 days. Entrepreneurs have responded by starting health care technology companies that are changing the way we interact with the entire system.

title: Etching Back to the Mainstream
description: Now that Rick Santorum has cleared Mitt Romneys calendar for the rest of the pre-convention season, the presumptive nominee and the Republican Party can straighten out their strategy for the general election.

title: Help Us Name the Baby Hawks
description: Updated, Tuesday, 2:02 p.m. | Thanks to everyone who suggested names for the baby hawks. Go here to cast a vote for your favorite among the top 10 most popular.

title: U.S. Tightens Rules on Antibiotics Use for Livestock
description: Farmers and ranchers will for the first time need a prescription from a veterinarian before using antibiotics in farm animals, in hopes that more judicious use of the drugs will reduce the tens of thousands of human deaths that result each year from the drugs overuse.

title: A Buffet of Magazines on a Tablet
description: Few words fire up the happiness transmitters in your brain more than free. But flat-fee unlimited comes close.

title: Do These Two Looks Mix Well?
description: TERRIFIC! Amazing! So exciting!!!

title: Santorums Dusted Indigo Period
description: Of all the amazing statements Rick Santorum made during this years presidential race, the one that astonished me the most was one that seemed innocuous.

title: TimesCast | April 11, 2012
description: Mitt Romney's pivot to the general election | A murder sends China's leadership into political turmoil | Kraftwerk plays at the MoMA.

title: How to Get AT&T to Unlock Your iPhone
description: AT&T has confirmed it will allow people to unlock their iPhones, which would mean that the phone could be used on other wireless networks. Most notably, it means you could have an iPhone on the T-Mobile network in the United States, as well as on other networks internationally.

title: Now Screening | A Portrait of Androgyne
description: Inspired by the writings of Claude Cahun, the photography duo ioulex teamed with the Belgian model Hannelore Knuts and the costume designer Christiane Hultquist (a k a Christian Joy) to bring Cahuns alter ego Androgyne to life in a fashion feature for the spring 2012 issue of Dossier. She was a rare woman among Surrealists and an early multimedia artist, says ioulexs Julia Koteliansky of Cahun. Her output included photographic self-portraits and collages combined with stage performances, writing, plays, essays and poetry. In the video from the shoot, which has its premiere exclusively here at T, Knuts recites pieces of Cahuns Heroines wearing looks that the stylist Polina Aronova pulled together by mixing Hultquists costumes with pieces from designers like Thom Browne, Proenza Schouler and Jil Sander. The first look incorporates Hultquists cagelike paper dress. A lot of paper clothing follows the same principles of origami, Hultquist says. I wanted to try something different, and based this on a fringe/bar-code print that Id designed. The dollar store across the street sells giant sheets of paper for 50 cents a piece. I cut out the entire costume by hand using an X-Acto knife.

title: Romney Camp Stumbles on Pay Equity Question
description: Mitt Romneys campaign scrambled Wednesday afternoon to clarify his support for the Lilly Ledbetter Fair Pay Act after top aides were caught flat-footed by the question.

title: One Direction Plus One Direction Equals One Lawsuit
description: The band may be called One Direction, but it turns out there are two claimants to that name. As a result, the British boy band whose debut CD, Up All Night, immediately went to the top of the Billboard pop chart when it was released last month is being sued by a pop-rock quartet from California that says it has been in business under that name since 2009.

title: For Union-Owned Bank, Lifeline Offers Chance for Growth
description: For Amalgamated Bank, having owners from both organized labor and the financial world is not just a marriage of convenience. The move will also help the bank take advantage of growth areas.

title: An Age-Appropriate Assist
description: John Antsy keeps a busy schedule. Tuesdays and Fridays, he heads over to see Don and Prudence Allender, who might need groceries or prescriptions picked up or a light bulb changed. Its a great boon, because neither of us is driving, Mrs. Allender said. Mr. Antsy, on the other hand, is still cruising around Waterloo, Iowa, in his 2000 Buick LeSabre.

title: CBS Green Marketing Program to Expand to Education and Healthy Diet
description: The CBS Corporation is expanding a marketing program that promotes environmental causes to include issues like healthier eating and education.

title: A New Perspective on Two Couturiers
description: 6:00 p.m. | Updated

title: Barclays Chiefs Pay Under Scrutiny
description: LONDON  Barclays is facing mounting criticism from investors.

title: Blackhawks Star Sidelined by Concussion Hopes to Return for Playoffs
description: CHICAGO  During a full-ice drill at the Chicago Blackhawks practice Tuesday morning, Patrick Kane skated across the blue line, dished the puck, got it right back and scored. The man in the middle of the give-and-go: Jonathan Toews.

title: Polk Study: Over Time, Allure of Hybrid Ownership Wanes
description: DETROIT  People who own a hybrid car are unlikely to get another one the next time they buy a new vehicle, according to a study released Monday by the consulting firm R.L. Polk.

title: Rough Trade to Open a Record Store in Brooklyn
description: One of the most famous independent record stores in the world is opening a branch in Brooklyn.

title: Google Plus Gets a Makeover
description: Google gave its flagship social network, Google Plus, a makeover Wednesday, unveiling a major redesign of the service.

title: Best Buy Inquiry Into Chiefs Behavior Will Continue
description: A day after Brian J. Dunn, the chief executive of Best Buy, abruptly resigned, the company said its investigation into his conduct was still active, though it still did not disclose details of what that conduct was.

title: Few U.S. Options as North Korea Readies Missile Launching
description: WASHINGTON  With North Korea poised to launch a long-range missile despite a widespread international protest, the Obama administration is trying to play down the propaganda value for North Koreas leaders and head off criticism of its abortive diplomatic opening to Pyongyang in late February.

title: A Portrait of Androgyne
description: The model Hannelore Knuts wears looks by Christian Joy for Dossier.

title: Obama Enlists Patriotic Millionaires
description: Wednesdays installment of President Obamas running campaign to raise the taxes of millionaires featured a group of wealthy people who agree with him, standing at his side as he professed that the idea is popular among the gilded elite from Warren Buffett on down.

title: At St. Jude, Firing Back at Critics
description: As St. Jude Medical defends itself against reports of deaths and injuries linked to problems with an implanted heart device, it finds itself in familiar territory. Since 2005, two competitors, Medtronic and Guidant, have faced similar scrutiny about critical flaws in their products.

title: Donna Murphy to Play the Witch in Into the Woods
description: Donna Murphy, a two-time Tony Award winner, will play the Witch in this summers Shakespeare in the Park production of the Stephen Sondheim-James Lapine musical Into the Woods, the shows producers at the Public Theater announced on Wednesday. Ms. Murphy joins several previously announced cast members, including Amy Adams as the Bakers Wife, Gideon Glick as Jack and Jessie Mueller as Cinderella. Still to be cast is the role of the Baker, played on Broadway by Chip Zien and then Stephen DeRosa.

title: A New Tool to Compare Financial Aid Offers
description: For students and parents whove spent the past few weeks crunching numbers from financial aid offers, a tool that the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau introduced on Wednesday may help make sense of it all.

title: Cond Nast Acquires Online Recipe Service
description: 7:33 p.m. | Updated

title: Cornering the Market on Super Bowl Rings
description: If you cannot get to London to see the crown jewels, their American cousins are on view in an N.F.L. Shop pop-up at West 42nd Street and Avenue of the Americas. That is where the 45 Super Bowl rings are being displayed through April 15, along with the original Vince Lombardi Trophy, a duplicate of which is awarded to each team upon winning the Super Bowl. The rings, as you would expect, are the sort of bling that can render nightclub doormen from New York to Las Vegas powerless. The one ring that is missing is the one that has yet to be presented to the Giants for winning Super Bowl XLVI (diamond mines worldwide are working extra shifts as you read this). The pop-up, called N.F.L. Shop at Draft, is in two parts (the other is on the next corner down, at West 41st Street and Avenue of the Americas). The shop is there to promote the N.F.L.s new partnership with Nike and New Era, and to sell merchandise to followers of the N.F.L. draft, which starts April 26 at Radio City. The stores are open 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. daily through April 30.

title: Rushdies Memoir Title Pays Tribute to a Pair of Fellow Authors
description: Salman Rushdies coming memoir about his years in hiding has a title, and it requires a little explanation.

title: Red Scare
description: Claiming that your opponent is a socialist just wont cut it anymore; like freedom and liberty the words been tossed around so much that no one knows what its supposed to mean, and it doesnt rile up the base the way it used to. That, at least, is the conclusion I drew from reading coverage of Rep. Allen Wests town hall event in Florida yesterday, where he said hes heard that up to 80 Democrats in the House are members of the Communist Party.

title: Protests and Clashes Are Seen in Chongqing
description: Thousands of Chinese protesters clashed with police and uniformed security forces wielding batons in an area of Chongqing on Wednesday, according to news reports and images posted by activists.

title: Shopping Snapshots: April 4
description: Cool girls have always borrowed from the boys. This spring, designers are making versatile shirt dresses, suspenders, oxfords and lace bow ties for women.

title: Teenage Birthrates Drop to Record Low
description: In February, the Guttmacher Institute reported that in 2008, the pregnancy rate among teenagers dropped to its lowest point in more than 30 years: only 67.8 pregnancies per 1,000 girls 15 to 19 years old, and even fewer pregnancies for younger girls. Now, the Economix blog reports that new numbers from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention show that births to teenage mothers are also at a record low: 34.3 births per 1,000 girls 15 to 19 years old in 2010, the lowest rate since the government began keeping track in 1940.

title: Announcing Fech 1.0
description: Fech now retrieves a whole lot more campaign finance data.

title: Job Growth Isnt Just a Womens Issue
description: Mitt Romney has been saying all along that he wants smaller government. On Tuesday, he added that he was angry that so many women have lost jobs in the last three years.

title: 141 Worth Street, 10:52 A.M.
Weighing the Evidence on Fish Oils for Heart Health
description: People who put their faith in fish oil supplements may want to reconsider. A new analysis of the evidence casts doubt on the widely touted notion that the pills can prevent heart attacks in people at risk for cardiovascular disease.

title: Minaj Dislodges Madonna From Top of Charts
description: This week on the music charts, Nicki Minaj opens at No. 1 and Madonna earns a dubious distinction with the biggest second-week sales drop for a No. 1 album in at least 21 years.

title: New Regulatory Filings Offer Limited Glimpse Into Paulsons Funds
description: New rules passed under the Dodd Frank Act are giving outsiders a peek into the murky world of hedge funds. Investors can now see information like ownerships stakes, investor composition and assets under management by fund, a veritable windfall for the curious.

title: Florida Prosecutor to Release New Information About Trayvon Martin Shooting
description: Updated | 3:07 p.m. Angela B. Corey, the Florida state attorney in the Trayvon Martin case, has scheduled a news conference for 6 p.m. on Wednesday, her office said in a statement. According to NBC News, the statement from the prosecutor said that she would release new information on the shooting at that time.

title: Marketing Plan: Solve a Problem, Then Spread the Word
description: Its no secret that how a product is marketed can make all the difference between success and failure. As I wrote, though, in my article  part of the special energy section in The Times on Wednesday  environmentally conscious marketers have only recently started hitting the sweet spot in positioning efficient televisions, appliances and other products for the home.

title: Prosecutor Files Charge of 2nd-Degree Murder in Shooting of Martin
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  More than six weeks after he shot and killed Trayvon Martin, an unarmed 17-year-old with no criminal record, George Zimmerman, the neighborhood watch coordinator at a small gated community in Sanford, Fla., was charged by a special prosecutor on Wednesday evening with second-degree murder and taken into custody.

title: Romneys Empathy Gap
description: Mitt Romney has an empathy problem. A new Washington Post/ABC News poll finds that 49 percent of respondents think that President Obama better understands the economic problems people in this country are having. Only 37 percent believe that Mr. Romney does. This echoes a finding from my own research: in a January YouGov poll, 51 percent said they believed that the phrase cares about people like me describes President Obama well, while 41 percent said that about Mr. Romney. And in a later poll, the empathy gap widened, with only 33 percent saying they believed that Mr. Romney cared about people like them. Perceptions of empathy are also correlated with whether people currently favor Mr. Romney or Mr. Obama.

title: The Course to the Stage Never Did Run Smooth
description: TO hear Christina Ricci tell it, she spent all of 2010 half-paralyzed with stage fright. A professional film actor since she was 9, Ms. Ricci waited two decades to attempt her first stage role, replacing Alicia Silverstone in Donald Marguliess Time Stands Still on Broadway.

title: Giants Working to Acquire Rivers to Bolster Linebackers
description: Two weeks before the N.F.L. draft, the Giants were on the verge of a move Wednesday to strengthen their group of linebackers, the position that was perhaps the most inconsistent for them during their Super Bowl season.

title: Glee Returns With an Off-Note Showing
description: The spring return of Foxs Glee on Tuesday did little to support the notion that it will return to its former ratings glory anytime soon. According to Nielsen, the dramedy dropped to a series low in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic and attracted just 6.7 million viewers, a level not seen since its pre-phenom first season. Its presence did seem to help New Girl and Raising Hope, however. Both programs were up in the 18-to-49 category when compared to last week. Fox announced on Monday that all three shows have been renewed for next season.

title: Have You Seen This Animal?
description: Ken Angielczyk, an assistant curator at the Field Museum of Natural History, is searching for fossils of ancient mammal relatives in northeastern Brazil.

title: Downtown Stage Stars (a Few With TV Credits) Will Populate Uncle Vanya
description: The cast for Annie Bakers new Off Broadway adaptation of Uncle Vanya includes a country estates worth of fan-favorite actors, including Michael Shannon (Boardwalk Empire) and Merritt Wever (Nurse Jackie), as well as stage regulars Reed Birney (A Small Fire), Maria Dizzia (a Tony nominee for In the Next Room, or the vibrator play), and Peter Friedman (After the Revolution). The ensemble was announced on Wednesday by the theater company Soho Rep, which is mounting this version of the Chekhov classic June 7-July 15.

title: How About the Bush Recession?
description: Poor George W. Bush. Presidents are supposed to have things named after them (although generally they have to die for the big-ticket items, like airports), or at least have big ideas associated with them (like FDRs New Deal, or LBJs Great Society). Ronald Reagan had a whole era named for him, not to mention Reaganomics.

title: In 89, Idea of Bounties Seemed Funny to Many
description: The N.F.L.s last bounty scandal of note did not provoke outrage or condemnation. It did not result in fines or suspensions. The accused perpetrators showed no remorse. The only person to receive any penalty was the victim.

title: Tip of the Week: Speed Dial for the Web
description: Visual bookmarks of your regularly visited sites can save time by letting you click a page thumbnail to start making your rounds on the Web. While Speed Dial has been a feature of the Opera browser for some time, the concept has also turned up in Microsofts Internet Explorer 9 browser  just click the button for a new tab to bring up a page of thumbnails for the 10 sites you visit the most.

title: Madonnas Sprint to No. 1 Has Made the Fall Even Harder
description: Last week, Madonna was on top of the world. Her latest album, MDNA (Interscope), opened at No. 1 on the Billboard charts, becoming her eighth release to reach the summit  among female performers, she is second only to Barbra Streisand, who has nine No. 1s.

title: An Online Art Collection Grows Out of Infancy
description: I dont know how many wonders of the world there are by now, but it is possible that the Google Art Project will someday join the list.

title: TimesCast | The General Election Begins
description: April 11, 2012  In speeches, conference calls, and TV appearances, the general election began in earnest Wednesday as Rick Santorum announced he was suspending his campaign.

title: At Streetcar Performance, the Howls Werent Just Stella!
description: Casting Hollywood stars may improve ticket sales to Broadway plays, but it can also bring out the unwelcome fan within some audience members.Consider Tuesday nights performance of the new revival of A Streetcar Named Desire.

title: TimesCast | Political Turmoil in China
description: April 11, 2012  In China, new revelations in the death of a British businessman last year have thrown the countrys political elite into turmoil.

title: Fallout at Arkansas, Post-Petrino
description: It was a dramatic enough moment when Arkansas Athletic Director Jeff Long fired football coach Bobby Petrino on Tuesday, but the hardest part of this mess may be what comes next. The fallout from Petrinos falling out is going to last some time.

title: Regulator Seeks Feedback on JOBS Act
description: The JOBS Act, the contentious new law that rolls back various securities rules, elicited strong opposition from regulators in recent months.

title: Excerpt: 'Magic/Bird'
description: A scene from Eric Simonsons new Broadway play starring Kevin Daniels as Earvin Magic Johnson, Tug Coker as Larry Bird and Deirdre OConnell as Georgia Bird.

title: Ruling Averts Testimony by a Detainee, for Now
description: FORT MEADE, Md.  A military judge on Wednesday averted a showdown over the First Amendment and the Obama administrations military commission trials at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, issuing a ruling that avoids for now testimony by a Saudi man about the Central Intelligence Agency and torture.

title: The Teacher Bias Against Girls and Math
description: Another discouraging research headline: Teachers Think White Females Lag Behind in Math.

title: In Mexico, a Double Dose of Derby
description: Last weekend, two derby games in Mexico provided a glimpse of where the currents may be taking the countrys soccer future. Now the teams involved must absorb the results and carry on in domestic and international competitions.

title: On the Titanic, Defined by What They Wore
description: A surprising amount of ephemera defied logic to survive the sinking of the unsinkable ocean liner that went to the bottom 100 years ago on April 15.

title: A New Way to Compare College Costs Online
description: Want to get a quick sense of how costs vary at the colleges youre considering, and how much debt youre likely to have upon graduation? The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau on Wednesday introduced an online financial aid comparison shopper tool that may help.

title: Pictures of the Day: Indonesia and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Indonesia, India, Turkey and Afghanistan.

title: Four Artists and a Funeral
description: The Life and Death of Marina Abramovic is a quasi opera directed by Robert Wilson, based on the performance artists life and imagined grand finale. Aside from Abramovic, it stars Willem Dafoe and Antony Hegarty (from Antony and the Johnsons), who is also the shows musical director.

title: Snap Elections for Greek Parliament Are Set for Early May
description: ATHENS  Greeces interim prime minister, Lucas Papademos, called for snap elections on Wednesday, opening the way for a contest that promises to be the most fiercely fought in decades but which might not yield a definitive result, potentially putting the debt-racked countrys international bailout plan in jeopardy.

title: On the Titanic, Defined by What They Wore
description: TATTERS and scraps, they emerged from the deep coated with mire and miraculously although tenuously intact. Treated with the reverence due relics of perhaps the greatest maritime tragedy and with all the care modern conservation science could summon, they were restored, put on display and then offered this week in an exceptional single-lot auction of the more than 5,000 objects (with a current estimated worth of $190 million) that salvagers of the Titanic found scattered across the North Atlantic seabed.

title: The Casual Horrors of Life in a North Korean Hell
description: When Blaine Harden wrote his shocking 2008 profile of Shin Dong-hyuk for The Washington Post, Mr. Shin was living in Seoul, South Korea, and already a published author. He had written Escape to the Outside World, a 2007 Korean-language account of his horrific upbringing.

title: App Smart Extra: Across the Universe
description: Mobile apps like Google Sky Map (free on Android), Star Walk ($3 on iOS) and SkyView ($2 on iOS, with a free version also available) have done a beautiful job of introducing the masses to backyard astronomy.

title: Perry Ellis Still Has Something to Say
description: FOR men of a certain generation, the Perry Ellis look of the early 80s was a classic: impeccably constructed khaki pants and a crisp white or blue cotton shirt, perhaps paired with a buttery soft trench coat, all of it conveying a kind of effortless elegance.

title: Kraftwerk at MoMA
description: The influential German electronic group is performing eight consecutive albums on eight nights at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Rose Should Be in Hall of Fame, Leader of Union Says
description: WASHINGTON  Attention Pete Rose: Michael Weiner has your back. The executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association said Wednesday that Rose should be in the Hall of Fame even though he gambled on baseball games. Players who took steroids should have a shot at the Hall of Fame as well, Weiner said.

title: The Imbalances in Chinas Economy
description: Nicholas R. Lardy, a senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics in Washington, is an authority on China and its economy. In his latest book, Sustaining Chinas Economic Growth After the Global Financial Crisis, he warns about dangerous imbalances in Chinas economy, starting with its emphasis on exports rather than household consumption.

title: Now Starring at Power Forward: Carmelo Anthony
description: Despite another efficiently high-scoring effort from Carmelo Anthony (29 points on 11 of 19 shooting), Tuesday nights loss to the Bulls dropped the Knicks back to a mere one-game lead over the Bucks for the conferences eighth and final playoff slot.

title: Jets Name Team President
description: Neil Glat, who assisted in N.F.L. expansion and stadium development during his 15 years working for the league, has joined the Jets as team president.

title: Electronic Musics Own Archaeologist
description: VERONICA VASICKA, the founder of the indie Brooklyn music label Minimal Wave, has been called a vinyl archaeologist for her obsession with excavating old records.

title: Chelsea vs. M.L.S. Stars: A Smart Match?
description: The Brits are back, and Major League Soccer could not be happier  or at least the Anglophiles at the leagues HQ in Midtown Manhattan could not be happier.

title: The Buzz
description: A PREVIEW of the must-attend parties, talked-about openings and fashionable nightspots for the week ahead.

title: Footing the Bill for MF Globals Lawyers
description: When four top MF Global executives testified before a Congressional subcommittee on March 28 about how $1.6 billion in customer money went missing during the firms final days, they were accompanied by teams of lawyers. Care to guess who is paying for all that legal firepower?

title: Shopping for Fair Isle Patterns
description: Shayna Kulik, the founder of Pattern Pulp, a design forum online, went shopping for home dcor wearing the once-preppy pattern.

title: Does Romney Still Need to Court Conservatives?
Market Ready
description: Q. My front hall has no closet. Whats the best way to create space for coats and shoes, so that its not seen as a problem by potential buyers?

title: A World War II Destroyers Demise in Mexico
description: A 69-year-old retired American warship from World War II has met its end in a Mexican port where it had languished for nearly a decade amid international legal wrangling and mounting bills.

title: A Party Girl Puts on a Good Face, but the Strain Is Heartbreaking
description: Last season the Metropolitan Opera had an enormous success with Willy Deckers grippingly spare, almost surreal new production of Verdis Traviata. It has come back this season as a vehicle for the soprano Natalie Dessay. Ms. Dessay missed the first performance on Friday night due to illness, so the veteran soprano Hei-Kyung Hong, an admirable artist, took over.

title: Help for Users Who Push Their Data Plans to the Limit
description: Users of the new iPad rave about how quickly it streams movies over cellular networks. But talk about a siren song: a couple of hours of that, and you can easily blow through a months data allotment.

title: The Checklist | Busy Bodies
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Storage That Stitches Together the Home Basics
description: The new multifunctional storage unit from Think Fabricate, a design studio in Brooklyn, is known as the Brooklyn TV Quilt, which might strike some as odd. But the name refers to one of its basic functions (holding a TV) and to the subtle patchwork effect created by the wood grain in the doors.

title: A Light Bulb Pulls a Disappearing Act
description: When the Swedish design studio Form Us With Love moved into a new space in Stockholm in 2010, the partners needed a metal mesh for a barrier around the spaces mezzanine level.

title: Camilla Huey Trades on Her Work, Not Her Name
description: THESE days, red-carpet cynosures name-check designers like theyre reading a Sears catalog. But one person remains uncited: Camilla Huey.

title: Domestic Warfare, Seen in Slow Motion
description: The lights rise on a spare Victorian drawing room. The place looks dead. Not only is the furniture draped in dust covers, but the floor is also a rumpled sea of cloth. The six people onstage are still. When they start moving, they move very, very slowly.

title: Mets Mark 50th Anniversary With an Effort Right Out of 1962
description: The Mets on Wednesday marked the 50th anniversary of their first game, a loss that inaugurated a season of remarkable ineptitude.

title: Business Day Live | Focusing on Mobile
description: April 11, 2012 - The billion-dollar turning point for mobile apps.

title: Intense Swings of Whimsy and Romance
description: The excitement of Las Vegas and the sophistication of Manhattan merged on Tuesday evening at Caf Carlyle, where Clint Holmess stirring new show, This Thing Called Love, saluted the songs of Cole Porter and Paul Simon. What do these composers have in common? Not much when you think about it. Mr. Simons knotty reflections with their undertone of whimsy and Porters besotted romanticism are poles apart.

title: Homes for $800,000
description: Properties in Providence, San Diego and Nashville.

title: What You Get for ... $800,000
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.

title: A Young Pianist Uncovers an Addition to the Repertory
description: Michael Brown, a pianist and composer fresh out of the Juilliard School, has made a strong impression in recent seasons in chamber music and as a concerto soloist. This month he collects a couple of prizes that each include a recital.

title: Oaktree Prices I.P.O. at $43, at Bottom of Range
description: The Oaktree Capital Group priced its initial public offering at $43 a share, at the bottom of the expected range for the investment giant, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Wednesday.

title: Wade, Allen Want to Be Paid to Play in Olympics
description: Several N.B.A. players have wandered into territory that wont go over well with a patriotic public: Ray Allen of the Celtics and Dwyane Wade of the Heat have decided to promote the cause that N.B.A. players should be paid to play in the Olympics and Allens teammate Rajon Rondo wants nothing to do with the Games, period.

title: Video: The Turning Point for Mobile Apps
description: Jenna Wortham and Louise Story discuss the way many start-ups are forgoing the Web and creating services designed specifically for mobile devices.

title: Latest Updates on the Trayvon Martin Case
description: The Lede followed developments in the Trayvon Martin case on Wednesday in Florida, where Angela B. Corey, a special prosecutor, announced that George Zimmerman, who shot the unarmed teen in February, has been charged with second-degree murder and taken into custody.

title: J.&J. Fined $1.2 Billion in Drug Case
description: A judge in Arkansas ordered Johnson & Johnson and a subsidiary to pay more than $1.2 billion in fines on Wednesday, a day after a jury found that the companies had minimized or concealed the dangers associated with an antipsychotic drug.

title: In Quebec, a Riverfront Home With a Military Pedigree
description: This five-bedroom house in Chambly, Quebec, built in 1812, was once an army barracks. It is listed for $1.787 million.

title: House Hunting in ... Canada
description: HISTORIC RIVERFRONT HOME NEAR MONTREAL

title: Recipe: Pisco Ginger (a k a Chilcano)
description: Adapted from The Pisco Book, by Gregory Dicum

title: An Imaginary Fly Listens In
description: EAVESDROPPING on an imaginary chat between Elsa Schiaparelli and Miuccia Prada: a few snippets from the dialogue assembled by the curators of the Met exhibition. Parts of the dialogue will be included in the catalog and video installations throughout the show.

title: Jake Dyson, Lamp Designer, on Form Versus Function
description: Growing up in England, the product designer Jake Dyson didnt have to look far for inspiration. His father, James Dyson, was well on his way to becoming one of the worlds most high-profile inventors. Seemingly bitten by the same bug, Jake, 39, established his own design studio in London in 2004. But rather than making vacuum cleaners and fans like his dad, hes been busy reinventing light fixtures.

title: Capturing the Gardens of America
description: From the late 1800s to 1935, Frances Benjamin Johnston was crisscrossing the country, photographing the gardens of wealthy Americans and writing about them in magazines, first for Country Life in America and later for House & Garden, The House Beautiful and others. She also captured the great gardens of Europe  Villa dEste in Italy, Cliveden in England, Vaux-le-Vicomte in France  to inspire American gardeners.

title: James Fairchild Opens in the Hamptons
description: The name Fairchild may be synonymous with publishing in New York, but James Fairchild, 55, chose fashion over the family business. Mr. Fairchild (the son of John Fairchild, of Fairchild Publications) spent two decades as a vice president for design at Ralph Lauren before moving to the Hamptons several years ago. And earlier this year, he opened a store there, in what used to be an ice cream shop.

title: IMG Artists Names New President
description: IMG Artists, a major representative of classical musicians, on Wednesday named a hotel and resort company executive, Jerry Inzerillo, as its new president and chief executive. Mr. Inzerillo comes to IMG from the Kerzner International Group, where he is president of the Kerzner Entertainment Group and responsible for building brand awareness among celebrities, VIPs and the entertainment world and organizing opening extravaganzas, according to the Kerzner Web site. He has also been president of the company that became Ian Schrager Hotels.

title: The Edge Goes to the Women
description: ACCORDING to Hamish Bowles, the international editor-at-large of Vogue and a collector of couture, Madeleine Vionnet was especially fond of her South American clients. The genius behind the bias-cut dress liked this stylish group because, as she put it, leurs fesses ondoyantes comme des carnivores. She thought her dresses looked marvelous spilling over strong, undulating buttocks.

title: Stone Links
description: A gathering of recent philosophy-related links.

title: Iran Says It Will Offer Unspecified Proposals at Coming Nuclear Negotiations
description: Irans top nuclear negotiator said Wednesday that he would offer new initiatives at the coming talks with world powers on its disputed nuclear energy program, apparently trying to strike a posture of conciliation without specifying which ideas he intended to propose.

title: Any Trial in Soldiers Death Would Be at Fort Bragg
description: Trials of the service members implicated in the death of Pvt. Danny Chen, the soldier from Manhattan who apparently killed himself last fall in Afghanistan, will be held at Fort Bragg, in North Carolina, if senior military officials decide courts-martial are warranted, the American military said Wednesday.

title: Memorable Play by the Champion Lea du Pont
description: One of the warmest, most pleasant bridge players, Lea du Pont of Rockland, Del., died last Friday of emphysema. She was 72.

title: Roche: Illumina Is No Apple
description: If honey doesnt work, try a well-timed sting.

title: His and Hers Cottages
description: In Lake Worth, Fla., a pair of 1920s bungalows  one pink, one blue  are home to a couple who bought them out of foreclosure.

title: With This Cottage
description: LAKE WORTH, Fla.

title: A Collector of 50s Dcor Finds an Apartment to Match
description: Cullen Meyers apartment is filled with his collections of Majestic lamps, Carlo of Hollywood paintings and pinup-girl calendars and figurines, along with bigger pieces like a wet bar.

title: Dcor That Says I Like Ike
description: CULLEN MEYER began collecting 1950s dcor at 12, starting with a lamp adorned with the face of a Nubian princess (he goes in for kitsch), and by the time he turned 25, two years ago, he harbored the great dream of any collector: finding a place to display his stuff.

title: E-Book Borrowing, Preceded by E-Book Waiting
description: As a technical matter, its remarkably easy to borrow an e-book from your local library. But not if you want to take out the best-selling biography of Steven P. Jobs, the hero of the Internet age who helped lure tens of millions of people to personal computers, tablets and other digital devices.

title: Electing to Sleep Elsewhere
description: ON many nights, as the sun sets over Denver, Reeves Brown finds himself alone amid the empty grandeur of the Boettcher Mansion, otherwise known as the official state residence of the governor of Colorado. Mr. Brown, who is in charge of local affairs for the state government, microwaves some soup for dinner, surrounded by a small museums worth of tapestries and antique Italian furniture. Then he makes his way up to a modest third-floor bedroom, where he tries to fall asleep.

title: Sales at the MoMA Design Store and Others
description: To celebrate the 20th anniversary of the Sky umbrella, designed by Tibor Kalman and Emanuela Frattini Magnusson, the MoMA Design Store is discounting all versions of it by 20 percent, through Tuesday (the collapsible Sky, regularly $38, is about $30); (800) 447-6662 or momastore.org.

title: Pieces With Fair Isle Patterns
description: FOR most people, name Fair Isle evokes memories of an era long gone  and the preppy sweaters that went with it.

title: Shaking Up Pisco, Perus Native Spirit
description: PISCO, the national spirit of Peru, is a trickster: it appears so clear and pure  yet before long, you are under the table. Peruvians like to say that good pisco will never give you a hangover, although after a recent night in Lima, I beg to differ. Pisco is made from a single distillation of young wine that holds the varietal qualities of one of eight different grapes from which it can be made. And like Champagne or tequila, Peruvian pisco is an official appellation; to be bona fide, it must adhere to strict, traditional production methods. Nothing  not even water  can be added.

title: Plans to Close 26 Schools Will Proceed Regardless of Financing, City Says
The Next Phase of the G.O.P. Campaign
description: To the Editor:

title: The Tallest One in the Hemisphere
description: As 1 World Trade Center grows closer to topping off  even with high winds playing havoc with the delivery of steel to the uppermost floors  it grows harder and harder to miss around the city. So the first thing you might wonder is: Why does the tallest structure in the Western Hemisphere need a logo? Isnt it logo enough by itself?

title: Spurned Executive Mansions
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg, who does not live in Gracie Mansion, isnt the only elected official who has rejected the house that comes with the job.

title: Meant to Last: Architecture Isnt Fashion
description: To the Editor:

title: RIM Warns Lucrative Fees May Decline
description: OTTAWA  Unlike other smartphones, BlackBerrys have always been the gift that keeps on giving, at least for Research in Motion, the company that makes them.

title: U.S.-Israeli Political Ties
description: To the Editor:

title: The Right to Protest
description: To the Editor:

title: Pastimes on the Titanic
description: To the Editor:

title: The Gains of College
description: To the Editor:

title: Posada to Be Honored at Home Opener
description: BALTIMORE  It has been six months since an emotional Jorge Posada walked out of Yankee Stadium, unable to express himself publicly except through his tears. Posada knew that night, after the Yankees season-ending loss to the Detroit Tigers, that he had played his final game as a Yankee.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Female Founders and Internet Freedom
description: Here are some of the most interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Wednesday. There are more here.

title: General Hospital Blessed With a 50th Season by ABC
description: Maybe it was Farah Fath, a former soap opera star, who said it best on Wednesday when ABC confirmed that it had renewed General Hospital for a landmark 50th season.

title: Stage Scenes: Christian Borle
description: A look at some of the actors past stage roles.

title: Ruling Favors Conservative Egyptian Candidate
description: CAIRO  An Egyptian court on Wednesday unexpectedly declined to disqualify for the moment an ultraconservative Islamist from running for president because of his mothers status as an American citizen.

title: Fed May Extend Support Past 2014, Official Says
description: WASHINGTON  Janet L. Yellen, the vice chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, said Wednesday that the lackluster trajectory of the economic recovery might require the Fed to continue its efforts to bolster growth even beyond the end of 2014.

title: Scouting Report
description: OPENINGS

title: Covering N.H.L. Playoffs Will Be a Team Effort
description: The N.H.L. playoffs began Wednesday night with three games, and viewers were going to see changes in the television coverage in the United States: four networks combining to carry all the postseason games nationally.

title: Beware of Faulty Intelligence
description: Tel Aviv

title: Georgia: 2 Plead Guilty in Bomb Plot
description: Two men have pleaded guilty to conspiring to buy weapons illegally for what federal agents describe as a terrorist plot by a fringe militia group. The F.B.I. recorded conversations in which the men, Frederick Thomas, 73, and Dan Roberts, 67, discussed plans to detonate explosives and shoot government workers in Atlanta and other cities, the federal authorities say. The men entered their pleas on Tuesday in United States District Court in Gainesville, Ga.; they face up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine.

title: California: Manson Is Denied Parole
description: Charles Manson, convicted of being the mastermind behind the 1969 murders of the actress Sharon Tate and six other people, was denied parole on Wednesday for the 12th time. Mr. Mason, 77, will not get another parole hearing for 15 years.

title: Rhode Island: Casino Referendums Set
description: Rhode Island could get its first full casinos through two referendums that will appear on the November ballot. Gov. Lincoln D. Chafee, an independent, signed a bill on Wednesday to let voters decide whether the Newport Grand slot parlor, in Newport, should become a full casino with table games. A similar referendum on the Twin River slot parlor, in Lincoln, has also been scheduled.

title: Trayvon Martin's Parents React
description: Sybrina Fulton and Tracy Martin offer their thoughts on the charges brought against George Zimmerman in the death of their son, Trayvon Martin.

title: Axl Rose Publicly Declines Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Induction
description: The biggest question hanging over the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame induction ceremony this weekend has been answered: Axl Rose has said he would not attend the event, and therefore there would be no reunion of the classic lineup of Guns N Roses.

title: A Claim About Jobs Doesnt Tell Full Story
description: At campaign events on Tuesday and Wednesday, Mitt Romney made the claim that 92.3 percent of the net total of jobs lost since President Obama took office belonged to women.

title: Rangers Look to a Veteran to Show the Way
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Brad Richards has occasionally found himself walking the streets of Lower Manhattan, wondering how it would feel to be part of a Stanley Cup parade in the Canyon of Heroes.

title: Dr.  Chu on Profits, Horse Manure and Other Forces of Technological Change
description: Steven Chu, the secretary of energy, is optimistic about the future of renewable energy.

title: Who Gets to Be French?
description: THE French language is justly renowned for its clarity and precision. Yet on a seemingly simple matter its speakers stumble into a fog  who or what can be defined as French? The question arose afresh in the wake of the Toulouse killings. No one doubted that the perpetrator was 23-year-old Mohammed Merah, a native son of Algerian descent. But was Mr. Merah French?

title: Why Trees Matter
description: Helena, Mont.

title: Campus Task Force Criticizes Pepper Spraying of Protesters
description: LOS ANGELES  Police officers at the University of California, Davis, should not have used pepper spray on protesters who had set up camp in the middle of campus as part of the Occupy movement last November, according to an investigation of the episode by a campus task force.

title: Strasburgs Comeback Is Gaining Strength
description: Stephen Strasburg became an overnight phenomenon during his rookie season with the Washington Nationals in 2010, but after spending almost all of last season recuperating from surgery he is effectively reintroducing himself in 2012.

title: Reviving Two Characters by Tearing Them Apart
description: WHEN beloved pairings split, fans may grow distraught, at the prospect of Simon without Garfunkel, Lennon without McCartney, or Martin without Lewis.

title: N.C.A.A. Champion Joins Rangers for the Playoffs
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Chris Kreider might have considered prolonging the celebration of Boston Colleges N.C.A.A. championship or completing what was left of the school year. But the Rangers, whose scouts have salivated over Kreiders speed and puck skills since the team drafted him in the first round in 2009, did not want to wait any longer for him to come aboard.

title: Severe Charge, With a Minimum Term of 25 Years
description: By choosing to charge George Zimmerman with second-degree murder in the killing of Trayvon Martin, Angela B. Corey, the special prosecutor appointed to the case in Florida, selected the toughest possible charge involving a killing short of first-degree murder, which requires a finding of premeditation and carries the death penalty as a possible punishment.

title: The Wages of Ideology
description: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin is struggling to fight off a determined effort to replace him in an extraordinary recall election scheduled for June 5. The original reason more than 900,000 Wisconsinites signed petitions to get him out of office was his signature on a bill that stripped most public employees of their collective bargaining rights. But, every few weeks, Mr. Walker provides new grounds for becoming the third American governor to be removed by his own electorate.

title: Searching for Justice in Florida
description: Law and order were advanced in Florida by the decision of a special state prosecutor to bring second-degree murder charges against George Zimmerman, the self-appointed neighborhood watchman who shot and killed Trayvon Martin, an unarmed teenager.

title: Wealthy Group Seeks to Reform Election Giving in New York
description: ALBANY  An unusual and well-heeled coalition, trying to tap public anger over the flood of money into politics, is pushing to enact a public financing system for elections in New York State.

title: Stores Go Online to Find a Perfect Fit
description: When Andy Dunn helped start Bonobos five years ago, he wanted to shake up the retail industry with a mens wear brand exclusively sold online.

title: Its More Than Lunch
description: When the leaders of India and Pakistan got together for lunch on Sunday in New Delhi there were no dramatic breakthroughs. But given their countries combustible history  and the ever present danger of even worse  the first visit to India by a Pakistani head of state in seven years was another small sign of progress. Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India and President Asif Ali Zardari of Pakistan both deserve credit for their sensible, workmanlike effort over the past year to improve relations between the two nuclear rivals.

title: Romney Taking Steps to Narrow His Gender Gap
description: Mitt Romney moved Wednesday to confront one of his most vexing general election problems  how to narrow the gender gap he faces against President Obama  but his campaign immediately found itself squeezed between its intensifying efforts to appeal to women and its need to avoid alienating conservatives.

title: Drop That Bog
description: To gardeners, there is something deeply gratifying about opening a bag of sphagnum peat moss. Its the smell and texture, as well as knowing that peat makes a good ground cover and soil improver. But, like so many other things in our lives, peat moss looks different, and far less gratifying, when you take climate change into account.

title: Things I Saw  No. 4
description: Suggestions for what youd like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

title: Fiery Manager Displays Contrite Side
description: PHILADELPHIA

title: 48% of Chicken in Small Sample Has E. Coli
description: A recent test of packaged raw chicken products bought at grocery stores across the country found that roughly half of them were contaminated with the bacteria E. coli.

title: Epilepsy Medicine Is Cited in the Killing of a Woman
description: The mother, a high school teacher and writer, called 911 on Tuesday morning asking for help with her teenage sons epileptic seizure. But her reason for needing assistance quickly changed.

title: Announcing Zimmerman Charges
description: Angela B. Corey, the Florida special prosecutor, announced a second-degree murder charge on Wednesday against George Zimmerman in the shooting death of Trayvon Martin.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 11, 2012

title: Is an Egg for Breakfast Worth This?
description: Supermarket eggs gleam with apparent cleanliness, and nothing might seem more wholesome than breaking one of them into a frying pan.

title: Ahmed Ben Bella, Revolutionary Who Led Algeria After Independence, Dies at 93
description: Ahmed Ben Bella, a farmers son who fought for France in World War II, turned against it in the brutal struggle for Algerian independence and rose to become Algerias first elected president, has died at his home in Algiers, the capital. He was 93.

title: Cut in E-Book Pricing by Amazon Is Set to Shake Rivals
description: The governments decision to pursue major publishers on antitrust charges has put the Internet retailer Amazon in a powerful position: the nations largest bookseller may now get to decide how much an e-book will cost, and the book world is quaking over the potential consequences.

title: Setback for Ex-Leader of Arts Club
description: Another month, another swing of the pendulum in the legal battles between the National Arts Club and its divisive former president, O. Aldon James Jr. On Wednesday, an appeals court judge effectively barred Mr. James from the club as a member  at least until the court can rule on the next round of legal papers.

title: Business Group Drops Support for Wage Bill
description: The long battle over a measure that would raise the wages of workers whose companies receive subsidies from New York City took a surprising turn on Wednesday, when a previously undisclosed loophole was scrapped, prompting a major business group to withdraw its support for the measure.

title: Off the Court, Onto the Stage
description: Magic/Bird, a play about the relationship between Magic Johnson and Larry Bird that evolved from hatred to a deep friendship from 1979 to 1992, opened Wednesday night at the Longacre Theater.

title: In Mystery of Hawk Deaths, Rat Poison Emerges
description: It had the makings of an avian mystery, albeit almost the opposite of that Hitchcockian one. Two red-tailed hawks were found dead, one in Central Park, one just outside. A third died 24 hours after being taken out of the park and sent to a wildlife rehabilitator because concerned park rangers could see that it was not acting right.

title: Indian Beer Bill Stalls; Industry Money Flows
description: Legislation in Nebraska that would curtail alcohol purchases to residents of a dry Indian reservation has stalled in a key committee whose members have received thousands of dollars in campaign contributions from the alcohol industry, according to state records.

title: Lightning That Halted L.I.R.R. Got Help From Workers Error, Report Says
description: When the Long Island Rail Road was paralyzed on Sept. 29 for nearly 12 hours after a lightning storm, nature was the obvious culprit  but not, it turns out, the only guilty party.

title: Guggenheim Project Challenges Western-Centric View
description: In an effort to reach beyond the Western art world the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation is embarking on a five-year program to work with artists, curators and educators from South and Southeast Asia, Latin America, the Middle East and North Africa. In addition to bringing curators from those parts of the world to the Guggenheim Museum in New York and organizing exhibitions that highlight art from their regions, the program will acquire art for the Guggenheims permanent collection.

title: Basketball Rivals in a Rematch With Low Stakes
description: About a third of the way through Magic/Bird, a new play about the basketball greats Magic Johnson and Larry Bird that opened on Broadway Wednesday night at the Longacre Theater, a moment of conflict, that crucial building block of drama, finally arrives.

title: A Slightly Bloody Tribute
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Today we welcome back Michael Shteyman, who is off seeking his fortune in the world of medicine but has stopped by to remind us 1) that becoming a BLOOD DONOR is a good thing, and 2) that it also happens to be the 100th anniversary of the death of CLARA BARTON, who founded the AMERICAN RED CROSS.

title: Whats Next for Butler Basketball
description: Matt Rhinesmith, a sports reporter for The Butler Collegian, wrote about the Bulldogs for The Quad this season.The Butler mens basketball team ended its season last month with an overtime loss to the Pittsburgh Panthers in the semifinals of the College Basketball Invitational, a tournament that Pittsburgh went on to win.

title: Priests Jury Is Told How a Complaint Was Scorned
description: PHILADELPHIA  A Roman Catholic bishop told his superiors that a church worker was trying to stir up conflict after she reported her concern that a priest in her parish was receiving pornography in the mail, a court heard on Wednesday.

title: Surname of Ex-Officials Wife Adds New Twist to Mystery
description: BEIJING  Chinese women, like Chinese men, are identified by their surnames followed by their given names. When Chinese women marry, they almost never take their husbands family name, and instead keep their own, which is typically that of their fathers family.

title: Britons Wanderings Led Him to Heart of a Chinese Scandal
description: BEIJING  At St. Marys Church in Londons Thames-side Battersea district, mourners who gathered for Neil Heywoods memorial service a few days before Christmas were perplexed by the instructions laid down beforehand by one of Mr. Heywoods classmates from Britains elite Harrow boarding school. He asked them not to approach Lulu Heywood, Mr. Heywoods Chinese wife, and to remain in the pews until she and their two children had left the church.

title: What Rick Santorum Wrought
description: Rick Santorum is a party crasher.

title: Comparing Job Losses
description: The number of jobs held by women is lower than it was in January 2009.

title: Provocative Views Seen in the Wings
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus  A fight over leadership of the Cypriot central bank could have repercussions throughout the European Union. The nations left-wing president, Demetris Christofias, is expected soon to appoint a new leader for the bank, an economist who has called for Germany to leave the euro zone.

title: Defining Campaign Spending Is at Heart of Edwards Trial
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.  Jury selection was scheduled to start Thursday in the federal trial of John Edwards, the start of at least six weeks of courtroom sparring between the corruption unit of the Department of Justice and a high-powered criminal defense team representing a man who twice reached for the presidency.

title: The Rich Get Richer as Kentucky Lands Noel
description: When the Kentucky freshman star Anthony Davis threw the ball in the air in celebration at the Final Four, the scene could well be remembered as more than a seminal moment in Wildcats basketball history. Daviss success in leading Kentucky to the national title and winning the national player of the year showed how short the line can be from top prospect to national champion.

title: Death Comes to the Vacant Lots of North Tulsa
description: TULSA, Okla.  In the minutes after a shooting spree left three of their neighbors dead and two others wounded, several residents told the police everything they had seen and heard. But only several. Abandoned properties hold no witnesses.

title: Patience Required for Digital Library Books
description: Many publishers have put restrictions on the availability of their digital books in public libraries resulting in long waiting lists.

title: Another Round: Conservation on a Human-Shaped Planet
description: Heres another round in what has become a heated, but ultimately productive, conversation on strategies for sustaining the planets biological integrity as humanitys influence builds. Critics of Peter Kareiva, the lead scientist for the Nature Conservancy, had the floor in the last post and now Kareiva reacts:

title: In Poppy War, Taliban Aim to Protect a Cash Crop
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  So focused are the Taliban on securing this years opium poppy crop  and the support of the farmers tending it  that in the early days of their spring offensive in the south, they are targeting not only the officials trying to eradicate the plants, but also the tractors they use.

title: Raymond Aubrac, an Exalted Leader of the French Resistance, Dies at 97
description: Raymond Aubrac, who took that nom de guerre as a storied leader of the resistance effort in Nazi-occupied France during World War II, died on Tuesday in a military hospital in Paris. He was 97.

title: Bay Citizen Ends Publishing Relationship With The Times
description: The Bay Citizen, an online news organization that has provided reporting from San Francisco and the surrounding area for The New York Times since 2010, has ended its relationship with the paper.

title: Death Penalty Repeal Goes to Connecticut Governor
description: HARTFORD  After more than nine hours of debate, the Connecticut House of Representatives voted on Wednesday to repeal the states death penalty, following a similar vote in the State Senate last week. Gov. Dannel P. Malloy, a Democrat, has said he will sign the bill, which would make Connecticut the 17th state  the 5th in five years  to abolish capital punishment for future cases.

title: Jets Name Executive
description: Neil Glat, who assisted in N.F.L. expansion and stadium development in his 15 years working for the league, has joined the Jets as team president. Glat will start with the Jets in early May, overseeing the organizations business operations after the winter departures of two executive vice presidents, Matt Higgins and Thad Sheely.

title: Photo Replay: April 11
description: The day in sports included beach volleyball practice in Rio de Janeiro and an N.H.L. playoff game in Nashville.

title: Strauss-Kahns Prostitution Scandal Taints Image of a Citys Beloved Hotel
description: LILLE, France  It was in this kitschy, faded and now infamous hotel, replete with fake flowers, colonnades and gold-plated statues, on a street lined with childrens stores, a church and a marriage counselor, that prosecutors say the elite of this northern city used to gather for sex. Today, the Htel Carlton de Lille is known around the world for having sheltered prominent businessmen, remorseful Freemasons and Belgian prostitutes, many of them linked to the onetime favorite candidate for the French presidency, Dominique Strauss-Kahn.

title: Celebrating Health Law, With a Poke at Romney
description: BOSTON  Former Gov. Mitt Romney, needless to say, did not attend. But at a sixth-anniversary celebration of Massachusetts landmark health care law on Wednesday, Gov. Deval Patrick, a Democrat, pointedly said his predecessor should be proud of the law, which has been a hot potato for Mr. Romney on the Republican presidential campaign trail.

title: Swishers Home Run Caps Yankees Sweep to Close Out a Trip
description: BALTIMORE  On a night like Wednesday, when the temperature dipped to 43 degrees, and batted balls seemed to sting from the fingers to the elbows, it can be hard to drive a pitch into the stands.

title: 6 Charged With Running Drug Ring From Bronx Day Care Center
description: Six Bronx residents have been charged with operating a prescription drug ring that is said to have used a day care center to store much of its supply, the authorities said on Wednesday.

title: South Sudan Says It Has Taken Over Disputed Town
description: MOMBASA, Kenya  South Sudanese officials said on Wednesday that their forces had taken control of a contested town in an oil-rich area along the border with Sudan, repulsing and pursuing Sudanese armed forces in the latest battle between two countries that are edging toward outright war.

title: Knicks Edge Bucks in Battle for 8th Place
description: MILWAUKEE  The battle for eighth place would not be determined by awe-inspiring defense or brilliant playmaking or any qualities that typically define great teams. This was, after all, a tussle for the Eastern Conferences last playoff berth, a spot reserved for the flawed and the hopeful.

title: Obama Wont Order Ban on Gay Bias by Employers
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama disappointed and vexed gay supporters on Wednesday with his decision, conveyed to activists by a senior adviser, not to sign an executive order banning discrimination by employers with federal contracts.

title: Report Says a Crop Subsidy Cap Could Save Billions
description: WASHINGTON  The federal government could save about $1 billion a year by reducing the subsidies it pays to large farmers to cover much of the cost of their crop insurance, according to a report by Congressional auditors due to be released on Thursday.

title: I.I.H.S. Study Suggests Child-Seat Anchor Systems Require Rethinking
description: Almost 10 years after the federal government required it in all passenger vehicles, the so-called Latch system is still managing to frustrate parents intent on protecting their children.

title: Life, Interrupted: The Patient in the Mirror
description: Today, Im writing from a hospital bed in New York City. Im in the bone marrow transplant unit, where this week Ive undergone 20 intensive chemotherapy treatments in anticipation of receiving my brothers stem cells. In the year since my diagnosis with leukemia, Ive struggled to hold onto a sense of who I am while I watch the person in the mirror change.

title: Life, Interrupted: A Family Gets Cancer
description: Suleika Jaouad was just starting her adult life when leukemia struck. Her diagnosis and her brothers role as her bone marrow donor have affected her entire family.

title: Treasury Faulted in Effort to Relieve Homeowners
description: WASHINGTON  A fund to support homeowners in the communities hit hardest by the collapse of the housing bubble has disbursed just 3 percent of its budget and aided only 30,640 homeowners in the two years since its creation, according to a report released on Thursday by a federal watchdog office.

title: Lakers Bynum Is Front and Center
description: SAN ANTONIO  The N.B.A. may be a league driven by small-to-midsize players with the skills to break down opposing defenses, but Andrew Bynum had a throwback performance Wednesday night as the Kobe Bryant-less Lakers stunned the Spurs, 98-84, at AT&T Center.

title: Corrections: April 12
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Across India, Nepotism as a Way of Life
description: The Indian upper class, like royalty, is sexually transmitted, Manu Joseph writes in The International Herald Tribune.

title: An Islands Other Fear  a Tsunami of Civilization
description: HONG KONG  Had a tsunami developed in the Indian Ocean after a massive earthquake on Wednesday, the worlds most isolated people would have been at serious risk. Perhaps, even, at risk of extinction.

title: Rushdies Memoir Title Pays Tribute to a Pair of Fellow Authors
description: Salman Rushdies coming memoir about his years in hiding has a title, and it requires a little explanation, Scott Heller writes in Arts Beat blog of The New York Times.

title: Cease-Fire Is Prevailing Across Most of Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A fragile cease-fire negotiated by the special envoy Kofi Annan prevailed in most of Syria on Thursday, the first vaguely optimistic signal in months in that nations bloody antigovernment uprising. But some deadly clashes were reported and activists said areas that had been riven by violence remained under virtual martial law, with tank deployments, armed checkpoints and rooftop snipers.

title: Greek Crisis Leaves Cyprus Mired in Debt
description: Cypruss close proximity to Greece made the expansion of Cypriot banks into the country appear to be a good idea. Now, the Greek debt crisis has exposed the perils of that strategy. The shaky state of Cypriot banks and government finances threatens to add another name to the list of euro countries needing international bailouts, Jack Ewing reports in The New York Times. Read more

title: How the Banks Endangered Medicare
description: Simon Johnson is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.

title: Picturing Jimi, Janis, Miles and Duke
description: The album cover may say Aretha in Paris, but Jim Cummins knows better.

title: Robert Caros Big Dig
description: Robert Caro probably knows more about power, political power especially, than anyone who has never had some. He has never run for any sort of office himself and would probably have lost if he had. Hes a shy, soft-spoken man with oldfashioned manners and an old-fashioned New York accent (he says toime instead of time and foine instead of fine), so self-conscious that talking about himself makes him squint a little. The idea of power, or of powerful people, seems to repel him as much as it fascinates. And yet Caro has spent virtually his whole adult life studying power and what can be done with it, first in the case of Robert Moses, the great developer and urban planner, and then in the case of Lyndon Johnson, whose biography he has been writing for close to 40 years. Caro can tell you exactly how Moses heedlessly rammed the Cross Bronx Expressway through a middle-class neighborhood, displacing thousands of families, and exactly how Johnson stole the Texas Senate election of 1948, winning by 87 spurious votes. These stories still fill him with outrage but also with something like wonder, the two emotions that sustain him in what amounts to a solitary, Dickensian occupation with long hours and few holidays.

title: Robert Caros Painstaking Process
description: A peek inside the writers office, where he has spent decades writing about Lyndon Johnson.

title: Whose Offer Is Sweetest?
description: THE applications have been filed, the acceptance letters gleefully read aloud. But before choosing where to enroll, students should carefully examine the financial aid offers presented by prospective colleges. We asked Zac Bissonnette, author of Debt-Free U., and Kalman A. Chany, author of Paying for College Without Going Broke and president of Campus Consultants, a New York-based financial aid advisory company, to discuss the best ways to compare offers. Excerpts from their answers follow.
