title: Study Links Raised Carbon Dioxide Levels to Oyster Die-Offs
description: Oyster hatcheries along the Washington and Oregon coastlines began experiencing calamitous die-offs beginning in 2006. Scientists suspected they were because of increased carbon dioxide levels in the air that were causing ocean acidification. That theory has now proved out, according to a study just published by the journal Limnology and Oceanography.

title: In Between Clay and Dust, Little Difference Between India and Pakistan
description: Musharraf Ali Farooqis second novel, Between Clay and Dust, technically takes place in a town in post-partition Pakistan, but you might not realize that when reading the book  and thats what the author intended.

title: British Hacking Scandal Suits to Be Filed in U.S.
description: LONDON  A high-profile British lawyer who has been closely involved in pursuing the hacking scandal at Rupert Murdochs British tabloids said on Thursday that he planned for the first time to sue on behalf of alleged victims in the United States, the center of Mr. Murdochs global media empire.

title: Signs Europe Bending on Airline Carbon Fee
description: ISTANBUL  The European Union, heading for a trade war over a new toll on the greenhouse gas emissions of international airlines using European airspace, has been warned that the measure could wreck the prospects for global action on climate change.

title: From New Yorks Benares, Fresh Food with Punch
description: Indian restaurants in New York City tend to be either high-end and high-priced, with the chefs using premium, fresh ingredients, or nondescript mid-range spots where frozen vegetables, meats and seafood are a mainstay.

title: Celery Recipes
description: Here are several ideas for using celery as a main ingredient (or close to one).

title: Sixteen Reasons to Take Celery Seriously
description: I used to hate celery. Even as an adult, even recently  I hated the strings, the smell and the taste. I have no explanation for my newfound appreciation other than my gradual realization that there are very few foods I dislike and even fewer for which I havent developed a taste. (Some game still turns me off, and I cant say Im in love with natto, the fermented soybeans adored by many Japanese. Beyond those, I cant think of anything I dont enjoy.)

title: Julia Louis-Dreyfus Takes the White House
description: Julia Louis-Dreyfus spent much of her childhood in and around Washington, D.C. But when she returned last September to shoot HBOs new comedy Veep, in which she plays Vice President Selina Meyer, decked out in a power bob and important-Washington-lady stockings, she got used to something new about the city: traveling by motorcade. She also noticed some curious overlaps between her life as a highly recognizable celebrity and the lives of highly recognizable politicians. Occasionally, for instance, a group of people on the street would see her emerging from the motorcade and react to her; shed respond in character as Vice President Meyer, pantomiming the exaggerated greeting a famous actress might bestow upon fans. It was worlds colliding in ways I hadnt anticipated, she says.

title: In Defense of Business Brokers
description: In his most recent column in Inc. magazine, Norm Brodsky, renowned entrepreneur and author, asks a provocative question: Do You Need a Business Broker? The column, prompted by a question from a reader, has caused an uproar throughout the normally quiet business brokerage community.

title: The Subversive Charm of Day Drinking
description: I used to frequent a corner bar in TriBeCa that looked like the setting of a Hopper painting. It was down the street from the college where I taught intro literature courses, and I decamped there in the early afternoon for a beer or two while slogging through freshman essays on Blake. But I didnt get much work done. The company was too interesting: ironworkers, painters, sculptors, people whose workdays started unusually early or uncommonly late  people for whom daytime is nighttime. And unlike their after-dark counterparts, no one was there to party. Pretty soon, I gave up my lonely corner banquette to join the guys sitting at the bar. I never looked back.

title: Its More Than Lunch
description: When the leaders of India and Pakistan got together for lunch on Sunday in New Delhi there were no dramatic breakthroughs, an editorial in The New York Times said. But given their countries combustible history  and the ever present danger of even worse  the first visit to India by a Pakistani head of state in seven years was another small sign of progress.

title: BrightSource Energy Withdraws I.P.O.

description: Had a tsunami developed in the Indian Ocean after a massive earthquake on Wednesday, the worlds most isolated people would have been at serious risk, Mark McDonald writes in the IHT Rendezvous blog of The New York Times, about the tribals in the North Sentinel Island, one of the Andaman islands. Perhaps, even, at risk of extinction.

title: On Fictional Broadway, and Then the Real One
description: CHRISTIAN BORLE knows what people think about Smash, his popular if picked-apart NBC drama about the making of a Broadway musical. Not because he goes online to see what they are saying about his performance  he learned to stop doing that long ago  but because, having recently wrapped his first season of the series, he is headed back to a Broadway stage, to a world in which everyone seems to have a thing or two to say about the on-screen depiction of the New York theater industry.

title: The March to Power
description: As Egypt prepares for presidential elections scheduled for May 23 and 24, the Muslim Brotherhood caused an uproar late last month by saying it would run a candidate, even though it had pledged not to do so. The Brotherhoods Freedom and Justice Party was the big winner of the recent elections for the first post-Mubarak Parliament, leading to fears that it would take over Egypts entire political system. But isnt the Muslim Brotherhood simply trying to make the most of the countrys new democracy?

description: The safe asset shortage meme has been gathering force lately, and is now the theme of a report from the IMF (pdf). The idea is that low long-term interest rates for the United States, the UK, and basically every country with its own currency that doesnt have large foreign-currency debts reflect the desperate search of investors for something safe to buy.

title: Daily Report: Amazon Set to Shake Industry by Cutting E-Book Prices
description: The governments decision to pursue major publishers on antitrust charges has put the Internet retailer Amazon.com in a powerful position, David Streitfeld reports in Thursdays New York Times. The nations largest bookseller may now get to decide how much an e-book will cost, and the book world is quaking over the potential consequences.

It was the first joint appearance of the current and former female justices at a public forum.

title: Uncommon Threads
description: For our latest womens issue, the artist Jacob Magraw  typically one who paints and draws took to needle and thread, fashioning a wildly colorful, Gertrude Jekyll-style garden in the shape of our trademark T. Magraw, 29 and a native of Seattle, splits his time between the tiny island of Waldron, in Washington state, and Sacramento, Calif. Both spots, he says, are beginning to show welcome, West-coast indications of spring. We think hes captured the season beautifully with this piece of intricate handiwork.

title: What Qualifies as Bartender Rock?
description: In my April Drink column, a tribute to the subversive pleasure of daytime drinking, I discuss what my friend Eric dubbed bartender rock. Erics a regular at the bar where I work and a professional bass player. His assessment struck a chord (forgive me) with some of the other day drinkers gracing the bar stools that afternoon when he instantly classified Jonathan Richman and the Modern Lovers as quintessential bartender rock. Others started tossing out names of bands and tracks that they think count, too. Bartender rock crosses genres: Pop, punk, hip-hop, country, R&B, and heavy metal all have their place.

title: Murrow Students Making Their Moves at Chess Nationals
At City Hall, a Matter of Transparency
description: When he was mayor, and was caught being inconstant on a matter of substance, Edward I. Koch defended himself by hauling out a quotation from Ralph Waldo Emerson.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Scrutiny for E-Book Pricing, and Phone-Hacking Lawsuits in U.S.
description: The Justice Department on Wednesday became an important player in the future of digital books, Julie Bosman writes, with the filing of an antitrust lawsuit against Apple and five of the largest book publishers. (Three of those publishers  Hachette Book Group, Simon & Schuster and HarperCollins  have agreed to settle; Macmillan and Penguin Group USA have not.) The impact: lower prices for e-books, as Amazon is freed to charge whatever price it wants, she writes, and, relatedly, an expected enhanced market position for Amazon.com.

title: Triple Trouble: Green Day to Release Three New Albums Over Four Months
description: When its last two studio albums have inspired a Broadway musical, what does an ambitious punk-rock band do next to keep its listeners scratching their heads? If youre Green Day you go into the studio and get cracking on three new albums to be released in the span of about four months. Following their best-selling 2004 release, American Idiot, and its 2009 followup, 21st Century Breakdown, whose songs were the basis for the American Idiot stage musical, the Green Day bandmates Billie Joe Armstrong, Mike Dirnt and Tr Cool said they were back at work with the producer Rob Cavallo in their home town, Oakland, Calif., to record a trilogy of albums: Uno!, scheduled for release on Sept. 25; Dos!, on Nov. 13; and  wait for it  Tr! on Jan. 15 next year. Green Day said in a statement, We are at the most prolific and creative time in our lives, adding: Instead of making one album, we are making a three-album trilogy. Every song has the power and energy that represents Green Day on all emotional levels. We just cant help ourselves.

title: After Decades of Limits, Myanmar Offers Riches
description: YANGON, Myanmar  One year into wide-ranging political reforms, this long-neglected city has some of the trappings of a boomtown.

title: Morning Buzz, April 12: Record Highs in Real Estate
description: Good morning. It will climb to the low 60s and remain sunny throughout the day, so if you plan to celebrate Look Up at the Sky Day, remember to wear sunglasses.

title: Leading Off: Who Lost in the Playoff Opener? Bears
description: The N.H.L. hopes you noticed that its playoffs started Wednesday night. The postseason is readily distinguished from the regular season by the lack of games involving the Toronto Maple Leafs. To entice you into the fold, the league offered up a classic grudge match between Philadelphia and Pittsburgh, a less classic but still grudge-filled Nashville-Detroit series and Los Angeles playing Vancouver for East Coast insomniacs and far-western Canadians. But like the regular season, the postseason also involves players smashing one anothers heads in, that charming part of the game we all cannot get enough of, which means that the league discipline guru Brendan Shanahan will have to raise his video-explanation skills to playoff level quickly.

title: Avengers Director Joss Whedon on His Creative Setbacks
description: Its not always a thrill a minute being Joss Whedon. Some days you get to be the show runner of a television series like Buffy the Vampire Slayer or the director and screenwriter of a superhero summer movie like The Avengers. And then there are the days you spend working on a show like Firefly, which gets canceled; or on Dollhouse, which gets turned into something you didnt want and then canceled; or you make a movie like The Cabin in the Woods (which Mr. Whedon wrote with its director, Drew Goddard) and it spends years on a shelf when the studio files for bankruptcy.

title: A Day in Court and a New Lawyer for Defendant in Martin Case
description: SANFORD, Fla.  A tall, lanky red-headed lawyer named Mark OMara appeared in court here on Thursday, standing next to his newest client, George Zimmerman, one of the most recognizable defendants in the country but a man he had met for the first time only the night before at the county jail.

title: Kick Starter | Missoni for Converse
description: There is no limit to what one can wear with a pair of classic Converse All Stars. And, the same goes for Missoni, who has dressed everyone and everything, from the shelves of Target (with their 2011 collaboration) to the Duchess of Cambridge (who wore a royal blue tweed M Missoni coat while shopping at Fortnum & Mason recently). So, its no surprise that for two years running, Missoni for Converse has been chucking out cool zigzagged sneakers. Three limited-edition high tops are out on Saturday: metallic sparkly green or pink printed with the companys signature chevron (for the ladies) and a navy space-dyed style (for the guys). Im a big fan of prixing, you know, print mixing, says Margherita Missoni, the Italian labels accessories designer. I love the idea of coloring the world in Missoni prints, one piece at a time, she says. It would be such a joyful place to live in.

title: Morning Walkabout: 4/12

Now it is known as the place where Dominique Strauss-Kahn is accused of being involved with a prostitution ring, making it a tourist attraction of a different sort. (The New York Times)

description: When Mary Mangans body was recovered from the frigid waters where the Titanic vanished, rescuers retrieved a delicate, golden watch engraved with M. Mangan and hands stopped at 2:20 am.

description: Officials at the University of California, Los Angeles have apologized for an e-mail sent to 894 wait-listed students that mistakenly congratulated them on their admission to UCLA.

title: Some Girls Are Better Than Others
description: Ah, to be a girl again! Not a child, of course, but an inhabitant of that rarefied, pH-balanced zone of romance and optimism where you might flirt and flounce and be easily bruised by a pea. Girls can put on a dress and twirl in a circle and others will clap and say, How pretty! Girls never question whether the attention they get is well-meaning. They skip through the forest with a basket full of treats for Grandma, happily telling every Big Bad Wolf they encounter exactly where theyre headed.

title: Markets, Mug Shots and More in Lyon, France
description: Yes, you can eat well here. But you can also see where cinema started and drink among the accused.

title: "First Generation"
description: A documentary follows the lives of four high school students who are the first in their families to go to college.

title: 36 Hours in Lyon, France
description: I know of only one thing that you can do well in Lyon, and thats eat, the 19th-century French novelist Stendhal remarked. Two centuries later, the image of Frances third-largest metropolis is still buried under a heap of food. No surprise. Frances most celebrated chef, the octogenarian Paul Bocuse, hails from Lyon, and the citys bouchons  homey restaurants serving rustic, traditional cuisine  are famous countrywide. But once you shovel off the tons of blood sausage and St. Marcellin cheese, you find far more than a picturesque feeding zone. The gateway to the Alps enfolds Roman ruins, Renaissance-era architecture, abundant art spaces, talented young designers, renovated riverfronts and a fast-rising neighborhood of futuristic architecture. Better, a new generation of chefs is bringing Lyonnaise cuisine into the 21st century. Even Mr. Bocuse is adapting to the new millennium: He recently opened his first design hotel.

title: A Rare Private Equity Chieftain in Obamas Camp
description: Hamilton E. James Jr., the president of Blackstone and one of the few prominent Democratic supporters from the private equity world, will host a fund-raiser for President Obama in mid-May, Nicholas Confessore reports for The New York Times Caucus blog. Read more

description: A new online bank aims to help graduates reduce their student debts, by paying rewards when they use their debit cards.

description: Improvements in the landscape for initial public offerings appeared to have stalled a bit on Thursday, as newly public shares of the Oaktree Capital Group tumbled.

He was limiting his diet to meet a contracted weight of 155 pounds; vacation days had been docked at his day job.

description: A World Financial Center building, home to several Wall Street firms, was evacuated on Thursday as the police investigated a suspicious package, according to New York officials.

description: There comes a time in early life when a slave becomes aware that he is a slave. And so it was with Henry Scott, a half-white child fathered by his master in Fauquier County, Va. Scott became acutely and painfully aware of his condition at age 8 in about 1856  and vowed to escape.

The screener called 911. The building, near ground zero, where terror threats are taken particularly seriously, was evacuated.

title: The Girl Who Paved the Way for Girls
description: In this weeks Riff, Heather Havrilesky writes about the the gaggle of girls (broke, new, dragon-tattooed) on screen today, and why Lena Dunhams new HBO show stands apart. Four decades earlier, the legendary New York Times television critic John J. OConnor, remembered for his unapologetic style and prolific career, wrote about the first major American television show to focus on the life of a single woman. Below, an excerpt from his original review.

title: Evicted From Park, Occupy Protesters Take to Sidewalks
description: The protesters arrived on Wall Street on Wednesday night carrying bedrolls, quilts and blankets. They spread pieces of cardboard on the sidewalks. Then, as several police officers stood nearby, the protesters made signs with anticorporate slogans.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Chief Sends Obama Letter Voicing Concern About Labor Killings in Colombia
description: With President Obama scheduled to attend the Summit of the Americas in Colombia this weekend, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.s president has sent him a toughly worded letter saying that he should not officially certify that Colombia has done enough to stop a decades-long series of killings of union leaders and supporters there.

Only a tiny sign beside the stoop suggests the gorgeously restored 19th-century town house is not a private home.

title: Ann Romneys Rsum Includes More Than Stay-at-Home Mother
description: Has Ann Romney ever worked?

title: Seven Actors Face a Big Challenge: He Just Said That?
description: THE seven actors in the new Broadway play Clybourne Park were mostly strangers to one another when they met for the first table read of this stinging comedy by Bruce Norris in January 2010. They had no real comfort zone among them as they began to wade through the mudslide of racial indignities set off by white characters arguing about integration in 1959 Chicago.

title: The Naked Appeal of Instagram
description: On Tuesday, I took a picture of a Naked Cowboy in Times Square. I was in a hurry and late, but I still wanted the picture. Not that I havent seen him dozens of times, but in addition to being a fixture whom tourists flock to  who doesnt enjoy a little naked cowboy every now and then?  his presence signified something broader that I wanted to share: In this instance, the change of seasons.

title: Independent Report Gives Mixed Scores to City Schools' Letter Grades
Biden Says Republicans Want a Romney Rule
description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. sought on Thursday to tie Mitt Romney directly to Republican opposition to higher taxes on millionaires, saying they want a Romney Rule that doubles down on tax cuts for the wealthy.

title: Lawyer for Phone-Hacking Victims Is Coming to America
description: The lawyer at the center of the legal battle against News Corporation over phone hacking at the companys British newspapers will arrive in New York on Monday and spend the week here.

title: Dick Teresi Talks About the Line Between Life and Death
description: In his new book, The Undead, Dick Teresi writes provocatively about the science of brain death and the impact it has on organ transplantation. Mr. Teresis strong opinions have generated strong responses; meanwhile, the ethical issues involved have recently made news in China, with the country announcing it would end the practice of transplanting organs from its executed prisoners. I spoke with Mr. Teresi about his book via e-mail. Below are excerpts of the conversation.

title: Theres Sex, Theres the City, but No Manolos
description: The new HBO series Girls slips in a wry acknowledgement of Sex and the City, and that tribute  a character describes herself as a Carrie with a touch of Samantha  is gracious but not entirely necessary.

title: TimesCast | April 12, 2012
description: An uncertain cease-fire in Syria | George Zimmerman appears in court | Reviving Brooklyns historic jazz scene.

title: The Get | Cartier Juste Un Clou Bracelet
description: The latest must-have bracelet from Cartier comes from the brands new Juste un Clou (Just a Nail) collection. A reinterpretation of a bracelet that Aldo Cipullo designed for the house in 1971, the 18-karat yellow gold bangle makes its debut tomorrow, to coincide with the opening of Cartier & Aldo Cipullo, New York City in the 70s, an exhibition of archival images on view at the companys Fifth Avenue flagship (through May 8). Featuring a discreet center hinge, it isnt the only bent-nail piece in the collection  bracelets and rings come in white and rose gold, with and without diamond embellishments, too  but it is the heftiest, which is always a plus when shopping for things like hardware .. .and gold. Hit it!

title: Wedding Q. and A.
description: Potluck Reception? Good Luck With That

title: Gifts From Japan, Less Celebrated in Manhattan
description: The blossoming cherry trees around the Tidal Basin in Washington, a gift of friendship from Japan in 1912, attract millions of ogling, photo-snapping visitors each spring. For their 100th anniversary, the fluffy pink blooms are receiving more attention than ever, featuring celebrations organized by the Japanese Embassy across this country and a special-issue 45-cent stamp.

title: Keep, Bear and Use
description: The modern drive against gun control started with an expansive interpretation of the Second Amendment as bestowing an absolute, individual right to keep and bear arms, rather than a societal right based on the need for a well-regulated militia.

title: Are Women Less Satisfied With Their Care Than Men?
description: Early on in my residency, a fellow surgeon-in-training revealed that she was switching fields. Her real love was not general surgery, she explained, but urology.

title: For Teenagers, 'Bully' Is Tough to Watch, but Important to Discuss
Image of the Day: April 12
Shanterrica Madden's Confession
description: On the night of Tina Stewart's murder, Madden was arrested, questioned by police, and initially denied any involvement in her roommate's death. But she eventually confessed to killing Stewart.

title: Point/Counterpoint: Nadal's Legacy
description: tennis

title: A Super PAC Mystery: A $500,000 Donation and a Refund
description: It may be one of the most expensive campaign refunds in history  or an example of how tangled the trail of political money can be in the age of super PACs and unlimited donations.

title: There Is a Lot of Big Tech News
description: Wow, what a week! If youre into tech news, surely your head was exploding from all the headlines. More news per second than CNN on a TV with CNBC, MSNBC and Fox News playing picture-in-picture.

title: Dance of the Bumblebees
description: See a larger version of the forest from this week. Compare with the enlarged version of last weeks image.

title: Lowitt Is Leaving Barclays
description: Ian Lowitt, a senior officer at Barclays and the last chief financial officer of Lehman Brothers, is leaving the British bank, according to a firm spokeswoman.

title: Gingrich Accuses Fox News of Bias
description: The fight for the Republican nomination is no longer just candidate versus candidate. Its candidate versus Fox News.

title: Seeing Things | Get Your Rocks and Eagles Here
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: The Instagram Deal: A Mark Zuckerberg Production
description: Mark Zuckerberg, the 27-year-old chief executive and co-founder of Facebook, does not usually play the role of deal maker.

title: Wry and Subtle Jesting? Not Here, Knucklehead
description: Every straight man has a stooge  Abbott had Costello, Crosby had Hope  the foil, the fool, the flunky, the goat. But for much of their career, after splitting from a famous straight man, the Three Stooges had only one another to kick and slap around. Beginning in the 1930s these immortal three ran amok for decades in some 200 short films, busting guts and raking in cash. Now, with stupidity a proud national pastime on the boob tube and off, the moment is ripe for a nyuk-nyuk revival, starting with The Three Stooges: The Movie, Peter and Bobby Farrellys thoroughly enjoyable paean to Moe, Larry and Curly and the art of the eye poke.

title: Romney Camps Parody Channels the Biden Id
description: In its latest attack, Mitt Romneys campaign is perhaps taking its strategy cues from The Onion.

title: Canada Seeks to Turn Coins Into Digital Currency
description: Last month, Canada announced that it would eliminate its penny. Now the Royal Canadian Mint is using one of the oldest forms of currency, gold, to attract software developers to its project, the MintChip Challenge, to transform the countrys remaining coins into digital currency.

title: Wings Absorb Blows, Predators Weber Fined
description: In Detroits 3-2 loss to Nashville in Game 1 of their playoff series, the Predators forced the Wings to play catch-up for the entire game, and received some strong goaltending from Pekka Rinne. The Wings also absorbed more than their share of bumps, bruises and cuts.

title: Departing EADS Chief Urges Europe to Recommit to Industry
description: PARIS  In his six years at the helm of EADS, Europes largest aerospace and military contractor, Louis Gallois has made it a large part of his mission to push his company deeper into emerging markets to offset flagging demand and high production costs at home.

title: BP Shareholders Approve Pay for New Chief
description: LONDON  The oil giant BP fended off a revolt by a minority of its shareholders Thursday over the award of a salary, bonus and stock package worth around $6.8 million to its chief executive, Robert W. Dudley.

title: Yesterdays Hostages; Todays Iran
description: Several of the Americans who were held by Iran between 1979 and 1981 reflect on tensions between that country and the United States and how their ordeal affects todays crisis.

title: 3 Decades Later, Ex-Hostages Press On for Damages From Iran
description: WASHINGTON  For more than three decades, David M. Roeder has watched as successive American presidents have struggled to engage Iran and, in his view, completely failed to hold it accountable.

title: Why Jim Yong Kim Wants to Run the World Bank
description: This week, I had the opportunity to interview Dr. Jim Yong Kim, the Obama administrations nominee to head the World Bank. Dr. Kim is the president of Dartmouth College and a public health expert. He is a physician and anthropologist, a founder of the nonprofit Partners in Health and a former World Health Organization official.

title: Grizzlies Manage to Create Depth With Design
description: Just months ago, the Memphis Grizzlies came face to face with their own woeful limitation; despite their ability to withstand trading one sidelined star (Zach Randolph) for another (Rudy Gay), injury elsewhere in the rotation had created considerable problems. Darrell Arthur was far from the most valuable of the Grizz, but his disappearance from the rotation because of a torn anterior cruciate ligament had left a gulf in production between the starters and the reserves. Arthur was the functional bridge between the two, and without his standout defense and consistency from midrange, Memphis was left to reconcile a disjointed alignment of talent.

title: Does Sugar Belong in Corn Bread?
description: When it comes to corn bread, no recipe is safe from scrutiny. In response to Sam Siftons article on corn bread, readers engaged in lively debate over how the dish is best prepared, whether Southerners know best and whether our version too closely resembled dessert.

title: Theater Talkback: Frank Langella Telling Tales
description: Frank Langella has had an accomplished stage career and a modestly successful one in films. But while his star turn on Broadway in Dracula transformed him into a matinee idol for a brief period, and he has won three Tonys and worked consistently ever since, Mr. Langella never became a major film star and never achieved the kind of immortality bestowed on many of the luminaries who glide through his terrific new memoir, amusingly titled Dropped Names.

title: Digital Notes: Updating Digital Royalties, and a Peek Under Pandoras Hood
description: A Royalties Deal: The music industry has never been accused of moving too fast when it comes to new technologies. On Wednesday, after months of negotiations, the major trade groups representing labels, music publishers and digital media services said they had reached an agreement over publishing royalties for a range of new and not-so-new digital music models, including locker services like Apples iTunes Match and bundled deals that add music access to cellphone accounts.

title: Old Montreal, Newly Hip
description: High fashion adds an of-the-moment feel to a part of the city that dates back centuries.

title: Neuhaus Launches a Flagship for Chocolates
description: For most Americans, praline conjures up the sugary pecan-studded candy from Louisiana. But in francophone Europe, pralines are filled chocolates. And it was exactly 100 years ago that the praline, a hard chocolate shell with a creamy flavored interior, made its debut at the Neuhaus chocolatier in Brussels.

title: Pregame Chatter: Tortorella Gets Reflective; Kreider Gets Homework
description: There was time before the Rangers playoff opener against the Ottawa Senators on Thursday for Coach John Tortorella to take one last look back at his teams regular-season achievements, and even to marvel at his players diligence and professionalism.

title: Apple Not Likely to Be a Loser in the E-Book Legal Fight
description: If Apple loses the legal case filed against it and book publishers on Wednesday over e-book pricing, will it be deeply wounded in its growing rivalry with Amazon?

title: An Art Scene Expands Beyond the Elite
description: ART galleries might be a mainstay in most large cities, but in So Paulo they have always been in short supply, catering to a small elite. But as Brazils economy has rapidly expanded over the last decade, a new social class has more disposable income to spend on luxury items like art.

title: A Lofty Retreat From Sweltering Shanghai
description: FOLLOWING in the footsteps of foreign missionaries, Chinese gangsters and Chiang Kai-shek, I traveled to the mountain outpost of Moganshan looking for a breather from full-throttle Shanghai. Before I reached my destination, however, I had an intimidating set of stairs to climb.

title: As Mali Prepares for Vote, Interim Leader Is Sworn In
description: BAMAKO, Mali  Twenty-two days after a military coup ended more than two decades of democratic rule in Mali, the leader of the countrys National Assembly was sworn in as interim president on Thursday.

title: Restaurant Report: Mizlala by Meir Adoni in Tel Aviv
description: Meir Adoni, the chef at Mizlala, sees the restaurant as the crazy younger sister of his haute-dining, white tablecloth establishment, Catit. This one is supposed to give you a good night out, he said.

title: A Hotel Insider Shares Secrets
description: THINK of Anthony Melchiorri as a capeless crusader for ailing hotels, swooping into troubled properties and conjuring cures. He is the host and driving force behind Hotel Impossible, a new show on the Travel Channel, and fixing what ails hotels is a skill he has been honing over decades in the industry. As general manager of the iconic Algonquin in New York, he oversaw a major renovation of the building and its image. He is also a former vice president of Tishman Hotels and is the founder of Argeo Hospitality, a hotel management and consulting firm.

title: Some Things Should Be Dead
description: Richard Forteys Horseshoe Crabs and Velvet Worms begins, as all serious books of science should, at an orgy. Specifically, the author is observing the nighttime mating ritual of thousands of clacking horseshoe crabs in spring along the Delaware coast. I am there, he writes, with my notebook and a fluttering heart.

title: At Nuclear Talks, Hopes That a New Iranian Attitude Will Reduce Tensions
description: ISTANBUL  At negotiations this week between Iran and six world powers, the United States and its allies hope to make enough progress to take some of the urgency out of the confrontation over Tehrans nuclear program, to reassure Israel and to arrange a second round of talks soon.

title: Exploring Americas, and the Worlds, Energy Choices
description: The New York Times sponsored a Energy For Tomorrow forum this week to clarify the countrys and worlds energy options in an era of economic turbulence and a changing climate. The participants including Secretary of Energy Steve Chu, energy analysts Daniel Yergin and Michael Levi and a host of other figures immersed in these issues. A broad theme was the need for an all of the above energy quest (a mantra of President Obama).

title: Michael Mahalchick: It
description: Canada

title: The Way We Live Now
description: Brooke Alexander Gallery

title: Douglas Huebler : Crocodile Tears
description: Paula Cooper Gallery

title: Richard Artschwager Early Works From the 1960s
description: Leo Castelli

title: Pamela Rosenkranz: Because They Try to Bore Holes
description: Miguel Abreu

title: By Request | The Bright Stuff
description: Whats Hot: Skin brighteners like Cliniques Even Better Clinical Dark Spot Corrector.

title: To Keep Start-Ups at Home, France Invests in Them
description: PARIS  The French government likes social media  so much so that the countrys sovereign wealth fund has invested 10 million euros in an online network.

title: Officers Are Advised to Look Out for Bottle Bombs
description: The safety alert went out Tuesday to all 76 police precincts in New York City from the chief of departments office.

title: Cover of Swiss Magazine Draws Accusations of Racism
description: A Swiss weekly magazine aimed to draw attention to what it presented as the scourge of robberies in Switzerland with a provocative cover of a young, dirty-faced boy pointing a gun at the camera and the headline The Roma are coming. It succeeded in being called racist.

title: Trustee May Sue MF Global Officials
description: The trustee unwinding MF Globals brokerage unit has threatened to sue the bankrupt firms executives and board over the misuse of customer money.

title: Hotel Review: Chez Swann, Montreal
description: THE UPSHOT

title: Movie Listings for April 13-19
description: Movies

title: Pop/Rock Listings for April 13-19
description: Pop

title: A Look at Why Consumers Are Using Prepaid Debit Cards
description: Its clear that prepaid debit cards  cards that you load with cash, spend down and then reload  are hot.

title: Jazz Listings for April 13-19
description: Jazz

title: Just Go to Sleep: The G-Rated Version
description: Go the ___ to Sleep rocked the best seller lists last year. The author, Adam Mansbach, famously struck a nerve with his profane plea to children everywhere:

title: Clemens Retrial Set to Begin With Prosecutors on Notice
description: WASHINGTON  After bungling its first attempt at prosecuting Roger Clemens on charges that he lied to Congress about his steroid use, the government on Monday will start its second effort to convict him in federal court.

title: Wade Backtracks on Olympic Pay
description: In perhaps the least surprising development of the day, Dwyane Wade has reversed course on his instantly unpopular idea that N.B.A. players should be paid to participate in the Olympics. In a statement released by the Miami Heat, Wade said, I do not want to be paid to go to the Olympics.

title: Modern Family Joins the Ratings Slide
description: Not to be left out from what has been a dismal week for broadcast ratings, another hit series succumbed to a downward trend on Wednesday night This time it was ABCs Modern Family that fell to season lows in total audience, at 10.3 million, and in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic, according to Nielsen. The series premiere of  Dont Trust the B in Apartment 23 followed, and managed a decent viewer sampling with 7 million.

title: Collision Over Roles of Women Sets Off Combative Debate Along the Trail
description: The campaign for the White House spilled into the politics of motherhood on Thursday as a combative back-and-forth involving a Democratic strategist and Mitt Romneys wife quickly revived a deeper, decades-old cultural debate about the roles of women in and out of the workplace.

title: Cakes Gone Wrong
description: A selection of cakes that have been featured on Cake Wrecks, the blog that posts photos of disastrous, professionally made confections.

title: Spare Times for April 13-19
description: Around Town

title: Lead Director at MarketAxess Departs
description: The electronic trading platform MarketAxess Holdings is losing Nicolas Rohatyn, a prominent financier who has helped shape the company for more than a decade.

title: Spare Times: For Children, for April 13-19
description: JIM HENSONS MUSICAL WORLD

title: Earth Music
description: Instead of visiting the zoo, spend some time in the native habitat of your local symphony orchestra. You will meet the badgering bass player, whose disparaging wisecracks you cannot quite hear; the flustered, quivering flutist who just wishes the oboist would play in tune (the feeling is mutual); and many other creatures, docile and gruff. Bernie Krauses new book, The Great Animal Orchestra, is not about this beastly symphony; it is about the symphony of beasts that surrounds us, a vast orchestra in the process of being silenced, perhaps even more endangered than our human animal orchestras.

title: New Barnes & Noble E-Reader Is Designed for Nighttime Reading
description: 5:33 p.m. | Updated Barnes & Noble wants you to take your e-reader to bed.

title: In Old Age the Servant Becomes the Served
description: In an efficient, mostly wordless sequence near the beginning of her quietly affecting film A Simple Life, the director Ann Hui shows the rhythms of shared routine and intimacy that bind the lead characters. Ah Tao (Deanie Ip) has fixed Roger Leung (Andy Lau) an elaborate meal that seems to be his ordinary fare. As she shuffles around serving, Roger eats with a kind of distracted concentration. There are no thank yous or compliments, just a request for ox tongue soon.

title: Santorum Says Suspending Campaign Was Financial Decision
description: In his first interview since ending his presidential campaign,Rick Santorum said Thursday that what pushed him out of the Republican race was his campaigns dwindling bank account.

title: Money Corrupts. Unlimited Money Corrupts Absolutely.
description: Richard Posner, a member of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit and arguably the countrys most influential federal judge, is also a prolific blogger. I feel pretty good about trying out new media after a long career in old media, but I have nothing on Mr. Posner, whos 73.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings for April 13-19
description: Classical

title: Google Announces 2-for-1 Stock Split
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google is getting back on its game.

title: Up Front
description: It would be self-serving for us to quote only the first part of Emersons famous description of a persons character: A man is known by the books he reads. But even considering the quotation in full ( . . . by the books he reads, by the company he keeps, by the praise he gives, by his dress, by his tastes, by his distastes, by the stories he tells, by his gait, by the motion of his eye, by the look of his house and so forth), its obvious where Emersons  and our  priorities lie.

title: Dance Listings for April 13-19
description: Dance

title: On Your Mark, Get Set, Go
description: At the Baselworld watch and jewelry show last month, a number of leading brands turned to the speedway for inspiration, breaking records in timekeeping and innovation, and collaborating with makers of some of the worlds fastest and most luxurious race cars. Celebrating its 150-year anniversary, Tag Heuer introduced the Carrera Mikrograph 1/100th Second Chronograph that, true to its name, measures time to exactly that level of precision. Its the first mechanical watch of its kind to do so. Bulgari teamed up with Maserati on the design of its new Octo Maserati timepiece  its lacquered dial features stripes that resemble the speed machines signature grills; the retrograde dial displays read like dashboard gauges. And Hublots Big Bang Ferrari watch, which sports an upholstered band, pedal-like pushers and internal mechanics so intricate they could rival a 12-cylinder engine, comes in scratch-resistant 18-karat Magic Gold, newly developed by the brand. Gentlemen, start your engines.

title: House to Begin Work on Tax Overhaul
description: The push for a broad overhaul of the federal tax code will begin in earnest next week with a series of meetings between Representative Dave Camp, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, and the Republican rank-and-file.

title: Breaking Down Traditional Chinese Medicine
description: For more than 3,000 years, traditional Chinese medicine has been an integral part of Chinese culture and the predominant medical treatment for a large part of the population. In recent decades, the practice has gained popularity in countries around the world, creating a multimillion-dollar global industry.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for April 13-19
description: Art

title: Theater Listings: April 13  19
description: Theater

title: Pictures of the Day: North Korea and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from North Korea, Iran and Romania.

title: Private Goldman Exchange Officially Closes for Business
description: We hardly knew ye, GSTrUE.

title: Tapping Psychic Undercurrents
description: The artist-as-curator group show, once strictly a summer perennial, now blooms year round. For a springtime example see The Spirit Level, organized by Ugo Rondinone and on view now at both branches of the Gladstone Gallery, which is going head to head with Chelseas high-season solos.

title: States Seek Curb on Patient Bills for Costly Drugs
description: The hemophilia drug that saves 7-year-old William Addison from uncontrolled bleeding costs $100,000 a year. His familys insurance pays virtually all of it.

title: Gunman Killed After Drugstore Holdup in East Harlem, Police Say
When the Best Teacher Doesnt Have a Degree
description: In the indelible opening scene of Philippe Falardeaus Monsieur Lazhar, Simon (milien Nron), a sixth grader at a Montreal middle school, catches a glimpse of the body of Martine, a popular teacher who has hanged herself from a pipe inside a classroom. He turns and runs.

title: Back on Staten Island Early, and Wriggling
description: There is an abundance of new snacks in the creeks of Staten Island  if you like eels.

title: The Origin of Everything
description: To the Editor:

title: De Blasios Communications Director Leaves
description: A key aide to the citys public advocate, Bill de Blasio, has left her position after only three months on the job.

title: Flexing His Way Through a Borrowed Plot
description: Real cinematic killer Bs may be extinct, but at the French film factory EuropaCorp the B-movie ethos of cheap genre thrills endures. A co-creation of the hit maker Luc Besson, EuropaCorp is the outfit that fired the bullet-headed Jason Statham into international fame with the Transporter franchise and resurrected Liam Neeson as a middle-aged tough guy with Taken. One of the companys latest, the English-language Lockout, is as dopey an entertainment as imaginable, but its also a reminder that the films star, Guy Pearce, has always had great screen magnetism, to which he has now added a bedrock of muscle. Also: he can act.

title: Loving, and Maybe Exploiting, Armenia
description: There are vistas in Braden Kings metaphysical road movie, Here, that are so beautiful you want to step through the screen and disappear into the Armenian landscape where much of it was filmed. In the most evocative scene, the camera slowly pans across pastures framed by distant mountains in which cattle graze amid a sprawling grid of power lines.

title: Connecting at Comic-Con
description: Images of some of the subjects and scenes of Comic-Con Episode IV: A Fans Hope.

title: Awake or Knocked Out? The Line Gets Blurrier
description: The puzzle of consciousness is so devilish that scientists and philosophers are still struggling with how to talk about it, let alone figure out what it is and where it comes from.

title: Age, They Hope, Wont Wither Them ... Quite Yet
description: Inside Late Bloomers, a tonally wobbly romantic comedy about the indignities of aging, is a somber marital drama struggling to get out. Much of the lurking gravity is etched on the attractive faces of its two stars, William Hurt, 62, and Isabella Rossellini, 59, who play Adam and Mary, a couple married 30 years experiencing the pangs of late middle age.

title: A Mecca for Mere Mortals Devoted to Superpowers
description: When Albert Camus observed that a mans work is a journey to rediscover the two or three great and simple images in whose presence his heart first opened, he couldnt have been thinking of the thousands of freaks, geeks and nerds who attended the 2010 Comic-Con convention in San Diego. But his words describe many among the hordes of fans, aspiring illustrators, collectors and designers whom Morgan Spurlocks documentary Comic-Con Episode IV: A Fans Hope surveys with amused sympathy.

title: Struggling for Justice
description: For more than three decades, the Americans who were taken hostage in Iran in 1979 have sought compensation for their ordeal.

title: No Fancy Footwork Needed
description: I USED to think I was virtuous for working out six days a week. Though I mostly sat in front of a computer for the rest of each day, I didnt think that mattered as long as I squeezed in some morning exercise.

title: Titanic at 100 at South Street Seaport Museum
description: Commercials for the release of James Camerons 3-D version of Titanic seem to be on a continuous loop as we approach the centennial of the ships sinking (Saturday and Sunday). Mr. Cameron isnt the first of us, and wont be the last, to be obsessed with the ships only voyage. In fact, one of the Misers first Betamax recordings was of the 1953 Titanic, starring Barbara Stanwyck and Clifton Webb. (The tape eventually broke from overuse.)

title: In Hole, Then Scrambling Out of One
description: Every junkies like a setting sun, Neil Young warns in his classic feel-bad drug song, The Needle and the Damage Done. You have to wonder if Patty Schemel, a drummer for the band Hole who soared high  sent aloft on fame, talent, drugs and all the familiar rock n roll rest  only to crash terribly low, ever listened to that song. In Hit So Hard, a documentary about her fast and brutal times, Ms. Schemel talks about her early musical influences and those formative years when she played along to anything on the radio, except perhaps for this one cautionary lament.

title: Turkish Military Leaders Held for Role in 97 Coup
description: ISTANBUL  A former general and 30 other officers were detained Thursday for their roles in a 1997 coup, continuing the clash between the government and the nations once-indomitable military.

title: Reverse Loans, Pre-Retirement
description: REVERSE mortgages, once associated mainly with homeowners in their 70s and beyond, are now being taken out by people nearing retirement to help pay off debts and remain financially solvent, a new report shows.

title: Times Talks: The 2012 Campaign
description: The Timess Rick Berke, an assistant managing editor, moderates a conversation about the 2012 presidential campaign with Richard W. Stevenson, political editor, Jim Rutenberg and Jeff Zeleny, national political correspondents, and Sheryl Gay Stolberg, political features correspondent.

title: Taking a Chain Saw to Horror Movie Clichs
description: Just before a recent advance screening of The Cabin in the Woods, a friendly publicist asked the assembled bloggers and critics if we would please refrain from disclosing any of the reveals, surprises and uncredited performances in the movie we were about to see. Im happy to oblige, though I worry that it might count as a spoiler even to mention that there are reveals, surprises and uncredited performances.

title: A Composers Score For a Dance With Death
description: In March 1828, the last year of his life, Schubert enjoyed a success with a public concert of his works in Vienna. He attracted the interest of publishers, but nothing much came of it. Before long he was again penniless and miserable. His health, which had been terrible since he contracted what was almost surely syphilis in his mid-20s, steadily deteriorated.

title: Are Hard-Line Cuban-Americans Strong as Ever?
40 Years After Renaming, Roosevelt Island Gets a Time Capsule
description: Its about time. Nearly 40 years after Welfare Island was renamed to honor President Franklin D. Roosevelt and a park was proposed in his memory, a stainless steel capsule containing memorabilia relating to the countrys 32nd president was buried Thursday in the four-acre Four Freedoms Park, which is scheduled to be completed next fall.

title: Go, Stop, Cringe: A Ferrari in the City
description: I USED to be scared witless to drive in New York City, and I considered myself a good driver too. I learned growing up in Boston, where people drove the way they do in Beijing now  regarding stop lights and one-way signs as optional advisories  and if you didnt have quick reflexes and eyes in the back of your head, you wound up riding home in a tow truck. So why did New York make me panic?

title: Q & A
description: No Chatting in the Lobby

title: Such Magnificent Beasts the Egyptians Made
description: In many ways the art of dynastic Egypt brought nature to a standstill, freezing the figure in an elegant, quietly pulsing suspended animation. Especially in its grandest, most monumental expression  the eerie, somnolent statues of the gods and of the pharaohs who were their earthly junior-god emissaries  Egypt offers us the sleekest, longest-running style in the history of art. It is also probably as instantly recognizable and firmly imprinted on human consciousness as any we know.

title: A Vast Museum That You Can Carry
description: Not all books have outlived their usefulness, but some have. The strictly informational kind, for example: does anyone buy dictionaries and encyclopedias in hard-copy form anymore? There was a run on the Encylopaedia Britannica after plans to cease printing paper editions were announced last month, but surely that had more to do with nostalgia than research needs.

title: A Portraits Long Fingers Suggest El Greco
description: Camilla Blaffer calls it her best find. A grimy old-master painting of a saint gazing upward, his hands crossed on his chest and a skull perched on a rock in the foreground. A friend of Ms. Blaffers bought the canvas, without realizing who painted it, on her behalf about 20 years ago at a small Paris auction. That canvas, along with hundreds of other artworks and decorative objects, languished in a warehouse outside Paris.

title: The Art of Remaking a Downtown
description: ORANGE

title: Selling Memorabilia of High-Flying Women
description: Nearly 10 percent of the 47 American women who have flown in space have died in the process, including four of the crew members on doomed space shuttles. Artifacts from female astronauts, dead and living, bring fairly high prices at auction because of their rarity.

title: Ruling Clears Way for Political Ads on Public Stations
description: Reversing a decades-old rule, a federal appeals court said on Thursday that public television and radio stations could not be prohibited from broadcasting paid political advertisements.

title: The Multilingual Pitch
description: A YEAR and a half ago, receiving ever more inquiries from overseas clients, Shawn Elliott, the broker/owner of Shawn Elliott Luxury Homes and Estates of Woodbury, added a translate tab to his Web site, shawnelliott.com, enabling visitors to view his listings in Mandarin, Cantonese, Korean, Russian, Spanish, Portuguese, Vietnamese, Japanese, Polish, French, Italian and German.

title: Preview: Richard Linklater's 'Bernie'
description: A clip from the coming film, starring Jack Black and Shirley MacLaine.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Emoticon History and Webby Nominees
description: Here are some of the most interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Thursday. There are more here.

title: How My Aunt Marge Ended Up in the Deep Freeze . . .
description: Bernie, the new film from Richard Linklater, the director of Dazed and Confused, is a dark deadpan comedy that Linklater has called his East Texas Fargo. It stars Jack Black as Bernie Tiede  a small-town funeral director beloved by nearly everyone in Carthage, Tex., sweet-natured and gregarious, a lover of show tunes and Jesus  who ends up murdering an ornery wealthy widow, played by Shirley MacLaine. Tiede stuffs her in a freezer, after shooting her four times in the back. Her frozen body stays there for nine months while Bernie spends a big chunk of her fortune, millions of dollars, on assorted good deeds and indulgences, buying the people of Carthage pretty much whatever they want  cars, Jet Skis, airplanes  and pledging a new wing for the Methodist church with hardly anyone bothering to ask where he got so much money.

title: The Bible Belt Goes to College
description: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

title: The Non-Hamptons Vie for Renters
description: AS temperatures heat up, so has the demand for summer homes in what some real estate agents call the non-Hampton Hamptons: Bedford, Pound Ridge and other semirural northern Westchester towns and villages with acres of open space and lots of greenery.

title: Taking Advantage of Elders
description: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: To the Editor: Regarding The Mystery of the Flying Laptop (April 8), my guess is that the T.S.A. logic dates from the days when laptops were thicker and the battery packs might, theoretically, have been replaced by explosives. This might explain why, at one point, they made passengers turn on laptops and phones to demonstrate they worked. However, both the shrinking thickness and lack of any evidence that anyone has been caught with a dangerous laptop render all this security theater moot. The absurd hysteria that has paralyzed the United States with fear since 9/11 is the source of this multibillion dollar waste of time, money and good sense. Norman McDougallThunder Bay, Ontario

title: The Turn in the Trayvon Martin Case
description: To the Editor:

title: 8th Ave. and 31st St., 1:44 p.m.
Training for the Jobless
description: To the Editor:

title: Executive Turntable: Universal Hires Former Warner Brothers Boss
description: Reorganizations of the major record labels over the last year or two have left the fates of a handful of top executives up in the air. One peg fell into place on Thursday when the Universal Music Group announced that it had made a deal for a new label with Tom Whalley, whose long rsum includes signing Tupac Shakur, Nine Inch Nails and the White Stripes.

title: Managing Pain
description: To the Editor:

title: Single Motherhood, Sitcom Style
description: Opens on Friday nationwide.

title: HBO Plans to Offer Free Access to a Pair of Comedies
description: HBO is demonstrating a lot of confidence in a pair of potential new hit comedies, and it wants to use them to seduce some nonsubscribers.

title: Mental Care for Children
description: To the Editor:

title: A Proposed Rule Seeks to Stop Runaway Cars
description: DETROIT  Federal safety regulators plan to require all new cars and trucks to have a brake-throttle override system, giving drivers the ability to step on the brake to stop the car if the accelerator pedal sticks or malfunctions.

title: Day 1 Aftermath: a $2,500 Fine and Acknowledging a Missed Call
description: It was a busy day at the N.H.L. office Thursday, as officials handled incidents from the opening games of the playoffs. It started with Brendan Shanahan, the league vice president for player safety, levying a $2,500 fine against the Nashville captain Shea Weber for slamming the head of Detroits Henrik Zetterberg into the glass in the Predators Game 1 win.

title: The Dawn of Egyptian Art
description: Images from a new exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: To Cut Health Costs, Can We Curb the Tests?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Good Life With Bad Choices
description: Opens on Friday in New York and Los Angeles.

title: At the Auto Show, Chevy Panders to the Pooches
description: On Wednesday, an unconventional breed of customer was welcomed at Chevrolets stand at the New York International Auto Show, for the brands commemoration of National Pet Day. Safety tips for pet travel were presented alongside the requisite car-buying advice at a media breakfast.

title: A Hate Crime, Solved Years Later
description: Opens on Friday nationwide.

title: Experts Share Tips for International Students Unable to Visit College Campuses
description: This is the time of year in which many colleges in the United States host campus visits, in the hopes that admitted applicants will get a better sense of the college environment and choose to enroll. This is much easier, of course, for students who are already in the United States. For international students, it is much more difficult to determine from afar which college atmosphere is the best fit.

title: Forced North by Drug Wars, but United in Exile
description: Juan Fraire Escobedos mother was gunned down in 2010 while protesting outside the state government offices in Chihuahua, Mexico, two years after his teenage sister was killed in Ciudad Jurez. Saul Reyes Salazar, a former city secretary in the nearby town of Guadalupe, buried six members of his activist family in three years. His nephew Jorge Luis Reyes, who was orphaned by the time he was 19, takes comfort in knowing where his mother is buried so he can leave flowers at her grave  if he ever steps foot in his native Mexico again.

title: Club Kids of Today Party With Their Predecessors
description: Opens on Friday in Brooklyn.

title: Review: In Detention, Horror, Comedy, Time Travel and Teenagers
description: Opens on Friday in New York, Los Angeles, Atlanta, Boston, Chicago, Houston, Miami, San Diego, San Francisco and Seattle.

title: North Korean Rocket Fails Moments After Liftoff
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea defied international warnings of censure and further isolation on Friday, launching a rocket that the United States and its allies called a provocative pretext for developing an intercontinental ballistic missile that might one day carry a nuclear warhead.

title: Musicians, Their Care and Feeding
description: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: Audits Find Flaws in Citys Property Assessments
description: The Bloomberg administration failed to warn homeowners about major changes in the way the city assessed the value of co-ops and condominiums, contributing to outrage over a sharp, unexpected spike in some peoples property taxes last year, according to a pair of audits released on Thursday by Comptroller John C. Liu.

title: E.P.A. Weighs Texas Plan to Cut Haze in National Parks
description: Last year, as wildfires raged in Texas, New Mexico and Arizona, visitors to Guadalupe Mountains National Park had to settle for a more limited view when hiking up Guadalupe Peak, Texas highest point.

title: Smokeless in Seattle
description: Seattle

title: Legislators With Benefits, Even When They Stray
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Jamaa Fanaka, Film Director, Dies at 69
description: Jamaa Fanaka, a filmmaker who had considerable success in 1979 with Penitentiary, a feature-length movie he made while still in film school, but who claimed to have been blacklisted afterward for raising questions about a dearth of jobs for black directors in Hollywood, died on April 1 in Los Angeles. He was 69.

title: Jane Taylor, Bassoonist of Dorian Quintet, Dies at 79
description: Jane Taylor, the founding bassoonist of the Dorian Wind Quintet, one of the premier ensembles to involve that uneasy alliance of flute, oboe, clarinet, French horn and bassoon, died on Sunday in Manhattan. She was 79.

title: The Myth of Sustainable Meat
description: Austin, Tex.

title: More On Safe Assets
description: So Brad and I are having an interesting discussion  not sure if it rises to the level of a debate  about whether were really suffering from a shortage of safe assets. Two points.

title: Mirkarimi Speaks Out, Citing Runaway Train of Innuendo
description: Two days before Ross Mirkarimi was sworn in as the new sheriff of San Francisco, reporters around town began receiving phone tips and text messages that the former city supervisor was being investigated by the police for alleged domestic violence against his wife. Within hours, Mr. Mirkarimi said, he was engulfed in a media storm based on myriad distortions that, he said, resulted in his suspension as sheriff and the possible end of his political career.

title: Baby-Sitting the Cook
description: Now that our boys are in school, our nanny has nothing to do for most of the day. So shes started cooking dinner for us. Sounds good, right? But I cant stand her food. She uses cheap ingredients and fillers; the meals taste bad and often give me stomach trouble. Shes also very sensitive, and if we dont clean our plates, the house fills with tension. My wife is thrilled with this arrangement and we really want to keep her. What should I do?

title: Looking for Signs That Its Meant to Be
description: BOB did not own a car. This approach to life might be reasonable in a city like New York, but it made him an oddball in Los Angeles, where prospective dates should be geographically convenient and should drive, if not a fancy car, then at least a reasonably comfortable one. Despite Los Angeless efforts to improve public transportation, dating usually requires some freeway driving. What kind of car one drives matters because much of the date will be spent in it.

title: Cuomo Acts to Advance Health Law in New York
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, stepping into the national debate over President Obamas health care law, used his executive power on Thursday to carry out one of its critical features in New York after the states Republican lawmakers blocked legislation to do so.

title: Consumer Bureau Declines to Resist Upfront Credit Card Fees
description: In one of the first tests of its willingness to show its muscle, the new agency created to protect consumers declined on Thursday to put up a fight.

title: Now the Playwrights and Artists Can Come Here
description: Walking into Berkeley Repertory Theaters rehearsal and office complex, on a nondescript street in West Berkeley, felt very different from the klieg lights of the companys downtown performance space.

title: How to Tell if the Iran Talks Are Working
description: AFTER a hiatus of more than a year, negotiations about Irans nuclear program are set to resume in Turkey on Friday between Iran and France, Germany, Britain, Russia, China and the United States. Though the participants foresee several rounds of discussions, all will be acutely aware that time to reach agreement peacefully may be running out.

title: In Brooklyn, a Guilty Plea to Aiding Terror
description: A Brooklyn man arrested last year as he was boarding an airplane destined for the Middle East admitted in court on Thursday that he had provided money to a terrorist group that he was traveling to join.

title: Town Mourns After Father and Daughter Are Killed in Bike Accident
description: As cars zipped along Treat Boulevard in the pouring rain Tuesday, a steady stream of people added flowers, teddy bears and personal notes to a sidewalk memorial for Solaiman Nuri and his daughter Hadessa.

title: An Overdose of Pain
description: Spain could be the next European economy brought down by German-led mismanagement of the euro-zone crisis. It need not turn out that way. But it surely will unless Chancellor Angela Merkel and her political allies inside and outside Germany acknowledge that no country can pay off its debts by suffocating economic growth.

title: For the Phillies, an Exchanging of the Guard
description: PHILADELPHIA

title: In Tight Race for Top Spot, Spurs Coach Prefers to Rest Aging Stars
description: SAN ANTONIO  When the Spurs traveled to Utah earlier this week to put their 11-game winning streak on the line, their lineup was lighter by 46.3 points a game, or their three leading scorers and most important players. Coach Gregg Popovich left Tim Duncan, Tony Parker and Manu Ginobili home.

title: More Evidence Against the Death Penalty
description: Connecticut is poised to become the 17th state without the death penalty and the fifth in five years to abolish it. Gov. Dannel Malloy is expected to sign the repeal bill approved by the Legislature in recent days.

title: Credibles Can Make Omelets for Years
description: Investors are often advised to avoid putting all their eggs in one basket. But in the Bay Area, a new investment model is being tested at the intersection of the Slow Food and Slow Money movements.

title: Sin of Omission
description: President Obama has signed many executive orders when Republicans in Congress persisted in blocking sound legislation. Yet he has inexcusably refused to issue an executive order banning discrimination by federal contractors based on sexual orientation or gender identity.

title: When Fists and Kicks Fly on the Subway, Its Snackman to the Rescue
description: The most enduring and useful custom of New York subway riders is that they don masks of stone at the turnstile, and keep them on until theyve gotten where they are going. The origins of this sound practice are beyond the memory of any living New Yorker, but even if it began with Peter Minuit, its value continues to be proved every day.

title: Gov. Christie and the Tunnel Project
description: If you find yourself in a stopped train in a Hudson River tunnel, or in a vehicle on a choked highway, in coming years, at least you will know why. In his drive to become the darling of the cut-costs-at-all-costs Republican crowd, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey ignored real economic analysis and relied on exaggerated worst-case scenarios to kill the largest public transit project in the nation in 2010.

title: For Vancouver, What Luongo Starts, Schneider Often Finishes
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Goalie Cory Schneider knows that his role with the Vancouver Canucks during the Stanley Cup playoffs is like a double-edged sword.

title: Long Losing Streak Hasnt Discouraged Lukas From Racing
description: HOT SPRINGS, Ark.  D. Wayne Lukas swings into the saddle as dawn creeps across the sky, the first one to the track every morning, a cowboy silhouette. Before long, Oaklawn Park will be buzzing with final preparations for the Racing Festival of the South and the Arkansas Derby.

title: Cannibalize the Future
description: One general rule of modern politics is that the people who talk most about future generations  who go around solemnly declaring that were burdening our children with debt  are, in practice, the people most eager to sacrifice our future for short-term political gain. You can see that principle at work in the House Republican budget, which starts with dire warnings about the evils of deficits, then calls for tax cuts that would make the deficit even bigger, offset only by the claim to have a secret plan to make up for the revenue losses somehow or other.

title: In Cash Push, 2 Campaigns Likely to Reject Public Funds
description: The big money in presidential politics is about to get a whole lot bigger.

title: Tax Face-Off: Romney vs. Me
description: Stubbornly, perversely, stupidly, I insist on doing my own taxes every year. I dont cut my own hair. I dont pickle backyard cabbage or home-school my kids. But I plow ahead with this most direct act of citizenship for one reason: if you want to understand power and influence in this country, you have to be familiar with the tax code.

title: For a Quickly Doomed Ship, a Very Long Afterlife
description: THE Titanic was a big ship. Its sinking, on its maiden voyage, was big news. So it may be fitting that many of the marketers and media companies commemorating the centennial of the disaster on Sunday are big, too.

title: A Leader of Schools Is Indicted for Fraud
description: When state investigators demanded last year to see personal tax returns filed by Eddie Calderon-Melendez, the founder and chief executive of a troubled network of charter high schools in Brooklyn, he produced them. One problem, according to the investigators, was that those state tax returns were falsified and had never been filed.

title: Sam Spade at Starbucks
description: If you attend a certain sort of conference, hang out at a certain sort of coffee shop or visit a certain sort of university, youve probably run into some of these wonderful young people who are doing good. Typically, theyve spent a year studying abroad. Theyve traveled in the poorer regions of the world. Now they have devoted themselves to a purpose larger than self.

title: The Odd-Man-Out Town House
description: THE accepted way to refer to a row of houses of two alternating designs is A-B-A-B-A. Sometimes the variations of longer rows make that A-B-C-D-A-B-C-D, which can wind up sounding like the opening of a Beethoven symphony.

title: Vitt, Facing Own Ban, Will Fill In for Payton
description: With Sean Paytons season-long suspension for his role in the New Orleans Saints bounty program starting Monday, the team took the first step toward moving on without him Thursday by naming the assistant head coach Joe Vitt as the interim coach. There is just one problem: Vitt must first serve a six-game suspension for his part in the bounty program.

title: Argentina Has Oil Firm in Its Sights
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The fate of Argentinas largest oil company, YPF, was thrown into doubt on Thursday as reports that President Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner was preparing to nationalize the company drew a warning from Spain that it would consider such a move a hostile action.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 12, 2012

title: In His Helicopter, Bloomberg Can Rule Skies, and Even Get to Albany
description: Among all the high-flying toys that a billionaire can buy, the futuristic AgustaWestland AW609 Tiltrotor, a hybrid helicopter-plane, is as coveted a trinket as they come. Forty people have lined up to buy the aircraft, which is modeled on the V22 Osprey used in the military. It maneuvers like a helicopter, but with the speed and altitude of a plane.

title: Luke Rodgers Isnt Giving Up
description: Deep in the heart of northern Europe there is an Englishman with dreams of returning to New York.

title: Must Be Prewar; Quirky Is O.K.
description: WHEN Savania Davies-Keiller and Michael Capotosto met through friends almost seven years ago, she was living in a sunny three-bedroom loft condominium in a 1910 TriBeCa building, formerly a printing warehouse, and he was living in a rented studio at London Terrace in Chelsea.

title: Whistle-Blower Claiming Visa Fraud Keeps His Job, but Not His Work
description: It has been 17 months since Jack B. Palmer first made a quiet complaint through internal channels at Infosys, the giant Indian outsourcing company he works for, saying he suspected some managers were committing visa fraud. Since then, Mr. Palmer says, he has been harassed by superiors and co-workers, sidelined with no work assignment, shut out of the companys computers, denied bonuses and hounded by death threats.

title: Greeces Right-Wing Fringe
description: As Greece reels from deep austerity cuts and prepares for elections, some ultranationalist groups like the Golden Dawn Party are appealing to increasingly insecure voters.

title: Red Sox Pick Up Right Where They Stumbled Off
description: BOSTON  The calendar says that the home opener for the 2012 Boston Red Sox will be played on Friday the 13th. In a sense, thats perfect.

title: Hard Times Lift Greeces Anti-Immigrant Fringe
description: ATHENS  On a recent morning in the upper-middle-class neighborhood of Papagou here, members of the Greek ultranationalist group Golden Dawn stood at an outdoor vegetable market campaigning for the coming national elections.

title: Are Elections Too Much Like Musical Chairs?
description: Economic conditions alter the outcomes of presidential elections, but economic conditions during certain time periods matter much more than others. Economic voters are short-sighted, it turns out, and their myopia makes American electoral accountability surprisingly haphazard.

title: Pakistan Gives U.S. a List of Demands, Including an End to C.I.A. Drone Strikes
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  In a rare show of unity, the government and opposition joined on Thursday to present the United States with a list of stringent demands, including an immediate end to C.I.A. drone strikes, that were cast in uncompromising words but could pave the way for a reopening of NATO supply lines through the country.

title: Murder Aside, China Inquiry Puts Couples Wealth on Trial
description: BEIJING  What began as a scandal involving the mysterious death of Neil Heywood, the British businessman whose body was found in November in a Chongqing hotel room, appears to be evolving into a broader investigation into the wealth of a politically powerful Chinese couple, Bo Xilai and his wife, Gu Kailai, and their financial interests.

title: Laying Bare the Broken Shards of Their Families
description: The Civilians, the enterprising troupe specializing in documentary theater drawn from interviews, takes its tape recorders back to the family living room in You Better Sit Down: Tales From My Parents Divorce, which opened Thursday night at the Flea Theater. The four performers in this modest but engaging collage of reminiscences portray their own parents  mostly their mothers  in conversations about their marriages, all past history, as the title makes clear.

title: Siblings Divided by Familiar Yet Formidable Walls
description: Just listen to them. Thats the implicit request made, rather shyly at first, by A Slow Air, David Harrowers quietly moving new play. But its not long before that request has assumed the clout of an irresistible command. And you think, But how could I not listen?

title: Sweet Ending
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Well, its Friday, which is date night in some circles. Some couples might get dressed up, head out for a nice meal and perhaps take in a film together. But Tim Croce has other ideas.

title: With Eight Games Left, Knicks Questions Abound
description: Lounging at his locker stall in Milwaukee late Wednesday  shirtless, arms folded, his feet soaking in a bucket  Carmelo Anthony was a picture of mid-April contentment.

title: Serene, for All Its Hip-Hop Cred
description: SINCE 1962, Anita Fridays home on 205th Place has provided her a vantage point for the waves of change that have come in succession to Hollis, her familys corner of Queens. At the start the population was predominantly white, said Ms. Friday, 80, who is black, and who recalled that over her first decade as a resident, most of her white neighbors moved away to Long Island.

title: Living In | Hollis, Queens
description: A largely working-class community in Queens with detached single-families, punctuated by a few apartment buildings and attached houses.

title: With Tweaks, Quinns Living-Wage Bill Aims Lower
description: Early this year, Christine C. Quinn, the speaker of the New York City Council, held a news conference at City Hall to announce that she had resolved one of the most contentious issues to face the Council during her six-year tenure  a proposed law that would raise the wages of workers in developments subsidized by the city.

title: Election Is a New Start for an Aide to Mubarak
description: CAIRO  Omar Suleiman, Egypts former spy chief and briefly its vice president, had all but vanished from the scene. Since surrendering power to a council of generals on behalf of President Hosni Mubarak more than a year ago, Mr. Suleiman, 74, had appeared in public just once: on the ritual pilgrimage to Mecca that Muslims are asked to complete before they die, being pushed in a wheelchair.

title: In Connecticut Vote, Death Penalty Critics Dont See Major Shift
description: There were references to being a tipping point and reflecting a paradigm shift in the use of capital punishment when the State House voted this week to make Connecticut the 17th state  the 5th in five years  to eliminate the death penalty in future prosecutions.

title: Vaccinations Begin in a Cholera-Ravaged Haiti
description: A year and a half after cholera first struck Haiti, a tiny portion of the population on Thursday began getting vaccinated against the waterborne disease that has infected more than 530,000 Haitians and killed more than 7,040.

title: Rangers Open Playoffs With a Powerhouse Display
description: There were no jitters. No letdowns. There was a stretch when they were back on their heels, but they survived that hiccup.

title: Lundqvist Sets the Stage by Standing His Ground
description: On Wednesday, Henrik Lundqvist brushed aside fears of a Sports Illustrated cover jinx, pointing out that the Masters champion Bubba Watson was on the front of most editions of the magazine. On Thursday, Lundqvist kicked aside, trapped and gloved almost every puck the Ottawa Senators sent his way.

title: Deal to Curb Isolation of Mentally Ill Inmates
description: BOSTON  A federal judge on Thursday approved a settlement meant to guarantee alternatives to segregation for mentally ill inmates in Massachusetts prisons.

title: On the Market in the Region
