description: A five-bedroom midcentury house in Westport, Conn., and a three-bedroom condominium in Nyack, N.Y.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: An Upper East Side co-op, a Gramercy area co-op and a Park Slope duplex.

title: Corrections: April 13
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Rangers-Senators Replay: Game 1
description: The Rangers defeated the Senators, 4-2, in the first game of their first-round playoff series at Madison Square Garden.

title: U.S. Judge Rejects Officers Lawsuit on Quotas
description: A federal judge on Thursday dismissed a lawsuit that accused a Bronx police precinct of using a strict quota system for arrests and of punishing an officer who complained about it, rejecting the officers argument that he was protected under the First Amendment.

title: Trade, Energy and Drugs Are Topics for Obama at Summit of the Americas
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Friday heads to Latin America for the third time for a summit meeting whose very location  Colombia  reflects the broader economic and security gains in the hemisphere.

title: Clouds on Solars Horizon
description: Late Wednesday night, BrightSource Energy, a start-up formed to build solar thermal power plants, was forced to make a humbling admission: Despite a year of hopes and efforts, it could not find the market it wanted for its stock. The company canceled its initial public offering of shares just hours before trading was to begin.

title: Devils Unite Under First-Year Coach
description: NEWARK  Since Martin Brodeur made his N.H.L. debut on March 26, 1992, the Devils have made 15 head-coaching changes, or about one every 16 months. Jacques Lemaire has held the job three times, Larry Robinson and Lou Lamoriello twice each.

title: Special Parking Rules in New York City
description: Alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Friday and Saturday because of Passover and Orthodox Good Friday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: State of Florida vs. George Zimmerman
description: Affidavit of Probable Cause

title: Fitness Fever, With You in Mind
description: THE search for a healthy lifestyle leads New Yorkers to many places. They hit the gym, run and bike in Central Park and along the Hudson, down protein drinks and shop for organic everything.

title: Opposition Finds Apathy Over Election in Russia City
description: ASTRAKHAN, Russia  Yulia Morozova did not vote for Oleg V. Shein, the opposition politician who has waged a four-week hunger strike to protest alleged ballot fraud in last months mayoral election here. But Ms. Morozova once worked at a polling station and said she did not trust the election results  no matter who was declared the winner.

title: Slow First Quarter in China, but Recent Signs of Growth
description: Chinas economic growth slowed sharply in the first three months of this year, but recent efforts by policy makers to jump-start its economy, the worlds second largest, appear to be already bearing fruit, with industrial and retail activity both rising during March, new data released on Friday showed.

title: A Test Kitchen for Design
description: IN her 15 years as a practicing architect, Kimberly Peck has amassed an eclectic portfolio. Her creations range from a 68th-floor apartment on Central Park South, dressed in jewel-tone colors, to a house in an upstate New York dairy community, population 633, using the frame of a 19th-century barn. And when you poke around the Web, you also discover that as an architecture student at Virginia Polytechnic Institute, Ms. Peck wrote her thesis on what she beguilingly describes as the table landscape.

title: Wright Can Play if He Can Take the Pain
description: Mets third baseman David Wright is off to a fast start this season, 7 for 12 at the plate for a .583 batting average. And in 66 career games at Citizens Bank Park in Philadelphia, where the Mets play this weekend, he has hit .281 with 15 home runs.

title: 50 Years at the Mike for the Mets
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Ralph Kiners 50-year career as a Mets announcer started with a bang in 1962. During his first postgame show, Kiners guest was Casey Stengel, the omnipresent manager of the fledgling Mets who could fill an entire show with tales tall and small.

title: Buyer Confidence: Portent or Blip?
description: MORE than 200 people showed up for an open house at a town house in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, last month, and the crowd, filled with stroller-pushing parents and young children, was so lively that an ice cream truck pulled up to join the happening.

title: Julia Louis-Dreyfus: A Very Large Head
description: Part 13: The actress explores the history of Elaines hair on Seinfeld.

title: Julia Louis-Dreyfus: The Mee-Ow Show
description: Part 4: The actress recounts how she was cast on Saturday Night Live right out of college.

title: Julia Louis-Dreyfus: A Seinfeld Curse
description: Part 8: The actress talks about what it was like to be the first female cast member to return as a host on Saturday Night Live.

title: Julia Louis-Dreyfus: Elaine Benes
description: Part 6: The actress recounts how she and her iconic Seinfeld character became publicly intertwined, and recalls when she realized Seinfeld had become a hit.

title: Julia Louis-Dreyfus: Making Veep
description: Part 10: The actress explains why the process of making Veep was a completely unique experience, even to a veteran television actress.

title: Julia Louis-Dreyfus: Not a Great Look
description: Part 7: The actress tells the story behind her famous Seinfeld dance, and explains why she now hates dancing.

title: Julia Louis-Dreyfus: I Was Horrible
description: Part 5: The actress recalls her experience on Saturday Night Live, where she started as a 21-year-old.

title: Julia Louis-Dreyfus: Disappointing Woody
description: Part 12: The actress tells the story of how she blew the single scene she had in Hannah and Her Sisters.

title: TimesTalks | Julia Louis-Dreyfus Preview
description: The actress discusses her iconic and award-winning comedic roles on Seinfeld and Veep.

title: Julia Louis-Dreyfus: Vincents Picks
description: Part 15: The actress discusses her own political activism and talks about what her sons think of her comedy.

title: Julia Louis-Dreyfus: Being Selina Meyer
description: Part 2: The actress discusses what attracted her to the title role in Veep, and explains why the vice presidency is a ripe subject for comedy.

title: Julia Louis-Dreyfus: Cornstarch Utensils
description: Part 3: The actress talks about how the experience of making Veep, a single-camera comedy, differed from her work on multi-camera sitcoms like Seinfeld and The New Adventures of Old Christine.

title: Julia Louis-Dreyfus: Having Said That
description: Part 9: The actress describes what it was like playing herself on Curb Your Enthusiasm.

title: Julia Louis-Dreyfus: Its Not a Parody
description: Part 11: The actress talks about her character on Veep and the great separation between her and the president on the show.

title: Julia Louis-Dreyfus: Intro
description: Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks, introduces the actress Julia Louis-Dreyfus.

title: Julia Louis-Dreyfus: He Vas My Boyfriend
description: Part 14: The actress recalls the comic actresses who influenced her the most growing up.

title: Yankees Face Unknown on Friday the 13th
description: The Yankees are the most successful franchise in professional sports, having won 27 World Series championships. But the team may be tempting fate by having its home opener on Friday the 13th. Never before, in a history that dates to 1901, has the franchise opened at home or on the road on that date.

title: Obamas and Bidens to Release Tax Returns
description: WASHINGTON  Punctuating a week of political assaults on Mitt Romney over taxes, President Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. plan to release their own income tax returns on Friday, along with a statement calling on Mr. Romney to do the same, according to an Obama campaign official.

title: Once Taboo, Germans Anti-Israel Whispers Grow Louder
description: BERLIN  To judge by the outpouring of comments from politicians and writers and from the newspaper and magazine articles in response to the Nobel laureate Gnter Grasss poem criticizing Israels aggressive posture toward Iran, it would appear that the public had resoundingly rejected his work.

title: South Sudan: Border Tensions Increase
description: South Sudan said Thursday that it was prepared to withdraw from the contested city of Heglig, which it captured from Sudanese forces this week, under certain conditions, but that it was also prepared to send its army back to Abyei, another contested city along the border. The minister of information, Barnaba Marial Benjamin, echoing statements by President Salva Kiir, said South Sudan cannot talk about withdrawal unless contested regions were demilitarized and international observers were put in place. Until then, Mr. Marial said, South Sudan would remain in Heglig, an oil-rich city that both Sudan and South Sudan claim and Sudan has controlled since 2005. But South Sudan has accused Sudan of using contested border regions as a springboard for attacks on its territory. Since their split last year, the two sides have been caught in a dispute over a host of issues, including citizenship, the demarcation of the border and how to share the Souths oil. On Thursday, the United Nations Security Council demanded a complete, immediate and unconditional end to all fighting between Sudan and South Sudan.

title: Yankees Are Bracing for the Power of Pujols
description: As a member of the St. Louis Cardinals, Albert Pujols, one of baseballs most dangerous and captivating hitters, played in only four games at the old Yankee Stadium: an interleague series against the Yankees in 2003 and then the 2008 All-Star Game.

title: Myanmar: Dispute Over Oath of Office
description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyis party said Thursday that it was negotiating with the government to change the oath of office for lawmakers because it contravened the partys official platform. Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi and 42 other members of her party, the National League for Democracy, won seats in Parliament in landmark elections on April 1. The victory was a major step toward reconciliation between the democratic movement and the military-backed government. But the party now says it objects to a part of the oath of office that commands lawmakers to protect and safeguard the countrys Constitution. Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi has repeatedly said some articles in the Constitution are undemocratic, including a provision that one quarter of the seats in Parliament are reserved for the military, and the party wants to amend the document.

title: In Newark, Mayor Saves a Woman From a Fire
description: Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark carried a woman out of a burning house and was treated for smoke inhalation on Thursday night.

title: Pennsylvania: Bomb Threats Continue After Arrest
description: The police at the University of Pittsburgh have arrested a New York man on charges of making terrorist threats to four professors, but he was not charged with making more than 60 bomb threats that have caused major disruptions across the campus since mid-February. The man, Mark Lee Krangle, 65, of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., a graduate student at the university in the mid-1970s, was arrested as he stepped off a plane at Pittsburgh International Airport on Wednesday, university officials said. The bomb threats, however, continued Thursday morning, causing hundreds of students to be rousted from dormitories, libraries and classrooms. No devices have been found.

title: All Aboard the Rangers Train
description: Amid the hustle and bustle of the New York City subway system, a train wrapped from top to bottom in Rangers red and blue is causing some passengers to stop in their tracks.

title: Ecuador: Failing Universities to Close
description: The police and education officials on Thursday moved to shut down 14 universities that the government determined did not meet basic academic standards. The schools, with a total of about 38,000 students, were on a list of failing universities, sometimes called garage universities because of accusations of their low quality. The move is part of a broad effort to improve higher education by President Rafael Correas government. The government said it would take a year to close the schools, allowing about 10,000 students who are in their final year of studies to graduate. Most of the remaining students would be given the chance to transfer to other academic programs.

title: On American Idol, a Shock and Then a Save
description: American Idol viewers proved this week that they are anything but predictable and that the best singers do not always win the popularity contest. The viewers voted to eliminate not only Jessica Sanchez, who has consistently been one of the most impressive performers on the show, but also the other two singers in the bottom three were Joshua Ledet and Elise Testone, who turned in powerhouse performances this week.

title: Luke Askew, Character Actor, Is Dead at 80
description: Luke Askew, a character actor perhaps best remembered as the wayward stranger who brings Peter Fonda and Dennis Hopper to a hippie commune in the 1969 motorcycle odyssey Easy Rider, died on March 29 at his home in Lake Oswego, Ore.He was 80.

title: Signs Europe Bending on Airline Carbon Fee
description: The European Union, heading for a trade war over a new toll on the greenhouse gas emissions of international airlines using European airspace, has been warned that the measure could wreck the prospects for global action on climate change, Harvey Morris writes in the International Herald Tribunes Rendezvous blog.

title: An Agonizing Life in Limbo for the Infosys Whistleblower
description: It has been 17 months since Jack B. Palmer first made a quiet complaint through internal channels at Infosys, the giant Indian outsourcing company he works for, saying he suspected some managers were committing visa fraud, Julia Preston writes in The New York Times. Since then, Mr. Palmer says, he has been harassed by superiors and co-workers, sidelined with no work assignment, shut out of the companys computers, denied bonuses and hounded by death threats.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,915 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Iran, the United States and a Political Seesaw
description: Far from a monolithic relationship, Iran and the United States have spent as many decades as friends as they have as enemies.

title: Stiff Sentences for 2002 Killings
description: A court on Thursday sentenced 18 Hindus to life imprisonment for killing 23 Muslims in Gujarat State in 2002 during Indias worst sectarian violence in recent years, The Associated Press reports. Five others were sentenced to seven years in prison.

title: Comolli Out at Liverpool After Getting the Numbers All Wrong
description: Theres a scene in Moneyball that depicts the Boston Red Sox and Liverpool owner John W. Henry in a discussion with Oakland As General Manager Billy Beane high above Fenway Park. Beane, played by Brad Pitt, has been summoned to meet with Henry after building a winning team with an unfashionable franchise based on statistical data ignored by everyone else; that system came to be known as Moneyball.

title: Amid Mass Protests, Syrian Cease-Fire Is Tested by Reports of Clashes
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrians by the thousands marched through the streets of cities and towns across the country on Friday, testing a tenuous, day-old cease-fire that the United Nations struggled to shore up when the rapid deployment of international observers snagged on Russian objections.

title: On the Bus, Away From the Pack
description: Eric Thayer, 37, has been covering the Republican nominating contest almost nonstop since last July in Iowa. He has mostly photographed for The New York Times but has also worked for Reuters in New Hampshire and South Carolina.

title: Off To Pomona
description: Very early, as you can see, to talk macro. Slides for the talk (pdf).

title: Delhi Tries to Lure Voters for City Elections
description: When Delhis polls open on Sunday for municipal elections, will the turnout be any better than last time?

title: First Generation Chronicles Students Difficult Path to College
description: The college admissions process can be confusing on its own, but the missteps are multiplied, it seems, when a young applicant looks around and can find no relatives whove ever been through it.

title: The Early Word: Big Money
description: In Todays Times:

title: Is There a Republican Alternative to Obamacare?
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

title: Reconnecting Through Art
description: At the Rubin Museum of Art in Manhattan, David Rosenberg, a guide, stood before a stone piece depicting a six-armed figure. Now, what would be a good reason to have six arms? Mr. Rosenberg asked his audience, a half dozen or so elderly adults with dementia and their caregivers.

title: Study Abroad, Mormon Style
description: Mormon college students pause their studies to serve in missions. Its a real education.

title: Greg Childs, Fifth-Ranked Receiver in 2012 Draft
description: Matt Waldman is the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, a testament to his obsession with film analysis, now available for download.  Examples of his work can be found at his blog. He is helping The Fifth Down rank skill position players before the draft:

title: At Age 19, From Utah to Uganda
description: LAST summer, Jared Dangerfield was simply 19, skateboarding the streets of suburban Salt Lake City, plugged into the Jewish reggae singer Matisyahu. He had just wrapped up his year at Utah State University, where there was a girl he liked to make laugh.

title: Rocket Failure May Be Test of North Korean Leaders Power
description: SEOUL, South Korea  For the new North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, the spectacular failure of a rocket meant to put a satellite into orbit was more than a $1 billion humiliation. It could be the first test of whether anyone will dare challenge his rule, and raises the question, American officials said, of whether he will be tempted to recover by staging a larger provocation.

title: Q&A: Removing Yourself From YouTube
description: Q.

title: Setting the Tone for Tenniss Much Bigger Stars
description: Professional tennis is, at its core, a selfish pursuit, but Ivan Ljubicic, who is about to play his last tournament, has done his part to make it less so.

title: Coupon Deals and the Search for New Customers
description: A few weeks ago I wrote a post about two small businesses that were taking different approaches to employing Groupon-style social-network marketing as a way of drumming up business.

title: JPMorgan Chases Earnings Beat Expectations
description: 9:03 a.m. | Updated

title: Morning Take-Out
description: JPMorgan Chases Earnings Beat Expectations | Kicking off a series of earnings reports from the nations biggest banks in the coming days, JPMorgan Chase said Friday that it earned $1.31 a share in the first quarter of 2012, compared with $1.28 a share in the same period a year ago. On a reported basis, revenue rose 6 percent, rising to $26.7 billion, from $25.2 billion.

title: Daily Report: Google Announces 2-for-1 Stock Split
description: Google may have had a challenging first three months of the year from a public relations standpoint, with government officials and ordinary users alike troubled by the companys new privacy policy, David Streitfeld writes in The New York Times on Friday. But its financial results, reported on Thursday, were another matter, as the company largely rebounded from a weaker previous quarter.

title: Opinion Report: Cutting Costs
description: From the editorial page

title: The Importance of Being Earnest
description: Take him and cut him out in little stars! Jessica Chastain fairly shouts, re-enacting her interpretation of Juliets famous monologue, the bold gambit that got her admitted to the Juilliard School a decade ago. Most people do it so precious and sweet, a girl just married, but she is going to be a woman, and he shall die means orgasm! It was crazy. I was on the ground by the end of the audition. When I finished, the admissions panel was like, Who is this little redheaded girl coming in here?

title: Wells Fargo Profit Rises 13%, as Revenue Increases
description: Wells Fargo, one of the nations largest consumer lenders, posted a 13 percent increase in first-quarter profit on Friday, the latest in a series of upbeat report cards for the bank.

title: For Obama, Going Positive May Be More Difficult This Time
description: President Obamas campaign has left no doubt about how it intends to run against Mitt Romney, portraying him as a bazillionaire elitist and conviction-free flip-flopper who has allied himself with the Republican Partys most extreme positions.

title: Channeling Iran in the High-Stakes Nuclear Talks
description: ISTANBUL  Lets play devils advocate and consider what Iran might want to say as it heads into talks in Istanbul this weekend with leading world powers that are intent on curbing its nuclear ambitions.

title: An Ineffectual Start for Elder Sister
description: NEW DELHI  When Mamata Banerjeedefeated the Communist Party of India (Marxist) last May after 34 years of power in West Bengal, her victory was portrayed by optimists as the beginning of a Kolkata Spring. Free of the communists rural thugs and urban heelers, the story went, the state would finally enter the 21st century.

title: Antiques Roadshow
A Georgian Olive Branch
description: TBILISI, Georgia  Visitors dont have to look much farther than Georgias largest ski resort, Gudauri, to see evidence of this small nations shifting policy toward Russia.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Back to the 50s in Politics, and Chris Nolan on Shooting in Film
description: Politico says it has found a thread in the Obama campaigns framing of its expected opponent, Mitt Romney: comparing him to Don Draper of Mad Men. Not the drinking, womanizing or even charisma of Draper, Politico is quick to point out, but rather, in Democrats eyes, as a hopelessly retro figure who, on policy and in his personal life, is living in the past.

title: New Share Class Gives Google Founders Tighter Control
description: Google may have the motto dont be evil. But it is certainly not a democracy.

title: Where Amish Snowbirds Find a Nest
description: FROM December through April, Amish travelers pack charter buses making overnight runs from Ohio to Florida. Stiff black hats are gingerly stowed in overhead bins as the bus winds its way through hilly farm country, making pickups in small towns with names like Sugarcreek, Berlin and Wooster.

title: Behind the Scenes of the Julia Louis-Dreyfus Photo Shoot
description: For the photo illustrations for this weeks profile of Julia Louis-Dreyfus, we asked Louis-Dreyfus to channel Audrey Hepburn  but with a twist. Youll notice that in each of the three film publicity stills we recreated  from Funny Face, Breakfast at Tiffanys, and Charade  something is awry. The idea was to put Louis-Dreyfus in these iconic poses that she (comically) cant quite pull off.

title: Morning Buzz, April 13: Opening Day in the Bronx
description: Good morning. Expect another sunny, at times windy, day with highs in the mid 60s.

title: S.& P. 500 Suffers Biggest Weekly Decline of the Year
description: Stocks fell on Friday, giving the Standard & Poors 500-stock index its biggest weekly decline of the year, as consumer confidence dropped, Chinas growth slowed and the cost of insuring against a Spanish debt default rose to a record.

title: Former Manager Is Convicted of Harassing Leonard Cohen
description: Everybody knows its not uncommon for fans of Leonard Cohens to become fixated on him and his romantic if sinister music. But a jury has decided that a former business manager of that Canadian singer-songwriter harassed him by sending him hundreds of e-mails and voicemail messages that at times left him feeling threatened, The Associated Press reported.

title: What Were Reading
description: The Village Voice: The sudden weekend warmth in New York should be a fine excuse to get your summer drink on. Robert Sietsema lists his five favorite margaritas around town.  Patrick Farrell

title: A Conversation With : The Meadow Author Adrian Levy
description: Adrian Levy is co-author of The Meadow, a newly released book about the 1995 kidnappings of six foreigners in Kashmir and the aftermath. He and Cathy Scott-Clark, both veteran journalists, also have written books about Russian artwork, Pakistans nuclear weapons and jade.

title: Friday Reading: States Seek To Limit Patients Drug Bills
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Fill in the Blank: Being a Reporter Is the ______ Job in the World
description: This week, we learned a few things about being a reporter that seem to suggest that the craft, as currently situated, is an unhappy piece of work.

title: Newark Mayor Speaks About Fire Rescue
description: Updated, 10:18 a.m. | Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark held a 10 a.m. news conference to talk about how he saved a neighbor from her burning home Thursday night.

title: In The Meadow, a Chilling Alternate View of the 1995 Kashmiri Kidnappings
description: In the summer of 1995, six foreign tourists were kidnapped in a meadow in Kashmir by a group calling itself Al Faran.

title: Even the Three Stooges Needed Second Fiddles
description: Disparage the Three Stooges if you must, you cineaste. Dismiss their films with a weary wave of your smoldering Gauloise. But give them this: Moe, Larry, Curly and Shemp inhabited a world entirely their own, a surreal place where cream pies could fly, and hammer blows to the head never drew blood.

title: Image of the Day: April 13
Renting a Giant Rat
description: Dear Diary:

title: Leading Off: The N.H.L. Goes Long
description: If the N.H.L. is good for anything  aside from its cottage industry in defining which skull-rattling hits are dangerous and which are just boys being boys  it is good for taking up time. Yes, it has a season that is best measured by the geologic time scale. Yes, its playoffs are so long the Stanley Cup champions have no idea whom they played in the first round. And so, on the second day of the playoffs, why not have four overtimes?

title: The Game Is Called Chicken
description: From Matt Bais article, we learned that the two parties leaders can get within a few hundred billion dollars of a nearly $3 trillion deficit deal. But we also learned that, even if one of those leaders (President Obama) were to concede the entire amount of that difference (i.e., rolling his revenue demands back from $1.2 trillion to $800 billion), the other leader (John Boehner) still couldnt sell it to his own team. Which means we didnt actually end up within a few hundred billion dollars of a deal. We ended up pretty much where we started: With one side absolutely refusing to raise even a minuscule amount of revenue and the other side willing to do trillions in cuts as long as it got some new revenue in return, but never getting it. Unlike Bai, I see little grounds for optimism here.

title: The Real Oil Shock
description: When Adam Davidson writes, In Europe, where taxes keep gas prices well above $5 a gallon, citizens are more likely to take public transportation and live near the center of town, what hes doing is expressing a real let them eat cake attitude. Outside the downtown areas of a handful of huge cities, Americans have very little access to public transportation. Europeans are more likely to take public transportation because nearly the entire map of Europe is served by affordable, clean and safe public transportation that runs frequently.

title: To Mooch or Not to Mooch?
description: A colleague recently took a business trip to Manhattan that was paid for by the organization we work for, an underfinanced nonprofit. There was construction at her hotel, which understandably affected her comfort. She complained and was offered three free nights for a subsequent visit. She hasnt told our supervisor, but she wants to use the credit for a weekend away with her husband. I feel she should offer the credit to our employer. We face serious budget constraints and could use the free stay on another business trip. NAME WITHHELD

title: I Was 18 and Pregnant
description: When I was 18 and about seven months pregnant, I bumped into a friend of my mothers at the clinic. Tante Safi was Egyptian  like my mother  and had lived in America for more than 20 years. I called her Tante, French for aunt. She had struggled with cancer for as long as wed known her.

title: The Incredible Shrinking Childhood
description: The fixation on a cure for early puberty makes an already uncomfortable time in a girls life infinitely more fraught. I had my first period at 10, and when I told my mother, she collapsed on the bed, sobbing: My baby is going to be short and fat. Short and fat! My body-mass index placed me on the extreme low end of overweight. What followed were two years of bone scans, forced physical activity, a strict diet and endless scrutiny of my bodys changes. No attempts were ever made to make me feel that puberty was normal, because my parents were very clear that my puberty was abnormal. In the long run, I turned out utterly normal (and taller and thinner than average), but I didnt feel comfortable in my own body until years after I no longer stood out as precociously mature.

title: Pump It Up
description: Oil, that is. Texas tea.

title: The Soft Middle of Franois Hollande
description: Even after a precampaign diet last year  less wine, less cheese and especially less chocolate  Franois Hollande, the Socialist who is currently favored to become the next president of France, still has a soft face and looks slightly sloppy in his medium-gray suits. He used to be referred to as Flanby, after a brand of wobbly caramel pudding, just one of a string of insulting nicknames for a convivial man considered always at the second rank of politics. He has been called a living marshmallow and Mr. Little Jokes, and just last year, Martine Aubry, the head of the Socialist Party, described him as a couille molle, a nasty way of saying he has no guts. Recently, a frustrated Nicolas Sarkozy, fighting hard to be re-elected, fumed: Hollande is useless! Hes useless, do you understand?

title: Who Made That Stiletto?
description: The ancient Greeks depicted Aphrodite in elevator shoes. Centuries later, Venetian courtesans clopped around in towering chopines, while during the reign of Louis XIV, red heels were a mark of nobility. But it was after World War II that the stiletto took hold. Soldiers who spent years abroad dreaming of high-heeled pinups, one historian wrote, came home to wives whose wartime work required more sensible shoes. As women returned to domestic life, higher heels could, and did, become all the rage. From the 1950s froth of experimentation, the stiletto was born.

title: The Second Shelf
description: To the Editor:

title: Paperback Row
description: A MOMENT IN THE SUN,  by John Sayles. (McSweeneys, $18.) With its political intrigue, fraught romances and life-threatening adventures, Sayless vast historical novel recalls both Harriet Beecher Stowe and Thomas Pynchon. The book opens in 1897, during the Klondike gold rush, and closes in 1903, the year after the Philippine-American War ended. In between, Sayles takes the measure of America from the perspectives of Western ramblers, war profiteers, black soldiers and Filipino insurgents.

title: Why French Parents Are Superior (in One Way)
description: Consider this: Our children are three times more likely to be overweight than French children. In fact, we lead the world in producing overweight children, but the French have one of the lowest rates of overweight children in the developed world.

title: Editors Choice
description: TIME TO START THINKING: America in the Age of Descent,  by Edward Luce. (Atlantic Monthly, $26.) To restore its waning competitiveness, America will need a much more effective federal government, Luce, a British journalist, warns.

title: Resting Places
description: One of the first things to strike you about Michael McGriffs work is that its populated: his poems have people in them. What strikes you next is that the citizens of McGriffville are mired in various stages of desperation.

title: Once More, With Feelings
description: For a while, we heard everywhere F. Scott Fitzgeralds pronouncement that there are no second acts in American life. We took it for the notion that youth was everything  you made it while you were young or not at all  but it primarily applies to Fitzgerald himself. By 1934, when Dick Diver appeared in Tender Is the Night, the stock market had crashed, the expatriate rich seemed beside the point and the beautiful young writer had only six years to live. He died at 44  a kid! His American life didnt get a second act.

title: The Iron Lady and the Gipper
description: In 1950, a 24-year-old industrial research chemist named Margaret Roberts stood unsuccessfully as a Conservative candidate in the British general election. We believe in the democratic way of life, she told the voters. If we serve the idea faithfully, with tenacity of purpose, we have nothing to fear from Russian Communism.

title: Executive Overreach
description: Some readers will come to Rachel Maddows first book expecting an entertaining left-wing screed against the military. They may be surprised to discover instead a lively but serious argument about American history.

title: Trench Poet
description: It has never been easy to follow Hamlet quite as far as he would like to go  as far, even, as the undiscovered country from whose bourn / No traveler returns. Just ask Horatio, who tries to prevent his reckless friend from chasing Old Hamlets ghost at the beginning of Shakespeares tragedy and who counsels an intellectual restraint toward its end as the two confront mortality itself in the graveyard. When Hamlet, contemplating Yoricks skull, attempts to trace the noble dust of Alexander to the cork that seals a cask, the prudent Horatio admonishes,  Twere to consider too curiously to consider so.

title: Under Siege
description: Children in Reindeer Woods, the first of the Icelandic writer Kristin Omarsdottirs novels to be translated into English, is an assured introduction to her work. In Lytton Smiths translation, its tone is placid throughout, a smooth skin that stirs only slightly, for laughters sake or to tremble in anticipation of violence.

title: Whos There?
description: Americans have developed a peculiar reverence for the concept of reality. We use the term to legitimize all manner of sleazy entertainment, and to judge our political leaders, whose capacity for being real is apparently measured by their willingness to drink beer with us. Of course, this bias has long informed our literary tradition, in which realism signifies authenticity and adulthood, the normative and hallowed province of James, Hemingway and Carver. Depart from it at your peril, ink-stained wretches, for a conveniently labeled ghetto awaits you  experimental, fabulist, surreal  all terms that signify, in the popular imagination anyway, artifice, obscurity and a kind of childish indulgence.

title: Goldmans Blankfein Collects $12 Million
description: Compensation for the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, Lloyd C. Blankfein, fell roughly 35 percent to $12 million in 2011, in a year when the companys stock tumbled 46.2 percent.

title: A Missionary Impulse
description: The Jews are like rats, Peter Beinarts grandmother told him when he was a boy. We leave the sinking ship. This grandmother  who was born in Egypt and lived in South Africa but dreamed of joining her brother in Israel  believed that Israel was the last refuge of a hounded people, and she made Beinart, who was born in the United States, believe it, too.

title: Breadwomen
description: Five or six years ago, my mother and I sat in a darkened theater talking about a couple we knew. The wife was an executive with Ivy League degrees. The husband had some nebulous part-time job, but mostly he stayed home with the kids. What, I wondered, does he have thats attractive to her? There was a pause. Sperm, my mother replied.

title: 100 Years at Sea
description: Centenaries are often just a dusting off and reassessment of faded historical memory. But 100 years after the Titanic sank in the North Atlantic, it is remarkable to contemplate how little the ship has drifted from public consciousness. Schoolchildren the world over still recognize the luxury liners name thanks to a centurys worth of books, articles, films and deep-ocean exploration. The interrupted stories of those who died on its voyage, however, and the troubled post-disaster lives of those who survived, are less well known. Two new books attempt to fill that void. Yet like the crew members who ushered the wealthy into the lifeboats first, these narratives favor first class over steerage.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: NO ONE  By Gwenalle Aubry.Translated by Trista Selous.  Tin House, paper, $12.95.

title: Dreams of Youth
description: Lynda Barrys excitable, bittersweet cartoons and collages are practically a cultural fixture, like little black dresses or The Simpsons. So its a welcome surprise to discover she actually had a formative period. BLABBER BLABBER BLABBER (Drawn & Quarterly, $24.95), the first volume of a projected complete-works series called Everything, compiles Barrys early comic strips, drawn circa 1980, when she was still groping toward her sensibility and developing her recurring characters. Still, theres not a lot you could call juvenilia here, beyond a pasted-in 1972 drawing of a creature emerging from a can of tomato monster soup (captioned I drew this in the ninth grade and felt incredible afterward)  except in the sense that her mature work aspires to be juvenilia, to extract nervous comedy and pathos from the way young people explain the world to themselves.

title: Big Jewels!
description: With heavyweight roles and gems to match, the brightest actresses from across the pond prepare to dazzle. Go to our interactive feature >>

title: Romney vs. Romney
description: Its unlikely that Mitt Romney saw the film The Graduate when it appeared in 1967. He was a 20-year-old Mormon missionary in France at the time, isolated from the cultural influences that shaped most Americans of the baby-boom generation, and his taste in movies ran to more wholesome fare like The Sound of Music. If he had seen it, though, one doubts that he would have scoffed along with his contemporaries during the scene in which a smarmy businessman declares that the key to the future is plastics. He might have considered it useful career advice.

title: My Life With Bob
description: With no small amount of trepidation, I lay open here the first page of my diary  high-schoolish stabs at intellectualism, fleeting girlish obsessions, deliberately obscure annotations and all. After many failed adolescent attempts at keeping a journal, the summer after my junior year in high school, I finally found a format I could adhere to: Never mind describing the back-and-lack-of-forths of unrequited crushes and falling-outs with friends. I decided to list the books I read instead.

title: Plans for The Elevens, a Member-Owned Restaurant, Are Still in Limbo
description: It was called The Elevens, and it was a shimmering dream: a sort of fusion of a utopian culinary community and Cheers bar. But now its opening has been delayed, and its owners have had to reconsider its central concept: a self-financed community of drinkers and diners.

title: After Rescuing Woman From Fire, a Mayor Recalls His Fear and Focus
description: There was a moment, Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark said Friday, when he thought we were not going to make it.

title: Business Day Live | April 13, 2012
description: Looking at earnings in the financial sector; Ron Lieber interviews Scott Griffith, chief executive of Zipcar; and on credit card fees, a test of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau's power.

title: Candor and Celebration on North Korean TV After Failed Rocket Launch
description: As my colleagues Choe Sang-hun and Rick Gladstone report, hours after a North Korean rocket disintegrated within minutes of launching on Friday, the countrys state media took the unusual step of admitting the failure.

title: Morning Walkabout: 4/13
description: Getting Blown Away, Literally The airport on the Caribbean island of St. Maarten is mere yards away from a strip of beach, making takeoffs a tourist attraction. But a YouTube video that has attracted more than four million views shows a woman who got too close being blown by a planes exhaust into a concrete barrier, despite warning signs. Airport officials now say they will increase security measures. (USA Today)

title: Making Spinach the Star of the Meal
description: Many people serve spinach as a side dish, but in this weeks Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman offers five new ways to serve spinach as the main course.

title: Believe Charter Network Founder Indicted
Minorca Revealed
description: What does a 270-square-mile biosphere look like? Take a tour of Minorca.

title: Off the Coast of Spain, a Tranquil Biosphere Reserve
description: MINORCA, the first place in Spain to see the sun rise, is aglow at the end of the day. As I pulled my suitcase down the cobbled, car-free lanes of Ciutadella, the islands ancient capital, an ocher glow bloomed across the faces of residents who sat on the terraces of back-street bars, their voices echoing within a canyon of Gothic and Baroque buildings.

title: Book Review Podcast
description: This week, Michael Kranish and Scott Helman discuss their biography of Mitt Romney; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Jeremy Denk talks about the sounds of nature; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: Obama, Like Buffett, Had Lower Tax Rate Than His Secretary
description: WASHINGTON  For months, President Obama has marveled that the billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett pays a lower tax rate than his secretary, citing it as an egregious example of an unjust tax code. It turns out that another famous and well-compensated American does, too: Mr. Obama.

title: The Munchkins Are a Problem: Hearts and Courage
In Defense of an Accused Teacher
Weekend Fare
description: The wichcraft ice cream kiosk reopens for the spring and summer on Friday from 2 to 4 p.m. in Bryant Park, north of 40th Street and east of Avenue of the Americas. A scoop of ice cream or an ice cream sandwich will be handed out free.

title: Times of London Sued in Hacking Scandal
description: LONDON  As Britains hacking scandal shows little sign of easing, a high-profile London lawyer who has been closely involved in pursuing cases involving Rupert Murdochs British tabloids said on Friday that his firm was suing the upmarket Times of London over e-mail hacking for which the newspaper has apologized.

title: Mammoth Lakes, Calif., Faces Bankruptcy
description: MAMMOTH LAKES, Calif.  It was a seemingly perfect day at this ski resort town high in the Sierra Nevada this week, one that could have redeemed the seasons poor snowfall under brighter circumstances. Families here on spring break were enjoying the slopes or shopping at the luxury outlet mall. Some stocked up at the Vons supermarket for dinner, while others braved the half-hour waits at the towns popular restaurants.

title: Inside the List
description: LOVE, NIA: There are two phone calls parents dont ever want to get from their children, the writer Adriana Trigiani once said. No. 1 is: Im in prison. Come fetch me. And No. 2 is, Ive written a novel . . . and its set in your hometown.  As far as I can tell Trigiani has never done time, unless you count writing for TV (she worked on The Cosby Show and other sitcoms), but she did set her first three novels in the Blue Ridge Mountain town of Big Stone Gap, Va., where she grew up. Since then she has frequently turned to her Italian-American heritage for material; her 12th novel, The Shoemakers Wife, which slides onto the hardcover fiction list at No. 5, is based on the lives of her immigrant grandparents. A couple of years ago, in a conversation with the novelist Lauren Baratz-Logsted, Trigiani said she is sometimes mistaken for the actress Nia Vardalos, who wrote and starred in My Big Fat Greek Wedding. Once on a plane, she said, a lady asked for my autograph. I said, Im not her. And she went back to her seat and halfway through the flight, she came back with a napkin, and she said, Either sign this or Ill tell the entire plane who you are and youll have to sign all the napkins. So, I signed, Love, Nia Vardalos, on the napkin.

title: Obamas and Bidens Release Their 2011 Tax Returns
description: The White House released on Friday the presidents and the vice presidents 2011 state and federal income tax returns.

title: Magic Fingers
description: Theres really no logic, says Peter Philips, Chanels creative director for makeup, explaining how he dreams up nail colors that regularly achieve mythic status before they even hit store counters. I observe and listen to women, and then I follow my heart and my guts. Its not a factory. Im not a chicken that lays an egg. I just try to seduce women into discovering something they want. Because if they dont like it, they wont wear it. Philips is obviously on to something, because Chanels nail polish sales have grown in the United States by 84 percent in the four years since he joined the brand.

title: Trial Starts in Plot Against Danish Paper Over Cartoons of Prophet
description: STOCKHOLM  Four men went on trial in Denmark on Friday on charges of plotting a shooting spree in late 2010 at a Danish newspaper that published cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad, with prosecutors suggesting they intended to focus on the defendants links to Pakistan.

title: Ford Tries to Save the Lincoln Brand
description: Ford Motor, alone among Americas Big Three automakers, staved off bankruptcy and survived the financial crisis. Its sales, profit and stock price have surged. Now it faces what may be an even tougher challenge: Can it save its faltering Lincoln brand?

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $13,000,000
description: A three-story Park Avenue town house never publicly listed for sale has changed hands for $13 million, making it the most expensive transaction of the week, according to city records.

title: Russian Lender Building Its Own Bloc in Eastern Europe
description: MOSCOW  The motto of the Russian state-owned bank Sberbank is always nearby. Its branches, adorned with a cheery green-and-white logo, are truly ubiquitous in its home market.

title: Poland Trying to Build Banks' Defenses
description: The Polish authorities say they are open to an inflow of Russian capital, even if they are doing what they can to bolster Polish banks against Russian takeovers.

title: Shumpert Is Old School, and in a Good Way
description: J.R. Smiths heroics were enough to lead the Knicks to what could prove to be the most crucial win of the season, a 111-107 victory over the Bucks onWednesday.

title: Despite Good News, U.S. Bank Stocks Fall
description: Congratulations to JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo for beating estimates. Yet, those earnings reports werent enough to prevent a sagging in bank stocks on Friday.

title: Mayor Cory A. Booker's Press Conference
description: Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark spoke to the press the morning after saving his neighbor from a burning building.

title: Weighing In on Consumer Agencys Action on Upfront Card Fees
description: Updated: Friday, 6:40 p.m. to add bureau comment.

title: The Great Locomotive Chase
description: For Confederates, the quickest connection across the Appalachian Mountains, which roughly split the eastern and western theaters of the war, was a railroad line from Richmond, Va., to Chattanooga, Tenn. From Chattanooga other lines fanned west and south toward the Mississippi and the Gulf of Mexico. Consequently, the Mountain Citys strategic significance was far greater than its population of just 2,500 people might lead one to believe.

title: A To-Do List for the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau
description: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau released preliminary plans this week to require banks to improve their mortgage servicing and become more open and accountable in their dealings with consumers.

title: On the Lens Blog: On the Bus, Away From the Pack
description: Eric Thayer, 37, has been covering the Republican nominating contest almost nonstop since last July in Iowa. He has mostly photographed for The New York Times but has also worked for Reuters in New Hampshire and South Carolina.

title: Editors Letter
description: Sometimes it takes a little while for a great actress to find her footing as a star. How could it be otherwise? When one earns ones living and professional acclaim by being an uncanny chameleon, it is a difficult trick to step unmasked into the bright light of fame. For Jessica Chastain, our cover girl, the path from critics darling to world-class celebrity has been one she has trod, in my view, with care and grace. When, in February, she walked the red carpet at the Oscars in a strapless embroidered gown by Sarah Burton for Alexander McQueen, she announced herself as being far more than a thespian able to portray anyone in any era for any auteur. (Her slate of releases is staggering.) I love that she chose McQueen for such a moment, that she understood how extraordinary fashion could be an entirely natural partner in the project of self-definition. Chastain is a great beauty and a terrific talent and, as Lynn Yaeger reveals, a lovely young woman on the verge of a major career.

title: Why Are Charter Schools Exempt from Bullying Law?
The New Republic Hawks Access to a Once in a Lifetime Dinner
description: The New Republic on Friday evening canceled its planned lottery to attend theWhite House Correspondents Association Dinner, after being told that it violated the associations rules. For more details, click here.

title: BET Plans a Late-Night Satirical News Show
description: Add BET to the list of channels who will be competing in late-night television.

title: Expanded Drawing Center to Reopen in September
description: The Drawing Center will reopen on Sept. 13 after a yearlong expansion, Brett Littman, the executive director announced on Friday.

title: Unseen Guides Silent Journeys to Lyric Nature
description: FOR decades Nathaniel Dorsky has been making work of rare and sometimes startling beauty. If you havent heard of him, its because he makes short, silent experimental films that feature brightly colored flowers, bursts of sunlight and shifting pools of shadow instead of characters, plots and stories. Mostly he remains unknown to the larger audience because his work is relegated to that ghetto known as American avant-garde cinema. On Monday a program of his recent work will be shown in downtown Los Angeles at Redcat, an exhibition space in Walt Disney Concert Hall; Mr. Dorsky, who talks about his work in accessible, charming fashion, is scheduled to appear in person. On Friday another program of his work will be at the UCLA Film & Television Archive, also in Los Angeles.

title: Wars: Imagined and Real
description: Politicians are always declaring a war on something. Often the conflict is entirely in their imaginations like the War on Christmas and the War on Religion. Sometimes its a label designed to lend a sense of urgency to a problem they are not going to fix  like the War on Poverty and the War on Drugs.

title: TimesCast | April 13, 2012
description: President Obamas tax returns become a political weapon | The 100th anniversary of the Titanics sinking.

title: A New Oversight Panel on Fracking
description: In an effort to streamline federal regulation of the domestic natural gas boom, President Obama on Friday announced creation of an inter-agency task force to ensure what he called the safe and responsible development of domestic natural gas resources.

title: General Motors Recalls 50,000 Crossovers for Windshield Wiper Flaw
description: 5:23 p.m. | Updated

title: Introducing By the Book
description: At his book signings and readings, David Sedaris, the author of many best-selling books, frequently promotes the work of other writers, telling audience members what hes been reading recently and heartily recommends.

title: Time for Some Garden Work: Redesign Planned at Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum
description: A cloistered garden at the historic Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston will be redesigned by the landscape architect Michael Van Valkenburgh, the museum announced on Friday.

title: The Danger of Flying While Khan
description: Shah Rukh Khan, Indias Tom Cruise, got detained at an American airport.

title: From an Early Adopter to a Social Media Star
description: ROMANY MALCO was doing a live comedy show online, playing Tijuana Jackson, a prison-hardened life coach, when the phone rang. Mr. Malco was in the middle of a dark bit, in which Tijuana tells a story about being molested as a child. I know it sounds crazy and horrible, but people would bust up when I would tell this story, he said.

title: China Says It May Reduce Role of Foreign Firms in Surveillance
description: BEIJING  The Chinese government, citing security concerns, has signaled that it may scale back the role that foreign companies play in the countrys fast-growing video surveillance industry.

title: Business Day Live: Car Sharing
description: Looking at earnings in the financial sector; Ron Lieber interviews Scott Griffith, chief executive of Zipcar; and on credit card fees, a test of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureaus power.

title: Journalists Invited to Pyongyang Are Scooped by Rocket Launching and Failure
description: More than 50 foreign journalists accepted coveted invitations to North Korea this week for the gala celebrations exalting the centenary of the countrys deceased founder Kim Il-sung, the ascension of his grandson Kim Jong-un to the top leadership posts and, perhaps most alluring, the launching of a multistage rocket that North Korea had said would triumphantly place a satellite into orbit.

title: Your Suggestions on Force-Placed Insurance
description: Paul Sullivan, in his Wealth Matters column this week, returns to a subject he has discussed before  force-placed insurance. That is hazard, flood or wind insurance that a mortgage lender buys for the homeowner at a price that is almost always higher than the market rate.

title: A World of Troubled Beauty
description: THE sheer beauty in Michael Glawoggers trilogy of documentaries showing people at work across the globe can be startling. Whether its a scene involving an Indian dye worker coated head to toe in ochre, a voluptuous Mexican stripper turned into a touchable goddess by mesmerized men, or a roiling open-air slaughterhouse in Nigeria, Mr. Glawoggers spectacles can induce in viewers awe at the visuals, surprise at the intimate access to exotic lives, and perhaps a vague sense of guilt. You might wonder: Is this for real, and is it O.K. to like it?

title: How Green Are Electric Cars? Depends on Where You Plug In
description: ITS a lot like one of those math problems that gave you fits in sixth grade: a salesman leaves home in Denver and drives his electric car to a meeting in Boulder. At the same time, a physicist driving the same model electric car sets out from her loft in Los Angeles, heading to an appointment near Anaheim.

title: Japan Seeks to Restart Some Nuclear Power Plants
description: TOKYO  Hoping to avert potentially devastating summer power shortages, Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda said Friday that his government would seek to restart two nuclear reactors, in what would be a first step toward ending an almost complete shutdown of the nations nuclear power industry.

title: Concern Raised Over Painkillers Use in Sports
description: When Mets pitcher R. A. Dickey partly tore the plantar fascia in his right foot last May, he turned to a treatment that in recent years has become a go-to elixir for professional baseball and football players: Toradol, an injectable anti-inflammatory drug.

title: Why Hopkins-Maryland Always Matters
description: BALTIMORE  When the Johns Hopkins University mens lacrosse team takes the field Saturday, it wont be just another game for the Blue Jays. It wont be just another meeting of top-ranked teams or just another rivalry game at historic Homewood Field. When Hopkins greets the University of Maryland at center field for the opening face-off  the surrounding grandstands appropriately divided between Hopkins light blue and Terrapin red  its never just another battle. Its a lacrosse war.

title: Chris Barley and Marc Kushner
description: DURING a summer internship in 2007, Chris Barley thought that he had found a mentor in the architect Marc Kushner. Both were 6-foot-4, dapperly handsome and from religious families.

title: Saints Owner Agrees to Buy Hornets
description: Tom Benson, the owner of the New Orleans Saints, agreed on Friday to buy the citys N.B.A. franchise, theHornets, for $338 million from the league.

title: Wheelies: The Repeal Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Meanings in the Market
description: MONEY isnt everything.

title: Behind the Poster: A Streetcar Named Desire
description: The latest Broadway revival of A Streetcar Named Desire, Tennessee Williamss 1947 classic play about sex, booze and betrayal set in an apartment in the French Quarter of New Orleans, is mostly faithful to the original. But there is one very big twist this time around: the cast is multiracial. The production, from the producers of the all-black 2008 revival of Williamss Cat on a Hot Tin Roof, stars Nicole Ari Parker as Blanche and Blair Underwood as Stanley, with Daphne Rubin-Vega as Stella and Wood Harris as Mitch. It is now in previews at the Broadhurst Theater.

title: Robert Duffy Brings Marc by Marc Jacobs to Las Vegas
description: Robert Duffy, the president of Marc Jacobs, opens the Marc by Marc Jacobs store in Las Vegas today at the Forum Shops at Caesars Palace. The new boutique, the companys second at Caesars (a Marc Jacobs collection shop opened in the Palace last year), will, like all great Marc by Marcs, stock a number of exclusive, location-themed accessories. Among them, playing cards ($10), one-of-a-kind sterling silver cuffs ($245) and belt buckles ($295) that look like they came straight from the rodeo show. To celebrate the grand opening, T asked Duffy for his tips on where to go and how to win in Sin City.

title: Flamenco, and Food, in Madrids Retiro Park
description: Now through the summer, visitors to Madrid can see first-rate Spanish dance and flamenco performed Wednesday through Sunday nights at the 540-seat, Florida Park theater in elegant Retiro Park. Before and during the performances, full-course dinners, tapas meals or simply drinks are available, depending on how much one wants to indulge.

title: From the Broncs to Coney, New York as a Scrabble Board
description: In the battle of the boroughs, its Queens, 15; Manhattan, 14; and Brooklyn, the Bronx and Staten Island with zero; at least when it comes to Scrabble.

title: Renewed Europe Worries Sap Deal-Makers Confidence
description: LONDON  Deal-making in Europe remains a tough sell.

title: Bridal Hunger Games
description: JENNIFER DERRICKS weight had crept to 159 pounds from 125, and she knew she would not fit into her grandmothers wedding dress.

title: New Woody Allen Film, Set in Rome, Draws Some Grumbling There
description: ROME  After London, Barcelona and Paris, Woody Allens newest tribute to a European capital, To Rome With Love, had its premiere here on Friday. But the amorous sentiment may not be requited judging by the grumblings of some Italian journalists and film critics at a crowded post-screening news conference.

title: Carbon In, Carbon Out: Sorting Out the Power Grid
description: Electric car mile-per- gallon equivalent in the United States.

title: After an Excellent Season, Some Questions for Minnesota
description: The University of Minnesota mens hockey team was picked to finish sixth out of 12 teams in its conference before the season  in the end it made it to the Frozen Four.

title: Yankees Adjust Order: Rodriguez Bats 3rd, Cano 4th
description: Manager Joe Girardi is tinkering with the Yankees lineup after only six games of the 2012 season. But it is not because of anyones early struggles, he said.

title: Parental Quandary: When Young Boys Joke About Rape
description: Two readers wrote to me recently with similar quandaries: young sons, around middle-school age, uncomfortable with the language thats beginning to surround them at school.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: The Latest Drops of God
description: There are seven new titles on the manga list this week. Most of them are fairly deep into their stories. At No. 1, for example, is Volume 8 of Season 2 of Rosario+Vampire, about a high school where the student body is comosed of werewolves and vampires. At No. 2 is Volume 39 of Bleach, whose main character can see spirits and helps usher them into the afterlife. And at No. 3 is Volume 27 of the romance Skip Beat! Im more likely to pick up Volume 3 of The Drops of God, which enters our list at No. 6 this week. The series, by Tadashi Agi and Shu Okimoto, centers on the son of a famous wine critic who must identify 12 wines to claim his inheritance. I included Volume 1 in our Holiday Gift Guide last year.

title: Louvre Teams Up With Nintendo for New Guides
description: PARIS  Who says video games and high art dont mix? The  Louvre this week offered a new fleet of interactive guides using the Nintendo 3DS, the handheld gaming devices, and featuring audio commentary about more than 700 sculptures and paintings along with three-dimensional models and high-definition photographs of several works.

title: Rose Terrible but Bulls Beat Heat Anyway
description: Picture this scenario: Miami is playing Chicago, a pre-playoff glimpse at the Eastern Conferences top teams. The Bulls Derrick Rose, the leagues reigningmost valuable player, is shooting terribly, missing 12 of 13 shots and scoring a career-low 2 points.

title: Learning to Run a Business by Running a Business
My Three Favorite Romney Spoofs of This Election Cycle
description: O.K., so we now know that in purportedly private moments, Mitt Romney talks about things like his wifes dressage horse. Laugh if you must. While he may not inspire all segments of the Republican base, Romney has truly overachieved when it comes to offering material to comedians. We did some Romney-parodying of our own in the magazine this weekend, with a new screenplay by Etan Cohen, imagining a conversation between Romney and Newt Gingrich. But theres so much more out there. Here are my favorite Romney spoofs of this election cycle.

title: American Idol and Touch Get Ratings Boost on CBS Repeats Night
description: A full slate of repeats on CBS allowed the other broadcast networks to gain some ground in the ratings on Thursday. Fox was by far the No. 1 network for the night, according to Nielsen data, as both American Idol and Touch received a bump in viewership from last week. They finished with 15.3 million total viewers and 8.2 million, respectively.

title: Seven on Seven Collaborators Discuss the Meeting of the Digital and Art Worlds
description: Seven on Seven, an annual contemporary-art-meets-technology summit that has attracted some big names from both the art and tech worlds since its founding in 2010, will have its third incarnation on Saturday at the New Museum in Lower Manhattan. The event, founded by Rhizome, the new-media art organization in New York, actually begins a day earlier, when seven artists and seven people from the world of the digital revolution, meet for the first time and pair off. Then they sequester themselves, reality-show-style, in rooms around the city for a single day of collaboration, trying to hatch a project that might look like art, an app or something else that defies easy classification, playing around in what Robert Rauschenberg called the gap between art and life.

title: A Dance-Heavy Coachella Begins in the Desert
description: INDIO, Calif.  This years edition of the three-day Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival begins on Friday, to run through Sunday. It has changed in at least one respect that the average festival-goer will barely notice: the entire lineup will repeat one week later, with identical order and set times. Both weekends have sold out; attendance is expected at around 75,000 per weekend.

title: Romney Warns Gun Lobby of a Second Obama Term
description: ST. LOUIS  As he works to energize the conservative base ahead of the general election, Mitt Romney came to the annual gathering of the National Rifle Association on Friday seeking support from a powerful group that has not always embraced him.

title: Fatal Collision Makes Car-Sharing Worries No Longer Theoretical
description: Last month, I wrote about RelayRides, a company that helps you rent your car to strangers. Its a big enough idea that the company has attracted investments from Google and General Motors.

title: RelayRides, Insurance and a Fatal Crash
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I explore the implications of a fatal accident that occurred when a renter at RelayRides, a car sharing company, had a fatal accident using someone elses personal vehicle that left four other people injured.

title: Want to Read Cuomos Story? Biographers Will Offer Options
description: The latest genre in book publishing appears to be biography of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.

title: Former Analyst Pleads Guilty in Dell Insider Trading Case
description: A former research analyst pleaded guilty to criminal charges in an insider-trading case that federal prosecutors have described as a circle of friends who together earned about $62 million in illegal gains in Dell stock.

title: Coming Soon: Taxmageddon
description: WASHINGTON

title: TimesCast | Zimmerman Appears In Court
description: April 12, 2012  After being charged with second degree murder in the killing of Trayvon Martin, George Zimmerman made his first court appearance Thursday afternoon.

title: As Nuclear Talks With Iran Restart, New Hopes for Deal
description: ISTANBUL  Diplomats gathered here on Friday for talks with Iran about its nuclear enrichment program, with European officials suggesting that a serious commitment from Iran to negotiate may be enough to continue the talks at another round in late May.

title: Google Ad Project Updates Classic Alka-Seltzer and Avis Pitches
description: A project by Google to reimagine classic advertising campaigns from the 1960s and 1970s for contemporary sensibilities  and technologies  is proceeding with work for two additional brands.

title: Live Analysis: Yankee Stadium Opener  Yankees 5, Angels 0
description: Justin Sablich, with the help of his Times colleagues, is covering the Yankees home opening game against the Angels live from Yankee Stadium. Continue reading for live updates and analysis.

title: Fivestory, a New Midtown Boutique, Chooses Carefully
description: On Thursday afternoon, Fred Distenfeld looked unfazed and spotless in his suit as workmen carried slabs of polished stone into the town house at 18 East 69th Street. On April 19, it will open as the boutique Fivestory.

title: Posada Throws Ceremonial First Pitch, to His Father
description: Jorge Posada watched his former teammate Andy Pettitte halt a one-year retirement to return to the Yankees last month. Now that Posada, the former catcher, is retired after 17 seasons with the club, he joked that he must wait a year, as Pettitte did, before he considered a return.

title: How Old Is the Fire Stone?
description: Ken Angielczyk, an assistant curator at the Field Museum of Natural History, is searching for fossils of ancient mammal relatives in northeastern Brazil.

title: Eyewitnesses to Mayor Booker's Rescue
description: Eyewitnesses recount Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark's rescue of  a neighbor from her burning home on Thursday night.

title: Dueling Pencils: 4 Firms to Compete for Project at Menil Collection in Houston
description: Four architecture firms will compete to design the first major building project under the Menil Collections long-range plan to improve its campus in Houston, Josef Helfenstein, the museums director, announced on Friday.

title: DeBoer: Popular With Devils, Less So With Panthers
description: As the Devils begin their series against Florida, it seems that both sides are happy that Peter DeBoer is the Devils coach.

title: In Brooklyn, a Tree for the Hopeful
description: For a few brief hours, a wish tree flourished in Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn, and the hopeful and the heartbroken pinned their desires to an English elm. Peace. Get the job. I wish my son wouldnt use drugs. I wish my wife would love me. All written on strips of ribbon and thumbtacked to the trunk. Then the parks department got wind of it. Soon, there was only one wish left. Read more on The Local

title: U.S. Condemns Prison Term for Ukraines Ex-Defense Chief
description: MOSCOW  The United States Embassy in Ukraine on Friday condemned as politically motivated the imprisonment of a former defense minister allied with Yulia V. Tymoshenko, the former prime minister whose own imprisonment has provoked an international outcry.

title: Sizing Up the Impact of Tax Cuts (and Their End)
description: Without the Bush tax cuts of 2001, 2003 and 2008 and the Obama tax cuts of the last few years, median after-tax household income would be about $1,750 a year lower than it is. All of those tax cuts, of course, face an uncertain fate, because they are scheduled to expire at the end of this year.

title: Ignoring College Rankings to Find My No. 1 School
description: Where did senior year go? I feel like someone pressed a fast-forward button from August to April. I blinked, and my college application process was over  except for the decision.

title: Book Review Podcast: The Unspoiled Sounds of Nature
description: In the New York Times Book Review, Jeremy Denk reviews The Great Animal Orchestra, the musician and naturalist Bernie Krauses new book about what can be heard in the worlds truly wild places, where human noise has not changed the soundscape. On YouTube, you can hear audio clips to accompany the book, like water sounds and fire sounds. Theres also a clip available of Mr. Krause explaining how the bursting cells of a tree make a kind of music, which one commenter on YouTube says sounds like Aphex Twin. Mr. Denk writes:

title: DealBooks Week in Review: Awash in Cash
description: We examined Facebooks $1 billion deal for a mobile start-up, Microsofts $1 billion deal for patents and a $2.15 billion lawsuit waiting to happen. A look back on our reporting of the last weeks highs and lows in finance.

title: Wavii: A Facebook for Topics
description: Facebook has transformed how we keep tabs on friends, by training people to constantly publish short status updates about the delicious meal they just ate or the killer vacation they just took. A site called Wavii opened to the public earlier this week that wants to do the same thing for topics, with short bursts of news on everything from corporate acquisitions to celebrities.

title: Seventh Avenue and 53rd Street, 11:41 A.M.
Bob Lutz, Design Critic? Grading the Ex-G.M. Executive on His Latest Gig
description: Robert A. Lutz, the former vice chairman and product czar of General Motors, has been peripatetic in retirement, taking on advisory roles for Lotus, G.M. and the electric truck and van start-up Via Motors, in addition to writing a book, Car Guys vs. Bean Counters: The Battle for the Soul of American Business. As a columnist for Forbes.com, Mr. Lutz recently assumed the mantle of design critic, discussing the front ends, or faces, of recently unveiled cars, including several from the current New York auto show.

title: Reasons to Be Sent to the Principal's Office
A Rsum Centering on Latin Jazz, With Interests That Include Cultural Fusion
description: The emblematic tune in Yosvany Terrys early set at the Jazz Standard on Wednesday night was the closer, Summer Relief, a slippery bit of cultural cross talk. It began with a Yoruba chant by the conga player Pedro Martnez, in a call-and-response with the band. A groove materialized, in irregular polyrhythm, and then came a coiled melody assigned to Michael Rodriguez on trumpet and Mr. Terry on alto saxophone.

title: Brushstroke Adds a Sushi Bar, and a Chef
description: Eiji Ichimura (above), who owned Ichimura on the Upper East Side before it closed in 2008, is now the sushi chef at Brushstroke, one of David Bouleys restaurants in TriBeCa.

title: Painting a New York Everyman
description: Moses is described in the Torah as the most modest man who ever lived. My father was the second most. He thought of himself, and wanted others to think of him, as simply ordinary. Perhaps that inspired me to often depict him as Everyman.  Max Ferguson

title: A Decision on the Bahrain Grand Prix  Oh, and Theres a Race in China Too
description: SHANGHAI  Until todays first practice sessions for the Chinese Grand Prix, the talk in Shanghai had not been about the race here at all, but about whether the Bahrain Grand Prix  the race scheduled after this one  would take place. Finally, after a day and a half in Shanghai, all the various stakeholders are agreed: Bahrain will happen.

title: TimesCast | Presidential Tax Returns
description: April 13, 2012 - The White House strategically releases President Obama's tax returns.

title: Meyer Defends His Tenure at Florida
description: Months before Urban Meyer can coach his first game with the Ohio State Buckeyes, he had to play some defense.

title: New Figures Stoke the Home Inequity Debate
description: A little more light is being shed on a type of loan that has been stinking up bank balance sheets.

title: The Matzo Economic Miracle
description: For this weeks Its the Economy column, Adam Davidson and I visited two of the leading matzo manufacturers in the country. We learned a few things about the matzo business. First, kosher laws make matzo-baking a total pain in the tuchus. Second, that can be good for business. After all, the complexity of kosher laws could scare off potential competitors.

title: Spring Staples | Twinkle Toes
description: Seasons change and so must accessories.

title: TimesCast: Presidential Tax Returns
description: The White House strategically released President Obamas tax returns. Richard W. Stevenson reports.

title: Photo Replay: April 13
description: The Grand National horse racing meeting continued in Aintree, England, and the world fencing championships took place in Kiev, Ukraine.

title: TimesCast | A Grandmother's Survival
description: Jim Dwyer, Metros About New York columnist, spoke with the New York City Council Speaker Christine Quinn about her grandmothers escape from the Titanic.

title: Lefties Arent Special After All
description: Amsterdam

title: Diamonds as a Commodity
description: Could diamonds be the new gold?

title: Dont Kill the Electric Car
description: My article in the Automobiles section on Friday addressed the question of electric-vehicle greenhouse-gas emissions.

title: Erik Larson to Write Book on Sinking of the Lusitania
description: Just as the publishing industry has finished marking the 100th anniversary of the Titanics sinking with dozens of related books, at least one publisher is looking ahead to another anniversary: the sinking of the British ocean liner Lusitania by a German U-boat during World War I. Crown Publishers, part of Random House, said on Friday that it had acquired a nonfiction book by Erik Larson, the author of The Devil in the White City, that will offer a fresh take on the sinking.

title: Has Motherhood Replaced Sexism?
description: Officially conceded, after the commentary on yesterdays post regarding Hilary Rosens description of Ann Romney as never having worked a day in her life: the mommy wars between (some) stay-at-home mothers and (some) mothers who work outside the home are still raging.

title: In 3-D: How Mariano Rivera Dominates Hitters
description: Mariano Rivera is one of the best closers in the game, thanks in part to a cutter pitch that leaves his hand much like a fastball but crosses the plate very differently.

title: Holland Tunnel Inbound to Shut Overnight
description: Ever get the urge to re-texture a tunnel roadway?

title: Bachata Royalty, Long-Haul Rapper, Australian Brats
description: Vena

title: A Nomadic Life Has Roots in Jazz
description: LISTEN to this, the pianist Kirill Gerstein said, clicking play on his iPhone. The recording, a synthesizer track that approximated the sounds of a piano and a vibraphone, was a rough demo for The Visitors, a work the jazz pianist Chick Corea had written for Mr. Gerstein and his former mentor the vibraphonist Gary Burton.

title: Mitch Petruss Newest Groove
description: As Mitch Petruss role with the Giants increased during the 2011 season, he found it more and more difficult to find time for his other passion: his alt-rock band, known as Vikings of the North Atlantic or VONA.

title: The Chic, Lethal Salons on the Screens of France
description: PARIS

title: Was Hilary Rosens Remark About Ann Romney Witless?
description: Several readers have objected to my calling Hilary Rosens comments about Ann Romney witless. They seem to think Ive joined Republicans in expressing faux outrage.

title: Ringing Voice and Guitar Echo Globally
description: CALL it double exposure. Folila, a new album by Amadou & Mariam, the blind husband-and-wife duo from Mali, was recorded twice, once in New York with an all-star cast of indie musicians and once in Mali with a crew of traditional instrumentalists. Though their original plan was to make two albums, they ended up mixing the separately recorded tracks together.

title: Adrift in New York, Web Comics Seek a Larger Audience
description: WHEN Ilana Glazer and Abbi Jacobson met for lunch at Cafe Cluny in the West Village recently, they looked tanner than usual. Ms. Glazer had taken up biking: Its my new thing, she said.

title: For Objects of a Gaze, a Chance to Return It
description: Whats with the shared bill? Over the past few months, choreographers have been pairing up everywhere, from New York Live Arts to the Kitchen and, finally, Danspace Project, where on Thursday evening, another double bill was unveiled, featuring Liz Santoro and Anne Zuerner. Theres something regressive about this way of packaging dance. Ms. Santoros We Do Our Best may not have been perfect, but it deserved its own night.

title: The Week in Pictures for April 13
