description: In a city known for accommodating for pets  where pet dogs, not to mention cats, outnumber the citys school-age children  and where local laws regulate doghouse architecture, San Francisco emergency planners are working to take care of pets in the next big earthquake.

title: Plan to Track Quake Threat Is Questioned
description: A hulking research vessel would haul air guns, echo sounders and other instruments along the California coast day and night for several months as part of a proposed $64 million effort to map seismic fault lines near the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant.

title: Heat in Forecast Prompts Changes for Boston Marathon
description: Runners who decide not to compete in the Boston Marathon because of the unusually warm weather conditions forecast for Monday will be allowed to defer their entries to next years race, the Boston Athletic Association announced. The announcement applies only to official entrants who do not start the race. No refunds for 2012 entries will be given. In addition, the finish systems that generally shut down just before 5 p.m. will remain open until approximately 6 p.m.

title: Once More With Feeling: Perry vs. Big Government
description: Ross Ramsey, executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: For You, What Was the Most Affecting Titanic Story, Event or Image?
description: April 16, 1:59 p.m. | Updated

title: Program That Sends Urban Students to Elite Colleges Comes to Houston This Fall
description: Starting this fall, high school seniors in the Houston Independent School District will have an opportunity to vie for one of 30 golden tickets to a unique higher-education experience.

title: It All Started One Night in the 80s at Gruene Hall
description: In 1985, a few years before the words singer-songwriter were permanently affixed to his name, 19-year-old Todd Snider showed up in San Marcos, knowing only that he had come to sing.

title: Prominent Political Prisoner Is Released Early in Belarus
description: MOSCOW  Belarus granted early release on Saturday to one of its most prominent political prisoners in a move that might be intended to ease its strained relationship with the European Union.

title: Failing Our Military Veterans
description: My Sunday column argues that we have let our veterans down. This column came to me in conversations with Ashley Gilbertson, an ace photographer for the Times who worked for years in Iraq and more recently has chronicled the struggles of veterans upon returning home. I was flabbergasted to learn from Ashley that more veterans kill themselves every year than the sum of all the soldiers killed in Iraq and Afghanistan since those wars combined.

title: Henry and Liverpool Try to Right Their Ship
description: John Henry and his partners in the Fenway Sports Group, who have won praise for their stewardship of the Boston Red Sox and were seen as saviors when they purchased Liverpool two years ago, now have two famed but struggling teams on their hands. Jer Longman checks in from Merseyside. Read the article and come back to comment.

title: For Wright, 9 Good Fingers Are More Than Enough
description: PHILADELPHIA  Any lingering doubt David Wright might have had about playing with a fractured right pinkie vanished after one pitch Saturday. Phillies pitcher Vance Worley threw a 90 mile-an-hour belt-high fastball that Wright crushed to the deepest part of the ballpark, beyond the marker on the center-field fence that indicates 409 feet.

title: Obama Says Legalization Is Not the Answer on Drugs
description: CARTAGENA, Colombia  Leaders at a summit meeting of many of the Western Hemisphere nations on Saturday discussed alternatives to what many consider a failed war on drugs that is too reliant on military action and imprisonment. But President Obama said flatly that legalization is not the answer.

title: Blaze Spreads on a Windy Day in the Bronx, Injuring 9 Firefighters
description: Two firefighters who fell through a collapsing floor were among at least nine injured on Saturday afternoon as they fought a fire that spread swiftly from one multifamily house in the east Bronx to three neighboring buildings, officials said.

title: N.R.A. Official Attacks Florida Shooting Coverage
description: ST. LOUIS  A senior official of the National Rifle Association accused the news media on Saturday of engaging in sensationalized coverage of the Trayvon Martin killing, in the first comments that the gun lobby has made publicly about the fatal shooting since it occurred six weeks ago.

title: NATO Sees Flaws in Air Campaign Against Qaddafi
description: WASHINGTON  Despite widespread praise in Western capitals for NATOs leadership of the air campaign in Libya, a confidential NATO assessment paints a sobering portrait of the alliances ability to carry out such campaigns without significant support from the United States.

title: Google Is Faulted for Impeding U.S. Inquiry on Data Collection
description: SAN FRANCISCO  When Google first revealed in 2010 that cars it was using to map streets were also sweeping up sensitive personal information from wireless home networks, it called the data collection a mistake. On Saturday, federal regulators charged that Google had deliberately impeded and delayed an investigation into the data collection and ordered a $25,000 fine on the search giant.

title: One Favorite Rolls, but Another Tails Off
description: HOT SPRINGS, Ark.  It was a good old-fashioned horse race at Oaklawn Park when Bodemeister went wire to wire to take the 76th running of the $1 million Arkansas Derby on Saturday. No drama, no gimmicks; Bodemeister, a Bob Baffert trainee, simply rolled to the lead and stayed there, widening away to a nine-and-a-half-length lead.

title: White House Opens Door to Big Donors, and Lobbyists Slip In
description: Last May, as a battle was heating up between Internet companies and Hollywood over how to stop online piracy, a top entertainment industry lobbyist landed a meeting at the White House with one of President Obamas technology advisers.

title: Coaches Face New Scrutiny on Sex Abuse
description: The case of Jerry Sandusky, a former defensive coordinator for Penn States football team accused of child sexual abuse, is now working its way through the courts. But it is already having an impact on thousands of other coaches, both volunteer and paid, who find themselves facing new scrutiny from parents, sports organizations and even state legislators.

title: Mild Punishment for a Vicious Hit
description: The playoffs were only hours old when they produced a tumultuous episode in Nashville, where Predators defenseman Shea Weber smashed the head of Red Wings forward Henrik Zetterberg against the glass.

title: Overly Aggressive Player Is Own Worst Enemy
description: It is almost always better to be the aggressor in chess. Players who give their opponents time to plan and organize an attack often end up losing.

title: Notes on (Civil War) Camp
description: Civil War paintings can be misleading.

title: Corrections: April 15
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Penguins Prospects and Communication Whiplash in 140 Characters
description: Heres a Twitter-scale post on an Antarctic icon, climate change and the news process, which often begins with a news release. Click the links in sequence to get my point.

title: Father Pat and the Brinks Job
description: Father Pat Moloney, an East Village activist, talks about his arrest in connection with a $7.4 million Brinks robbery in 1993.

title: Senators Win, but Only After a Few Angry Shots
description: It was nothing more than retribution, frontier justice in its simplest form. But in the peculiar context of playoff hockey, what the Ottawa Senators did at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night was also a stroke of tactical genius.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 14, 2012

title: Ottawa Rallies Around Alfredsson After a Hard Hit Sends Him Off for the Evening
description: For the second time this season, Daniel Alfredsson of the Senators was unable to finish a game at Madison Square Garden, apparently because of a head injury. But Alfredssons teammates rallied around their captain for Ottawas 3-2 overtime victory over the Rangers in Game 2 of the first-round series.

title: Rangers-Senators Replay: Game 2
description: A look at the Ottawa Senators overtime victory over the Rangers at Madison Square Garden in Game 2 of the teams first-round playoff series.

title: Out of Adversity, Visions of Life
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast

title: An Art Critic in Africa
description: Seeing culture on its own terms. Articles, commentary and pictures.

title: Maire Abraham, Zachary Conrad
description: Dr. Maire Madden Abraham and Zachary Elliot Conrad were married Saturday afternoon at St. Helens Roman Catholic Church in Westfield, N.J. The Rev. Michael A. Saporito, the churchs pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: Ginamarie Lafkas, Nathan Aumock
description: Ginamarie Nichole Lafkas and Nathan Michael Aumock were married Saturday at the Willowdale Estate in Topsfield, Mass. Leading the ceremony was John A. Rudberg, the bridegrooms stepfather, who received temporary permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to officiate.

title: Amanda Kay, Andrew Gitkind
description: Amanda Lynn Kay and Dr. Andrew Ian Gitkind were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Sharon B. Ballan at the Garden City Hotel in Garden City, N.Y.

title: Stephanie Adams, Patrick Ryan
description: Stephanie Maria Adams and Patrick Martin Ryan were married Saturday by the Rev. David Kerrigan, a retired Roman Catholic priest, at the Kay Chapel in Newport, R.I.

title: Meghan Giulino, Paul DeLaney III
description: Meghan Elizabeth Giulino and Paul Henry DeLaney III were married Saturday at the St. Albans Schools chapel on the grounds of the National Cathedral in Washington. The Rev. William P. Billow, Jr., an Episcopal priest and the former senior chaplain of St. Albans, performed the ceremony.

title: Carolyn Sufrin, Jacob Harold
description: Dr. Carolyn Beth Sufrin and Jacob Christopher Thomas Harold were married Saturday evening in an outdoor ceremony at Annadel Estate Winery in Santa Rosa, Calif. Benjamin S. Abram, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Tina Tyrell and Ethan Pomerance
description: Tina Tyrell and Ethan Ira Pomerance were married Saturday in New York. The Rev. Susan Turchin, an interfaith minister, officiated at the Carlyle hotel. Later that day, Dan Gordon, who is the bridegrooms brother-in-law and a Universal Life minister, led a ceremony that included Jewish and Greek Orthodox elements at La Grenouille, the restaurant.

title: Anne Keenan, Alexis Seeley
description: Anne Fleming Keenan and Alexis Katherine Seeley were married Saturday at the Brooklyn Winery in Brooklyn. Sarita Bhatt, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Jamie Ruzow, Gregory Radwan
description: Jamie Alison Ruzow and Gregory Ian Radwan are to be married Sunday at the Glen Island Harbour Club in New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Joshua M. Davidson is to officiate.

title: Claire Agre, Blair Johnson
description: Claire Coleman Agre and Blair Alexander Johnson were married Saturday at the Cylburn Arboretum in Baltimore. Seamus McNally, a friend of the couple who became an American Marriage Ministries minister for the ceremony, officiated.

title: Giulia Melucci and Gavin Smith
description: Giulia Anne Melucci and Gavin Steven Grainger Smith were married Monday at the Oratory Church of St. Boniface in Brooklyn. The Rev. Dr. Joel M. Warden, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Janet Teagle, Jeremy Graham
description: Janet Will Teagle, the daughter of Janet D. Teagle and Walter C. Teagle III of Mill Neck, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Jeremy Martin Graham, a son of Phyllis Ann Graham and James Mack Graham Jr. of Plano, Tex. The Rev. Simon Foster, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Johns of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, N.Y.

title: Lucy Painter and Malaga Baldi
description: Dr. Lucy Naughton Painter and Malaga Jan Baldi are to be married Sunday in their New York apartment by Richard Sadowsky, a Universal Life minister.

title: Anina Nolan and Powell Fraser III
description: Anina Chrysler Nolan and Powell Alexander Fraser III were married Saturday evening at the Jupiter Island Club in Hobe Sound, Fla. Katherine G. Carew, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Kate Yulman, Gregory Williamson
description: Kate Jennifer Yulman, the daughter of Janet K. Yulman and E. Richard Yulman of Miami, was married Saturday evening to Gregory Scott Williamson, a son of Madeline Williamson of Brooklyn and the late Kenneth Williamson. Rabbi Terry A. Bookman officiated at the Breakers resort in Palm Beach, Fla., with Cantor Lisa Segal taking part.

title: Caitlin Monahan, Ryan Condal
description: Caitlin Hennessey Monahan and Ryan J. Condal were married Saturday at St. Vincent de Paul Church in Bayonne, N.J. The Rev. Joseph F. Barbone, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Cara McNamara, Jasmit Sandhu
description: Cara Elizabeth McNamara and Jasmit Singh Sandhu were married Saturday evening at the Riverview, an event space in Simsbury, Conn. The Rev. A. Waine Kargul, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated. In the morning, a Sikh ceremony was led by Giani Komal Singh at the Guru Nanak Darbar Gurdwara, a Sikh temple, in Southington, Conn.

title: Jeffrey DeHart, Benjamin Halton
description: Jeffrey Patterson DeHart and Dr. Benjamin Thomas Halton were joined in a commitment ceremony on Saturday. Alfred Fuchs, a Universal Life minister, officiated at the Fleisher Art Memorial, a community arts center in Philadelphia.

title: Marie Harf and Joshua Lucas
description: Marie Elizabeth Harf and Joshua Paul Lucas were married Saturday at the Vienna Presbyterian Church in Vienna, Va. The Rev. Erin E. Bair, an Anglican priest and a friend of the couple, performed the ceremony.

title: Elizabeth Chuck and Lucien Noel Jr.
description: Elizabeth Renee Chuck and Lucien Francois Noel Jr. were married Saturday at Battery Gardens, a Manhattan restaurant. Susanne Wilson, who is affiliated with Journeys of the Heart, a nondenominational religious organization, officiated.

title: Anne Buckman, Andrew Calder
description: Anne Tracy Buckman and Andrew Thomas Calder were married Saturday at St. Thomas Church in New York. The Rev. Andrew C. Mead, an Episcopal priest and the churchs rector, performed the ceremony, with the Rev. Kirk Ullery, a Roman Catholic priest and an uncle of the bride, taking part.

title: Desire Hernndez Snchez, Neil Kernis
description: Desire C. Hernndez Snchez, a daughter of Dr. Ana R. Snchez Duverge and Dr. Miguel H. Hernndez Gutierrez of Puerto Rico, was married Saturday to Neil Irwin Kernis, a son of Susan Collins Kernis and David N. Kernis of Trumbull, Conn. Kenneth S. Greenwald, the bridegrooms godfather, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at his Manhattan apartment.

title: Stoudemire Is Hitting His Stride in Practice
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Amare Stoudemire ran up and down the court at a scrimmage Saturday, moving much like the top-scoring threat the Knicks signed to a maximum contract in the summer of 2010.

title: Avoiding Another Tick on the Doomsday Clock
description: HONG KONG  Its still 5 minutes to midnight.

title: 100 Tornadoes in 24 Hours, but Plenty of Notice
description: WOODWARD, Okla.  The tornadoes were unrelenting  more than 100 in 24 hours over a stretch of the Plains states. They tossed vehicles and ripped through homes. They drove families to their basements and whipped debris across small towns throughout the Midwest. In some areas, baseball-size hail rained from the sky.

title: Anointing Rock Legends From the Coasts
description: CLEVELAND  The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum, a gleaming glass pyramid on the shore of Lake Erie, has become a proud symbol of this city. And Clevelands rock fans turned out in droves for the halls 27th induction ceremony on Saturday, only the third time it has been held here.

title: A Coachella Festival United by Dance Music
description: INDIO, Calif.  I may give up on thinking about the central musical focus of Coachella. Let me put that another way: if one were to give up, this would be the year. The vibe this time is kind of Pauly D goes to Burning Man, sponsored by Volcom and NPR. The mostly blue-state, caucasian, neo-lotus-eating North American aesthetic mean, late teenage to middle-age, small-batch to mass-pop.

title: Kendall Wright, Third-Ranked Receiver in 2012 Draft
description: Matt Waldman is the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, a testament to his obsession with film analysis, now available for download.  Examples of his work can be found at his blog. He is helping The Fifth Down rank skill position players before the draft:

title: Complex Attack by Taliban Sends Message to the West
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Taliban suicide bombers and gunmen barraged the diplomatic quarter and the Parliament in the Afghan capital for hours on Sunday and struck three eastern provinces as well, in a complex attack clearly designed to undermine confidence in NATO and Afghan military gains.

title: North Korean Leader Stresses Need for Strong Military
description: SEOUL, South Korea  In his first speech in public since assuming the leadership of North Korea, Kim Jong-un said Sunday that his first, second and third priorities were to strengthen the military, and he declared that superiority in military technology was no longer monopolized by imperialists.

title: Lapses in Cease-Fire Reported as U.N. Monitors Prepare to Begin Mission in Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  With an initial team of six United Nations military observers scheduled to arrive in Syria on Sunday to monitor compliance with the cease-fire, government shellfire continued to rake central Homs and other flash points.

title: Drinks for Bellying Up to The Bar With Less Belly
description: Vacation isnt the ideal time to start counting calories, but for hotel guests still preparing for bikini season, Fairmont Hotels & Resorts doesnt see why you shouldnt have your cocktail and lose weight too. Its skinny drink initiative has encouraged bartenders at several of its hotels and restaurants to offer drinks with fewer calories and healthier ingredients this spring.

title: Disruptions: Innovation Isnt Easy, Especially Midstream
description: In Instagrams early days, in offices in the South Park neighborhood of San Francisco, basking in the blue glow of half a dozen computer screens, sat an old Polaroid camera. It was a Rainbow SX-70 OneStep Land Camera.

title: Taliban Free 384 Inmates in Pakistan
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  In what is being called the biggest jailbreak in Pakistani history, Taliban fighters stormed a prison in the northwestern town of Bannu early Sunday, freeing almost 400 prisoners, including a militant commander who tried in 2003 to assassinate the president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf.

title: Pomp and Fireworks in North Korea
description: North Koreans celebrated the 100th birthday of Kim Il-sung, North Koreas founding president.

title: Geithner Scolds Romney Over Women and Jobs
description: WASHINGTON  Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner joined the partisan sparring over women on Sunday, rejecting out of hand the Romney campaigns assertion that the burden of joblessness had fallen disproportionately on women.

title: For Americans Abroad, Taxes Just Got More Complicated
description: PARIS  As income tax filing deadline rolls around, spare a thought for the millions of Americans overseas who have been singled out by Congress for special treatment, with a new form that will add to the hassle of tax time for many and, critics say, set up the unwary for penalties.

title: More on the Link Between Earthquakes and Fracking
description: Scientists from the United States Geological Survey have cautiously weighed in on a subject that has sparked public concern in some parts of the country: spates of small earthquakes in oil- and gas-producing areas.

title: Insane in Spain
description: Back from travel! (But more crazy travel next week)

title: Israel Moves to Block Activists From Entering
description: BETHLEHEM, West Bank  Hundreds of police officers fanned out at Ben-Gurion International Airport on Sunday as Israel moved to block scores of pro-Palestinian campaigners from entering the country.

title: With Italy and Spain, Further Tests for Europe
description: BRUSSELS  Is the euro crisis back with a vengeance, or do investors have a needless case of anxiety?

title: Excerpt: 'Peter and the Starcatcher'
description: A scene from the Broadway play about Peter Pan, at the Brooks Atkinson Theater.

title: The Hunger Games Has Another Big Weekend
description: The Hunger Games was the No. 1 movie in North America for an astounding fourth weekend in a row  the first release to achieve that feat since Avatar. The Hunger Games (Lionsgate) took in an estimated $21.5 million over the weekend for a new domestic total of $337.1 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticketing data.

title: Bachmanns Praise of Romney Falls Short of Endorsement
description: Just five months ago as a presidential candidate, Representative Michele Bachmann took aim at Mitt Romney by saying he has been very inconsistent in his positions.

title: Scenes From Coachella, Day 2
description: A look at some of Saturdays performances at Coachella.

title: Bay Out With Jammed Finger
description: PHILADELPHIA  Mets outfielder Jason Bay was scratched from Sundays lineup against the Phillies with a jammed right ring finger. Bay sustained the injury sliding into first base Saturday. David Wright sustained a fractured right pinkie last week on the same type of play.

title: Some Side Dishes Served Up as a Varied Main Course
description: In most of its recent New York performances the Takacs Quartet, which established itself as one of the worlds eminent string ensembles soon after its founding in 1975, has hewed to canonical staples. Mozart, Beethoven, Schubert and Mendelssohn dominated its edifying programs in the city last year. Likewise its latest recordings for the Hyperion label have focused on Haydn, played with vigor and refinement.

title: Volley of Words on the Ravages of War
description: Federer Versus Murray often comes off more like a highlight reel than a play.

title: A Festival With Broader Horizons
description: The annual cinematic blitz that is the Tribeca Film Festival is once again poised to hit. For two weeks, beginning Wednesday with the world premiere of the romantic comedy The Five-Year Engagement, made by the team behind Forgetting Sarah Marshall, 90 feature films will blaze across screens around New York City. The invasion will culminate with the premiere of The Avengers, a popcorn explosion in which superheroes band together to forestall global catastrophe.

title: Celebrating Robinson and Other Black Players, on the Field and in an Exhibit Hall
description: 1:54 p.m. | Updated Major League Baseball will again honor Jackie Robinson for his role in breaking the color barrier, which occurred 65 years ago Sunday, when players across baseball wear 42 on their uniforms, a nod to Robinsons number with the Brooklyn Dodgers.

title: Scenes From Coachella, Day 2
description: More Photographs

title: There Go Starving Artists, Trying It All, Even the Lotto
description: In Mandorla, Jenny Rochas evening-length work, the atmosphere was something akin to a rowdy or forlorn carnival, depending on your point of view. (For me it was on the sad side, but that had more to do with the weakness of the production than its tone.) Ms. Rocha, clearly the mandorla of her Mandorla  an almond-shaped aura that surrounds religious figures  was center stage much of the time.

title: Rock Music With Tropical Punch, a Soundtrack for a Hip Island Hotel
description: The sense of completion on the first Tanlines album, Mixed Emotions, which was released last month by True Panther, is palpable. Its patient, brightly colored and often exuberant, walking the line between spare club music and dance-minded rock, with mild Caribbean flourishes for added punch.

title: Iraq Emerges From Isolation as Telecommunications Hub
description: PARIS  Iraq, cut off from decades of technological progress because of dictatorship, sanctions and wars, recently took a big step out of isolation and into the digital world when its telecommunications system was linked to a vast new undersea cable system serving the Gulf countries.

title: Crowd-Sourcing Expands Power of Brain Research
description: In the largest collaborative study of the brain to date, scientists using imaging technology at more than 100 centers worldwide have for the first time zeroed in on genes that they agree play a role in intelligence and memory.

title: Cue the Goal-Line Technology Debate
description: Goal or no goal? Travesty or justice?

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Zen for High Schoolers: Notice the Anxiety. Notice the Fear.
description: La-keeyatta Steward, 17, sat on a small black pillow one recent Tuesday afternoon, her legs tucked under her. Her meditation instructor told her to imagine her body pulled upward by a string, so she lowered her shoulders and straightened her back.

title: Daring to Cut Off Amazon
description: TULSA, Okla.  Plenty of people are upset at Amazon these days, but it took a small publishing company whose best-known volume is a toilet-training tome to give the mighty Internet store the boot.

title: After Hearing With Shanahan, Rangers Hagelin Is Suspended Three Games
description: 8:47 p.m. | Updated Matt Carkner suspended one game for instigating an altercation with Brian Boyle. Here is the video of Brendan Shanahan explaining the punishment.

title: Anthonys Big Day Is No Match for Big Three
description: For 42 minutes, the ledger was nearly even  Carmelo Anthony on one side, points flying from his fingertips, the Miami Heat on the other, unleashing every ounce of their star power to match him in a rousing Sunday matinee at Madison Square Garden.

title: For Most, Choice of Stay-at-Home Motherhood Is Far From a Luxury
description: The layoff notice was not a complete surprise. At the shipping center in Denver where Jeanine Maez filled mail orders, the trend had been toward paperless transactions.

title: A Not-Quite-Young Man With a Plan Follows a Type-A Pursuit of Health
description: In Drop Dead Healthy A. J. Jacobs describes taking the Staten Island Ferry en route to the starting line of his first triathlon. A passenger notices Mr. Jacobss duffel bag not because it is camouflage patterned but because the camouflage colors are red and pink.

title: Arguing About Language
description: Today Im going to hopefully beg a question which will incentivize the reader to share their views. Yes, Im writing about English grammar and usage.

title: Book Publishings Real Nemesis
description: The Justice Department finally took aim at the monopolistic monolith that threatened to dominate the book industry. So imagine the shock when the bullet aimed at threats to competition went whizzing by Amazon  which not long ago had a 90 percent stranglehold on e-books  and instead, struck five of the six biggest publishers and Apple, a minor player in the realm of books.

title: Excuses Spring Eternal, but Not in Fair Weather
description: It was so warm this past winter, many golf courses in the Midwest and the North never closed, with players tromping around the grounds from Thanksgiving to St. Patricks Day. Those courses that did close flung open the doors for the spring season several weeks earlier than usual, and with good conditions.

title: Dressing Up and Discovering Whats in the Toy Box
description: Its a little worrisome to discover that the kids have emptied out the costume trunk. So many props should keep them occupied, and maybe theyll entertain the grownups while theyre at it, but the situation is already messy, and its bound to get messier.

title: Reconfigured Requiem With Words to the Fore
description: For the Hungarian conductor Ivan Fischer the unexpected is the norm. Among other experiments, Mr. Fischer likes to test unusual seating plans with the Budapest Festival Orchestra, which he helped to found and directs, and other orchestras, to alter balances and bring out intriguing details, especially those involving woodwinds.

title: New York Public Library Defends Plan to Renovate
description: The New York Public Library is engaged in a public-relations blitz to address criticism from scholars and writers who object to the librarys plan to reimagine its Fifth Avenue flagship building at an estimated cost of $300 million.

title: Double-counting Doubletalk
description: Some readers have asked me for a reaction to Steve Rattners piece on Medicare and the Affordable Care Act. The short answer is that its a classic piece of concern trolling  the practice, all too common among a certain class of commentators, of professing sympathy with progressive policy goals, then, invariably, finding a way to support right-wing talking points.

title: Man, Alive to Machine Possibilities
description: Last week Ralf Htter, the singer and founder of the pioneering German electronic band Kraftwerk, recalled the first time the band came to New York City: in 1975, for an American tour to promote Autobahn, an unlikely hit sung in German and backed by electronics. The group members were carrying, he said, a few suitcases, some synthesizers in padded boxes they had built themselves and, for visuals, a slide projector.

title: Inequality and Crisis Response
description: Wells and Krugman from the Occupy Handbook has been serialized in Slate Salon

title: Remembering Hans Kreijns, Dutch Champion
description: One of the worlds great players, Hans Kreijns from the Netherlands, died on April 4 at 83.

title: A Sketch Artist Animates a Fraternity of Bumblers
description: The four interrelated tales of Okis Movie, Hong Sang-soos beguiling new film, are preceded by Pomp and Circumstance, played over handwritten credits. Elgars stately march becomes an ironic refrain to the misadventures and regrets of the three recurring characters, two men and a woman, who navigate different stages in their lives at a film school. The unsubtle musical theme is also a sharp contrast to Mr. Hongs casually brilliant feat of storytelling, akin to an ingeniously wrought suite of literary short fiction.

title: Mets Stumble Against Phillies, Missing Out on a Sweep
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Mets entered Citizens Bank Park on Friday with a two-game losing streak, David Wright injured and the heart of their lineup struggling. They faced a three-game series against the Phillies, who have won five consecutive National League East crowns and were sending Cliff Lee and Cole Hamels to the mound during the weekend.

title: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include retail sales for March and business inventories for February (Monday); housing starts and industrial production for March (Tuesday); weekly jobless claims, home resales for March, leading economic indicators for March, and the Philadelphia Fed index (Thursday).

title: Its Like a Borgasmord
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Man, Im full. I just finished Lynn Lempels puzzle and I dont think I could eat another square, sorry, thing.

title: Bradley Cooper Joins The Elephant Man
description: Bradley Cooper, Peoples Sexiest Man Alive in 2011, will take on one of actings most unflattering roles, in the Williamstown Theater Festivals revival of The Elephant Man. Mr. Cooper will portray John Merrick, the deformed man at the center of the play, by Bernard Pomerance. Mr. Cooper portrayed Merrick as part of his senior thesis at the Actors Studio Drama School, and appeared in the festivals production of The Understudy by Theresa Rebeck in 2008. He will be joined onstage by Patricia Clarkson, who will play an actress who befriends Merrick during his hospital stay. Ms. Clarkson, also a veteran of the festival, appeared in The Ride Down Mount Morgan by Arthur Miller in 1996. Directed by Scott Ellis (The Little Dog Laughed), The Elephant Man is scheduled to run from July 25 to Aug. 5. Ticket orders can be placed at wtfestival.org.

title: Stones to Record? Not So Fast
description: After saying at a news conference last week that the Rolling Stones would head into a recording studio this month to just bat some ideas around, the guitarist Ronnie Wood has amended those comments after receiving a phone call from Mick Jagger. I heard from Jagger; hes going: What the hell? We dont know anything yet, Mr. Wood, above, said on Sunday, speaking with Billboard.com from the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in Cleveland, where he was inducted on Saturday for the second time. He said that he had expressed a personal view and that he would love to go into the studio, but that nothing had been set. So I have to make a personal apology to the rest of the band, he said. I didnt mean to say things out of line.

title: TED Teams With NPR
description: TED, the nonprofit group that sponsors conferences on ideas, is coming to NPR. A 10-episode series titled TED Radio Hour will begin on April 27 on NPR stations and at ted.npr.org, the two organizations plan to announce on Monday. The show, hosted by Alison Stewart, the former anchor of the PBS series Need to Know, draws from an archive of more than 1,200 TED talks, each lasting 18 minutes or so, which become the kernels for a broader conversation, Eric Nuzum, NPRs vice president for programming, said by telephone. Each episode is organized around a theme: one pairs competing talks on the cause of happiness; others look at the power of crowds and food sustainability. Chris Anderson, who runs the TED conferences, said in a phone interview that the challenge was to take material that was in some cases three or four years old and make it seem fresh and relevant by letting Ms. Stewart explore points in more depth and bring in other voices. Local stations will broadcast the program at varied times; WNYC in New York is scheduling it for the summer. NPR will wait to approve a second season, but Mr. Anderson is optimistic: I dont think the worlds going to run out of ideas any time soon, she said. I would say that curiosity is a self-fueling fire. TED is also exploring television. There are lots of conversations and discussions afoot, Mr. Anderson said, declining to provide specifics.

title: Yale Drama Winner
description: Beautiful Province, a new play by Clarence Coo about a 15-year-old boy who travels across Canada with his French high school teacher, is the winner of the 2012 Yale Drama Series award for an emerging playwright, the judge for the series, John Guare (The House of Blue Leaves, Six Degrees of Separation), is to announce on Monday. Mr. Coo will receive the $10,000 prize, from the David Charles Horn Foundation, and the play will be published by Yale University Press. A staged reading is set for Sept. 18 at Lincoln Center Theater. The runners-up were Saviana Stanescu for Useless and Jesse Weaver for We Shall Catch Larks.

title: Severe Storms Spawn Tornadoes in the Midwest
description: At least 122 tornadoes were reported overnight Saturday across Oklahoma, Kansas, Nebraska and Iowa, causing damage across the region and killing six people in Oklahoma.

title: Bidding to Change Golfs Perception as Sport for Rich
description: Wednesday is National Golf Day, and a chief goal of the day is to explain golf in all its forms, not just those typically envisioned by non-golfers.

title: Pandora Courts Local Advertisers, by Offering Well-Defined Listeners
description: The music was pumping and the finger food laid out in abundance one recent evening in a subterranean Manhattan bar, as executives of Pandora Media, the Internet radio service, mingled with some of their most prized new advertisers.

title: A Great Show in China, a Lingering Cloud Over Bahrain
description: SHANGHAI  As I wrestled my way out of the sardine can of a Metro train car packed with racegoers for the Chinese Grand Prix Sunday I said to myself, Hey, wait a minute, this series is not supposed to have succeeded in China! Why do I see thousands of spectators disembarking from this train, and only a tiny minority of them being foreigners?

title: Improving the State of Americas Teeth
description: To the Editor:

title: Private Student Loans
description: To the Editor:

title: The Cost of Cutting Welfare
description: To the Editor:

title: The Importance of Trees
description: To the Editor:

title: Gas Wells Project in Utah
description: To the Editor:

title: Evolution of a Game
description: Bill Pennington talks to Arnold Palmer and his grandson Sam Saunders about golf club technology.

title: Safety of Chicken Meat
description: To the Editor:

title: Mere Mortals Approach to Shot That Won Masters
description: Ive been thinking about Bubba Watsons astonishing, Masters-winning shot from the pine straw next to the 10th hole at Augusta National last week. I wonder how average recreational players would approach such a shot: 160 yards with overhanging trees in the way, and you must hook the ball about 40 yards and land it on a severely elevated green protected by deep bunkers and a cathedral of tall, intimidating loblolly pines.

title: Making Visas-for-Dollars Work
description: AMONG the most popular tools for attracting foreign investment to the United States is the EB-5 program. It seems like the perfect win-win: any foreigner who invests between $500,000 and $1 million here, and creates at least 10 domestic jobs from that investment within two years, gets a green card.

title: Progressive Rock Station, WBCN, Returns on HD
description: From a newly repurposed electric green school bus parked next to his split-level home in suburban Hingham, Mass., Sam Kopper is broadcasting music live on a Friday night. But is anyone listening?

title: Europes Economic Suicide
description: On Saturday The Times reported on an apparently growing phenomenon in Europe: suicide by economic crisis, people taking their own lives in despair over unemployment and business failure. It was a heartbreaking story. But Im sure I wasnt the only reader, especially among economists, wondering if the larger story isnt so much about individuals as about the apparent determination of European leaders to commit economic suicide for the Continent as a whole.

title: Teixeira Is Slow to Start; Girardi Is Slow to Worry
description: After an off-season spent changing his workout routine and losing weight in an effort to improve his batting average, Mark Teixeira was hitting .188 with only two extra-base hits through the Yankees first eight games.

title: Murray Rose, Australian Olympic Swimming Star, Dies at 73
description: Murray Rose, who won four Olympic gold medals in swimming for Australia, becoming one of his nations most celebrated athletes before going to Hollywood to try his hand in the movies, died Sunday in Sydney, Australia. He was 73.

title: Trial in Martin Case, Filled With High Emotion, Would Draw a News Swarm
description: The Orlando Sentinels Twitter account for the Trayvon Martin case is up and running. So, too, is its topics page, with links to all the newspapers articles about Mr. Martin and the man who shot and killed him, George Zimmerman, as well as video clips of its reporters talking about the case on television. A Facebook page will go online on Monday. And a Web video series might be next.

title: Africas Free Press Problem
description: AS Africas economies grow, an insidious attack on press freedom is under way. Independent African journalists covering the continents development are now frequently persecuted for critical reporting on the misuse of public finances, corruption and the activities of foreign investors.

title: President Speaks Out on Guard Investigation
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama commented for the first time on Sunday about the Secret Service employees accused of soliciting prostitutes before a summit meeting in Cartagena, Colombia, saying he expected a high standard of conduct from his security team and adding that he would be angry if the accusations were proved true.

title: A Conversation With Arnold Palmer About Golf Clubs
Butch Bouchard, Imposing Pillar of Montreal Canadiens Defense, Dies at 92
description: Butch Bouchard, the Hall of Fame defenseman and longtime captain of the Montreal Canadiens, who played on four Stanley Cup championship teams in the 1940s and 50s, died on Saturday in Brossard, Quebec, near Montreal. He was 92.

title: N.H.L. Suspends Rangers Hagelin Three Games for Elbowing Alfredsson
description: Carl Hagelin was late for the Rangers practice Sunday afternoon, but he had an excuse. Hagelin, a rookie wing, spent about 15 minutes in a phone hearing with Brendan Shanahan, the N.H.L.s vice president for hockey operations and player safety.

title: Lou Goldstein, Borscht Belt Master of Simon Says, Dies at 90
description: Lou Goldstein was the consummate tummler, one of a zany species of entertainer who kept them laughing, or tried to, long ago in the borscht belt hotels of the Catskills.

title: The Sweet Spot
description: THE other day Rick Santorum, with rigor mortis setting into his campaign, stepped up to a microphone in Mars, Pa. (Yes, really.) His complaint was a familiar one: For too long the Republican aristocracy has shoved moderate nominees down the throats of the voters. Theres one person, he declared, referring to Ronald Reagan, who understood we dont win by moving to the middle. We win by getting people in the middle to move to us.

title: After Florida Shooting, N.R.A. Crowd Sticks to What It Knows
description: ST. LOUIS  Inside the seven-acre showroom at the National Rifle Associations annual convention here during the weekend, firearm enthusiasts filtered in and out of the sea of booths displaying handguns and the holsters designed to hide them.

title: News Corporations Pursuer Had Modest Start
description: Rupert Murdoch has made a career of painting his critics as elitist, privileged and out of touch. But the English lawyer who stands at the center of the legal battles that have engulfed his News Corporation did not attend a select law school or work at a top London law firm.

title: From the Birthplace of Big Brother
description: The George W. Bush team must be consumed with envy. Britains government is preparing sweeping new legislation that would let the countrys domestic intelligence agencies monitor all private telephone, e-mail, text message, social network and Internet use in the country, bypassing requirements for judicial warrants.

title: Letting Carmelo Anthony Go It Alone May Not Help Knicks
description: There may or may not have been a playoff statement made by the Miami Heat on Sunday at Madison Square Garden, but there certainly was a personnel seminar conducted by LeBron James and Dwyane Wade. Stylistically and statistically, they sent a pointed message to the Knicks on the virtues of all-stars who go out of their way to share.

title: Declining as a Manufacturer, Japan Weighs Reinvention
description: AMAGASAKI, Japan  A few years ago, the densely built-up coastal region around this port was called Panel Bay because of its concentration of factories making the sophisticated flat-panel screens that were symbols of Japans manufacturing prowess. But now the area has become a grim symbol of its industrial decline.

title: Keeping a Promise to Home Care Aides
description: Evelyn Coke, who died in 2009 at age 74, was a home care aide whose case for fair pay went to the Supreme Court in 2007, where she lost 9 to 0. At issue were federal rules that define home care aides as companions, a label that exempts employers from having to pay minimum wage and time-and-a-half for overtime. The justices said that only Congress or the Labor Department could change the rules.

title: Many U.S. Immigrants Children Seek American Dream Abroad
description: Samir N. Kapadia seemed to be on the rise in Washington, moving from an internship on Capitol Hill to jobs at a major foundation and a consulting firm. Yet his days, he felt, had become routine.

title: Trying to Turn Arizona Blue
description: President Obamas aides have said said they thought it was possible to win Arizona, a state that analysts believe is heading Democratic in national elections, but may not be there yet.

title: Antibiotics Off the Farm
description: Two important events in recent weeks  a regulatory guideline and a federal court decision  have raised hopes that progress can be made in curbing the widespread use of antibiotics to spur growth in cattle, chickens, pigs and other food animals.

title: Raising Twins Where They May Never Belong
description: LONDON  My partner likes to say our children will soon be more British than American. This is because they will soon spend more of their 2-year-old lives in Britain than in the United States.

title: Car Hits and Kills a Boy in Brooklyn
description: A Brooklyn teenager was killed over the weekend after falling from his bicycle and being hit by a car, the authorities said.

title: Obama Camp, Seeing Shift, Bets on Long Shot in Arizona
description: PHOENIX  President Obamas re-election campaign is dispatching workers across Arizonas college campuses and Latino neighborhoods this spring, registering as many new voters as they can in an organized, three-month effort to determine whether they can put this unlikely state into play for Democrats this November.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 15, 2012

title: 3 Arrested in Manhattan as March Turns Into a Melee
description: A group of people who had attended an anarchist book fair in Manhattan later marched to a nearby Starbucks on Saturday night and began swinging at the windows with metal pipes, as frightened customers hid under tables, the police said.

title: Going Gets Rough; Flyers Take Charge
description: PHILADELPHIA  All the elements that have so far fashioned the Flyers-Penguins matchup as the most compelling of the N.H.L. playoffs were present Sunday at Wells Fargo Center, but so was perhaps the one component it had lacked.

title: Pseudoscience and Tennessees Classrooms
description: Eighty-seven years after Tennessee was nationally embarrassed for criminally prosecuting the teaching of evolution, the state government is at it again. This time it has enacted a law that protects teachers who invite students to challenge the science underlying evolution and climate change. The measure is a transparent invitation to indulge pseudoscience in the classroom and a transparent pandering to a vocal, conservative fringe.

title: Victims Advocates Protest as Prosecutors Detain 17-Year-Old Rape Victim in California
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In a case that has pitted law-enforcement officials against advocates of victims rights, prosecutors in Sacramento County, Calif., have detained a 17-year-old girl for twice failing to appear in court to testify against the man accused of raping her.

title: Unanswered Questions in F.C.C.s Google Case
description: One of the most audacious projects ever to come out of Google was the plan to photograph and map the inhabited world, one block at a time. But a report over the weekend from federal regulators has rekindled questions over exactly what the company was doing  questions the search giant has spent years trying not to answer.

title: Homegrown Bomb Plot Is Rarity for Open Court
description: The three high school classmates from a workaday section of Queens were trained in bomb-making in the tribal areas of Pakistan, where they received their orders directly from senior members of Al Qaeda, prosecutors said. They gathered explosives, chose targets and picked the days in September 2009 when they planned to take their own lives, in three separate bombings in the New York subway system.

title: More Blacks in Management Would Be a True Robinson Tribute
description: On Sunday, Major League Baseball celebrated another Jackie Robinson Day. Sixty-five years ago, Robinson broke the majors racial barrier.

title: Peter and the Starcatcher
description: Photos of the new Broadway show at the Brooks Atkinson Theater.

title: Americas Meeting Ends With Discord Over Cuba
description: CARTAGENA, Colombia  A summit meeting of Western Hemisphere nations ended without a final statement of consensus on Sunday, after the United States and some Latin American nations remained sharply divided over whether to continue excluding Cuba from such gatherings.

title: Steely Traffic Managers Ease a Holland Tunnel Snarl
description: Joe Pittelli was hit by a vehicle while he fixed potholes on the Van Wyck Expressway; his arm was sideswiped while he was paving the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive; and he was once knocked off a ladder while installing a parking sign in Long Island City.

title: Effortless Flights of Fancy
description: Theyre surfing the clouds at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, where Peter and the Starcatcher opened on Sunday night. And even inveterate fearers of flying are likely to find themselves following the folks onstage into altitudes where eagles get nosebleeds.

title: Corrections: April 16
description: NATIONAL

title: Tutoring Surges With Fight for Middle School Spots
description: As their parents sat anxiously in a waiting room, five children were sharpening their test-taking skills in a tutoring center in TriBeCa, underlining words that might hold clues to the answers and crossing off the illogical multiple-choice options intended to trip them up. For homework, there were more practice problems.

title: Fire in Catskills Ravages Site of Old Browns Hotel
description: A fire over the weekend swept through a condominium complex in the Catskills that was once the Browns Hotel, where Jerry Lewis and other comedians entertained crowds of vacationing New Yorkers.

title: Opening Up a Path to Four-Year Degrees
description: PHILADELPHIA  At the end of his first year at the Community College of Philadelphia, Christopher Thomas decided that his goal  to go back to school and get a degree  was no longer worth it. He was in debt from thousands of dollars in student loans. After class, he rode a bus an hour and a half to a suburban restaurant where he worked as a waiter. When the shift ended at midnight, it took him three buses to get home. He couldnt afford a computer, so in the middle of the night, he walked to his aunts house and used hers to finish his class work.

title: Two Giants of Finance Will Release Diversity Data
description: At the behest of New York Citys public pension funds, two of the biggest financial companies with headquarters in the city, Goldman Sachs and MetLife, have agreed to publicly disclose information about the racial and gender breakdowns of their staffs.

title: Do We Need More Advice About Eating Well?
G.O.P. Lawmakers and Romney Face a Delicate Tango
description: WASHINGTON  If Mitt Romney is considering a quick pivot to the center as he heads into the general election, he will find an imposing impediment: fellow Republicans in the House.

title: Let the Nanotargeting Begin
description: Over the past decade, political campaigns, interest groups and a network of private companies have developed sophisticated tools to target tinier and tinier fractions of the electorate. Campaigns now have access to the voting histories, housing values, recreational preferences, automobile ownership and television and Internet viewing habits of individuals. The explosion of consumer data derived primarily from credit card usage and Nielsen ratings has become a powerful weapon in the hands of politicos.

title: Gingrich and Paul Defy Calls to Rally Around Romney
description: With Rick Santorum out of the Republican presidential field, clearing a path to the nomination for Mitt Romney, the fight to become the partys standard-bearer is over, right?

title: Spanish Kings Hip Surgery Follows Controversial Hunting Trip
description: King Juan Carlos of Spain underwent hip replacement surgery during the weekend following an accident in Botswana, where he had gone to hunt elephants, a vacation that spurred criticism of the monarchs lifestyle at a time when the country is coping with an economic crisis.

title: Were Not Really Bad Kids
description: HUNTINGDON, Tenn.  The Carroll Academy girls basketball team had just lost by 59 points to Dresden High School, the top team in the conference. Still, Tonya Lutz, Carroll Academys coach, lauded her teams effort. Randy Hatch, Carroll Academys day-to-day director and founder of the basketball program, reached into a pocket and slipped $20 to one of the girls, as he usually does after games.

title: Ai Weiwei on the Pen and the Gun
description: HONG KONG  When we last looked in on Ai Weiwei, the rebellious Chinese artist was suing the Beijing tax authorities over their charges against him. The Public Security folks had pulled the plug on Weiweicam, his project that was streaming live video feeds from inside his house to the Internet. He has continued to break the rules of his release from prison, blaming his lack of self-discipline, telling The Economist, Cmon, I cant even lose weight!

title: Photo Replay: April 15
description: The Philadelphia Flyers beat the Pittsburgh Penguins for a 3-0 lead in an Eastern Conference quarterfinal, and baseball players wore No. 42 in tribute to Jackie Robinson.

title: On Block in Harlem, Neighbors Push for Restoration Will End in Demolition
description: Gentrification, or at the very least prettification, has reshaped block after block in Harlem, but it has not fully arrived at East 126th Street between Madison and Park Avenues.

title: In Market for Rings, Any Price Seems Worth Paying
description: Both No. 3 hitters at Yankee Stadium on Sunday are signed to 10-year contracts. Both will be 41 on opening day of their final years. The Angels Albert Pujols has just started his deal, and the Yankees Alex Rodriguez is into the fifth year of his.

title: April 16, 1947 | Fire Causes Huge Explosion in Texas City
description: On April 16, 1947, Americas worst harbor explosion occurred in Texas City, Tex., when the French ship Grandcamp, carrying ammonium nitrate fertilizer, caught fire and blew up, devastating the town.

title: New Tumult in Egypts Politics After Panel Bars 3 Candidates for President
description: CAIRO  Candidates in Egypts presidential race scrambled Sunday to find their footing in an increasingly slippery field as new questions emerged about whether Hosni Mubaraks former spy chief would be allowed to compete.

title: Word of the Day | perceptive
description: perceptive \pr-sep-tiv\ adjective

title: In Ad Campaign, SAP Looks Beyond Business Customers
description: Software companies dont have an easy time marketing themselves to a mass audience, especially when the software is a complicated business product meant for cloud computing or data analytics.

title: Towns Is Said to Decline to Run Again for Congress
description: Representative Edolphus Towns of Brooklyn will not seek a 16th term in Congress, a senior Democrat with knowledge of the decision said on Sunday.

title: Yankees Slumbering Bats Quickly Come to Life
description: Yankees fans seemed unsure how to react when Tim Tebow, the Jets backup quarterback, was shown in the stands, but they knew just how to respond when the Yankees sluggish lineup began to awaken on a warm Sunday night at Yankee Stadium.

title: Good Wife Watch: A Political Spouse Once More
description: Three weeks ago The Good Wife left viewers dangling in anticipation of a showdown between the two most powerful women in Peters life as Alicia (Julianna Margulies) marched into the hair salon where her mother-in-law, Jackie (Mary Beth Peil), was waxing eloquent on her sons political future.

title: Americans, the Tax Man Cometh
description: April 25, 9:00 p.m. | Updated

title: News Quiz | April 16, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays front page. Good luck!

title: As Army Prepares to Shrink, Its Chief Tries to Reassure His Soldiers
description: WIESBADEN, Germany  Hundreds of American troops crowded the bleachers inside a gymnasium at the historic garrison here as Gen. Ray Odierno, the Armys top officer, tried to address what seemed to be on the minds of every soldier: the future.

title: Raising the Memory of the Titanic, and a Citys Role in Its Creation
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland  One hundred years after the Titanic slid beneath the icy Atlantic, this city, where the doomed ship was built, noted the occasion on Sunday by unveiling a memorial to the victims in a ceremony that was part of an effort to shape a shared history in what is still a deeply divided society.

title: Is Siachen Worth Fighting Over?
description: In the snowy wastes of Siachen, where Pakistani and Indian soldiers face off in a high-altitude battle zone ringed by Himalayan peaks, the fight is against the mountain, not the man, Declan Walsh writes in The New York Times.

title: M.L.S. Week 7: Sevens Wild
description: Three players  Thiery Henry, Kenny Cooper and Chris Wondolowski  are tied at the top of the goal-scoring race (what Major League Soccer and others call the race for the Golden Boot) after two-thirds of the threesome joined the Red Bulls French star at the top, with seven goals.

title: Trickle of Returning NRIs to Become a Flood
description: Samir N. Kapadia seemed to be on the rise in Washington, moving from an internship on Capitol Hill to jobs at a major foundation and a consulting firm. Yet his days, he felt, had become routine, Kirk Semple writes in The New York Times.

title: Norwegian Man Claims Self-Defense in Killings
description: OSLO  By turns defiant, impassive and, just once, tearful, the self-described anti-Islamic militant who admitted killing 77 people last year, including scores of young people at a summer camp on a tranquil wooded island, went on trial here on Monday.

title: U.N. Truce Observers Arrive in Syria as Shelling Continues
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  An initial team of six United Nations military observers arrived in Syria on Monday to monitor compliance with the fragile, four-day-old cease-fire negotiated by the special envoy Kofi Annan, his spokesman said, as activists reported government shelling in Homs, Hama and other areas.

title: Popular Support for Growing Trade Ties Between India and Pakistan
description: The loosening of trade barriers between India and Pakistan was warmly greeted in Delhi and at the border town of Attari in recent days.

title: Afghan Forces Quell Attack; Few Civilians Are Killed
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The complex attacks that immobilized much of Kabul and touched the main cities of three eastern Afghan provinces ended Monday morning with 39 of the attackers killed, 16 of them in Kabul, according to senior Afghan officials.

title: Scenes From Coachella, Day 3
description: As of 10:30 p.m. Sunday night, this things winding down. Two of the sets I watched closely today were The Weeknd, the para-R&B project of the Canadian singer Abel Tesfaye, and At the Drive-In, the para-hardcore band from El Paso, Tex., reforming  if perhaps only briefly  after an 11-year absence.

description: As millions of gardeners prepare for spring planting, a new study underwritten by The Nature Conservancy warns that imported nursery stock poses an increasing threat to the environment.

title: How Do You Archive Your Life?
description: Handwritten notebook entries, scrapbook pages, running lists in a computer file, hard drives full of pictures  all are ways to record, remember and even tally your experiences. Do you have a system of archiving your life? Why do you think people keep track of things and places, and hold on to objects like ticket stubs to concerts and plays?

title: In the Arcadian Woods
description: Often I sense its electric energy during the initial phone call. Anxiety is like that. It leaps from you to me then back again like some unruly spirit. But that faint buzz reveals surprisingly little else about the being on the other end of the line. Who is not at times worried, nervous, troubled, frantic or even panicked? Anxiety may be an omen of vast import, or not much at all. Like the robot in the television series Lost in Space who proclaims Danger, Will Robinson, this primal alarm sends out its warning, but of what? As a psychiatrist, it is part of my job to find out.

title: A Half-Pound of iPhone Dock
description: Maybe Apples plastic iPhone stand doesnt seem a substantial enough vessel for your beloved 4S. Dont worry, Element Case has you covered.

description: President Obamas campaign and the Democratic Party raised $53 million in March as the Republican primary wound down, Mr. Obamas campaign manager announced in a video Monday morning.

description: Coty tried to rally support on Monday for its $10 billion unsolicited bid for Avon Products. But it was unclear whether the effort had succeeded.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Planning for Zimmerman Trial, and What Breitbart Wrought
description: The shooting death of Trayvon Martin has transfixed social networks and news coverage, and thats before there was an arrest. Now that George Zimmerman has been charged with second-degree murder in the shooting, news outlets are preparing for a televised trial that could receive blanket coverage on television networks and Web sites, Brian Stelter writes. It has the potential to be as big as the O. J. Simpson trial  and just as divisive, said Piers Morgan, the CNN interviewer.

title: Monday Reading: When to Buy That Plane Ticket
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Gary Oldman to Direct Jack White Concert Webcast
description: Even though he has never been any of these things in real life, Gary Oldman has slipped seamlessly into the film roles of a violent, dreadlocked pimp; a vampire count; and a man who sliced off his own face. Now can he play the part of the director of a live concert broadcast, without having done it before?

title: The Trademarked Beard
description: MOSCOW  I was discussing a newly submitted article with a colleague at the magazine we edit when another editor ran into the room shouting, Did you see? They didnt let Verbitsky out of the country because someone has trademarked his beard. Mikhail Verbitsky, a mathematician, is a popular blogger.

title: On the Campaign Trail, Reciting Family History
description: They are certainly a luckless bunch, all those would-be mayors not named Quinn. How improvident of them not to have had a grandparent who booked passage on the Titanic, thereby giving them an interesting legacy of their own for all those reflections on the great ships final moments, a century ago on Sunday.

title: Leading Off: The N.H.L.s Head Games
description: If the N.H.L. had any grasp on long-term reality, it would be curled up in the fetal position at headquarters today. Because for all its occasionally impressive-sounding talk about making the game safer, for all of the discipline guru Brendan Shanahans suspension videos and for all the traditional claptrap about players knowing whats best for the game (which is why, the argument goes, they should patrol it themselves, with their fists), just go ahead and enter the first round of the playoffs into evidence in all of those future concussion lawsuits against the league. While theyre at it, the players should just go ahead and sue one another as well for treating other players heads like piatas.

title: Ancient Chinese Relics to Be Displayed at Discovery Times Square
description: In Times Square, one kind of ancient religious legacy is about to make way for another. Warriors: Defenders of Chinas First Emperor, a new exhibition of artifacts, including 10 of the terracotta soldiers created more than 2,000 years ago to protect Chinas first emperor, Qin Shi Huang, in his afterlife, will open at Discovery Times Square on West 44th Street on April 27. The new exhibition, which succeeds a popular show featuring examples of the Dead Sea Scrolls, will also include a set of gates from an ancient Han burial chamber, never before publicly displayed, and 20 other artifacts that will be shown in the United States for the first time, among dozens of other pieces.

title: Some Tax Breaks Unavailable to Same-Sex Couples
description: Updated: Tuesday, 12:55 p.m., to clarify how the earned income credit works in the example provided.

title: Video of Anders Behring Breivik in Court
description: As my colleagues Mark Lewis and Alan Cowell report, Anders Behring Breivik, the gunman who has admitted that he killed 77 people during twin attacks in Norway last year, appeared in court in Oslo on Monday.

title: Animating Crumb
description: A new museum exhibition in Paris features an interactive animation of a Robert Crumb comic, a collaboration between the American cartoonist and a Belgian digital media artist.

title: Business Day Live | April 16, 2012
description: Weighing an economic slowdown in China and commodities traders boycott an exchange over regulatory dispute.

title: Maggie Smith Departing Downton Abbey? Studio Says Not True
description: It looks like Lady Violet, the Dowager Countess of Downton Abbey, will not yet have the time to discover what a weekend is: Maggie Smith, the actress who portrays that character on Downton Abbey, the hit British costume drama, is not planning to leave that series, a press representative for the studio that produces it said Monday.

title: To Fight a Dam, Rather Than Live on Your Knees
description: At a casual glance, Lake Turkana in northern Kenya may not seem a fount of milk and honey. The temperature around the lake hovers around 100 degrees, and tourists are warned not to approach the water because of the crocodiles and vipers lurking among the volcanic rocks.

description: Weighing an economic slowdown in China, and commodities traders boycott an exchange over a regulatory dispute.

title: GMA Appears to Nudge Today From Top Spot After 16 Years
description: Updated, 11:00 p.m.The morning television shake-up that NBC News said would not come  even as recently as two weeks ago  arrived on Monday when ABCs Good Morning America, based on preliminary weekly ratings, defeated NBCs Today show for the first time in 852 weeks.

title: New York Public Library President is Taking Reader Questions
description: The New York Public Librarys plan to bring its Mid-Manhattan branch and the Science, Industry and Business Library into its lion-flanked Fifth Avenue landmark building  creating a circulating as well as a research library there for the first time  has caused concern among academics and writers.

title: Scenes From Coachella, Day 3
description: A look at some of Sundays performances at Coachella.

title: Kenyans Sweep Top Spots in a Warm Boston Marathon
description: BOSTON  He felt his first cramp in the first mile. With more than 25 miles still to run in unseasonably steamy conditions, Wesley Korir knew then and there that the 116th Boston Marathon was going to be unlike any other race he had ever run.

title: Surviving a Deadly Twister, Twice in 65 Years
description: WOODWARD, Okla.  On April 9, 1947, Wilma Lake was alone in her apartment on Oak Avenue when a tornado swept through this rural town in the dark of night. She survived  crouching beneath a table  but many of her neighbors did not.

title: Video of Taliban Firefight in Kabul and Its Aftermath
description: As my colleague Alissa J. Rubin reports, Afghan forces on Monday ended a complex attack by Taliban fighters in the heart of Kabul and the main cities of three provinces, retaking a building in the capital that had been used as a base of operations.

title: Morning Walkabout: 4/16
description: Parks and Recreation Just in time for summer trip planning, the May issue of Outside magazine features 12 off-the-beaten-path national parks that you just might have to yourself. (Outside)

title: In New York, Tutoring Intensifies in Race to Middle School
description: In New York City, where even seats in public schools can be the rewards of a Darwinian contest, the tutoring industry has found a whole new lode to mine: preparing fourth and fifth graders for the standardized tests that are crucial for getting into top middle schools. The result may be an unfair advantage for families who can afford the extra money and time.

title: Monday Motorsports: Nico Rosberg Wins First Formula One Grand Prix of His Career
description: Nico Rosberg, the Mercedes AMG Petronas driver, was first on the starting grid entering the Chinese Grand Prix on Sunday. Were this the highlight of the weekend for the Mercedes factory team, which hadnt captured a pole since 1955, it would have been momentous, but Rosberg had grander plans.

title: Romney Talks of Ending Some Tax Deductions for Wealthy
description: Mitt Romney inadvertently offered a public preview of some of his economic plans on Sunday, revealing to high-dollar donors at a private fund-raising event that he wants to eliminate tax deductions for wealthy people who own second homes.

title: Numberplay: Living on the Far Side
description: Imagine each of the planets in our solar system were evenly covered by a billion people. At any given moment how many people would be living on the far side? (The far side is the part of a planet not visible from any other planet.)

title: Protesters Arrested in Sleep-Out and Demonstration Near Stock Exchange
description: Updated, 11:24 p.m. | The police arrested four people near the New York Stock Exchange on Monday morning after telling Occupy Wall Street protesters, who have been gathering there for a week, that they were not permitted to sit or lie down on sidewalks. Several additional arrests followed in the evening, with the possibility of more to come.

title: Death Row Inmates Best Lawyer Was Himself
description: WASHINGTON  Albert Holland Jr., a death row inmate in Florida, has no legal training and seems to be suffering from a mental illness  perhaps a disorder involving paranoia or delusional thoughts, a federal judge wrote recently.

description: The Look: Wild. An animal-print tee gets on swimmingly with a pair of black Daisy Dukes and desert boots.

title: China Premier Calls for End to Corruption
description: As a murder and corruption scandal enveloping a former member of Chinas elite leadership continued to snowball, Prime Minister Wen Jiabaoissued a new call on Monday for the government to end a culture of graft lest it lead to the end of Communist rule.

title: Capitals Goalie Takes Rapid Rise Save by Save
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  Just a month ago, 22-year-old goalie Braden Holtby stepped off the ice in St. Johns, Newfoundland. His team, the Hershey Bears of the American Hockey League, had just been defeated, 6-1.
