description: More Photographs

title: In Economics, You Are What You Model
description: Oh, for the days of two-handed economists. Following the 2008 financial crisis, we are instead plagued by warring camps of macroeconomists who agree the profession has achieved a deep understanding of the economy and who disagree about almost every detail.

title: A Population Antidote: High School for Girls
description: High school for girls = population control = sustainable growth.

title: Anheuser-Busch InBev to Take Controlling Stake in Caribbean Brewer
description: Anheuser-Busch InBev, the worlds largest brewer, agreed on Monday to take a controlling stake in the Caribbean drinks maker Cerveceria Nacional Dominicana, or C.N.D., for $1.2 billion.

title: Briton in a Chinese Scandal Reportedly Brokered Overseas Money Transfers
description: BEIJING  Neil Heywood, the British businessman at the center of a scandal involving the former Chinese Politburo member Bo Xilai, was believed to have transferred large sums of money overseas illicitly for Mr. Bos family before his death in November, one person familiar with an inquiry into the case said on Monday.

title: U.N. Council to Expand North Korea Sanctions
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The United Nations Security Council officially censured North Korea on Monday over the failed rocket launching of a satellite last week, saying it strongly condemns the action and had ordered its sanctions committee to expand the blacklist of North Korean goods, companies and individuals connected to that countrys nuclear and missile programs.

title: Supreme Court Rejects Former Enron Chiefs Latest Appeal
description: The Supreme Court on Monday declined to hear the latest appeal by Jeffrey Skilling, the former chief executive of Enron serving a 24-year sentence in a federal prison for his role in the energy companys collapse.

title: Romney Moving Ahead With Search for Running Mate
description: Mitt Romney is starting to bear down on his search for a running mate, but he cautioned in an interview on Monday that a final selection may not come until the Republican convention in August. And he disclosed that he had picked someone to lead the search.

title: Can Roads and Russian Forests Coexist?
description: In 2009, in checking back on development patterns in the Amazon River basin, I examined this question: Can Roads and Rain Forests Co-Exist? Heres a Dot Earth Postcard from Erik Hoffner, a writer and photographer associated with Orion Magazine, examining the same question in the context of Russias old forests and new highway plans. His missive is sent from northern California, not Russia, because hes there to help honor Evgenia Chirikova, a Russian forest campaigner whos the European honoree in this years Goldman Environmental Prize awards.

title: Freedom Comes to Washington
description: President Abraham Lincoln signed the District of Columbia Emancipation Act into law on April 16, 1862, a step heralded by abolitionists across the country. Never before had Congress passed a measure designed to destroy slavery in a place where it was already entrenched. As one newspaper put it: The actual interest at stake was not extensive  a citadel never occupies a large proportion of the territory it represents  but the principle involved in the question was vital. The capitals liberation was, Frederick Douglass wrote, a priceless and an unspeakable blessing for those it freed and the first great step towards that righteousness which exalts a nation.

title: BTG Pactual Chief Fined Over Insider Trading
description: LONDON  Andr Esteves, the chief executive of the Brazilian bank BTG Pactual, was fined 350,000 euros ($457,000) by the Italian financial regulator on Monday for insider trading.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Steven Amato, chief content officer at Omelet, Los Angeles, was named president, a new post, and chief content officer of a new division, Omelet Studio. Omelet also recently formed an agency management committee that is composed of Mr. Amato; Ryan Fey, chief brand officer; and Don Kurz, chairman and chief executive, along with five managing directors: Naj Allana, Mark Anderson, Sarah Cathcart, Sean McNamara and Mike Wallen.

title: The Tappan Zees Future, According to Readers
description: Our call for submissions for how the Tappan Zee Bridge  due to be replaced  might be reimagined as a walkway and/or park drew some thoughtful suggestions, including an edible bridge, a Bridge of Flowers and a call to demolish the thing.

title: Rollaways of BMW 7 Series Sedans Prompt Upgrade of Safety Investigation
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said reports of 16 crashes prompted it to intensify an investigation into whether the automatic transmission on almost 122,000 BMW 7 Series sedans could slide into Neutral and roll away when the driver intended the gear selector to be in Park.

title: Disney to Team With Chinese Company to Make Iron Man 3
description: Iron Man is going to China.

title: Coty Tries to Rally Support for Avon Bid Amid Skepticism
description: If Avon Products stock price is any indicator, Coty still has some work to do in persuading investors in the cosmetics company to accept its $10 billion unsolicited bid.

title: U.S. Candidate Is Chosen to Lead the World Bank
description: WASHINGTON  The World Bank on Monday named as its next president Jim Yong Kim, a global health expert and the president of Dartmouth College, a widely expected appointment that continues the longstanding tradition of an American leading the Washington-based development institution.

title: How the Buffett Rule Would Affect Small Businesses
description: On Monday afternoon, the Senate is poised to consider  if only briefly  the so-called Buffett Rule, President Obamas plan to make sure that millionaires pay at least as much of their income in tax as middle-class Americans. Supporters, however, are not likely to find the 60 votes necessary for the Senate to actually debate the bill.

title: Missing: 5 Guitars Belonging to Tom Petty Band
description: Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers are offering a $7,500 reward for the return of five guitars that were stolen from a studio near Los Angeles where the group was rehearsing for a United States tour, the rock group announced on its Web site. Last Thursday, someone got into the studio in Culver City and made off with two of Mr. Pettys prized instruments  a 1967 12-string Rickenbacker electric and a 1965 Gibson electric. Also missing were three other rare guitars belonging to the bassist Ron Blair, the rhythm guitarist Scott Thurston and the lead guitarist Mike Campbell.

title: Tribeca Film Festival Announces an Eclectic Lineup of Juries
description: The jurors who will decide the winners of the competitive categories at this years Tribeca Film Festival are your usually unusual bunch of entertainment industry notables, including Academy Award winners, up-and-comers and the guy who manages Justin Bieber.

title: Media Companies Ask Judge to Open Florida Defendants File
description: Lawyers representing more than 20 media companies on Monday asked the Florida judge overseeing the trial of George Zimmerman, the neighborhood watch organizer who killed the teenager Trayvon Martin, to unseal the court file.

title: TimesCast | April 16, 2012
description: Afghan forces end an attack by the Taliban | Egyptians face a shifting presidential race | Retraction rates are rising in scientific journals.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Charles McGrath on Dreaming in Caro-ese
description: Charles McGrath, writer at large for The Times, wrote this weeks cover story on the biographer Robert Caro, who just finished the latest volume in a massive biography of Lyndon Johnson that he has been working on for nearly 40 years. McGraths most recent articles for the magazine were on Stephen Colbert and the novelist Nicholson Baker.

title: Ads Urge Book People to Help Children Read
description: A new public service campaign seeking to help children read brings together two collections of all-stars: a Whos Who of literary characters and a lineup of well-known musicians.

title: J.K. Rowling Starts Her Potter Encyclopedia
description: J.K. Rowling may be putting the finishing touches on her first novel for adults, a dark comedy set for release in September, but she hasnt forgotten about Harry Potter.

title: Image of the Day: April 16
The Myth of Shrinking Government
description: Mitt Romney was overheard yesterday telling a group of big donors that he has a secret plan to eliminate a bunch of federal departments and agencies. Because the plan is so terribly secret, he couldnt even tell this friendly group what precisely he plans to cut, but he assured them that he will do plenty of big, important cutting and consolidating.

title: Iraq Election Officials Arrest Casts Doubt on Prospect for Fair Voting
description: BAGHDAD  In making the optimistic case for the development of democracy here, American officials typically point to the 2010 parliamentary elections, which were judged largely free and fair by international monitors including the United Nations. But with the arrest of the head of Iraqs election commission, the prospect for fair elections has been thrown into question.

title: Sex Pistols to Reissue God Save the Queen
description: The Sex Pistols said they would rerelease God Save the Queen in late May for the 35th anniversary of the singles controversial debut back in 1977, the New Musical Express reported. First released during Queen Elizabeths Silver Jubilee, the song created a political firestorm. The lyrics and nihilistic vision of Britains future offended many people and the BBC refused to play it: God save the Queen/ She aint no human being / There is no future / In Englands dreaming. (The Sex Pistols, never ones for understatement, also referred to the British government as a facist regime.) Still, the song went to No. 2 on the British singles chart.

title: The Real Reasons Why You Buy
description: Before we buy something we tell ourselves stories.

title: Milan Furniture Fair | Colour One for Mini
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: The Sound and the Fury
description: Q. What are the noises that M.R.I. machines make?

title: Talk Pizza With Bittman
description: Save the date: Mark Bittman, who argues this week that the best pizza is the kind you make yourself, will host an hourlong chat this Wednesday at 3 p.m. Eastern Daylight Time on The Timess Facebook page (facebook.com/nytimes), answering reader questions on the ins and outs of making pizza. Among the topics to be discussed: how to achieve the perfect crust in a home oven, tricks for working with dough, unusual toppings to embrace, whether its worth investing in a pizza stone and the larger question of what makes for a successful pie. You are welcome to post your pizza-related comments and questions for Mr. Bittman below, but please join in at the appointed hour to participate in the discussion in real time.

title: Gout and About
description: Ive been meaning for a while now to write a follow-up to my gout blog post, the robust reaction to which gratified me and confirmed yet again that so very many of usfor health, ethical, environmental or budgetary reasonsmust carefully limit and choose what we eat, in ways that are often challenging and sometimes even frustrating. But I lacked the time. And I lacked just the right fresh material for an update.

title: Raised-Fist Salute Has Varied Meanings
description: Anders Behring Breivik, the anti-Muslim militant who admitted to killing 77 people in a bombing and shooting spree last year, began his first day of trial on Monday with a disturbing, rod-straight salute of the arm, his fist closed tightly.

title: Tax Day Procrastination Links
description: For nearly two decades, Monsanto and corporate agribusiness have exercised near-dictatorial control over American agriculture. But public opinion is turning against Monsanto, and in November, a statewide citizens ballot initiative will give Californians the opportunity to vote for GMO labeling (a similar measure was introduced in Vermont, but is currently stalled by cowardly legislators). This is going to be huge. By the way, a poll suggests that 60 percent of California voters would support a soda tax. Related: now we finally know whats been missing from our family dinners: Sierra Mist.

title: Fence Is Behind an Explosion of Life in a Wild Corner of Hawaii
description: KAENA POINT, Hawaii  Before Polynesian settlers arrived here hundreds of years ago in their outrigger canoes, Hawaii had more than 120 species of birds  and no mammals to eat them. Land birds flourished in the absence of land predators, and seabirds flew in from all over the world to nest undisturbed on the ground.

title: Protecting Kaena Point
description: Visitors can enter the 60-acre nature reserve through three gates.

title: Homes With Star Quality Are Now Hiring an Agent
description: To step inside Merele Williams-Adkinss deliciously restored Clinton Hill brownstone is to enter a world of 15-foot ceilings, white marble mantels and fabulous art. You feel as though you have sauntered into pages of an elegant furniture catalog, or onto the set of a quirky independent film. And in a sense, you have.

title: Alfredsson Will Not Return for Game 3
description: 7:10 p.m. | Updated

title: Koran Giveaway in Germany Has Some Officials Worried
description: BERLIN  A drive by a fundamentalist Muslim group to give a copy of the Koran to every German, Swiss and Austrian household has tapped into the widespread anti-Islamic feeling in Germany and created an uproar among politicians and security officials concerned that the group handing out the holy books is using the campaign as a cover to recruit radicals.

title: In Mali, Art as Real as Life Itself
description: BAMAKO, Mali  Political tumult in the last few weeks  a military coup, a Tuareg and Islamist takeover in the north  has all but eliminated tourism in this West African nation, which has long been a magnet for Western travelers in search of firsthand encounters with living art traditions.

title: Where Do Our Global Children Belong?
description: What country parents best has become the American neurotic obsession de jour, with the French scoring high points for both the training and the feeding of children, as our colleagues over at the Motherlode blog have been chronicling.

title: Argentina to Seize Control of Oil Company
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Argentinas president, Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner, announced on Monday that the government would seize a majority stake in YPF, the nations largest oil company.

title: Kreider Makes Rangers Debut
description: 7:47 p.m. | Updated

title: After Mistakes, Scientists Try to Explain Themselves
description: Naoki Mori, the Japanese cancer researcher who has had 30 papers retracted by scientific journals, was asked to give his side of the story. In an e-mail, he acknowledged that his colleagues were lax in certain regards in the preparation of papers, but he denied having committed a grave offense.

title: Fashion News Were Reading Now
description: 1:48 p.m. | Updated Status Update: Remember the Fashion NYC2020 survey Mayor Bloomberg announced about two years ago? He and other officials set out to analyze New York Citys fashion industry and, they hoped, identify strategies to better position the city as a global fashion hub. The forecast? Nothing to cheer about, WWD reports. (Read the full report.)

title: For Two Economists, the Buffett Rule Is Just a Start
description: WASHINGTON  High earners who are worried that this years Tax Day will be the last one before their rates rise have more than just the White House and Washington to blame. They can also look to two academically revered, if publicly obscure, left-leaning French economists whose work is the subtext for the battle over tax fairness.

title: Israeli Anger at Foreign Provocateurs Boils Over
description: Updated | 10:11 p.m. Viral video of a senior Israeli Army officer striking a Danish man in the face with a rifle on Saturday in the West Bank, during a mass bicycle ride challenging restrictions on the use of certain roads by Palestinians, has drawn attention to an increasingly acrimonious struggle between the government of Israel and European rights activists who travel to the region.

title: Does Exercise Make You Overeat?
description: Some people respond to exercise by eating more. Others eat less. For many years, scientists thought that changes in hormones, spurred by exercise, dictated whether someones appetite would increase or drop after working out. But now new neuroscience is pointing to another likely cause. Exercise may change your desire to eat, two recent studies show, by altering how certain parts of your brain respond to the sight of food.

title: Want Your College Student to Party Less? Pay Less
description: It may be possible to provide too much support to your college-age children  too much financial support, at least.

title: A Sharp Rise in Retractions Prompts Calls for Reform
description: In the fall of 2010, Dr. Ferric C. Fang made an unsettling discovery. Dr. Fang, who is editor in chief of the journal Infection and Immunity, found that one of his authors had doctored several papers.

title: With Test Week Here, Parents Consider the Option of Opting Out
After 73 Years of Shoes, a Store Is Closing Its Doors
description: Tom Austin Shoes, a 73-year-old mainstay of the Serious Grown-Up Menswear district in the West and East 40s (J. Press, Paul Stuart, Brooks Brothers and others) will be closing at the end of May. It is to reopen later this summer as an Allen Edmonds store, carrying only that manufacturers shoes, belts, apparel and accessories.

title: Matilda Wins Record-Setting Seven Olivier Awards
description: Matilda the Musical, an adaptation of the Roald Dahl novel headed to Broadway next season, won seven Olivier Awards, the London equivalent of the Tonys, on Sunday night.

title: Central Bank Not Expected to Try to Ease Europes Crisis
description: FRANKFURT  As the euro zone crisis shows signs of heating up again, political leaders are once more looking to the European Central Bank for help.

title: U.S. Greenhouse Gas Emissions Headed Up Again
description: After dropping for two years during the recession, emissions of the gases blamed for global warming rose in 2010 as the economy heated up, the Environmental Protection Agency reports.

title: New Home Jersey: Hoops R U.S.
description: If one color has been missing from recent iterations of the jersey worn by United States national team players  men and women  it is most certainly red.

title: Italian Government Takes Steps to Oust Maxxi Museum Board
description: ROME  Less than two years after the opening of Maxxi, Italys national museum of contemporary art, the Italian Culture Ministry last Friday initiated procedures to replace the board of directors of the foundation that manages the museum with a government-appointed administrator. The decision was taken, according a terse statement issued by the ministry, after the board failed to approve the 2012 budget, which is expected to register a significant deficit.

title: Beetles Birth Explosion Puts Trees Under Stress
description: Mountain pine beetles attack and kill weak pine trees, boring into bark to lay their eggs. They attack the trees in hordes, and their larvae feed off fungi in the trees.

title: Table Talk | Donna in Williamsburg
description: Leif Huckman was midslumber when he first found inspiration: I had a dream where I walked to a bar whose door sign read Donna. I let it roll around in my head for a few days, and it felt right. It stuck. The dream, coupled with his longing to have a nearby spot that served both dependable cocktails and late-night snacks culminated in Huckmans new bar Donna, which opens tonight in South Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

title: 2 Pulitzers for Times; Huffington Post and Politico Win
description: The New York Times won two Pulitzer Prizes on Monday for its reporting on Africa and for an investigative series on loopholes that allow the wealthiest Americans and corporations to avoid paying taxes. In a sign of the changing media landscape, two primarily online news outlets, The Huffington Post and Politico, won their first Pulitzer Prizes.

title: On Love and Autism: Our Favorite Student Comments
description: Love on the Spectrum: In the video above, Jack Robison and Kirsten Lindsmith, two college students living in Greenfield, Mass., discuss how autism affects their lives and relationship.

title: 2012 Pulitzer Prizes for Letters, Drama and Music
description: The Pulitzer Prizes were announced on Monday. The complete list of winners in Letters, Drama and Music is below.

title: 2012 Journalism Pulitzer Winners
description: PUBLIC SERVICE

title: They Kill the Tyrant but Cant Seem to Bury Him
description: Greek tragedy, magic realism and pulpy horror movie conventions collide in Jos Riveras Massacre (Sing to Your Children), an assaultive allegorical consideration of the use of violence as a response to life under a repressive regime, and of our own role in perpetuating that tyranny.

title: Real Words or Gibberish? Just Ask a Baboon
description: While baboons cant read, they can tell the difference between real English words and nonsensical ones, a new study reports.

title: Drilling Down: Small Businesses and Location-Based Marketing
description: In this weeks Dashboard roundup of small-business news, we quoted from a blog post in which Brian Honigman, a digital marketing manager for Marc Ecko Enterprises, offers advice on using location-based networks. We went back to Mr. Honigman to dig deeper into how small businesses can use these services. A condensed version of the conversation follows.

title: Carlyle Executives I.P.O. Pitch, in Their Own Words
description: Why invest in the Carlyle Groups stock as the private equity giants initial public offering nears? Let the firms top executives explain.

title: A Return to Celery City
description: I wrote about celery once before long ago; I dont know why, since as I mentioned in my piece Sunday in The Times Magazine, I had detested it. But if youre a food writer for long enough, you get to write about almost everything.

title: Ex-Goldman Director Faces New Insider Trading Claim
description: Rajat K. Gupta, the former director of Goldman Sachs and Procter & Gamble who is accused of leaking secret corporate information to the convicted hedge fund manager Raj Rajaratnam, faces a new insider-trading claim.

title: Nap Time, Brought to You by Daimler
description: According to Daimler, the day is coming when your Mercedes-Benz will no longer sit idly by as your driving fitness erodes.

title: Following the Crowd Isnt Just for Teenagers
description: Many a parent may say that teenagers succumb to peer pressure. A new study reports that toddlers and chimpanzees do too  but orangutans, on the other hand, dont seem to follow the crowd.

title: Community College Serves as a Path to Four-Year Institutions
description: This years graduating class at the Community College of Philadelphia includes many students who will soon enter four-year colleges, including the University of Pennsylvania and Bryn Mawr, Michael Winerip writes this week.

title: Exxon and Russias Oil Company in Deal for Joint Projects
description: HOUSTON  Exxon Mobil and the Russian state oil company Rosneft signed a strategic agreement on Monday that will open American domestic oil and gas fields to Russian investment for the first time.

title: Touched by Bloodshed, Working Now to Spare Others
description: Last month, Tameeka Ford Norville was sitting in her lilac-colored office at the Ingersoll Community Center in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, where she runs an after-school program, when the phone rang. Shots had been fired in the housing projects next door, a resident told her. Ms. Ford Norville locked the centers doors and told her staff to make sure the children were accounted for.

title: On Campus, Opening Up Conversations About Sex
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  For a table set up by a campus student group, this one held some unusual items: a gynecologists speculum, diaphragms, condoms (his and hers) and several packets of lubricant. Nearby, two students batted an inflated condom back and forth like a balloon.

title: The Get | Eliane Fattal for S.J. Phillips Think of Me Ring
description: Nestled in Londons West End on New Bond Street stands the 143-year-old jewelry house S.J. Phillips. Little has changed for the British purveyor of rare and exceptional pieces  some dating back to the 1600s  and thats part of its charm. But every now and then a client comes along who is as distinctive as the gems in the vitrines.

title: Israeli Military Officer Suspended for Striking Activist With Rifle
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli military announced the suspension on Monday of a senior officer caught on videotape striking a Danish pro-Palestinian activist in the face with an M-16 rifle during a standoff between soldiers and participants in a bike tour organized to draw attention to the living conditions of Palestinian villagers in the West Bank.

title: Fire Lieutenant Dies Fighting Brooklyn Warehouse Blaze
description: Updated, 9:58 p.m. | A veteran New York City fire lieutenant died on Monday after battling a three-alarm blaze at a warehouse in Brooklyn, the authorities said.

title: Barclays Unites Corporate Finance and Deal Teams
description: Barclays announced on Monday that it has combined its corporate coverage and deal-making teams into a new corporate finance mergers and acquisitions group, according to an internal memorandum obtained by DealBook. The newly reorganized unit will be led by Tom King, Paul Parker and Ros Stephenson. One specific objective here is to secure more lead left financings and more transformational and one-stop M.&A. deals, Hugh E. McGee III, Barclays global head of investment banking, wrote in the memo.

title: Early Investors See Promise in Palestinian Start-Ups
description: DUBAI  When Yadin Kaufmann helped start Veritas Venture Partners in 1990, Israels technology industry barely existed. Only a handful of companies had gone public on American exchanges and financing was tough to come by.

title: The Science of Obituaries: Dead Pools, Obits in the Can and More
description: In Sundays column, I wrote about the obituaries in The New York Times. I didnt have space to bring a number of elements in so I would like to supplement the column with some additional stuff relating to obits, which I find to be one of the most interesting content elements in The Times.

title: Teenage Birth Rates Continue to Drop
description: Fewer teenagers gave birth in 2010 than in any other year since 1946, government researchers announced last week, and there is good evidence that todays teenagers are initiating sex later and using birth control more consistently than previous generations did.

title: As a Defendant Bullies and Boasts, Questions Arise on a Courts Limits
description: THE HAGUE  In the nine years since his arrival in The Hague, Vojislav Seselj, a Serbian politician, has often harangued judges and has taken pride in provoking and trying to outwit prosecutors. At a recent hearing in his war-crimes trial, he had another bit of theater up his sleeve.

title: Tides and the Titanic (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: TimesCast | Attacks End In Afghanistan
description: April 16, 2012  Afghan forces ended coordinated attacks by the Taliban on Monday. Thirty-eight attackers were killed but civilian casualties were low.

title: In Sickness and Health (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Doctors on Pets (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: TimesCast | Egypt's Presidential Race
description: April 16, 2012  Egypts presidential elections will take place next month, but the field has already changed significantly for voters.

title: Making Babys Shots Less Tearful
description: Infant vaccinations can be a distressing experience for both parent and child. But new research suggests that parents can lessen the sting of an injection by soothing their babies with a quick series of comforting measures, including a popular technique called swaddling.

title: Canadian D.J. to Kick Off a Summer of Canadian Art at Mass MoCA
description: In the pop music world, the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art in North Adams has built substantial indie credibility through its affiliation with Wilco and its sponsorship of the Solid Sound Festival. Now the museum is adding to that reputation by inviting Brendan Canning, a founder of the Canadian musical collective Broken Social Scene, to be the D.J. at a Memorial Day weekend dance party that is part of the opening of an exhibition of Canadian art that will continue through next spring.

title: Now Showing | Backstage at the Vera Wang Bridal Show
description: On Sunday afternoon Vera Wang presented her spring 2013 bridal collection, which, due to its lack of white dresses, didnt feel very bridal at all. Looking to the Far East for inspiration, Wang chose red, a color that is believed to be protective and also to symbolize love, to star in the show. Cinnabar, cherry and scarlet were the hues. Out of the 15 looks presented, 10 were strapless. One standout, a crimson mermaid gown with a hand-draped bodice and inverted flange skirt with embroidered crystal wheat detailing, had everyone in awe. Watch the dresses come to life here in a behind-the-scenes video directed by Don Ashby exclusively for T.

title: Reality TV, No Channel Changing Allowed
description: If reality television didnt exist, Caden Manson/Big Art Group would have had to invent it. The caterwauling banalities and strenuous camp on more or less constant display in the companys Broke House, at the Abrons Arts Center, bring to mind a grad student bingeing on the Bravo channel after taking a bit too much allergy medication.

title: Absorbing Lifes Lessons, Happy or Sad
description: The only generic thing about Barbara Cooks new show at Feinsteins at Loews Regency is its unnecessary title, Lets Fall in Love: unnecessary because everyone familiar with Ms. Cooks voice is already in love with her. Ms. Cook, now 84, still has the goods. By that I mean a darkened soprano that is beautiful by any measure and the gift for conveying a profound empathy.

title: Really? Car Accidents More Frequent on Tax Day
description: THE FACTS

title: Too Many Pills for Aging Patients
description: My 92-year-old aunt was a walking pharmacy, and a month ago it nearly killed her. The episode also cost the American medical system several hundred thousand dollars.

title: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from New York, Norway, Afghanistan and North Korea.

title: Anders Breivik
description: The Anders Breivik trial started in Oslo on Monday. Mr. Breivik, the self-described commander of the Norwegian Resistance Movement, has admitted to killing 77 people in a rampage last July, but according to the story in todays Times has denied criminal responsibility on the grounds that he was protecting Norway from Islamic immigration.

title: Perfecting the Art of Expression in Movements Subtle and Bold
description: A head shuttling over still shoulders, side to side, pupils swiveling along seductively. Thats a cartoon representation of Indian dance, but its nevertheless an essential ingredient of the Bharata Natyam tradition. When Priyadarsini Govind, a Bharata Natyam virtuoso from Chennai, in South India, performs the gesture, her head moves decisively but minimally, the better to set off an extraordinary pair of eyes.

title: Behind the Scenes at Vera Wang Bridal
description: A close look at Vera Wangs spring 2013 bridal collection.

title: Wines and Beers, by the Slice
description: I KNOW what you are thinking: What could possibly be said thats new about wine and pizza? Theres nothing to it. Just pick some fresh Italian red wine, not too expensive, like Barbera dAlba or Dolcetto di Dogliani, and be done with it.

title: Deputy Chancellor Rodriguez Retires
On a Sunday Shift, Caught in the Talibans Sights
description: Nawroz was just a simple cook, working with the 10 masons and carpenters in a partly-finished six-floor building near the Parliament complex in Kabul.

title: The Caucus Click: Securing the Scene for Romney
Seeing Mets Ring in a Desert Spectacle
description: LAS VEGAS  Ten times a week, 48 weeks a year, the Cirque du Soleil spectacle Ka plays inside the MGM Grand Hotel and Casino here. The show, created and directed by Robert Lepage, occupies the custom-built Ka Theater, which has a capacity just under 2,000. Since Ka opened, on Feb. 3, 2005, more than 5.5 million people have arrived amid hissing flames and tribal drums to watch it.

title: Early Works in Church Setting, With a Japanese Twist
description: The Japanese early-music ensemble Anthonello had an unusual programming notion for its New York debut, presented as part of the Early Music Foundations series at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine on Saturday evening. The concert, Music as the Shogun May Have Heard  1591, promised to look at the brief period in the 16th century when Christian missionaries established a foothold in Japan, bringing with them the first Western music heard there.

title: Attention Problems May Be Sleep-Related
description: Diagnoses of attention hyperactivity disorder among children have increased dramatically in recent years, rising 22 percent from 2003 to 2007, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. But many experts believe that this may not be the epidemic it appears to be.

title: Mark Rylance Play, Written With a Favorite Poet, Is Coming to Minneapolis Theater
description: Mark Rylance has cribbed from the work of Louis Jenkins long enough. Having twice recited compositions by Mr. Jenkins, the mischievous poet of Duluth, Minn., in lieu of more traditional acceptance speeches at the Tony Awards, Mr. Rylance will give him proper credit on a new play they have written together that will make its debut at the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis next year.

title: Future, SWV and Kat Edmonson Release New Albums
description: FUTURE

title: Aides Play Down Romneys Talk on Taxes for Wealthy
description: Senior advisers to Mitt Romney said Monday that Mr. Romney, the presumptive Republican nominee for president, was merely tossing around ideas, not making policy announcements, when his chat with donors about some significant changes to the tax code was overheard by reporters at a fund-raiser this weekend.

title: Coachella, Part 1: Few Surprises
description: INDIO, Calif.  Well, in the end its a business. But so it is at the beginning, and in the middle.

title: Endless Screenings Dont Bring Everlasting Health
description: This month, nine major medical specialty groups published a list of 45 tests and procedures that often have no clear benefit for patients and can cause harm  CT scans for simple headaches, for example, and X-rays for routine lower back pain. You dont often hear calls from doctors for fewer tests and procedures.

title: Defending Muslim Law From Those Invoking It
description: There are good ways and bad ways to die. Then there was the death afforded, around A.D. 750, to a Persian political adviser named Ibn al-Muqaffa. His limbs were dispatched from his body, and he was forced to watch as they were roasted slowly in an oven.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: E-Book Covers and Digital Resurrection
description: Here are some of the most interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Monday. There are more here.

title: Pizza and Calzone Recipes
description: Have a ball of pizza dough in front of you? Heres what to do with it.

title: Reasons for Cohabiting
description: To the Editor:

title: $800 Million Target for Romney Campaign and Republican Committee
description: 9:28 p.m. | Updated  A new joint fund-raising initiative between Mitt Romney and the Republican National Committee will aim to raise $800 million by November, part of what Mr. Romneys campaign estimates will be a total of $1 billion spent to defeat President Obama and elect Mr. Romney, a former Massachusetts governor.

title: Not Mere Companions
description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklyns Northside Festival Unveils Lineup
description: The rapper GZA, one of the founders of the Wu-Tang Clan, will perform all the songs from his landmark 1995 album Liquid Swords as part of this years Northside Festival in Brooklyn, organizers announced Monday. He will be backed up by Grupo Fantasma, a Latin funk outfit from Texas.

title: Using Opioids to Treat Pain
description: To the Editor:

title: Graham Company Plans Move to Cunningham Studios
description: The place probably has good dance vibes.

title: The Challenge of Going Vegan
description: From Bill Clinton to Ellen DeGeneres, celebrities are singing the benefits of a vegan diet. Books that advocate plant-based eating are best sellers. But is eliminating meat and dairy as simple as it sounds?

title: Pulitzer Prizes: The Effects of War at Home
description: Craig F. Walker of The Denver Postwas awarded his second Pulitzer Prize on Monday afternoon for Welcome Home: The Story of Scott Ostrom, which won in the feature category. And Massoud Hossaini of Agence France-Presse won the 2012 prize for breaking news photography for his coverage of a bloody attack in Afghanistan  his third major award for the image.

title: Nationals Beginning to See Their Moves Pay Off
description: WASHINGTON  Except for a few seasons, including several dating to Calvin Coolidges presidency, baseball has been unkind to Washington. Whether as the Senators, who deserted the city twice, or the Nationals, Washingtons teams have been a fixture at the bottom of the standings. They made it to Broadway in the hit play Damn Yankees, but in the world of baseball, they have been a continual flop.

title: Pulitzer Fiction Snub Has Book Publishers Fuming
description: Just when the publishing industry thought things couldnt get any worse.

title: Friendship, Competition, Pathogens: Gauging an Outbreak at the Olympics
description: In anticipation of the Summer Olympics in London in July, The Lancet Infectious Diseases, a British medical journal, has been publishing a series exploring the possibility that the Games could trigger a global outbreak of disease.

title: Are Young Social Activists Too Idealistic?
description: To the Editor:

title: Patterns: Doctors Stake in Lab Affects Biopsy Rate
description: Urologists with a financial interest in a laboratory send more prostate biopsies for analysis and have a lower rate of cancer detection than those who use independent labs, according to a new study.

title: A Rise in Retractions
description: April 16, 2012 - Science writer Carl Zimmer interviewed Dr. Arturo Casadevall about the recent rise in retractions in scientific journals.

title: Risks: More Signs of Rests Regulatory Powers
description: Researchers have found further experimental evidence that inadequate sleep can increase the risk of obesity and diabetes. A five-week study showed that sleep disruption decreases insulin secretion, increases blood glucose levels and slows metabolism enough to lead to significant weight gain.

title: G.S.A. Officials Get a Grilling Over a Trip to Las Vegas
description: WASHINGTON  It is a remarkable moment when Congressional Democrats and Republicans turn their scorn from each other and join forces to focus it on someone else.

title: Hazards: Poor Health in Pregnancy Linked to Delays
description: A mothers diabetes, hypertension or obesity during pregnancy may increase her childs risk of autism and developmental problems.

title: Knicks Are Back Where They Started
description: The season was new, hope was abundant and the Garden was four shades of jolly after the Knicks defeated the Boston Celtics on Christmas Day. All things seemed possible.

title: The Buffett Rule: Right Goal, Wrong Tool
description: Syracuse

title: In Senate, Republicans Block Debate on Buffett Rule
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Republicans on Monday blocked a move to open debate on the so-called Buffett Rule, ensuring that a measure pressed for months by President Obama and Senate Democrats to ensure that the superrich pay a tax rate of at least 30 percent will not come to a decisive vote.

title: The Well transformation; cutting corners in science; and sex at Harvard.
description: The Well transformation; cutting corners in science; and sex at Harvard.

title: Is Support for Gay Rights Still Controversial?
As the Jets Regroup, Holmes Has No Regrets
description: The Jets reconvened Monday for the first time since the day after their season ended in dysfunction and despair, a teachable moment that presented an opportunity for introspection and self-improvement.

title: Lewis Nordan, Writer Who Spun Lyrical Tales, Dies at 72
description: Lewis Nordan, a Mississippi-born writer whose fiction conjures a dreamlike world that straddles the whisker-thin margin between a legend and a lie, but whose best-known novel was based on a historical murder of national import, died on Friday in Cleveland. He was 72.

title: With Jeter Hot, and Other Yankees Not, It May Be Too Hard to Rest Him
description: With a three-run homer and a double in Sunday nights victory over the Los Angeles Angels, Derek Jeter continued his terrific start to the season. He had 15 hits, including a team-high six extra-base hits, and through nine games, he was off to the third-best start in his career.

title: How Well, and How Poorly, We Harvest Ocean Life
description: To hear some people tell it, the increasingly energetic and sophisticated fishing industry has left the worlds oceans a shambles, with species of cod, sharks, tuna and other fish hunted almost to extinction and vast stretches of the ocean floor wrecked by bottom-scraping trawlers.

title: Call to Restore Income Tax on Suburbanites
description: The Manhattan borough president, Scott M. Stringer, will call on Tuesday for restoring New York Citys long-abandoned suburban commuter tax to help stabilize the finances of the regions creaky mass transit network.

title: Iran: Ready to Resolve Dispute, and Eager to Ease Sanctions
description: Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Salehi said Monday that Iran was prepared to resolve the nuclear dispute with world powers at their next meeting, in Baghdad on May 23, if the West showed some good will by easing the sanctions imposed on Iran. Mr. Salehi, above, also hinted that Iran might be willing to change its uranium enrichment policy, which is at the heart of foreign suspicions that the Iranians are secretly developing the capacity to make nuclear weapons. The first talks in 15 months on the dispute adjourned Saturday with both sides calling them constructive. Mr. Salehi told the Iranian Student News Agency that the talks were a turning point in the Iran-West dialogue. Still, neither the United States nor the European Union has indicated any intention to ease the sanctions, which their proponents call necessary to press Iran to negotiate in good faith. On Monday, United Against Nuclear Iran, a pro-sanctions group based in New York, said that Porsche AG, the German auto company, would end its business in Iran, making it the second carmaker to do so this month.

title: Jones and Mets Facing Off for a Final Season
description: ATLANTA  The longtime Braves third baseman Chipper Joness announcement that he would retire at the end of the year has turned this season into a farewell tour of sorts.

title: Economy or Personality?
description: With the focus now fully on the campaign between Barack Obama and Mitt Romney, commentary about the issues, the voting blocs and the strategies of the two campaigns dominates political discourse. But having polled on the last 10 presidential elections, Im struck by a meta-question about each candidates viability that may trump all else. Obama and Romney both carry so much political baggage that one or the other will have to defy modern political history to win in November.

title: Echoes of the End of the Raj
description: London

title: Greece: Ex-Official Is Detained
description: Akis Tsochatzopoulos, a former defense minister, was detained Monday after testifying in connection with a money-laundering racket he is accused of using to conceal under-the-table payments from military-procurement deals. With elections on May 6, the authorities are eager to show foreign creditors that action is being taken to stamp out the corruption that contributed to Greeces dysfunctional state. Mr. Tsochatzopoulos has denied any wrongdoing.

title: Justices Weigh Overtime Exemption for Drug Firm Representatives
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court considered on Monday whether representatives of pharmaceutical companies who visit doctors offices to promote their companies products are entitled to overtime. The answer turns on whether those visits are sales calls or something else.

title: Mali: Ancient Books Stolen
description: The United Nations expressed alarm on Monday over the safety of ancient books and documents in the storied city of Timbuktu as reports said that rebels had pillaged and looted the Ahmad Baba Institute of Higher Islamic Studies and Research, as well as other institutions. Many of the archives document Timbuktus golden era between the 12th and 15th centuries. Irina Bokova, director general of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, appealed to Malis neighbors and art collectors to refrain from trying to sell the stolen items and urged warring factions in Mali to respect Timbuktus rich history as a cultural crossroads and center of learning.

title: South Sudan: Blasts at U.N. Site
description: The United Nations said Monday that one of its peacekeeping compounds in South Sudan sustained material damage over the weekend when it was hit with five bombs. No United Nations employees were hurt, but two people on the base were killed, initial reports said. Susan E. Rice, the American ambassador to the United Nations, condemned the attack, which is under investigation, and she called the escalating violence between South Sudan and Sudan a threat to regional as well as international peace and security.

title: Embarrassed by Bad Laws
description: A year ago, few people outside the world of state legislatures had heard of the American Legislative Exchange Council, a four-decade-old organization run by right-wing activists and financed by business leaders. The group writes prototypes of state laws to promote corporate and conservative interests and spreads them from one state capital to another.

title: In a Changing Market, Low Prices vs. More Comfort
description: IN the past, when domestic airlines talked about providing more comfortable service for passengers in coach, the conventional wisdom always cleared its throat and pointed out that this had not worked. No, the conventional wisdom insisted, passengers are interested only in getting the cheapest fare.

title: Disabilities Act Prompts Flood of Suits Some Cite as Unfair
description: A small cadre of lawyers, some from out of state, are using New York Citys age and architectural quirkiness as the foundation for a flood of lawsuits citing violations of the Americans With Disabilities Act.

title: Talking With Iran
description: Irans agreement over the weekend to hold a new round of nuclear talks next month with the United States and five other powers is a constructive development. On Monday, Irans foreign minister, Ali Akbar Salehi, said Tehran is ready to resolve its nuclear disputes quickly and easily and suggested flexibility on uranium enrichment.

title: When Mom Travels for Work
description: Amy Kossoff Smith, the founder of a parenting Web site, has a ritual when she has to go on the road. She leaves a printed itinerary of all the carpools, sports practices and games, baby-sitter hours and anything else her husband might need.

title: Witness Details Plot to Attack Subways
description: At Al Qaedas terrorist camp in the mountains of Pakistan, three former high school classmates from Queens encountered heavily armed Islamic militants from all over the world.

title: Romneys Favorability Is Weakest on Record, Polling Shows
description: Mitt Romney is facing a severe crisis of popularity.

title: Mothers Will Get the Glory in P.&G.s Campaign
description: THERE are few things that seem more patriotic than mothers and the Olympics. On Tuesday, Procter & Gamble, the worlds largest advertiser, will announce its new campaign  its biggest ever  called Thank You, Mom, focusing on thanking mothers of Olympians and would-be Olympians around the world.

title: Maersk Mc-Kinney Moeller, Longtime Shipping Magnate, Dies at 98
description: Maersk Mc-Kinney Moeller, an immensely rich and powerful Danish businessman who transformed his familys shipping company into the worlds largest, died on Monday in Copenhagen. He was 98.

title: Fists Are Up, and So Are the Penalties
description: The signature image of the opening games of the first round of the Stanley Cup playoffs has not been a dramatic overtime goal or an acrobatic save.

title: Make-or-Break Verbs
description: This is the third in a series of writing lessons by the author.

title: In Schools Cut by the City Ax, Students Bleed
description: New York City is filled with schools marked twice over for death.

title: Ex-Teacher at Bronx Private School Accused of Sexual Misconduct
description: A former math teacher at Riverdale Country School in the Bronx was arrested Monday on charges of engaging in sexual conduct with a teenage student.

title: An Unexpected Memento While Walking at OHare, And Other Misadventures
description: I REMEMBER my first business trip.

title: Alabama Digs a Deeper Hole
description: A new legislative session has given Alabama lawmakers an opportunity to repeal the cruel, destructive and embarrassing immigration law they passed last year  the worst in the nation. It looks as if theyre blowing it.

title: Homelessness Among Female Veterans
description: The Veterans Affairs Department is in the middle of an ambitious five-year plan to end homelessness among veterans by 2015. It should make sure that this effort protects the vulnerable population of women, whose risks and needs can be far different from those of men.

title: Stock Split for Google That Cements Control at the Top
description: Its stupid, Larry Page, Googles co-founder and chief executive, exclaimed about the prospect of splitting the companys shares. If you own 10 shares at $40 or one share at $400, its the same thing! You just need to know how to divide.

title: How Does Press Irk Cuomo? Document Offers Clues
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is known to be sensitive to news coverage of his administration, and his aides are often quick to chastise reporters who write things they find objectionable.

title: The White House Argument
description: Ive been critical of President Obamas budgets. Ive argued that while I like the way Obama preserves spending on things like scientific research and programs for the vulnerable, he doesnt do enough to avoid a debt crisis.

title: Sons Parties and Privilege Aggravate Fall of Elite Chinese Family
description: BEIJING  As the grandson of revolutionary giants, Bo Guagua enjoyed the prestige and privilege that accompanies membership in Chinas red aristocracy.

title: Santorum to His Supporters: Stay Tuned
description: Rick Santorum said Monday night that he would be active in the presidential campaign, but he did not endorse Mitt Romney or encourage voters in states like Pennsylvania to vote for Mr. Romney in their coming primaries.

title: After Refining Image, New Scandal for Secret Service
description: WASHINGTON  For an agency that has long been known as a good ol boys club, the prostitution scandal involving 11 members of the Secret Service has dredged up an image that the agency appeared to have moved beyond.

title: Licensing Push After 2 Deaths From Elevators
description: Elevator technicians would have to be licensed to work in New York City under legislation proposed at a public hearing on Monday and written in response to two elevator deaths in Manhattan in the last four months.

title: City Settles Lawsuit That Claimed Bias and Retaliation
description: New York City has agreed to pay $750,000 to a blackofficial of the citysHuman Resources Administration who had claimed in a lawsuit that the agencys commissioner and others had retaliated against her because she had complained aboutcontracting practices.

title: Turning the Tables on Russia
description: Who knew that what corrupt Russian officials care about, more than just about anything, is getting their assets  and themselves  out of their own country? They own homes in St. Tropez, fly to Miami for vacation and set up bank accounts in Switzerland. They understand the importance of stashing their money someplace where the rule of law matters, which is most certainly not Russia. Besides, getting out of Russia is one of the pleasures of being a corrupt Russian official.

title: Last Resort, So Checkout Is a Problem
description: Peering through her silver lorgnette, the martini-packing woman with the big jewelry is woozy with disorientation. Theres certainly nothing familiar about this terrain, says the woman, Babe, an aging heiress played by Shirley Knight in the murky stew of exotica called In Masks Outrageous and Austere, which opened on Monday night at the Culture Project.

title: Look Over There
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  This puzzle evoked a great deal of nostalgia for me. Not that signs with arrows on them are necessarily nostalgic, but I admit to having owned an IM WITH STUPID T-shirt back in the day, and having my friends jockeying not to be standing on the pointing arrow side of me. Ah, adolescence.

title: ... And Love Handles for All
description: What if we have it backward? What if the 310-pound man trying to jam into the middle seat and the 225-pound woman breaking into a sweat only halfway up the stairs arent the undisciplined miscreants of modern American life but the very emblems of it?

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 16, 2012

title: Income Earned by the Wealthiest
description: Work by the French economists Emmanuel Saez and Thomas Piketty shows income inequality growing in the United States, with the top 1 percent of earners taking home more and more of the nations income.

title: Afghan Assaults Signal Evolution of a Militant Foe
description: WASHINGTON  Western military and intelligence officials acknowledged on Monday that they were surprised by the scale and sophistication of the synchronized attacks in Afghanistan on Sunday, seeing it as a troubling step in the evolution of the Haqqani Taliban network from a crime mob to a leading militant force.

title: Impact of Atlantic Yards, for Good or Ill, Is Already Felt
description: The battle over Atlantic Yards has already raged longer than the Civil War, with eight years of protests, petitions and lawsuits seeking to halt a project that promised to reshape the heart of Brooklyn.

title: Notes on Poll-Watching, as Shift Toward General Election Season Begins
description: In a couple of weeks, well be starting our FiveThirtyEight forecasts for the general election. But theres still a fair amount of work to get those ready, and we seem to be seeing an increasing number of head-to-head polls pairing President Obama against Mitt Romney in the meantime. Thus, as we transition into general election season, I wanted to articulate a few quick reminders about the philosophy I take toward looking at these polls and other important pieces of general-election related data.

title: Predators Weber Is Villain to Red Wings Fans
description: DETROIT  Nashville Predators captain Shea Weber realizes that he is probably not the most popular person visiting Detroit right now.

title: An Online TV Site Grows Up
description: Five years ago, some of the most powerful players in television banded together to introduce Hulu, a streaming service intended to revolutionize the TV industry.

title: Bad Decisions, Good Intentions
description: HUNTINGDON, Tenn.  Carroll Academy warmed up on one end of the court. Sacred Heart of Jesus, a private Roman Catholic high school in Jackson, Tenn., warmed up on the other. The thump, thump, thump of basketballs bouncing on the wood floor echoed through the vast emptiness of the Jackson Community College gym.

title: Davis Strikes a Telling Blow Against a Nemesis
description: ATLANTA  Tommy Hanson has one of the best curveballs in baseball. Ike Davis, it is known, prefers fastballs.

title: Middle School Chess Team Wins National High School Championship
Boyle Unstoppable, Lundqvist Untouchable
description: OTTAWA  The Rangers and the Senators stuck to hockey in Game 3 of their playoff series Monday night, leaving the sucker-punching, brawling and elbowing of the previous two games behind.

title: Yankees Knock Around Pavano Early, but the Twins Get to Garcia Often
description: During four injury-riddled years as a Yankee, Carl Pavano tormented hometown fans, managing only 26 starts and 9 victories from 2005 to 2008. He has been healthy since leaving the Bronx, and on Monday night, he dispensed more anguish to those same fans, this time wearing another uniform.

title: Feisty Start to the Playoffs
description: Brawls, dangerous hits and questionable tactics in the N.H.L. postseason.

title: N.H.L.s Shanahan Explains Weekend Suspensions
description: OTTAWA  On Monday morning Brendan Shanahan, the N.H.L.s chief disciplinarian, explained why he suspended the Rangers Carl Hagelin three games for elbowing Ottawas Daniel Alfredsson and the Senators Matt Carkner one game for attacking Brian Boyle in Saturdays Game 2.

title: Veteran Defenseman Is Valuable Voice for Panthers in the Playoffs
description: SUNRISE, Fla.  Mounted on the back wall of the BankAtlantic Center press box is a photograph of a young, clean-shaven Ed Jovanovski celebrating a berth in the 1996 Stanley Cup finals with the Florida Panthers.

title: N.F.L. and Union Meet on Bounties
description: With the N.F.L. still considering discipline for New Orleans Saints defensive players involved in the teams bounty program, members of the players unions leadership  including Saints quarterback Drew Brees, the former Saints linebacker Scott Fujita, whose name has surfaced in connection with the bounties, and the union executive director DeMaurice Smith  met with league officials Monday.

title: Woman Saved by Newark Mayor Speaks Out
description: A Newark woman who was rescued from a fire Thursday by Mayor Cory Booker has given her first interview.

title: A Steady Postseason Presence in Goal Sets the Tone for a Victory
description: OTTAWA  In the third period of Monday nights playoff game, at a point when the Ottawa Senators appeared to be threatening to gain control, Rangers goalie Henrik Lundqvist lost his stick with at least one Senator in an ideal shooting position.

title: New Yorks Poverty Rate Rises, Study Finds
description: The number of New Yorkers classified as poor in 2010 increased by nearly 100,000 from the year before, raising the poverty rate by 1.3 percentage points to 21 percent  the highest level and the largest year-to-year increase since the city adopted a more detailed definition of poverty in 2005.

title: Once Every 36 Years, Primary Fight for Indiana Senator
description: INDIANAPOLIS  At age 80, Richard G. Lugar, one of the longest-serving members of the United States Senate, is getting a crash course in what a campaign looks like.

description: INTERNATIONAL

description: reverent \rev-rnt, re-v-; re-vrnt\ adjective

title: Antipoverty Tax Program Offers Relief, Though Often Temporary
description: DURHAM, N.C.  Karen Spain spent several long months before receiving her tax refund this year in a state of suspended panic. The rent was three months late. Her cars brakes were shot. And she could no longer afford to pay her electricity bill.

title: Prosecutor Who Ran Ethics Unit Leaves Justice Dept.
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department on Monday announced the departure of a high-profile prosecutor who ran its ethics unit during the botched case against Senator Ted Stevens and has since played a prominent role in the Obama administrations efforts to prosecute officials for leaking information to the press.

title: Panetta Reassessing His Travel Options
description: Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta said Monday that he was looking for less expensive alternatives to his travel most weekends from Washington to his walnut farm in Carmel Valley, Calif., which costs taxpayers close to $32,000 per trip. Mr. Panetta is required to travel on military aircraft so he can remain in constant and secure contact with the White House and national security officials. The Associated Press has calculated that his 27 round-trips to California since he took office in July have cost the government as much as $860,000. So far he has reimbursed taxpayers $17,000, or $630 per trip, based on a government formula. Mr. Panetta said at a news conference that he regretted the cost and was studying alternatives that might save money and also enable him to fulfill his responsibilities not only to my job, but my family. He gave no hint about the alternatives. The Pentagon press secretary, George Little, said that no one wants the secretary of defense making decisions on classified military operations from the middle seat on a crowded commercial jet.

title: Rangers-Senators Replay: Game 3
description: A look at the Rangers win against the Ottawa Senators in Game 3 of the teams first-round playoff series.

title: News Quiz | April 17, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Champions League Preview: Would a Barcelona-Madrid Final in May Be Trouble for Spain in June?
description: Cristiano Ronaldo set a Spanish league record on Saturday by scoring his 41st goal of the season in Real Madrids win over Sporting Gijon, but Spains newspapers didnt even get a chance to report the unprecedented feat before Barcelonas Lionel Messi matched it with two against Levante that day.

title: Thinking About a Round-Trip Ticket From Myanmar
description: HONG KONG  Does Daw Aung San Suu Kyi dare travel abroad yet? Would her departure create a flash point for reactionary generals to roll back recent reforms in Myanmar and block her return? And if she does take the risk, where will she go first?

title: April 17, 1961 | The Bay of Pigs Invasion Against Castro
description: On April 17, 1961, about 1,500 C.I.A.-trained Cuban exiles began the Bay of Pigs invasion of Cuba in what would become a failed attempt to overthrow the government of Fidel Castro, the Marxist revolutionary who had seized power in January 1959.

title: On Witness Stand, Norwegian Says He Would Kill Again
description: OSLO  Demanding his acquittal, a self-styled anti-Islamic militant on trial for killing 77 people in Norways worst peacetime atrocity took the stand for the first time on Tuesday, describing the deaths as the most spectacular sophisticated political act in Europe since the Second World War and saying he would do it again.

title: Test Yourself | English, April 17, 2012
description: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the theater review Rapping Your Mind-State Around Darwin.

title: 100 Tornadoes in 24 Hours
description: WHERE did more than 100 tornadoes strike in 24 hours? (This map may help.)

title: Meet Nancy Powell, the United States New Ambassador to India
description: Nancy Powell, the first female American ambassador designate to India, will arrive in New Delhi later this week bearing a few words of Hindi, a much-used camera and ambitious plans for the countries relationship, according to an introductory video released Tuesday by the Embassy.

title: Searching for the Next Snuggie
description: The Inventors Association of Manhattan meets on the second Monday of each month in the conference room of a Times Square law firm. I went to their most recent meeting to explore an idea that Ive been hearing a lot about lately  that we are living in a golden age of the independent inventor. Or as Ron Reardon, a patent agent who was a guest speaker that evening, explained, the odds of making money arent good  1 in 100, 1 in 1000, Im not sure  but they are better than the lottery.

title: What They Said: Indias Interest Rate Cut
description: The Reserve Bank of India has cut the repo rate, or the rate that it lends money to commercial banks, by 50 basis points to 8 percent, the first rate cut in three years. The Reserve Bank left the reserve repo rate and cash reserve ratio, or amount of cash banks must keep on hand, unchanged at 7 percent and 4.75 percent, respectively.

title: Should Couples Live Together Before Marriage?
description: According to a recent Op-Ed, a majority of young adults in their 20s will live with a romantic partner at least once, and more than half of all marriages will be preceded by cohabitation. Why do you think this is? Why do you think of cohabiting, or living together before marriage, in general? Why?

title: The Taliban Attacks: Afghanistan
description: A series of brazen attacks by the Taliban rocked Afghanistan on Sunday, with suicide bombers and gunmen staging offensives in Kabul and three eastern provinces for nearly 18 hours. A Taliban spokesman said the attacks were a message to those foreign commanders who claim that the Taliban lost momentum.

title: Yes, I Took My Ninth Grader on a College Tour (and It Was Worth It)
description: Dave Marcus is the author of Acceptance: A Legendary Guidance Counselor Helps Seven Kids Find the Right Colleges  and Find Themselves (Penguin Press).

title: Fantasy Focus: Early Player Movement
description: We at RotoWire spend a lot of time trying to tell you how to manage your teams, be it on the radio or in our advice articles. But sometimes its more helpful to see tangible results  how are those who are investing their own hard-earned money managing their rosters? Who are the top pickups, and just as importantly, who is getting dropped?

title: Frito-Lay Pledges a Major Shift Toward Natural-Gas Trucking
description: On Tuesday, Frito-Lay announced it would add 67 trucks that would run on compressed natural gas, known as C.N.G., to its fleet. Eventually, the company said, a majority of its longer-range vehicles would run on C.N.G., as well as liquefied natural gas for longer-distance hauls.

title: Do Small Businesses Create Jobs?
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

description: Matt Waldman is the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, a testament to his obsession with film analysis, now available for download.  Examples of his work can be found at his blog. He is helping the Fifth Down rank skill position players before the draft: 1. Michael Floyd, Notre Dame (6-2, 220)

title: Australia to Withdraw From Afghanistan Earlier Than Planned
description: HOBART, Australia  Prime Minister Julia Gillard of Australia said on Tuesday that she expected her country to complete its military withdrawal from Afghanistan a year ahead of schedule, citing recent security improvements there while also acknowledging that the peoples of the worlds democracies are weary of this war.

title: Q. & A.: Michael Brune, Executive Director of the  Sierra Club
description: All environmental politics is local, and local politics can be fierce, particularly at the Sierra Club. Witness members outrage over the revelation in February that the group had accepted $26 million for its Beyond Coal campaign from a natural gas company, Chesapeake Energy.

title: From Bleak Central India, a Peoples Movement
description: In Pati, an impoverished region in the central Indian state of Madhya Pradesh, members of the Barela tribe often work as laborers for less than a dollar a day. Drought and logging have reduced what was once a lush forest to a mountainous desert, and many members of the community moved away to survive.

description: HONG KONG  The Indian central bank cut interest rates sharply on Tuesday in a sign that worries about slowing economic growth are starting to outweigh concerns about stubbornly high inflation.

description: A week of early skirmishes between President Obama and Mitt Romney suggests that their campaigns are prepared for a spring and early summer filled with repeated expressions of political umbrage.

title: Goldman Profit Falls 23%, but It Surpasses Analysts Forecasts
description: 7:35 p.m. | Updated

title: Quiet Additions to a Modernist Masterpiece
description: RONCHAMP, France  Completed in 1955, Le Corbusiers hilltop chapel of Notre Dame du Haut in this hardscrabble patch of eastern France attracts some 100,000 supplicants each year, architectural and religious. If critics still sometimes blame Le Corbusier for inspiring generations of soulless, cookie-cutter housing projects and office parks, he remains the high priest of Modernism for singular works like this.

title: Site to Be Seen | Threadflip.com
description: Manik Singh never claimed to know much about fashion. What the Silicon Valley-based engineer did know was that his wife, Theresa, had a little closet problem  that is, a collection of unworn items clogging up the racks. But when he asked her (and other female friends) why they held on to these garments, the answer he kept hearing was: Its too hard to do anything else with them.

title: The Taliban Attacks: Pakistan
description: LONDON  On Sunday before dawn more than 100 Taliban equipped with automatic weapons and rocket-propelled grenades stormed the central prison in Bannu, a town adjoining the restive tribal belt along Pakistans border with Afghanistan. After blasting the main gate with explosives and blowing holes through walls, they freed 384 prisoners, among them Adnan Rashid, a former Pakistan Air Force technician who was on death row for plotting to assassinate former President Pervez Musharraf.

title: Spain Weighs Response to Nationalization of YPF
description: MADRID  Repsol YPF, the Spanish oil company, said Tuesday that it would seek at least $10.5 billion in compensation for Argentinas planned nationalization of its extensive operations there.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: A Hollywood Agent Goes Bollywood
description: As interest in Bollywood continues to grow in the United States, American talent agencies are taking note. Jai Khanna, a manager with Brillstein Entertainment Partners, is targeting talent from India, hoping to bring them into the American mainstream. Beverly Hills-based Brillsteins client list, which already included heavyweights like Brad Pitt, Adam Sandler and Bill Maher, now boasts Irrfan Khan and Hrithik Roshan, and could soon welcome many more Bollywood names, if Mr. Khanna has his way.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Corporate Control at Google, and a New Tupac Tour?
description: Hulu, created as an online service for watching network television, will pitch original programming to advertisers on Thursday as part of the upfronts, which are typically reserved for cable channels and network broadcasters. It is quite a shift for Hulu, which is growing steadily (two million subscribers for its $8-a-month Hulu Plus service), Amy Chozick and Brian Stelter write, despite disagreements among its corporate owners, and the new restrictions those owners have placed on free streaming of network shows.

title: Steps From a Terrorism Trial, No Signs of Fear
description: Here are things that took place in Cadman Plaza Park in Brooklyn Heights around noon on an uncommonly warm Monday:

title: Tuesday Reading: Fatal Car Crashes Rise on Tax Day
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Britain Arrests Muslim Cleric, Again Seeking Deportation
description: LONDON  The British authorities on Tuesday rearrested Abu Qatada, a radical Muslim cleric who was released from prison in February after a European court overruled British judges and blocked his deportation to Jordan on terrorism charges. They said they would resume efforts to remove him from Britain.

title: Bill Clinton Is Headliner at Sustainability Enclave
description: The Sustainable Operations Summit, an annual meeting of leaders from the political, business and environmental spheres, will unfold this week in New York City with Bill Clinton as the keynote speaker.

title: Young People Tire of Old Economic Models
description: At the recent United Nations conference on gross national happiness,a scattering of young participants looked on with a clear sense of urgency as mainly graying dignitaries, economists, scholars and others pondered ways to gauge progress that go beyond traditional monetary measures. One was Christopher Stampar, a sophomore from the University of Miami who works for the nonprofit group Nourish 9 Billion. He received one of the most enthusiastic rounds of applause when he let it slip that he was 19. Read his blog post on the experience here.

title: Obama Calls for Increased Oversight of Oil Markets
description: 11:25 p.m. | Updated  Read a revised version of this post.

title: Daily Report: Google Founders Solidify Power
description: Andrew Ross Sorkin looked at Google decision to split its its shares in his weekly column on DealBook. He does not mince words on Larry Page, Googles co-founder and chief executive.

title: Not Shaken, Not Stirred: James Bond Drinks Beer
description: James Bond may never lose his taste for fast cars or dangerous women, but his famous preference for martinis  shaken, not stirred  will be broadened in his next film adventure to allow for the occasional swig of mass-market Dutch lager. This latest sign of the times is a result of a product placement deal between the brewers of Heineken beer and the producers of the James Bond movie franchise, one that even the series star, Daniel Craig, is lamenting as unfortunate.

title: Push in Paris for More Pressure on Syria as Money Ebbs and Cease-Fire Wobbles
description: PARIS  International sanctions aimed at the Syrian government have cut its financial reserves in half, and pressure must be maintained on Damascus to stop its bloody crackdown on opponents despite a shaky five-day cease-fire, the French foreign minister, Alain Jupp, said on Tuesday.

description: Good morning. Be sure to file your taxes early so you have enough time to enjoy thesunny day, with temperatures climbing into the mid-70s.

title: Vodafone Takes Legal Action Over Tax Proposal in India
description: LONDON  The British telecommunications giant Vodafone said Tuesday that it had started legal proceedings against the Indian government over a proposed retroactive tax law that could cost the company more than $2 billion.

title: For Chefs at Home, a Pie Above the Rest
description: IM here  back in the Dining section with a new column  to insist once again that not only can you cook it at home, but you can likely cook it better.

title: Stocks Climb on Profits and Spains Debt Sale
description: Stock markets rose Tuesday on both sides of the Atlantic, propelled by encouraging corporate profits, a well-received sale of government debt in Spain, a recovery in Apple shares  and the lack of any strikingly bad news.

title: Online Cloud Services Rely on Coal or Nuclear Power, Report Says
description: The infrastructure that supports the Internet, online commerce and nearly all corporate data services is engaged in a vast migration eastward in search of energy prices cheaper than anything available in Silicon Valley, where the digital revolution began, according to a report released Tuesday by the environmental group Greenpeace.

title: What Were Reading
description: Eater: Spring in New York feels like summer, and ros is on the mind. Sommeliers around the city pick their favorites for 2012.  Eric Asimov

title: Answering a Readers Question About Gout
description: A question that came up in response to yesterdays gout post made me realize I should be much clearer about something, given how prevalent gout is and how important it is for the information I provide to be correct.

title: Football, Baseball and the Evolving Tastes of Fans
description: Major League Baseball is under way, and its Saturday afternoon ratings are down slightly from last year. Thats nothing new. In October, the sensational Cardinals and Rangers seven-game World Series drew an average of 16.6 million viewers a night. Before that, the last time a Cardinals World Series went seven games was 1987; the average nightly audience was 35 million.

title: Taxpayers Warned to Beware of E-Mails From I.R.S.
description: Tax season is finally coming to a close: Tuesday is the deadline for filing your federal income tax return.

title: Where Enterprise Enemies Hug
description: Steve Marcus/ReutersJim Curry of OpenStack, right, at the AT&T Developer Summit in January.

description: For the European Central Bank, an uneasy role; what Instagram brings to Facebook; and the online television site Hulu comes of age.
