description: For European Central Bank, an uneasy role; What Instagram brings to Facebook; and the online television site Hulu comes of age.

title: Wheelies: The Butterfly Effect Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Sleep Apnea, or A.D.H.D.?
description: On the Well blog today, Kate Murphy reports that many children are being given a diagnosis of attention hyperactivity disorder when in fact they have another problem: a sleep disorder, like sleep apnea. Sleepless children become moody and wired, and have trouble focusing and sitting still. No one is saying A.D.H.D. does not exist, says one expert, but we need to rule out sleep issues first.

title: A Desk Lamp That Keeps Going and Going
description: Known for its unstoppable bunny and the batteries that keep him going, Energizer recently introduced a line of well-designed household lighting products, including flameless candles and accent lamps.

title: Leading Off: A Pause in the Goonery
description: The Rangers accomplished something notable other than a 1-0 victory over Ottawa in their first-round playoff series Monday night. Yes, goalie Henrik Lundqvist climbed back onto that pedestal he has decorated and called home this season. And yes, we are learning that Brian Boyle has skills way beyond growing a cheesy mustache. But more remarkable is that the Rangers won without resorting to thuggery. No messages sent. No ax grinding or headhunting. In the N.H.L. playoffs  and especially for the pugilistically-inclinded Rangers this qualifies them for a Nobel Peace Prize.

title: Discovery Shuttle Makes Final Flight
description: Before being permanently brought down to Earth, the space shuttle Discovery hitched a final ride on Tuesday to its new home at the Smithsonian on the back of a 747.

title: Boehner and McConnell Endorse Romney
description: 4:09 p.m. | Updated  House Speaker John A. Boehner of Ohio formally endorsed Mitt Romney as the Republican presidential nominee on Tuesday, throwing the weight of his office behind Mr. Romney, a former Massachusetts governor, roughly a month before the candidate can amass the delegates necessary to make it official.

title: Face Time | Chlo Sevigny
description: When I heard Chlo Sevigny would be making a guest appearance on NBCs Law & Order: SVU on April 18, I knew exactly what was in order. Before you could say indie actress, I was knocking on Sevignys door, camera in hand, sans makeup bag. (Apparently, Sevigny is not too keen on having her makeup done.) She had a few events to attend that night and was just about finished with her prettifying process. I wanted to know more about her makeup know-how, the products she uses and who does that fabulous hair.

title: Morning Walkabout: 4/17
description: Into Africa Holland Cotter, in a series of articles, makes a compelling case for visiting West Africa for the art alone. (And a handy multimedia guide distills it for you.) (The New York Times)

title: Americans Fill Orange Prize Shortlist
description: Three Americans have been named to the shortlist of the Orange Prize for Fiction, an annual prize in Britain that is awarded to a novel written by a woman in English. The finalists this year include Ann Patchett for State of Wonder, Cynthia Ozick for Foreign Bodies and Madeline Miller for Song of Achilles, a debut novel. Ms. Patchett, who opened a bookstore of her own in her native Nashville last year, won the Orange Prize a decade ago for her novel Bel Canto. The other finalists are Esi Edugyan for Half Blood Blues, Anne Enright for The Forgotten and Georgina Harding for Painter of Silence.

title: Less Money. More Voters.
description: Its been a bad year for the twin goals of getting more people to participate in democracy and reducing the level of special-interest money to influence them. As more states continue to impose onerous voter ID requirements on minorities and the poor, unlimited dollars from the wealthy continue to pour into (not-really) independent groups to pay for attack ads.

title: On Our Radar: Cautious Support for British Fracking
description: A report commissioned by the British government recommends that it allow the shale gas exploration process known as hydraulic fracturing to proceed, but with tighter rules on monitoring seismic activity and more detailed drilling surveys. [Reuters]

title: The Girth of the Globe
description: Several readers wrote to me in response to todays column with the same smart, interesting question: What about Europe? What about all the other countries that, like ours, are fundamentally wealthy and have abundant food and yet dont have our rates of obesity or as many fat people as we do? Dont their citizens face the same genetic and evolutionary obstacles that we do?

title: The General Election Ground Game: A First Look
description: Having essentially secured the Republican nomination, Mitt Romney now faces a general election to-do list. He must try to repair his favorability ratings among independent voters, which were eroded by a bruising primary campaign. He must try to close a gender gap that shows women supporting President Obama by a wide margin.

title: For Some Pitchers, No Reason for Fear
description: In a recent video from M.L.B. Productions, some of the games biggest stars talked about which hitters in baseball are the most intimidating to face.

title: Well-Tended Flower Children
description: AESTHETICALLY speaking, hippies have never been my bag. Im all for peace, love and understanding, but Im also partial to regular showers, stiletto heels and gender-specific haircuts. Psychedelic motifs make me dizzy, and tie-dye just seems as if laundry day went terribly wrong.

title: A Final Chance to Name the Baby Hawks
description: Update, April 19, 6 p.m. | The voting is now closed. The voting form has been removed. Results will be posted Friday morning. Thank you for voting!

title: Special Treatment for Murakami Paperback
description: 1Q84, the 925-page Haruki Murakami novel whose translucent jacket dazzled design aficionados upon its release last year, will receive special treatment with its paperback publication next month. The book will be published as a three-volume set on May 15, a spokesman for Vintage said on Tuesday. John Gall, the art director for Vintage, designed the paperbacks to be visible through a clear plastic box, fitting together to create one image. The list price is $29.95, and Vintage will initially print 50,000 copies.

title: Dewey Loses Eight More Partners as Departures Accelerate
description: Eight more lawyers announced Tuesday that they were leaving Dewey & LeBoeuf, adding to the wave of departures from the embattled New York law firm.

title: Whos Afraid of Greater Luxembourg?
description: Luxembourg is about as cuddly as countries come: prosperous, picturesque and delightfully tiny. At 999 square miles, it is the smallest but one of the European Union states [1]. You could drive its length (55 miles) or its width (35 miles) in less time than it takes to watch a feature-length movie  provided you dont stop at one of the many touristy villages or vineyards along the way. The capital, also called Luxembourg [2], is a cozy city of barely 100,000 souls; its major problem is not drugs or urban decay, but the apparently unfixable fact that its rather boring [3].

title: Police Officer Stabbed in Head in East Harlem
description: Updated, 9:00 p.m. | A man with a concealed knife plunged the blade into the left temple of a police officer responding to an emergency call placed by the mans mother on Tuesday morning, the police said.

title: Union Files Complaint Against Dance Theater of Harlem
description: 4:33 p.m. | Updated

title: In the N.B.A., There Is a Message in Point Differentials
description: In the N.B.A. teams are ranked in their conference and division by the percentage of games won. Whether a team is victorious by a single point or a large margin plays no part in the standings with the rare exception of tie breakers. In essence, a team that wins all five of its games by 20 points is deemed equal to a team that wins its five games by 1 point.

title: Couple Questioned About Bomb Threats at University of Pittsburgh
description: A transgender couple who have been protesting the University of Pittsburghs transgender policy are scheduled to appear on Tuesday before a federal grand jury investigating the rash of bomb threats at the universitys main campus since mid-February, The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette reported on Monday.

title: Photos of The Moment | Coachella
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Utahs Hayward Gets an Earful of Wests Foul
description: There are several dozen ways to commit a foul. Some are hard, bordering on violent, and others are so ambiguous that only the referee detected something amiss.

title: Tupac Shakur Illusion a Hit Online, but Tour Uncertain
description: 4:53 p.m. | Updated

title: Photo Replay: April 17
description: Livorno soccer players honored Piermario Morosini, who collapsed and died on the field on Saturday, at a ceremony in Leghorn, Italy; and the Monte-Carlo Rolex Masters tournament continued in France.

title: Potato Pizza
description: Mark Bittman makes a simple pizza with potato and rosemary.

title: Citigroups Chief Rebuffed on Pay by Shareholders
description: In a stinging rebuke, Citigroup shareholders rebuffed on Tuesday the banks $15 million pay package for its chief executive, Vikram S. Pandit, marking the first time that stock owners have united in opposition to outsized compensation at a financial giant.

title: Panetta Proposes New Sexual Assault Rules for the Military
description: Under pressure from Congress and veterans advocates, Secretary of Defense Leon Panetta on Monday announced new policies to combat sexual assault in the ranks. Most significantly, the secretary will require that all sexual assault complaints be handled by more senior officers  colonels or Navy captains  than the unit commanders who typically handle them now, a move expected to lead to more prosecutions.

title: TimesCast | April 17, 2012
description: An accused Norwegian killer asks for an acquittal | A Secret Service investigation continues | The space shuttle Discovery retires.

title: In Agent Scandal, Inquiry Leads to Colombian Bordellos
description: CARTAGENA, Colombia  At the Ligueros Club, one of many busy bordellos in this seaside tourist city, prostitutes dressed in lingerie wait for a bell to ring, signaling the arrival of men on the prowl. But the next group of American visitors to walk in the door may not be customers at all.

title: Bill Porter, Designer of Pontiac GTO, Moves to a New Biorhythm
description: Bill Porter, the former General Motors designer credited with the 1968 Pontiac GTO, has become something of a trend spotter in retirement. On April 13, at a meeting of the Society of Automotive Historians, he explained in the lecture, The New Biomorphs: An Emergent Trend on the Automotive Design Scene, what had caught his eye in recent years.

title: Visiting Artists | Diana Al-Hadid
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: ALEC Backs Down
description: Its not often that a grassroots campaign against a well-funded business organization actually works. But that may have happened today. The American Legislative Exchange Council  responsible for spreading stand-your-ground laws and voter ID restrictions to dozens of states around the country announced that it will disband its Public Safety and Elections Task Force, the internal panel that was the impetus for those kinds of laws. ALEC will now concentrate on economic issues.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: The Fight Over E-Books
description: To the Editor:

title: Denver Lacrosse Looks to Regain Magic of Last Season
description: Despite last seasons magical Final Four run, the University of Denver Pioneers have dropped to fourth in the Eastern Collegiate Athletic Conference with only the April 21 matchup with Fairfield remaining in conference play.

title: Pursuing Foreign Fraud Claims on American Soil
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission issued a report last week on whether investors should be able to pursue fraud claims on foreign securities transactions that take place outside the United States.

title: Blight Threatens Californias Citrus Trees
description: In a worrisome development for citrus growers in California, or anybody there who has a beloved lemon or orange tree in the yard, the citrus disease huanglongbing, or citrus greening, has been found in southeastern Los Angeles County, the California Department of Food and Agriculture reports.

title: Carriers Warn of Crisis in Mobile Spectrum
description: AT&T, Verizon, T-Mobile and Sprint say they need more radio spectrum, the government-rationed slices of radio waves that carry phone calls and wireless data.

title: Wearable Computers Are the Next Big Devices, Report Says
description: The wearable computing wars are about to begin, says a report released Tuesday by Forrester Research.

title: Palestinians Restate Demands to Netanyahu
description: JERUSALEM  President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority sent a letter to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Tuesday, reiterating that for peace talks to resume, Israel must stop settlement building in the West Bank and East Jerusalem and accept the 1967 borders as a basis for a two-state solution.

title: Ready for My Video Chat Close-Up
description: SEVERAL weeks ago, a plastic surgeon in Virginia started a media frenzy when he publicized a new procedure that he said could help people look younger when they appear on Skype and other video chat services. He named the surgery the FaceTime Face-Lift, after the popular iPhone feature.

title: Do College Students Need Sex Ed?
description: Over the last 10 years, a growing number of colleges have begun organizing week-long programs devoted to all things sexual.

title: Ted Nugents Remarks Reverberate Against Romney
description: 8:53 p.m. | Updated The rock star Ted Nugent became the latest  and perhaps least likely  proxy in the battle between the Obama and Romney camps as Democrats seized on vaguely threatening remarks that Mr. Nugent made over the weekend at a National Rifle Association conference and representatives of President Obama and Mitt Romney did their best to distances themselves from the comments.

title: Are We Running Out of Spectrum?
description: Wireless companies say that smartphones are threatening to overwhelm their networks, and are asking the government for help. But some experts maintain that technology already has the answers.

title: On Reality TV, Every House Has Its Horror
description: As spring house-buying season gears up, there will no doubt be a lot of talk about why home sales are sluggish, or at least not as robust as they used to be. Unemployment, low consumer confidence, tight credit and more arcane Wall Street metrics will all be implicated, but the real culprit is sitting blame-free in Americas living rooms and dens: the television.

title: Twitter Empowers Engineers With New Patent Agreement
description: 2:36 p.m. | Updated Adding comment from Facebook and Foursquare. 4:59 p.m. | Updated Adding comment from Bijan Sabet, an investor in Twitter.

title: Nature Made | Kria Jewelry Collection
description: You cant find bones and skeletons just out and about, laments the Reykjavk-born designer Johanna Methusalemsdottir. Fortunately, Methusalemsdottir gets help from her friends and family in Iceland, who collect and ship boxes of skeletons, teeth and other natural discards to her so that she may use them in her jewelry collection, Kria. My studio is filled with bones and weird things that keep me really happy, says the designer, who moved to New York as a teenager and currently makes every piece by hand in her Brooklyn studio. Her latest collection, her fifth, was inspired by the cod, a fish that kicked off decades of territorial disputes and has been central to Icelandic culture for centuries. Pieces look like wisps of smoke, cast in sterling silver and tethered to thin chains. The look book stars Methusalemsdottirs 18-year-old daughter, India Salvor Menuez, wearing the delicate and primal-looking pieces. The coarse sweater, the knitting, it really reminded me of fish nets and I wanted it to feel like a portrait of an old sailor or maybe a Native American, says Methusalemsdottir. Just very organic, nothing forced.

title: Father Knows Best
description: The tax filing deadline is upon ustwo days later than usual since April 15 fell on a Sunday and Monday was Emancipation Day, which the Internal Revenue Service dutifully recognizes. Despite this reprieve, an estimated 10 million filers are expected to ask for an extension, and Mitt Romney is among them.

title: A Slice, and a Relaxed Wine or Beer Pairing
description: Im reading a new book, Tastebuds and Molecules: The Art and Science of Food, Wine and Flavor by Franois Chartier, an extraordinary high-wire wine-and-food pairing equivalent of molecular gastronomy. Not surprisingly, the book is endorsed by Ferran Adri and Juli Soler of El Bulli, with whom Mr. Chartier, a French-Canadian wine and food writer, worked closely for several seasons at their restaurant.

title: Juggling Family and Work Travel
description: I leave for an overnight business trip in an hour.

title: Bank of America Said to Put Foreign Wealth Management Unit Up for Sale
description: Bank of America is exploring a potential sale of its foreign wealth management unit, after the business has failed to generate attractive returns, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Tuesday.

title: Moving Past a Haunting Image
description: Shah Marai didnt get to see Tarana Akbaris smile the first time he met the Afghan girl.

title: The Prisoner as Talk Show Host
description: When Anderson Cooper began a syndicated talk show, his first guest was the grieving father of Amy Winehouse.

title: Presidential Election in France Raises New Concerns for Investors
description: PARIS  To the list of worries about the euro zone, add one in bold: the fate of France as it heads into the first round of a closely contested presidential election this weekend.

title: In Rome, Its the Week of Culture
description: Seeing cultural sites in Italy this week just became easier. Italys 14th Settimana della Cultura (Week of Culture) started on Saturday and goes through April 22. In Rome, that means free entrance to state-run sites like the Baths of Caracalla, Crypta Balbi, Palazzo Altemps and Palazzo Massimo (the Colosseum, Forum and Palatine are not participating this year). The Galleria Borghese will also be free, although the 2-euro fee for the obligatory reservation is not waived.

title: The Voice Still Leads on Monday, Even as Viewership Slowly Erodes
description: The Voice is the only hit show that NBC owns, so its ratings results are being scrutinized intensely at that network  and, not incidentally, at the Fox network, which did not appreciate the threat this season to the hegemony of its own singing competition, American Idol.

title: Second Amendment and Beyond: Pondering Gun Rights, Laws and Culture
description: With the Trayvon Martin case, the recent school shooting in Ohio and the trial of Anders Behring Breivik in Norway, debate about guns and gun restrictions are in the news, and, perhaps, the subject of discussion in your classroom or home.

title: Blackhawks Andrew Shaw Suspended for Three Games
description: Andrew Shaw of the Chicago Blackhawks has become the fifth player suspended by the N.H.L. after just six days of Stanley Cup playoff games.

title: Audi Is Said to Be Ready to Buy Ducati
description: FRANKFURT Audi, the luxury car unit of Volkswagen, plans to enter the motorcycle business by acquiring Ducati, an Italian maker of high-end two-wheelers, a person briefed on the transaction said Tuesday.

title: When Too Big to Fail Gets Bigger
description: Goldman Sachs is still growing. Does that mean financial reform is proving a big fail on the too big to fail question?

title: Does Pier 17 Deserve Another Chance?
description: It seems like only 27 years ago that an enormous shopping pavilion opened on Pier 17 at the South Street Seaport. That is because it was only 27 years ago.

title: A Serious Warning and a Talking Liver
description: Give a man a fish, and hell eat for a day. Give a man some knowledge, and hell create a genetically modified salmon that could escape and wreak havoc on our ecosystem. Thats one of the messages of Prometheus Within, a transfixing if occasionally didactic new work written and directed by Theodora Skipitares at La MaMa.

title: Mike Genos Cheese Portraits
description: A Philadelphia artist paints seductive portraits of Manchego, Shropshire Blue, Cheddar and more.

title: Like the Mona Lisa, but on a Cracker
description: PHILADELPHIA

title: And the Winner Isnt ...
description: Nashville

title: Rediscovering Pulitzer Winners After a Blank Year
description: The Pulitzer Prize for fiction (known as the Pulitzer Prize for the novel before 1948) has been awarded to many books whose titles are immediately familiar to anyone who made it as far as middle school: The Grapes of Wrath, The Old Man and the Sea, The Good Earth, To Kill a Mockingbird. But do any of you remember Scarlet Sister Mary, by Julia Peterkin? Or Lamb in His Bosom, by Caroline Miller? Anyone?  Bueller?

title: New Study Identifies 'Opportunity Gap' for Students
Waiting for Brown, S.M.U. Joins Legions of His Basketball Employers
description: When you see a headline linking Larry Brown to yet another coaching job, it is hard not to suspect its from someone doing satire. Because Brown and his apparent quest to coach every mens basketball team in the universe has long passed silly.

title: Business Day Live | Hulu's Programming
description: April 17, 2012  Online television site Hulu comes of age.

title: House Campaign Committees Each Claim Upper Hand in Money Battle
description: As the two political parties brace for battle over control of Congress this year, the committees charged with helping to elect majorities in the House are busy raising as much cash as possible.

title: Through Rose-Framed Glasses
description: If youre getting a toothache thinking about pastels and floral prints this season, Kerin Rose, the hands behind the eyewear line A-Morir, offers a playful, noncommittal way to approach these trends.

title: Is Veganism Good For Everyone?
Fte Accompli | An Evening With Robert De Niro

title: Fistfuls of Pills
description: In todays Personal Health column in Science Times, Jane E. Brody takes up a topic all too familiar to readers of this blog: the overmedication of the elderly.

title: Intel Reports Flat Revenue, but Says Growth Is Ahead
description: SAN FRANCISCO  As PC makers regroup after the floods in Thailand last autumn, Intel is preparing to regain dominance of the computer chip market.

title: Consumers Have Concerns About Mobile Banking Security, Survey Finds
description: Roughly one of every five Americans used their mobile phone for some sort of banking activity last year, and about the same proportion say they will probably use mobile banking in the future, a recent survey from the Federal Reserve found.

title: Strong Sales Lift Earnings at Coca-Cola
description: Sales of the Coca-Cola Companys myriad beverages grew around the world in the first quarter, led by consumption in India, where volume soared 20 percent.

title: N.B.A. Takes a Look at Jersey Sponsorship
description: Six mannequin torsos  three wearing Chicago Bulls jerseys and three with Boston Celtics jerseys  sat on tables in front of N.B.A. owners in a meeting room at the St. Regis hotel in Manhattan.

title: BitsVideo: What Instagram Brings to Facebook
description: Nick Bilton and Nicole Perlroth discuss Facebooks $1 billion acquisition of Instagram.

title: Morgan Spurlock on Producing a Show for Hulu
description: As Hulu makes a bigger push into original programming ahead of its upfront on Thursday, some TV creators have found the streaming-video service to be a welcome alternative to high-stakes network programming. Hulu can keep a show on, regardless of the ratings, unlike a network that typically pulls the plug immediately if a show doesnt match advertisers expectations.

title: Business Day Live | The Instagram Sale
description: April 17, 2012  What Instagram brings to Facebook.

title: TimesCast | Secret Service Investigation
description: April 17, 2012  The Secret Service is investigating allegations that agents hired prostitutes in Cartagena, Colombia, as President Obama attended the Summit of the Americas meeting last weekend.

title: The Montanara Arrives in New York
description: Neapolitan-style fried pizza is on the menu at two new pizzerias, Don Antonio by Starita and Forcella.

title: From Europe, Lessons on Frying Pizza
description: THE most surprising thing about the montanara, a fried pizza that in less than a year has found a niche in New Yorks crowded pizza ecosystem, is that Americans needed to import the idea from Europe.

title: Sales Are Stagnant, but I.B.M. Earnings Beat Analysts Expectations
description: I.B.M. is a tale of two growth stories. Revenue is anemic, but earnings are robust.

title: TimesCast | Norwegian Seeks Acquittal
description: April 17, 2012  Anders Behring Breivik, the Norwegian who is accused of killing 77 people in an attack last summer, takes the witness stand and shows no remorse.

title: UBSs Bourkoff Resigns as Americas Head of Investment Banking
description: UBS head of investment banking for the Americas, Aryeh Bourkoff, has resigned to pursue other opportunities, the firm announced in an internal memorandum on Tuesday.

title: The French Plan a New York Fte
description: The French have big plans for New York on Sept. 22: La Fte de la Gastronomie, an all-day and evening tribute to the glory of French dining, and not just haute cuisine. Plans are still being formulated, but a meeting was held Tuesday morning in one of the grand salons of the French Consulate on Fifth Avenue to announce the purpose of the event and some of the details, and to get the ball rolling.

title: Searching for Someone She Has Already Found
description: In pacing, tone and general absurdities, Your Boyfriend May Be Imaginary, a sharp new comedy by Larry Kunofsky, has the feel of a David Sedaris story.

title: The Knotty Ties Binding Americas Ex-Leaders
description: The term Presidents Club is used to describe airport lounges that exclude most passengers. It can also designate any group of civic leaders or other association that wants to sound important. It has sometimes been used by American presidents to describe the ties that bind them, but it is not a formal entity. Ex-Presidents Herbert Hoover and Harry S. Truman joked about starting a former presidents club when they met at the inauguration of President Eisenhower and wondered what to do with their futures.

title: A Bridge in a Day
description: The Massachusetts Department of Transportation is learning the advantages of a technique known as accelerated bridge construction to move a span into place in a day.

title: Publishing Is Cranky Over Snub by Pulitzers
description: One day after the Pulitzer Prize board said it would not award a Pulitzer in fiction for the first time in 35 years, the publishing industry was still seething, with some going as far as offering surrogate winners.

title: Mayoral Hopefuls Begin to Define Their Education Policies
Did Someone Order an Instant Bridge?
description: BOSTON  The River Street Bridge here is normally unremarkable, the kind of structure people drive over every day without a thought. When it fell into disrepair, state officials knew that replacing it would normally involve two years of detours and frustration for local drivers.

title: In Jersey City, a LeFrak Office Project Awaits a Tenant
description: JERSEY CITY  The Newport neighborhood here, at 600 acres among the largest urban mixed-use developments on the East Coast, has seemed in no real hurry to be completed.

title: David Kramer
description: Mr. Kramer, 46, is a principal of the Hudson Companies, which specializes in urban development. The company builds market-rate, affordable and institutional housing, and its projects include Riverwalk on Roosevelt Island and the J Condominium in Brooklyn.

title: Revealing Prostate Cancer, Buffett Plays Down Effect
description: Warren E. Buffett disclosed on Tuesday that he had prostate cancer, a development that would probably heighten the questions over his successor as the chief executive of his conglomerate, Berkshire Hathaway.

title: The Preppy Sets Sail in the Riviera
description: FRENCH style was the starting point for Joseph Altuzarras fall collection, the one with the coin fringe, the military coats and the cargo pants tucked into high boots. French style was also the starting point for Mr. Altuzarras new collaboration with J. Crew, but the results couldnt be more different.

title: North Korea Says It Will Abandon Deal With U.S.
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea said on Tuesday that it was abandoning an agreement it made in February with the United States, in which it promised to suspend uranium enrichment, nuclear tests and long-range missile tests.

title: Tom Pettys Stolen Guitars Are Recovered
description: Five guitars stolen last week from Tom Petty and his band have been recovered, and one person is under arrest in connection with the theft, The Associated Press reported on Tuesday.Lt. Ron Iizuka of the Culver City, Calif., police department declined to provide details, though he confirmed the guitars stolen last Thursday from a rehearsal studio had been found.

title: Video: Hulus Evolution
description: Online television site Hulu is coming of age.

title: Judge Dismisses Howard Sterns Suit Against Sirius
description: A New York judge has dismissed a lawsuit by Howard Stern against Sirius XM Radio over potentially hundreds of millions of dollars in stock payments that Mr. Stern said had been promised but not been paid.

title: Asked and Answered | Joseph Altuzarra
description: There are few things that fashion folk love more than fresh-off-the-runway style for a bargain. Last year, J.Crew proved that shoppers could have just that when they collaborated with the 2010 CFDA / Vogue Fashion Fund winners Billy Reid, Prabal Gurung and Eddie Borgo. This week, the preppy-classic brand introduced its latest combined efforta seven-piece capsule from the 2011 CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund winner Joseph Altuzarra that includes a list of closet staples like denim bottoms, cashmere sweaters and crisp, gingham shirts ($85-$345). Here, T talks to Altuzarra about his design process, his CFDA win and the cake that came soon thereafter.

title: Alison Eighteen
description: Inside Alison Price Beckers American brasserie in the Flatiron district.

title: A Seat at the Adults Table
description: DID somebody forget to tell Alison Price Becker that in the decade since she last operated a Manhattan restaurant, all of New York below 42nd Street has been taken over by kids, and that their idea of going out to eat resembles some kind of blood sport?

title: From Brazils Book of Rocks
description: Ken Angielczyk, an assistant curator at the Field Museum of Natural History, is searching for fossils of ancient mammal relatives in northeastern Brazil.

title: Pictures of the Day: West Bank and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from the West Bank, Iran, Norway and Kuwait.

title: The Lowly Anchovy: Customers Finally Take the Bait
description: WHEN Renae and Neill Holland began selling fried anchovies almost a year ago at Smorgasburg, the Brooklyn food fiesta, they werent sure what to expect.

title: Three Standout Dishes at Alison Eighteen
description: For those who feel harassed by how complicated dining in New York has become, Alison Eighteen may feel like something of a safe harbor. Its a straightforward restaurant where you arent told that everything is meant to be served family style, or tapas style, or in a tasting menu that has to be ordered a month in advance.

title: Seared Red Rice With Spinach, Mushrooms, Carrot and Egg
description: Rice bran oil has a very high smoke point, so its a perfect oil for searing and stir-fries where that high-heat seared flavor is desired. You can make this dish with any type of rice, but I love the red rice Ive been finding in whole-foods stores, whether from Thailand or Bhutan.

title: His Best Friend at His Fingertips, a Pianist, 96, Plays On
description: Thats his fountain of youth right there: the martini, a patron squealed the other night at Ninos Tuscany on West 58th Street.She was pointing to a brimming two-olive vodka martini resting on the grand piano being played by Irving Fields.

title: Beware the Suited Men Wielding Letter Openers
description: Years before Everybody Loves Raymond propelled Brad Garrett to stardom, he was a stand-up comedian opening for Frank Sinatra in Las Vegas. He capped his warm-up act on one particularly unresponsive night by deadpanning: Youre a great audience. Stick around for Frank.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: IKEA TV and a Google Rival
description: Here are some of the most interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Tuesday. There are more here.

title: Classics, Homespun and Fresh
description: THE stretch of Metropolitan Avenue that passes through Forest Hills, Queens, seems less like a city thoroughfare than a small-town main street. Most buildings rise just two or three stories. They house the library and post office, hardware stores and knickknack dens, an aging sweet shop and a still-vigorous chocolatier.

title: Dining Calendar
description: G.M.O.s and Fake Meat

title: Have You Always Wanted a Roll-Up Water Bottle?
description: In this weeks Its the Economy column, Adam Davidson asks if we have entered a golden age of American invention. We learned that its easier than ever for inventors to go from idea to prototype to finished product, but its harder than ever to protect those ideas from copycats. So has intellectual theft turned inventors into a secretive, media-wary bunch? Not the inventors we met.

title: Off the Menu
description: OPENING

title: Senate Republicans Announce Plan to Support Challenge to Recess Appointments
description: Senate Republicans said on Tuesday that they would file a legal brief in support of a company challenging the constitutionality of recess appointments made by President Obama this year.

title: Amazon Acquires Rights to James Bond Books
description: Amazon Publishing has snapped up the rights to publish 14 James Bond books in the United States, the company said on Tuesday.

title: Military News Roundup: Taliban Evolution, Veteran Disabilities and Homelessness, and Panettas Travel
description: The New York Times Web site is rich with military-related stories today. So, here, for your skimming pleasure, is a roundup of all the good reading.

title: Levon Helm in Final Stages of Cancer Battle
description: Levon Helm, the drummer with the Band, has reached the final stages of his battle with cancer, according to a note posted on the musicians Web site.Mr. Helm, 71, received a diagnosis of throat cancer in 1998 and nearly lost his voice, though he has continued to sing on albums and at concerts.The note, signed by his daughter and wife, asked fans to send prayers and love to him as he makes his way through this part of his journey.

title: The Story of a Girl, and How It Spread
description: The Holocaust documentary Inside Hanas Suitcase recounts the story of a Jewish girl from Czechoslovakia named Hana Brady, whom the Nazis orphaned; separated from her brother, George; and killed at Auschwitz. Hana and her suitcase are already well known to the many readers touched by Karen Levines similarly titled 2002 book. This heartstring-tugging film from the director Larry Weinstein earnestly carries on Ms. Levines dual dramatization of Hanas tale and its transmission.

title: The Guide and Spirit of Ailey II Steps Down
description: Somewhere near the top of the modern-dance family tree, where the foliage is plentiful, youll find Sylvia Waters.

title: At London Olympics, NBC Says, If Cameras Are on It, Well Stream It
description: All 32 sports at the 2012 Summer Olympics in London will be streamed live at nbcolympics.com.

title: What a Pianist Is Learning From 32 Sonatas
description: For any serious concert pianist, Beethoven is more than just a composer. His music for the piano, and in particular his 32 numbered sonatas, are a summit by which prowess and insight are measured as well as a process by which those qualities can be developed. Far from being fixed on a page, the sonatas live anew in the hands of each performer who comes to them with integrity and passion.

title: In Judging Hostile Bids, Look at How Recent Targets Fared
description: Just say no.

title: Talking Points: Bayern Munich 2, Real Madrid 1
description: Mario Gomezs goal in the 90th minute gave Bayern Munich a 2-1 victory over Real Madrid on Tuesday in the first leg of their Champions League semifinal. Video highlights from UEFA.com in the link above. Here are a few quick talking points; please discuss and add your own.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,923 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: In a Shift, Vornado Addresses Investor Concerns
description: Vornado Realty Trust, whose diversified portfolio includes a large swath of office towers near Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan and strip shopping centers in the Northeast and California, was once considered the company with the magic touch. But lately many investors and analysts have soured on Vornado, a real estate investment trust, saying it failed to capitalize on opportunities in the downturn and has become too unwieldy for investors to evaluate.

title: TimesCast | Space Shuttle Retires
description: April 17, 2012  The space shuttle Discovery flew atop a 747 to Washingtons Dulles International Airport from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida.

title: Should We Eat Less Meat? None at All?
description: To the Editor:

title: Park Slope Historic District Now Citys Biggest
description: Park Slope, already home to the biggest historic district in Brooklyn, now contains the largest contiguous swath of protected buildings in the entire city.

title: No Pulitzer in Fiction
description: To the Editor:

title: Spinning Eerie Harmonics Into a Panorama of Emotions
description: The composer Christian Ofenbauer, a professor at the Mozarteum University in Salzburg, Austria, aims to write music senza espressione, avoiding the expressive gestures inherent in Baroque, Classical and Romantic music. Plenty of contemporary composers have abandoned traditional musical devices to exciting effect, but there was little to retain a listeners interest in Mr. Ofenbauers BruchStck IX when the Quatuor Diotima performed it at the Austrian Cultural Forum on Monday evening.

title: Graphic Cigarette Warnings
description: To the Editor:

title: Popular J.&J. Drugs May Not Return Until 2013
description: Efforts to fix manufacturing problems at three Johnson & Johnson plants are taking longer than expected, meaning that some popular over-the-counter consumer brands may not return to store shelves until next year, company executives said Tuesday.

title: Illness and Superstition
description: To the Editor:

title: Neuhaus Opens on Madison Avenue
description: For most Americans, the word praline conjures up the sugary pecan-studded candy from Louisiana. But in francophone Europe, pralines are filled chocolates. And it was exactly 100 years ago that the praline, a hard chocolate shell with a creamy flavored interior, made its debut at the Neuhaus chocolatier in Brussels.

title: A Warming Trend From North Africa
description: Harissa is the sriracha of North Africa, a chile-based condiment that elevates many a dish. Though its origins are Tunisian and it is most widely used there and in Algeria, its popularity has recently spread to Morocco, where more restaurants are serving it, especially with grilled meats. Mina Kallamni, 65, who grew up in Casablanca, said she did not even taste it until she was 16, but then she became hooked. In New York, she has founded Casablanca Foods with her son Fouad, and their first product is harissa. Unlike typical harissa, which is a ruddy red-orange, hers is a vibrant magenta. It is made without preservatives. The spicy version takes no prisoners; the tangy mild and medium are more approachable.

title: Ibrico Pork in the Neighborhood
description: Call it the other red meat. Uncured cuts of pork from Spanish Ibrico pigs, the same ones that forage for acorns and become some of the finest hams on the planet, are now being sold online in the United States, by Wagshals in Washington; La Tienda in Williamsburg, Va.; and Nicky USA in Portland, Ore. Need I say grilling season? The fresh meat is red, beeflike and marbled. Seared medium rare, then sliced, it is silky-tender, with a mildly earthy flavor. It is not as buttery as Wagyu beef, so you are not sated after two bites.

title: Midsummer Night Swing Unveils Its Lineup
description: The lineup for the Midsummer Night Swing series of concerts this year includes a European boogie-woogie combo with Charlie Watts on drums and a concert by masters of forr music from northeastern Brazil, some of whom have rarely appeared outside their homeland, Lincoln Center announced on Tuesday.

title: A Memorial, Ribald and Reverent, for Christopher Hitchens
description: On Friday in the Great Hall of Cooper Union, friends and fans of Christopher Hitchens, the author and columnist who died on Dec. 15, will gather for some highmindedness and some laughs, according to Graydon Carter, the editor of Vanity Fair.

title: Twins Mauer and Morneau Flash Old Form
description: For one night, it was 2006 all over again, with Joe Mauer and Justin Morneau collecting key hits in a Minnesota Twins victory.

title: Israeli Minister Agrees Ahmadinejad Never Said Israel Must Be Wiped Off the Map
description: Last Updated, April 18 | In a reminder that Persian rhetoric is not always easy for English-speakers to interpret, a senior Israeli official has acknowledged that Irans president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, never actually said that Israel must be wiped off the map.

title: The Unwait Unpitch
description: Carol Roth, business analyst, evaluates an investor pitch from a small business.

title: With Eye on Past, Karzai Lays Out Vision for an Independent Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In a sweeping speech on Tuesday that touched on some of the heroes of Afghanistans past 150 years, President Hamid Karzai laid out a vision of a modern, independent Afghanistan that could outlast security upheaval and foreign entanglement. And he made an emotional defense of his outreach to the Taliban, urging the insurgents again to lay down their weapons, if only to hasten the withdrawal of American forces.

title: Senate Banking Committee to Hold MF Global Hearing
description: A former director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who has come under fire as the bankruptcy trustee for MF Global will appear next week before a Congressional panel examining the collapse of the brokerage firm.

title: The Pizza Issue
description: Videos, recipes and articles to help you achieve the perfect pizza or calzone at home. (And, if you must, tips on where to find a good restaurant pie.)

title: Top Iran Nuclear Scientist, Once Targeted for Assassination, Gets New Emergency Post
description: The head of Irans Atomic Energy Organization, a top nuclear scientist who narrowly avoided an assassination attempt less than two years ago, has been given a new post as the commander for nuclear and radioactive emergencies, the Iranian military announced Tuesday.

title: Guillen Returns to Dugout After Suspension
description: MIAMI  Ozzie Guillen, Miami Marlins loose-lipped manager, is not going to change his outspoken ways, but he said his recent comments about Fidel Castro have made him change what he will be outspoken about  hopefully for the better.

title: British Ultranationalist Warns of Shariahs Creeping Influence, and Twitter Laughs
description: Updated | Wednesday | 5:03 p.m.  It began when the leader of the English Defence League, an ultranationalist group opposed to the building of mosques in Britain  and New York  suggested a hashtag to go with his outraged Twitter post regarding the image of a mosque on the homepage of the social media site.

title: Partner Exodus May Upend Deweys Loans
description: An accelerating wave of partner defections from the New York law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf is now threatening to violate the firms loan agreements with its banks.

title: Cuomo Reported Income of Over $230,000 in 2011
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo earned more than $230,000 last year from his state salary and investment income, according to tax filings his office made available for review on Tuesday.

title: Buses With 3 Doors? Whats a Rider to Do?
description: In many cities around the world, there are simple established rules for riding buses: board at the front and exit at the back, making for an orderly passenger flow.

title: Web Site Stole Job Seekers Data in Tax-Fraud Scheme
description: A Web site that promised to connect people with much-needed jobs during the recession was actually a means to steal the applicants personal information in a scheme to file fraudulent tax returns, prosecutors said on Tuesday.

title: Mets Find Help in Unlikely Place
description: ATLANTA  One of the most obvious components of the Mets strong start this season has been the quality of their starting pitching.

title: Each Side Accuses the Other of Breaking Syrian Cease-Fire
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Antigovernment activists in the Syrian conflict accused President Bashar al-Assads forces on Tuesday of the most widespread violations of an already fractured five-day-old cease-fire, including the tank shelling of neighborhoods in at least two cities and the use of helicopters to attack suspected rebels in mountainside villages.

title: Paul Bogart, TV Director, Dies at 92
description: Paul Bogart, a puppeteer who bumbled into the new medium of television in 1950 and rose to be an Emmy-winning director known for popular shows like All in the Family and The Defenders, died on Sunday in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 92 and lived in Chapel Hill.

title: The Apple Pushers
description: A clip from The Apple Pushers, a film written and directed by Mary Mazzio, narrated by Edward Norton.

title: Phony Mommy Wars
description: WASHINGTON

title: Kurds Remain on the Sideline of Syrias Uprising
description: KILIS, Turkey  The Kurds of Syria, long oppressed by the government of President Bashar al-Assad, are largely staying out of the fighting that has gone on for more than a year in their country, hedging their bets as they watch to see who will gain the upper hand.

title: William Finley, Actor in De Palma Movies, Dies at 71
description: William Finley, a character actor who appeared in many films by Brian De Palma, most memorably as the title character in the 1974 rock opera The Phantom of the Paradise, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 71 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Flyers Are in Control, Surprising Themselves and the Penguins
description: VOORHEES, N.J.  Three games into a series in which their opponents, the Pittsburgh Penguins, have seemingly careened out of control, the Philadelphia Flyers are pleased, and maybe even a little surprised, that they are not behaving like the Flyers often have in the past.

title: Regulators to Ease a Rule on Derivatives Dealers
description: As federal regulators put the finishing touches on an overhaul of the $700 trillion derivatives market, a major provision has been tempered in the face of industry pressure.

title: Britain Presses for Information on Death in China
description: LONDON  After months of soft-pedaling by British diplomats in the case of a British businessman believed to have been murdered in China, Prime Minister David Cameron and his government abruptly changed course on Tuesday, going to Parliament with a blunt demand that China expose the truth behind this tragic case and do so in a manner that is free from political interference.

title: Abiding by the Fair Sentencing Act
description: The Fair Sentencing Act of 2010 addressed a gross inequity in federal sentences by reducing the disparity in punishment for a crime involving crack versus powdered cocaine. Previously, under a 1986 law, 50 grams of crack (the weight of a candy bar) led to a mandatory minimum sentence of 10 years  the same sentence that applied to 5,000 grams of powdered cocaine (enough to fill a brief case). A street dealer of crack cocaine often got a longer sentence than the major trafficker who sold the powdered cocaine made into crack. The new law cut the 100 to 1 ratio to 18 to 1  not equalizing the penalties as it should have but markedly reducing the difference.

title: The Big Spill, Two Years Later
description: Friday is the second anniversary of the explosion at BPs Deepwater Horizon rig that killed 11 workers and spilled upwards of five million barrels of oil into the Gulf of Mexico. Thanks partly to natures resilience, some progress has been made. The gulf is open to fishing, beaches are mostly clean and President Obama has resurrected an ambitious oil exploration plan that he shelved immediately after the spill.

title: A Visit With The Greatest Living Food Writer
description: Colin Spencer, whom Germaine Greer once called the greatest living food writer, turns 80 next year, and shows no signs of slowing down. His latest book, From Microliths to Microwaves, a history of food in Britain from pre-historic times to the present, is the work of a scholar. (In it he argues, in a way thats reminiscent of Jared Diamond, that agriculture  or at least agriculture as its practiced now  is one of the great tragedies of the human race.)

title: Using His Software Skills With Freedom, Not a Big Payout, in Mind
description: Nadim Kobeissi, master hacker, summoned for interrogation multiple times as a teenager by cyber-intelligence authorities in Beirut, Lebanon, sat in the backyard of a restaurant in Brooklyn, astounded that he was being treated to lunch.

title: Marketers Find a Friend in Pinterest
description: IN an age of fat data plans and broadband access, Pinterest has a message for the media: a picture is worth a thousand words. Thats 35 Twitter posts, give or take.

title: Romney Aide Turns Focus to Search for His No. 2
description: Beth Myers, the longtime adviser whom Mitt Romney has chosen to supervise his search for a running mate, was assigned a humble role during the candidates 2002 run for governor of Massachusetts: to stand in for his Democratic opponent, Shannon OBrien, during mock debates.

title: Right Steps on Military Sexual Assault
description: Defense Secretary Leon Panetta on Monday announced several encouraging steps to fight sexual assault in the military. The most notable is the requirement that complaints be handled by senior officers  colonels or Navy captains  instead of lower-ranking officers who are often ill equipped or reluctant to pursue assault cases.

title: Alone, Armed With Only a Whistle
description: LONDON  The most scrutinized person during Wednesdays Champions League semifinal between Barcelona and Chelsea may not be Lionel Messi. Or the defenders assigned the often futile task of denying him a goal.

title: At a Brooklyn School, the Cool Crowd Pushes the King Around
description: The classroom at Intermediate School 318 in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, was filled on Tuesday with the thumping and clattering of a half-dozen high-speed chess matches, played with a rambunctious energy more reminiscent of a hockey game than of Garry Kasparov and Deep Blue.

title: Sony Plans Major Cuts in EMI Jobs
description: The European Commission is expected to issue a ruling on Thursday in one of the music industrys biggest deals in the past decade: Sonys proposed $2.2 billion takeover of EMI Music Publishing.

title: Threat to California Citrus May Finish Backyard Trees
description: ALTADENA, Calif.  Like so many residents here, Martin Koning-Bastiaan grows citrus in his yard: lemons and limes, almost a dozen varieties of oranges, and grapefruit trees that are about 100 years old.

title: Frenzied Hours for U.S. on Fate of a China Insider
description: WASHINGTON  On the evening of Feb. 6, a vice mayor of a major Chinese city who had a reputation as a crime fighter turned up at the American Consulate in Chengdu in an agitated state, telling a tale of corruption and murder that has ensnared the Obama administration in a scandal it wants nothing to do with.

title: Colleagues Trace the Void Left by a Firefighter
description: The black and purple bunting hung from Engine 237 in Bushwick, Brooklyn, on Tuesday, ornamenting the sadness that surrounded the death of Lt. Richard A. Nappi. But in truth, the lieutenants reach far exceeded any one place, and with his passing, so did the circles of grief.

title: Solar Company to Cut 2,000 Jobs and Close a German Factory
description: Five months ago, First Solar was celebrating making the millionth solar module at a plant it had built in Frankfurt, to double its production in Germany, the worlds largest market for solar power.

title: Penguins Are Looking for Answers
description: 11:09 p.m. | Updated

title: Competition Needs Protection
description: To believe publishers and authors, the government just handed Amazon a monopoly over the book market: The price-fixing suit against Apple and the nations top publishers filed by the Justice Department last week will free Amazon to offer ruinous discounts in the booming new market of electronic books, drive brick-and-mortar bookstores out of existence and kill off publishers lucrative business of ink on paper.

title: Organizer of Subway Plot Testifies About Plans Evolution
description: The Queens man who admitted being the organizer of a plot to blow up subways in New York City in September 2009 appeared in court on Tuesday to testify at the terrorism trial of Adis Medunjanin, a high school classmate accused of helping him in the plot.

title: Murder-Suicide in Brooklyn, the Police Say
description: Two men are dead in East New York, Brooklyn, after one man shot the other and then turned the gun on himself, the police said on Tuesday.

title: Egypt Panel Affirms Ban on 3 Candidates for President
description: CAIRO  The presidential election commission confirmed the disqualification of three leading presidential candidates on Tuesday.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 17, 2012

title: Keeping the Peace, Armed With Only a Whistle
description: Jer Longman of The Times, in London to cover Wednesdays Champions League semifinal between Chelsea and Barcelona at Stamford Bridge, reports on the man who could have the biggest impact on the game: the German referee Felix Brych. Chelsea is familiar with Brych, who worked one of the Blues matches against Napoli in the Round of 16, but it would be understandable of their fans were wary of any referee in his spot after a couple of heartbreaking experiences against the Catalans in recent years. Read the article here, and come back to comment.

title: Romneys Critique of War Policy Gets a Closer Look
description: Mitt Romney has made Afghanistan a showcase for his attacks on President Obamas foreign policy. He says Mr. Obama has undercut American interests by setting timetables for withdrawing troops, providing the Taliban  who displayed their resilience with attacks over the weekend  further reason to wait things out. He called Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta misguided and so nave for announcing plans to hand over primary combat responsibilities to Afghan forces next year and leave American troops mainly in training and other roles.

title: Shopping for Laundry Gear
description: Stuart Leslie, an industrial designer, shopped for accessories that look good enough to put on display.

title: 54 New Schools Will Open This Fall, Bloomberg Says
description: Brushing aside criticism of his longstanding policy to close poorly performing schools and replace them with new ones, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced on Tuesday that the city would open 54 new schools in the fall, many of them in spaces vacated by schools being closed.

title: One for the Country
description: I had to catch a train in Washington last week. The paved street in the traffic circle around Union Station was in such poor condition that I felt as though I was on a roller coaster. I traveled on the Amtrak Acela, our sorry excuse for a fast train, on which I had so many dropped calls on my cellphone that youd have thought I was on a remote desert island, not traveling from Washington to New York City. When I got back to Union Station, the escalator in the parking garage was broken. Maybe youve gotten used to all this and have stopped noticing. I havent. Our country needs a renewal.

title: Court Weighs Revisions in Cocaine-Case Sentences
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court heard arguments on Tuesday about an aspect of one of the greatest controversies in American criminal law: the differing treatment of crack and powder cocaine.

title: A Deft Health Care Move
description: The refusal of New Yorks Republican-led State Senate to establish a health insurance exchange, as required by the federal health reform law, has left the state in a pickle. Gov. Andrew Cuomo was wise to step in with an executive order that will accomplish much the same purpose.

title: Valentine Is Brushed Back by His Own Words
description: BOSTON

title: Dance the Night Away
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  I know what youre thinking. Youre thinking, These dances  with the exception of 38 Across  are not danced in a square. Theyre mostly danced in either lines or circles.

title: In California Quake Research, Boring Is the Hoped-for Result
description: SAN DIEGO  It was billed as one of the most ambitious earthquake simulations ever attempted. Engineers constructed a five-story building  complete with an operating room, an elevator, a kitchen loaded with glassware and a heavy air-conditioning unit perched on the roof  and placed it atop a platform known as a shake table on the outskirts of San Diego. Observers were issued hard hats and a strict set of safety instructions.

title: New Jockeying Over Online Release of Data on Political Ads
description: LAS VEGAS The fight between broadcasters and regulators over the online release of political advertising data entered a new round this week at the broadcasters annual conference.

title: Panel Faults Congress for Inaction on Drilling
description: WASHINGTON  Members of the presidential panel that investigated the 2010 BP oil rig explosion and spill sharply criticized Congress on Tuesday for refusing to act on any of its recommendations and gave the Obama administration and the oil industry mixed marks.

title: In Quick Transition, College Champion Finds His Place With Rangers
description: OTTAWA  Chris Kreider was bombarded by congratulatory phone calls and text messages after making his professional debut in the Rangers 1-0 victory over the Senators in Game 3 of their first-round playoff series Monday.

title: Justices Cite Protections for Lawyers in Inquiries
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court ruled unanimously on Tuesday that private lawyers hired by municipalities to conduct investigations are entitled to protections against lawsuits generally available to government lawyers.

title: Corrections: April 18
description: NATIONAL

title: Panthers Top Devils by Erasing 3-0 Deficit
description: NEWARK  Jose Theodore was summoned to the Florida Panthers bench, found a seat and tilted his face mask back on his head, done for the night after just 6 minutes 16 seconds. Theodore had allowed three goals on six shots, the victim of a Devils onslaught.

title: Studies Question the Pairing of Food Deserts and Obesity
description: It has become an article of faith among some policy makers and advocates, including Michelle Obama, that poor urban neighborhoods are food deserts, bereft of fresh fruits and vegetables.

title: Debate Grows as Europe Fears Return of a Crisis
description: BERLIN  The European financial crisis has shown signs of reigniting in recent days, sharpening the debate between the champions of austerity and a growing chorus urging more expansionary policies to promote growth.

description: WASHINGTON  An influential conservative policy group that came under attack after the Trayvon Martin shooting for pushing Stand Your Ground gun laws nationwide said Tuesday that it was getting out of the law enforcement and social policy arenas and returning to its economic roots.

title: City to Open 54 New Schools in September
Reported Arrests in Mali Raise Questions About Junta
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Casting doubt on Malis transition back to civilian rule after a military coup last month, soldiers arrested a number of leading political figures in the capital late Monday and early Tuesday, according to members of the opposition.

title: Santorum Offers Hints on His Plans, but First, a Debt
description: What does Rick Santorum want?

title: Forced to Use Their Backup Plan, Yankees Discover It Works Just Fine
description: The Yankees have a lineup loaded with All-Stars, but Tuesday was a night for the other guys, as Manager Joe Girardi seemingly made all the right moves.

title: The Nets Are Putting New Jersey Behind Them
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  As the Nets were having their final team picture taken before the franchise moves to Brooklyn, the official photographer said something that could have resonated with many at the teams practice facility:

title: No Savings Are Found From Welfare Drug Tests
description: MIAMI  Ushered in amid promises that it would save taxpayers money and deter drug users, a Florida law requiring drug tests for people who seek welfare benefits resulted in no direct savings, snared few drug users and had no effect on the number of applications, according to recently released state data.

title: The Impermanent Republican Majority
description: For those who believe that demography is destiny, there was no more jaw-dropping figure from the 2004 presidential election than this finding from the nations far-flungmetropolitan frontier: George W. Bush carried 97 of the nations 100 fastest growing counties.

title: Costa Concordia Wreck Cuts Two Ways for Giglios Tourism
description: The tourism-dependent Italian island of Giglio has had a drop in overnight bookings but an increase in day trips since the cruise ship capsized.

title: Senate Budget Panel to Take Up Deficit Plan
description: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the Senate Budget Committee said on Tuesday that he would introduce the blueprint of President Obamas bipartisan deficit reduction panel to his committee as the starting point for negotiations over a long-term debt plan.

title: A Shipwreck Cuts Two Ways for an Islands Lifeblood
description: GIGLIO, Italy  As the first tourists of the season cross the channel between the Tuscan mainland and the island of Giglio, the breathtaking view they are seeking is not of Giglios crystal-clear waters or its ochre and pink granite rocks.

title: Canucks and Senators (and Canada) Brace for Early Exit
description: OTTAWA  How far the mighty have fallen, eh? With the Vancouver Canucks facing elimination in a four-game sweep in Los Angeles on Wednesday night and the Ottawa Senators facing an uphill fight against the top-seeded Rangers, there is a strong chance that no Canadian teams will be left in the Stanley Cup playoffs after one round.

title: Tough Second Half for Giants; for Jets, a Marquee Game
description: The Giants will try to defend their Super Bowl championship with a schedule that is backloaded with tough games while the Jets will again have an opportunity to command headlines, with a Thanksgiving night matchup against the New England Patriots.

title: As Gas Prices Cast Cloud, Obama Calls for Scrutiny on Market
description: WASHINGTON  With his re-election prospects influenced by the price of gasoline, President Obama on Tuesday demanded more cops on the beat to crack down on oil market manipulation, calling on Congress to bolster federal supervision of oil markets and to increase penalties for subverting markets.

title: Pfizer Nears Sale of Infant Nutrition Unit
description: Pfizer is nearing a deal to sell its infant nutrition business, with a winning buyer that could be picked as soon as next week, people briefed on the matter said Tuesday.

title: Indian Companies Spend Overseas for Growth
description: Piramal Healthcare became the latest Indian company to invest overseas, with an agreement Monday to buy a research and development portfolio from Bayer HealthCare Pharmaceuticals of Germany.

title: Pfizer Close to Selling Another Unit
description: Pfizer is nearing a deal to sell its infant nutrition business, with a winning buyer that could be picked as soon as next week, people briefed on the matter said Tuesday.

title: Seeing a Global Warming Connection
description: A recent poll shows that many Americans believe recent weather events were likely made worse by global warming.

title: In Poll, Many Link Weather Extremes to Climate Change
description: Scientists may hesitate to link some of the weather extremes of recent years to global warming  but the public, it seems, is already there.

title: Stoudemire and Knicks Have Plenty to Cheer
description: The broadest smile in the building, 90 minutes before tip-off Tuesday night, belonged to a coy and nearly giddy Amare Stoudemire, an antsy star waiting for his chance to join a Knicks joyride that is still accelerating, improbably, toward the finish.

description: lexicographer \lek-s-k-gr-fr\ noun

title: Unpleasant Whiff of Politics Seen in Afghan Pullout
description: HONG KONG  A general who once commanded Australian forces in Afghanistan said the decision by Australia and leading NATO countries to speed up the pullout of their troops from the Afghan theater carries an unpleasant whiff of politics and self-interest.

title: Three More Players Suspended, and Raffi Torres Is Next
description: 1:15 p.m. | Updated The N.H.L. announced that Phoenixs Raffi Torres will have a hearing Friday, and until then, he is suspended indefinitely.

title: Demographics and the 2012 Election
description: In a column in Campaign Stops, Timothy Egan writes:

title: I Know What It Feels Like
description: HUNTINGDON, Tenn.  Patrick Steele stood alone near the door to the locker room. It was a Friday night doubleheader, the girls before the boys, and the gym at Big Sandy was as full as any Carroll Academy had seen.

title: BJPs Delhi Win Another Blow for Congress
description: The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) won big in Delhis municipal elections on Sunday, preserving their majority in the north and east corporations while leading in the South to capture a total of 138 seats of the 272 seats.

title: News Quiz | April 18, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: So, You Want to Move Back to India?
description: A recent article about the children of Indian and Chinese immigrants moving back to their parents home country to seek their own American Dream hit a nerve with New York Times readers, who alternately lamented Americas moribund growth prospects and wrote enviously of those moving.

title: Vodafone Takes Legal Action Over Tax Proposal in India
description: The British telecommunications giant Vodafone said Tuesday that it had started legal proceedings against the Indian government over a proposed retroactive tax law that could cost the company more than $2 billion, Mark Scott writes for DealBook in The New York Times.

title: Arizona Republicans Pick Jesse Kelly for Congressional Race
description: LOS ANGELES  Republican voters in Arizona chose Jesse Kelly on Tuesday to face off against Ron Barber in the special election to fill the Congressional seat vacated by Gabrielle Giffords.

title: Test Yourself | Math, April 18, 2012
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Pete Diamantis at Math for America from the article In Haiti, Global Failures on a Cholera Epidemic.

title: April 18, 1906 | Earthquake Destroys Much of San Francisco
description: On April 18, 1906, an earthquake struck San Francisco and set off raging fires. The quake had a magnitude between 7.7 and 8.3 on the Richter scale and came shortly after 5 a.m. in two shocks that lasted more than a minute.

title: The Coachella Festival
description: WHAT is the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival?WHAT photographs in the slide shows of the festival do you find most interesting? (Here are photos from the first day, second day and third day.)

title: Margaret Atwood and Tax Reform
description: Simon Johnson is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.

title: Online Education Venture Lures Cash Infusion and Deals With 5 Top Universities
description: SAN FRANCISCO  An interactive online learning system created by two Stanford computer scientists plans to announce Wednesday that it has secured $16 million in venture capital and partnerships with four major universities.

title: What Is Your Fantasy Vacation?
description: T Magazines spring travel issue lists ideas for vacations from biking in Africa to shopping at a Belgian flea market, while The 45 Places to Go in 2012 include London for the Olympics, Mexico for a food festival and a Caribbean Island for pampering at a five-star resort. Where would you like to go, and what would you like to do, on your fantasy vacation?

title: Couche-Tard to Buy Statoil Fuel & Retail for $2.8 Billion
description: LONDON  The Canadian convenience store operator Alimentation Couche-Tard agreed on Wednesday to buy Statoil Fuel & Retail of Norway for $2.8 billion, part of a strategy by the Canadian company to expand into the Scandinavian and Eastern European markets.

title: Rankings Did Not Motivate College Official Who Falsified SAT Scores, Report Finds
description: The former admissions dean at Claremont McKenna College, who recently admitted to exaggerating SAT scores for several years, was not trying to improve the schools standing in the closely watched U.S. News & World Report rankings but instead attempting to conceal bad news from his boss, the schools president, who had established goals for higher SAT statistics, according to a report released Tuesday.

title: The Early Word: Positioning
description: Todays Times

title: Bright Side for Saints in Season-Long Suspension of Payton
description: The news media learned this week that Sean Payton essentially cannot have any contact with anyone in the N.F.L. during his season-long suspension. Many people in New Orleans believe Roger Goodell has been overzealous in punishing their team.

title: The First Opium Win
description: GHAZIPUR, India  Afghanistans annual opium harvest is coming, and the Taliban are expecting this years bumper crop to fund yet another season of political assassinations and coordinated attacks like the ones that struck Kabul and other Afghan cities this Sunday.

title: Can the Samajwadi Party Ease U.P.s Shia-Sunni Conflict?
description: A chill ran down Ruby Rizvis spine when, about three weeks ago, she heard the footsteps of hundreds of people outside her house near Mahboob Ganj Chauraha in Lucknow. After ensuring the safety of her three children, she peeped out of the window of her first-floor home. The mob, some 1,500 strong, she estimates, approached her husbands pharmacy on the ground floor, with swords and metal rods.

title: Dissident to Travel Out of Myanmar After 24 Years of Resolving to Stay Put
description: BANGKOK  After 24 years of stubborn campaigning for democracy in Myanmar and a steely determination to stay inside the country despite official admonishments to leave, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi will make her first foreign trip since 1988, visiting Norway and Britain, the spokesman for her political party said on Wednesday.

title: Prosecutors Press Norwegian on Extremist Affiliations
description: OSLO  The self-described anti-Islamic militant on trial for killing 77 people in Norway last summer insisted on Wednesday that he belonged to a cell within an organization with members across Europe.

title: How Exercise Could Lead to a Better Brain
description: The value of mental-training games may be speculative, as Dan Hurley writes in his article on the quest to make ourselves smarter, but there is another, easy-to-achieve, scientifically proven way to make yourself smarter. Go for a walk or a swim. For more than a decade, neuroscientists and physiologists have been gathering evidence of the beneficial relationship between exercise and brainpower. But the newest findings make it clear that this isnt just a relationship; it is the relationship. Using sophisticated technologies to examine the workings of individual neurons  and the makeup of brain matter itself  scientists in just the past few months have discovered that exercise appears to build a brain that resists physical shrinkage and enhance cognitive flexibility. Exercise, the latest neuroscience suggests, does more to bolster thinking than thinking does.

title: Can You Make Yourself Smarter?
description: Early on a drab afternoon in January, a dozen third graders from the working-class suburb of Chicago Heights, Ill., burst into the Mac Lab on the ground floor of Washington-McKinley School in a blur of blue pants, blue vests and white shirts. Minutes later, they were hunkered down in front of the Apple computers lining the rooms perimeter, hoping to do what was, until recently, considered impossible: increase their intelligence through training.

title: 2012 N.F.L. Mock Draft, Updated
description: Jonathan Bales is the founder ofTheDCTimes.comand is helping analyze draft prospects for The Fifth Down in his Scouting the Draft preview series.

title: Should I Stay or Should I Go?
description: I was in the middle of a staff meeting when my wife called. Our 16-year-old cat, who had not been eating for days, was clearly nearing the end and my wife had a vet on the way to the house. My son, who works with me, was about to leave to go home. I had what I would call the moment. All working people have them  the moment when you ask yourself, Should I go home, or should I stay and continue to fight the battle? Quick. Make a decision.

title: Conquering Food Deserts With Green Carts
description: 9:21 a.m. | Updated When we think of a desert, we dont picture southwest Philadelphia or a small town in upstate New York. But thats the description given to areas of the United States that lack ready access to healthy food  like fresh fruits and vegetables. These grocery-store deprived zones have come to be known as food deserts and the federal government estimates that they are home to millions of Americans (pdf), including more than 23 million people who live in low-income neighborhoods that are more than a mile from a supermarket.

title: Device Malfunction Casts Doubt on Industry Pledge
description: As doctors scramble to understand the risks posed by a flawed heart device component made by St. Jude Medical, the episode is raising a bigger question  whether the $10 billion heart device industry has fully embraced promised safety reforms.

If you speak of starting a project, or taking a trip, or trying to pay a debt, the outcome is always understood to be conditional.

When he finally got his chance to start, he quickly developed into one of the N.F.L.s best centers of the late 1970s and early 80s. Saul died on Sunday of complications from leukemia. He was 64 years old. A few thoughts:

title: A Match Made in Literary Heaven: Descendants of Dickens and Tolkien to Collaborate
description: A literary partnership between Charles Dickens and J. R. R. Tolkien would have been downright impossible, if not undesirable. (A tale of hungry workhouse hobbits who want more gruel? An evil, all-seeing eye visited by foreboding spirits on Christmas?) But a London publisher has nonetheless found a way to get their names onto the same project, in the form of a collaboration between descendants of Tolkien and Dickens, BBC News reported. The publisher Thames River Press said it would release two fantasy novels written by Michael Tolkien, aimed at younger readers and based on stories told to him by his grandfather, the Lord of the Rings author J. R. R. Tolkien. Gerald Dickens, a great-great grandson of Dickens, will narrate the audiobook releases. BBC News said the first book, called Wish, was inspired by the Florence Bone story The Rose-Colored Wish and chronicles two children who come into possession of an evil sorcerers enchanted artifact; the second book, Rainbow, takes its inspiration from another work by Ms. Bone called The Other Side of the Rainbow.

Vain Glorious | Ardency Inn
description: Coachella may not be where youd expect to have a beauty brand make its debut, but for Ardency Inn its proven to be ideal. Based on the energy and the aesthetic of New Yorks music scene, the concept is the brainchild of the Paris-born marketing and business development executive Gilles Kortzagadarian  an LVMH alum with time clocked at Dior, Benefit and Makeup Up For Ever  and his partner Stephane Siboni. The five-piece offering includes highly pigmented, buildable color cosmetics packaged in boxes with colorful boom box prints, modeled in the campaign visuals by an assortment of up-and-coming musicians like Holly Marilyn of the Child. The gimmicks, however, stop at the innovative, well-executed formulas. Standout products include Encore Long Play Lip Color in Lovecat (a teeth-whitening, blue-based red), Punker One Stroke Liquid Eyeliner (a multi-use felt-tip pen) and Night Lights Shadow in Borealis Black (gunmetal shimmer suspended in rich, refined black powder).

title: $420 Superman Check Sells for $160,000
description: It took 56 bids, but a check endorsed by the creators of Superman that conceded the ownership rights to the character went for $160,000 at auction at Comicconnect.com.  The check was issued by Detective Comics Inc. and was for $420, which included $130 for the rights to Superman, $210 for stories in Detective Comics, and two $36 payments for stories in More Fun and Adventure Comics. It was made out  incorrectly  to Seigel and Schuster, misspellings of the surnames of Jerome Siegel and Joe Shuster, the writer and artist team who created Superman.
