title: Dont Say Gay. Do Say Intelligent Design.
description: The small government Republicans who dominate the Tennessee Legislature are taking a very active role in public education. Earlier this month the governor allowed passage of a law protecting teachers who challenge the scientific weaknesses of topics such as biological evolution, the chemical origins of life, global warming and human cloning. The sponsors say it fosters critical thinking; its opponents point out the obvious: Its an anti-science measure intended to promote creationism and intelligent design, and to cast doubt on climate change.

title: Is Citi Just the Beginning?
description: When I walked into work this morning, I found this anonymous message on my voicemail. The call, of course, was referring to the fact that Citigroups shareholders voted down CEO Vikram Pandits $14.9 million pay package for 2011. (The caller was wrong to refer to Pandit as the chairman.) True, the vote was nonbindingthe result of Dodd-Frank, which calls for shareholder votes on pay packagesbut it has clearly shaken Citi, which announced that it would meet with shareholder groups to hear their complaints. Their main gripe is that Pandits pay is not linked strongly enough to performance. But the main reason Im posting this readers short response is that I think she may well be on to something:

title: Summitt Stepping Down as Tennessee Coach
description: Less than a year after she received a diagnosis of early onset Alzheimers disease, Pat Summitt has stepped down as Tennessees womens basketball coach, ending her remarkable 38-year career in building one of the signature programs in the sport.

title: Tesco to Spend $1.6 Billion to Revive U.K. Business
description: LONDON  The British supermarket chain Tesco announced a 1 billion investment program Wednesday that it hopes will revive earnings in its home market by expanding its online business while adding fewer large stores.

title: In Arizona, Immigrants Make Plans in Shadows
description: PHOENIX  Miguel Guerra has a wife, three children and a house. He has a car, but no drivers license. He has business cards, but no immigration papers. He got into the habit of keeping his cellphone close when he drives so he can quickly call a cousin, the only legal resident among his relatives in the United States, in case he gets pulled over.

title: Making the Most of Nothing
description: ALTHOUGH I am married with no plans to be single, I recently signed up for several online dating sites as research for a book I am writing. The process was fun until I saw a question asking me to describe my hair. I didnt want to check the bald box. I wanted to say I had a shaved head. But a shaved head wasnt a choice. (What? No write-ins?) So I sighed and checked bald, no doubt setting off an instant downgrade of my profile.

title: Champions League: Barcelona at Chelsea
description: Bayern Munichs 2-1 victory over Real Madrid on Tuesday, on a last-minute goal by Mario Gomez, was a terrific way to start the Champions League semifinals. Wednesdays match  Barcelona at Chelsea  was just as good. To follow the game as it happened, read on.

title: A Comfy Chair? A Little Quiet? Your Own Table? Sorry, Maam, Were All Out
description: Can restaurant design be discriminatory?

title: Sony Is Said to Gain Europes Approval on $2.2 Billion EMI Bid
description: Sony has won European regulators approval for its $2.2 billion takeover of EMI Music Publishing, which would create the largest catalog of songs in the world, according to a person briefed on the process.

title: Cavaliers Continue Slide; Pistons Play for Pride
description: N.B.A. draft conspiracy theorists may have raised an eyebrow or two if they were watching the Cleveland Cavaliers at the Detroit Pistons on Tuesday. The Cavs, 13th in the Eastern Conference, and the Pistons at 10th, are clearly cruising toward the lottery.

title: Italy Pushes Back Balanced Budget by 2 Years
description: ROME  Prime Minister Mario Monti on Wednesday pushed back Italys balanced budget target by a year, amid a deepening recession that economists say has been worsened by new austerity measures.

title: On Our Radar: Tree Killer Crosses the Hudson
description: The emerald ash borer has been found east of the Hudson River for the first time, in the Dutchess County hamlet of Rhinecliff. Luckily, the colony was caught less than a year after it got established, forestry experts say. [Associated Press]

title: After Argentinas Move on Oil Company, Spanish Corporations Take a Wary View
description: MADRID  N2S, a Spanish supplier of software to the energy sector, has almost half of its 85 employees in Latin America, spread among Mexico, Brazil and Peru.

title: Fresh Face | Amira Ahmed
description: The breakout model Amira Ahmed is more than just a beautiful face framed by a short, edgy haircut. For the half-Somali, half-Filipino, who surfs the West Coast  I love waiting for that special wave  and hits the Tignes in the French Alps to snowboard between fashion seasons (simply a must!), modeling is as much about traveling and maintaining the routine-less lifestyle she knows so well as it is a job. Born in Stockholm, the 22-year-old grew up on her stepfathers boat, where, she says the sea became my playground. Upon coming ashore, she attended boarding school in Prague, then college in London where she studied international relations. Its natural that I would find work that I could do everywhere, she says. Now based in Brooklyn, Ahmed most recently landed campaigns for Gap, AllSaints and LOreal. Just dont expect her to start nesting anytime soon.

title: Ask Anne Lamott, Author of Some Assembly Required
description: What, exactly, do you ask a woman whos already written that I thought such awful thoughts that I cannot even say them out loud because they would make Jesus want to drink gin straight out of the cat dish, who has called her own mind barely inhabitable and added that when people have seen you at your worst, you dont have to put on the mask as much?

title: In Spain, Euro Rescue Fund May Face Its Biggest Test
description: LUXEMBOURG  The euro zones rescue fund has already helped mount full-scale bailouts of three of Europes smaller economies.

title: Justices Limit Suits Under Law on Torture
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court ruled unanimously  on Wednesday that the family of an American citizen killed during a visit to the West Bank may not sue the Palestinian Authority and the Palestine Liberation Organization under a 1991 federal law, the Torture Victim Protection Act.

title: When American Faith Transcended Differences
description: The obvious allusion in the title of Ross Douthats new book, Bad Religion, is to a veteran Los Angeles  punk band. But I kept thinking of Dan Aykroyds Saturday Night Live character Leonard Pinth-Garnell, a pompous fop who hosted sketches like Bad Cinema and Bad Ballet. Pinth-Garnell would introduce a ridiculous performance  think of John Belushi attempting arabesques  then sum up merrily at the end: Well now! That wasnt very good at all, was it?

title: Goldman Is Said to Be in Talks to Sell Petershill Fund
description: Goldman Sachs is said to be in negotiations to sell one of its most notable portfolios, Petershill, which has suffered some major setbacks in its hedge fund investments.

title: Earth Day and All Days: 10 Ways to Learn About the Environment
description: Sunday will be the 42nd annual Earth Day celebration. Here are 10 ideas for commemorating the day, observed each year on April 22, or exploring issues related to the environment in the classroom or home on any day of the year.

title: Berkshire Shareholders Unfazed by Buffett Diagnosis
description: Not every corporate executive gets a call from the president asking about his health. But then, there is only one Warren E. Buffett.

title: Sampling Rap, Salsa and Al Jazeera
description: AT a party last fall celebrating Terry Richardsons photography exhibition Mom & Dad at the Westway, a former strip joint turned nightclub in the far West Village, the D.J. Venus X blasted through a torrent of disparate musical styles during her two-hour-plus set: Chicago juke (a low-fi interpretation of break beat); Dominican dembow (a Latin spin on reggaetn); local underground rap; South Africa house music; Spanish salsa; Turkish techno.

title: Reimagined Cinderella Casts Its Leading Couple
description: The Broadway-bound production of Rodgers & Hammersteins Cinderella has found a leading lady who fits the glass slipper  as well as the actor to play her prince. Laura Osnes, who starred as the outlaw Bonnie Parker in the Broadway musical Bonnie & Clyde last year, will play a re-invented Cinderella in the production aiming to open during the 2012-13 theater season, while Santino Fontana (Sons of the Prophet, Billy Elliot) will play the prince, the shows producers said on Wednesday.

title: Clemenss Lawyers Want to Limit Pettittes Testimony
description: WASHINGTON  The lawyers for Roger Clemens are seeking to limit the testimony of Yankees pitcher Andy Pettitte at Clemenss perjury trial, according to a document filed Wednesday in United States District Court.

title: Consumer Advocates Seek Halt to Yo-Yo Car Financing
description: Consumer advocates are urging the federal government to crack down on so-called yo-yo automobile financing. Thats when a buyer is allowed to leave the sales lot with a car even though the sale isnt technically final, only to be called back to the dealership days later and pressured to sign a new financing agreement with less favorable terms.

title: Dear Reformers: Teachers Are Neither Heroes Nor Zeroes
No Disney Ending for This Woodworker
description: What would a world without art be like? In Pinocchios Ashes, the Danish playwright Jokum Rohdes leaden satire, the answer is: unpleasant.

title: The Flaws in the New Liquidation Authority
description: How would one of the large American financial institutions fare in the new Dodd-Frank Orderly Liquidation Authority? Thats the question that motivates a new paper I wrote for a symposium at the University of Cincinnati, and it seems to have already hit a nerve.

title: City Opera Returning to Its Roots
description: New York City Opera, which last year announced a plan to take opera to the people with performances around the city, said on Wednesday that it had established agreements to perform in two places: the Brooklyn Academy of Music and New York City Center, its original home.

title: A Big Step Forward for Liquefied Gas Exports
description: Cheniere Energy crossed a big hurdle in its push to export natural gas this week when the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission gave its stamp of approval to the Houston companys proposed liquefied gas export terminal in Sabine Pass, La. FERCs assent had been considered the most uncertain element of a long government approval process, and the Texas-based company now hopes to start exporting by late 2015 or early 2016. It would be the first major liquefied gas export terminal in the lower 48 states.

title: Volkswagen Group to Add Ducati to Product Portfolio
description: 10:48 a.m. | Updated

title: Judge Quits Trayvon Martin Case Over Potential Conflict
description: The Florida judge overseeing the murder case against George Zimmerman stepped aside on Wednesday at the request of Mr. Zimmermans lawyer, who had questioned whether her assignment could create a potential conflict of interest.

title: Reactions to Death of Dick Clark, New Years Eve Icon
description: 9:15 p.m. | Updated

title: Dickey Picks Bad Day to Have a Bad Start
description: ATLANTA  For all the fickleness of its flight, R. A. Dickeys knuckleball had been producing remarkably steady results for its owner.

title: Beauty Spots
description: SCENT MEMORIES

title: City App Contest Won by a Tool for Those Who Make Apps
description: There were almost 100 entries into New York Citys third annual Big Apps contest, grappling with urban issues like transportation, education and land use. In the end, the top prize went to a project whose main goal was to make it easy for developers to make more apps.

title: Name Change
description: The filmmaker Sharon Shattuck recalls the apprehension she experienced when her father, a transgender cross-dresser, decided to legally adopt a womans name.

title: Name Change
description: Ive heard much debate in the past year about what constitutes a healthy family. Some politicians argue that the best environment for a child is one with a mother and a father  and the underlying context here is that a normal family should be helmed by a normal heterosexual couple.

title: TV Emperor of Rock n Roll and New Years Eve Dies at 82
description: Dick Clark, the perpetually youthful-looking television host whose long-running daytime song-and-dance fest, American Bandstand, did as much as anyone or anything to advance the influence of teenagers and rock n roll on American culture, died on Wednesday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 82.

title: Fig. 19
description: BACK in the early 2000s, a lounge called Passerby blurred the line between gallery and bar. Attached to Gavin Browns Enterprise gallery in Chelsea, it drew cool, artsy patrons who might have gone to an opening at the gallery earlier that night.

title: Theater Talkback: A Good Play Can Be Read as Well as Seen
description: You cant see Quiara Alegra Hudess Water by the Spoonful right now, even though it just won the Pulitzer Prize for drama. The play, the second part of a trilogy, ran for less than a month in its world premiere at Hartford Stage in late 2011. The other two finalists, Jon Robin Baitzs Other Desert Cities and Stephen Karams Sons of the Prophet, were far better known, having enjoyed prominent and well-received New York productions; Other Desert Cities is playing on Broadway and is a likely contender for the Tony Award for best play, to be announced in June.

title: Syrian First Lady Is Urged to Challenge Crackdown
description: President Bashar al-Assad made a rare appearance with his wife, Asma, on Syrian state television this week, greeting throngs of supporters and packing food aid for the restive city of Homs, shattered by a military bombardment this year that was itself ordered by Mr. Assad.

title: Flying Through Airport Lines
description: MORE than 10 years after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks completely altered the airport experience, travelers have a variety of options that will shorten wait times at security and immigration. But speedier processing has some downsides. Some programs charge a fee, and all require surrendering such personal information as employment background, travel history and biological data like fingerprints.

title: More Than Mrs. Sting
description: DURING a visit to India to celebrate her 50th birthday, Trudie Styler consulted a seer. Recently, she recalled the episode, highlighted by a reading of her Vedic chart, with mock incredulity. Oh, madam, by golly, this chart is very unique, she was told. By 2012, you could be asking for the Taj Mahal  and you would get it.

title: Hot Off the Press | Kiosk Paper
description: Alisa Grifo and Marco ter Haar Romeny started Kiosk with an especially infectious idea: to highlight functional design goods from around the world, focusing on one country at a time. Their store, perched one floor above SoHos Spring Street, opened in 2005, and its concept quickly caught on. They now curate small international pop-ups, including one in the Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museums famed gift shop.

title: U.S. Companies, Hiring Abroad
description: American-owned multinational companies grew in 2010, but they mostly grew abroad.

title: Enjoying Turntables Without Obsessing
description: Buying records is easy. You can find them by the milk crate at yard sales, for a few dollars apiece in used record stores, and there are new, special pressings by contemporary musicians like Shelby Lynne, whose Just a Little Lovin album, at $30, is a top seller. But buying the instrument needed to listen to them, a turntable, is a different matter.

title: Do Romneys Favorability Ratings Matter?
description: Mitt Romneys personal favorability ratings have been relatively poor throughout this election cycle. In his best surveys, roughly equal numbers of Americans have said they hold favorable and unfavorable impressions of Mr. Romney while in other cases they have been substantially net-negative.

title: PayPal Strength Helps eBay Exceed Forecasts
description: EBay, the Web site where people once auctioned off the detritus of attics and garages, is quietly positioning itself to become a force in mobile retailing, as evidenced by a sustained turnaround of its Internet marketplace and the soaring popularity of the PayPal online payment system.

title: The Yoga Moguls Sordid Fall
description: Back in 2010, Mimi Swartz wrote a profile in The Times Magazine of John Friend, the founder of Anusara Yoga, who at the time was expanding his brand of feel-good yoga to 200,000 students in 70 countries and was planning a huge arts-and-yoga center in Encinitas, Calif.

title: Rice Noodle Salad With Crispy Tofu and Lime-Peanut Dressing
description: Unrefined expeller-pressed peanut oil contributes a wonderful nutty flavor to this dressing.

title: Why Was Warren Buffett Screened for Prostate Cancer?
description: A day after Warren Buffett announced he had prostate cancer, the question on the minds of many men and their doctors is this: Why was an 81-year-old man screened for the disease in the first place?

title: Share Your Memories of Dick Clark and New Years Eve
description: Dick Clark, who died on Wednesday, helped make rock n roll a staple of American pop culture with American Bandstand.

title: A Swiss-E.U. Battle Over (European) Immigrants
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union reacted angrily Wednesday to a move by Switzerland to stem a recent wave of immigrants from central and eastern Europe, calling it discriminatory and unjustified.

title: For a Closing School, Mock Trial Team Successes Are Bittersweet
Photos of Soldiers Posing With Body Parts Add Strain to a Taxed Relationship
description: The United States presence in Afghanistan received another political black eye on Wednesday after The Los Angeles Times published photographs apparently showing United States soldiers posing with body parts of dead insurgents. Reacting quickly, a wide assortment of American officials, all the way up to President Obama, condemned the actions. Our colleagues Graham Bowley and Alissa J. Rubin report that Leon E. Panetta, the defense secretary, said of the photographs: This is not who we are, and its certainly not what we represent when it comes to the great majority of men and women in uniform. President Obama called for an investigation of the matter and said that those responsible would be held accountable, according to the White House.

title: On and Off the Clock, Conduct Matters
description: Michael W. Peregrine, a partner at the law firm McDermott Will & Emery, advises corporations, officers and directors on issues related to corporate governance, fiduciary duties and internal investigations.

title: In Rome, Art Meets Astronomy
description: Romes artistic bent would usually be described as a mix of Renaissance and Baroque, with dusting of ancient. But through April 22, the Fondazione Alda Fendi is showing Transit of Venus, its new Esperimenti, which runs counter to that trend. This event, the latest in occasional multimedia shows that blend projection and displays, is a collaboration between Alda Fendi of the fashion house of the same name, and the curator Raffaele Curi. It is loosely inspired by the passage of Venus between the Earth and the Sun, estimated to happen June 6.

title: Reporter in Azerbaijan Beaten After Filming Dispute
description: MOSCOW  An Azeri newspaper reporter was severely beaten by guards from Azerbaijans state oil company on Tuesday when he tried to film the demolition of houses by company employees.

title: UBSs Stenzler Departs as Co-Head of U.S. Mergers
description: UBSs co-head of mergers and acquisitions in the United States, Ehren Stenzler, has left the firm, a spokesman for the Swiss firm said on Wednesday. It is the second prominent departure from the investment bank in two days.

title: Italdesign-Giugiaro Maintains Traction With a Longtime Client
description: Giorgetto Giugiaro and his firm Italdesign recently unveiled new designs for an old client, demonstrating that the studio has retained customers since its acquisition by the Volkswagen Group in 2010.

title: Its Not You, Its Me, We Tell Our Clothes
description: CATHY BEGIEN estimates she has purchased 50 shirts from Steven Alan, the house brand of the independent-design hub based in downtown Manhattan. I loved their washed-out, wrinkly, comfy preppiness, said Ms. Begien, 36, a brand manager for a designer, who lives in the West Village. I loved having a brand-new one because it smelled a certain way.

title: In a Prebuttal, Romney Attacks Obamas Economic Record
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Mitt Romney on Wednesday issued a withering dissection of President Obamas speech at the Democratic National Convention in Denver four years ago, delivering a point-by-point rebuttal of what he said were his opponents unfulfilled promises to revive the economy.

title: Scouting Report
description: OPENINGS

title: Alex Pragers Compulsion
description: Alex Prager, whose work has appeared in The Times Magazine, has a new must-see exhibition: Compulsion, showing at the Yancey Richardson Gallery in New York. In addition to photographs, Prager puts forth a beautiful short film, La Petite Mort. Pragers witty take on orgasm brings high drama and humor together in a most unusual way.

title: Ambitious Photo Tools That Wont Make You Feel Dumb
description: If you want to share a photo on the fly, theres Instagram, and then theres everyone else.

title: Stone Links: The Unanswered Question
description: A gathering of recent philosophy-related links.

title: Pictures of the Day: Mexico and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Mexico, Gaza, South Korea and Afghanistan.

title: And the Walls Came Tumbling Down, Again
description: JANET W. FOSTER, a Columbia University architectural historian, is well versed in the nuances of the Dutch-American farmhouse, the slope of a Queen Anne, the hue of a Downingesque cottage.

title: London Debut for Sundance
description: LOS ANGELES  This is typically the time of the year when John Cooper, the director of the Sundance Film Festival, catches his breath. The art house spotlight has moved on to New York, where the Tribeca Film Festival started Wednesday. The Cannes Film Festival will take over from there. The next Sundance? Still a safe nine months away.

title: Bank of New York Mellon Earnings Slip
description: Bank of New York Mellon reported Wednesday that its first-quarter earnings fell 1 percent as revenue lost from the sale of a unit and lower foreign-exchange trading offset gains from rising asset levels.

title: The Church Versus the Right
description: In February, the Catholic Church attempted to impose its opposition to birth control on its employees, upsetting Democrats and the left. This week, the Church is criticizing Republicans, acting in the highest tradition of its social mission by speaking out against spending cuts on programs for the poor.

title: Of Pretzels, Space Heaters and the Fate of the Planet
description: A reader in New Mexico, John Mihelich, raises an interesting question about my recent article  about a climate change poll. The poll showed that a large majority of the public believes that global warming is influencing the weather in the United States and that it probably made some recent weather disasters worse.

title: Digital Notes: Coke and Spotify Team Up to Go Everywhere
description: Can Coke help bring Spotify to all the corners of the world?

title: TimesCast | Photos Strain Relations
description: April 18, 2012  In Afghanistan, newly released photos strain already tense relations with the United States.

title: Swingin on the Moon to Las Vegas Lounge Music
description: The wild party continues at the Iridium, where the singer and bandleader Terese Genecco recently celebrated her third anniversary of once-a-month Tuesday-evening performances with her raucous eight-piece Little Big Band. This spiky-haired self-described love child of Dean Martin and Judy Garland is a natural extrovert whose combined roles of performer, bandleader and M.C. make her a gregarious cheerleader for the brassy 50s and 60s Las Vegas lounge music she adores.

title: Apollo Raises Bid for Great Wolf to $7 a Share
description: The battle for Great Wolf Resorts isnt over yet.

title: Rocks Most Benign Satisfactions
description: Pick your poison: the simp or the cad. Being held through the night or getting a high five on the way out the door. Warm and fuzzy or cold and brusque. Pretty lies or ugly truth.

title: Are Most People in Denial About Their Weight?
description: As I was walking through the gym the other day, I caught a glimpse of an overweight woman across the room. But then I did a double take, and then another. The woman was me  I had seen my own reflection in a distant mirror and, for a split second, hadnt recognized myself.

title: Dick Clarks Insight  Tape New Years Stars in August
description: Ted Harbert, the chairman of NBC Broadcasting, said that one of Dick Clarks great strengths was that he was a great booker. He knew that stars made the rating for these shows. One of his most brilliant coups, Mr. Harbert said, was how he assembled the New Years Eve show.

title: Seeing Scipio Through Eyes of Mozart as a Teenager
description: Back in 2001, when the Gotham Chamber Opera was known as the Henry Street Chamber Opera, it introduced itself with the American stage premiere of a bona fide Mozart rarity, Il Sogno di Scipione: a work that the composer wrote when he was 15 but that apparently went unperformed until 1979. The staging, by Christopher Alden, was modern and quirky, and a universe removed from the vision of mythical antiquity that Mozart imagined. But it was a hit, and the company quickly found its footing as a purveyor of unusual works, old and new.

title: Vatican Reprimands a Group of U.S. Nuns and Plans Changes
description: The Vatican has appointed an American bishop to rein in the largest and most influential group of Catholic nuns in the United States, saying that an investigation found that the group had serious doctrinal problems.

title: Guitars Ring With Harmonious Humility, as Youth Meets Age
description: Innocence and experience have almost always found a meeting place in jazz, which by its nature produces an endless tide of youthful prodigies and wise old men. Theres nothing unusual about the exchange of insight across generations, but occasionally you see it happen in real time, as clearly as a light bulb flicking on in the room. Thats the case at the Blue Note this week, where the venerable guitarist Jim Hall has augmented his working trio with a second guitar player, the bright-eyed virtuoso Julian Lage.

title: 3 in Scandal Being Forced Out of Secret Service, Officials Say
description: WASHINGTON  Three Secret Service employees implicated in a prostitution scandal during President Obamas trip to Colombia last week are being forced out of the agency.

title: A Prefab, Short on the Fab
description: WEST HURLEY, N.Y.

title: Regulators Defend Derivatives Rule
description: Regulators approved a rule on Wednesday that spells out the type of derivatives dealers that will soon face federal oversight, a crucial piece of the broader regulation for the market that played a major role in the financial crisis.

title: Its Not About Winning the Game
description: Ruth Fremson has photographed a number of schools over the years, but shes gained  full access into only one, in 2007, at a high-achieving public high school in Massachusetts.

title: Mark Bittman on the Art of Making Pizza
description: Mark Bittman (who thinks the pizza you cook yourself is better than any you could buy) answered your pizza-making questions on The New York Times Facebook page Wednesday afternoon; below are highlights from the conversation. For recipes, how-to videos and more, let the Pizza Issue be your guide: nytimes.com/pizza.

title: The New York Times/CBS Poll
description: The results from the latest New York Times/CBS poll on the 2012 presidential race.

title: Unearthing Dwellers of an Aquatic Past
description: Ken Angielczyk, an assistant curator at the Field Museum of Natural History, is searching for fossils of ancient mammal relatives in northeastern Brazil.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted April 13 through 17 with 957 adults throughout the United States.

title: In Wariness on Economy, Poll Finds Opening for Romney
description: A rising number of Americans see improvement in the economy, but a persistent wariness about their own financial circumstances is allowing Mitt Romney to persuade voters that he could improve their economic prospects more than President Obama, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: A Home in The Farmhouse Style in Malta
description: A four-bedroom house, built using the limestone of a dismantled 18th-century Maltese palace, has the solid frame of a traditional Maltese farmhouse, but a fully modernized interior.

title: House Hunting in ... Malta
description: A HOME IN THE FARMHOUSE STYLE IN MALTA

title: Dick Clark Dies at 82
description: Dick Clark, the television host of American Bandstand, did much to advance the influence of teenagers and rock n roll on American culture.

title: Homes for $500,000
description: Properties in Texas, Chicago and Washington, D.C.

title: What You Get for ... $500,000
description: TAYLOR, TEX.

title: Views on the 2012 Election, Candidates and the Economy
description: Results from nationwide telephone interviews conducted April 13-17 with 957 adults, including 852 registered voters.

title: Devils Still Put Their Faith in Brodeur
description: NEWARK  The Devils have much more pressing issues these days than their goaltender. They need to cut back on their penalties, for one, because the Florida Panthers are carving them apart with their efficient power play during the teams first-round playoff series.

title: Barcelona Ballet at City Center
description: The dancer ngel Corella brought his company to City Center on Tuesday.

title: In the Catskills, Assembled From a Kit
description: A modern prefab house made of galvanized steel is awash in light and air.

title: House Passes Transportation Extension
description: The House on Wednesday easily passed the 10th stop-gap measure extending existing transportation law, this time through September  adding the Keystone XL Pipeline into the mix.

title: Saving an Officers Life, With Running Clothes Beneath His Scrubs
description: View more videos at: http://nbcnewyork.com.

title: Laundry Gear
description: STUART LESLIE is an industrial designer who has helped develop a surprisingly broad range of consumer products, from home appliances to the packaging for single servings of Heinz ketchup.

title: Embracing Spanish Heritage and Riding a Citys Energy
description: Dancers like ngel Corella are hard to come by, and that speaks to more than just the radiance of his technique. Hes generous with his talent too. On Tuesday evening Mr. Corella returned to City Center with his Barcelona Ballet, formed in 2008 as Corella Ballet Castilla y Len.

title: Radicchio or Asian Greens Salad With Golden Beets and Walnuts
description: Walnut vinaigrette is especially compatible with bitter greens like radicchio and pungent Asian greens. Both work beautifully here.

title: 007 Shakes Things Up in Istanbul
description: While much of Istanbul is beaming with pride that it was chosen as a location for Skyfall, the next movie in the James Bond series, some merchants in the Old City seem to be shaken, not stirred.

title: Sales at Mitchell Gold + Bob Williams and Others
description: Upholstery is 20 percent off and floor models are 30 percent off at Lekker Home, through April 22 with the code springbreak (the Dromedary love seat by John Derian, originally $2,850, is $2,280); 1317 Washington Street, Boston, (617) 542-6464, lekkerhome.com.

title: Brooklyn Toile, Graffiti and All
description: The traditional toile pattern depicts pastoral scenes, but the wallpaper company Flavor Paper is reinventing it with three new Brooklyn-themed designs.

title: Scene City: Vanity Fair Kicks Off Tribeca Film Festival
description: Movie stars, power players and politicos turned out for Vanity Fairs annual Tribeca Film Festival party.

title: Dartmouth Chooses Architects for Revamping of Art Museum
description: Dartmouth College has selected Tod Williams Billie Tsien Architects to design a major expansion and renovation of its Hood Museum of Art, the college announced on Wednesday. The Hoods collection has increased to more than 70,000 works and the project, which will increase gallery space at the museums 1985 building and add classrooms, new entrance areas and amenities, is part of Dartmouths new Arts District.

title: Tumi Prices I.P.O. at $18 a Share, Above Estimated Range
description: Tumi is packed and ready for its initial public stock offering.

title: Oven-Roasted Salmon, Quinoa and Asparagus With Wasabi Oil
description: Seasoned oils like the wasabi oil I buy at my local specialty grocery can embellish a simply cooked piece of fish, a bowl of grains or steamed vegetables. Here the salmon is cooked in the oven, and the wasabi-seasoned oil (mine is canola oil-based) is drizzled on just before serving. Its served with quinoa, which you can also dress with the oil, and vegetables in season.

title: Brooklyn Museums Feminist Art Post to Become Permanent
description: Elizabeth A. Sackler, the art collector and philanthropist, announced a major donation to the Brooklyn Museum at its Brooklyn Ball gala benefit on Wednesday evening, where she was an honoree. Ms. Sackler, whose gift created the Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art five years ago at the museum, announced a seven-figure donation to support the establishment of a permanent curator of feminist art for the institution.

title: Deconstructing the Pulitzer Fiction Snub
description: To the Editor:

title: Independents in Washington
description: Artists, actors and shopkeepers are turning a once gritty stretch of 14th Street into a creative corridor.

title: The NK Shop Moves to a New Space in Los Angeles
description: After three years on Highland Avenue in Hollywood, Todd Nickey and Amy Kehoe have moved their beloved NK Shop, and their interiors business, to the heart of the Los Angeles design district. They merged two storefronts on Beverly Boulevard into a 3,200-square-foot retail space with plenty of room to display their own furniture line, as well as tabletop and decorative accessories (by the likes of Olmay Home, Campo de Fiori and Terrafirma) and vintage pieces.

title: Donna, in Williamsburg, Brings Back the Patina of the Old
description: Nobody can patina like Evan and Oliver Haslegrave, the brothers, ages 29 and 32, who have designed so many of a certain type of neo-antique East Village, Lower East Side and Brooklyn establishment in recent years: two bars (Elsa and Duck Duck) and three restaurants (Paulie Gees, Manhattan Inn and Goat Town), as well as a beer store, an ice-cream parlor and a clothing boutique. They are distinguished by the Haslegraves exquisite lighting and handcrafted details, and recall the McNally brothers in their early years.

title: A Garden Inspired by Mexico
description: The vast majority the of 3,000 plants in John G. Faireys Texas garden are from seeds of heat-tolerant natives of the area.

title: Growing From His Mistakes
description: HEMPSTEAD, Tex.

title: Greenhill Swings to a 1st-Quarter Profit
description: Greenhill & Company reported a $16.1 million profit for its first quarter, swinging from a loss a year ago as the firm benefited from a 51 percent surge in advisory revenue.

title: Gardening Advice From John G. Fairey
description: JOHN G. FAIREY has much to teach gardeners, in his offhand way, when they visit.

title: On the Road to the Cannabis Cup
description: It may not be celebrated like roses or orchids, but marijuana is a flowering plant all the same, with a community of growers dedicated to its propagation (and boosting THC content). Each November, the best of them gather in Amsterdam for the High Times Cannabis Cup, a kind of taste-off for the stoner set.

title: Qualcomm Beats Forecast, but Strains to Get Chips
description: Qualcomm, the largest maker of mobile phone semiconductors, reported earnings that exceeded Wall Streets expectations on Wednesday, but it also forecast disappointing sales and profit for the current quarter as it increases spending to improve output of new chips for smartphones.

title: Yums Profit Jumps 73%, Helped by Taco Bell Sales
description: Yum Brands, the owner of the KFC and Pizza Hut restaurant brands, said Wednesday that its first-quarter profit rose 73 percent as new menu items at the Taco Bell chain helped its same-store sales rebound.

title: Market Ready
description: Q. Whats the best way to declutter my home before I show it to potential buyers? Can I leave packed boxes in a corner or do I need to move things into storage?

title: Where Art and Design Meet
description: The 15th annual Sculpture Objects and Functional Art Fair opens on Friday at the Park Avenue Armory, with more than 50 galleries showing studio art and design, all for sale and open to the public.

title: An Anti-Abortion Film
description: To the Editor:

title: The Budget Mess
description: To the Editor:

title: The Plight of Lefties
description: To the Editor:

title: Mixed Pairs Winners at Spring Nationals
description: The winners of the Rockwell Mixed Pairs at the Spring Nationals in Memphis last month were Sheila Gabay of Newton, Mass., and Pat McDevitt of Brookline, Mass. They finished two-thirds of a board ahead of Bernace De Young of Miami and Richard Reitman of Los Gatos, Calif. Third were Les and Gloria Bart, a husband and wife from Bradenton, Fla.

title: Antibiotics in Livestock
description: To the Editor:

title: Bills Seek to Change Rule on Generic Drug Labels
description: Democrats in the Senate and House introduced companion bills Wednesday that would permit generic drug companies to update warning information about the drugs they manufacture, a change that could allow patients to sue the companies for failing to warn about the risks of taking their drugs.

title: Lionel Richie on Top After 26 Years
description: After 26 years Lionel Richie is No. 1 again. Mr. Richies latest album, Tuskegee (Mercury Nashville), with new country versions of his old hits like Hello and Easy, made with stars like Shania Twain and Willie Nelson, is on the top of Billboards album chart in its third week of release. Helped by a prime-time special last week on CBS, Tuskegee sold 128,553 copies, the label announced, a 35 percent jump from the previous week. It is Mr. Richies first No. 1 album since Dancing on the Ceiling in 1986, which featured hits like Say You, Say Me and the title track. Adeles 21 (XL/Columbia) holds at No. 2, with 92,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan, which rounds its publicly reported numbers to the nearest thousand. Nicki Minajs Pink Friday: Roman Reloaded (Young Money/Cash Money/Universal Republic), which opened at No. 1 last week, fell to No. 3, with 81,000 sales, a 68 percent drop. And the British boy band One Direction  not to be confused with the American group One Direction, now suing the British group over its use of the name  holds at No. 5, with 66,000 sales of its debut, Up All Night (Syco/Columbia). Also this week, two new albums charted high: New Life (RCA) by the R&B singer Monica  is No. 4, with 69,000, and Slipstream (Redwing) by Bonnie Raitt opened at No. 6, with 64,000, her highest-charting album and best sales week in 18 years, Billboard reported.

title: Witness Describes Bomb-Making Process for Thwarted Subway Plot
description: The ingredients could be found in supermarkets, beauty shops and hardware stores. They included seemingly innocuous items like flour, butter, batteries, a two-liter soda bottle and Christmas lights. And, the man added, ball bearings.

title: Anticipating Space Shuttles Arrival, Old Warplanes Ship Out
description: On the flight deck of the aircraft carrier Intrepid, sacrifices had to be made.

title: John Golding Dies at 82; Zeroed In on Abstraction
description: John Golding, an English art critic, scholar and painter who courted abstraction in every facet of his career  seeking to define it in the work of others and to produce it in his own  died on April 9. He was 82.

title: Canada: Request to Leave Guantnamo
description: Omar Khadr has applied to be transferred to a prison in Canada from Guantnamo Bay to serve the remainder of his sentence for war crimes. Mr. Khadr, a Canadian, was captured in Afghanistan in 2002 after a firefight that left an American sergeant, Christopher Speer, dead. In 2010, a United States military commission sentenced Mr. Khadr, who was 15 at the time of the episode, to 40 years in prison, but he is only required to be imprisoned for a maximum of 8 years under the terms of a plea bargain. The Conservative government had been reluctant to repatriate him. But a government official, who declined to be identified because of restrictions on discussing negotiations with other governments, said American officials had asked for his application to be granted as a diplomatic favor.

title: Tunnel and Dredging Projects to Make Room for Bigger Ships in Harbor
description: The Panama Canal was more than 2,000 miles away, but very much on the minds of the officials who stood next to a hulking machine on Staten Island on Wednesday to announce a project that involves building a water tunnel to Brooklyn and dredging New York Harbor to make room for deeper cargo ships.

title: In a Shift, Medicare Pushes Bids
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration said Wednesday that it would vastly expand the use of competitive bidding to buy medical equipment for Medicare beneficiaries after a one-year experiment saved money for taxpayers and patients without harming the quality of care.

title: Bloomberg Calls for Residential Smoking Rules
description: The owners of residential buildings would have to adopt smoking policies and disclose them to prospective apartment buyers and tenants, under a law proposed Wednesday by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who has made curbing smoking a cornerstone of his public health policy.

title: I Won the Ballgame
description: HUNTINGDON, Tenn.  It was a last chance. The score was close. And Tonya Lutz was not going to let the opportunity slip.

title: Guantnamo Trials Should Be Open
description: LAST week I stood before a military judge at Guantnamo Bay to argue that the press and public had a constitutional right to observe the proceedings of military commissions. It is an argument Ive made scores of times on behalf of news organizations objecting to closed proceedings in criminal and civil trials, but this was the first time that a military commission  part of a system of tribunals created in 2006 to try terrorism suspects  agreed to hear such arguments from the press.

title: U.S. Caps Emissions in Drilling for Fuel
description: WASHINGTON  Oil and gas companies will have to capture toxic and climate-altering gases from wells, storage sites and pipelines under new air quality standards issued on Wednesday by the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Early Bloomers
description: THE naturalist and philosopher Henry David Thoreau coined a wonderful word for an imagined instrument in his 1854 book, Walden: the realometer. Thoreaus realometer would allow an inquiring person to measure the reality of his perceptions, to push past the mud and slush of opinion, and prejudice, and tradition, and delusion, and appearance ... to a hard bottom.

title: NATO After Libya
description: NATO can be proud of the role it played in supporting the overthrow of Libyas murderous dictator, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. But the alliances own confidential assessment, reported in The Times on Sunday, pointed out that European members, who were among the first to call for military action, could never have pulled it off without extensive American involvement.

title: In a Semifinal, One Shot by Chelsea Foils Many Chances by Barcelona
description: LONDON  The pressure was withering, two dozen shots whizzing past, the teams own control of the ball infrequent. But Chelsea knew that its patience and muscularity had given trouble through the years to Barcelonas finesse.

title: On Broadway, Investors With Shallow Pockets
description: Broadway musicals usually cost $5 million to $10 million to produce, and that money often comes in checks for $50,000 or more from experienced investors who wouldnt mind the tax write-off if their show flops. But this seasons revival of Godspell has introduced a new breed: shareholders who have put as little as $1,000 each into the $5 million musical and in return have gotten a rare inside look at show business, including the ear of the lead producer.

title: The Intrepid Prepares for the Enterprise
description: The Intrepid Sea, Air and Space Museum of New York City removed three planes from its deck in preparation for the arrival of the Enterprise, the prototype for space shuttles.

title: Neighbors Wet Concrete Floods Hotel Cafe
description: A wall gave way on the first floor of Le Parker Meridien hotel in Midtown Manhattan late Wednesday morning and sent concrete spewing into the hotel coffee bar from a construction site next door, the citys Buildings Department said.

title: Womens Work
description: Were accustomed to talking about a divided Supreme Court, riven with ideological conflict. But a mean little 5-to-4 decision that the court issued last month all but overlooked in the breathless run-up to the Affordable Care Act arguments, suggests another kind of divide as well: a gender gap.

title: Speculators and the Gas Pump
description: No matter what Mitt Romney and other Republicans say, there are no easy fixes for rising gas prices. With the national average price hovering near $4 a gallon, Americans are understandably concerned, and President Obama was right to call for more scrutiny of the oil markets.

title: Things I Saw  No. 5
description: Suggestions for what youd like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

title: Need Research on Generation Y? Theres a Film for That
description: NBCUNIVERSAL is forming a unit called Curve Films, but there is no intention for it to compete with siblings at the company like Universal Pictures or Universal Television.

title: Hit on Hossa Draws Suspension and Adds to Safety Concerns
description: CHICAGO  The Chicago Blackhawks and the Phoenix Coyotes have played three overtime thrillers in the first three games of their series, but the focus at the United Center on Wednesday  as it has been across the N.H.L. throughout the playoffs  was on suspensions, illegal hits and player safety.

title: In Ohio, Hurdles for Both Candidates
description: ELYRIA, Ohio  The battle for Ohio is on, but for many voters here choosing between President Obama and Mitt Romney is like trying to decide between liver and brussels sprouts  a selection they would rather not have to make.

title: Ireland Takes Up Bill on Abortion Access
description: DUBLIN  One of the most deeply divisive issues in Irish society was reignited Wednesday night when the Irish Parliament began debate on a bill that would provide for limited access to abortion.

title: Officials Say a Little Italy Tradition Is Back: The Mob at San Gennaro
description: Little Italy  or Littler Italy, as certain wits have called it  has lost a good deal of its square footage and authentic flavor over the years. Caught between an encroaching Chinatown and a growing SoHo fashion trade, its pork stores and red-sauce joints have been left to huddle largely on its main drag, Mulberry Street. The 2010 census failed to find a single neighborhood resident  not one  who was actually born in Italy.

title: Birth Control and Teenage Pregnancy
description: An encouraging new report shows a big decline in the rate of teenage births. From 2009 to 2010, the birth rate among young women ages 15 to 19 fell 9 percent, to 34.9 per thousand, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. That is a record low for the 65 years that data have been available, and a remarkable 44 percent drop from the 1991 rate. This good shift is largely the result of an increase in teenagers use of birth control  a fact that Congressional Republicans ignore as they seek to dismantle reproductive health programs.

title: Stabbed in Brain, Officer Escaped Deaths Door
description: The wild swing connected to the left side of the police officers head, a presumed punch until the blood started flowing. The officer, Eder Loor, reached to his temple and felt the handle of a knife.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 18, 2012

title: NASA Contest Seeks Videos On Its Earth-Probing Efforts
description: NASA is holding a contest in which earthlings are invited to create short videos showing what you find inspiring and important about the unique view and understanding of Earth provided by NASA science. Heres their video promoting the competition, which is open for entries (posted to YouTube) between Earth Day, Sunday, April 22, and May 31:

title: A Dose of Compassion
description: Medical marijuana, which can help relieve pain and nausea in patients with cancer and other illnesses, is now available in the District of Columbia and 16 states, including New Jersey. There is no reason patients in New York State, who are under the care of doctors, should be deprived of this useful treatment.

title: For Senate Democrats, Vote Revolves Around Women
description: WASHINGTON  Republicans have seized on gas prices as their motivating political issue of the moment. House Democrats cling to the Ryan budget as the document that is going to propel them back to power when voters recoil at its spending cuts. But the political weapon of choice for Senate Democrats is the plight of women, and they appear to have no intention of letting it go.

title: Nazareth High School to Remain Open
description: When it was decided that Nazareth High School in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, would close in June, the players on the schools nationally ranked girls basketball team thought they were leaving their school with a final championship send-off. But on Wednesday the Lady Kingsmen found out they will be back to defend their title in 2013.

title: Approval Is Seen for Sonys Takeover of EMI Publishing
description: Sony has won the approval of European regulators for its $2.2 billion takeover of EMI Music Publishing, a critical step in the companys bid to create the largest catalog of songs in the world, according to a person briefed on the process.

title: Not Quite a Teen, Yet Sold for Sex
description: If you think sex trafficking only happens in faraway places like Nepal or Thailand, then you should listen to an expert on American sex trafficking I interviewed the other day.

title: Rape Suspect Is Freed, Long After a Woman Recants
description: The allegations that the Brooklyn district attorney announced in June were shocking: Four men were accused of abusing a young woman for a decade, raping her and forcing her to have sex with others beginning when she was 13.

title: Mistaken Identity May Be Closer Than It Appears
description: Its a rich, slow-spreading smile, like butter melting in a skillet over a low flame. And whenever it creeps across James Cordens face in the splendidly silly One Man, Two Guvnors, which opened on Wednesday night at the Music Box Theater, you know two things for sure: Youre in for trouble, and youre already hooked. Struggle as you will, there aint nothing you can do about it.

title: A Family Numbed by Grief and Booze
description: Time crawls to a dead stop as you watch Ninth and Joanie, a stupefyingly dull drama by Brett C. Leonard presented by the increasingly rudderless Labyrinth Theater Company at the Bank Street Theater. The actual presence of a kitchen sink might enliven Mr. Leonards kitchen-sink drama about an Italian-American father and son immured in grief in South Philadelphia. Watching the slow drip of a leaky faucet for two hours would be more entertaining than this misguided production, directed with ponderous indulgence by Mark Wing-Davey.

title: Outliers
description: Administrivial Leaving on a Jet Plane Alert! Im all packed and leaving to speak at the Erma Bombeck Writers Workshop this weekend, but fear not; there will be Wordplay even in my absence because the emus are just that good. They will also be holding down the fort until I get back, so keep solving and feel free to discuss the puzzles as always. Enjoy your weekend, and Ill see you for the Monday post.

title: Corrections: April 19
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Pentagon Sought to Stop Paper From Using Photos
description: The grisly photographs of American soldiers posing with the body parts of Afghan insurgents during a 2010 deployment in Afghanistan were the source of a dispute between The Los Angeles Times and the Pentagon lasting weeks.

title: Papers Detail BP Settlement in Gulf Oil Spill
description: The estimated multibillion-dollar settlement between BP and lawyers representing individual and business plaintiffs in the 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil spill was fleshed out on Wednesday in hundreds of pages of motions and exhibits.

title: Do Wealthy Colleges Deserve Their Tax Breaks?
Indian State Finds Itself in Tight Grip of Addiction
description: KAZIKOT VILLAGE, India  In this village not far from the Pakistani border, the wheat harvest is only days away. Water buffaloes are resting in the shade. Farmers are preparing their fields. And drug addicts like Pargat Singh are crouched in the shadows, injecting themselves with cocktails of synthetic drugs.

title: In Brazil and Elsewhere, Dismay at Argentinas Nationalization Move
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  In a fiery speech justifying her decision to nationalize the oil company YPF, Argentinas president, Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner, cited her admiration for Petrobras, Brazils state-controlled oil giant, and other state oil companies in Latin America.

title: A Boys Fast Fame, Built of Cardboard and Tape
description: LOS ANGELES  On an industrial street lined with auto repair shops, there are few signs that this is the home of an Internet sensation. But slow down at the end of the block, just off the freeway in eastern Los Angeles, where a 9-year-old boy has created a makeshift arcade in his fathers auto parts store with balls, cardboard boxes and tape.

title: Knicks Say Goodbye to New Jersey
description: NEWARK  The Knicks packed their jerseys and their high-tops, boarded a bus and crossed the Hudson River one final time Wednesday night, not to pay their last respects to the Nets of New Jersey, but to bury them, without sentiment or sympathy.

title: Penguins Turn Tables and Trounce Flyers
description: PHILADELPHIA  Several questions emerged after the Penguins resurfaced by trouncing the Flyers in Game 4 on Wednesday night, but one above all seemed most relevant: just how did Pittsburgh ever lose? Not the previous three games of this playoff series, but at all?

title: Missing a Pet Peacock? Coyotes Come to Atlanta
description: ATLANTA  The urban coyote problem has come to Atlanta at last.

title: Seeking the Polish Soul, by Drink and Bite
description: In Polands capital, Warsaw, Poles are finding a new confidence in the simpler tastes formerly associated with the smothering grip of Communism.

title: Flavor of Nostalgia Grows More Appealing to Poles Brimming With Pride
description: WARSAW  The bartenders in white shirts and black bow ties served endless shots of vodka followed by platefuls of herring in oil, and the occasional kielbasa, on small white plates as the crowds eagerly downed their drinks with an enthusiastic toast: Na zdrowie! Polish for Cheers.

title: Kuroda Loses Command; Yankees Lose Gardner
description: Hiroki Kuroda was introduced to his new home fans last Friday, when he pitched eight scoreless innings in the Yankees home opener. It was a memorable welcome for Kuroda, who last off-season signed a one-year contract to pitch in the Bronx this season. Manager Joe Girardi gushed about his performance. The capacity crowd gave him a standing ovation.

title: Pakistani Judge Upholds 3 Womens Conversions
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A controversy over religious conversions that has captivated Pakistanis was resolved in dramatic fashion on Wednesday when a judge ruled that three Hindu women who converted to Islam under disputed circumstances had chosen to go with their new Muslim husbands, causing consternation among the families they left behind.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Ellison in Court, and Spectrum Sale
description: Here are some of the most interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Wednesday. There are more here.

title: Tweaking Iconic Logos, a Student Makes His Mark
description: HONG KONG  Tampering with the worlds most recognized corporate logos can be a dicey enterprise. Why fool around, for example, with the red-and-white swirl of Coca-Cola? Or the once-bitten apple of Apple?

title: With Rally, Senators Prove to Be Rangers Match
description: OTTAWA  The Rangers are facing an opponent as scrappy and resilient as themselves.

title: Veterans Department to Increase Mental Health Staffing
description: The Department of Veterans Affairs will announce on Thursday that it plans to hire about 1,600 additional psychiatrists, psychologists, social workers and other mental health clinicians in an effort to reduce long wait times for services at many veterans medical centers.

title: Life, Interrupted: A Young Cancer Patient Faces Infertility
description: The family minivan idles at the intersection of 59th and York in Midtown Manhattan. My boyfriend swabs my midriff with alcohol as he steadies the needle. My parents look on from the front seat, quietly studying their 22-year-old daughter and the young man theyve known for only a month. The needle is filled with gonadotropin, a hormone that stimulates the ovaries to produce eggs. Im late for my checkup at the fertility clinic.

title: Rangers-Senators Replay: Game 4
description: Henrik Lundqvist made 28 saves, but Ottawa rallied from a two-goal deficit to win.

title: Focus, People!
description: The general election is off to an inauspicious start.

title: Word of the Day | ideology
description: ideology \i-de--l-je, i-\ noun

title: Love in the Time of Cancer
description: During her yearlong battle with leukemia, Suleika Jaouads diagnosis has tested and strengthened her relationship with her boyfriend, who stuck by her side throughout her treatments.

title: Punjab in the Tight Grip of Addiction
description: In this village not far from the Pakistani border, the wheat harvest is only days away. Water buffaloes are resting in the shade. Farmers are preparing their fields. And drug addicts like Pargat Singh are crouched in the shadows, injecting themselves with cocktails of synthetic drugs, Jim Yardley writes in The New York Times, about Kazikot village in Punjab State.

title: Test Launch of Agni V, Indias Long-Range Missile
description: India said Thursday it had successfully launched a missile with nuclear capability and a 3,100-mile range, giving it the ability to strike Beijing and Shanghai, Hari Kumar and Heather Timmons report in The New York Times.

title: Signs of an Asian Arms Buildup in Indias Missile Test
description: NEW DELHI  Indias successful test on Thursday of a long-range ballistic missile capable of carrying a nuclear warhead is the latest escalation of an arms race in Asia, where the assertiveness and rising military power of China has rattled the region and prompted a forceful response from the Obama administration.

title: After Ugly Incidents, Wondering Where to Assign Blame
description: This is the time of year when the N.H.L.  with the energy and excitement brought by the playoffs  lands on the national stage. From overtime games that can extend into the morning hours, to the fast, physical play to the uncertainty of every series, the league has the ability to attract the casual fan for its postseason.

title: Bibby Makes Most of a Chance to Contribute
description: NEWARK  The final Knicks-Nets game in New Jersey on Wednesday night bore witness to point-guard matchups that might have left the fans preferring a game of four-on-four had the stakes not been high.

title: Beijing Auto Show Preview: Mercedes Concept Style Coupe
description: Two years ago at the Beijing auto show, Mercedes-Benz stretched the form language, as well as the spelling, of the shooting brake body style with a design study it called the Concept Shooting Break. Now the German automaker is poised to rekindle the semantics wars with the Concept Style Coupe, a compact four-door vehicle scheduled to make its official debut in Beijing on April 23.

title: News Quiz | April 19, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: What They Said: India Tests Agni V Nuclear Missile
description: India said Thursday that it had successfully launched a new nuclear-capable missile from Wheeler Island off the coast of Odisha, the eastern state formerly known as Orissa. The missile gives India, for the first time, the capability of striking the Chinese cities of Beijing and Shanghai. Scientists at Indias Defense Research and Development Organization developed the missile.

title: A Leader of Jazz at Lincoln Center Steps Down
description: Paul Simon and his band invaded Jazz at Lincoln Center on Wednesday night to raise money for the nonprofit arts institution. Wynton Marsalis and the in-house orchestra backed Mr. Simon up, putting a jazz sheen on a stirring set from the songwriters long career.

title: April 19, 1995 | Timothy McVeigh Bombs Oklahoma City Building
description: On April 19, 1995, a truck bomb exploded outside the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building in Oklahoma City, killing 168 people and injuring 500. It was the deadliest terrorist attack on American soil until the events of Sept. 11, 2001.

title: What the World Said: Foreign Reaction to Indias Long-Range Missile Launch
description: Mark Toner, Spokesperson, United States Department of State :Naturally, I just would say that we urge all nuclear-capable states to exercise restraint regarding nuclear capabilities. That said, India has a solid nonproliferation record. Theyre engaged with the international community on nonproliferation issues. And Prime Minister Singh, I believe, has attended both the nuclear  both of the nuclear summit  security summits, the one in Washington and then Seoul. (Daily Press Briefing)

title: The First Middle School Chess Champs
description: WHAT is the first middle school team to win the United States Chess Federations national high school championship?

title: Test Yourself | English, April 19, 2012
description: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article Obama Is President, but Football Is King.

title: Behind the Scenes of Power
description: Never-seen photographs by Garry Winogrand, with audio commentary from George McGovern.

title: Amazon Creates a Software Rental Store
description: Amazon.coms Amazon Web Services business, facing looming competition for its business of renting online data storage and computing, is introducing a store where customers will be able to rent business software from a number of third-party providers, including I.B.M., Microsoft and SAP.

title: Breaking Into Prison
description: Sean Kernans noirish photo essay on prison life was not the result of careful planning, research or even an interest in issues of incarceration.

title: Help Us Identify Whos in These Photographs
description: This weeks Look features recently discovered photographs by Garry Winogrand from the 1960 Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles. To identify the faces in the crowd scenes that Winogrand captured, our photo department and others talked to dozens of people who were at the convention, including George McGovern. (Listen to McGoverns story about the awkward confrontation at that convention between Robert Kennedy and Lyndon Johnson.)

title: Is It Ethical to Eat Meat?
description: Herbivore, omnivore or carnivore? Some people just cant go a day without chicken, steak or fish, while others refuse to eat food that has even touched meat. The Well blog recently wrote about The Challenges Of Going Vegan in a society dominated by meat and dairy. Meanwhile, The Ethicist is running an essay contest for adults asking them to tell us why its ethical to eat meat. What do you think?

title: South Korea Says It Has New Missile
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea said Thursday that it had developed and deployed a new cruise missile capable of a precision strike anywhere in North Korea.

title: Pressure Builds for Tougher Line as Syria Is Said to Shun Peace Plan
description: PARIS  International pressure for a harsher line on Syria escalated Thursday, with the president of France calling the Syrian leader a liar, the American secretary of state moving a step closer to endorsing use of military force, and the head of the United Nations accusing the Syrian government of failing to carry out nearly every element of a peace plan that went into effect a week ago.

title: Cisco Announces Its $850 Million Spin-In
description: Cisco has notified its employees that it has funded an advanced networking startup, called Insieme, with $100 million, with the right to eventually buy the company for as much as $750 million more.

title: Vodafones Legal Notice Against India Could Be Followed by Others
description: British telecom giant Vodafone Groups legal proceedings against the Indian government, announced Tuesday in reaction to a recent proposed tax change, have little precedent in India, legal experts say.

title: Fraternity at Holy Cross Runs Deeper Than Greek Life
description: The College of the Holy Crosss graduating class of 1972 included a number of particularly distinctive alumni: a National Football League running back who won a Super Bowl with the Miami Dolphins in 1973, then established a successful legal career; a writer who received the Pulitzer Prize; even a justice of the Supreme Court.

title: Ranking Tight Ends in 2012 N.F.L. Draft
description: Matt Waldman is the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, a testament to his obsession with film analysis, now available for download. Examples of his work can be found at his blog. He is helping The Fifth Down rank skill position players before the draft:

title: The Largest Marginal Tax Rate Ever?
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: The Early Word: Battlegrounds
description: In Todays Times:

title: European Regulators Approve J.&J.s Takeover of Synthes
description: LONDON  European regulators approved Johnson & Johnsons $21 billion acquisition of the medical equipment maker Synthes on Thursday after the company agreed to divest part of its European operations.

title: Q&A: New Maps for an Old GPS
description: Q.

title: Pakistan Judge Upholds Womens Conversions to Islam
description: A controversy over religious conversions that has captivated Pakistanis was resolved in dramatic fashion on Wednesday when a judge ruled that three Hindu women who converted to Islam under disputed circumstances had chosen to go with their new Muslim husbands, causing consternation among the families they left behind, Salman Masood writes in The New York Times.

title: Bohemian Lobster
description: Time: About 30 minutes.

title: Dover Sole Duglr
description: Time: About 25 minutes.

title: Sliced Beef Fillets From the Banks of the Rhone
description: Time: About 20 minutes.

title: Post-Prozac Nation
description: Few medicines, in the history of pharmaceuticals, have been greeted with as much exultation as a green-and-white pill containing 20 milligrams of fluoxetine hydrochloride  the chemical we know as Prozac. In her 1994 book Prozac Nation, Elizabeth Wurtzel wrote of a nearly transcendental experience on the drug. Before she began treatment with antidepressants, she was living in a computer program of total negativity . . . an absence of affect, absence of feeling, absence of response, absence of interest. She floated from one suicidal reverie to the next. Yet, just a few weeks after starting Prozac, her life was transformed. One morning I woke up and really did want to live. . . . It was as if the miasma of depression had lifted off me, in the same way that the fog in San Francisco rises as the day wears on. Was it the Prozac? No doubt.

title: Give Me Butter! Always Butter!
description: Fernand Point was not one of your gym-going, globe-trotting, Ph.D.-equipped chefs. He was a roast-chicken-for-breakfast-eating, two-bottles-of-Champagne-at-lunch-drinking, big fat (no way around it) guy, the stereotype of the mid-20th-century French chef and almost without question the most influential of his time.

title: Would You Trust Ridejoys Web Site?
description: Last year, three friends who were making arrangements to drive to the famous Burning Man festival in Nevadas Black Rock Desert concluded that there was great interest in ride-sharing but no easy way to match up those who had space in their cars with those who needed rides and would help pay for gas and other expenses. So they set up Burningmanrides.com.

description: LONDON  The British government found itself in a right royal pickle on Thursday on the issue of European human rights law over its bid to deport a radical Muslim cleric reputedly linked to Al Qaeda.

title: Daily Report: Facebook Valued at $104 Billion
description: Facebook bought Instagram for $1 billion in early April, agreeing to pay roughly 30 percent in cash and 70 percent in stock. At that level, Facebook is pegging its value at north of $75 billion. But Facebook could actually be worth more, reports Evelyn M. Rusli of DealBook.

title: Norwegian Defends Shooting and Regrets Death Toll Wasnt Higher
description: OSLO  The man on trial here for killing 77 people last year in twin attacks said Thursday that he regretted not having killed even more and that he was justified in shooting young people at a political camp because regardless of their age, they had taken on political leadership roles.

title: Nokia Posts $1.2 Billion Loss as Phone Sales Tumble
description: Nokia, struggling to reinvent its smartphone business around Microsofts Windows Phone software, said Thursday that it might have to cut prices of its cheaper Lumia models to keep its new phones competitive in some markets.

title: Ford to Build Plant in China to Bolster Global Sales
description: BEIJING, CHINA  Ford Motor has chosen China for its largest factory expansion program in a half century, announcing on Thursday that it would build a $760 million assembly plant in Hangzhou, two weeks after announcing another $600 million plan to expand an assembly plant in Chongqing and less than six weeks after completing a third assembly plant in Chongqing.

title: A Rough Patch for Western Waterfowl
description: Federal Fish and Wildlife Service officials say that a drought-induced bird die-off in the Lower Klamath National Wildlife Refuge along the California-Oregon border has ended. But they warn that unless proposals to reconfigure water distribution along the Klamath River are enacted, the problem could recur.

title: Cannes Film Festival Lineup Is Unveiled
description: David Cronenberg, Lee Daniels, Walter Salles, Ken Loach and Michael Haneke will be among the directors vying for the Palme dOr at this years Cannes Film Festival, its organizers announced on Thursday. The slate of 22 features that will be shown in competition at the festival, which runs from May 16 through 27 and will open with Wes Andersons latest film, Moonrise Kingdom, also includes The Paperboy, a drama directed by Mr. Daniels (Precious), adapted from the Pete Dexter novel and starring Nicole Kidman, Matthew McConaughey, Zac Efron and John Cusack; a film version of Jack Kerouacs On the Road, directed by Mr. Salles (Dark Water); Amour, a new work by Mr. Haneke, a previous Palme dOr winner for The White Ribbon; and The Angels Share, a comic caper from Mr. Loach, who received that award for The Wind That Shakes the Barley. Mr. Cronenbergs adaptation of the Don DeLillo novel Cosmopolis, featuring the Twilight star Robert Pattinson, will also be in competition, while Antiviral, the debut film by his son, Brandon Cronenberg, will be among the features shown in the festivals Un Certain Regard lineup. Other much anticipated works by filmmakers like Paul Thomas Anderson and Terrence Malick were not completed in time for the festivals deadlines, Cannes director Thierry Frmaux said.

title: New York Times Co. Reports Gain in Net Income
description: The New York Times Company reported a large gain in first-quarter net income on Thursday, driven mainly by the sale of its regional newspapers, the sale of part of its stake in a New England sports group and an increase in circulation revenue at its flagship newspaper.

title: Neemans Own
description: JERUSALEM  About two weeks ago, on the eve of Passover, Israels justice minister, Yaakov Neeman, dropped a policy bomb. He proposed a bill that would allow a small majority of legislators in the Knesset to reinstate laws struck down by the Supreme Court.

Iraq Insurgency Asserts Presence With Wave of Attacks
description: BAGHDAD  A string of deadly explosions and other attacks shook Iraq on Thursday, with bombings in Baghdad and the northern city of Kirkuk resulting in the most fatalities. Over all, nearly three dozen people were killed and more than 100 were wounded, according to security officials.

title: Easter in Ramallah
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  Almost every year for over one hundred years on the Saturday before Orthodox Easter, the main street in Ramallah has been overtaken by marching boy scouts and girl scouts banging drums and blowing trumpets before tens of thousands of onlookers.

title: 3 Arrested by British in Inquiry on Bribery
description: The British police arrested three people on Thursday as part of an inquiry into accusations of bribery stemming from the news-gathering and corruption scandal that has engulfed Rupert Murdochs media empire, the police said, bringing to 46 the number of arrests during more than a year of investigations.

title: Samurai Shopper | Shooting Stars
description: The Samurai Shopper is not used to being a fly on the wall, but sometimes its a real buzz to be one. Recently I hung around the Chelsea Piers watching the photographer Patrick Demarchelier, the hairstylist Serge Normant and the beauty entrepreneur Laura Mercier put together Merciers look for her spring 2013 cosmetics collection. It was fun traipsing over wires and riffing through racks of tastefully curated coats, ornate necklaces and bales of tulle. And it was an education watching Mercier transform two gorgeous models into even more gorgeous models with makeup on. When makeup personnel at department stores have a go at me, I end up looking like RuPaul, only half as good.

title: Kobach and Romney
description: Mitt Romney is in a bind.

title: Is This the End of Proper Grammar? Hopefully Not
description: Unsurprisingly, The Associated Press won a Pulitzer Prize for investigative reporting early this week, for articles about the New York Police Departments surveillance of Muslim neighborhoods and organizations in the wake of 9/11. Also unsurprising was fresh controversy that the award stirred, given the sensitive subject.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Least Gruesome Gruesome War Photos, and Idol on Dick Clark
description: The decision by The Los Angeles Times to publish two photographs of American soldiers with the body parts of Afghanistan insurgents came after the strenuous objections of the Pentagon, Brian Stelter reported. The objections were not about embarrassment, the Pentagons spokesman insisted in an interview, but about the potential for the photographs to incite violence. The two photographs, out of a total of 18, that The Times published were the least gruesome, according to the reporter who obtained them.

title: Display Space (for You) High Above Broadway
description: Women confident enough to want to see themselves on a billboard in Times Square can have their wish come true this week courtesy of Dove. As part of a new promotion called Show Us Your Skin the company will display photographs that women submit of themselves. The photos need not be limited to smiling faces. Women can submit a head shot, a full-body shot or focus on a body part like legs, feet or hands.

description: Business for private equity firms may be improving, but it was not enough to lift the Blackstone Groups first-quarter profit.

description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: India Struggles to Deliver Enough Power
description: NELLORE, India  India has long struggled to provide enough electricity to light its homes and power its industry around the clock. In recent years, the government and private sector sought to change that by building scores of new power plants.

title: CVR Energy Reaches Agreement With Icahn
description: CVR Energy, an oil refining and marketing company based in Sugarland, Tex., said on Thursday that it had reached a deal with Carl C. Icahn to allow the investor to pursue a takeover offer for $30 a share, plus a contingent cash payment right, or more than $2.6 billion.

description: Good morning. Today will rise to a sunny 67 degrees. And, of course, have a happy Dutch-American Friendship Day.

title: A Well-Hydrated Romance, Courtesy of Nicholas Sparks
description: Of course they killed someone, I overheard a young woman say to her friend after a screening of The Lucky One. Its a Nicholas Sparks movie. And how. This is the seventh of Mr. Sparkss wildly popular novels to reach the screen, and it seems useful, in the interests of scholarship, to apprehend the Nicholas Sparks movie as a genre unto itself, with a distinct set of rules and defining features.

description: What book is on your night stand now?
