description: The troupe preformed at the Joyce.

title: R.N.C. Rejects Changes to Nominating Contests for 2016
description: PHOENIX  Members of the Republican National Committee considered  and rejected  changes to their presidential nominating process for 2016 after a contest this year that some members say was too long and drawn out.

title: Robert De Niro Sr.: Paintings and Drawings, 1960-1993
description: DC Moore

title: Polly Apfelbaum: Flatland: Color Revolt
description: DAmelio Gallery

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Slow Motion and Black Boxes
description: Here are some of the most interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Thursday. There are more here.

title: JUILLIARD ORCHESTRA
description: Avery Fisher Hall

title: European Union Youth Orchestra
description: Carnegie Hall

title: Farallones Deaths Follow Dangerous Year in Sailing
description: The Farallon Islands, 28 miles from the Golden Gate Bridge, are known as the Devils teeth for the sharp, rocky spires that spring from the open ocean. Frequent gale force winds and steep, breaking waves make it a threatening shore for approaching boaters. But since the annual Full Crew Farallones Race began, in 1907, using the islands as the turning point, there had never been a fatality.

title: Trailing Her Heart, Pushpin by Pushpin
description: The French title of Mia Hansen-Loves new film is Un Amour de Jeunesse. A straightforward (if somewhat generic) translation might have been Young Love, but the English version, Goodbye First Love, is an improvement. The movie, Ms. Hansen-Loves third feature (after All Is Forgiven and The Father of My Children), endows each word of that title with equal weight. It examines, with compassion and clarity, a young womans discovery of passion and also of the pain, disappointment and partial wisdom that follow.

title: Lead by Example, Clinton Tells Sustainability Forum
description: Chill out  sometimes this stuff takes years.

title: More Than a Bicycle Shop
description: The combination of bicycles and beers at Red Lantern Bicycles, located on Myrtle Avenue in a still-gentrifying part of Fort Greene, Brooklyn, is unique in New York.

title: Parents Ask Walcott for More Seats for Gifted and Talented Students
Test Scores and Housing Costs
description: Parents hoping to enroll their children in the best public schools have long known that where you live matters and that housing prices can be dictated by the quality of the nearby schools.

title: On Sundays, the DVR Runneth Over
description: LIKE a lot of television fans, Kelly Foster had a problem last Sunday. Too much TV  and not enough time to watch or hard drive space to record it all.

title: Connections That Seem to Erase Boundaries
description: A few years ago the art historian Thierry de Duve observed that we are living in a paradoxical moment when the increasingly specialized culture of art is transmitted through the most general channels, like museums and galleries. The observation feels particularly apt with regard to the Guggenheim Museums Being Singular Plural, an exhibition of recent video and film from South Asia.

title: Looks Like a Rodent, Croons Like a Bird
description: First things first: The hyrax is not the Lorax. And it does not speak for the trees. It sings, on its own behalf.

title: These Women Refused to Stay in the Kitchen
description: Anecdotes keep emerging about how American female artists would battle misogyny, skeptical relatives and heavy skirts to paint somewhere remote and possibly dangerous. A dozen recent and forthcoming publications and exhibitions cover such art heroines of a century and more ago.

title: Mother of Invention, Cousin of Design
description: Dont look now, but we may have just passed through the golden age of earplug design. The Museum of Modern Art seems to have become cognizant of this possibility in 2006 when, in one fell swoop, it acquired at least 11 sets, designed between 1978 and 2003. With contours variously biomorphic and gently jagged, they include single- and multiple-use plugs and some designed specially for musicians or swimmers.

title: Recreational Basketball: More Than Choosing Sides
description: BEN CHAYON and Josh Marcus started NYC Basketball last summer because of their love for the sport and their conclusion that people enjoy amateur leagues for something more than proving that they can still hit a 15-foot jump shot with a hand in the face.

title: These Be the Verses
description: Philip Larkins body of work is so slender and, often, so seemingly slight, so devoid of belly fat and blather, as to make Elizabeth Bishop (whom I now think of as his nearest American counterpart) look like a blimp and a bigmouth. Of the 730 pages of The Complete Poems, a mere 90 are taken up by those poems Larkin saw fit to collect in his lifetime. One of the main challenges posed by this edition is that it asks us to reconcile the discrepancy between those slim 90 pages and the sprawling rest.

title: From the Miser, a Salute to the Gutter in Brooklyn
description: The Miser is no mere individual, but rather a state of mind. So as one Miser moves on to new frontiers, another steps bravely into the breach.

title: Whistling Eclecticism: Motors and Fishing Line
description: The peripatetic MATA Festival has had homes in various corners of Brooklyn and Manhattan over the last 15 years. Now Brooklyn has become the nerve center of the youthful, vibrantly eclectic indie-classical movement that has always been an important part of MATAs DNA, so it made sense for the festival to set up at one of that styles outposts, Roulette, in its new quarters on Atlantic Avenue.

title: Firing Away With Old-School Antics
description: In the last couple of years Rick Ross has brought back 1990s-style hip-hop maximalism: beats, boasts, personality, spending, all epic size. So its not all that surprising that hes also successfully resurrected that other throwback rap extravagance, the extended crew.

title: The World Meets in Brooklyn
description: When I was a kid, my parents would park me in our local museum  the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston  on Saturday and let me wander, which I liked to do. So I got to absorb a big art collection in a sociable, stroll-by way.

title: Two Guantnamo Detainees Freed, the First in 15 Months
description: WASHINGTON  Two Chinese Muslim detainees held for years without trial at the prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, were released in El Salvador this week, the Pentagon announced Thursday. It was the first prisoner transfer out of Guantnamo in more than a year.

title: For Cyclists Seeking Repairs, and Beer
description: RED LANTERN BICYCLES in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, is a serious cycling shop: The air smells of chain grease; Sunlite tires, Planet Bike fenders and unbuilt Bianchis crowd the repair floor; and there is an antique penny-farthing in the window.

title: A Master Opens the Door to an Empire
description: The title of a new exhibition, Drer and Beyond: Central European Drawings in The Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1400-1700, presents a bit of a conundrum. How do we get beyond Albrecht Drer (1471-1528), the ne plus ultra draftsman and all-around Northern Renaissance master, an artist so secure in his greatness that he painted himself as Jesus?

title: Excerpt: 'Strange Interlude'
description: A scene from the Eugene ONeill play at the Shakespeare Theater Company in Washington.

title: Can Running Make Us Happier?
description: In this weekends special health issue, which is devoted to mental wellness, Gretchen Reynolds writes about a recent study from the University of Illinois that shows that mice living in cages with running wheels do better on mouse intelligence tests (in the form of mazes) than those living without them. Running, it turns out, leads to neurogenesis, the birth of new cells in your hippocampus, and that seems to make you smarter.

title: Let Them See You Sweat
description: A look at several places for a schvitz in New York City.

title: When Dog Disappears, the Humans Seem Lost
description: If you found Benji the Hunted unbearably intense or Marley & Me a bit too hard-edged, then Darling Companion may be the dog movie for you. On the other hand, if you like to watch cute pooches doing cute stuff on screen, you may be a little disappointed. Not that Freeway, the rescued mutt in the middle of Lawrence Kasdans mild, creaky new film, isnt adorable. Its just that hes not around all that much. Fairly early on, he bounds off into the woods, and for the next hour or so impressive noncanine cast members search for him, acting out various minor relationship dramas as they go.

title: Born Out of Necessity
description: Images from the new design exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: In Latest Pay Rebuke, Investor to Oppose Goldman Director
description: In the latest rebuke of how eye-popping pay packages are awarded on Wall Street, a major institutional investor is taking the rare step to oppose the re-election of a Goldman Sachs board member who approves compensation for many of the banks top executives.

title: Defining Eras
description: An interactive look at how the set for the Broadway play Clybourne Park ages 50 years during intermission.

title: U.S. Investigates a Goldman Executive Over Insider Trading
description: Federal prosecutors in California are investigating whether a Goldman Sachs executive leaked confidential information about two publicly traded companies to Raj Rajaratnam, the convicted hedge fund manager.

title: Tick-Tack-Toe for the Vigorously Unsquare
description: MACHINE GUN KELLY was spinning around on his chair. As a player on a game show, MGK (as this young rappers nametag read), had far less gravitas than the average TV contestant  but he sure was fun to watch. The bottle of Champagne that he occasionally swigged from one recent Monday afternoon probably had something to do with it.

title: The More Things Change
description: A look at the set and costume design for the Broadway play Clybourne Park.

title: Wandering Seoul in Patterns of Coincidence
description: At once direct and elusive, The Day He Arrives is a story about what might have been or perhaps once was. It pivots on a teacher and lapsed film director, Seong-jun (Yu Jun-sang), who, when the movie opens, has just arrived in Seoul. Hes in town to see a friend, but theres something rootless and sad about him, suggesting that hes after more than a visit. As one day gives way to another  days that look remarkably the same  his visit takes on existential weight, and the movie becomes an exploration, both playful and rueful, of desire, narrative and the idea beautifully expressed by Faulkner in Absalom, Absalom! that maybe nothing ever happens once and is finished.

title: Crossing Over in Form and Dimension
description: Broadway creativity merges old-fashioned stagecraft with technological sophistication to create the atmosphere of Ghost: The Musical.

title: Young Women Are More Career-Driven Than Men
description: As reflected in the recent flap over a liberal strategists remark that Mitt Romneys wife had never worked a day in her life, societal expectations of whether women should prioritize paid work have changed drastically over the years. Womens priorities have changed, too.

title: Risking Death in War, and Back Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Slice of Life in a Cage
description: Spiked with energy and attitude, the nonfiction movie Fightville takes a fast look at a few men who, for pleasure and sometimes profit, like to smack and take down other men while practicing mixed martial arts. Produced, directed and edited by the married couple Petra Epperlein and Michael Tucker (Gunner Palace), Fightville gestures toward some promising subjects  men and masculinity, bread and circuses  about which it has surprisingly little to say, despite its washes of spilled blood; its ringside seat at that great, eternal fight known as hope versus desperation; and its occasional quotations from the likes of Nietzsche and Whitman. The increased popularity of M.M.A. is reflected in the uptick of attention paid to it and its practitioners in popular culture, including in movies like Steven Soderberghs thriller Haywire (which stars the female fight sensation Gina Carano) and Gavin OConnors under-seen mens melodrama Warrior (about two battling brothers, played by Tom Hardy and Joel Edgerton, and their punishing problems). In January, MTV started its run of the reality television show Caged, about a clutch of young fighters from the Louisiana city of Minden. In the first episodes hyperventilated opening minutes someone explains that one of the locals made it big time, as the shot holds on an image of Dustin Poirier, a main character in Fightville.

title: The New Hungarian Secret Police
description: Another Hungary post from my Princeton colleague Kim Lane Scheppele, after the jump.

title: John DAgata and Jim Fingal Address the Facts
description: Minutes before John DAgata, Jim Fingal and Heidi Julavits appeared at McNally Jackson on Prince Street Wednesday night to discuss the controversial book The Lifespan of a Fact, two young women in the crowd were overheard discussing the nature of writing. When you get down to it, one told the other, its really all just fiction.

title: Join Us to Talk About the N.F.L. Draft
description: The Rockettes will not be the stars at Radio City Music Hall next weekend, when some big-name quarterbacks take center stage during the N.F.L. draft. Judy Battista and Mike Tanier, who write about pro football for The Times, will look ahead to this years draft during a Google Plus video hangout on Wednesday, April 25, at Noon Eastern. And we would like to invite selected readers to join them in the conversation. If you are available for 30 minutes beginning at that time and would like to hang out with us, use the comment area below to tell us what kind of a football fan you are, who you root for, and what questions you have about perhaps the biggest day on the N.F.L. calendar. Please also include a link to your Google-plus profile page and note that to participate in the hangout you will need a Google-plus profile and a video camera-enabled computer. If you cannot join us at that time, feel free to leave a question you would like answered and be sure to check back on The Fifth Down on Wednesday afternoon to watch a video of the hangout. We look forward to it.

title: Competition Apparently Up Slightly for Private Schools
description: For a few years, the news on private school admissions has been grim. It was harder to get into some of New York Citys top schools than to gain entry to Harvard. Once in, the tuition bill could be higher (not counting room and board, that is).

title: Drug War on Doorsteps All Over Ciudad Jurez
description: Charlie Minns documentary Murder Capital of the World is a briskly paced, pessimistic examination of the drug war that has ravaged Ciudad Jurez, Mexico, since 2008. The statistics speak for themselves. The number of murders in this border city of over one million residents skyrocketed from 44 in 1990 to more than 3,000 in 2010, according to the film.

title: Avoiding Mortgage Relief Scams
description: THE offers seem like answers to the prayers of a struggling homeowner: a promise of legal tactics to forestall foreclosure, reduce mortgage balances and interest rates, or restore credit.

title: Stern Shines Light on W.N.B.A. and Development League
description: The message of David Sterns remarks in front of the American Society of Newspaper Editors in New York on Thursday was that things in the N.B.A. are going well. So well that the commissioner believes it is time for people to take a second look at the leagues smaller offshoots: the N.B.A. Development League and the W.N.B.A.

title: Neighbors Balk at University Plan
description: MATTHEW KLAUER bought the picturesque former Wykeham Rise school property in Washington in 2008 with the intention of redeveloping it as an inn and spa. Neighbors balked, and the zoning commission rejected the plan, so Mr. Klauer has now come up with a new proposal: Wykeham University.

title: Protests and Gunfire Greet U.N. Observers in Syria
description: As my colleagues Neil MacFarquhar and Rick Gladstone report, diplomatic wrangling over the deployment of a small team of United Nations military observers to Syria, where a cease-fire agreement appears to be violated daily, continued on Thursday.

title: The Cost of Green Grass
description: NEW JERSEYS recently enacted Fertilizer Law, designed to protect waterways from becoming overly nourished, sets new limits on the amount of nitrogen and phosphorus that can be used on lawns and restricts the times when fertilizer can be applied. It is considered the toughest in the nation.

title: This Vampire May Be Conjured From the Pages of a Book
description: The all-girls school  a hotbed of passionate attachments, mannish gym teachers and blossoming sexuality  has long been fertile fodder for young-adult entertainment, and The Moth Diaries takes full advantage of its hormonal setting. Pumping up the pangs of puberty with vampire lore and family trauma, the director, Mary Harron (adapting Rachel Kleins 2002 novel), produces a Gothic stew of satisfying kinkiness if unsatisfying resolution.

title: CVC Is Said to Be Near Deal to Buy AlixPartners
description: CVC Capital Partners is nearing a deal to buy AlixPartners, the consulting firm known for its restructuring work, from current owner Hellman & Friedman, for more than $1 billion, people briefed on the matter told DealBook.

title: The Uncertain Fate of Farmland
description: Brentwood

title: Getting Off the Bus
description: To the Editor:

title: After Endorsing, Indiana Governor Criticizes Romney
description: Gov. Mitch Daniels of Indiana endorsed Mitt Romney for president on Wednesday  then criticized him a day later in an interview with The Indianapolis Star.

title: Ann Romneys Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: As Sudanese Clashes Escalate, So Do Bellicose Exchanges
description: LAMU, Kenya  Less than a year after the nation of South Sudan was born out of a delicate peace agreement with Sudan, the two countries have plunged into war, a Sudanese government spokesman said Thursday.

title: A Setback for Gay Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Up Close and Very Personal: The Crimes That Pay a Mans Way
description: From the start of Snow on tha Bluff, which runs without any introductory credits, this jolt of a film drops into a you-are-there crime scene: Three college students  one manning a video camera  drive into the Bluff, a run-down neighborhood in West Atlanta (actually, run-down is being kind), looking to buy drugs. A dealer approaches the car, smoothly talks his way in, directs them to a secluded street, then, pulling out a handgun, robs them of their money and  why not?  the camera.

title: Opposing Big Government
description: To the Editor:

title: Visas Denied to Artists
description: To the Editor:

title: Bastrop State Park Emerging From Rehab
description: Less than a year after a wildfire burned 96 percent of Bastrop State Parks 6,613 acres in Central Texas, the park is showing signs of rebirth. Camping areas and hiking trails have recently reopened, and grass and trees are growing from the once-charred soil.

title: If They Can Make It in New York City
description: The New York City of Downtown Express is a colorful carnival of multiethnic street buskers, subway performers and randomly jamming musicians. Among them is Sasha (the violinist Philippe Quint), a Russian immigrant with an overbearing father (Michael Cumpsty), a scholarship to Juilliard, and an imminent recital that he hopes will be a gateway to Carnegie Hall and permanent legal residency.

title: Q & A
description: When Stabilized Units Are Combined

title: City Councilmembers Say Co-location Complaints Come to Them First
In Tough Times, Three Planned Parenthood Branches Fight Back by Merging
description: ADDISON Texas Planned Parenthood advocates have been outspoken about the hits they have taken from state lawmakers in the last year  including major cuts to family-planning financing, a new abortion sonogram law and being kicked out of a Medicaid health program for poor women.

title: Want That Ring? Let the Man Be a Man
description: Tim Storys rom-com film isnt just based on Steve Harveys book Act Like a Lady, Think Like a Man, its also a two-hour advertisement for it. In Think Like a Man the camera lovingly and frequently frames copies of the book. Mr. Harvey appears in the movie dispensing advice. And when the characters talk about relationships, they often begin like this: Steve says. ...

title: Mobile Data Service Fees Help Bolster Profit at Verizon
description: Verizon Wireless, the nations largest cellphone service, on Thursday reported that in the first three months of the year fewer customers joined its service compared with the same period last year.

title: Battle Over a Chinese Company Turns Physical
description: It may be a tiny Chinese educational company worth a little over $200 million. But the ChinaCast Education Corporation has found itself embroiled in a battle worthy of a John Grisham novel.

title: A Welcoming Crew to Plug You In
description: WHEN Megan Langston moved into MiMA, a new rental development at 450 West 42nd Street, in early April, there were no four-hour waits for the cable guy to set up her service.

title: As Asians Flock to Northern Virginia, Laws and Palates Collide
description: FALLS CHURCH, Va.  In the rear of the Great Wall supermarket here, customers linger over razor clams, frozen conch and baby smelt arrayed at the fish counter. Crabs clamber over the ice. Below, sea bass circle in glass tanks. A girl in a stroller, eye level with a school of tilapia, giggles in delight.

title: A Stain That Wont Wash Away
description: San Francisco

title: Chimps Eat, Scratch, Groom
description: To experience Chimpanzee, the latest piece of gorgeously shot pablum from Disneynature, is to endure an orgy of cuteness pasted over some of the most asinine narration ever to ruin a wildlife movie. Delivered by Tim Allen, this nonstop flow of tittering observations and nursery-level commentary feels sadly misjudged, a demeaning soundtrack that shreds the dignity of the animals it purports to celebrate.

title: China: Tibetans Set Themselves on Fire
description: Two Tibetan men on Thursday set themselves on fire in the town of Barma in the mountainous area called Ngaba by Tibetans and Aba in Chinese, according to Tibet advocacy groups. The men, Sonam and Choephak Kyap, both in their 20s, are related to each other. Free Tibet, a group based in London, said witnesses reported that the men appeared to be critically injured; a researcher for another group said reports he received indicated that they had died. The episode took place outside a monastery, but the two are laymen. Since March 2011, at least 34 people in Tibetan areas of China have set themselves on fire to protest Chinese rule; more than two dozen have died.

title: A Fillys Unlikely Journey From a Rescue Project to the Racetrack
description: The bettors may not like what they see when they come across the name Notinrwildestdremz, scheduled to race Sunday at Aqueduct. The filly is 4, late to be making her first start, and her morning workout times suggest she is in no hurry to get to the finish line. She is by the sire Griffinite, who has never produced a horse of any note; she is not much bigger than a Great Dane; and her trainer, Billy Turner, usually does not have his horses peak in their first try.

title: Hopscotching From One Block of Ice to the Next
description: I love polar bears. I cant imagine who doesnt, what with advertisers having them animated and selling soft drinks, or walking in suburbia hugging drivers of eco-friendly cars. Everyone has seen videos of polar bears on melting blocks of ice. The heart moves.

title: In Boston, Romney Ramps Up for Fall
description: BOSTON  Mitt Romneys nondescript base camp on the outskirts of the North End of Boston has until now seemed too large for his presidential campaign  roughly 15,000 square feet of space on the first floor has sat largely empty and unused, even during Mr. Romneys first presidential bid in 2008.

title: Romney Bulks Up Team for General Election
description: BOSTON  Mitt Romney has been busy dashing across the country. He is honing his message, raising money and, of course, bringing on new staff members to prepare for a general election contest against President Obama.

title: New in Los Angeles, and Willing to Do Anything for Money
description: Going Down in La-La Land is a familiar enough story of a young and beautiful person hoping to make it big in Hollywood only to attain disillusionment. Here the new arrival is Adam (Matthew Ludwinski), a gay would-be actor who rooms with Candy (Allison Lane), a friend-girl from New York whos also looking for her big break  or sugar daddy  while explaining the dos and donts of networking in Los Angeles. After Adam scrambles for work of any sort, low-level connections lead to gay pornography and its apparent sideline, escort servicing.

title: Sometimes Its Safer Not to Be a Superstar
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor at The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: New Meaning to the Term Rock Bottom
description: Where do you go from hopeless? Im not living my life, Jean Remy, the hero of the well-meaning but frequently ham-handed Jean Gentil, tells a companion as the two find shelter for the night under a bridge. Im always sad.

title: Now, Eli Mannings Following Peyton Into Comedy
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Eli Manning is used to speaking in football terminology, so it was not altogether surprising that he fell back on familiar jargon when discussing his coming appearance as the host of Saturday Night Live.

title: Block by Block | North Moore Street
description: North Moore is the quintessential TriBeCa street, paved with cobblestones and lined with warehouses that have been converted into posh apartments and independent stores.

title: Loading-Dock Chic on North Moore Street
description: As the life-size fake Holstein grazed outside Bubbys on the corner of North Moore Street and Hudson one recent afternoon, a man in a kerchief and a five-day beard was putting a fresh coat of light-blue paint on a wooden bench that usually sits on the sidewalk outside the restaurant.

title: Marketing Hotels as Places Full of Fun and Discovery
description: RENAISSANCE, a hotel brand owned by Marriott International, and Revel, a new resort and casino in Atlantic City, are running lifestyle campaigns intended to attract young, hip guests.

title: Shop Till You Drop, 19th-Century Style
description: BROADWAY between Union and Madison Squares is a little stub of a street, six blockslong, an oddball diagonal adrift in the matrix of the grid plan.But it contains some of the great retail architecture of the 19th century.That a casual amble from 23rd to 17th Street may end with fresh vegetables and cider doughnuts is all to the good.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: Iran: Dispute Over Islands Grows
description: Irans military escalated tensions with the United Arab Emirates on Thursday, warning the countrys leaders to cease their claims of sovereignty over Abu Musa and two other contested islands at the strategically important mouth of the Persian Gulf. The warning, from Gen. Ahmad Reza Pourdastan, Irans army commander, was the first time he had commented on the dispute since it was resurrected this week when President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad paid a surprise visit to Abu Musa and said Iran wanted to make it and the two neighboring islands into a tourist attraction. The United Arab Emirates denounced the visit, calling it provocative. The Mehr News Agency quoted General Pourdastan, above, as saying that Iran has had sovereignty over these islands since old times and the Islamic republic will defend this right with full force. Abu Musa is the largest of the three islands, which sit in the Strait of Hormuz, the narrow passageway that is considered a vital shipping lane for oil tankers.

title: Battlefield Friendship Through Violence of World War II
description: My Way is a lot of war movie. This corny globe-trotting melodrama about a friendship strained by World War II is Kang Je-kyus lavish follow-up effort to his domestic hit Tae Guk Gi. The friendship story line acts mostly to tie together enthusiastically shot battlefield set pieces, innumerable episodes of intra-army abuse, and generally demonstrations of heroic endurance amid wretchedness.

title: Tupacs Posthumous Live Tour
description: Providence, R.I.

title: A Sculptor, Trying to Peer Behind Masks
description: Snapping open a violin case, Peter Bulow reveals a line of clay heads  fellow passengers from his subway rides, carved on the fly. They fit in the palm of the hand they were born in. This is the sketch work of a sculptor shaping at the speed of the A train as it rumbles from 59th Street to 125th Street.

title: A Co-op With Elbow Room
description: OVER time, in their Upper East Side rental, Evan Lapidus and Natalie Ings felt the walls closing in.

title: Collaboration on Hepatitis Drugs Lags
description: A combination of two pills proved extremely effective in treating hepatitis C in a small trial, raising hopes among researchers that the disease will be curable without an injected drug that has debilitating side effects.

title: Angering Taxi Drivers, Panel Adopts Plan on Hailing Livery Cabs
description: After the city spent decades trying to improve taxi service beyond central Manhattan, the Taxi and Limousine Commission voted on Thursday to adopt rules allowing New Yorkers to legally hail livery cabs in northern Manhattan and the four other boroughs, starting this summer.

title: My, How Youve Grown!
description: DRESSED in hard hats but cloaked in hedge fund millions, Harsh and Purvi Padia studied a 4,200-square-foot penthouse with panoramic views under construction last year in TriBeCa and then stunned the listing broker, Fredrik Eklund, with their assessment: Too small.

title: Household Debt Payments Hit 17-Year Low
description: The Federal Reserve estimates that the household debt service ratio fell to its lowest reading since 1994.

title: Democrats Joining G.O.P. on Pipeline
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama is finding himself increasingly boxed in on the Keystone pipeline fight as more Congressional Democrats are joining Republicans in backing the project, which has strong labor support and could generate significant numbers of jobs in economically hard-hit states.

title: Beyond Stop-and-Frisk
description: New Haven

title: In a Midmarket Gallery, Imagining a Perfect City
description: The last time Erick Lyle was part of a huge undertaking on Market Street, he ended up handcuffed in his underwear.

title: Testing the Teachers
description: Theres an atmosphere of grand fragility hanging over Americas colleges. The grandeur comes from the surging application rates, the international renown, the fancy new dining and athletic facilities. The fragility comes from the fact that colleges are charging more money, but its not clear how much actual benefit they are providing.

title: Troubling Signs
description: Some of the same problems that interrupted the economic recovery last year have recently reappeared.

title: Jury Statute Not Violated by Protester, Judge Rules
description: The next time the 80-year-old retired chemistry professor takes his protest to the plaza outside the federal courthouse in Manhattan, he may make it home without being locked up.

title: Amid Inquiry, SoHo Recalls Less-Fashionable Past
description: At the Lucky Brand boutique on Prince Street, denizens of the new SoHo spent Thursday listening to the sound of law officers digging up the old. As investigators drilled in the basement of the building next door, Annia Rossi, 24, talked about Etan Patz as if discussing another world.

title: A Military and Intelligence Clash Over Spy Satellites
description: WASHINGTON  The nations spies and its military commanders are at odds over the future of Americas spy satellites, a divide that could determine whether the United States government will increasingly rely on its own eyes in the sky or on less costly commercial technology.

title: Coach Has the Senators Believing in an Unlikely Playoff Run
description: OTTAWA  Among those who were surprised to find the Ottawa Senators in the Stanley Cup playoffs were the teams fans.

title: With Classroom Breakfasts, a Concern That Some Children Eat Twice
description: It is an innovative, intuitive and increasingly common way to ensure that food reaches the mouths of hungry children from low-income families: give out free breakfast in the classroom at the start of each school day.

title: Returning to the Sermon on the Mount
description: Forget the church, follow Jesus is the cover message on a recent issue of Newsweek, featuring an essay by Andrew Sullivan. He maintains that whats really important about Christianity is the moral code of Jesus Sermon on the Mount, freed from the dubious theology and corrupting politics that have plagued the history of the institutional church. The idea is widely attractive, with non-Christians and even some atheists professing admiration for what Sullivan (quoting Thomas Jefferson) calls the most sublime and benevolent code of morals which has ever been offered.

title: Two Days After a Benching, Brodeur Sets a Playoff Record
description: NEWARK  As if his 101st victory in the Stanley Cup playoffs really needed punctuation, Martin Brodeur provided a flourish in the third period Thursday, snatching a rising shot by Tomas Kopecky, the Florida Panthers forward, with his glove. It was vintage Brodeur.

title: Money Rules
description: Theres one key that always fits Washingtons locks: a big campaign check. President Obama boasts about the many small donors who propelled him to office, but its the biggest givers who find the White House doors smoothly swinging open. Mitt Romney has tried to appeal to those in the middle class, but theyre not invited to the retreats with those who give him $50,000.

title: Clean Air and Natural Gas
description: The Obama administrations new rules aimed at cutting harmful emissions from natural gas wells are a win for the environment, for the public and for industry. And despite what Republican politicians claim, the rules will not impose major new costs or slow what has been a remarkable boom in natural gas production.

title: U.S. Expands Inquiry of Suspected Misconduct by Agents in Colombia
description: WASHINGTON  The Secret Services investigation into alleged misconduct with prostitutes by agency personnel in advance of President Obamas trip to Colombia last week has been expanded to determine if the misconduct was confined to the 11 employees who were first tied to the scandal, according to a senior American official.

title: The Courage of Dieu Cay and Natalya Radzina
description: The Committee to Protect Journalists has named 12 countries  including Iraq, Russia, the Philippines, Afghanistan, Pakistan and Mexico  to its annual impunity index because they allow deadly violence against the press to go unpunished. The threats to journalists are also highlighted in a welcome, new State Department initiative. From now until World Press Freedom Day, May 3, the departments HumanRights.gov Web site will tell the stories of people who have been killed, jailed or otherwise blocked from reporting the news and exercising the fundamental right to free speech.

title: N.F.L. Warns That Vikings Could Move
description: N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell will fly to Minnesota on Friday to warn state lawmakers that if they do not help the Vikings build a new stadium, the team will be forced to explore other options, including leaving the state.

title: Rising Fears That Recovery May Once More Be Faltering
description: WASHINGTON  Some of the same spoilers that interrupted the recovery in 2010 and 2011 have emerged again, raising fears that the winters economic strength might dissipate in the spring.

title: Union Opposition Is Stirred by Stricter Requirements for Crane Operators in the City
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced a series of new licensing and testing requirements for crane operators in the city on Thursday, stirring union opposition less than three weeks after a fatal crane accident on the West Side of Manhattan reignited a debate on industry practices.

title: American Nuns, Conscience and the Vatican
description: The Vatican is reining in the leadership conference that represents 80 percent of American Catholic nuns, accusing the group of serious doctrinal problems and promoting radical feminist themes. That seems a misreading of the very fine work in schools, charities, prisons and impoverished neighborhoods being done by about 60,000 nuns across the nation.

title: Threat of Credit Downgrade Persists for Morgan Stanley
description: Morgan Stanleys rebuilding efforts are starting to take hold, as it posted one of its strongest quarters since the financial crisis.

title: Bishop Denies Testimony Alleging He Abused Youth
description: PHILADELPHIA  A Roman Catholic bishop from West Virginia denied on Thursday that he had ever sexually abused children, as alleged by a witness in the trial of two other priests here who are accused of abusing children or failing to stop the abuse.

title: Slashing the Tires on the Welcome Wagon
description: Is this safe? the man asks, as he guardedly takes a seat on a packing crate in the first act of Clybourne Park, Bruce Norriss sharp-witted, sharp-toothed comedy of American uneasiness. Oh, foolish mortal. Of course it isnt safe. Youre about to start talking about (can I say the word?) race. You might as well be running blindfolded through a minefield.

title: In Basement, Hopes to Solve 79 Case of Missing Boy
description: Investigators equipped with jackhammers entered the basement of a building in SoHo on Friday morning, starting the second day of the most extensive search to date for the remains of Etan Patz, a 6-year-old boy whose disappearance more than 30 years ago focused national attention on the problem of missing children.

title: Jets Look for Boom in Draft, Not Bust
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  One of the Jets glaring needs heading into next weeks N.F.L. draft is the same position that produced their biggest bust under General Manager Mike Tannenbaum. Of the eight outside linebackers on their draft board, seven played defensive end in college, like Vernon Gholston, taken sixth over all in 2008. The Jets released him in March 2011 after three sackless seasons.

title: A Freckled Beauty
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Mike Nothnagel is a swell guy and a terrific constructor, so you wont mind communing with him on his puzzle today, Im sure. Hes a KINDRED SPIRIT, one of us. Until youve been Nothnageled, of course, and then its a totally different situation, but fortunately that doesnt happen too often.

title: Fate of Mixed Martial Arts in New York State Again Rests With Assembly
description: ALBANY  The political debate over whether to legalize mixed martial arts is coming to a head in Albany, where concerns over the morality of ultimate fighting, as it is often known, as well as the labor practices of the sports biggest organization, have made New York one of only several states where the bloody bouts are banned.

title: Turmoil in Egypt Race Puts Spotlight on Panels Motives
description: CAIRO  When a panel of judges closed the door on the candidacies of three leading presidential contenders this week, anger at the ruling burst into the open, with some candidates publicly accusing the panel of being manipulated by the countrys military rulers.

title: Updating a Formula as Stoudemire Returns
description: Amare Stoudemire could be in uniform and in the starting lineup Friday night, a celebratory moment for anyone associated with the Knicks.

title: A Spate of Teenage Suicides Alarms Russians
description: MOSCOW  Russia has been hit with a wave of copycat teenage suicides so pronounced that President Dmitri A. Medvedev felt compelled on Thursday to warn news media outlets against making too much of the deaths, for fear of attracting more imitators.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 19, 2012

title: Hip-Hop to Be Square
description: MTV2 puts a shiny new coat on an old game show and hopes the addition of hip-hop luminaries will make it a hit with young audiences.

title: Rubio, in Appeal to G.O.P.s Conscience, Urges Compromise on Dream Act
description: WASHINGTON  With Republicans increasingly concerned about losing Hispanic voters this November, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida on Thursday pressed his party to embrace a compromise measure allowing young illegal immigrants a pathway to legal status.

title: A Search Renewed
description: More than three decades after Etan Patz, a 6-year-old boy, vanished as he walked to a school bus stop in SoHo, authorities are excavating a nearby basement in hopes of finding his remains.

title: Is Prostitution Safer When Its Legal?
As Fenway Turns 100, Its Yankees-Red Sox
description: The Red Sox opened Fenway Park with a 7-6 victory over the New York Highlanders on April 20, 1912. The Highlanders soon became the Yankees, and the rivalry between the two clubs blossomed into what some consider the best in sports.

title: Oakland Police Caught Between Reform and Crime Surge
description: Last month, at his first executive meeting as Oaklands new police chief, Howard A. Jordan laid out his priorities for the police department in Californias most violent city.

title: Mental Health Center for Youth Is Closing
description: Fourteen San Francisco teenagers who have been living in a locked mental health treatment program  children with traumatic backgrounds who require so much care that most other programs turned them away  are being moved. The Seneca Center Community Treatment Facility at San Francisco General Hospital will close permanently by May 16, after the city cut $900,000, almost a third of its budget.

title: In Mexico, a Volcano Rumbles, but Few Flinch
description: SANTIAGO XALITZINTLA, Mexico  The night sky sparked bright; dust fell on the villagers. Popocatpetl, the monstrous volcano shadowing this tiny town, rumbled once again this week, spewing forth a cloud of ash and scaring Mexican authorities, who raised threat levels and dispatched civil protection services.

title: After Ouster, Reclaiming His Place in Air Force
description: Four years after he was discharged under dont ask, dont tell, Anthony Loverdeis poised tobe reinstated in the United States Air Force.

title: The Boys Who Cried Fox
description: Just last week, Newt Gingrich delighted observers on both the right and the left when he slammed Fox News for bias and distortion. Gingrich claimed that the conservative news channel slanted its coverage to favor the less conservative establishment candidate, Mitt Romney. At first this seemed to be just another example of the former speakers ability to unabashedly embrace contradictory ideas. This is, after all, a man who saw nothing inconsistent about inviting reporters to the private meeting with Delaware Tea Party leaders where he made his comments.

title: Keeping Score: Nashs Efficiency Keeps Suns in the Hunt
description: Contrary to the expectations of nearly every preseason prognosticator, the Phoenix Suns are battling for the final spot in the Western Conference playoffs. As usual, the Suns ageless point guard, 38-year-old Steve Nash, is leading the way.

title: Florida: Task Force Is Chosen to Consider Gun Laws
description: Gov. Rick Scott on Thursday named the members of a task force that will examine the states guns laws, including the expansive and controversial Stand Your Ground law, which has been cited in the Feb. 26 shooting death of Trayvon Martin by a neighborhood watch volunteer. The 17-member panel is being led by Lt. Gov. Jennifer Carroll; the vice chairman is the Rev. R. B. Holmes Jr., pastor of Bethel Missionary Baptist Church in Tallahassee, one of the states largest churches. The task force will report back to the governor and the Legislature. Ms. Carroll said the group includes a mix of law enforcement officials, lawmakers, neighborhood watch leaders, defense lawyers and prosecutors, among others. She said it would begin its work on May 1 and hold public meetings around the state. We are not walking into this with any preconceived notions, Governor Scott said.

title: Stanley R. Resor, Vietnam War Army Chief, Dies at 94
description: Stanley R. Resor, who as secretary of the Army from 1965 to 1971 oversaw the troop buildup in Vietnam, investigated the massacre of civilians by American soldiers at My Lai and laid the groundwork for the all-volunteer Army, died on Tuesday at his home in Washington. He was 94.

title: Measles Cases Rose in 2011
description: Measles cases quadrupled in the United States last year, but outbreaks are still rare compared with those in Europe, the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said Thursday. There were 222 cases of measles reported in the United States, a third of which required hospitalization, the agency said. Most of those 17 outbreaks are known to have begun in foreign visitors or in Americans returning from abroad  usually from Europe. But the virus then often spread to children whose parents did not vaccinate them. Vaccination resistance is concentrated in certain communities, making children there more vulnerable. By contrast, there were 37,000 measles cases last year in Europe, where resistance to vaccination is more common.

title: Corrections: April 20
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Grandersons Home Runs Power Yankees Past Twins
description: While the struggling starter Phil Hughess role remained as vexing as ever for the Yankees, it was Curtis Granderson who ended up commanding the most attention Thursday night, smashing three home runs in a 7-6 victory over the Minnesota Twins.

title: Maybe Red Sox Just Arent Very Good
description: BOSTON

title: After Mediocre Performance, Indie Rocker Ousted From Idol
description: Colton Dixon, the 20-year-old indie rocker from Tennessee, was eliminated from American Idol on Thursday night, leaving only six contestants remaining on Foxs singing competition.

title: Atltico Wins in Semifinal
description: Radamel Falcao scored two goals to help host Atltico Madrid beat Valencia, 4-2, in the first leg of the Europa League semifinals on Thursday. Miranda and Adrian Lopez also scored for Atltico, the 2010 champion.

title: The Closer: Grandersons Waiting Game
description: For a few innings, with the games result still in doubt, Curtis Granderson must have been rather unsure of how to react to his hitting display on Thursday.

title: Student Loan Interest Rates Loom as Political Battle
description: President Obama begins an all-out push on Friday to get Congress to extend the low interest rate on federal student loans, White House officials said, an effort that is likely to become a heated battle along party lines. If Congress fails to act, the interest rate on the loans, which are taken out by nearly eight million students each year, will double on July 1, to 6.8 percent.

title: Jonathan Frid, Ghoulish Dark Shadows Star, Is Dead at 87
description: Jonathan Frid, a Shakespearean actor who found unexpected  and by his own account unwanted  celebrity as the vampire Barnabas Collins on the sanguinary soap opera Dark Shadows, died last Saturday, April 14, in Hamilton, Ontario. He was 87.

title: Striking Comparisons: U.S. Options at Forward
description: Despite facing some early turbulence, United States Coach Jurgen Klinsmann has for the most part steadied the ship.

title: Paying the Price of a Fat Pet
description: In the year before she died, Lacey, a white German shepherd, was crippled by a weight problem and hip dysplasia, barely able to walk.

title: Word of the Day | compile
description: compile \km-pi(-)l\ verb

title: Who Made That Pie Chart?
description: William Playfair  a businessman, engineer and economics writer from Scotland  created the first known pie chart in 1801. Seeking to illustrate the Turkish Empires landholdings for his statistical breviary on the European nation-states, Playfair sliced a circle into three wedges whose sizes were determined by land area. According to a paper called No Humble Pie: The Origins and Usage of a Statistical Chart by Ian Spence, professor of psychology at the University of Toronto, Asias wedge was the largest and colored green, to indicate that it was a maritime power. Europe was made red to indicate it was a land power. Its not clear why Playfair made Africa yellow, or what inspired him to make a circle graph at all. But, Spence writes, it was the first pie chart to display empirical proportions and to differentiate the component parts by color.

title: Preliminary 2012 Acceptance Rates for International Students at U.S. Colleges
description: This week, we released our third annual college admissions report  a listing based on acceptance rates supplied by those colleges and universities that responded to a survey from The Choice over the last few weeks.

title: Signs of an Asian Arms Buildup in Indias Missile Test
description: Indias successful test on Thursday of a long-range ballistic missile capable of carrying a nuclear warhead is the latest escalation of an arms race in Asia, where the assertiveness and rising military power of China has rattled the region and prompted a forceful response from the Obama administration, Heather Timmons and Jim Yardley write in The New York Times.

title: BRICS Agitate for a Seat at the Table
description: Do the worlds powerful emerging markets need their own development bank? If China has anything to say about it  and it has quite a lot  the answer is a resounding yes, Didi Kirsten Tatlow writes in The New York Times.

title: 4 Americans Killed in Afghan Helicopter Crash
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A United States Black Hawk helicopter crashed in southern Afghanistan on Thursday, killing all four American service members on board, NATO and American officials said.

title: News Quiz | April 20, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: No Power, No Boom
description: India has long struggled to provide enough electricity to light its homes and power its industry around the clock, Vikas Bajaj writes in The New York Times. In recent years, the government and private sector sought to change that by building scores of new power plants, Mr. Bajaj writes. But that campaign is now running into difficulties because the country cannot get the fuel principally coal  to run the plants.

title: April 20, 1971 | Supreme Court Rules That Busing Can Be Used to Integrate Schools
description: On April 20, 1971, the United States Supreme Court upheld the use of busing to achieve racial desegregation in schools.

title: Test Yourself | English, April 20, 2012
description: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article As Cars Are Kept Longer, 200,000 Is New 100,000.

title: What a Poll Can Tell You About the National Mood
description: Note: All the questions in this edition of 6 Qs About the News can be answered by looking at these graphics, which show the results of a recent national poll about views on the 2012 election, candidates and the economy.

title: A Most Intimate Bond
description: When doctors realized that they could not separate Carmen and Lupita Andrade, conjoined twins, their mother, Norma, was devastated. She had traveled to the United States from their home in Veracruz, Mexico, specifically to save her daughters, then 2, from a lifetime of disability and ridicule.

title: What Things Did You Create When You Were a Child?
description: Have you seen the viral video about the 9-year-old boy who built an arcade out of cardboard? Did you make things out of found materials when you were little  whether pillow forts, paper dolls, sandcastles or anything else? What are your best memories of creating things? Why?

title: Serena Williams Is Playing Fed Cup With Eye on London Olympics
description: The tennis sphere and Twittersphere were brimming with reasonable doubt, but with her next Olympics in the balance, Serena Williams has kept her Fed Cup appointments in 2012.

title: Seeking Your Questions on Financial Aid Offers
description: As families finalize their college choices before the May 1 deadline, finding the best fit for their students and their budgets, weve once again opened our virtual guidance office for some advice.

title: A Silver Lining in Indias Coal Crisis
description: A power crisis in energy-starved India that has stalled the construction of thermal plants doesnt strike one immediately as a piece of good news.

title: Are College Entrants Overdiagnosed as Underprepared?
description: Judith Scott-Clayton is an assistant professor at Teachers College, Columbia University.

title: Scouting the Draft: Notre Dames Harrison Smith
description: Jonathan Bales is the founder ofTheDCTimes.comand is helping analyze draft prospects for The Fifth Down in his Scouting the Draft preview series.

title: The Early Word: Fight or Retire Response
description: In Todays Times:

title: The Childrens Investment Fund Wages Battle With Coal India
description: In 2010, when the Indian government sold 10 percent of the shares of Coal India, one of the worlds largest coal mine operators, the transaction was a way to raise money to help reduce its budget deficit, Vikas Bajaj writes for DealBook in The New York Times.

title: Haitong Raises $1.7 Billion in Hong Kong Share Sale
description: 12:00 p.m. | Updated

title: Q&A: Saving PDF Files Right to the Phone
description: Q.

title: Decoding the French Presidential Election Early
description: LONDON  Election junkies may have to rely on coded messages via Twitter for an early indication of the outcome of the first round of Frances presidential election on Sunday.

title: Tomorrows Privacy Struggles, On Display Today
description: Brian Ach/AP Images for AT&TThe Drive Safely iPad app gives a parent updates on a teenagers driving practices in real time.

title: A Sweet Follow-Up to a Traumatic Evening
description: In May 2010, I wrote a blog post called Are You Doing What You Truly Love? It was about attending a lively breast cancer benefit, a fashion show with cancer survivors modeling art bras. Amid the many women strutting down a long runway to thumping music and yells from an enthusiastic crowd was an under-30 breast cancer patient who collapsed midstride. The chemotherapy had perhaps taken its toll on her heart and she experienced a severe arrhythmia. Basically, her heart stopped. Those of us who were there watched, shocked and saddened, as paramedics worked over her lifeless body. For all of us, it was a jarring reminder of how rapidly things can change and how important it is to make the most of those precious moments between dawn and dusk every day.

title: Daily Report: Nokia, Microsoft and Verizon Report Earnings
description: Tech earnings are in the news, with Nokia, Microsoft and Verizon all reporting their quarterly results.

title: Dewey & LeBoeuf Said to Consider Prepackaged Bankruptcy
description: Dewey & LeBoeuf is contemplating a prearranged bankruptcy filing, in which the ailing law firm would reach an agreement with its creditors over a reorganization plan while simultaneously combining with another firm, according to a person with direct knowledge of the plan who requested anonymity because he was not authorized to discuss itpublicly.

title: Fossil Hunting Near New York, Brazil
description: Ken Angielczyk, an assistant curator at the Field Museum of Natural History, is searching for fossils of ancient mammal relatives in northeastern Brazil.

title: G.E. Profit Beats Expectations
description: General Electric, with the fallout from the financial crisis receding, is finally starting to look like what it is  the nations largest industrial company.

title: In Strategy Shift, Obama Team Attacks Romney From the Left
description: WASHINGTON  So long, flip-flopper. Hello, right-wing extremist.

description: LALIBELA, Ethiopia

title: Live Near a Great School? It's Costing You
A Play That Resounds in the Heart and the Gut
description: ITS a little depressing.

title: Ryan Lindley, 5th-Ranked Quarterback in 2012 Draft
description: Matt Waldman is the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, a testament to his obsession with film analysis, now available for download. Examples of his work can be found at his blog. He is helping The Fifth Down rank skill position players before the draft:

title: Aasif Mandvi on Food, Islam and Women
description: Its perhaps one of the most sumptuous paeans to Indian cuisine ever made.

title: Opinion Report: Radical Nuns?
description: From the editorial page

title: State to Propose New Graduation Requirements for Students with Disabilities
An Arms Race at Arms Length
description: As India celebrated on Thursday the successful launching of Agni V, a long-range ballistic missile capable of reaching Beijing and carrying a nuclear weapon, much of the world yawned. Is it ignoring a growing arms race in Asia at its peril?

title: Romney to Address Republican Leaders
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  Mitt Romney will address Republican leaders from around the country here on Friday, as he assumes with some fanfare the mantle of the partys not-quite-official presidential nominee.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: Skyfall on Istanbul
description: ISTANBUL  I blame James Bond for my romantic vision of Istanbul. I got my first glimpse of the city from the edge of a seat in a dark Philadelphia theater on a Saturday afternoon in the early 1960s, watching Sean Connery save the world from the evils of Spectre in From Russia with Love.

title: The Many Traditions of Passover
description: Dear Diary: Overheard next to me last week while getting a facial on West 72nd Street on the Upper West Side:

title: Rape, a Scar from Apartheid
description: JOHANNESBURG  This week a cellphone video depicting a 17-year-old girl being gang-raped by seven men between the ages of 14 and 20 went viral in South Africa. The rapists were encouraging one another and offered the girl 25 cents to not report them.

title: 3 Arrested at Heathrow on Suspicions of Terrorism
description: LONDON  Three men have been arrested at Heathrow Airport and held on suspicion of possessing articles and documents with intent to use them for terrorist purposes overseas, the police said on Friday.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: N.F.L. Matchups, and USA Today Journalists Become a Target
description: Building the 2011-2012 N.F.L schedule, which was released Tuesday night, is a complex project run by a league planners, aided by computers, Judy Battista writes. Among the factors: competitive fairness; who plays on Thursday night, with a short week to prepare; potential baseball playoff competition for stadiums and parking lots; and, yes, offering popular matchups. The stakes are high, with networks paying billions for the rights to the games, which, last fall, accounted for 23 of the 25 most-watched television shows among all programming.

title: Image of the Day: April 20
Fill-In | Remembering Dick Clark
description: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first several paragraphs of Stephen Holdens appraisal of Dick Clark, The Man Who Made Rock n Roll Safe Enough for America.

title: Olympus Shareholders Shake Off Scandal
description: TOKYO  There was the odd accusation of farce and kabuki theater, but Olympus had little trouble winning approval Friday for a new slate of directors at the first shareholders meeting since its $1.5 billion accounting scandal emerged, a reminder of the leeway Japanese investors still give to ill-performing boards.

title: In Store | Jussara Lee
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Apollo Raises Offer Again for Great Wolf Resorts
description: The bidding for Great Wolf Resorts is coming fast and furious.

title: I.M.F. Adds $430 Billion in Emergency Lending Ability
description: WASHINGTON  The International Monetary Fund has raised at least $430 billion in extra lending capacity to be used if the euro zone crisis worsens or global financial conditions deteriorate, it said Friday afternoon.

title: I Am Sorry, Zimmerman Says as Bail Set at $150,000
description: SANFORD, Fla.  Speaking publicly about the case for the first time, George Zimmerman, the man accused of second-degree murder in the shooting of Trayvon Martin, an unarmed 17-year-old, briefly took the witness stand at his bail hearing on Friday and apologized to the teenagers parents.

title: In Prague, a Gallery With Art for and by Children
description: Pragues littlest hands now have the chance to show off their work in an actual gallery. The citys first Art Gallery for Children opened in March. Its organizers hope that not only exposing children to art, but letting them contribute to it will inspire them to be more creative.

title: TPG Abandons $818 Million Bid for GlobeOp
description: LONDON  The private equity firm TPG Capital on Friday said it was abandoning its 508 million ($818 million) bid for GlobeOp Financial Services, a major provider of administrative services for hedge funds

title: In One Mans Return, the Tax Codes Unfairness
description: Like most Americans (though not Mitt Romney, who got an extension), I filed my 2011 tax returns this week and paid my five layers of income tax: federal, state, local, self-employed and something called the metropolitan commuter tax (even though I live in New York City and dont commute). When I first looked at the returns, I was incredulous.

title: Plutocrats and Printing Presses
description: These past few years have been lean times in many respects  but theyve been boom years for agonizingly dumb, pound-your-head-on-the-table economic fallacies. The latest fad  illustrated by this piece in todays WSJ  is that expansionary monetary policy is a giveaway to banks and plutocrats generally. Indeed, that WSJ screed actually claims that the whole 1 versus 99 thing should really be about reining in or maybe abolishing the Fed. And unfortunately, some good people, like Daron Agemoglu and Simon Johnson, have bought into at least some version of this story.

title: Revenue Drops at GE Capital
description: GE Capital, the finance arm of the industrial giant General Electric, continues to shrink.

title: Kings Speech Play Closes Early in London
description: The story of a stuttering monarch called on to deliver a crucial announcement to his subjects at the onset of World War II would seem to be as dramatic as they come. And apparently selling a stage production of that tale to British theatergoers is no picnic either. The producers of a theatrical version of The Kings Speech, which dramatizes the story of King George VI and his speech therapist, Lionel Logue, that transferred to Londons West End last month announced that it would close early because of poor ticket sales, The Telegraph reported.

title: Obama to Appear on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon
description: Jimmy Fallon is making a further statement about his up-and-coming status in late-night television by landing the first big late-night political appearance of the full-on presidential race: President Obama has agreed to be the guest on his show Tuesday night.

title: Morning Buzz, April 20: A Crackdown in City Parks
description: Good morning. Today will bring clear, sunny skies, with a high of 71 degrees.

title: Friday Reading: Paying the Price for Fat Pets
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: What Were Reading
description: Nations Restaurant News: California Pizza Kitchen, once the dominant ambassador of Left-Coast pizza glitz in the malls of America, is feeling its years, so its going back to the drawing board. The chain will open a new prototype in Florida to test a host of brand upgrades intended for national rollouts so that we will be the pizza authority again, said G.J. Hart, its chief executive.  Glenn Collins

title: US Airways Strikes Deal While It Eyes American
description: Doug Parker, the chief executive of US Airways, has long sought to merge his company with another major airline. But after seeing Delta, United and Continental all slip away and become part of mega-carriers, he made a move on Friday for one of the last of the big ones: the bankrupt American Airlines.

title: Mali Leader Finds Refuge in Senegal After Coup
description: DAKAR, Senegal  The former president of Mali, ousted in a military coup last month, has arrived in Dakar, officials said Friday, in flight from a country still in the grip of the soldiers who forced him out.

title: Poe Taunts Filmmakers Evermore
description: ITS probably safe to assume that Edgar Allan Poe does not rest quietly in the Baltimore grave that claimed him, at 40, in 1849. In the works that made him famous  poems like The Raven and Annabel Lee, stories like The Fall of the House of Usher and Ligeia  death is never quite the end: something lives on, not happily.

title: On the Sidewalk, Peddling a Street Game
description: Amid the noonday bustle on Flatbush Avenue  just off the tables piled with paperbacks or perfume  Darryl Jones worked the crowd.

title: The Ripped, Bikini-Clad Reverend
description: I stood by the mailbox holding a package that weighed about as much as an apple. Inside, I knew, there was a bikini. I was almost afraid to open it. How could something so small hold such a big risk?

title: My Sisters Last Pleasure
description: My sister, who was born with Down syndrome, has end-stage dementia with advanced Parkinsons disease. She can no longer recognize anyone, and her quality of life is limited to eating and sleeping. Now her doctors are asking me to let them insert a feeding tube, which would keep her from choking but prevent her from ever actually eating again. I love her. How can I remove one of her last pleasures? Should I make the decision for her that I would want for myself in similar circumstances? NAME WITHHELD,  New York

title: How the Comedy Nerds Took Over
description: In 1992, I sat in a comedy club in Toronto with an 86-year-old Henny Youngman, and as he watched the performer onstage, he grew so enraged that he almost heckled his own opening act. A young comic was warming up the audience with crowd work  asking people where theyre from, working off their responses, etc.  and Youngman looked on with disdain.  Where you from? Where you from?  he muttered. Who cares where theyre from? They paid to see you. Tell them some damn jokes.

title: The 4.8.12 Issue
description: Just One More Game . . .

title: Jeffrey Deitchs Party House
description: NAME: Jeffrey Deitch

title: The Maniac in Me
description: My brother Scott and I talk about anxiety the way some brothers talk about money, which is to say often and always with an eye on who has more of it. We arent really in competition, however: our anxieties are different breeds. Mine is cerebral. It starts with a thought  a what if or a should have been or a never will be or a could have been  and metastasizes from there, sparking down the spine and rooting out into my body in the form of clamminess, fatigue, palpitations and a terrible sense that the world in which I find myself is at once holographically insubstantial and grotesquely threatening. On more than one occasion my anxiety has paralyzed me over something as inconsequential as the choice between blue cheese and vinaigrette on a salad.

title: Murdochs Muscle
description: When I last saw you, at a White House Correspondents Dinner after-party in 2000, you were squiring around a foxy actress named Kathleen York. I have a pretty stiff public appearance, I guess. The private me is very different. I party hard.

title: How to Hunt Bigfoot
description: A BIGFOOTS howl is multidimensional: a deep and undulating whoop that starts low and ends in a high, feral squeal or resolves completely, like a siren. The first time I unleashed one, while crouching on a bluff overlooking the eastern bank of the Apalachicola River, Matt Moneymaker  who, moments earlier, had loosed a robust, commanding shriek that echoed cleanly through the valley  responded with a hearty guffaw.

title: Cheerful Debauchery
description: Judging by this satisfyingly scandalous new memoir, Frank Langella has slept with, been propositioned by, or at least swapped dirty jokes with a breathtaking swath of stars over his illustrious half-century career. Each of the 65 chapters in Dropped Names offers a no-holds-barred eulogy somewhere between mash note and carpet-bombing. The collection paints Hollywood and Broadway as teeming with vulgar, neurotic and irresistible company, and Langella as relentlessly affable in the face of nonstop groping by famous people in far-flung locations. He ambles into history and falls into notable beds like some kind of sexy Forrest Gump or beefcake Zelig.

title: Visiting the Sites
description: A photographic tour of some iconic Los Angeles structures.

title: The Shape of Things to Come
description: Surely the word vessel must rate high among the loveliest in the English language. Its meaning contains (vessel-like) a well-wrought urn, a far-sailing ship, a throbbing vein. Spoken, its whispering consonants cut swiftly past. Printed, its letters even resemble a boat: jutting prow, double-curved hull, high stern. Can it be a coincidence that this Middle English artifact encloses  centered perfectly  the Latin esse, the primal verb to be?

title: Trailing a Master Photographer in Los Angeles
description: THE photographer Julius Shulman captured Los Angeles and its surroundings in the middle of the 20th century as the city was shedding its small-town roots and becoming an international capital. In a career that started with a shoot for Richard Neutra in 1936 and ended with his death in 2009, Shulman photographed virtually every important midcentury modernist architects work  especially those on the West Coast  not to mention taking on an almost daily stream of jobs for businesses, cities and publications.

title: An Island of One
description: The intersection of the global and the nearly indetectable, even subatomic, realms of the personal is territory Graham Swift maps with particular acuity. His sense of leverage, and of the vectors of connection between, say, the way a woman sits in a car on the Isle of Wight and the horror of Sept. 11, is exquisite. From his early novel Waterland (which interweaves a marriage, a kidnapping, 300 years of the history of the Fens and the ways of the eel) to the novel that won him the Booker Prize, Last Orders (which tracks the spoken and unspoken connections among a group of elderly World War II veterans gathered in a pub), Swift has used extraordinarily subtle means to talk about the way we live now and how its infused not only with the way we lived then but with the way other people lived, and live.

title: Her Calling
description: In her celebrated novels, Housekeeping (1981), Gilead (2004) and Home (2008), Marilynne Robinson gives us isolated towns and single houses where the afternoon sun draws the damp out of the grass and . . . the smell of sour old sap out of the boards on the porch floor. It is a laconic world where adults conserve syllables as if to conserve breath while children brave an outsized landscape by day and seek shelter by night even as they long to break away from the regime of small kindnesses that makes home both comforting and confining.

title: He Made It Look Easy
description: Dwight D. Eisenhowers memoirs came out while I was in graduate school in the 1960s, and one of my professors commented  not entirely facetiously  that hed been surprised to see print on the pages. My fellow students and I were being taught that despite Eisenhowers victories in World War II, the presidency had been beyond his capabilities. Like Ulysses S. Grant, another general to make it to the White House, Ike won elections easily, but did not rise to the responsibilities these thrust upon him.

title: BMW Adds 2,800 Vehicles to Recall for Potential Fire Hazard
description: BMW has informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration of its plan to recall another 2,846 of its 8- and 12-cylinder models because of a fire hazard.

title: Restaurant Report: Yardbird in Miami Beach, Fla.
description: Miami Beach lies about as far south of the Mason-Dixon line as you can get while still in the continental United States. Yet its restaurants generally seem more influenced by New York than the deep South.

title: Hotel Review: Boca Beach Club in Boca Raton, Fla.
description: THE UPSHOT

title: Bend, Ore., a Brewers Town
description: ON a frosty winter night in Bend, Ore., members of a local home brewers club swilled beers inside Boneyard Beer, where a tiny tasting room is plastered with snowboard stickers and beer posters.

title: The Tech-Savvy Traveler
description: AT 28 years old, Soraya Darabi is an old hat at staying on the cutting edge of social media. Her first job out of college was in the communications department for Cond Nast Digital for products like epicurious.com. At 23, she became the manager of digital partnerships and social media at The New York Times and went on to help found Foodspotting (foodspotting.com), a Web site and digital application that aggregates real-time dining advice.

title: Race, the Remix
description: From the first slave ship arriving in harbor, America stole and judged blacks. Black life that didnt fit into white logic was commercially exploited or lynched. Slave bodies lied to their masters. Denied dancing and musical instruments, slaves expressed a hidden tradition of musicality and poetics by tongue and signal. The trickster was born. In his new work of literary and cultural criticism, The Grey Album: On the Blackness of Blackness, the accomplished poet Kevin Young unearths, orchestrates, improvises and imagines lies and more lies  in short, American history.

title: Letters to the Travel Editor
description: To the Editor: Regarding When to Buy That Plane Ticket (Practical Traveler, April 15), weve reached the point where buying an airline ticket is a blood sport. The relationship of customer and airline should not be a competition, yet that is what it has become. I honestly think Id like to return to the era of regulated (albeit higher) fares when everyone on the plane paid the same price in each class no matter when the ticket was bought.

title: Northern Light
description: The first English translation of Amsterdam Stories, by the Dutch author Nescio (1882-1961), should have a much more vibrant cover. The books most enduring effect is of color, as Nescio attempts to do with words what the Impressionists did with paints  to record the play of light on water, the beauties of a sunset.

title: Unbridled
description: If you read only three novelists on Mexico  and you should read many more, but thats your affair  choose Juan Rulfo, Roberto Bolao and Daniel Sada. Rulfo cleared the way for magic realism with Pedro Pramo, published in 1955, a decade before the Boom. Bolao, a Chilean whose great subject was Mexico, asserted that realism itself was magic enough to support a novel, and his gangs of visceral realists and killers bore him out. Meanwhile Sada, who died last year, reveled in wordplay and mimicry in his Joycean celebrations of Mexicos cowboy north.

title: Dark Hours
description: Heres how the novelist Candia McWilliam, stricken at age 50 with a rare neuromuscular disorder called blepharospasm, had to work in order to get this memoir written: I hoist my forehead up with the flat of my left hand as I laboriously and inaccurately type with my right, and when my eyelids get wise to this and clamp insistently down, I lift them with my thumb and little finger, dedicating the latter to my right eye, the thumb to my left. Near the end, she sustained this pose for a minimum of eight hours a day over a period of 56 days, even as my eyes fight back and weep to be shut down and left in peace.

title: Are Travel Agents Back?
description: THE complimentary wine and fruit platter was sent up to Jessica Griffin and her family moments after they strolled into their roomy suite. They were accompanied by a bellhop who placed their bags near a tidy crib made up with luxurious, high thread-count sheets for Ms. Griffins 1-year-old daughter.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: THIS ISNT THE SORT OF THING THAT HAPPENS TO SOMEONE LIKE YOU  Stories.  By Jon McGregor.  Bloomsbury, paper, $16.

title: Twisted Business
description: The protagonist of Mark Allen Smiths weird but transfixing first novel, THE INQUISITOR (Holt, $27), takes great pride in his work. He does his research, attends to details, keeps scrupulous records and, all things considered, gives honest value for his services. The chosen name of this consummate professional is Geiger, and the awkward thing is, hes in the torture business.

title: Up Front
description: This week, Paul Muldoon reviews The Complete Poems, by Philip Larkin. Muldoon was a teenager in Northern Ireland in the 1960s when he first encountered Larkins work. I was introduced to contemporary poetry at high school, he said by e-mail, so we were reading Larkin and Hughes along with Wordsworth and Herbert. Ive a feeling that his sense of things being intensely sad appeals to teenagers as much as the old.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE GREAT ANIMAL ORCHESTRA: Finding the Origins of Music in the Worlds Wild Places,  by Bernie Krause. (Little, Brown, $26.99.) This passionate amalgam of science and autobiography argues that in the wild, animals vocalize with a musicianly ear.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE CRIMEAN WAR: A History,  by Orlando Figes. (Picador, $22.) The Crimean War (1853-56), in which France and Britain sided with the Ottoman Empire in its clash against Russia, shattered almost four decades of European peace. Today, we remember fragmentary stories: the charge of the Light Brigade, Florence Nightingale. Figes restores the conflict as a major turning point in European and Middle Eastern history, one that provided the tinder for World War I.

title: American Decline
description: To the Editor:

title: In Praise of Berger
description: To the Editor:

title: In Praise of Oates
description: To the Editor:

title: The Second Shelf, Cont.
description: To the Editor:

title: The Laughs Evoked by Anguished Souls
description: WASHINGTON  Great gusts of laughter are rippling through the Shakespeare Theater Companys capacious Sidney Harman Hall here. If you stood outside the auditoriums doors, listening to the happy tumult inside, you might assume that one of Shakespeares comedies was being performed, or that some of Nol Cowards bright young things were deploying their barbed wits in plush drawing rooms.

title: Some Book
