description: I knew of several barns where I thought the past might lie.

title: Business Day Live | April 20, 2012
description: Brian Stelter looks at how the Discovery Channel dodged global warming politics; Annie Lowrey on the I.M.F. | Ron Lieber assesses vacation rental services like Airbnb.

title: Inside the List
description: ODD COUPLE: Here at the Book Review, intuition and free association play big roles when we decide who should review the books we send out. So if one novelist reviews another, theyll often overlap in terms of tone or themes or prose style. But sometimes a counterintuitive pairing works just as well. In 1988, Anne Tyler reviewed Libra, Don DeLillos novel about the Kennedy assassination, in these pages. Tyler and DeLillo were already literary heavyweights, but you wouldnt have looked for them on the same fight card  DeLillo had a reputation as a chilly analyst of paranoia and pervasive social forces, while Tyler was known for her intimate dissections of grief and domestic estrangement. (That hasnt changed: The Beginners Goodbye, her novel about a man haunted by his dead wife, is at No. 11 on the hardcover fiction list.) Still, she loved Libra, and came away persuaded that the C.I.A. could have been involved in the assassination. DeLillo must have had the same source materials available to anyone else, she wrote. But he takes the stale facts and weaves them into something altogether new. . . . That finally were interested less in the physical events of the assassination than in the pitiable and stumbling spirit underlying them proves Libra to be a triumph. DeLillos novel went on to spend five weeks on the best-seller list.

title: Directors Playing Against Type
description: The Organizer

title: Bias Law Used to Move a Man Off Death Row
description: FAYETTEVILLE, N.C.  Concluding that racial bias played a significant factor in a death sentence here 18 years ago, a judge on Friday ordered that it be changed to life in prison without parole, the first such decision under North Carolinas controversial Racial Justice Act.

title: When Losers Take Center Stage
description: April seems to be the time of year when the winners and losers come into sharper focus. In hockey, teams are getting knocked out of the playoffs, sometimes in embarrassing upsets. In basketball, the best teams are gearing up for a long spring while losing teams are jockeying for better draft picks. In football, the teams in the news are those with the top picks in the draft  and often the most rebuilding to do. And in baseball, the gauzy honeymoon known as spring training has evaporated and some fans realize that their teams are in for a very long season.

title: Department of Cultural Tourism | Next Stop Glasgow
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Editor's Note: The Health Issue
description: Hugo Lindgren, the editor of the magazine, and Ilena Silverman discuss this weeks special issue on health, which is all in your mind.

title: How Psychedelic Drugs Can Help Patients Face Death
description: Pam Sakuda was 55 when she found out she was dying. Shortly after having a tumor removed from her colon, she heard the doctors dreaded words: Stage 4; metastatic. Sakuda was given 6 to 14 months to live. Determined to slow her diseases insidious course, she ran several miles every day, even during her grueling treatment regimens. By nature upbeat, articulate and dignified, Sakuda  who died in November 2006, outlasting everyones expectations by living for four years  was alarmed when anxiety and depression came to claim her after she passed the 14-month mark, her days darkening as she grew closer to her biological demise. Norbert Litzinger, Sakudas husband, explained it this way: When you pass your own death sentence by, you start to wonder: When? When? It got to the point where we couldnt make even the most mundane plans, because we didnt know if Pam would still be alive at that time  a concert, dinner with friends; would she still be here for that? When came to claim the couples life completely, their anxiety building as they waited for the final day.

title: Oils for Cooking and Drizzling
description: For home cooks with a sense of adventure, experimenting with aromatic and flavored oils can transform a dish. But deciding which type of oil to use isnt always easy.

title: Living Under the Volcker Rule: A Preview for Banks
description: A huge amount of time and effort has been spent debating what will happen once the Volcker Rule is in place. Perhaps we already know.

title: Portraits of Philip Larkin
description: Students at Parsons The New School for Design offer their view of the poet.

title: Chinese Court Overturns a Young Tycoons Death Sentence
description: BEIJING  The Supreme Peoples Court on Friday overturned the death penalty against a 31-year-old woman who was convicted of financial fraud three years ago after becoming rich through a company that sold beauty products and other goods.

title: No Friday Patrols by U.N. Observers in Syria
description: Updated | 6:04 p.m. The Moroccan colonel leading a small team of United Nations military observers in Syria dealt a severe blow to the hopes of opposition activists late Thursday when he announced that his monitors planned to avoid working on Fridays, the traditional day of mass protests in the country.

title: Morning Walkabout: 4/20
description: Out With the Old The Intrepid museum makes way for the arrival of the Enterprise, the prototype for the space shuttles, which will fly into New York City next week and is expected to go on display in July. (The New York Times)

title: Baby Hawks Christened by Readers
description: For the second year in a row, City Rooms highly literate readers have turned to the pages of a classic novel for baby hawk names.

title: Weekend Fare
description: The Sikh Day Parade and festival (above), on Saturday from 11:30 a.m. to 3:30 p.m., begins with the parade at Madison Avenue and East 36th Street marching to 26th Street, where the festival takes place and includes plenty of food for sale.

title: Book Review Podcast
description: This week, Frank Langella discusses his new memoir; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Kevin Young talks about his book The Grey Album; Andrew Delbanco on the essays of Marilynne Robinson; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: At Riverpark, Its Not Far From Farm to Table
description: Riverpark, the restaurant in the Alexandria Center, a group of office towers overlooking the East River at 29th Street, has had its own farm since last year. Nearly 200 different edible herbs, vegetables and berries are planted in soil in 4,000 milk crates set up in the plaza in front of the restaurant. Now the restaurant has added outdoor dining on the farm. A table that seats up to 12 guests has been set up under a tented covering on a deck, along with a bar. And there, Sisha Ortzar (above), the chef who runs the restaurant in partnership with Tom Colicchio, will serve lunches and dinners.

title: Dylan Fondly Recalls Levon Helm
description: Bob Dylan called his former collaborator Levon Helm one of the last true great spirits of my or any other generation in a note he posted online.  Mr. Helm, former drummer and vocalist with the Band, which backed up Mr. Dylan in the 1960s, died of complications of cancer on Thursday at age 71.

title: Anthony Marx, New York Public Libary President, Answers Reader Questions
description: When the New York Public Library announced plans in 2008 to renovate its Fifth Avenue main building, the project sounded glamorous and exciting: it would be designed by the prominent British architect Norman Foster. For the first time, the landmark would become a circulating as well as a research library, with abundant computers, ample public space  even a cafe.

title: The Genius of Unstructured Summer Time
description: Writing at Mamiverse, Belen Aranda-Alvarado has been thinking about Caines Arcade  an elaborate cardboard arcade made by a 9-year-old boy  and wondering if George Monroy, Caines father, a dude who sells used car parts out of a store in East L.A., is the parenting guru my generation so desperately needs.

title: The Munchkins Are a Problem: Call In the Teamsters
The Right to Register
description: Imposing rigorous identification requirements isnt the only way to keep poor people and minorities from voting. Another strategy is to restrict the flow of information about elections to those on public assistance, so that they never even learn of their right to register. That happens to be illegal, and this week Georgia became the latest state to promise to stop this practice.

title: April 22  28
description: ITS been quite a year in movies for cults and the charismatic leaders who control them. Elizabeth Olsen played a damaged refugee from a group in Martha Marcy May Marlene, and the barely seen Gods Land depicted a Texas commune waiting for a spaceship to deliver it to the promised, er, dimension.   SOUND OF MY VOICE, perhaps the best of all, opens Friday in New York.

title: Perez Snagged by Baseballs Twitter Policy
description: Indians pitcher Chris Perez keeps his Twitter page very active, posting about music and baseball and carrying on conversations with fans. And just because one of his posts ran afoul of Major League Baseballs Twitter policies and he was fined $750, Perez says he wont stop sharing his thoughts that way.

title: Whom Do Women Call? Husbands Lose Out to Daughters
description: A fascinating new study of nearly two billion cellphone calls and almost half a billion text messages shows how our loyalties, as measured by phone communication, can shift over time.

title: Stop and Vogue: Antigone Meets The Postmodern
description: SEVERAL years ago Trajal Harrell, a brainy downtown dance experimentalist with a sharp sense of humor, created a choreographic labyrinth in the form of a question: What would have happened in 1963 if someone from the voguing ball scene going on in Harlem had traveled downtown to perform alongside the early postmoderns at Judson Church?

title: Tackling Real Estate in a Do-It-Yourself Approach to I.R.A.s
description: THE past couple of years have left many people staring in disbelief at the returns on their individual retirement accounts. Consider last year, when the Standard & Poors 500-stock index finished the year essentially where it started.

title: The Tenor Who Wants To Sing It All
description: PLEASE dont call Jonas Kaufmann the German tenor: it raises too many preconceptions about a restricted repertory a German tenor should address, and Mr. Kaufmann wants to sing it all. He seems to be doing just that with major opera companies from New York to Vienna, performing an impressive range of roles with a finely chiseled, deftly modulated lyric-dramatic voice capped by a secure, ringing top.

title: Looking Beyond a Milestone, for Some More Cans to Bang
description: CHANGE has run rampant in the East Village during the last few decades, with curvilinear high-rises now dotting an urban landscape that once seemed flatter and more human scaled. But at B&H Dairy, a cheery lunch nook on Second Avenue just south of St. Marks Place, you could imagine that time had stood still. The service was friendly, the fare simple and hardy.

title: Rich Ross, Disney Studio Chairman, Is Forced Out
description: 8:45 p.m. | Updated

title: Bulls Wait for Roses Injuries to Heal
description: The Chicago Bulls know a few things for sure right now: theyre headed to the playoffs and have a strong shot to be the top seed in the Eastern Conference. The Bulls are eying the 76ers, currently in the eighth spot, as their first-round opponent.

title: Book Review Podcast: Frank Langella on the Famous People He Has Known
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Ada Calhoun reviews Frank Langellas new memoir, Dropped Names: Famous Men and Women as I Knew Them, in which the actor of stage and screen pulls very few punches about his relationships and run-ins with bold-face names. Ms. Calhoun writes:

title: Kids These Days: Teenage Production of God of Carnage Coming to Boston in May
description: Even audiences familiar with Yasmina Rezas comedy God of Carnage, and the way it reduces its four adult characters to squabbling children over the course of roughly 90 minutes, might raise an eyebrow at a production of the play that will open in Boston next month.

title: The City of Sky-High Rent
description: GARY L. MALIN, the president of Citi Habitats, the citys largest rental brokerage firm, has seen the real estate market at its giddiest heights and its deepest despair. There should be little that surprises him.

title: Molly Palmer and Lee Cowan
description: FOR one week of October in 2009, Falcon Heene of Fort Collins, Colo., had the attention of his seemingly very concerned parents, the local police and a large contingent from the national news media that included Molly Palmer and Lee Cowan, both then working for NBCs Today show.

title: Face Time | Taylor Schilling
description: I spoke to Taylor Schilling in Los Angeles last week. The hot young actress was kicking off the press tour for The Lucky One, which opens today. Its her biggest role to date, and I was curious about how she was handling all the hoopla. Naturally, I also wanted to know what was in her makeup bag.

title: The Escalation in Hostile Takeover Offers
description: Hostile offers seem to be everywhere. Its a surprising development considering that some prominent investment bankers in mergers and acquisitions were predicting their demise after Air Products yearlong failure to acquire Airgas. These bankers argued that hostile offers were just too difficult to pull off. Companies apparently disagree, and for those trying to keep track of this burst of activity, here is a brief tour through the biggest of the battles:

title: The Marathons Random Route to Its Length
description: London

title: This Weeks Movies
description: The Timess critics weigh in on Darling Companion, Fightville, Marley and Goodbye First Love.

title: Off the Charts: Retail Sales Bounce Back
description: Retail sales in the United States rose a surprisingly strong 0.8 percent in March. Over all, retail sales were 5 percent higher in the past 12 months than they were in the 12 months through July 2008, when sales peaked as the credit crisis and recession began to hit. The charts show the change in sales from the peak for overall retail sales and for 10 categories of retailers. The biggest gains have come from Internet retailers, while neither auto dealers nor retailers catering to homeowners have made a complete recovery.

title: Retail Sales Recover, Mostly, From Recession
description: THE American consumer seems to be spending again. Except, that is, on products dependent on home sales.

title: Parental Quandary: Do Siblings Need to Fight Physically?
description: This weeks parental quandary is mine.

title: Prime Targets for Scam Artists
description: Heres a question youd think would be simple to answer: How many older Americans fall prey to frauds and scams each year?

title: Life on Her Own Terms for Beyoncs Little Sister
description: SHE has a million-plus followers on Twitter, but often walks her son to school. She was interviewed by Italian Vogue, but goes incognito to pop-up parties in Chinatown. She vacations on yachts in Europe, but talks giddily of sneaking into the Chick-fil-A in Greenwich Village.

title: West End to Get First New Theater in 30 Years
description: LONDON  The West End area is getting a new theater, its first in 30 years.

title: TimesCast | April 20, 2012
description: Tensions build in Bahrain ahead of Formula One race | The French election hinges on the extremes | DVRs struggle to handle Sunday nights lineups.

title: Worried Egyptians Jam Tahrir Square, but Unity Is Elusive
description: CAIRO  Tens of thousands of Egyptians packed into Tahrir Square in central Cairo on Friday in a spasm of last-minute concern that Egypts ruling generals might be trying to sabotage the promised transition to civilian democracy after the presidential election beginning next month.

title: S.E.C. Files Charges Against Father and Son, and Twin Brothers
description: Securities fraud cases, at least on Friday, were a family affair.

title: Tipping a Hat to the Planet
description: The Green blog turns 2 on Sunday. Excited?

title: No Place for Heated Opinions
description: Frozen Planet, the seven-hour series that has attracted millions of viewers to the Discovery Channel in recent weeks, shows Earth in extremis. On this planet, the poles are violently cold, yet are also atypically vulnerable to the warming trends that are endangering polar bear populations and causing huge chunks of ice to break off Greenland and Antarctica.

title: Ahead of Bahrain Grand Prix, Incidents Put Formula One Teams on Edge
description: As Brad Spurgeon wrote Friday in a special report for The Times, the Bahrain Grand Prix, which was canceled in 2011 after civil unrest broke out in the former Gulf emirate, remains the most politically charged race on the Formula One calendar.

title: Fairness Can Pay Economic Dividends
description: Theres a reason they call economics the dismal science, but Professor Armin Falks presentation at an economics conference in Berlin a few days ago made me smile. Thats because his big conclusion  fairness has a financial pay-off  is so cheering.

title: Friends for Life? Wait Till Kids Enter the Picture
description: NOTHING can sink a friendship like differences over parenting. Sometimes the areas of disagreement are stark and dramatic, leading to blowups and out-and-out breaks. Most of the time theyre subtle and unstated, a matter of dark looks and long-simmering resentments, that erode, rather than rupture, formerly close relationships. Often they arise from a vague sense of betrayal, a friends having changed once he or she has had children, breaking unspoken assumptions about shared values and goals, how to live and who to be.

title: Airliner Crashes Near Pakistani Capital, Killing 127
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A commercial airliner flying in a thunderstorm crashed into a wheat field outside Islamabad on Friday evening, killing all 127 people on board. It was the second major plane crash near the capital in two years, reviving worries about safety standards in a domestic aviation industry that is plagued by weak regulation, corruption and labor unrest.

title: How Doctors and Patients Do Harm
description: Just how broken is the United States health care system? Dr. Otis Brawley, chief medical officer for the American Cancer Society, paints a grim picture in his new book How We Do Harm: A Doctor Breaks Ranks About Being Sick In America (St. Martins Press).

title: Proofpoint and Infoblox Rise on Debuts
description: Two enterprise technology companies had debuts on Friday worthy of social media darlings.

title: The Boom in Enterprise I.P.O.s
description: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg News

title: Business Day Live: Discovery Channel Quiet on Global Warming
description: Brian Stelter looks at how the Discovery Channel dodged global warming politics; Annie Lowrey on the I.M.F. | Ron Lieber assesses vacation rental services like Airbnb.

title: For Playoff Purposes, Should the Knicks Try to Lose? Discuss
description: In recent weeks, the specter of one of the most front-loaded draft classes in memory has made the N.B.A.s race to the bottom  in a word, tanking  a subject of much discussion.

title: An Albatrosss Flight from Extinctions Edge
description: Early this week I was sent an encouraging update from a conservation group on the status in the Hawaiian Islands of the short-tailed albatross, a remarkable ocean-roaming bird that once numbered in the millions but, devastated by the feather trade and other impacts, nearly vanished early in the 20th century. Heres an excerpt from the release, followed by some valuable context from the biologist (and frequent Dot Earth voice) Carl Safina, whose books include the marvelous Eye of the Albatross:

title: Backwards Alabama
description: The Alabama House on Thursday passed an immigration bill, a revised but still-reprehensible version of HB56, last years law that criminalized thousands of Latino immigrants, encouraged racial profiling and made Alabama a national symbol of intolerance.

title: Video: This Weeks Movies
description: Today we start a new video feature, This Weeks Movies, which offers some critical guidance for select new film releases. This episode includes our critics takes on the new Lawrence Kasdan dog movie, Darling Companion, as well as one documentary about mixed martial arts (Fightville) and another about Bob Marley (Marley). There is also a look at the French drama from Mia Hansen-Love, Goodbye First Love, which A. O. Scott designated a Critics Pick.

title: Wicked Women Looking Fabulous
description: WHEN Ursula Andress, clad in a silver bikini, lifts her stiletto shoe after a killing scene in the 1965 film The 10th Victim, the thought flashed through my mind  as I am sure it would a designers  that the style would look fabulous today. Its safe to assume that many in fashion have scrutinized this film, set in the future and directed by Elio Petri and also starring Marcello Mastroianni.

title: Wordplay, Hip-Hop, New Orleans and Brazil
description: THEESatisfaction

title: A Rappers Strange Trip to Russia
description: Why has it taken so long for someone to make a movie about the musician John Fort? His life story certainly has the requisite sweep: Fort grew up fatherless and poor in Brownsville, Brooklyn, only to get a scholarship to one of the best prep schools in the country, Phillips Exeter. He received a Grammy nomination for his work with the Fugees, then embarked on a critically acclaimed solo career, before getting arrested at Newark Airport for carrying $1.4 million in liquid cocaine. He was sentenced to a mandatory 14 years in prison, served seven, and then had his sentence commuted in 2008 by George W. Bush at the urging of a pair of unlikely allies: the singer Carly Simon and the Republican Utah Senator Orrin Hatch.

title: What to Think About Before You Hit Send
description: IT seems almost pass to write now about how to use e-mail. After all, havent most of us moved past that to tweeting, texting, Facebooking and whatever the social network flavor-of-the-month is?

title: Passing Some Judgment on Talent-Show Arbiters
description: JUDGE not, lest ye be judged warns the Bible, and certainly the contestants and fans of reality television competitions have let their opinions be known about the opinions of Simon Cowell, Len Goodman and their brethren. But what do experienced courtroom judges think of their TV counterparts?

title: Judging the Judges
description: Experienced courtroom judges weigh in on their TV counterparts.

title: Ottawas Shooting Gallery Threatens Rangers
description: Except for the two times they allowed overtime goals to the Senators, the Rangers have never trailed on the scoreboard during the four games of their first-round series. But the Rangers have been out-shot by Ottawa by a wide margin, as shown in the repeated images of Henrik Lundqvist trying to make saves with big Senators forwards at the top of his crease.

title: For Stewards of Historic Homes, No Salary but Unbeatable Rent
description: It has been nearly a quarter-century since Roy Fox had a regular salary. He is not a lottery winner or the recipient of some grand family fortune. He is, in short, the type of person who long ago would have been priced out by New Yorks ever-climbing housing market.

title: A Taste of Ricotta
description: Melissa Clark provides a few ideas on how to use your homemade ricotta.

title: Setting Sail in Stop Motion
description: A look behind the scenes of the animated film The Pirates! Band of Misfits.

title: Three to Quit Secret Service as Inquiries Widen Scope
description: WASHINGTON  The Secret Service announced Friday that three employees under investigation in connection with misconduct with prostitutes last week in Colombia have decided to resign, bringing to six the number of people forced out of the agency.

title: Living Large, Paying No Rent
description: Roy Fox, a retired radio host, is one of only 19 people lucky enough to nab the role of resident caretaker of a city-owned historic home, a job that comes with free housing, but no salary.

title: A Speech Re-enacted
description: Roy Fox, the caretaker of the King Manor Museum, the original home of Senator Rufus King, re-enacts an anti-slavery speech originally delivered on February 11, 1820.

title: How Andreessen Horowitz Bunted on an Instagram Investment
description: 10:46 a.m. | Updated Added link to Ben Horowitzs blog post on the subject.3:53 p.m. | Updated Added comment from Ben Horowitz of Andreessen Horowitz.

title: Spain Stings Argentina Over Oil Company Nationalization
description: MADRID  Spain said Friday that it would seek to restrict imports of biodiesel fuel from Argentina, its first retaliatory measure after the government in Buenos Aires decided to seize control of the assets there of Repsol YPF, the largest Spanish oil company.

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $12,600,000
description: A 13-room Park Avenue co-op that sold for $12.6 million was the biggest sale of the week, according to city records.

title: As States Lock In to Movie Stars Taxes, California Tries to Cope
description: LOS ANGELES  Movie stars are a famously mobile group. Their tax dollars have been moving around, too.

title: Woeful Ratings Week Continues, as American Idol Joins In
description: The lows and woes continued for network series on Thursday night, extending what has been a week filled with record-setting depths for a raft of shows.

title: Stoudemire Rejoins Knicks, With Little Time to Experiment
description: CLEVELAND  The Knicks frontcourt at Friday mornings shootaround looked as everyone imagined it would when the season started, laughing with each other, jawing with opponents.

title: Winners, Losers and Gun-Toting Straight Shooters
description: WHEN Top Shot, the History channel marksmanship competition, closes out its fourth season on May 1, the person who successfully shoots the most targets in the final showdown will win. The one who doesnt will not.

title: The Challenges in Hedging Tail Risk
description: If theres one word investors use to describe the markets over the past few years, its unpredictable. Unforeseen events were everywhere.

title: First Aid
Principals, Show Us Your Office
Graphic Books Best Sellers: Hero on the Beach
description: At No. 1 on the hardcover graphic books best-seller list this week is Flex Mentallo: Man of Muscle Mystery, written by Grant Morrison and illustrated by Frank Quitely. The book, published by DC Comics, collects the four-issue 1996 series starring Flex, though the character was introduced in 1991. In 2005, the creators worked on the critically acclaimed All-Star Superman. Their take on Superman was an instant classic, so I really wanted to love Flex Mentallo. Instead, my feeling for the work  which is beautifully drawn and crammed with ideas  was more of a deep like.

title: Baseball Has Its Worshipers, and at N.Y.U., You Get Credit
description: On the night before opening day, the end of a baseball fans version of Advent, John Sexton entered his classroom at New York University to speak of Joe DiMaggio. He came to speak, too, of Ernest Hemingway and Gay Talese, of Lord Krishna and a sacred tree in the Amazon, and what he called this notion of touching the ineffable.

title: Taking All Responsibility for Whats in Your I.R.A.
description: Paul Sullivan, in his Wealth Matters column this week, writes about people so frustrated with the poor returns in their individual retirement accounts that theyve moved their money into self-directed I.R.A.s.

title: Best Part of the Breakup: New Songs
description: AT 6 p.m. on a Tuesday in mid-March the people streaming into the Living Room, a Lower East Side club geared to singer-songwriters, werent there for happy hour. Word had quietly gone out to friends and associates that Norah Jones and her band would be performing songs from her new album, Little Broken Hearts, and the small room was packed.

title: DealBooks Week in Review: A Rising Debate on Inequality
description: Beating profits estimates is no longer enough for Wall Street chiefs looking to earn million-dollar raises. That was the message delivered this week from Dallas, New York and London.

title: Home-Sharing? Dont Ignore Liability
description: In the last month or so, Ive written one column raising questions about how your insurance company might feel about you putting your car up for rent by the hour and another about the fallout for a customer of a company called RelayRides after someone who rented her car died behind the wheel and injured four others in the process.

title: Finding an End to the Parent-Teacher Wars
description: According to Ron Clark, Disneys American Teacher of the Year, new teachers remain in our profession an average of just four and a half years, and many of them list issues with parents as one of their reasons for throwing in the towel.

title: Airbnb and the Big Liability Insurance Questions
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I take a look at the liability insurance issues that come up for people who rent their homes (or rooms in their homes) on sites like Airbnb and HomeAway. As in other areas in the burgeoning collaborative consumption movement, like peer-to-peer car-sharing, insurance companies want to know just how much youre sharing and how many people youre sharing with.

title: Jogging Your Brain
description: The fastest way to a fit brain is a fit body, writes Gretchen Reynolds in this weeks New York Times Magazine.

title: Wheelies: The Rational Exuberance Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Penn State-Paterno Rift Gets $5.5-Million Salve
description: Penn States announcement that it has paid the Paterno family more than $5.5 million in honoring Joe Paternos contract obligations seemed like it might signal that the school and the family of its legendary coach had settled whatever differences might linger over Paternos firing. But the familys lawyer said they have retained the rights to sue the school, even though Penn State had requested a release of that right.

title: Teach the Books, Touch the Heart
description: FRANZ KAFKA wrote that a book must be the ax for the frozen sea inside us. I once shared this quotation with a class of seventh graders, and it didnt seem to require any explanation.

title: Tadashi Shoji Designs Gowns for All Silhouettes
description: A fan of stretchy, nonconstrictive fabrics and patterns that prize comfort and wearability, Mr. Shoji does not discriminate against size or age.

title: The Unforeseen Consequences of the Bahrain Grand Prix
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  Formula One completed its first day of practice on Friday. Nico Rosberg, the driver for the Mercedes team who won the race in China last Sunday, completed the fastest lap of the day as protesters gathered for further demonstrations around the capital to coincide with the three days of rage that uprising leaders have called for during the three days of the Bahrain Grand Prix.

title: Red Sox Toast 100 Years at Fenway Park
description: BOSTON  More than 200 former players, including dozens of former fan favorites like Luis Tiant, Carl Yastrzemski, Jim Rice and Pedro Martinez, helped the Boston Red Sox commemorate the 100th anniversary of the opening of Fenway Park on Friday.

title: Silhouettes Tailored to Every Woman
description: SHE signed it for me  she is so cute! So sweet! the designer Tadashi Shoji gushed as he lovingly clutched a piece of paper to his chest. On it was the original sketch he had made of the gown that the actress Octavia Spencer had worn to the Academy Awards in February. Next to the drawing of the gown, an elaborately draped white sheath covered in sparkly beads, Ms. Spencer had signed her name, along with the words: Love you!

title: TimesCast | Bahrain Grand Prix
description: April 20, 2012  The controversial Bahrain Grand Prix, which begins on Friday, has become a flash point between the Sunni royal family and much of the majority Shiite population.

title: The Week in Pictures, April 20
description: A look back at the weeks events in New York City and the region.

title: Why Should a Disability Limit High School Choices?
Warren and Brown Trade Jabs Over Taxes
description: BOSTON  It has been a week of tax wars for Senator Scott P. Brown of Massachusetts and his presumed Democrat opponent, Elizabeth Warren.

title: TimesCast | Extreme Voters in France
description: April 20, 2012  The first round of Frances presidential election takes place Sunday, and voters on the extremes, the far left and the far right, will play a significant role.

title: Former Treasurer Convicted of Bribery in Indonesia
description: JAKARTA  An Indonesian court on Friday sentenced the former treasurer of the governing Democrat Party to four years and 10 months in prison and fined him 200 million rupiah for bribery, in the first of several verdicts in a case that has riveted the nation and shaken the party of President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono.

title: Guard at the Met Wounded When Gun Goes Off
description: Shortly before 3 p.m., a single shot rang out at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Porsches Know-It-All 911
description: Computers mediate nearly all of the 911 Carrera S driving experience, but it still delivers unparalleled immediacy in its reflexes while retaining a supple ride for everyday use.

title: US Airways Strikes Deal With AMRs Unions
description: In an unusual move that could prefigure a serious bid for its bankrupt rival, US Airways said it had reached an agreement with the three main labor unions at American Airlines to support a merger, Jad Mouawad of The New York Times reports. Read more

title: 911: Brainpower to Match the Brawn
description: SANTA MARIA, Calif.

title: Nostalgia for the Lada: Cold War, Toasty Heater
description: HELSINKI, Finland

title: A Russian Porsche by Way of Finland?
description: WHILE the Finns welcome Russian investment, like the decision to build the Marussia B2 sports car here, no one expects it to become a big seller in Finland.

title: A Golf With Exceptional Grip
description: TESTED 2012 Volkswagen Golf R

title: Pictures of the Day: South Sudan and Elsewhere
description: Photos from South Sudan, Egypt, Pakistan and New York.

title: Documentary Filmmaker Wins Against I.R.S., Which Saw Her as a Hobbyist
description: LOS ANGELES  Documentary filmmakers can breathe a sigh of relief, knowing that the producer and director Lee Storey on Thursday won her case against the Commissioner of Internal Revenue in the United States Tax Court.

title: At No. 5 in Womens Lacrosse, Is Maryland Under the Radar?
description: The No. 5 Maryland womens lacrosse team, as it seemingly always has done, has had a successful season, losing just three games and heading into the A.C.C. tournament this weekend with eight wins in its last nine games. But rewind two and a half months in College Park, and this is probably not where the Terrapins expected to be.

title: The DVR Log Jam
description: April 20, 2012  If are you having a hard time deciding what to watch on TV Sunday night, youre not alone.

title: A Push to Make Motors With Fewer Rare Earths
description: FOR much of the last century, the straightforward solution to making a car perform better has been to install a bigger engine. In the hybrids and electric cars of coming years, however, the answer might be installing motors with more powerful magnets.

title: Just 10 Looks | The Best of Bridal
description: These days, a walk down the aisle can seem more like a walk down a runway. White wedding gowns are still the norm, but brides can also opt for crimson, sapphire and blush. There are also pretty prints to choose from. Here, 10 of our favorite styles from the fall bridal collections.

title: Obama Holds Fund-Raising Edge Over Romney
description: 4:40 p.m. | Updated  President Obama raised about $35 million in March, according to reports filed with the Federal Election Commission on Friday, leaving him with more than $104 million in the bank as he prepares to square off against Mitt Romney, the likely Republican nominee, in the general election campaign.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, April 20
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Adjusting a Waistline for a Wedding, but at What Cost?
description: A Field Notes column last Sunday (Bridal Hunger Games) reported on some diets that brides use to drop 15 or 20 pounds before their weddings: Weight Watchers and a personal fitness trainer, juice cleanses, the Dukan diet, diet pills, hormone shots and, new to the United States, a feeding tube diet.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: An Upper West Side co-op, a Douglaston colonial, a Clinton Hill condo and an East Village duplex.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A four-bedroom town-house condo with terraces and ocean views, steps from the beach in Long Beach, N.Y.

title: Lada Love
description: With his collection of Ladas, Risto Nykanen hopes to keep alive the memory of the boxy Soviet automobiles that were once the family car of Finland.

title: Carr and Stelter on Embarrassment of TV Riches Sunday Night
description: David Carr and Brian Stelter discuss how Sunday night has become jammed with the most prestigious shows of the week, whether on cable or network TV, including The Good Wife on CBS; Nurse Jackie on Showtime; Girls on HBO; Mad Men and The Killing on AMC. Some are complaining that their DVRs cant keep up with the offerings.

title: Syria Protests Cite Observers and a Truce as Faltering
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Demonstrations erupted across Syria on Friday, with some of the protesters anger focused on United Nations observers, who have decided that they will not circulate on Fridays, the normal day for mass rallies that are suppressed by the government. Despite an ostensible cease-fire, violence flared across the country, with a roadside bomb killing 10 soldiers in the south, according to the state-run news, while YouTube videos posted from the devastated city of Homs showed flames and intense black smoke after government shelling of a downtown residential neighborhood.

title: John Fort's Journey to Russia
description: The Fugees musician documents his nine-week trip to Russia.

title: The Person, Not the Alzheimers
description: A new book and photo exhibit portray efforts around the world to help Alzheimers patients connect with the outside world by focusing on their individual traits and histories.

title: Before the Cast Takes the Stage, the Crowd Is on Its Feet
description: At the Ailey Citigroup Theater on Wednesday night, the standing ovation came before the show started. Robert Battle, the artistic director of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, commanded the audience to rise, but the ovation would have happened anyway. After 38 years as artistic director of Ailey II, the organizations second company, Sylvia Waters was stepping down. To honor her, the least you could do was stand up.

title: Photo Replay: April 20
description: A look at the day in sports, from the field at Fenway Park to the open water.

title: Watching Every Click You Make
description: WHEN you write a post on Facebook about your sudden craving for blue cheese, an advertisement for gout prevention might suddenly pop up on your page. Post the phrase bacon tidbits, and you might get an ad for a book called Forbidden Lessons in a Kabul Guesthouse.

title: Infrastructure Spending Yields Results
description: I dont usually do personal-anecdote analysis, but a quick thought here.

title: One on One: Lane Becker, Author of Get Lucky
description: Lane Becker, above left, is the co-founder of Get Satisfaction, an online customer service community platform, and the co-founder of Adaptive Path, which claims to be one of the worlds first user experience design firms. Mr. Becker has co-written a book titled Get Lucky with Thor Muller, above right, also a co-founder of Get Satisfaction. The book, as Mr. Becker describes it, is a manual for serendipity in the digital age. Below is an edited interview.

title: Income of the Elderly
description: In response to this post, some readers asked for data on the income of the elderly. Heres the Social Security Administration source. If you look at Table 9B6 youll see (left column) that 55 percent of the elderly get more than half their income from Social Security; 33 percent get more than 80 percent of their income from that source.

title: Gaming Meets Giving
description: Carol Roth, business analyst, evaluates an investor pitch from a small business.

title: The Science of the Search for the Boy on the Milk Carton
description: Upon the discovery of buried human remains, forensic archaeologists and anthropologists typically keep digging in a circle around them, in effect creating, beneath the bones, an elevated section of dirt.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, April 20
description: More Photographs

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Drone Lists and iPhone Rumors
description: Here are some of the most interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Friday. There are more here.

title: Is It Ethical to Eat Meat? You Be the Judge
description: With a clap of thunder and a puff of smoke, the Ethicist columns first-ever essay contest ended on April 8. Then slowly the smoke drifted away, and we beheld the results. They were astonishing.

title: With This Mussel Sauce, One Spoonful Leads to the Next
description: THERE are some recipes that are all about showcasing the main ingredient, honoring that pristine piece of fish or dry-aged steak with a sprinkle of salt and pepper and nothing more.

title: How to De-Beard Mussels
description: Farmed mussels are fine to use in this weeks recipe, spicy coconut mussels with lemon grass, above. If you are lucky enough to get your hands on some wild mussels (which are generally more intensely flavored than the farmed kind), you might have to de-beard them. Its not hard but it does mean sorting through them one by one.

title: Chic in Review | Dont Mess With La Lohan
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Police Examine Death of Man Who Was Hit by Patrol Car
description: The Police Department is investigating the death of a man who was struck by a police car after a chase in the Brooklyn housing project where he lived.

title: Stardom and Middle Age
description: Ingrid is the interesting one. She begins as a trophy-wife type with a French twist, goes through an entertaining Patsy Stone of Ab Fab phase and ends up as Janis Joplin.

title: Video: On Crostini, or a Spoon
description: A few weeks ago, I demonstrated how to make fresh ricotta. This weeks video gives some ideas on how to use it. And of course, you can always use it to fill a calzone or two.

title: The Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: Argentina announces it will nationalize YPF, Jim Yong Kim is named president of the World Bank and Citigroup shareholders rebuff a pay package for the companys chief executive.

title: Kyle Larsen Voted Into Hall of Fame
description: Only one player was voted by his peers into the American Contract Bridge Leagues Hall of Fame this year: Kyle Larsen of San Francisco.

title: Bill Would Expand Insurance for Crops
description: For decades, farmers have been able to receive government money for not growing crops.

title: A Break From Romanticism With Some Mozart
description: The pianist Garrick Ohlsson has been demonstrating his credentials as a Romantic powerhouse this season, with arresting performances of Liszt in honor of that composers bicentennial. He gave a Liszt recital at the 92nd Street Y in January and will perform a variation on that recital at Carnegie Hall on April 29.

title: G.O.P. National Committee Warmly Embraces Romney
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  If any crowd would be expected to noisily receive Mitt Romney, it is the 50 leaders of the state Republican Parties  stalwarts careful not to make an endorsement during the primary season, but whose every fiber is tied to the success of the nominee.

title: Whats It Like Having Power? How Would I Know?
description: Veep, HBOs new comedy starring Julia Louis-Dreyfus as vice president of the United States, has an awful lot of cursing in it. Too much, perhaps: if you fear the de-electrification and eventual domestication of swear words, you may feel that Veep takes us a little farther down that road. On the other hand, political people do swear. They have to, for their mental health. Todays public servant is gaffe-phobic, linguistically constipated, mortgaged in spirit to this lobby or that. He must speak  when on display  in ceaseless, toneless platitudes. Then the heavy door closes, with the press and the people on the other side of it, and the air splinters with profanity.

title: Benjamin Dickinson on 'First Winter'
description: Benjamin Dickinson, the director of "First Winter," discusses his film about a group of friends who become stranded while on a yoga retreat.

title: Young Pianist at Home in the Past and the Present
description: Some young performers specialize in contemporary music because they think it is important to do so or to acquire a hip professional profile. The best reason to play new music is because it fascinates you. The Chinese-born, 28-year-old American pianist Jenny Q Chai demonstrated true affinity for contemporary music throughout the challenging program she played on Thursday night at Zankel Hall.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,924 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: Top Score Isnt Enough for Preschooler Seeking Seat in Prime Gifted Programs
Front and Back Rooms, Surprises on the Side
description: TRATTORIA Vivolo, run by the affable Dean Vivolo, is one of the weirdest-looking restaurants around. The distinctive shiny chrome diner, which is the restaurants front room, is a vestige of another age, before such eateries morphed into the behemoths built today. The surprising view from the sparkly back dining room is of a huge mural painted on the side of a nearby building. The picture of a sunny oceanfront seen through a few birch trees will make most customers smile, as will the restaurants other incongruities.

title: New Meters for the Rhymin of Simon
description: Transformations, extrapolations and a few collisions were on the program when Paul Simon performed with the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra on Thursday night at the Rose Theater, part of a three-night fund-raising series. (With tickets costing hundreds of dollars, perhaps it was no coincidence that the first words Mr. Simon sang were Shes a rich girl, from Diamonds on the Soles of Her Shoes.)

title: State Scraps Pineapple Test Question
What Were Reading Now
description: Anyone could have predicted this: House Republicans are seeking to slash food stamp funding in order to preserve Pentagon spending. Wow. No kidding. Lets kill poor people in other countries instead of feeding people here? What a concept! Almost makes me want to not write about anything else.

title: Tribeca: In First Winter the Power Goes Out, so the Director Uses Candles
description: In the drama First Winter, playing at the Tribeca Film Festival on Friday night, with more screenings next week, a group of Brooklynites seek solace on a yoga retreat. They get more peacefulness than they bargained for when a catastrophic event leaves them without power and dwindling resources. The critic Stephen Holden singled out the film in his look at the festivals 11th edition. The first feature from the director Benjamin Dickinson, First Winter was shot on 16-millimeter film and uses only natural lighting (including cheap candles from Ikea). The spare narrative is mirrored in the filmmaking style, and in this video, Mr. Dickinson explains the methods he used to create the mood.

title: Just Try to Believe: Life Will Get Better
description: The very fact of living feels strangely tenuous for the restless souls of Chekhovs Three Sisters. The distant future and recollections of a happier past are forever tugging them away from thoughts of the present, lending the characters an almost ethereal quality. Even a seemingly inarguable event like the breaking of a clock seems to hint at an existential mystery.

title: When the Supermarket Is a Mile Away
description: To the Editor:

title: Fox Network at 25: Blazing Trails and Burning Bridges
description: In April 1987 the Fox Broadcasting Company opened for business in prime time with two half-hour comedies, Married ... With Children and The Tracey Ullman Show.

title: A Film Settles Accounts From the 60s
description: Booker Wright, a black waiter in a whites-only restaurant in Greenwood, Miss., neither protested nor preached as the civil rights movement of the 1960s roiled the Delta. But the film Bookers Place: A Mississippi Story, scheduled to premiere on Sunday at the Tribeca Film Festival, portrays him as one of the small heroes of that grand movement.

title: The Local Approach, Applied to Seafood
description: ONLY a gutsy and independent chef would name a restaurant after a mollusk better known in Europe than here, as Bill Taibe has done with his new place, the Whelk in Westport. But, as he said in a telephone interview, I enjoy sharing my knowledge about food with others. Calling the new place Le Mer, as a bookend to his other Westport restaurant, Le Farm, would have been, in his words, too obvious, like hanging lifesavers or anchors on the walls.

title: A Fenway Park Celebration Ends When the Yankees Step on the Field
description: BOSTON  In what was surely the largest number of Red Sox ever assembled, 212 former players gathered Friday afternoon to help 36,770 fans celebrate the 100th anniversary of Fenway Park. But, as has often happened here, 25 Yankees spoiled the party.

title: Bettman Supports Shanahan and Defends Leagues Safety Record
description: With the first round of the playoffs attracting attention for fighting, illegal hits and suspensions, N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman said Brendan Shanahan was doing a very, very good job in his role as the leagues disciplinarian.

title: A Lifelong Catholic Pays Tribute to the Nuns
description: To the Editor:

title: What Are the Effects of Raising the Minimum Wage?
description: To the Editor:

title: Journalism in Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: The Week in Pictures for April 20
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include national chess champions from a school in Brooklyn, the Intrepids preparations for the arrival of the space shuttles prototype, and the resumption of the search for Etan Patz.

title: Afghan Youth Orchestra Plans to Visit the U.S.
description: One of the best-known facts about music in Afghanistan, at least in the West, is that it wasnt. The Taliban banned it when they took power in 1996, beating musicians, burning instruments and destroying cassette tapes in the name of their severe and extreme vision of Islam.

title: A Visit to Beirut
description: To the Editor:

title: Attention Expats: Singapore Is Better Than Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG  Singapore and Hong Kong are engaged in a constant battle: which, oh which, is the more important Asian financial center? And which is more capable of attracting the top-quality workers that are needed to run the trading floors, logistics operations and universities that make both cities global players?

title: A Prominent Bankruptcy Lawyer Now Ministers to His Firm
description: Over the last several decades, Martin J. Bienenstock has established himself as one of Americas most prominent bankruptcy lawyers, advising General Motors and Enron. Now, he faces perhaps the most challenging assignment of his career: the restructuring of his own law firm.

title: Beijing Auto Show Preview: Lamborghini Urus Concept Hints at Hyper-S.U.V.
description: 8:05 a.m. | Updated

title: Gingrich Wont Leave Race, or Costly Secret Service Protection
description: As long as Newt Gingrich stays in the presidential race, he is still receiving Secret Service protection  at a cost of more than $40,000 a day.

title: Reviewing the Porsche 911 Carrera S
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, John Pearley Huffman reviews the Porsche 911 Carrera S, the heightened-horsepower specification of the 911, which underwent a major refresh for the 2012 model year.

title: Deporting Parents Hurts Kids
description: LAST May, President Obama told an audience in El Paso that deportation of immigrants would focus on violent offenders and people convicted of crimes; not families, not folks who are just looking to scrape together an income.

title: French Media Question Election Reporting Rules
description: PARIS  After months of noisy campaigning in the presidential race  rousing the crowds, pressing flesh, inundating Twitter  Frances politicians and pollsters fell silent at midnight Friday, by law.

title: Quirky Buccaneers With Feet of Clay
description: COMPUTER graphics may dominate animation features today, but some filmmakers are not ready to abandon more traditional techniques, even as those styles have gotten a dimensional makeover. Henry Selick breathed new life into stop motion with the first such feature to be released in 3-D, Coraline (2009). This year four more artisans will revisit 3-D stop-motion: Chris Butler and Sam Fell this summer with ParaNorman; Tim Burton, in the fall with Frankenweenie; and Peter Lord, a founder of the British animation company Aardman whose Pirates! Band of Misfits opens Friday.

title: Forced to Retire at 22
description: SHOREVIEW, Minn.  The enlarged cutout on the wall of the PINnacle Wrestling School, in an industrial park here north of Minneapolis, shows Jake Deitchlers finest moment in Greco-Roman wrestling. On his knees with fists clenched, Deitchler screams with joy after winning the 2008 Olympic trials at 146 pounds, making him the first high school wrestler in 32 years to qualify for the United States team.

title: Robust, Italian and Out to Charm
description: RESTAURANTS like Sacramones are what have made Italian cuisine the Islands favorite: places where the owners extend a warm welcome, and the food is robust, abundant and reasonably priced.

title: Bahrains Formula One Gala Not Going as Planned
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  The Sunni monarchy has been hoping that the Formula One Grand Prix, its showcase annual event, would restore Bahrains stature as a stable Persian Gulf kingdom, blighted after months of antigovernment protests by the Shiite majority that led to the cancellation of the race last year.

title: From a Charcoal Pit, a Slice of Portugal
description: THERE are plenty of ethnic restaurants in Hoboken  Indian, Malaysian, Cuban, take your pick  but as best I can determine, only a single Portuguese establishment.

title: Hillman Curtis, a Pioneer in Web Design, Dies at 51
description: Hillman Curtis, a former rock musician who became a prominent first-generation Web designer and a visionary figure in the Internets evolution from a predominantly text-based medium to the multimedia platform it is today, died on Wednesday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 51.

title: Amid Proxy Fight, Canadian Pacific Profit Rises
description: The Canadian Pacific Railway reported Friday that it had a first-quarter profit of 142 million Canadian dollars, a 318 percent increase from the same period a year before. But it was unclear if the results would undermine a proxy campaign for control of the railway led by William A. Ackman, the hedge fund manager, who is seeking to replace most of the railways directors and its senior management through a vote at its annual meeting next month. Fred Green, the chief executive of Canadian Pacific, said the quarterly results were an endorsement of the railways management and their operational plans.

title: Space Shuttle Will Be Late to New York
description: The countdown clock for the arrival of New York Citys first space shuttle will have to be reset.

title: Prime Spot
description: AMONG the more than 300 guests who attended the March 14 state dinner for David Cameron, the British prime minister, were a chosen few: the 19 people who got to sit at the head table with the president and the first lady.

title: Sudan Says Military Evicts Souths Army From Oil Area
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan  Sudan claimed Friday that its military had been victorious in forcing South Sudanese soldiers to pull out of a contested oil region as tensions between the two African neighbors remained high.

title: For Earth Day, a Film Created by the Whole World
The Holiday for Fans of Liberalized Marijuana Laws
description: Despite a buzz-killing backdrop of federal raids and local crackdowns, marijuana fans celebrated their high holiday on Friday in all the traditional ways: smoking, speaking out and  no doubt  snacking.

title: A Bahraini Activist Explains the Standoff Over Formula One
description: Thousands of opposition protesters marched in Bahrains capital on Friday, to protest the kingdoms decision to go ahead with the Formula One Grand Prix this weekend, despite a crackdown on dissent in the country and a hunger strike by a jailed rights activist.

title: Bewitched (Before Samantha)
description: John van Drutens Bell, Book and Candle  or at least the sassy, stylish production now at Hartford Stage  could bring back wall-to-wall carpeting.

title: Teddy Charles, Jazz Musician Turned Sea Captain, Dies at 84
description: Teddy Charles, a gifted vibraphonist who teamed up with many of the musicians who revolutionized jazz in the 1940s and 50s and then literally sailed away to become a sea captain, died on Monday in Riverhead, N.Y. He was 84.

title: Scholars Pay Homage to Mets, 50 Years On
description: During his nearly 79 years, Ed Charles, also known as The Glider, has gone from playing baseball in the segregated Deep South to having a pivotal role as a Mets third baseman in the 1969 World Series to reciting his poetry on television. Some of lifes quirky turns have surprised him more than others, he said, but he never thought he would be sitting around with a bunch of Ph.D.s talking about his beloved Mets.

title: In a Rowdy Democracy, a Dictators Daughter With an Unsoiled Aura
description: GONGJU, South Korea

title: Wall St. Protesters Lying on Sidewalk Are Arrested
description: The police arrested a group of Occupy Wall Street protesters who were lying on a sidewalk at the corner of Wall Street and Broad Street on Friday afternoon after one demonstrator announced that the law allowed them to do so as a form of political protest.

title: They Dressed Like Groucho
description: You could say, with partial plagiarism: It was the best of nights. It was the worst of nights.

title: Bank of America Accord in Lawsuit Is Challenged
description: Lawyers leading a class-action lawsuit in federal court in Manhattan against the directors of Bank of America over its purchase of Merrill Lynch have agreed to settle the matter for $20 million even though damages in the case could reach $5 billion, according to plaintiffs in a parallel suit against the banks board in Delaware.

title: Martin Poll Dies at 89; Built a Movie Studio in New York
description: Martin Poll, who helped revitalize film production in New York in the 1950s and 60s and later made his name in Hollywood, producing films like the Oscar-winning historical drama The Lion in Winter, died in Manhattan on April 14. He was 89.

title: Bill Cunningham | Upsize
description: On the fashion scene, theres a new interest in the carryall bag. Devoid of hardware, it relies on the simplicity of design and craftsmanship.

title: Voting for Yesterday in France
description: Paris

title: A Familiar Spectacle, With High Wattage
description: Is it those dancing feet, those bright costumes or those high-wattage smiles that dazzle the audience most in the first scene of the John W. Engeman Theaters production of 42nd Street? It is hard to decide, and it doesnt really matter, because they blend into one terrific opening number, which turns out to be a harbinger of an altogether enjoyable show.

title: Suspected Sale by China Stirs Concern at White House
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration says it believes that a Chinese manufacturer sold North Korea the chassis and other parts for a missile-transport vehicle displayed in a military parade this week, a senior official said Friday, raising new concerns about Chinas ability to enforce a ban on military sales to North Korea.

title: The Voice of Authority
description: It was Nov. 25, 1963, three days after the Kennedy assassination, and the powerful columnist was calling the neophyte president. Already, Joseph Alsop had penned a personal letter to Lyndon Johnson offering his support. The phone call was an attempt to offer something more: advice.

title: Obama Sees Steep Dropoff in Cash From Major Donors
description: President Obamas re-election campaign is straining to raise the huge sums it is counting on to run against Mitt Romney, with sharp dropoffs in donations from nearly every major industry forcing it to rely more than ever on small contributions and a relative handful of major donors.

title: Profit Quadruples for Canadian Pacific Railway
description: OTTAWA  The Canadian Pacific Railway reported Friday that it had a first-quarter profit of 142 million Canadian dollars, a 318 percent increase from the same period a year before. But it was unclear if the railways favorable results would undermine a proxy campaign for its control led by William A. Ackman, the hedge fund manager.

title: Search for Boys Body Returns to Cellar That Looked Uneven Decades Earlier
description: Investigators looking into the disappearance of Etan Patz began focusing recently on a handyman after a review of old case files showed that a concrete floor in a building in SoHo where he once had a workshop  and that was on the route Etan took when he disappeared  had looked uneven or was not all the same color, a person briefed on the case said on Friday.

title: Among His Duties, Choosing the Guests
description: A look at the more than 800 people who have accepted invitations to state dinners, in some cases more than once.

title: Assads Lies
description: The United Nations Security Council gave Syrias president, Bashar al-Assad, a chance to end the killing and avoid complete chaos with a plan that called for a cease-fire, a withdrawal of troops from embattled cities and a political transition. It is deplorable  but no surprise  that he reneged on nearly every promise.

title: In Venezuela, a Shortage of Staples
description: Venezuela is one of the worlds top oil producers, but shortages of staples are a chronic part of life.

title: With Venezuelan Food Shortages, Some Blame Price Controls
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  By 6:30 a.m., a full hour and a half before the store would open, about two dozen people were already in line. They waited patiently, not for the latest iPhone, but for something far more basic: groceries.

title: Before Hosting Bandstand, Growing Up in a City With a Complicated Story
description: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y.  The picture in the 1947 A. B. Davis High School Yearbook seems to tell a familiar story.

title: White Gloves Not Needed
description: WASHINGTON

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 20, 2012

title: The Global Economy at Risk
description: Anxieties about Europe dominated this weeks meetings in Washington of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank. Fund officials warned that the euro-zone crisis poses a grave danger to a weak global economy. Europes leaders, masters of denial, are still insisting on destructive austerity.

title: A Film Festival Debut With a Local Twist
description: THOM POWERS, co-director with his wife, Raphaela Neihausen, of the Montclair Film Festival  to be held May 1 to 6  said that putting together the towns first cinematic extravaganza had been a wholly immersive thing since they signed on in November.

title: Mismapping the Peninsula
description: Gen. George B. McClellans amphibious invasion of the Virginia Peninsula in March and April 1862 involved one of the great logistical achievements of the Civil War. By April 2 he had amassed 58,000 men, 15,000 horses and mules, 1,100 wagons and 44 batteries, along with extensive supplies and telegraph wire  and more troops were on the way.

title: Corrections: April 21
description: FRONT PAGE

title: The Lyric Little Bandbox Turns 100
description: Home runs come in various guises and sizes. But it is beyond dispute that the most magnificent home runs in baseball are hit at Fenway Park. More specifically, to left field in Fenway Park. So magnificent are they, in fact, that if youre really being fair about it, it doesnt matter who hits them. Even, as on Friday, Alex Rodriguez and Nick Swisher and Russell Martin did.

title: A Love Story, Past and Present
description: The Last Five Years, by Jason Robert Brown, which Crossroads Theater Company is presenting in New Brunswick, is a two-character musical. It could be said, though, that the third character is time.

title: Justice Under North Carolinas Racial Bias Law
description: Marcus Robinson, who has been on death row in North Carolina since 1994, was the first person to challenge a death sentence under the states 2009 Racial Justice Act. That law is the nations first to give inmates the chance to have their sentences reduced to life without parole based on proof that racial bias played a significant role in their case.

title: Restrained Youths Death in Yonkers Is Investigated
description: The police and state officials are examining a surveillance video that recorded the death of a 16-year-old boy at a private residential treatment center in Yonkers this week as staff members physically restrained him on the floor after a basketball game.

title: A Healthy Breakfast
description: When it comes to making certain that children start the school day with a good breakfast, New York City could learn a lot from Newark, Detroit and Los Angeles. Administrators there are helping children in need  10 million in the country  get a healthy breakfast at their desks.

title: Stirring Memories of Better Times
description: BOSTON

title: Friday Night Music: Leonard Cohen
description: A bit of beauty to end the week. Original:

title: When Pineapple Races Hare, Students Lose, Critics of Standardized Tests Say
description: A reading passage included this week in one of New Yorks standardized English tests has become the talk of the eighth grade, with students walking around saying, Pineapples dont have sleeves, as if it were the code for admission to a secret society.

title: Events Marked by Large Streamers
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Just what a Saturday puzzle should be, if not a tad on the easy side. I didnt have to turn my brain inside out for every single answer, which kept me on the hook just enough to finish Barry C. Silks puzzle.

title: F.B.I. Investigation Into Representative Don Young
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation released documents relating to a criminal investigation it conducted into Representative Don Young, Republican of Alaska, and a 2005 budget appropriation he helped secure for a highway project.

title: In Figure and Form, Sculpture All Around
description: WHITE PLAINS  Entering Sculpture: On and Off the Wall, the group exhibition that fills both floors of ArtsWestchesters Arts Exchange, you first encounter Emil Alzamoras Spaceman, an all-white ceramic astronaut the size of a toddler mounted just above eye level. Arms reaching back, knees bent upward, helmeted head facing down, the figure might be hurtling through space, were its back not firmly anchored to the gallery wall.

title: Alaska Lawmaker Put Campaign Money to Personal Use, Ex-Aide Told Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Don Young and his family routinely used campaign funds for personal expenses, like hunting trips, meals and charter flights to his home in Alaska, a former campaign aide to Mr. Young told federal criminal investigators.

title: Guillen Is the Marlins Gift to Cable TV
description: The Miami Marlins are, for obvious reasons, an ideal team to follow in the Showtime series The Franchise this season. They have shed the Florida part of their name and redesigned their uniform. They escaped a football stadium for a colorful new home, Marlins Park. Jeffrey Loria, the owner, hired a new manager, Ozzie Guillen, and added Jose Reyes, Mark Buehrle, Heath Bell and Carlos Zambrano to the roster.

title: Blood, Sweat and Illicit Bets
description: For more than a year, Devin Yalkin has photographed unsanctioned underground boxing matches in Chinatown in all their sweaty, bleary glory.

title: The Bachelor Vote
description: Even if you like Barack Obama, we cant afford Barack Obama.

title: Rangers Boyle Does Everything Bigger
description: HINGHAM, Mass.  Brian Boyle was always the biggest one, whether at St. Paul Elementary School in the center of town or on the ice of the nearby Pilgrim Skating Arena, where he first learned to skate at age 3.

title: Devils Kovalchuk Trying to Make Up for Lost Time
description: NEWARK  Ilya Kovalchuk worked out Friday instead of practicing with the Devils. With Game 5 of their Stanley Cup playoff series against Florida set for Saturday, Kovalchuk seemed to appreciate a day off his skates, even if he did not really need one.

title: Israeli Desert Yields a Harvest of Energy
description: KETURA, Israel  Arriving at this bone-dry kibbutz in the Arava Desert late one afternoon in August 2006, Yosef Abramowitz, a social activist, Jewish educator and multimedia entrepreneur from Boston, opened the door of his van and was hit by a wall of heat.

title: Looking to Move Up, Knicks Fail to Capitalize in Cleveland
description: CLEVELAND  Carmelo Anthony looked claustrophobic while playing with another post player on the court. Amare Stoudemire missed three free throws, had a shot blocked and looked lost. The Knicks shot 1 of 7 from the floor, and looked sluggish; they were outrebounded, 9-4, by a frontcourt pairing of Antawn Jamison and the rookie Tristan Thompson.

title: Romney Set to Merge Staff With National Committee
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  Mitt Romneys top aides plan to move quickly after the primaries on Tuesday to integrate the campaigns growing staff with the Republican National Committee, in an effort to avoid logistical stumbles that have hampered past nominees, campaign aides and committee officials said Friday.

title: Fire Kills Two and Injures Four Others in Upper Manhattan
description: A woman and her husband were killed after a fire broke out on Friday in a second-floor apartment in Upper Manhattan, the authorities said.

title: Putting Meditation Back on the Mat
description: SEATED cross-legged on a black cushion atop a yoga mat, I struggled to keep my eyes closed and repeat the Sanskrit mantra in my head: ham-sa  I am that. Outside, on Third Avenue, police sirens wailed and cars honked as I tried to sit still in a room with eight other meditation students, keeping my breath slow and steady. Just as I was about to lose the focus on my breath, a soothing voice nearby chimed in: You can hear the noises without getting attached to them. The attention comes from the inside.

title: Obama 2012 vs. Obama 2008
description: The Obama campaign is lagging behind its fund-raising pace of four years ago.

title: Gone, Not Forgotten
description: DECADES can dull the shock and ease the sting of even a great tragedy. But, as New Yorkers learned this past week, some horrors never lose their grip.

title: Post Offices Face Hurdles in Efforts to Diversify
description: WASHINGTON  Well before online bill paying was popular, the Postal Service in 2000 began operating a secure system that would have allowed it to remain the primary conduit for most Americans monthly payments. But the Internet industry objected, and Congress successfully pressured the Postal Service to abandon it.

title: No Contract Negotiations for the Hot-Hitting Wright
description: David Wright, who entered the Mets series opener against the San Francisco Giants on Friday with baseballs highest batting average, said before the game that there had been no discussions with the front office this season about his contract.

title: Kazakhstan: Reporter Attacked
description: Five men attacked a journalist, Lukpan Akhmedyarov, near his home in Uralsk late Thursday, stabbing him eight times, his editor said Friday. Mr. Akhmedyarov had recently received threats warning him to halt his involvement in organizing antigovernment protests, said Tamara Yeslyamova, the editor of Uralskaya Nedelya, the newspaper where Mr. Akhmedyarov worked as a reporter. Doctors said he was expected to survive. Such attacks are not uncommon in Kazakhstan, an authoritarian former Soviet republic where journalists critical of the government are rarely tolerated. The Committee to Protect Journalists, based in New York, condemned the attack. The police have opened an investigation, local media outlets reported.

title: Britain: Media Scandal Fuels Lawsuits
description: Rupert Murdochs British newspaper group faces dozens of new lawsuits, a court was told Friday, as the phone-hacking scandal continues. A lawyer for several of the claimants, Hugh Tomlinson, said 44 new cases had been filed. British news reports indicated that two further claims had also been made. The cases include claims by Cherie Blair, the wife of former Prime Minister Tony Blair; the soccer player Wayne Rooney; and Ted Beckham, the father of the soccer player David Beckham. Mr. Murdoch has already settled dozens of claims alleging illegal interception of voice mail messages by his reporters. A spokeswoman for News International, Mr. Murdochs British newspaper group, declined to comment.

title: Italy: Berlusconi Defends Burlesque
description: Former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi made a surprise appearance on Friday at a court in Milan where he is on trial on charges of abuse of power and paying for sex with an underage nightclub dancer. Speaking to reporters during a break in the trial, Mr. Berlusconi said that nothing untoward ever took place in his homes and that the dinners he hosted were elegant and proper. Responding to allegations by witnesses that women at the dinners, dressed as police officers and nuns, carried out stripteases, he explained that his guests were merely practicing for burlesque competitions. He added: Women are exhibitionist by nature. And if they are in show business, they like to put on shows.

title: Tending a Bar Between the Tracks
description: WITH 33 years on the job, Tim Myles, 61, is the senior man on the Long Island Rail Roads staff of 11 bar-cart attendants who work Pennsylvania Stations platforms. Mr. Myless regular spot is on the platform between Tracks 20 and 21, at the bottom of the busiest staircase to the tracks, where he serves more than 20 departing trains a shift.

title: The Hare and the Pineapple Question
description: A controversial  some say confusing  reading passage included this week in one of New Yorks standardized English tests became the talk of the eighth grade.

title: Mets Pitching Rebounds, but Hitters Fail to Deliver
description: After poor starts from Johan Santana and R. A. Dickey, the Mets were in dire need of a remedy for their sudden epidemic of subpar pitching.

title: Concern in G.O.P. Over State Focus on Social Issues
description: Fiscal issues and union rights were front and center in many Republican-controlled legislatures last year. But this year, with the nation heading into the heart of a presidential race and voters consumed by the countrys economic woes, much of the debate in statehouses has centered on social issues.

title: Keeping Body and Image in Shape
description: When the N.B.A. Hall of Famer  Walt Frazier, the loquacious Knicks analyst on the MSG network, is not on the road with the playoff-bound team, which he led to its first N.B.A. championship in 1970, the focal point of his Sundays is his bedroom. There Mr. Frazier, a k a Clyde, multitasks by exercising in bed, napping or surfing the cable channels. When he does go out, he works in a stop at  Clyde Fraziers Wine and Dine, the restaurant in Hells Kitchen where he is a partner, acting as host and in-house celebrity. Mr. Frazier, 67, lives in a condo in West Harlem with his son, Walt III, 45, a forest of foliage (he is a plant freak) and 200 flamboyant suits. He also owns a bed-and-breakfast on St. Croix.

title: Red Storm Lose a Coach to Michigan
description: Kim Barnes Arico led St. Johns to four N.C.A.A. tournament appearances during a 10-year transformation of a womens basketball program that was winless the Big East season before she took over. Now she will try to realign the expectations at Michigan.

title: An Excerpt From Central Park: An Anthology
description: From Framed in Silver, by Mark Helprin, in Central Park: An Anthology:

title: Looking at New York as a Target
description: WHAT happened in Manhattan on Sept. 11, 2001, was a stunning wake-up call. But in New York at War: Four Centuries of Combat, Fear and Intrigue in Gotham (Basic Books, $29.99), the historian Steven H. Jaffe skillfully reminds readers that the city had been a tempting target before, that it suffered casualties in earlier conflicts and that other generations of officials worried about immigrants with dual loyalties and about balancing New Yorkers security and their civil liberties.

title: Gardners Olympic Bid Stalls
description: Rulon Gardners effort to win a third Olympic medal in Greco-Roman wrestling at age 40 ended when he did not appear for a weigh-in at the Olympic trials in Iowa City, Iowa. Gardner won a gold medal at the 2000 Sydney Olympics and a bronze in Athens in 2004, but has since struggled with his weight. He ballooned to as much as 474 pounds before appearing last year on the television program The Biggest Loser.

title: No City for Old Tankers
description: AN empty oil tanker makes a forlorn setting for a ghost story, and at Pier 9B in Red Hook, Brooklyn, the other day, the winds of April wailed a haunting accompaniment to a tale of maritime woe. Inside the tanker, the Mary A. Whalen, Carolina Salguero raised her raspy Brooklyn voice above the clang of iron chairs being blown over on the deck.

title: The Secret Life of a Society Maven
description: THERE are certain stories that begin in earnest only when they seem to reach an end. It turns out, I wrote one last year.

title: A Facial Theory of Politics
description: HOW important is a political candidates appearance?

title: League Plans New H.G.H. Study
description: The N.F.L. has agreed to perform a population study to determine if the level of human growth hormone that triggers a positive test should be higher for its players.

title: The New Shades of Feminism?
