description: For many women, there are certain cultural critics who are like heat waves. Their polemical expeditions are forgettable between occurrences but stultifying in the instance and show no signs of letting up. They veer toward the specious, speculative art of the trend story. Sex, gender and domestic habit make up their range of interest, and whenever a relevant cultural sensation comes along, they can be counted on to tell us why were all worked up.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: Comedy

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: Unidentified gunmen shot dead a police officer on Friday in the heart of Srinagar, Kashmir Live reported. The attack comes just a few days after  an announcement by Chief Minister Omar Abdullah to remove security bunkers from Srinagar city in the following months. (Hindustan Times)

title: Half a World Away, a Familiar Name
description: A lot of people know about Syd Greenberg in China. Mind you, he hadnt been back there since the mid-1940s, when he was an Army Signal Corps photographer assigned to the China-Burma-India theater of operations, documenting how American and Chinese Nationalist troops fought the Japanese.

title: The Weekend Word: Cash
description: Todays Times

title: Russell Wilson, 4th-Ranked Quarterback in 2012 Draft
description: Matt Waldman is the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, a testament to his obsession with film analysis, now available for download. Examples of his work can be found at his blog. He is helping The Fifth Down rank skill position players before the draft:

title: This Sunday: The Keys to Intelligence, Happiness and Mental Health
description: Watch a video of Hugo Lindgren introducing the magazines special health issue.

title: Counting on Votes From Paris-on-Thames
description: LONDON  In the campaign for the first round of Frances presidential election on Sunday, the main candidates have not forgotten the voters of Paris-on-Thames.

title: Much Ado About Zero (Wonkish)
description: Ryan Avent and Matt Yglesias have been having a debate about whether the zero lower bound really matters for monetary policy, which is related to  but not the same as  the debate about whether the Fed is falling way short on the job. So let me throw in my two basis points here.

title: About That Hammock
description: Recently I linked to Harold Pollacks outrage over remarks by Paul Ryan, in which Ryan suggested that our safety-net programs are a hammock that lulls able-bodied people to lives of dependency and complacency.

title: Hotel Rooms With a View Of Photography Shows
description: Dozens of hotels have notable art collections, but a few are focusing specifically on photography, with shows that wouldnt be out of place at a gallery. W Hotels, for example, will introduce its first Instagram photo exhibition on May 1 at the Living Room in its Times Square property. The hotel is in partnership with the photo-sharing company to curate a display of pictures from New York-based Instagrammers who capture architecture, design and street art in the city. The exhibition will be on display through June.

title: Avoid Roaming Charges With Offline Apps
description: For travelers who want to use digital applications abroad but would like to avoid the outrageous post-vacation data charges, Lonely Planet has a solution. The company recently introduced a series of travel-guide apps for several countries that can be used offline.

title: For Earth Day, a Bit of Perspective
description: Millions of people worldwide will take to the streets, the parks and the National Mall on Sunday for the 43rd Earth Day, but perhaps some readers of the Green blog have yet to make specific plans. Heres one idea: Tune in to Earth: The Operators Manual, one of the more interesting documentary series to come along in years.

title: Dutch Austerity Talks Fail as Geithner Prods Europe
description: BRUSSELS  More uncertainty loomed for the euro zone on Saturday after the prime minister of the Netherlands, Mark Rutte, said he expected new elections to take place following the collapse of talks on new austerity measures.

title: Oracle Vs. Google, Week One
description: It was Larry vs. Larry as two powerful chief executives of two of the most successful tech companies squared off in court in person.

title: Success, Finally, on the Champions Tour
description: SAVANNAH, Ga.  Michael Allen smoked a drive down the middle, then lighted a victory cigar. He had a three-stroke lead on the final hole of the Encompass Insurance Pro-Am last Sunday in Tampa, Fla. The gesture was brash if not premature, but for Allen, on the verge of his first victory on the Champions Tour since 2009, it was a moment to savor.

title: The Mets at 50: The Good, the Bad, but Mostly the Ugly
description: In 18 years of living under the same roof, there was only one late-night, father-waking-son baseball celebration  and it wasnt for a World Series victory or trade-deadline blockbuster.

title: Corona and Tijuana Have Matching Ambitions
description: As Club Tijuana continues its surprising push toward the playoffs in the Mexican Primera Divisin, Joe Corona is anchoring its midfield while at the same time establishing himself as one of the best young American players.

title: Obama Urges South Sudan and Sudan to End Strife
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama urged Sudan and South Sudan to end their fighting and begin negotiations to settle the intensifying conflict between the newly separated countries.

title: From Morris to Lee: Ten Zeros in a Row
description: When a pitcher throws 10 shutout innings, as the Phillies Cliff Lee did on Wednesday in San Francisco, it evokes memories of Jack Morris, who did it for Minnesota in Game 7 of the 1991 World Series.

title: Variety: An Earthly Acrostic
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  April 22 is a good day to discuss all things Earthbound and, of course, discussing our planet has to include a discussion about life on Earth.

title: Discarded Manager Basks in Cheers at Fenway
description: BOSTON

title: U.N. Agrees to Send More Cease-Fire Observers to Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The United Nations Security Council unanimously approved increasing the number of cease-fire monitors in Syria on Saturday, and the battered Syrian city of Homs was calm for the first time in months as an advance team of those observers toured the city.

title: In Bahrain, More Clashes, and Death of a Protester
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  After a night of clashes between antigovernment demonstrators and the police, a protester was found dead Saturday near this capital, as Bahrain struggled to restore calm before an international auto race on Sunday. Opposition groups blamed the police for the death.

title: Finding Economic Lessons in Fading Era of Card Shows
description: Can the dying world of baseball card conventions provide a lesson in economics?

title: Afghanistans Spy Agency Says It Thwarted 2 Attacks
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghanistans intelligence agency, which has come under fire from Afghans for failing to detect multiple attacks here last weekend, said Saturday that it had apprehended militants plotting to kill one of the countrys vice presidents and another group smuggling tons of explosives into the capital hidden in a truck of potatoes.

title: A Note on the French Election
description: I dont know much about French politics. From here, however, it looks as if Sarkozy has a very clear idea of what he should be doing on economic policy, while Hollande doesnt.

title: In France, Using Lessons From Obama Campaign
description: PARIS  Arthur Muller, Vincent Pons and Guillaume Liegey, young Frenchmen who met in Cambridge, Mass., at Harvards Kennedy School of Government and M.I.T., are working hard to get out the vote, American-style, for the Socialist challenger for the French presidency, Franois Hollande.

title: In Comfortable Retirement, and Getting Tired of It
description: During my 14 years in the N.F.L., my favorite day was Monday. As long as I wasnt preparing for surgery or being released, Mondays were special. They signified that I had made it through another week and was ready for another opponent. Even the soreness was oh, so sweet.

title: A Ban on Some Seafood Has Fishermen Fuming
description: GLOUCESTER, Mass.  Standing on the deck of his rusted steel trawler, Naz Sanfilippo fumed about the latest bad news for New England fishermen: a decision by Whole Foods to stop selling any seafood it does not consider sustainable.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Edwards Trial Set to Begin, Reopening a Story of a Derailed Political Career
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.  John Edwards, whose personal life and political career have publicly fallen apart over the last five years, will face a federal jury on Monday in the state that sent him to the Senate and twice rallied around his quest for the presidency.

title: Lincecum Looks to Rebound From Slow Start
description: Tim Lincecum is scheduled to start against the Mets on Sunday at Citi Field, an opportunity for New York fans to get a look at the star pitcher for the San Francisco Giants. His appearance may be even more pronounced because Lincecum is searching for his first victory after struggling in three outings this season. Lincecum is 0-2 with a 10.54 earned run average.

title: A Head-Scratching, Bone-Chilling Schedule
description: Leave it to the N.F.L. to turn the announcement of its regular-season schedule into a midweek celebration of events that will not occur for five months.

title: The Pros and Cons of Hiring Outsiders
description: AS an employee, you may feel at some point in your career that you arent being paid what youre worth. If the feeling is acute enough, you may lobby for a promotion and a raise. But suppose that doesnt work. Then maybe, you think, its time to apply elsewhere.

title: Multiple Paths to a Goal
description: IM an only child. I decided early on that I needed the equivalent of brothers and sisters, so over my lifetime Ive created deep relationships.

title: Letters: How to Balance Faith and a Business Career
description: To the Editor:

title: On Black Sea Swamp, Big Plans for Instant City
description: ZUGDIDI, Georgia  Reaching the site where Georgias government is breaking ground for Lazika, its grandiose city of the future, requires navigating livestock  shaggy cows and huge spotted hogs that sunbathe on the road to the hypnotic chirping of innumerable frogs.

title: Letters: Voting With Your Feet in a Race of the States
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters: The Flow of Funds to Nimble Companies
description: To the Editor:

title: Wal-Mart Hushed Up a Vast Mexican Bribery Case
description: MEXICO CITY  In September 2005, a senior Wal-Mart lawyer received an alarming e-mail from a former executive at the companys largest foreign subsidiary, Wal-Mart de Mexico. In the e-mail and follow-up conversations, the former executive described how Wal-Mart de Mexico had orchestrated a campaign of bribery to win market dominance. In its rush to build stores, he said, the company had paid bribes to obtain permits in virtually every corner of the country.

title: Dont Be Evil, but Dont Miss the Train
description: BACK in 2004, as Google prepared to go public, Larry Page and Sergey Brin celebrated the maxim that was supposed to define their company: Dont be evil.

title: Whats Your Story? Tell It, and You May Win a Prize
description: This interview with  Russell Goldsmith, chairman and chief executive of City National Bank in Los Angeles, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Master of the Media Spotlight Is Now Its Victim in China
description: BEIJING  Intimidating and courting Chinese journalists, Bo Xilai, an ambitious Communist Party official, fueled his political career by ably shaping his public image and seizing the spotlight in a way no peer had as he governed a Chinese city. But with his purge from the partys top ranks this month, Mr. Bo has suddenly found himself the target of the same media apparatus that he once so carefully manipulated, and that now vilifies him in the name of the partys leaders.

title: The Preschool Race Is No Joke
Bobcats Are Fighting a Losing Battle
description: The Charlotte Bobcats probably feel that this season could not end soon enough, but first the team has some important business to take care of. It needs at least one more win to avoid finishing with the lowest victory total since the N.B.A. was formed in 1949.

title: When 24 Hours Is 23:59 Too Long
description: THE Hagglers recent column about PayPal, the online money transfer company, summoned forth a fresh round of I cant stand PayPal e-mail. This one stood out.

title: NATO Plans in Russian City Are Protested
description: MOSCOW  Nationalist and leftist groups marched on Saturday in a central Russian city to protest a proposal by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to set up a transit hub for goods shipped to and from Afghanistan.

title: 30 Seconds: Different Star Turn for an Old Knuckleballer
description: Tim Wakefield retired at 45 in February after a 19-year pitching career that included 200 wins, 186 of them with the Boston Red Sox, and 2,156 strikeouts. But Wakefields elusive pitch is fluttering again in the big-screen documentary Knuckleball. The film had its premiere Saturday as part of the Tribeca Film Festival in New York. The movie chronicles the careers of Wakefield and R.A. Dickey of the Mets.

title: Stocks and the Economy, Singing Different Tunes
description: THE test of a first-rate intelligence is the ability to hold two opposed ideas in the mind at the same time, and still retain the ability to function, F. Scott Fitzgerald wrote in 1936. He might have been describing the difficulties faced by current analysts of the financial markets.

title: Cardinals Create a 14-Karat Squirrel
description: The St. Louis Cardinals would not have won last years World Series without Chris Carpenter, who beat Texas in Games 1 and 7. So when the team president, Bill DeWitt III, worked with Jostens to design the championship rings, he made sure to consult Carpenter on his most unorthodox idea.

title: Employees, Too, Want a Say on the Bosss Pay
description: FINALLY, the shareholders are stirring.

title: With Torres Suspension, N.H.L. Sends Message About Mayhem in the Playoffs
description: It took a week of unprecedented postseason mayhem and a slew of embarrassingheadlines, but the N.H.L.may finally have found the will to curb the on-ice chaos that marked the start of this springs playoffs.

title: Utahs Hatch Will Face a Primary for Senate
description: SANDY, Utah  United States Senator Orrin G. Hatch, a six-term Republican who had been targeted for elimination by Tea Party groups, survived a test from nine challengers at his partys state convention here on Saturday, but failed to win the supermajority needed to avoid a primary race.

title: Giants Low-Key Ways Carry Over to Draft
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Over the last two years, the Jets have made several splashy off-season moves while the Giants have, in the words of the veteran linebacker Mathias Kiwanuka, done it in the background.

title: Veteran Center Lands With the Knicks
description: CLEVELAND  Knicks Coach Mike Woodson described the newest Knick, Dan Gadzuric, in less than flattering terms: A veteran big thats been around, that can use fouls, rebound and defend. A similar description could be made of the player hes essentially replacing.

title: Rape Accusation Against Handyman Tied to Search for Missing Boy
description: Federal agents and the police continued working with jackhammers to dig up a SoHo basement on Saturday in a search for the remains of Etan Patz as reasons behind their renewed interest in excavating the concrete floor emerged.

title: Botswanas Pride
description: Amantle Montsho, an Olympic hopeful who won the 400-meter track title at the world championships in August, has inspired a generation of female athletes in Botswana.

title: Why Are We Drugging Our Soldiers?
description: SINCE the start of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, there has been a large and steady rise in the prevalence of post-traumatic stress disorder among our troops. One recent study of 289,000 Americans who served in those countries found that the rates of the disorder jumped to 22 percent in 2008 from just 0.2 percent in 2002.

title: A Battle Beyond Breakfast
description: With its cereals losing ground, Kellogg, and its research institute in Battle Creek, Mich., is coming up with new products and strategies to help its sales abroad.

title: When a Sugar High Isnt Enough
Shoulder Pain Is a Setback for Pineda
description: BOSTON  For several weeks, starting pitcher Michael Pineda had been making what seemed to be steady progress in his recovery from shoulder tendinitis, passing each stage in the process without reporting any difficulties.

title: Alice Temperley
description: Alice Temperley is an English fashion designer who introduced her label, Temperley London, in 2000. Interest in her clothing has surged in the last year because of the popularity of her clothes with the Duchess of Cambridge, formerly Kate Middleton, and her sister, Pippa.

title: Bartleby Would Understand
description: For years now, presidential candidates and those running for House seats have dutifully filed their campaign financing reports, as required by federal law, electronically. But the Senate, ever arrogant, has clung to an antique, cumbersome paper method that serves to delay final disclosure of donors, often until after Election Day.

title: A Fair Shot at a Job
description: The United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ruled 25 years ago that it was illegal under the Civil Rights Act for companies to exclude people from employment based on arrest or conviction records  unless there was a compelling business reason. Since companies all over the country appear to be ignoring this important policy, the E.E.O.C. needs to strongly reaffirm the ruling and give employers detailed guidance on how to comply when it meets to consider this issue on Wednesday.

title: This Prodigal Season
description: The shadbush, a spindly white-flowered shrub, is starting to bloom. That means American shad  the fish technically known as Alosa sapidissima  are likely to be running up the great rivers of the Northeast, the Delaware, the Hudson, the Connecticut and their tributaries. You can join the red-eyed legion of shad anglers casting shad darts, a type of lure, on the Delaware. Or, you can simply read John McPhees The Founding Fish, which contains everything you need to know about the fish, though it might not help you hook one.

title: The Latest on the Doomsday Virus
description: We can worry less that a newly created bird flu virus might kill tens or hundreds of millions of people if it escaped from the laboratory. But there is still some residual danger. And we remain appalled at the slipshod way in which this research was authorized despite its potential dangers to public health and national security.

title: Another G.O.P. Roadblock
description: With their continuing attacks on abortion rights and reproductive health services, Congressional Republicans have shown themselves to be insensitive to womens concerns. This week, the Senate is expected to take up the proposed reauthorization of the Violence Against Women Act, another measure many Republicans are opposing.

title: Charles W. Colson, Watergate Felon Who Became Evangelical Leader, Dies at 80
description: Charles W. Colson, who as a political saboteur for President Richard M. Nixon masterminded some of the dirty tricks that led to the presidents downfall, then emerged from prison to become an important evangelical leader, saying he had been born again, died on Saturday in Falls Church, Va. He was 80.

title: A Dangerous Mind?
description: LATE last year, a jury in Boston convicted Tarek Mehanna, a 29-year-old pharmacist born in Pittsburgh, of material support for terrorism, conspiring to provide material support to terrorists and conspiring to kill in a foreign country, after a 35-day trial in which I testified as an expert witness for the defense.

title: The Dream of Leaving Cuba
description: Havana

title: How Broadway Games the Tonys
description: BROADWAY likes to think of itself as a cultural engine humming year-round, but judging by the opening dates of many plays and musicals, it has become the narrowest of operations: an awards-obsessed, audience-starved industry that really revs just one month a year.

title: The Flight From Conversation
description: WE live in a technological universe in which we are always communicating. And yet we have sacrificed conversation for mere connection.

title: In Customer Service Consulting, Disneys Small World Is Growing
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Maryland teachers were instructed to engage children by crouching and speaking to them at eye level. Chevrolet dealers were taught to think in theater metaphors: onstage, where smiles greet potential buyers, and offstage, where sales representatives can take out-of-sight cigarette breaks.

title: Sacking a Palace of Culture
description: LONG before I became one of the New York Public Librarys so-called literary lions, I was a habitu of all of that great institutions research facilities, from the hushed music division in the Performing Arts branch at Lincoln Center to a shabby corner of the Muhlenberg branch on West 23rd Street. I have returned Booker T. Washingtons stare in the Schomburg Center in Harlem, and the glassy gaze of Winnie-the-Pooh (yes, the original Bear of Little Brain, rather mangy now) in what used to be the Donnell branch, on West 53rd.

title: In Therapy Forever? Enough Already
description: MY therapist called me the wrong name. I poured out my heart; my doctor looked at his watch. My psychiatrist told me I had to keep seeing him or I would be lost.

title: Everyones Lives, in Pictures
description: ALIENATION, its worth remembering, used to be integral to photography. Susan Sontag wrote, in 1977, While real people are out there killing themselves or other real people, the photographer stays behind his or her camera, creating a tiny element of another world: the image-world that will outlast us all.

title: A Hard Look at the President
description: FOUR weeks ago, I criticized The New York Times for overplaying an article on an investment made by Ann Romneys blind trust. The article was but one installment of the intense campaign coverage scrutinizing Mitt Romney as he bids for the Republican presidential nomination.

title: An Invitation to Abuse and Chaos
description: Arizonas cold-blooded immigration statute was enacted in 2010 to bring about attrition through enforcement  to make life so harsh for undocumented immigrants that they would be driven out of the state. It invites unfettered racial profiling and the abuse of police power. And, if allowed to stand, it opens the door to states writing their own foreign policy, in defiance of the Constitution.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Books in a Digital Age
description: Readers discuss e-book pricing and the future of publishing.

title: Mets Rally After Losing 3-Run Lead to Giants
description: The follies were replayed on televisions throughout the clubhouse, repeatedly showing Manager Terry Collins wincing with disgust. The music still played and the players still smiled, because a win helped soothe Collinss frustration.

title: The Footprints on a Path to Gold
description: MAUN, Botswana  Victor Nkapes 12-year-old daughter was running around the familys cattle post here, amid the brambles, cows, goats and an occasional donkey, when he was struck by something that made the girl different.

title: Platos Body, and Mine
description: IF only I had read Plato.

title: On Old Walls, New Despair
description: LISBON

title: A Body, a Scandal and China
description: IT all began with a dead body, in a hotel in the Chinese city of Chongqing. The corpse belonged to a British businessman who was said to have drunk himself to death  odd, considering that he rarely drank.

title: Hoyer and Epstein Try to Build Winner for Wrigley
description: Jed Hoyer won two World Series, each with a very different meaning, as an assistant under Theo Epstein for the Boston Red Sox. The 2004 title signified the completion of a job that started before they arrived. The 2007 title fulfilled a new vision.

title: The Wrath of Grapes
description: We know from a rare personal admission that Mitt Romney experienced a faint whiff of alcohol, a long, long time ago. I tasted a beer and tried a cigarette once as a wayward teenager, he said last November, and never tried it again.

title: Gray Matter: A Facial Theory of Politics
description: In Gray Matter, Leonard Mlodinow writes that eyes of a certain curvature and a slight widows peak can help win an election.

title: Portugals Pain, in Pictures
description: In Sundays column, I describe how Portugals capital changed through the lens of Ana Luisa Nogueiras camera, which she used to photograph the writing on Lisbons buildings. Here are just a few of the pictures she has taken over the last two years.

title: Down With Everything
description: DOES America need an Arab Spring? That was the question on my mind when I called Frank Fukuyama, the Stanford professor and author of The End of History and the Last Man. Fukuyama has been working on a two-volume opus called The Origins of Political Order, and I could detect from his recent writings that his research was leading him to ask a very radical question about Americas political order today, namely: has American gone from a democracy to a vetocracy  from a system designed to prevent anyone in government from amassing too much power to a system in which no one can aggregate enough power to make any important decisions at all?

title: Alex Cassie, Who Aided Great Escape From Nazis, Dies at 95
description: It was on the moonless night of March 24 and 25, 1944, that 76 Allied prisoners of war, most of them British, clambered down a 30-foot shaft and crawled through a 340-foot-long tunnel below the supposedly escape-proof Stalag Luft III camp in eastern Germany  the daring breakout that was celebrated in the classic 1963 movie The Great Escape.

title: Taking the Waste Out of Wastewater
description: Drinking water reclaimed from sewage might sound disgusting, but it could be a necessary solution to our domestic water woes.

title: Taking the Waste Out of Wastewater
description: Fourteen states suffering under drought. Water use in Southwest heads for day of reckoning. Water-pollution laws violated more than 500,000 times in five years. Ruptures in aging water systems cause pollutants to seep into water supplies.

title: Letting Go Of
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Let us all breathe a sigh of relief. The Sunday puzzle has returned to normal. However you might define that.

title: Bert Weedon, Guitar Teacher to a Generation, Dies at 91
description: Bert Weedon, a British guitarist whose popular instructional manual Play in a Day taught the instrument to a generation of young hopefuls  young hopefuls named Pete Townshend, Eric Clapton, John Lennon and Paul McCartney  died on Friday at his home in Beaconsfield, in the English county of Buckinghamshire. He was 91.

title: Champions Come and Go Over 50 Years of Columns
description: In November 1934, Lester Markel, the Sunday editor of The New York Times, wrote to Jos Ral Capablanca, a former world chess champion:

title: The China Syndrome
description: My Sunday column is about the extraordinary scandal unfolding in China around Bo Xilai and his family. I thought I had seen everything in China, but Im floored when a Politburo members wife is detained for allegedly murdering a foreigner.

title: Program for Low-Income Housing Compels Building in Poor Neighborhoods
description: Plans to build a low-income apartment complex for seniors in one of San Antonios most fashionable neighborhoods had been posted for barely a week in January when the fury began.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 22
description: With Mitt Romney revamping his campaign to suit his status as the presumptive Republican nominee, the chatter about who could be his No. 2 is getting louder.

title: Furnishing the House, Savoring the Crme Brle
description: Five years ago, youd have been hard-pressed to find a cocktail-craving 30-something headed to a haute bar in Dallass design district, a once-industrial enclave centrally situated close to the Main Street district, near downtown. But now the design district is attracting new retailers, deep-pocketed developers and plenty of shoppers, thanks to a slew of buzz-worthy restaurants, chic stores and daring art galleries opening alongside brand-new apartments and lofts.

title: Postgame Comments: Real Madrid 2, Barcelona 1
description: Cristiano Ronaldo scored his league-leading 42nd goal from a tight angle in the 73rd minute  answering a tying goal moments earlier from Alexis Sanchez  to give Real Madrid a 2-1 victory at Barcelona on Saturday. The defeat was Barcelonas first at home in 55 games, and most likely signaled the end of the Catalans three-year reign as Spanish champions.

title: Bahrain Race Is Not First Controversy for Formula One
description: LONDON  The furor over the decision to run this years Bahrain Grand Prix has cast Formula One motor racing into a controversy that is making headlines around the world, some of them in countries where most people would scarcely know their Fangios and their Schumachers, their Nrburgrings and their Monzas, from names picked at random from a telephone directory or an atlas.

title: A Healing Presence Through 3 Administrations
description: When Gov. Ann Richards needed a flu shot in 1992, she summoned Tim Flynn, the Texas Capitols recently installed nurse, to her office.

title: Rangers Await the Return of a Dynamic Rookie
description: The Rangers lineup will get a needed injection of speed for Game 6 in Ottawa on Monday when Carl Hagelin returns from his suspension. Hagelin was suspended for three games by the N.H.L. for a high hit in Game 2 that gave the Senators captain Daniel Alfredsson a concussion.

title: Remembering a Fallen Firefighter
Conservative Nonprofit Acts as a Stealth Business Lobbyist
description: Desperate for new revenue, Ohio lawmakers introduced legislation last year that would make it easier to recover money from businesses that defraud the state.

title: Two Late Touchdowns Lift Yankees to a Surreal Victory in Boston
description: BOSTON  After so much frustration and disappointment two weeks into the season, it seemed things could not get any worse for the Boston Red Sox. But along came Nick Swisher, Mark Teixeira and the Yankees to prove that it could.

title: Presidential vs. Political Trips: A Blurry Line, and Tricky Math
description: WASHINGTON  Facing 5,000 enthusiastic students at Florida Atlantic University, President Obama rolled up his sleeves and raised his voice to chastise Republicans for their spending cuts and broken-down theories, evoking chants of Four more years!

title: Quietly Finishing the Job That Walsh Started
description: When the meddling and the mayhem became too much, Donnie Walsh extracted himself from Madison Square Garden and retreated 700 miles to the west, his work unfinished.

title: In Uprooting of Kurds, Iraq Tests a Fragile National Unity
description: KHANAQIN, Iraq  In January, the dismembered body of Wisam Jumai, a Kurdish intelligence officer, was discovered in a field in Sadiyah, a small town in northeastern Iraq. Soon his family and friends, one after another, received text messages offering a choice: leave or be killed.

title: In the 21st Perfect Game, Another Sigh for the Mets
description: With the third overall pick in the 2004 draft, the Mets decided to find a future ace for their starting rotation. They focused on three college pitchers: Justin Verlander of Old Dominion, Jered Weaver of Long Beach State and Philip Humber of Rice.

title: From the Bench to the Grass Roots
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor at The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Todays Vineyards, Yesterdays Tall Oaks
description: On a recent sunny day in the Napa Valley, Robin Grossinger cupped his hands around his eyes and surveyed the landscape. He said the scene gave him a feeling of grandeur.

title: Top-Seeded in First Round, Rangers May Not See the Second
description: The Rangers were not supposed to be hearing boos at Madison Square Garden this spring. But that was how their fans sent them off Saturday night after a 2-0 loss to the Ottawa Senators put the Rangers, the top-seeded team in the Eastern Conference, on the brink of elimination in the first round of the playoffs.

title: San Francisco Puts Brakes on an App for Transit
description: If all goes according to the five-year plan approved by the Board of Supervisors, the city and county of San Francisco will upgrade its technology infrastructure to accommodate such trendy things as social networks, cloud computing, crowd-sourcing, open-source software and location-aware apps. But by then it will be 2016, or more than 10 product cycles by Silicon Valley standards.

title: CrossFit Oakland
description: Sweaty people run laps on an urban side street, dodging forklifts from nearby industries. They go into a warehouse, where they grunt and groan through their weight lifting and conditioning workout at Crossfit Oakland, in Emeryville. Some say CrossFit is a cult. Others, especially post-workout, dont say anything. They cant. Theyre too tired.

title: Double Doses of Runs Batted In
description: In Saturdays Yankees victory over Boston, Nick Swisher and Mark Teixeira each had six runs batted in. It was the fifth time in Yankees history that two players drove in at least six runs in the same game.

title: Gouged by Some Small Groceries, Food Program Cracks Down
description: At Rancho Grande Supermarket in San Pablo, a package of 18 corn tortillas recently cost $7.80.

title: Garcia Is Dark Cloud in Yankees Silver Lining
description: BOSTON  Somewhat obscured by the Yankees remarkable comeback over the Boston Red Sox on Saturday was another bad start by Freddy Garcia, whose velocity was down and whose pitches were up in the strike zone.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 21, 2012

title: Senators Keep Lid on the Top Scorers
description: The cry of coaches in the Stanley Cup playoffs is for the best players on the team to actually play like the best players. After losing to Ottawa, 2-0, in Game 5 on Saturday to fall behind by three games to two in the Eastern Conference quarterfinals, the Rangers can search for a lot of reasons for their struggles. But the failures of Marian Gaborik and Brad Richards surely lead the list.

title: Corrections: April 22
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Rangers-Senators Replay: Game 5
description: The Ottawa Senators pushed the top-seeded New York Rangers to the brink of elimination with a 2-0 victory Saturday night.

title: Pedestrians Injured After Three-Car Wreck Spills Onto Sidewalk in Midtown
description: At least 10 people were injured Saturday night after a three-vehicle accident at the intersection of 42nd Street and Avenue of the Americas in Midtown, the police said.

title: Esther Klein, Matthew Wolf
description: Esther Julia Klein, the daughter of Hannah Koplowitz Klein and Robert P. Klein of Wheaton, Md., is to be married Sunday morning to Matthew Scott Wolf, a son of Meryl J. Wolf and William H. Wolf of River Vale, N.J. Rabbi James L. Simon is to officiate at the Estate at Florentine Gardens, an event venue, in River Vale.

description: Nicole Debra Goodman, the daughter of Kenneth E. Goodman of Bedford Hills, N.Y., and the late Barbara S. Goodman, was married Saturday evening to Jordan Bernard Dubbs, the son of Wendy W. Dubbs and Ivan C. Dubbs of White Plains. Rabbi Howard J. Goldsmith officiated at Capitale, an event space in New York.

description: Sandra Jessica Tushingham and Matthew Hughes Bynum were married Saturday evening at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y. The Rev. Janice L. Sutton, a United Methodist minister, officiated.

description: Stacey Leigh Carfi and Dr. Andrew Alexander Stec were married Saturday evening at the Hilton Key Largo Resort in Key Largo, Fla. The Rev. Joe Gallant, a priest ordained by the National Catholic Church, led a nondenominational ceremony.

Zimont and Larry L. Zimont of Chicago. The Rev. George M. Witt, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York, where he is pastor.

description: Kristiina Elisabet Anstey and Thomas Christopher Molnar were married Saturday evening at St. Pauls Episcopal Church in Delray Beach, Fla. The Rev. Canon William H. Stokes, an Episcopal priest and the churchs rector, performed the ceremony, with the Rev. Dr. Wendel W. Meyer, also an Episcopal priest, taking part.

description: Ryann Allyne Pointon and Christopher Michael Imperioli were married Saturday by the Rev. Sarah Segal McCaslin, a Presbyterian minister, at the Galapagos Art Space in Brooklyn.

description: Stephanie Margaret Veale, the daughter of Dianne M. Veale and Dr. Christopher J. Veale of West Hartford, Conn., was married Saturday evening to Sean Park Dobbin, the son of Linda Sue Park and Ben E. Dobbin of Rochester. Teresa Werth, a Sanctuary of Life minister, officiated at the Memorial Art Gallery in Rochester.

description: Ariel Esther Greenstein and Patrick Michael Dalin are to be married Sunday evening at Congregation Rodeph Shalom in Philadelphia. Rabbi Jill L. Maderer is to perform the ceremony.

description: Lesley Ann Slater and Kenneth Matthew Stumphauzer were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Janet Roberts at the Yale Club in Manhattan.

description: Rachel Lauren Simonson and Jeffrey Marcus Cohen are to be married Sunday evening at Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn Heights, N.Y. Rabbi Alan B. Lucas is to perform the ceremony.

description: Melissa Marshall McGuirk, a daughter of Nancy D. McGuirk and Terence Foster McGuirk of Atlanta, was married Saturday evening to Harold Edward Maude III, a son of Cathy K. Maude and Mr. Maude Jr. of Philadelphia. The Rev. Dr. Victor Donald Pentz, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Wesley United Methodist Church on St. Simons Island, Ga.

title: Diego Prieto and Brad Oscar
description: Diego Prieto and Brad Oscar, both actors, were married Monday evening at the Arena Stage at the Mead Center for American Theater in Washington. Molly Smith, a Universal Life minister and the theaters artistic director, officiated.

title: Elana Wilf and Brett Tanzman
description: Elana Beth Wilf, a daughter of Audrey and Zygmunt Wilf of Springfield, N.J., is to be married Sunday to Brett Evan Tanzman, the son of Brenda and Roy Tanzman of South Brunswick, N.J. Rabbi Eliot I. Malomet is to officiate at the Museum of American Finance in New York.

title: Alice Hagge, Adam Carey
description: Alice Van Keuren Hagge and Adam Max Carey were married Saturday evening at the Claremont House Bed and Breakfast in Rome, Ga. The Rev. L. B. Caywood, a retired Methodist minister, officiated.

title: Emily Muncie, Benjamin Ciesinski
description: Emily Katharine Muncie and Benjamin Alan Ciesinski were married Saturday at Calvary Episcopal Church in Cincinnati. The Rev. Jason E. Leo, the churchs rector, performed the ceremony.

title: Natalie Jones and Patrick Hallahan
description: Natalie Rita Jones and Patrick William Hallahan were married Monday in McLean, Va., at the home of Terry McAuliffe, a former chairman of the Democratic National Committee. Mr. McAuliffe, a friend of the couple who was appointed a civil celebrant by the Circuit Court of Fairfax County, Va., for the occasion, officiated.

title: In Game as in the Season, Things Kind of Snowballed
description: BOSTON  With each somber pitching change in the grisly late innings Saturday, Bobby Valentine absorbed the fans frustration at Fenway Park. The Boston Red Sox are playing just as poorly for Valentine as they did for Terry Francona last September, and the boos washed over him.

title: Already in Myanmars Reformation, an Impasse
description: HONG KONG  Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and 42 members of her National League for Democracy insist they will not take the oath of office on Monday unless a single problematic word is changed: The newly elected members of Parliament are refusing to swear that they will safeguard the Constitution. Instead, they want to say theyll respect it.

title: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
description: In Tehelka, a profile of Maharashtra Chief Minister Prithviraj Chavan suggests that within a year or a month, depending on which anonymously sourced politician you listen to, a new leader will have replaced the state chief minister belonging to the Congress Party. The problem with Mr. Chavan, according to the article, is as much that he was imposed on Maharashtra by New Delhi to clean up the aftermath of the Adarsh housing society scandal in 2010, as that he is by all accounts a good man, unable to be swayed by land interests thereby unsuited to the states politics.

title: Ryan Tannehill, 3rd-Ranked Quarterback in 2012 Draft
description: Matt Waldman is the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, a testament to his obsession with film analysis, now available for download. Examples of his work can be found at his blog. He is helping The Fifth Down rank skill position players before the draft:

title: Kenyans Kipsang and Keitany Take Wins at London Marathon
description: LONDON  They finished the way they always seem to finish now in big-city marathons, Kenyans winning so elegantly and regularly that they become almost interchangeable in their dominance.

title: Have a Good Earth Day
description: Happy Earth Day, everyone. I hope at least some moment for you holds the joy exhibited by my son Jack when he got to dance inside an ancient redwood.  Share some such moments here.

title: Hollande and Sarkozy Head to Runoff in French Race
description: PARIS  The Socialist candidate, Franois Hollande, won a narrow victory in Sundays first round of Frances presidential elections, riding promises of economic growth and a general dislike for the incumbent, Nicolas Sarkozy, into a favorable position before a runoff with Mr. Sarkozy on May 6.

title: Updates on the French Presidential Election
description: The Lede followed developments in the first round of presidential voting in France on Sunday as President Nicolas Sarkozy came in second against his Socialist challenger, Franois Hollande, in his bid for a second term. The two will compete head-to-head in a run-off election on May 6.

title: That Special Day: Bah, Humbug?
description: When I was growing up in the suburbs of New York, our first local Earth Day was organized around a drive to a town field where families were urged to dump items from their basements for recycling rather than tossing them in the trash. Hmmm. Recycling. It was an eye-opening concept for a kid in 1970.

title: With Pact, U.S. Agrees to Help Afghans for Years to Come
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  After months of negotiations, the United States and Afghanistan completed drafts of a strategic partnership agreement on Sunday that pledges American support for Afghanistan for 10 years after the withdrawal of combat troops at the end of 2014.

title: The Drywall Chronicles
description: So Mitt Romney gave a speech at a closed Ohio drywall factory, which he tried to use as a symbol of Obamas economic failure. The symbolism was perfect  not as an illustration of Obamas failure, but as an illustration of just how stupid Romney thinks we are.

title: Offering Luxury Stays With Some Breaks
description: The closest that many travelers get to a luxury hotel is by looking at an ad in a glossy magazine, but several new properties offer posh living for the midrange budget.

title: Disruptions: With New Comforts, Growing Complacent
description: Google and Facebook, young and successful companies that they are, risk being left behind as technology shifts from PCs and Web browsers to mobile devices.

title: Double Doses of Runs Batted In
description: In Saturdays Yankees victory over Boston, Nick Swisher and Mark Teixeira each had six runs batted in. It was the fifth time in Yankees history that two players drove in at least six runs in the same game.

title: Leading U.S. Under-20s, Ramos Likes What He Sees
description: As the third United States under-20 camp of the year was winding down recently in Portland, Ore., the teams new head coach, Tab Ramos, was still getting settled into the job.

title: Excerpt: 'A Streetcar Named Desire'
description: A scene from the Broadway revival of the Tennessee Williams play, with Blair Underwood as Stanley and Nicole Ari Parker as Blanche.

title: Netherlands Pushes for Austerity Cuts Even as Debt Crisis Deals Blow to Leadership
description: BRUSSELS  The Dutch government  one of the last in Europe with an untarnished credit rating on the line  indicated Sunday that it would press ahead with efforts to pass an austerity budget, even as it appeared to be the latest European leadership forced into early elections by the Continents debt crisis.

title: Applying the Torres Blueprint to Neils Hit on Boyle
Secret Service Needs More Women, Lawmakers Say
description: WASHINGTON  Two female lawmakers, both of them members of oversight committees, said Sunday that the dearth of women Secret Service agents might have contributed to the scandal linking agency personnel to prostitutes in Colombia. And they credited a female supervisor in the agency for bringing it to light.

title: Think Like a Man Tops the Weekend Box Office
description: The No. 1 movie in North America over the weekend, and by a long shot (sorry, Zac Efron), came as a shock to the movie industry: Think Like a Man, a low-budget ensemble comedy aimed at African-American audiences, took in an estimated $33 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data. Sony spent less than $13 million to make this film, which is based on Steve Harveys book Act Like a Lady, Think Like a Man and features the comedian Kevin Hart.

title: Original Review: A Streetcar Named Desire
description: Brooks Atkinsons original 1947 review of the Tennessee Williams play starring Marlon Brando, Jessica Tandy and Kim Hunter.

title: Goodbye, Cruel World, Im Joining the Circus
description: They say theater is the most ephemeral art, and yet its not just the landmark buildings on Broadway that remind us of ghosts of show business past.

title: Vigorous Interpretations of Sounds Both Old and New
description: In a mosaic each detail appears splendidly conceived, the cellist Christophe Coin wrote in the booklet notes for a recording of string quartets by Beethoven as performed by the Quatuor Mosaques, the sterling Austrian ensemble of which Mr. Coin is a member. But it is the overall picture that one takes in at a single glance, he continued, explaining that a similar process is brought to bear when a quartet weighs all the various factors that go into forming an interpretation.

title: The Flick of a Skirt Can Speak Louder Than Words
description: Katie Workum takes on a lot in Fruitlands, her new dance named after a failed commune created in the 19th century by the American transcendentalist Amos Bronson Alcott. His daughter was Louisa May Alcott, and its hard to push her most famous novel to the back of your mind when watching this showcase for four women, each strong in a delicate way.

title: Administration Torn on Secret Service Scandal Response
description: WASHINGTON  Just before Air Force One begins its descent, a group of agents huddle in a cabin near the back to study a map, a diagram and a step-by-step itinerary detailing the presidents every move once he steps off the plane.

title: Discovering New Old Garry Winogrand Photographs
description: This weeks Look pages feature pictures taken by Garry Winogrand at the 1960 Democratic National Convention. They were discovered last year by Leo Rubinfien when he was going through the vast archive of Winogrands workat the Center for Creative Photography in Tucson.

title: What We Talk About When We Talk About QE
description: Karl Smith is bemused; in two posts he asks what Wall Street thinks quantitative easing does, and apparently is getting a lot of vehemence but no coherence. (I liked this comment: Zero hedge commentary suggests the fed manipulates our very life blood, as ordered by the lizard men, in order to create infinite debt and establish a soviet central planning regime.)

title: High on Emotion in the Mediterranean Glow of Folk Motifs
description: Nelly van Bommel, who was born to Dutch parents and grew up in France, is a choreographer with a penchant for athleticism and humor. Her narrative threads are loose, but one intention  at least made evident in Pinguli, Pinguli, shown at the Baryshnikov Arts Center on Wednesday night  is to tell quick episodic stories that lean on the side of absurdity.

title: 'Jesus Christ Superstar'
description: Scenes from the 2012 Broadway revival at the Neil Simon Theater starring Paul Nolan as Jesus and Josh Young as Judas.

title: The First Round of the French Elections
description: Residents of France went to the polls on Sunday to winnow the field of presidential candidates from ten to two, who will face each other in a runoff on May 6.

title: TimesCast | Small Money for Broadway
description: A new grassroots business model on Broadway, as small investors back a revival of Godspell.

title: Climate Change to Affect Corn Prices, Study Says
description: Researchers have found that climate change is likely to have far greater influence on the volatility of corn prices over the next three decades than factors that recently have been blamed for price swings  like oil prices, trade policies and government biofuel mandates.

title: A Lighter Side of Arm Wrestling, for Charity, Sport and Feminism
description: In a sweaty, packed back room at Public Assembly in Williamsburg on Friday night, an M.C. pumped up the crowd with profanity-laced announcements, burlesque dancers and an accordionist vied for the crowds attention, and a dance-off was in the offing.

title: The Mets Ring After Oiling
description: No more sliding god entrances. Siegmund and Sieglinde move their intimate moments closer to the audience. And the creaking quotient has been reduced.

title: Slashes and Shrieks in a Clamorous Return to the Barricades
description: David Coll, a young American composer based in Belgium, provided a perfectly reasonable accounting for the impulses that led him to create Position, Influence, a work presented at Roulette on Friday evening during the third and last program of this years MATA Festival. In an onstage interview Mr. Coll said that the piece reflected his political awakening during two years spent in Paris recently.

title: Taking Eye Off Standings, Knicks Escape Against the Hawks
description: ATLANTA  The first step in the Knicks playoff preparation was to stop fixating on their playoff preparation, or at least the part about improving their postseason position.

title: Aiming for Clarity, Fed Still Falls Short in Some Eyes
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, has tried to speak more clearly and more frequently than his predecessors. He has lectured college students, met with members of the military and, since last April, held quarterly news conferences.

title: Glaad Media Awards Honor Chaz Bono and Others
description: The 23rd Glaad Media Awards honored Chaz Bono, the transgender activist and author; the actor Josh Hutcherson; and others on Saturday in Los Angeles. The film Becoming Chaz was chosen as outstanding documentary, and Mr. Bono received the Stephen F. Kolzak Award, which was presented by his mother, Cher, and stepmother, Mary Bono Mack, for his work in fighting homophobia. Mr. Hutcherson was recognized for his efforts with the antibullying campaign Straight but Not Narrow.

title: Cavorting in Bed and on the Stump Around Election Time in California
description: At the start of Seth Greenlands comic novel The Angry Buddhist two American women get matching tattoos to commemorate their quickie affair in Mexico. Mr. Greenland notes that it will be harder for the married woman to explain why she has a new manga-style kitten on her buttock than it will for her single lover. Really, its hard to argue with that.

title: Giroux and Flyers Finish Off Penguins
description: PHILADELPHIA  Just before the opening face-off of the Flyers playoff game against the Penguins on Sunday, Claude Giroux of Philadelphia skated over to his bench. He wanted to tell his teammate Danny Briere something. Briere leaned in close.

title: A Muscular Performance to Ring Through Museum Halls
description: The Turkish pianist Fazil Says performance at the Metropolitan Museum on Friday night was the only traditional piano recital presented in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium this season. That there was not a whole series of piano recitals represents a significant change in the institutions musical offerings.

title: American Psycho as a Musical
description: The Headlong Theater Company in London has announced that the world premiere of the musical adaptation of American Psycho, based on the 1991 novel by Bret Easton Ellis, will be part of its 2012-13 season.Rupert Goold (Enron) will direct the production, which has music and lyrics by Duncan Sheik (Spring Awakening) and a book by Roberto Aguirre-Sacasa (Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark). An opening date has not been set.

title: QE Or Not QE, That Is The Question
description: OK, some readers have asked me to react to this critique by Mike Kimel. Brief response: Kimel apparently misses the distinction between ordinary monetary policy and quantitative easing, and also misunderstands what the Fed is buying.

title: The Living Word
description: There is a standard view about language that one finds among philosophers, language departments, pundits and politicians. It is the idea that a language like English is a semi-stable abstract object that we learn to some degree or other and then use in order to communicate or express ideas and perform certain tasks. I call this the static picture of language, because, even though it acknowledges some language change, the pace of change is thought to be slow, and what change there is, is thought to be the hard fought product of conflict. Thus, even the revisionist picture of language sketched by Gary Gutting in a recent Stone column counts as static on my view, because the change is slow and it must overcome resistance.

title: Rangers, Sent to Brink, Have Very Little to Say
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The Rangers have learned the painful lesson that 51 wins, 109 points and the Eastern Conference regular-season title are of little value in the Stanley Cup playoffs. More than six months of resounding success over an 82-game season will become meaningless if they lose one of the next two games in the conference quarterfinals with the Ottawa Senators.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: A More Vocal Federal Reserve
description: The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, has tried to speak more clearly and more frequently than his predecessors.

title: Scots Win Lady Milne Trophy
description: The Lady Milne Trophy is an annual competition among womens teams representing England, Ireland, Northern Ireland, Scotland and Wales. This years event was held last weekend in Llandrindod Wells, Wales.

title: What the National Fronts Victory Will Mean
description: LONDON  The French love a protest vote and the electoral system is devised to indulge them. On Sunday, we are told, they voted with their hearts and in two weeks time they will vote with their heads.

title: The Caucus Click: The Week in Pictures
description: In Mitt Romneys first full week without a major challenger to the Republican nomination, he focused his attacks on President Obama, who visited the swing state of Ohio for the fourth time since January.

title: Film Festival Blooms With Ripe Perversity
description: If youre one of those people who like to leave a movie theater feeling as if youve been punched, the Tribeca Film Festival stands ready to slug you.

title: A Chance to Draw Attention to Yourself
description: What does it take to get a guy in his late 30s, a woman in her late 40s and a man in his early 60s practically thrown out of the august Upper East Side town house of the Society of Illustrators?

title: A Son of Restaurants Calls for the Check
description: The dishes come out of the kitchen punctually in The Big Meal, Dan LeFrancs multigenerational play set entirely in a series of unnamed restaurants.

title: A Ruler in Crosswords
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Its rare that we see a theme with repeated words in it, but we have one today, and I have to say that I thought it was very clever.

title: Filmmaker Wins Case Against I.R.S.
description: Documentary filmmakers can breathe a sigh of relief, knowing that the producer and director Lee Storey won her case last week against the commissioner of Internal Revenue in United States Tax Court. The I.R.S. tried to disallow Ms. Storeys deduction of expenses incurred while making and marketing the film Smile Til It Hurts: The Up With People Story. The movie played the festival circuit after it was finished in 2008, but it has yet to become a moneymaker. So the tax collectors contended that Ms. Storey, who is a practicing lawyer when she is not making documentary films, was engaged in a hobby  not a business  because she enjoyed filmmaking and wasnt turning a profit despite considerable efforts to do so. That contention sent shivers through the ranks of documentary filmmakers, many of whom are in the same boat much of the time. Among the organizations that joined in a brief in support of Ms. Storeys position  that businesslike behavior and an honest effort to turn a profit, among other things, entitled her to the deductions  were the International Documentary Association, Film Independent, the National Association of Latino Independent Producers, Women Make Movies, the National Alliance for Media Art and Culture, and the University Film and Video Association. In a ruling dated April 19 the tax court saw it Ms. Storeys way. The court said that she was engaged in a real business, that her deductions were legitimate, and that she did not owe about $250,000, plus penalties, that was being claimed by the I.R.S. for 2006, 2007 and 2008.

title: Private Electronic Lagoons Just Above the Aural Horizon
description: Watchful waiting was good strategy at the Unsound Festival, a five-day international caucus of the (mostly) electronic fringe in New York that ended on Sunday. Unsounds offerings covered thrash-metal, dub reggae and ethereal pop. But they converged on a fondness for the amorphous, the unresolved, the shadowy, the liminal  sounds appearing just above the aural horizon  merged with the technology of loops, echoes and effects, and often with a video backdrop.

title: With His Closer Struggling, Collins Decides Its Time for Pep Talk
description: Frank Francisco represented the Mets version of a splashy off-season signing when the cash-poor club gave him a two-year, $12 million deal to close games. After Franciscos second week in the role, Manager Terry Collins has already had to issue a vote of confidence.

title: Part of Waste Problem Is Now Part of Solution
description: HONEST TEA, like other organic beverage sellers, normally promotes its real leaves, fair trade certified tea, less sugary taste and environmentally friendly packaging. Its newest campaign acknowledges that it is part of a problem of waste in discarded drink containers and, to counter that, encourages more recycling.

title: Pelfrey Remembers a Perfect Teammate
description: Mike Pelfrey watched the highlights of a former minor league teammate, but it was not the same player he remembered.

title: Czechs Protest New Austerity Measures
description: PARIS  Czechs over the weekend staged some of the biggest demonstrations in their country since the fall of Communism, taking to the streets to protest the austerity measures and rampant corruption that have brought the center-right government to the brink of collapse.

title: As Protests Continue, Vettel Wins Bahrain Grand Prix
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  For the first time in a three-day weekend of auto racing at the Formula One circuit outside Manama, the emphasis on Sunday was on just auto racing.

title: TV Corrects Itself, Just Not on the Air
description: After broadcasting an audio clip on the Today show about George Zimmerman last month that hit the trifecta of being misleading, incendiary and dead-bang wrong, NBC News management took serious action: it fired the producer in charge and issued a statement apologizing for making it appear as if Mr. Zimmerman had made overtly racist statements.

title: When a Woman Decides on an Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include the Standard & Poors/Case-Shiller home price index for February, new home sales for March and consumer confidence for April (Tuesday); durable goods for March, weekly jobless claims and pending home sales for March (Thursday); gross domestic product for the first quarter and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for April (Friday).

title: China, Amid Uncertainty at Home and in Europe, Looks to Germany
description: BRUSSELS  As Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China tours Europe this week, it is no accident that Germany occupies a special place on his itinerary.

title: A Reimagined Library: Are the Changes Good?
description: To the Editor:

title: John A. Hoyt, Champion for Animals, Is Dead at 80
description: John A. Hoyt, who made the Humane Society of the United States the largest anticruelty organization in the country during an era when changing cultural attitudes were greatly expanding the number of animal protection groups, died on April 15 in Fredericksburg, Va. He was 80.

title: Approaching a Ball That Bends the Rules
description: No one has ever accused golf of being a lawless society. Indeed, one of the tenets of the game is that the players police themselves.

title: Compensation for Hostages
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Agreement on a Global Firewall, but Little Beyond That
description: WASHINGTON  Meetings of finance ministers and central bankers here over the weekend started with a pledge by wealthy nations to significantly increase the lending capacity of the International Monetary Fund to defend against the possibility of worsening economic conditions in the debt-laden euro zone.

title: The Wrong Way to Stop Fake Drugs
description: Washington

title: Start-Up Aims to Stream Pay TV Onto Web Devices
description: In a move that could hasten the slow pace of so-called TV Everywhere, a technology start-up is introducing a way to move a whole subscriptions worth of TV onto the Web, with or without the subscription companys permission.

title: From Doughnuts to Dollars, Building a Winner
description: From the visitors dugout last week, before a game at Fenway Park, Jon Daniels gazed out to his past. It was right up there, in the center-field bleachers, where he sat for the 1999 All-Star Game in Boston. Daniels had just graduated from Cornell and was working nearby, on the business side of Dunkin Donuts. He could not have known his future was right before him.

title: The Face of U.S. Wrestling Will Change for the Games
description: IOWA CITY  Sandwiched around Rulon Gardners failed comeback and Henry Cejudos defeat and shoe-removing retirement, USA Wrestling filled its Olympic team with fresh-faced talent grappling for broader fame.

title: Jeep Signs On as USA Basketball Sponsor
description: The United States Olympic program might not have picked its basketball team yet, but the team already has a full lineup of sponsors.

title: Kings Eliminate Canucks; Bruins Head to Game 7
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  A year ago the Vancouver Canucks came within a game of winning the Stanley Cup, losing the finals to the Boston Bruins in seven games.

title: Go West, Young Religion: Mormonism on Exhibit
description: SALT LAKE CITY  The president, according to Mormon doctrine, is literally a seer, a prophet  the president, that is, of the church. Usually American presidents have a somewhat lower reputation.

title: How States Should Approach Immigration
Let Arizonas Law Stand
description: Philadelphia

title: Kuroda-Darvish on Live in Japan
description: BOSTON  The Yankees game against the Boston Red Sox was rained out Sunday, which was bad news for those with tickets to Fenway Park, but great news for baseball fans in Japan.

title: Why Griffin Could Be in Better Position With Redskins

title: Valentine Gets the Blame, and Readily Accepts It
description: BOSTON  A cold, steady rain that postponed Sunday nights game was the only respite Bobby Valentine and the Boston Red Sox could find from their current dismal predicament. An awful week that began with a controversy and included five consecutive losses was capped Saturday with the teams worst defeat in recent history, at the hands of the Yankees, no less.

title: G.A.O. Calls Test Project by Medicare Costly Waste
description: WASHINGTON  Medicare is wasting more than $8 billion on an experimental program that rewards providers of mediocre health care and is unlikely to produce useful results, federal investigators say in a new report.

title: Gritty Musical Mainstay in the East Village Fades Out
description: For 16 years, the Lakeside Lounge employed a formula that never changed: a handpicked band every night, a jukebox loaded with classic songs, a cadre of quick-witted bartenders working under strings of colored lights, and an old-time photo booth that spat out strips of pictures shot using real film.

Timing it to a visit by the Portland Trail Blazers  a franchise based about 50 miles southwest of the volcano  the Nets commemorated the event by handing out key chains filled with authentic Mount St. Helens ash.

title: The New York Primary
description: Every four years, the New York primary becomes less significant. The front-loading of the parties nominating processes has become so intense that Republican voters have made their choice before New Yorkers get a chance to vote on Tuesday. But in a year that started with the most right-wing fringe lineup we have seen, Republicans could have done a lot worse than Mitt Romney.

title: Rain, Snow, Sleet and Congress
description: How vital is the United States Postal Service? The Senate is attempting to answer that this week as it debates the services obvious need to drastically reform its business model in the age of electronic communication. Postal officials say they must close about 3,700 underused post offices (there are 32,000 nationally) while offering alternative services through local businesses. They also want to consolidate hundreds of regional processing centers and eliminate Saturday mail deliveries.

title: Bahrain Holds Grand Prix, Keeping Protesters at Bay
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  Despite clashes between antigovernment protesters and the police in recent days, the Formula One Grand Prix, Bahrains showcase annual event, went off without incident on Sunday.

description: The day in sports, including the ice hockey under-18 world championships in the Czech Republic, the London Marathon, and the United States Olympic wrestling trials in Iowa City.

title: Do You Know Your Rights?
description: Under federal labor law, employees have the right to join together to seek better pay and working conditions, with or without a union. If an employer tries to punish organizers, employees have the right to seek protection from the National Labor Relations Board. But employees still dont have the right to be informed of their rights.

title: Mud-Less Season
description: There are clear advantages to a spring without mud. I have not lost a boot to the suction of the barnyard swamp. I havent had to cut drainage channels through the corral. Nor have I had to tractor through primeval ooze while hauling a round bale to the run-in shed.

title: Egypt Cancels the Delivery of Gas to Israel
description: CAIRO  Egypts state-owned natural gas company said Sunday that it was ending a deal to ship gas to Israel because of a payment dispute. Israeli officials responded by warning that the termination cast a new shadow over the bilateral peace treaty.

title: Newly Elected Myanmar Lawmakers Balk at Word in the Oath of Office
description: HONG KONG  Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the opposition leader in Myanmar, and 42 members of her party who won seats in Parliament in by-elections this month, insist they will not take the oath of office on Monday unless one word in it is changed. Instead of swearing to safeguard the countrys current Constitution, they want to say they will respect it. So far, the government has not agreed.

title: Good Wife Watch: A Familiar Face Returns to the Firm
description: Did she or didnt she? Viewers of The Good Wife aching for a resolution to the wacky Jackie story line were probably sorely disappointed by Sundays episode, The Penalty Box, in which Peter (Chris Noth) makes a brief appearance and Mommy Dearest (Mary Beth Peil) is but a ghost. With no reference to last weeks flurry of activity  Peter declared his gubernatorial candidacy, Alicia decided to stand by his side, Jackie was conveniently, and melodramatically, hospitalized  this installment had a Hamburger Helper feel to it: mostly filler, little meat.

title: The Cookstove Conundrum
description: Cooking the family meal can be a dangerous business for poor people in developing countries. According to a study by the World Health Organization, indoor air pollution from primitive household cooking fires is the leading environmental cause of death in the world. In most rural homes, which lack electricity, a stove can be an open fire and the fuel as basic as wood, dried animal dung or agricultural residue, together known as biomass fuels. The result is nearly 2 million deaths a year, worldwide, almost as many as are caused by malaria and tuberculosis combined. Whats worse, cooking with biomass releases carbon dioxide and black carbon into the atmosphere and consequently is a significant contributor to climate change.

title: Prelude to a Kiss
description: The house I grew up in was ordinary in most ways  a small stucco two-story in suburban Florida at the end of a block lined with more of the same. One thing did set it apart, though: it was outfitted with an advanced security system of 57 crucifixes. The crosses were strategically hung throughout the house: the moment you left the gaze-range of one Christ, you walked straight into the radar of another. There were no blind spots, not even in the bathroom. I understood and even admired their ubiquity. There was no place in the house where I could hide from scrutiny. It was checkmate.

title: First Among Estates
description: MOSCOW  As many as 65,000 people gathered in front of the Cathedral of Christ the Savior in Moscow on Sunday. Judging by the large number of buses parked nearby, theyd been brought in from various parts of Russia. This was not another anti-Putin protest; it was not even a protest: it was a huge communal prayer. Some of the participants were members of the clergy, dressed in gaudy gold-on-red church garb. But most appeared to be ordinary churchgoers whod heeded the clergys call to come pray in defense of the church. Its leaders say it is under attack.

description: Infosys executives have been advised that the United States Department of Homeland Security has found errors in a significant percentage of the companys business visa documents, Infosys said in an April 18 filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company and some of its employees are targets of an investigation by the United States Attorneys Office for the Eastern District of Texas, the filing said. The New York Times first wrote about the investigation last June.

title: What a Drip
description: The Chemex, that iconic nonelectric coffee maker, has finally met its match. The Kone filter from Able Brewing Equipment ($55 at ablebrewing.com) is a gorgeous piece of coffee gear, a stainless steel filter that fits most cone drippers, and whose precise holes (cut by a photochemical process) allow for a steady flow while minimizing sediment. The resulting best-of-both-worlds brew has the richness of French press and the clean flavor of drip. And unlike other metal filters, theres no mesh to scrub. Now in its third iteration (a bumper was added, and its holes reconfigured), the Kone is a fixture at next-generation coffee bars like Caf Grumpy on Manhattans Lower East Side and Intelligentsia Coffee and Tea in Venice, Calif. Ables founder, Keith Gehrke, a former roaster at a coffee company and a co-founder of Coava in Portland, Ore., is now working on a ceramic coffee maker. Soon, the Kone will have its match, too.

title: Thinking About Finances in the Search for a Missing Boy

title: The Simpsons Wishes a Happy Anniversary to (Almost) Everyone at Fox
description: As if celebrating Christmas at the end of April wasnt surprising enough: During a special night of programming to celebrate 25 years of the Fox network, the producers of The Simpsons slipped in the above title card at the end of a Sunday rerun of Simpsons Roasting on a Open Fire, the holiday-themed special that was the pilot for that satirical animated series. Its the latest in a long line of potshots that The Simpsons has taken at its corporate sibling, but will it be enough to reawaken the friendly(ish) war of words between that show and Fox News? Stay tuned.

title: Fact Check: Income Losses Under Obama
description: Mitt Romney has been citing an interesting economic statistic lately about the economy under Barack Obama: Well, lets look at what happened. On the bright side, the city will be spared the snow that western New York State is expecting. Highs here will reach the mid-50s.

title: Breakfast Meeting: The Search Is On for Missing Prime-Time Viewers
description: Where are all the television viewers? Thats the question network executives are asking, Bill Carter reports, as they study the lower ratings for prime-time programming this spring. Viewing is down across the board, and its affecting hit shows like Modern Family as well as less popular offerings. Network executives cite good weather and the change to daylight time, but some analysts see more fundamental reasons, including the sporadic scheduling of new episodes and the preference of more viewers to watch shows on a delayed basis, instead of live.

title: What Were Reading

title: Charles Colson, R.I.P.
description: I took the last week off from blogging and columnizing in order to do some promotion for my new book on American Christianity, Bad Religion, and thus far one of the questions Ive been asked most frequently involves the proper relationship between Christian faith and politics. In the book, I simultaneously argue that the corrupting influence of partisanship (on both the religious left and religious right) helps explain at least some of institutional Christianitys post-1960s decline,andthat Christians cannot simply be apolitical and leave partisan controversies alone, which would seem like the obvious way to avoid such corruption entirely. Which raises the obvious follow-up: Well, what would a healthier Christian engagement with political issues look like?

title: How to Protect Yourself From Your Own Investing Ignorance
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at BAM Advisor Services. His book, The Behavior Gap, was published earlier this year. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog.

title: BBC Ends Production on Upstairs, Downstairs Revival
