description: The European Union agreed Monday to suspend nearly all of its punitive sanctions against Myanmar even as a political dispute over the wording of a clause in the countrys Constitution kept Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the leader of the opposition, from attending her first day in Parliament.

title: An Owner Struggles With a Canine Military Complex
description: Dear Diary:I was walking on Broadway in the lower 90s. As I approached the corner of 93rd Street, I became aware of a slightly muffled cacophony of yelling and barking coming from around the corner.

title: Even in the N.B.A., Fists (and Elbows) of Fury
description: This was not a development we saw coming: the N.B.A. must have been feeling a little overlooked and falling short on societys lets-get-really-violent trend. After all, the N.H.L. was going all in on the bloodlust and getting all that fabulous publicity about its complete lack of regard for its players heads. So, in steps the player formerly known as Ron Artest, he of Malice at the Palace infamy, to throw an elbow at Oklahoma Citys James Harden vicious enough that the N.H.L.s discipline guru Brendan Shanahan reflexively fired up his video camera.

title: Tigers Burned Again by Umpire Error
description: The frustration was clear, and quite understandable, from the Detroit Tigers on Sunday. They had just lost, 3-2, in 11 innings, to the Texas Rangers at Comerica Park. The loss itself wasnt what irked the Tigers, but the way it happened  or rather, shouldnt have happened.

title: Morning Walkabout: 4/23
description: Talk Back In case you missed it, the Practical Traveler, Michelle Higgins, took a break from her weekly column to survey travel agents, who have experienced an uptick in business from people who want to save money and effort slogging through countless online reviews. Do you use a travel agent? Why or why not? (The New York Times)

title: Susan Barnes: 'Believe You're Worthy'
Romney Faults Obama on Portrayal of America
description: SOUTH PARK TOWNSHIP, Pa.  At a stop at a coal and natural gas company near Pittsburgh, Mitt Romney devoted much of his speech Monday to criticizing President Obama, implicitly faulting the president for apologizing for the country.

title: Business Day Live | April 23, 2012
description: What American Airlines hopes to achieve in bankruptcy court and LPL Financial's Jeffrey Kleintop on market outlook.

title: Business Day Live: American Airlines in Bankruptcy Court
description: What American Airlines hopes to achieve in bankruptcy court and LPL Financials Jeffrey Kleintop on market outlook.

title: Monday Motorsports: In Bahrain, Sebastian Vettel Rediscovers Winning Form
description: The stands were filled, the paddocks were buzzing and the racecars topped 195 miles per hour on the straights. The 2012 Bahrain Grand Prix happened.

title: No Sign Found of Boys Body as a Search in SoHo Ends
description: Federal agents and police detectives on Monday ended their lengthy search of a SoHo basement for evidence in the 1979 disappearance of Etan Patz, with the New York Police Departments chief spokesman saying no obvious human remains had been recovered.

title: Sounds of the Kitchen
description: For a new generation of American chefs, one of the most crucial ingredients in the kitchen is audible, not edible.

title: Tips for Fighting Fraud
description: Maybe youve noticed unnerving warning signals that an older adult has become entangled in financial fraud.

title: Knowing When to Put an End to Therapy
description: Is it time to call it quits with your therapist?

title: Sounds of the Kitchen
description: For New York chefs like Eddie Huang of Baohaus, one of the most crucial ingredients in the kitchen is audible, not edible.

title: Cheney File Traces Heart Care Milestones
description: WASHINGTON  For a man who has long battled advanced heart disease, Dick Cheney has had a remarkable streak of being in the right place at the right time.

title: What Are the Words of Wisdom You Live By?
description: In this weekends special health issue, my brother Daniel Smith writes about his (and my) various attempts to counter anxiety. In the adaptation from Daniels book Monkey Mind, he mentions a project I started years ago called the Book of Scott. As he rightly points out, it was born  in part  of envy.

title: Whos Rocking to the Music? Thats the Chef
description: THINGS can get frantic at Recette. Its one of those tiny West Village spots where the kitchen and the dining room rub up against each other like passengers in a packed subway car. But even in the pandemonium of a dinner rush, even with orders and questions pouring in from all directions, Jesse Schenker, the 29-year-old chef, manages to stay in the zone.

title: The Nations Champion Barista Makes it Look Easy
description: On Sunday, Katie Carguilo of Crown Heights, Brooklyn, became the first New Yorker to win the United States Barista Championship, held this year in Portland, Ore. A coffee trainer at the Counter Culture Coffee Training Center on West 26th Street in Manhattan, Ms. Carguilo, 28, bested 54 other contestants during the four-day competition. She will represent the United States in the World Barista Championship, to be held this June in Vienna.

title: The Eternal, Internal Mommy Wars
description: Wherein, in motherhood, lies the conflict?

title: Armed and Glamorous
description: In 2000, when the Philadelphia artist Adam Wallacavage began renovating his Victorian brownstone, each room of which has a different theme, old Charles Addams books were his design manual. Wednesday always had an octopus painted on the end of her bed, says the skateboarder turned photographer turned chandelier maker. That was pretty much the inspiration for the octopus chandeliers. Those chandeliers, which he originally designed for his 20,000 Leagues Under the Sea-themed living room, mix baroque styling with creepily realistic details like suction-cup-lined arms. The fixtures, handmade with epoxy clay or cast in plaster, have evolved to incorporate vintage squeaky toys and Hello Kitty heads, and will be on view this month in Shiny Monsters at the Philadelphia Art Alliance. I like to do a mix of goofy and elegant, Wallacavage says.

title: What Do You Listen to in the Kitchen?
description: I cant roast a chicken without music. I wouldnt even try.

title: Summer Scheduling: Soccer Coming to Yankee Stadium
description: Yankee Stadium is expected to play host to its first soccer matches this summer as part of the World Football Challenge. Details of the tournament are expected to be announced soon. While the Mets home, Citi Field, hosted exhibition games last year, the new Yankee Stadium has yet to host a soccer game, though its since-demolished predecessor had a great history of doing so.

title: U.S. Sets New Sanctions Against Technology for Syria and Iran
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama moved to tighten sanctions on Syria and Iran on Monday by taking aim at those who provide their authoritarian governments with technology to track down dissidents for abuse, torture or death.

title: E.F. Hutton Alumni Betting on 1980s Brand Appeal
description: In film, on television and in music, the 1980s are back with a vengeance. So why not on Wall Street, too?

title: Street Style: Collars and Bow Ties
description: The best of readers photos from the week of April 16.

title: MSNBCs Top Spokesman Leaves for Gannett
description: Jeremy Gaines, the top spokesman for the cable news channel MSNBC for the last decade, is leaving to take over corporate communications for the Gannett Company, the owner of USA Today and two dozen television stations.

title: UBS Lures Away Bank of America Executive
description: UBS is replenishing its ranks in America.

title: The Spirit of Sisterhood Is in the Air and on the Air
description: When first we meet Hannah, the wondrously mopey mid-20s heroine of HBOs new hit series Girls, she seems to have more strikes against her than a bowling alley at Fenway Park. Her parents have cut off her monthly stipend. Her literary-magazine boss refuses to turn her unpaid internship into a real job. Her atonal lover explores his sex fantasies on her awkwardly untitillated body. She lives in New York City. She majored in English.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Carla Ballecer and Karen Gereffi joined Johannes Leonardo, New York, part of WPP, in new posts. Ms. Ballecer becomes a senior copywriter and Ms. Gereffi becomes a senior art director. They worked together as a team at R/GA, New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, on accounts like Google, Nike and Walmart.

title: Viddy, a Video-Sharing App, Attracts Biz Stone and Shakira as Backers
description: After photo-sharing apps like Instagram, will the next big thing in social media be video-sharing apps?

title: He Aint Heavy, Hes My Metal Model
description: A marketer named Moscot has a new mascot, in the form of the heavy metal music community.

title: Microsoft Deal May Give Facebook Heft in Yahoo Patent Fight
description: 2:00 p.m. | Updated with Yahoo statement

title: Amid Hazing Concerns, Binghamton University Halts Pledging
description: April 27, 2012 | Updated  After a growing number of complaints about hazing, Binghamton University in New York has halted all pledging this spring at fraternities and sororities, our colleague Peter Applebome reports.

title: The Bee Gees Robin Gibb Emerges From Coma
description: Defying the predictions of his doctors, Robin Gibb, the Bee Gees singer, has emerged from a coma after more than a week, but he remains in intensive care and is battling advanced colorectal cancer, his physician said on Sunday.

title: TimesCast | April 23, 2012
description: A leftist wins the first round of the French presidential election | Newly elected officials protest their oath of office in Myanmar | The Nets bid farewell to New Jersey.

title: Prosecutor Says Clemens Obsessed Over Legacy
description: WASHINGTON  In their second chance in nine months to introduce Roger Clemenss perjury case to jurors, prosecutors in federal court portrayed Clemens on Monday as a man so bent at preserving his legacy as one of baseballs greatest pitchers that he lied to Congress about his use of performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Please Try This at Home
description: Anyone can explore the living world just as Alexander von Humboldt and Charles Darwin did, even homebodies willing to venture no farther than the terrain around their doorstep. The modern natural historian can capture with camera rather than rifle. Binoculars are handy, but not required. Jars are good for putting bugs into, and heavy books for pressing plants, and a person can never have too many field guides. The one must is a journal, in which explorers note each thing found, when and where. It can be motivating to maintain a running species tally.

title: Microsoft and Facebook Align Further With Patent Deal
description: SEATTLE  A plan by Facebook to acquire a broad range of patents through a deal with Microsoft is on its surface yet another twist in the battles over intellectual property engulfing the tech business.

title: Heavy Backpacks Can Spell Chronic Back Pain for Children
description: My 11-year-old grandsons, Stefan and Tomas, weigh about 80 pounds each. On the 20-minute walk to their middle school and the uphill walk home, they carry backpacks that weigh about 12 pounds each, or 15 percent of their body weight.

title: Government by Executive Order
description: President George W. Bush used his executive power to bypass Congress, almost as a matter of routine. Now President Barack Obama is pulling a similar stunt.

title: Mr. Smith Goes to Kutaisi
description: KUTAISI, Georgia  It took me more than three hours last Thursday to get from the center of Tbilisi, Georgias capital and commercial and cultural hub, to the countrys brand new Parliament building, a stadium-sized oyster-shell-shaped building enmeshed in steel netting. Thats because the Georgian Parliament is being relocated to Kutaisi, this small countrys second-largest city, some 150 miles west.

title: Investment Fund to Pay $1.3 Billion for Edinburgh Airport
description: LONDON  The investment fund Global Infrastructure Partners agreed on Monday to buy Edinburgh Airport for 807 million, or $1.3 billion, in its latest acquisition in the British airport sector.

title: Before Game 6, Tight and Tight-Lipped
description: OTTAWA  Daniel Alfredsson, the captain of the Ottawa Senators, said he was looking forward to playing Monday night; Brian Boyle is out; and there are two ways for an N.H.L. coach to be uncommunicative  a jolly way and a tight, simmering way.

title: So Much Life on a Little Patch of Earth
description: BELLINGHAM, Wash.  Ive logged thousands of miles to catch a glimpse of one exotic creature or another, to Costa Rica to be dazzled by the bird known as the resplendent quetzal, to Hawaii to admire sea turtles, to Venezuela to spy man-eating anacondas. So it seemed more than a little odd that the one time I made a sighting worthy of a scientific publication, I was looking out of my living room window.

title: Nestle Pays a High Price for Pfizer Unit
description: Nestl is throwing down its cash.

title: Riverdale, 6:20 A.M.
Pentagon Suspends Security Clearances in Scandal
description: BOGOT, Colombia  The Defense Department has suspended the security clearances of some of the 11 members of the military who are under investigation in a widening prostitution scandal in Colombia, Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta said Monday.

title: Look of The Moment | Rosie Huntington-Whiteley
description: The Look: Making the Cutoff. Add a dash of embellishment and pair with a crisp white shirt.

title: Beijing Auto Show: Volkswagen E-Bugster Presages Shape of Drop-Top Beetle
description: Volkswagen used the Beijing auto show to unveil a convertible version of its E-Bugster, an electrically powered Beetle concept first shown in Detroit in January.

title: M.T.A. Driver Charged With Keeping Woman on Bus
description: A city bus driver was arrested in the Bronx and charged with unlawful imprisonment Sunday night after he refused to let the police take an emotionally disturbed woman off his bus, the police said.

title: Neils Hit Hangs Over Rangers-Senators Series
description: OTTAWA  A question about retribution hung in the air Monday morning ahead of Game 6 of the Rangers-Senators series. It centered on this Game 5 hit by Ottawas Chris Neil on the Rangers Brian Boyle

title: Losing the Future: Gutting Science Training
description: Last month I wrote about how state budget cuts were forcing public universities to raise tuition and cut programs. Some of the subjects most valuable for job and economic growth  like engineering, computer science and health sciences  have been most vulnerable, because they also happen to be among the most expensive to teach.

title: A Red Sox Moment Even Nonfans Could Love
description: Even a Yankees fan could love this photo. Well, maybe on best behavior.

title: NATO Shows Confidence in Afghan Security Forces
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A week after a complex insurgent attack paralyzed the capital, NATO commanders on Monday offered a startlingly buoyant assessment of security gains across the country and of the readiness of the Afghan police and the army to take full control of their country as American and other international forces leave.

title: Review of White House Staff Shows No Misconduct in Colombia
description: The White House said on Monday that it had investigated its own staff members and concluded that none of them were involved in the prostitution scandal in Colombia that has ensnared members of the Secret Service and the military.

title: Police Report Lead in Theft of Chinese Artifacts from Cambridge Universitys Fitzwilliam Museum
description: Police think that a stolen white minivan may have been used in a theft earlier this month of precious works of art from China worth nearly $29 million from the Fitzwilliam Museum at the University of Cambridge in England, the BBC reported.

title: In a Rivalry Game, Maryland Lacrosse Edges Hopkins
description: One of the greatest rivalries in lacrosse lived up to its advance billing on Saturday night, when Johns Hopkins and Maryland played their 108th game. The sold-out crowd of 8,500 at Homewood Field saw a thrilling battle between the Blue Jays and the Terrapins, two top-ten teams.

title: Resignation of Police Chief in Martin Case Is Rejected
description: SANFORD, Fla.  Several hours after the city manager publicly announced that he had reached an agreement with Chief Bill R. Lee Jr. to resign over the Sanford Police Departments handling of the Trayvon Martin shooting case, the City Commission voted late Monday afternoon to reject Chief Lees resignation.

title: Really? Optimism Reduces the Risk of Heart Disease
description: THE FACTS

title: Reader Idea | English Language Learners Discuss Love and Happiness
description: Here is another in our Great Ideas From Readers series.

title: Plea for Bushwick High: Give Last-Chance School Another Chance
Whos Afraid of Lindsay Lohan? Troubled Star to Play Elizabeth Taylor
description: Its pretty clear what Elizabeth Taylor and Lindsay Lohan have in common: Ms. Taylor was one of Hollywoods most talented and prolific actresses who performed in such enduring films as Cat on a Hot Tin Roof, Suddenly, Last Summer and Butterfield 8, while Ms. Lohan has performed janitorial duties at a morgue while awaiting a probation violation hearing.

title: Donations for Eyeglasses in Poor Nations Are Better Than Recycling Used Pairs
description: Giving used eyeglasses to poor countries may please the donors, but it is not worth the high delivery costs, a new study has concluded, and a $10 donation would do more good.

title: Social Securitys Financial Health Worsens
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration reported a significant deterioration in the financial outlook for Social Security on Monday, while stating that the financial condition of Medicare was stable but still unsustainable.

title: Americans Remain Wary of the Stock Market, Survey Finds
description: Americans may be starting to feel more financially secure, but many remain wary of investing in the stock market, a new poll from Bankrate.com finds.

title: A Europe Tired of Cutbacks Has Few Alternatives
description: FRANKFURT  Citizens from Prague to Paris to Amsterdam have made it abundantly clear the last few days that they are tired of the economic austerity forced on them by the euro zone debt crisis.

title: Under Scrutiny, Google Spends Record Amount on Lobbying
description: With Congress and privacy watchdogs breathing down its neck, Google is stepping up its lobbying presence inside the Beltway  spending more than Apple, Facebook, Amazon and Microsoft combined in the first three months of the year.

title: Michaels Stores C.E.O. Connected to Wal-Mart Bribery Case
description: As Michaels Stores prepares to go public, the companys chief executive, John B. Menzer, has been connected to the Mexican bribery inquiry facing Wal-Mart Stores.

title: Safety: Accidental Child Deaths Ebb; Risks Do Not
description: Accidental deaths among children under age 20 declined 29 percent from 2000 to 2009, according to a report from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, but deaths from poisoning and suffocation increased substantially.

title: TimesCast | French Elections
description: April 23, 2012  On Monday, analysts attributed part of a sharp drop in European markets to a narrow first-round victory by an anti-austerity Socialist in the French presidential election.

title: American Car Parts Makers Gain in Russia
description: MOSCOW  Critics of the Obama administrations thawed diplomatic policy toward Russia, known as the reset, say it has brought few concrete results. But this week, a visiting American trade delegation is promoting an economic benefit  a doubling of exports of American car parts to Russia over the past year.

title: Assessing the Small Business Tax Cut
description: Early last week, the Democrats held a vote on a tax bill that defined their political philosophy but had no chance of passing. That was the Paying a Fair Share Act of 2012, better known as the Buffett Rule, which failed to get the 60 votes necessary for the Senate to take up the bill. On Thursday, House Republicans countered by passing their Small Business Tax Cut. The bill cleared the House handily, 235-173, largely on party lines, but it is no more likely to become law than the Buffett Rule.

title: Ex-Prime Minister of Iceland Convicted on Charge Related to Financial Crisis
description: 6:05 p.m. | Updated

title: Vermont Weighs Ending Vaccine Exemption
description: Vermont lawmakers are considering eliminating the philosophical exemption to the vaccination requirements that usually apply to children attending school and day care in the state. Vermont has one of the highest rates in the country of children who arent vaccinated according to the schedule recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and supporters of ending the exemption (which essentially allows parents to opt out of some or all of the recommended vaccinations on behalf of their children) argue that low vaccination rates contributed to an outbreak of pertussis in the state earlier this year.

title: White House Announces Arts Education Plan
description: President Obama, aided by prominent artists, hopes to help turn around low-performing schools with a new arts education program, the White House announced on Monday.

title: Leaderless for Months, CBS Films Appoints Co-Presidents
description: LOS ANGELES  After a difficult start in 2007, CBS Films continues to regroup quietly, and on Monday it named Terry Press and Wolfgang Hammer co-presidents.

title: Prevention: Shingles Vaccine Is Shown to Be Very Safe
description: A study of people who received the shingles vaccine has found that it is safe and well tolerated, with an extremely low rate of side effects.

title: Patterns: Brain Scans Forecast Eating and Sexual Behavior
description: Researchers have succeeded in predicting eating behavior and levels of sexual desire.

title: When Reyes Returns to Citi Field, Will Cheers Follow?
description: David Wright said he expected Jose Reyes to receive a warm reception from the Citi Field crowd when he returns Tuesday night with the Miami Marlins, the team Reyes joined as a free agent this winter.

title: Facebooks Profit Falls 12% Ahead of Expected Offering
description: With its initial public offering drawing closer, Facebook disclosed on Monday that its profit in the first quarter fell 12 percent, to $205 million, as its expenses continued to climb.

title: Mothers Challenge a Trace Contaminant in Tide
description: In their quest to rid cleaning products of toxic chemicals, consumer advocates have now set their sights on Tide, the best-selling laundry detergent.

title: A Ratings Reprieve for the Networks
description: After plummeting to new depths in the ratings last week, the broadcast networks were granted a small reprieve on Sunday. According to Nielsens estimates, overall numbers were up when compared to last weeks in both total viewers and in the a18-to-49-year-old demographic coveted by most advertisers. ABC in particular received some positive news, its second Hallmark Hall of Fame film, Firelight, drew 7.6 million total viewers, an improvement over the 6.5 million that watched the networks first Hallmark movie last fall, Mitch Alboms Have a Little Faith. Once Upon A Time (also on ABC) was up slightly when compared to its last new episode from three weeks ago, from 8.36 million total viewers to 8.84 million.

title: The Confusion of Hospital Pricing
description: When Augie Hong awoke with severe abdominal pain nearly two years ago, he went to the hospital emergency room closest to his home in San Francisco. The diagnosis was acute appendicitis, and doctors removed his inflamed appendix.

title: TimesCast | Myanmar's Political Discord
description: April 23, 2012  After months of campaigning and a landmark election in Myanmar, Monday was supposed to be the first day of Parliament for former political dissident Aung Sun Su Kyi.

title: Pretty Famous, but Still Star-Struck
Street Style: Coachella
description: Looks from the second weekend of the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival in Indio, Calif.

title: Mexican Immigration to U.S. Slowed Significantly, Report Says
description: Mexican immigration to the United States, the largest wave of migrants from a single country in the nations history, has stopped increasing after four decades of surging growth and may be declining, according to a report released Monday by the Pew Hispanic Center.

title: Instagram Deal Puts Horowitz on Defensive
description: Ben Horowitz, the co-founder of venture capital giant Andreessen Horowitz, has one thing to say to the armchair quarterbacks who criticized his decision not to double down on Instagram: Check the scoreboard.

title: Dutch Governing Coalition Resigns After Failing to Pass Austerity Budget
description: THE HAGUE  The Dutch prime minister, Mark Rutte, announced the resignation of his coalition government on Monday after its partners failed to agree on austerity measures, leaving the Netherlands with a messy leadership vacuum at a time of anxiety about the euro.

title: Noodle Soups From the Garden: Simple Vegetarian Pho Broth
description: Not long ago I had a delicious vegetarian pho in a Vietnamese restaurant in Los Angeles. The broth was heady with sweet spices and, like the traditional meaty soup, was served with rice noodles, bean sprouts and fresh herbs. I asked the waiter if he knew how the chef made the stock, and the sous chef came out and told me it involved lots of vegetables (well, yes), spices and  MSG! Though I often get headaches after eating monosodium glutamate, this restaurant didnt use much of it. Still, when I left, I was determined to come up with my own meatless version of pho, sans MSG.

title: Met Opera Unveils Summer Season
description: Free full-scale performances by the Metropolitan Opera in New York Citys parks increasingly look like a thing of the past. For the fifth summer in a row, the Met will present recitals instead of complete opera performances.

title: More Bartender Rock': Readers Choices
description: In my last post here, I asked readers to chime in on this whole nebulous business of bartender rock. A few went a long way toward defining it, getting much further than I did. Here, for example, isexplainer guy from Chicago: I think the throughline as to what qualifies is that it has credibility. . . . Its music that doesnt insist upon itself, but rather catches peoples ears and pushes them to ask, Who is this? Peter from Oakland added, A certain raggedness  or at least a roughness around the edges  seems to define much of what youve suggested.

title: A Dastardly Plot to Avoid Taxes
description: Contrary to the conventional wisdom, Republicans are not against all tax increases. Rep. Eric Cantor, the House Majority Leader, thinks poor people might need a tax hike.

title: The Trade Show, Updated
description: The convention and meetings business is a middle-aged child of the jet age, nurtured by cities that built or greatly expanded exhibition halls, starting in the 1970s, to compete for corporate and association events.

title: U.N. Observers Prove Little Deterrent to Syrian Attacks
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian government forces engaged in a bloody game of cat and mouse against United Nations observers on Monday, seeming to punish cities like Hama after the monitors left for daring to protest, and adopting a low profile as the monitors visited the Damascus suburbs.

title: Recasting Gives a Lift to Sister Act
description: Recasting shows can be a challenge for Broadway producers when stars leave once their contracts are up  even causing some shows to shutter, as Promises, Promises did in 2011 when producers saw little upside in replacing Sean Hayes and Kristin Chenoweth. But one Broadway musical has been having a good run of late with its new leading lady: The musical Sister Act has been performing far better at the box office since the former child star Raven-Symon took over the lead role of Deloris Van Cartier on March 27.

title: Interview With Alex Karpovsky
description: Alex Karpovsky discusses his leading roles in the thriller Rubberneck, which he also directed, and the comedy Supporting Characters. Both films played at the Tribeca Film Festival in 2012.

title: Now Booking | Patagonias Best Beds
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: At Kennedy Airport, an Artist Fights to Save Her Sculpture
description: The managing agent for four airlines that run Terminal 1 at John F. Kennedy Airport had a plan: remove and destroy a two-story-tall sculpture that they commissioned 14 years ago and bring in more food stands.

title: The Urge To Tighten
description: Do we need this? Sheila Bair has joined the crew urging the Fed to stop trying to promote economic recovery, on the grounds that its feeding a bond bubble.

title: Bushism Forever
description: Just to confirm what I said in todays column:

title: For 50th Birthday of Shelby Cobra, Vintage Snakes Convene in California
description: In February 1962, Carroll Shelby set out to beat the Chevrolet Corvette by inserting a Ford V-8 engine into a lithe A.C. Ace roadster from England. Born humbly in the speed shop of Dean Moon near Los Angeles, the resulting Shelby Cobra would achieve nobility. And the road-going production version, built on Princeton Avenue in Los Angeless Venice neighborhood, sold well for a specialty model, a less punitively priced alternative to the Ferrari.

title: Honoring a Fathers Memory With Words Carved More Deeply Than an Epitaph
description: If I were forced to describe Hctor Abads memoir, Oblivion, in a single word, that word would probably be: meh. His book is, to quote an offhandedly poisonous Paul Simon song lyric from the 1980s, all right in a sort of limited way for an off night.

title: Deployments Hard Lessons for Children, and Their Teachers
description: Maren Newbold is a rising kindergartner at Yuma Lutheran School in Arizona. Shes a 5-year-old with a cheeky grin, shiny blond hair and a tiny, almost whispery voice. Shes also getting ready to bid her father farewell: hes a Marine Corps aviator stationed at Marine Corps Air Station Yuma, about to embark on his second deployment in two years.

title: Jimi Hendrix, dith Piaf and Other #KitchenPlaylist Staples
description: First we asked chefs to share their cooking playlists; now weve turned to you. Below are a few highlights culled from Twitter; tweet yours at @nytdining using the hashtag #kitchenplaylist.

title: Tribeca Video: Alex Karpovskys Pair of Firsts at the Festival
description: Alex Karpovsky may be one of the hardest working actor-filmmakers you dont know well. A regular player on the indie scene, Mr. Karpovsky has directed five films in the past decade and appeared in a dozen movies in the past two years. He frequently pops up in films that play South by Southwest and Sundance. But this is a year of firsts for him. He has his first recurring role on a television series (Lena Dunhams Girls) and hes making his first appearance at the Tribeca Film Festival with two movies: Rubberneck, a psychological thriller that he also directed, and Supporting Characters, a comedy in which he plays a film editor. In this video, Mr. Karpovsky discusses his work both in front of and behind the camera.

title: For David Paterson, Next Stop: M.T.A.
description: Over the years, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority board has had among its members its share of lawyers, failed mayoral candidates, union leaders  even the wife of a former Beatle.

title: Bill Would Crack Down on Lavish Events
description: The Senate will be voting on Tuesday on a broad measure to limit spending at government conferences, and Senator Tom Coburn, the Oklahoma Republican who is the amendments author, wants his colleagues to know lavish events are not confined to the General Services Administration, which came under fire recently for holding an extravagant conference in Las Vegas.

title: When Bots Attack
description: Hmm. In my inbox:

title: Drilling Down: Making the Most of Cookiegate
description: In Mondays Dashboard roundup of small-business news, we highlighted the experience of John Walsh and his Bethel Bakery, a Pittsburgh-area institution that found itself in the national spotlight last week when Mitt Romney compared his cookies to those at 7-Eleven. Mr. Walsh immediately responded by promoting a Cookiegate Special. We went back to him to see how its going. A condensed version of the conversation follows.

title: Vegetarian Pho With Asparagus and Noodles
description: When I make pho with vegetables other than those used to make the broth, as in this springtime pho, I cook the vegetables separately, so as not to infuse their flavor into the broth, and very briefly, so that they retain some crunch. I like to use thick stalks of asparagus and cut them on the diagonal into 2-inch lengths.

title: Sudanese Warplanes Said to Attack South
description: An aerial bombardment and ground assault on South Sudan in recent days indicated that fighting with Sudan may not be over.

title: Sweetness That Bites Back
description: FREAKISH. Bizarre. Absurd. Beyond human experience. And thats been the more measured reaction to the 2010 vintage for German rieslings, which consisted of an unusually small crop of grapes that combined ludicrously high levels of acidity with unexpected amounts of sweetness.

title: Even in a Prime Neighborhood, Some Forlorn Vacancies
description: As you walk east on 82nd Street with the Metropolitan Museum of Art at your back, Madison Avenue up ahead and lavish homes all around, you might not notice the pretty, pink town house on the south side of the street, No. 12. Its brick facade and white marble base seem perfectly at ease in the neighborhood, but if you stop for a moment and look up, you will see that several windows on the face of this fine building, on this most pristine block, are shattered.

title: S.E.C. Charges Former Calpers Chief With Fraud
description: Federal regulators charged the former chief executive of the nations largest pension fund on Monday with defrauding a private equity firm into paying $20 million to his close friend, the latest case to raise questions about suspected conflicts of interest at state retirement funds.

title: Barnes & Noble Shares Surge 18% After Jana Takes a Stake
description: Shares in the bookseller Barnes & Noble soared more than 18 percent on Monday after the hedge fund Jana Partners bought a 12 percent stake in the company.

title: A Face in the Sun
description: Q. Will a facial moisturizer with S.P.F. 15 protection keep the skin from generating vitamin D on a sunny day?

title: Big Price Tags Attached to Even the Littlest Leagues
description: Youth baseball and softball seasons are opening across the United States. It is a time for youngsters to field grounders and work on their swings while their parents determine whether they need to take out a home-equity loan before heading to the sporting goods store.

title: Netflix Added 3 Million Online Subscribers in Quarter, but Expects Slower Growth
description: Netflix said on Monday that it finished the first quarter with nearly three million more streaming subscribers than it had started with, showing continued interest from Internet users despite the companys missteps last year.

title: Ravens Can Recognize Old Friends, and Foes, Too
description: Ravens have the ability to recognize old friends, a new study reports. And just like humans, they react negatively when seeing a foe.

title: Many Veterans Face Long Wait for Mental Health Evaluations, Report Finds
description: The inspector general for the Department of Veterans Affairs released a report on Monday confirming what many veterans have long suspected: it takes longer to get a mental health evaluation from V.A. clinicians than the department has been willing to acknowledge.

title: Portugals Finance Minister: We Tried Stimulus and It Didnt Work
description: Defending austerity is not getting any easier for Europes politicians. And Vitor Gaspar, Portugals finance minister, has it harder than others. The countrys unemployment rate is 14 percent, and its economy, which has been stagnant for years, is expected to shrink another 3.3 percent in 2012.

title: More Reserve Teachers Finding Permanent Jobs
TimesCast | A Farewell to New Jersey
description: April 23, 2012 - Monday night, the Nets will play their final basketball game in New Jersey.

title: The Bill Clinton Habit
description: If you were running the re-election campaign for President Obama, who would you ask for advice? Perhaps the man who almost destroyed his own presidency, and contributed to his wifes loss in the 2008 primaries?

title: A Bounty Hunter in the Big Easy
description: Gene Thacker, a New Orleans bounty-hunter known as Tat-2, is the central figure in Big Easy Justice, a 10-part series on Spike on Tuesday nights.

title: Shakespeare and the City
description: Michael Cooper, who covers cities and urban affairs for the national desk of The New York Times, spent part of Monday, Shakespeares birthday, highlighting the playwrights best lines about #cities.

title: A Surprising Risk for Toddlers on Playground Slides
description: Last spring, Katie Dickman of Dunkirk, Md., was at the playground with her 18-month-old toddler, Hannah, when the little girl asked to ride down a twisting slide. Ms. Dickman accompanied her daughter, carefully keeping the child on her lap as they coasted to the bottom.

title: Heart Transplants for Older Patients
description: Is Dick Cheney just the first of a new wave of older patients who will be receiving heart transplants?

title: Elizabeth Warren Introduces Herself to Massachusetts Voters in New Ad
description: BOSTON  In a new television ad, Elizabeth Warren compares her climb from modest roots, to the struggles of college students today, who she says, drown in debt while big corporations like G.E. pay nothing  zero  in taxes.

title: A wildlife expedition close to home; girlfriends of many species; and puncturing a myth about obesity.
description: A wildlife expedition close to home; girlfriends of many species; and puncturing a myth about obesity.

title: Prowling New Orleans With Guns Galore
description: NEW ORLEANS  The man known as Tat-2 didnt want his passengers to feel uneasy as he gave them a personal tour of greater New Orleans the other day.

title: How Testing Is Hurting Teaching
Todays Scuttlebot: RIM Revamping and a $35 PC
description: Here are some of the most interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Monday. There are more here.

title: Facing Cyberattack, Iranian Officials Disconnect Some Oil Terminals From Internet
description: TEHRAN  Iran disconnected several of its main Persian Gulf oil terminals from the Internet on Monday, local news media reported, as technicians were struggling to contain what they said were intensifying cyberattacks on the Oil Ministry and its affiliates.

title: Next Up to Bat: A Whiff of the Yankees
description: Its practically a Zen koan: what is the smell of 27 World Series championships?

title: Pictures of the Day: South Sudan and Elsewhere
description: Photos from South Sudan, Bahrain, Syria and the Philippines.

title: New Editor for Chicago Sun-Times
description: The Chicago Sun-Times and its sister print and digital media properties have a new editor. Wrapports, the investment company that owns the Sun-Times Media group, announced on Monday it had appointed Jim Kirk to the newly created role of editor in chief and senior vice president.

title: Petits Pois de LOustau de Baumanire
description: Adapted from Sylvestre Wahid

title: Xerox Results Exceed Predictions
description: Xerox, a provider of copiers, printers and business services, reported first-quarter earnings on Monday that exceeded analysts estimates after companies and governments farmed out more tasks to cut costs.

title: Provenal Peas
description: At LOustau de Baumanire, a restaurant-cum-hotel in Les Baux, France, the peas go from garden in the morning to table at lunchtime.

title: Spring Brings Caviar in a Pod
description: PARIS

title: Boehner Sees One-in-Three Chance G.O.P. Will Lose House
description: Speaker John A. Boehner of Ohio said on Monday that Republicans had a one-in-three chance of losing control of the House in November, a surprisingly downbeat assessment from a Republican leader who until now has expressed no fears of losing the gavel.

title: New Albums From Jack White, Sarah Jaffe and Kenny Garrett
description: JACK WHITE

title: In Pursuit of Riches, and Travelers Supplies, in the Asteroid Belt
description: Perhaps it will be a platinum rush that finally opens up the final frontier.

title: American Airlines Cites Progress in Labor Talks
description: American Airlines went to court on Monday to ask a bankruptcy judge to void labor agreements with its three unions, though it signaled that the carrier had made progress in talks with one of those unions, representing its mechanics, that might result in fewer job cuts than American initially sought.

title: A Little Sondheim Music, 17 Ways, but No Words
description: The songs of Stephen Sondheim represent such an ideal marriage of lyrics and music that it is hard to imagine these elements divorced. Still, on its own, Mr. Sondheims music is as rich, intricate and ingenious as music can be.

title: Behind the Story: A Cancer Doctor on Depression and the Possible Next Antidepressant
description: Siddhartha Mukherjee, whosearticle on depression appears in this weeks health issue, is an assistant professor of medicine in the division of medical oncology at Columbia University. His book, The Emperor of All Maladies: A Biography of Cancer, a portion of which was adapted in the magazine as The Cancer Sleeper Cell, won the 2011 Pulitzer Prize in general nonfiction. Mukherjee has also written for the magazine on whether the use of cellphones can cause cancer.

title: Dancing Shoes Are Optional
description: Encores at recitals tend to display an artists virtuosity and range; it is rare that they can stand as symbols of the concerts they cap. But when the pianist Kirill Gerstein played a dazzling, slippery tude arrangement (by Earl Wild) of the Gershwins I Got Rhythm at the end of his exhilarating solo debut at the 92nd Street Y on Saturday, it neatly encapsulated what he had been doing so excellently all evening.

title: American Track Gets New Leader
description: Just three months before the London Olympics and more than a year after its last chief executive left in a messy, protracted dispute, USA Track and Field finally settled on a new leader on Monday. In hiring Max Siegel, it did not travel far from its home base, choosing a former board member who has been serving as a marketing consultant for the organization since last year.

title: Sheep Crochets, Pig Flips, Rats Wear Parkas, and Dragon Outsmarts Man
description: Dorothy had only the Scarecrow, the Tin Man, the Cowardly Lion and Toto. Snow White had just seven dwarfs. Lilly, however, the young heroine of The Dragon Child, has all 12 animals of the Chinese zodiac to help her face the challenges of life. One of the beasts, as the title would indicate, is her parent. But, as it goes in fairy tales, the parent is mostly absent.

title: Fly and Human Mothers Share a Milk Enzyme
description: Female tsetse flies produce only one egg at a time. The larva hatches in the mothers uterus, and she feeds it with a milklike substance that she produces.

title: The Neurological Roots of Lingering Regret
description: Studies have suggested that older adults are better off letting go of regrets, while younger adults, with more time left to make life changes, may benefit more from holding on to them.

title: The Path to Veganism (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Handle With Caution (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Hollywood Strivers at Home in Their Anthill
description: We loved Teenage Wasteland, the adoring fan tells the aging (as in late 20s) actress, bemoaning the quick cancellation of the show that made her sort of famous. The creators have a new show set up at CW, right?

title: For All the Fish in the Sea (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Pho With Spinach and Tofu
description: You can fuse Asian cuisines in this version of pho, substituting soba for the rice noodles and seasoning the tofu with a little soy sauce.

title: Before Its I.P.O., Google Looked Stronger Than Facebook
description: How did Google do?

title: China Extends Reach Into International Art
description: SHANGHAI  Chinas drive to achieve world status in more than just economic power has now turned to art museums, a push that is also resulting in the showing of more Chinese art in the United States.

title: Pho With Broccoli and Quinoa
description: This time I decided to include a high-protein grain in my vegetarian pho broth instead of traditional noodles. The broccoli is thinly sliced and steamed or blanched separately.

title: Too Many Receipts? A Solution in Your Pocket
description: YOU know what makes me feel as if Im on the road circa 1987? Those annoying blank receipts that taxi drivers hand you at the end of the ride.

title: A New Variant of Malware Takes Aim at Mac Users
description: Earlier this month, security researchers discovered a new piece of malware had infected more than half a million Apple computers in what was the largest-scale attack on Apples Mac OS X operating system to date.

title: Pho With Carrots, Turnips, Broccoli and Tofu
description: I like this sweet, colorful combination of julienne carrots and turnips with either traditional rice noodles or heartier buckwheat soba. The carrots and turnips can be simmered directly in the stock, as they will contribute to its sweet flavor. The broccoli should be steamed separately.

title: Excerpt: 'The Lyons'
description: A scene from Nicky Silver's play, now on Broadway at the Cort Theater with, from left, Linda Lavin, Kate Jennings Grant, Dick Latessa and Michael Esper.

title: In Europe, Now What?
His Imagination Leaps Onto the Page
description: The adventurous New Victory Theater seems to be on a mission to prove that theater for children can be serious without being ponderous. In The Book of Everything, an adaptation of a novel by the Dutch writer Guus Kuijer, the 9-year-old hero, Thomas Klopper, must deal with weighty matters: religion, fear, a tyrannical father.

title: Romney Backs Extending Low Interest Rates on Student Loans
description: CHESTER TOWNSHIP, Pa.  Mitt Romney circled back at the end of a brief news conference Monday afternoon to clarify an issue he had failed to mention before: his support of a temporary extension of a low interest rate on federal student loans, which President Obama also favors.

title: Not Much Suspense Likely in New York G.O.P. Primary
description: Three weeks ago, Republican officials in New York imagined presidential candidates barnstorming across the state, voters turning out for the states primary in droves, and people across the country waiting in suspense for the results.

title: Two Cuban Actors in Tribeca Film Missing After Flight to Florida
description: Una Noche, or One Night, a film showing at the Tribeca Film Festival, tells the story of three young Cubans who decide to defect to the United States, and last week the three main actors were scheduled to join the films director, Lucy Mulloy, at the New York premiere. But a funny thing happened when the plane landed in Miami last Wednesday: two of the actors promptly disappeared.

title: Saints Deny Listening In on Rival Coaches
description: The New Orleans Saints denied a report Monday that said General Manager Mickey Loomis had the ability to eavesdrop on opposing coaches during games from 2002 to 2004.

title: Rubio Is Latest Possible Running Mate to Join Romney on the Campaign Trail
description: CHESTER TOWNSHIP, Pa.  Senator Marco Rubio of Florida looked on respectfully Monday afternoon as Mitt Romney addressed a group of reporters in a suburb of Philadelphia. He clasped his hands behind his back, rested them on his hips and folded them in front of him. He nodded almost imperceptibly at the appropriate times and, later, clapped along with the crowd.

title: Is Quick Therapy the Best Therapy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpt: 'Nice Work If You Can Get It'
description: Kelli OHara sings Someone to Watch Over Me from the new Broadway show at the Imperial Theater.

title: Virginia Tech Fires Its Mens Coach
description: Virginia Tech fired Seth Greenberg as its mens basketball coach after nine seasons, after an exodus of assistants in recent years that left the program lacking the sort of continuity and collegiality Athletic Director Jim Weaver said he sought. Greenberg, whose only N.C.A.A. tournament trip with the Hokies came in 2007, did not learn that he had been fired until about an hour after a release was sent to reporters about a news conference later in the day.

title: Davis Drops to .136; Mets Drop to .500
description: The sun never came out during a prolonged day at Citi Field  leaving a small crowd shivering in the dark cold and drizzle  and neither did the Mets offense.

title: Benefits of Nuclear Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Defense Department Plans New Intelligence Gathering Service
description: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon is revamping its spy operations to focus on high-priority targets like Iran and China in a reorganization that reflects a shift away from the war zones of Iraq and Afghanistan that have dominated Americas security landscape for the past decade.

title: Access to Healthy Foods
description: To the Editor:

title: The Depressing Lot of the Conflicted American Mother
description: Motherlode has asked women at different stages of their family and career lives to respond to Elisabeth Badinters The Conflict by describing how reading it has affected their views or plans for work and motherhood. The following is a continuation of an ongoing conversation.

title: When Lawyers File Suit for Accessible Workplaces
description: To the Editor:

title: Nigerias Population Boom: A Problem, or Not?
description: To the Editor:

title: Tissue Maker Takes Flushables to Facebook
description: AMONG users of moist toilet paper wipes, 54 percent keep the product hidden from view, most often under the bathroom sink, according to consumer research by Kimberly-Clark, which makes Cottonelle Fresh Care, the leading flushable wipe. That troubles the brand, which reports that consumers who display wipes openly  typically atop the toilet tank  tend to use them twice as frequently.

title: Yankees-Rangers Will Pair Japanese Pitchers
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  For the seventh time in major league history, two Japanese pitchers are scheduled to start against one another, and for perhaps the first time, it will be two of the best.

title: Louisiana: Prison Conditions Draw Threat
description: In a sternly worded letter delivered to the Orleans Parish sheriff on Monday, the federal Department of Justice threatened litigation if urgent and substantial action were not taken to address widespread constitutional violations at the Orleans Parish Prison. Last November, as Mondays letter publicly disclosed, federal officials sent the sheriff a draft consent decree, an agreed-upon but judicially mandated blueprint for comprehensive reform. The letter charged that the sheriff, Marlin Gusman, had failed to seriously negotiate since then, and that problems found in a federal investigation into the jail over two years ago have persisted or have worsened. In response to growing criticism, Sheriff Gusman announced the closing of one of the largest buildings at the jail complex two weeks ago.

title: A Good Brain Drain
description: To the Editor:

title: Rhode Island: Pension Changes Proposed in Providence
description: Mayor Angel Taveras of Providence proposed a $638 million budget that assumes additional contributions from the citys tax-exempt institutions and pension system changes. Mr. Taveras called on the City Council to adopt pension changes that he said would save at least $16 million in the coming fiscal year. The changes would also reduce the citys unpaid pension liability, currently more than $900 million, by more than $236 million, he said. Changes to the pension system would most likely be challenged in court. Earlier this year, Mr. Taveras, a first-term Democrat, warned of possible bankruptcy unless the city found new revenues and significantly cut spending on its retirees.

title: Numberplay Will Not Appear This Week
description: We apologize for the inconvenience. Numberplay will appear as usual next week.

title: Civilians Describe Atrocities in Blue Nile
description: Two men in a detention center are burned to death. A woman, breastfeeding her child, is executed with a machine gun on the spot. A pregnant woman, whose only crime is sitting in the wrong market at the wrong time, has her leg blown off by an Antonov bomb.

title: City Council to Assess Easing Steep Fines on Street Vendors
description: Moustapha Cisses entrepreneurial ambitions all but died last month.

title: In Barcelona, Passion and Worry Fill Air Around a Team Not Used to Losing
description: BARCELONA  The heart of Catalonia burst with color on Monday as an unending array of roses covered the sidewalks from Las Ramblas to Avinguda Diagonal up near the Camp Nou stadium. April 23 here is La Diada de Sant Jordi, a celebration of St. George, Catalonias patron saint, who inspires a cultural phenomenon that is remarkably similar to Valentines Day  though with less chocolate and, oddly, more books.

title: For an Old Italian Game, a Crescendo of Sorts
description: There was one corner of Woodlawn that seemed as if it would always remain stubbornly Italian: the bocce courts in Van Cortlandt Park.

title: As China Official Rose, His Familys Wealth Grew
description: DALIAN, China  Just a few weeks before his dramatic fall from power, Bo Xilai wrote an inscription in calligraphy, praising the Chongqing Water Assets Management Company, and urging support for its operations.

title: The Europeans Are Revolting
description: Robin has a comment on the implications of European turmoil at the Guardians Comment is Free.

title: In a Change, Mexico Reins In Its Oil Monopoly
description: COATZINTLA, Mexico  For seven decades, Pemex, Mexicos state-owned oil monopoly and a mainstay of the governments revenue, regulated itself  which is a polite way of saying it could do pretty much as it pleased.

title: Peace Without Partners
description: Tel Aviv

title: Actress Takes Stand at Trial in the Killings of Relatives
description: CHICAGO  Preparations for the arrival of Jennifer Hudson, the singer and actress and beloved product of Chicago, at this citys criminal courthouse were elaborate and months in the works: a private entrance was readied, a crush of news and entertainment reporters were required to sign pledges to abide by stringent rules of courtroom decorum and potential jurors were quizzed about their knowledge of American Idol and Dreamgirls.

title: France Votes Its Discontents
description: The first-round vote in the French presidential election produced a curious bi-directional backlash  from the left against the policies of austerity and from the right against immigration. The final round, which will be held on May 6, is likely to be important for all of Europe.

title: Wal-Mart Stock Falls Nearly 5%
description: Wal-Marts stock fell almost 5 percent on Monday, accounting for about one-fifth of the losses in the Dow Jones industrial average, as investors reacted to a bribery scandal at the retailers Mexican subsidiary and a report that an internal investigation was quashed at corporate headquarters in Arkansas.

title: Callous Choices in the House
description: For months, House Republicans have been trying to wriggle out of the agreement they made in August that will force deep cuts in military spending. Now we know how they propose to do it: They will take tens of billions out of programs for the poorest Americans, particularly food stamps, along with health care for the middle class.

title: A Would-Be Shoe Bomber Testifies in a Terror Trial
description: He was supposed to be the other shoe bomber. Saajid Badat said Osama bin Laden himself had dispatched him to board a plane with a bomb sewn in his shoe, which he would detonate in midair as part of a choreographed attack that would crash the American economy.

title: For Bocce, a New Generation of Devotees
description: A dusty old game favored by Italian old-timers has evolved into a trendy social sport  one largely without taxing physical demands.

title: Occupy Movement Looks Toward Political Conventions
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Hay and grass seed cover the bare spots on the lawn in front of the stately old City Hall where Occupy Charlottes camp held its ground for nearly four months. The occupiers are gone now and the protest movement quieted after arrests, a new anticamping ordinance and, to a degree, the groups own missteps along the way.

title: Displaying Value: The Case for the Liberal Arts Yet Again
description: Early on in his new book, College: What It Was, Is, and Should Be, Andrew Delbanco of Columbia University quotes the economist Richard Vedder and the former university president William Brody to the effect that little has changed in higher education despite enormous changes in technology, demographics, funding models, and student habits and attitudes. Vedder notes that with the possible exception of prostitution, teaching is the only profession that has had absolutely no productivity advance in the 2,400 years since Socrates. Brody is less wry, but the point is the same: If you went to a [college] class circa 1900, and you went today, it would look exactly the same.

title: A Test on Equal Pay
description: On the question of equal pay for women, Mitt Romney has planted himself on both sides of the issue, flipping and flopping at the same time.

title: Ryan Seacrest to Remain as Host of  American Idol
description: The Fox network said Monday evening that Ryan Seacrest had agreed to continue hosting the nations most popular reality television show, American Idol.

title: The Undocumented and the Unborn
description: The Nebraska Legislature took a strange road to a good result last week. It overrode Gov. Dave Heinemans veto of a bill to provide free prenatal care to undocumented immigrant women.

title: MetLife Settles Cases on Benefits
description: MetLife on Monday became the third big life insurer to settle regulatory accusations of failing to keep track of policyholder deaths, trapping money that should have gone promptly to the beneficiaries.

title: George Rathmann, Amgen Chief, Dies at 84
description: George B. Rathmann, who was the first chief executive of Amgen and helped build it into the worlds largest biotechnology company, died on Sunday at his home in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 84.

title: To Curb Rowdiness, Long Island Rail Road Will Ban Alcohol on Late-Night Weekend Trains
description: The notion of enjoying a cold one aboard a rush-hour commuter train leaving Manhattan may seem like a time-honored tradition, evoking visions of communal bar cars or perhaps a cocktail hour spent in solitude at ones seat. But after midnight on weekends, the specter of alcohol aboard Long Island Rail Road trains carries a far more malevolent overtone; passengers described them as the drunk trains, characterized by fights and boisterous behavior. In March, passengers were accused of attacking two conductors.

title: Hitting the Beach in Bangladesh
description: COXS BAZAR, Bangladesh  Its not Hawaii, and its not St.-Tropez. But Coxs Bazar is an up-and-coming beach resort, with lush vegetation and soaring property prices to match.

title: Insurers Alter Cost Formula, and Patients Pay More
description: Despite a landmark settlement that was expected to increase coverage for out-of-network care, the nations largest health insurers have been switching to a new payment method that in most cases significantly increases the cost to the patient.

title: Round Up the Usual Scapegoats
description: BUDAPEST

title: Arkansas Thinks Big in Hiring New Coach
description: John L. Smith has run with the bulls in Pamplona, skydived from 14,000 feet and climbed a peak of Mount Kilimanjaro. In the football world, he is known as an eccentric, whose legacy as a head coach ranges from being an innovator of the spread offense to telling his Louisville team at halftime of a bowl game that he was leaving for another job.

title: Chvez Out of Sight but Big as Life on Twitter
description: CARTAGENA, Colombia  During an extended stay in Cuba for cancer treatment, President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela has taken to sending messages to the folks back home with slogans like, We will live! and We will be victorious!

title: A Brooklyn School Saved Lives, and Some Now Try to Return the Favor
description: I was 18 years old with a baby and three high school credits. I was a gangbanger. I was shot and left for dead.

title: The Creative Monopoly
description: As a young man, Peter Thiel competed to get into Stanford. Then he competed to get into Stanford Law School. Then he competed to become a clerk for a federal judge. Thiel won all those competitions. But then he competed to get a Supreme Court clerkship.

title: Talking With Your Fingers
description: The latest word on the street about English in America  always bad, it seems  is that the shaggy construction of texting and e-mail spells the death of formal writing. Yet the truth about English in America  always sunnier, in fact  is that the looseness and creativity of these new ways of writing are a sign of a new sophistication in our society. This becomes clear when we understand that in the proper sense, e-mail and texting are not writing at all.

title: A Reinvented Palais de Tokyo Reopens
description: The Palais de Tokyo, near the Place du Trocadero in Paris, has had a number of uses during its 75-year history. Before the opening of the Centre Pompidou on Rue Beaubourg in 1977, for example, it was the home of Frances national collection of modern art (formerly known as the Palais des Muses dArt Moderne). In the 1980s it presented photography, films, and objects and decor of the cinema. And eventually it even closed.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 23, 2012

title: State Ponders Relinquishing Its Oversight of Vulnerable
description: ALBANY  The Cuomo administration is strongly considering relinquishing some of the states oversight and monitoring responsibilities over vulnerable populations, and giving that power to a nonprofit advocacy group, a top administration official said Monday.

title: The Overrated Vice Presidential Home-State Effect
description: In comparison to the dog-and-pony show that has dominated the political news cycle as of late, the question of whom Mitt Romney might pick as his vice presidential nominee is at least one of some substantive importance. Since 1900, about 25 percent of the men and women nominated for vice president by the major-party candidates have later become presidential nominees themselves, and 15 percent have actually become president, whether by winning the office on their own or by succeeding an incumbent who died or resigned in office.

title: Report on State Agency Oversight of Vulnerable
description: The State Office for People With Developmental Disabilities cites a fundamental conflict that prevents it from exercising oversight and proposes to turnover much of its work to a non-profit group.

title: Deficit, and Inconsistent Play, No Cause for Alarm to the Devils
description: NEWARK  Martin Brodeur laughed when he leaned back inside the Devils dressing room Monday and said, Ive done it all. And he has been in this spot before  three times in the last four years  with the Devils facing first-round elimination from the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: Becoming an Olympian, and Then a Newlywed
description: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa  Less than 48 hours after making the United States Olympic wrestling team in front of 13,000 fans, Stephany Lee arrived at the wedding chapel in a Ford Explorer carrying Colorado plates and a small entourage. She changed into jeans and a striped shirt. Beaming, she made her way to an altar sitting in front of five rows of padded pews.

title: Tainted, but Still Serving on Corporate Boards
description: When David M. Poppe sat down a little over a week ago to write a letter to his investors, he knew he was taking an unusual step.

title: Call for Growth to Counter German Push for Austerity
description: BERLIN  With political allies weakened or ousted, Chancellor Angela Merkels seat at the head of the European table has become much less comfortable, as a reckoning with Germanys insistence on lock-step austerity appears to have begun.

title: Classes Resume at Scene of Shootings in Oakland
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  In the makeshift memorial in front of Oikos University, around a table on which seven framed portraits were lined up, most of the flowers had withered and many of the handwritten notes had curled. But as classes began to resume on Monday morning after a gunman fatally shot six students and an administrator three weeks ago, the shootings effects remained raw among the students, teachers and even passers-by.

title: French Far Right a Challenge for Europe and Sarkozy
description: PARIS  To win re-election in the runoff on May 6 against the Socialist Franois Hollande, Nicolas Sarkozy will need the support of right-wing voters who have turned their backs on him, disappointed with his presidency.

title: Ghost the Musical
description: Photos from the new Broadway show at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater.

title: Fees and Anger Rise in California Water War
description: SAN DIEGO  There are accusations of conspiracies, illegal secret meetings and double-dealing. Embarrassing documents and e-mails have been posted on an official Web site emblazoned with the words Fact vs. Fiction. Animosities have grown so deep that the players have resorted to exchanging lengthy, caustic letters, packed with charges of lying and distortion.

title: A Haunted Hotel, a Haunted Family: Who Let the Ghosts Out?
description: Big hotels can be creepy, even when theyre not swarming with cultish conventioneers. Just think of the Overlook in the 1980 movie The Shining, the place that drove Jack Nicholson even further around the bend than usual.

title: Waiting for Dad to Die: Laughs Pile Up
description: Oh, theyre just awful people, those Lyons. Theyre whiny, denigrating, vicious, self-centered, recriminatory  the sort of blood kin who cant cling to one another without drawing blood. And theyre a family that you will really, really want to spend time with. Honestly. And not just for (you should excuse the expression) the pleasure of their company.

title: In a Broadway Afterlife, Time Goes by So Slowly
description: Generally speaking, I dont believe in ghosts. But Im convinced that the spirits of Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne have taken up temporary residence in the wings of the Broadway theater that bears their names, where the new musical adapted from the popular movie Ghost opened on Monday night.

title: Draggin Girl
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Greetings! Im back from the Erma Bombeck Writers Workshop, and I must say I had a fabulous time. Not only was it incredibly inspirational to see all of these writers in one place being watched over by the spirit of Erma Bombeck, but I also learned a lot, including how to successfully break the ice with attendees by using the ladies room while wearing a live microphone.

title: Bigger Role for Outside Conservative Groups
description: In states with some of the most competitive Senate races, Republican allies are out-spending Democrats.

title: Live and in Person, History Comes to Chicagos Classrooms
description: CHICAGO  It was an unusual day in social studies class at Frederick Von Steuben Metropolitan Science Center, a public high school on the North Side of this city. Mondays class was taught by a substitute teacher: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the former president of the Soviet Union.

title: Even as It Hurts Mexican Economy, Bribery Is Taken in Stride
description: MEXICO CITY  Every now and then, the health department shows up at Jos Luis Garcas food store in an affluent neighborhood here. Mr. Garca immediately reaches for his wallet.

title: Rangers Live to Fight Another Day
description: OTTAWA  Facing the embarrassment of early elimination by the lowest-seeded team in the East, the top-seeded Rangers were hurtling toward an elimination that would have undone a seasons worth of accomplishment. A force field seemed to have surrounded the Senators net. When Craig Anderson was not making saves, Rangers forwards were missing open corners and firing the puck wide.

title: Jeter and Rodriguez Help Yanks Prevail in Early Showdown
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Age is not an issue that Derek Jeter likes to entertain. A year ago, when he was 36, he bristled at suggestions that his extended batting slump was the result of his advancing years.

title: The Mega Millions Solution
description: The Mega Millions lottery last month with its whopping $656 million prize captured the intense interest of Americans across the country. Estimates suggest that as many as 100 million people participated. No matter that the odds of winning the jackpot were known to be much less than being struck by lightning twice. Investing a few bucks (or in the case of Washington Wizards forward Chris Singleton, ten thousand) for the chance to become a centa-millionaire was irresistible for nearly half of the adult population of the country.

title: Corrections: April 24
description: FRONT PAGE

title: New Fashion Wrinkle: Stylishly Hiding the Gun
description: Woolrich, a 182-year-old clothing company, describes its new chino pants as an elegant and sturdy fashion statement, with a clean profile and fabric that provides comfort and flexibility.

title: Murdochs Set to Testify Before Judicial Panel
description: LONDON  In the protracted saga of Britains tabloid newspaper scandal, there have been few episodes more challenging for Rupert Murdoch and his son James than the testimony each will give this week at the judicial inquiry that has been holding excoriating hearings for the past five months into wrongdoing at the core of the scandal.

title: Player Trades: Rare in N.F.L., Common for Eagles
description: PHILADELPHIA  Last October, cornerback Asante Samuel accused the management of the Philadelphia Eagles of playing fantasy football.

title: Saying Goodbye, a Former Net Talks About the Knicks
description: NEWARK  Micheal Ray Richardson made a ceremonial appearance at Prudential Center on Monday night to help bring the curtain down on the New Jersey Nets, but he took the opportunity to offer good news on the state of another former team, as only he could.

title: Conservative Groups Spending Heavily in Bid to Win a Senate Majority
description: The conservative groups that helped Republicans win the House in 2010 are pouring money this year into an aggressive campaign to capture the Senate, a goal that they consider just as vital as winning the White House.

title: In Egypt Race, Battle Is Joined on Islams Role
description: CAIRO  He has argued for barring women and non-Muslims from Egypts presidency on the basis of Islamic law, or Shariah. He has called for a council of Muslim scholars to advise Parliament. He has a track record of inflammatory statements about Israel, including repeatedly calling its citizens killers and vampires.

title: Time Expires on the Nets in New Jersey
description: NEWARK  The Nets longtime public address announcer, Gary Sussman, was back on the microphone for their final game in New Jersey on Monday night.

title: Egypt Rejects Registration Bids From 8 U.S. Nonprofit Groups
description: CAIRO  An Egyptian ministry has rejected the applications for registration of eight American nonprofit groups, state media reported, in the governments first action on the status of foreign-backed nonprofit groups since its criminal prosecution of three American-backed organizations set off a crisis in relations with Washington this year.

title: Champions League: Chelsea Tries to Buck the System in Barcelona
description: Barcelonas players claimed that a tear had rolled down the face of the game after they were felled by Jos Mourinhos defensive Inter Milan two years ago.

title: Word of the Day | ogle
description: ogle \o-gl also -\ verb

title: Canada: Immigration Hearing for Relative of Tunisian Leader
description: While a large number of people from Montreals Tunisian community attended an immigration hearing on Monday for Belhassen Trabelsi, the brother-in-law of Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali, Tunisias former president, Mr. Trabelsi was not among them. His lawyer told the Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada that Mr. Trabelsi feared for his safety. The government of Canada wants to revoke Mr. Trabelsis permanent resident status because it says that he failed to remain in Canada for at least two out of every five years. After trying Mr. Trabelsi in absentia, a court in Tunisia sentenced him in September to 15 years in prison and fined him about $500,000 for corruption. A wealthy businessman, Mr. Trabelsi has acknowledged that family connections gave him a position of privilege in Tunisia, but he denied having gained any illicit benefits.

title: S.E.C. Sues SinoTech Energy of China for Fraud
description: HONG KONG  The Securities and Exchange Commission has sued another China-based company and two of its executives, charging them with lying to investors about the value of the companys assets and how it used $120 million in proceeds from its initial public offering on the Nasdaq.

title: Russia: Opposition Candidate Is Ending His Hunger Strike
description: An opposition candidate whose hunger strike to protest alleged ballot fraud drew national attention said Monday that he would start eating solid food. The candidate, Oleg V. Shein of the Just Russia party, said ballot fraud robbed him of victory in the mayoral race last month in Astrakhan, a regional capital in southern Russia. Mr. Shein said he stopped eating solid food March 16, though he drank water, and in recent days had some juice and a glucose injection. He said he would begin eating on Tuesday.

title: Russia: Police Captain Arrested in Crackdown on Corruption
description: A police captain in Moscow was arrested over the weekend on charges of accepting a bribe of more than $40,000, according to a police statement released Monday, part of an apparent crackdown on police corruption after several scandals involving law enforcement personnel. The captain, who was not identified, was accused of taking the money from a car salesman in exchange for ignoring legal infractions. The police statement said the captains superiors would also be punished. Despite efforts by President Dmitri A. Medvedev to push for police reform, corruption remains widespread and abuse common. In March, a man died in police custody after officers allegedly sodomized him with a bottle. The episode incited national outrage and prompted new calls for reform.

title: In Japan, Suffer the Children
description: HONG KONG  She just took the razor and then she started cutting in front of me.

title: Power Play Is a Boost for Richards
description: OTTAWA  The Rangers win over the Ottawa Senators on Monday brought the end of a frustrating stretch for Brad Richards.

title: Bo Xilai and Gu Kailai Family Connections
description: The close relatives of Bo Xilai, a former Chinese Politburo member, and his wife, Gu Kailai, may have profited from the couples political influence.

title: Rangers-Senators Replay: Game 6
description: The top-seeded Rangers staved off elimination with a 3-2 victory in Ottawa.

title: A Hit Maker Bets Future Earnings on India Expansion Plan
description: Insiders use outside money to make movies and television shows. That is the basic rule of Hollywood investment, Michael Cieply writes in The New York Times. But Peter A. Chernin is changing the rules.

title: Air National Guard Lobbies Successfully Against Budget Cuts
description: In combat zones, National Guard units generally take their orders from active duty commanders. Not so in Washington.

title: News Quiz | April 24, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: In an Unlikely Corner of Asia, Strong Promise of Growth
description: Bangladesh is probably one of the last places in Asia people would expect to see a thriving beachside resort with luxury hotels, Bettina Wassener writes in The New York Times. And yet, Coxs Bazar is exactly that  a place where affluent Bangladeshis go for a weekend of seaside fun.

title: A Conversation With: Zuber Jafri
description: A decade ago, Ahsan Jafri, a former member of parliament, was killed in the riots that besieged the state of Gujarat. On Feb. 28, 2002, witnesses said that Muslim women and children sought refuge in Mr. Jafris home in the Gulberg Housing Society, and that he made frantic phone calls seeking help because a mob that had gathered outside. The police arrived too late, survivors had said, and Mr. Jafri was killed along with 69 others when the mob set fire to his home. His widow, Zakia Jafri, filed suit in court in an effort, she says, to find justice.

title: April 24, 1916 | Irish Nationalists Stage Easter Uprising in Dublin
description: On April 24, 1916, on Easter Monday, groups of Irish nationalists revolted against British rule by seizing a post office and other buildings in Dublin and declaring the formation of the Irish Republic.

title: Test Yourself | English, April 24, 2012
description: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article Enzymes Try to Grab the Spotlight.

title: As Book Sales Grow, Publishers Flock to India
description: David Davidar recalls the advice once given to him by the writer R.K. Narayan about publishing books in India. Dont worry, youll be gone in a few years, Mr. Narayan warned. There arent enough writers here.

title: At Wal-Mart in Mexico, a Bribe Inquiry
description: Note: These questions focus on the basic details explained in the opening of a complex and lengthy news article. Students can answer them by reading down to the subheading The Allegations Emerge.

description: For the past dozen years, Pablo Delano has been consumed by the mystery of a Barcelona Biscuit Tin: who shot the hundreds of decaying negatives that were packed into the beat-up box he bought for $60 at a Barcelona flea market? Who were the people in the pictures? Where were the photos taken?

title: Earth to Ben Bernanke
