title: Murdoch Case Shifts Its Focus to a Minister
description: LONDON  The long-running tabloid newspaper scandal that has shaken Rupert Murdochs global media empire delivered a new jolt on Tuesday as its powerful and lucrative television operations moved to the center of a British judicial inquiry with disclosures that a senior cabinet minister, or at least an aide claiming to speak for him, worked covertly to help win approval for a $12 billion takeover of the BSkyB network.

title: Why Do You Share Photos?
description: The purchase of Instagram by Facebook for $1 billion has put a lot of focus on the popularity of taking and sharing photographs online. Do you use Instagram or other photo services and apps? What compels you to share photos? How do you share them, and with whom?

description: A major insurer of active-duty troops, USAA, has released details from a study on the driving safety records of thousands of troops who returned from Iraq or Afghanistan. And as expected, the results showed that many struggle to readjust to American highways.

This year, plenty of benches are occupied by the likes of Bryce Harper and Mike Trout, while owners await word that the players organizations will give them a big league role.

title: Le Pen Pricks
description: The Socialist candidate Franois Hollande and President Nicolas Sarkozy may be the ones who qualified for the second round of the French presidential election, but the big winner in Sundays first round was Marine Le Pen, of the far-right National Front. Though she won only third place, she garnered 18 percent of all votes, a record for her party.

For many Indian Americans and others interested in work from the region, buying a quality piece is now out of reach.

description: Chase Stuart is a contributor to SmartFootball.comandFootballguys.com

description: One intriguing outcome of the iPad is how it has encouraged developers to create hybrid apps that dont fit neatly into one genre. There are a lot of iPad books, especially for kids, that experiment with sounds, video and gamelike elements to enhance their storytelling.

title: Study Links Plant Damage to Nanoparticles

title: Samsung Heirs Stage a Korean Soap Opera

Partly because of his reticence, what few public remarks he makes are studied by his reverential employees with the same zeal that devout Christians might apply when parsing biblical quotations.

title: From Bangladesh to Rochester, With a Missed Connection
description: The Newlyweds, Nell Freudenbergers affecting if sometimes ungainly new novel, starts off as a sort of high-concept Hollywood movie, mashing up the familiar fish-out-of-water story line with a girl-torn-between-two-boys plot. What all feels a bit like a paint-by-numbers exercise, however, gradually opens out into a genuinely moving story about a woman trying to negotiate two cultures, balancing her parents expectations with her own aspirations, her ambition and cynical practicality with deeper, more romantic yearnings.

Roy writes in The International Herald Tribune. The triple talaq is a formula of repudiation, she writes. The first two times it is pronounced, it can be revoked, but the third time it makes a divorce binding, according to some interpretations of Islamic law.

title: Why AT&T and Verizon Are Rooting for Windows Phones

AT&T has been hurling loads of money at marketing Nokias Lumia 900, a smartphone that runs on the Windows Phone operating system. And now Verizon, too, has revealed plans to aggressively promote Windows Phone 8, the next version of Microsofts software.

title: Another Passionate Plea to Save Bushwick High
Philippine Court Rules Aquino Estate Must Be Split Among 6,000
description: MANILA  In a landmark decision, the Supreme Court in the Philippines ruled unanimously on Tuesday to break up the rambling estate owned by the family of President Benigno S. Aquino III, parceling out land to more than 6,000 farmers and their families and removing a main obstacle to ending the oppressive plantation culture that has dominated the country for decades.

title: Former Edwards Aide Testifies About Elaborate Efforts to Hide Affair

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Grilling for James Murdoch, and Facebook Tops 900 Million Users
description: James Murdoch, son of Rupert Murdoch and former head of the familys British newspapers, is testifying in London Tuesday before a commission investigating press ethics, facing detailed and exhaustive questions from one of the commissions lawyers, Robert Jay. When the question of phone-hacking came up, Mr. Murdoch stuck by his contention that he was ill informed by his subordinates, otherwise he would have ordered the executives to cut out the cancer, John Burns and Alan Cowell reported. He was also asked about his contacts with Prime Minister David Cameron, and whether political support from the Murdoch newspapers was tied to support for its business goals  a charge he denied. Rupert Murdochs testimony is set for Wednesday.

title: Image of the Day: April 24
Cost of Spains Housing Bust Could Force a Bailout
description: By any measure, the Spanish real estate boom was one of the headiest ever. Spurred by record-low interest rates, Spaniards piled into holiday villas along the Costa Blanca, gaudy apartments in Madrid and millions of starter homes throughout the country.

title: Tuesday Reading: Knowing When to Put an End to Therapy
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Losing a Starring Role in the Republican Primary
description: Twas but a few weeks ago that New York States Republican Party sounded practically giddy about the presidential primary that would be held on April 24 (which crack investigative reporting, in the form of looking at a calendar, reveals is upon us). This is our time, party leaders said, gushing like Sally Field when she accepted an Oscar in 1985.

title: New Dolby Technology to Make Horror Movies Scarier
description: If you dont like the sounds in scary movies but sometimes get dragged along to the theater anyway, youre not going to be a big fan of the latest technology from Dolby Laboratories.

title: On Our Radar: BP Settlement Dispute
description: Shrimp processors ask a federal judge to delay preliminary approval of BPs proposed settlement of economic claims from the 2010 oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. They contend that it favors shrimp harvesters and boat captains at the expense of shrimp docks, processors and others. [Reuters]

title: Leading Off: Coaching Follies at Arkansas
description: It seems it was about five minutes ago that everyone was applauding the Arkansas athletic director for standing up as the voice of integrity. In reality, it was two weeks ago when Jeff Long made his impassioned speech that he had to fire the football coach Bobby Petrino because Petrinos list of ethical transgressions trumped his winning record. In record time, however, Arkansas grabbed that new banner of goodness and light and whacked integrity right on the head with it.

title: Modis Ratings
description: NEW DELHI  Narendra Modi, the leading figure of Indias right-wing Bharatiya Janata Party (B.J.P.), didnt make Time magazines list of the 100 most powerful people in the world this year. Midway through the online polling, after Modis stock had started to surge, liberals in India organized a counter-campaign. In the end, 256,792 votes were cast for him and 266,684 votes against.

title: Man Is Accused of Killing His Half-Sister and Wounding His Mother
description: Wednesday, 2:08 p.m. | Updated A family was torn apart by violence early on Tuesday morning when a man turned a gun on his mother after killing his 13-year-old half-sister, then engaged police in a lengthy predawn shootout in Washington Heights, the police said.

title: Company Admits It Bilked Clients on Big Projects
description: The giant construction company that worked on Citi Field, the renovation of Grand Central Terminal and scores of other high-profile projects has admitted to a huge fraud scheme in which it overbilled clients for more than a decade and has agreed to pay $56 million in fines and restitution to avoid criminal charges, federal prosecutors announced Tuesday.

title: Congress Takes Fresh Look at MF Global
description: A Congressional panel is continuing the examination of the collapse of MF Global and the firms misuse of customer money, as lawmakers seek to find ways to prevent a repeat of the financial debacle.

Part 1 on Monday examined how the evolution of the N.F.L. into a passing league is affecting the quarterback and wide receiver positions: a good quarterback just isnt good enough anymore. Today, a look at offensive lines, running backs and tight ends.

description: LONDON  Europes open-borders policy is coming under threat as mainstream politicians react to what they perceive as a growing challenge from right-wing, anti-immigration parties such as Frances National Front.

description: The United States was placed into a first-round group with France, Colombia and North Korea during the draw Tuesday in London for this summers Olympic womens soccer tournament.

description: Good morning. Today should climb to a partly cloudy 60 degrees with strong winds possible in the afternoon.

title: What Were Reading
description: The Economist: From a distinguished journal, a loving evocation of the bagelness of Murray Lender, the pioneering bagel man who died last month at the age of 81. His term for the classic hole-in-the-roll was the Jewish English muffin, of course, and if he won praise as the Barnum of bagelmania, he also introduced innovations that appalled purists, including pre-slicing, freezing and Minute-Maid cross-promotions. Despite a stroke, he played his drums joyously until nearly the end.  Glenn Collins

title: AT&T Posts Profit Despite Slow Contract Growth
description: AT&T, the nations No. 2 cellphone carrier, barely added any new monthly contract customers in the first quarter, but the company still managed to post a profit because it made so much money from the data plans of existing customers.

title: Charles Aznavour Cancels New York Shows in Contract Dispute
description: Charles Aznavours cancellation of three shows at New Yorks City Center this week was because of a contract dispute, not health problems, the French singer told the radio station RTL in an interview on Monday.

title: When $2,600 in Premiums Yields $1.7 Million in Claims
description: Premiums for long-term care insurance, which helps cover the cost of nursing home or in-home care for the aged or disabled, have been steadily increasing, an industry group reported earlier this year.

title: MF Global Trustee Calls for Fund to Protect Customers
description: The trustee tasked with returning more than $1.6 billion in missing customer money after the demise of MF Global has suggested establishing an insurance fund for commodities customers to safeguard assets in the event of a future collapse, according to a statement he read at a Congressional hearing on Tuesday.

title: A Tricky Museum Question
description: Dear Diary:Im sitting at the information desk one afternoon at the American Museum of Natural History. A woman, with a heavy accent, approaches to ask a question.

title: Timely | Elisa Strozyk, Next Floor
description: After getting a masters degree in the Textile Futures program at Londons Central Saint Martins in 2009, the Berlin designer Elisa Strozyk decided to make something that was part wood flooring, part rug. The result: wooden carpet. Sounds simple, but each rug is made of hundreds of individually sanded and oiled pieces of wood veneer that are cut and attached by hand to a textile base. The carpets, which are now produced and distributed by the German furniture manufacturer Bwer, generated so much interest in Strozyk that she skipped the usual apprenticeships and set up her own studio. She calls her work the never-ending experiment. Stay tuned.

description: Seldom has an MF Global hearing passed where partisan shots were not taken.

(The New York Times)

title: Institute Calls for Improved Coordination of Standards for E.V.s

description: The Tennessee Supreme Court has upheld a lower court decision allowing Fisk University to sell a 50 percent stake in a 101-piece art collection donated by Georgia OKeeffe, The Associated Press reported on Monday.

title: Inviting Cinderella Species to the Ball
description: We humans are quite fond of ourselves. So much so that our narcissism tends to influence our preferences for other species, too. We generally favor big, attractive mammals with forward-facing eyes, and this bias is reflected in the conservation dollars we donate. While polar bear fatigue does occur, conservation organizations that focus on large charismatic animals like that Arctic creature or tigers, elephants or chimpanzees  often referred to as flagship species  generate the most financial support, regardless of the animals status on the endangered species list.

title: MF Global Hearing Addresses Recovery of Missing Client Money
description: At the MF Global hearing on Tuesday, Senator Bob Corker, Republican of Tennessee, asked a simple question.

title: Sinead OConnor Cancels Her Tour
description: Sinead OConnor says she is canceling her 2012 tour because she has bipolar disorder, the latest in a series of erratic pronouncements by the Irish songwriter suggesting she is deeply troubled.

title: For Maryland Womens Lacrosse, a Low Seed and Another Title
description: There have been questions all year about whether the Maryland womens lacrosse team is as strong as it has been in recent seasons. The graduation of three senior defenders cast doubt on the defense. The offensive inconsistency earlier in the regular season cast doubt on the attackers. And above all, the teams losses to Duke and North Carolina cast doubt on itsperennial domination in the Atlantic Coast Conference.

title: Eight Things I Learned From Reading Every Last Word of The Economist
description: I subscribe to way too many magazines, which means, inevitably, that I toss out a lot of them without reading every last article. Or sometimes, alas, without reading any articles at all. Some magazines, of course, are harder to throw out than others, The New Yorker being the classic example. To subscribe to The New Yorker is to accept the feeling of inadequacy that comes with flipping on SportsCenter rather than attacking the unread pile of them on your bedside table.

title: Judge Rules That Protester Cant Oppose Twitter Subpoena
description: A criminal court judge in Manhattan ruled on Friday that a writer from Brooklyn did not have the standing to oppose a subpoena delivered by prosecutors to Twitter seeking three months of old messages.

title: Cooper Union Will Charge Tuition for Graduate Students
description: After months of agonized debate about its 110-year-old tradition of free education, Cooper Union will begin charging graduate students next year while maintaining, at least for now, its no-tuition policy for undergraduates, the colleges president said Tuesday.

title: Lost Occupation, Lost Art as Sports Cartooning Declines
description: BALTIMORE  Mike Ricigliano practices a nearly extinct newspaper art: he is a sports cartoonist, poking fun at sports figures with pen, paper and a gag writers shtick.

title: Sons of Anarchy Creator to Track Real-Life Mayhem for Discovery

title: Redistricting Shapes Pennsylvania Primaries
description: Redistricting remains a wild card in many House races this year, and Tuesdays primary in Pennsylvania will provide the latest test. Two Democrats are ensnared in a member-on-member battle, and one will emerge with his political career fatally wounded. Other Democrats and Republicans are fighting off feisty outside challenges with a redistricting twist.

title: Minor Comeback for NBC on Monday, as It Faced Weaker Competition

description: Ken Rogoff has a piece in the FT comparing Europes woes to those of a family with a shared checking account, some of whose members start abusing the privilege.

title: Business Day Live: Calls for Inquiry Into Wal-Mart Bribery
description: What the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act might mean for Wal-Mart; Facebook and Microsofts alliance; and after missteps, a cautious recovery for Netflix.

title: Back to the Scene of a Former Fossil Site
description: Ken Angielczyk, an assistant curator at the Field Museum of Natural History, is searching for fossils of ancient mammal relatives in northeastern Brazil.

title: Hello, Illinois? Your Congressman Is Getting Off the Phone
description: WASHINGTON  In an institution hampered by perpetual uncertainty, there are a few comforting givens on Capitol Hill.

title: Dying Art, Lost Occupation
description: Examples of sports cartooning, a nearly extinct newspaper art, including panels on the state of the industry drawn by those still dedicated to the craft.

title: One Island, Two Countries
description: Apart from a dwindling seal colony and the automated lighthouse towering over it, nothing seems remotely remarkable about Market Island, a tiny skerry [1] in the strait separating the Gulf of Bothnia from the Baltic Sea. But Market, which is Swedish for boundary marker (not market, as you might assume), is an uninhabited sea-rock with a difference. It not only marks the meeting of two seas, but the meeting of Sweden and Finland.

title: The Cotton Kings of Texas
description: As the reality of the war and the grip of the Union blockade settled upon the South, two brothers who had been among the most successful plantation owners in Texas decided to diversify their holdings  by taking up the dicey new business of blockade-running.

title: The Lowdown on Google Drive
description: Googles online storage service, Google Drive, is finally out with the expected 5 gigabytes of free storage. While the service has been discussed for months, few people had anticipated all that Google included in the service.

title: Nissan Is Latest Company to Get Hacked
description: Nissan confirmed its computer systems were hacked two weeks ago.

title: Spurs Quietly Take Top Spot in West
description: It happened so stealthily, without fanfare, but the results cannot be denied: the San Antonio Spurs have clinched the top seed in the Western Conference. The Spurs demolished the Blazers, 124-89, in San Antonio to lock things up in the regular seasons waning days.

title: Channeling Bardots Up-Do
description: RETRO geometric prints, sleeveless shifts, false eyelashes: Walk into a dress shop or drugstore these days, and you might think youve been teleported back to 1965. With celebrities like Adele showing off vintage looks, and Mad Men inspiring makeup by Este Lauder and clothes by Banana Republic, is it any wonder many women are trying to tease their hair?

title: Turntable Setup for the Obsessive
description: Last weeks personal-tech feature was about a turntable guide which the headline writer rightly titled, Enjoying Turntables Without Obsessing.

title: Former City Finance Commissioner Fined $22,000 for Conflict
description: A former seniorBloomberg administration official has been fined $22,000 by the New York City Conflicts of Interest Board, primarily for using a city computer account to send e-mails related to her paid service as a board member of a real estate company.

title: Fox News Host Corrects Obamas Silver Spoon Quote
description: Nearly a week after it started, the myth of the silver spoon seems to have been settled.

title: The iPhone Is Still a Strong Seller for AT&T and Verizon
description: Analysts are getting nervous about Apple after looking at the financial results of AT&T this morning and Verizon last week.

title: A Pitch to Collect Charity From Casino Gamblers
description: Last week, I told you about a business that wants to take the wait out of waiting rooms. This week, weve got a video pitch from the social enterprise Casino Patron Charities that wants to turn casino gambling into a charitable activity by making it easy for casino gamblers to donate the change on their winnings to charity.

title: Its Fight Time in Bangkok
description: On a recent trip to Thailand, my fourth since 2000, I was fortunate to have some new adventures. One of the highlights was getting to see the national sport, the martial arts discipline known asmuay Thai, firsthand and up close.

title: Chris Bangle, the Novelist, Selects Winner of Design Competition
description: To promote his allegorical novel about automobile design, former BMW design chief Chris Bangle held a contest where young artists would illustrate some of the vehicles in the story.

title: TimesCast | April 24, 2012
description: A former aide to John Edwards is now the prosecution's star witness against him | Europe's deep spending cuts cause concern over economic growth.

title: Champions League Semifinals: Chelsea 2, Barcelona 2
description: A stunner. Chelsea is through to the final on May 19 in Munich on aggregate and no one can seem to believe it.

title: What Primary?
description: Mitt Romneys top fundraising zip code is 10021, comprising East 69th Street to East 76th Street in Manhattan. Its one of the countrys richest areas, and reliably politically active in the large-donations sense of that term: In 2000, it supplied the most campaign dollars to both George W. Bush and Al Gore of any postal code in the United States.

title: Living Portion Size Me
description: After being bullied about his weight for years, Marshall Reid, 12, chronicled his attempts to lose weight.

title: A Childs Helping Hand on Portions
description: SANFORD, N.C.

title: Scene City: Carnegie Hall Gala Honoring Bill Cunningham
description: More than 450 people gathered for a cocktail party and dinner to honor the New York Times photographer with a Carneige Hall Medal of Excellence.

title: Engineer Arrested in BP Oil Spill Case
description: HOUSTON  Two years after the immense BP oil spill that killed 11 people and blackened beaches along the Gulf of Mexico, federal prosecutors have filed the first criminal charges related to the accident, accusing a former company engineer of destroying evidence by deleting text messages that discussed the amount of oil leaking from the stricken well.

title: Notes From the Recipe Tester: Why Peel a Pea?
description: Denise Landis has been testing recipes for The New York Times for more than 20 years. She is also the author of Dinner for Eight: 40 Great Dinner Party Menus for Friends and Family. Here, she offers tips for making one of this weeks Dining recipes.

title: South Sudan Says Sudan Strikes Again
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  As aerial bombardments continued in the border region between Sudan and South Sudan on Tuesday, the South Sudanese president, Salva Kiir, met with President Hu Jintao of China, a crucial friend to both nations, saying that Sudan had declared war on his country, a spokesman for the South said.

title: To Find Diversity Hot Spots, Follow the Ants
description: More on the biodiversity front:

title: Mets Put Bay and Pelfrey on Disabled List
description: The Mets lost two games to the San Francisco Giants on Monday, dropping their record to .500 this season. On Tuesday, they lost two players.

title: Jailed Ex-Premier in Ukraine Goes on Hunger Strike
description: MOSCOW  Ukraines jailed former prime minister, Yulia V. Tymoshenko, declared a hunger strike on Tuesday after what she said was an assault by prison guards that left her black and blue.

title: Brown and Warren Spar Over Tax Returns
description: 3:16 p.m. | Updated BOSTON  Senator Scott P. Brown, Republican of Massachusetts, said on Tuesday that he would release his personal tax returns from the last six years and challenged Elizabeth Warren, his presumed Democratic opponent, to do the same.

title: Lumire | Made in France
description: When Lejaby Lingerie, the 82-year-old French bra-and-corset maker, announced last year that it was shuttering its fourth and only remaining factory in France and heading to Tunisia, it represented more than just another blow for French industry. It also provided one of the most unexpected symbols of the French presidential campaign: the bra.

title: That Brawl? Elite Club Wants Nothing Said
description: The 144-year-old New York Athletic Club is known for its nurturing role in the history of American amateur sports, the hundreds of Olympic medals its members have won, and its fancy headquarters on Central Park South featuring squash courts, guest rooms, a library and a strict dress code.

title: Debt Collector Is Faulted for Tough Tactics in Hospitals
description: Hospital patients waiting in an emergency room or convalescing after surgery are being confronted by an unexpected visitor: a debt collector at bedside.

title: Cooper Union Will Charge Tuition for Graduate Students
description: Cooper Union, which has a century-old tradition of free tuition, will begin charging graduate students for their education, our colleague Richard Prez-Pea reports.

title: Everybody Got Dressed for Bill
description: Last night, more than 450 people gathered at the Waldorf-Astoria for a cocktail party and dinner to honor Bill Cunningham, The New York Times photographer, whose two columns, On the Street and Evening Hours, appear each week in Sunday Styles.

title: Georgetown Faculty Latest to Chide Ryan
description: Representative Paul D. Ryan, the Republican chairman of the House Budget Committee, has been excoriated by some Roman Catholic leaders ever since he claimed this month that his budget plan, which slashes antipoverty programs, was inspired by the moral teachings of his Catholic faith.

title: An E-Book That Glows in the Dark
description: If you intend to buy an e-book reader, heres a tip: First, spend an evening sitting cross-legged on a lotus leaf, surrounded by incense and sitar music.

title: Louis Langree Named Music Director of Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra
description: Louis Langre, the French conductor who has been a mainstay of the Mostly Mozart Festival as its music director for a decade, will also become music director of the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra. Mr. Langre, 51, will start his four-year contract the season after next, the Cincinnati Symphony announced on Tuesday, but he will conduct two programs with the orchestra in November. He will immediately put a Francophone stamp on his new job, leading works by Franck, Messiaen and Saint-Sans in the first set of concerts that month.

title: The Boy Who Changed His Familys Diet
description: On the last day of fourth grade, a fellow student stood in front of Marshall Reid and levied the cruel words that would change his familys life. Youre fat, he said.

title: Tribeca: Wavumba and a Legends Last Shark Hunt
description: Kenya enchanted Jeroen van Velzen when his peripatetic family moved him there briefly as a child. In a fading fisherman on the countrys coast, the Dutch filmmaker found an embodiment of both his dreams about the place and the point where rosy imaginings collide with reality.

title: Off the Beaten Track: Six Guys in a Starbucks in Bahrain
description: This is a continuation of yesterdays post: Finding a Bahrain Different Than the One I Expected

title: More People Seeking Help Cite Burden of Student Loans
description: More people seeking debt counseling are citing student loan debt as their main reason for seeking help, an analysis by a large credit-counseling agency shows.

title: Ferrari Hybrid Powertrain Loses Flywheel, but Picks Up Power
description: Is the world ready for the better, faster, stronger version of the Ferrari Enzo? If it is, it had better be prepared for it to be a hybrid.

title: Late in the Season, the Knicks Have Won Bigger
description: In my last post on Off the Dribble, I wrote that the percentage in which teams blow out their opponents may indicate they are stronger than their record would indicate. This season, the Knicks have won 28 percent of their games by 10 or more points. That rate ties them for seventh best in the N.B.A., a substantial showing despite their middle-tier ranking in terms of actual wins.

title: Treating Sensory Processing Disorders in One Stop
description: The new WeeZee play complex in Westchester has a cute name, but a serious mission: Louise Weadock, a psychiatric nurse and parent, founded the facility, based on her own and others research, to provide play and developmental activities for children with (and without) sensory disorders, and to continue the research into the effectiveness of sensory play as therapy.

title: LeRoy T. Walker, a Pioneer of U.S. Olympics, Dies at 93
description: LeRoy T. Walker, a leading American track and field coach who was the first African-American to coach a United States mens Olympic track team and to serve as the president of the United States Olympic Committee, died Monday in Durham, N.C. He was 93.

title: Tortorella on Game 7: My Thought Is to Win It
description: Even on an off day, more than 48 hours before his Rangers host the Senators in Game 7, Coach John Tortorella chose not to engage in a discussion about what the first Game 7 in New York since 1994 means for the franchise and the city of New York.

title: Photo Replay: April 24
description: A look at the day in sports included sunset surfing in Australia and a German Olympic balancing act.

title: Tina Fey on the 30 Rock Live Episode and the Shows Future
description: The first time, its a stunt; the second time its a tradition. On Thursday, 30 Rock will once again journey from its home at Silvercup Studios in Long Island City, Queens, to NBC headquarters at 30 Rockefeller Plaza in Manhattan for an episode that will be shown live. As it did in a similar outing in October 2010, 30 Rock will ditch its filmed format and adapt its fast-paced repartee and cutaway sight gags to a no-second-chances style more familiar to Saturday Night Live (whose base of operations at Studio 8H will again be the site of the 30 Rock show).

title: Scoring Is the Issue for Denver Lacrosse
description: Despite an 8-7 lead with only 19 seconds remaining in the fourth quarter, the No. 10/12 Pioneers lost by 9-8 in overtime to then-No. 17 Fairfield on Saturday afternoon at Lessing Field in Connecticut. With the loss, Denver dropped to 7-5 over all and 3-3 in the E.C.A.C., clinching the No. 4 seed in the conference tournament thanks to Air Forces 14-4 loss to Ohio State over the weekend.

title: Obama Opens Two-Day Trip to Try to Recapture Youth Vote
description: BOULDER, Colo.  President Obama opened a two-day, three-campus swing on Tuesday designed to recapture the youth vote that helped propel him to the White House four years ago, presenting himself once more as a product of poverty in implicit contrast to his wealthy opponent.

title: Clemenss Lawyer Tries New Approach
description: WASHINGTON  Standing in front of the jury box, Rusty Hardin, Roger Clemenss lawyer, spoke in a near whisper as he ended his opening argument Tuesday, begging jurors to realize that the governments perjury case against Clemens is tragically wrong.

title: The Crisis of Zionism
description: Something Ive been meaning to do  and still dont have the time to do properly  is say something about Peter Beinarts brave book The Crisis of Zionism.

title: Discoverys Soggy Logic on Frozen Planet
description: Heres a question to ponder after reviewing the video of melting penguin ice sculptures above shot at the glitzy New York City celebration of the American production of Frozen Planet.

title: Paris Festival Looks Beyond Borders  to Portland, Ore.
description: France loves nothing more than to fete its own patrimonial heritage. However the Gat Lyrique in Paris (3 bis rue Papin; 33-1-53-01-51-51) has decided to import and honor a bit of foreign culture. Having paid tribute to Istanbul and Berlin, the organization turns its attention to the far-flung Pacific Northwest: specifically Portland, Ore. From April 24 to 29, Paris is host to the Keep Portland Weird festival.

title: North African Chicken With Spicy Green Sauce
description: Time: About 1 hour 45 minutes plus overnight soaking

title: Spicy Green Sauce
description: 1 preserved lemon (available at Middle Eastern groceries) or the grated zest of 1 lemon

title: A Tunisian One-Pot Dish, as Spicy as You Like It
description: THERES a little Tunisian spot in Paris I like to visit for a casual meal. Its totally bare-bones, but the place has a great feel and the food is simple and good.

title: Wayne Shorter and Rufus Wainright Among Montreal Jazz Fest Performers
description: Wayne Shorter, Esperanza Spalding, Stanley Clarke and Hiromi Uehara are among the prominent jazz artists who will perform at the 33rd Montreal Jazz Festival this summer, organizers announced Tuesday. Like most major jazz festivals, the Festival International de Jazz de Montreal long ago abandoned any claim to purity and now includes several pop and rock groups. Rufus Wainwright, for instance, will open the festival on June 28 with a free outdoor concert at La Place de Festival. Among the other non-jazz musicians scheduled to perform are James Taylor, Ziggy Marley, Janelle Monae and Seal.

title: Putin to Pass Control of Party to Medvedev
description: MOSCOW  Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin said Tuesday that he would step down as chairman of United Russia, the political party he has led since 2008, and hand the reins of the parliamentary majority to his protg, President Dmitri A. Medvedev.

title: At Duke, Wall Street May Still Hold Allure
description: Do college students still want to work on Wall Street? The question has proved hard to answer. (DealBook said no. The Wall Street Journal, two weeks later, disagreed.)

title: Key Issues in Deciding College Footballs New Postseason
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla.  The czars of college football  conference commissioners, ESPN executives and select university and bowl officials  descended on the Westin Diplomat hotel this week for a pivotal series of meetings tied to the future of the sports postseason.

title: Jessica Ogdens Creature Comforts
description: The designer Jessica Ogden once put on a fashion show that was inspired by Haruki Murakamis Kafka on the Shore, a novel in which fish fall from the sky and a man converses with cats. The set featured stuffed animals and props that were meant to evoke a surrealist beach party, a whimsical conceit that is perfectly in keeping with Ogdens elegantly nave aesthetic. Seven years later, the idea has taken on new life in Lilys Castle in the Sand, an exhibition that opens tomorrow at the Apartment, a boutique-cum-gallery in Copenhagen. Lilys Castle features Ogdens paintings and clothing designs as well as an expanded collection of appliqud and patchwork elephants, butterflies and other animals, some plush-toy cuddly, others the size of a rocking horse, and all of them gathered for afternoon tea. Ogden, who lives in Paris and designs quilts and the Madras line for A.P.C., worked with the costume designer Lee Benjamin, who outfitted Leigh Bowery and now collaborates with the comedian and drag queen Jonny Woo and the performance artist Scottee, to create the menagerie. She traces her fascination with the world of play  I imagine these animals gossiping about whos wearing what and who shall we invite next time, she says of her Lewis Carroll-style party  to her childhood in Jamaica, where her British parents moved before she was born. Growing up there, she says, gives you a lot of freedom for inventing games from nothing.

title: Change of Tone Could Help Google in European Antitrust Case
description: BRUSSELS  For the past two years, Google has worked hard to avoid facing formal antitrust charges in Europe that could mean years of expensive litigation and encourage the authorities in other parts of the world to take comparable action.

title: New Yorker Word Nerds Drop Slacks in Online Contest
description: Last Friday, the New Yorkers Culture Desk blog announced a contest asking readers to nominate the word that most urgently needs to be eliminated from the English language. And now, the results are in: for the next week, no one who speaks English  or at least writes it on the magazines Web site  will be allowed to describe someone else as wearing slacks.

title: After Delaware Primary, Gingrich Campaign Will Reassess Race
description: Could this finally be Newt Gingrichs swan song? After a roller-coaster campaign that saw the former House speaker stage multiple comebacks  hitting his high moment when he clobbered Mitt Romney in South Carolina three months ago  Mr. Gingrich now seems to be thinking about dropping out of the race altogether.

title: Talking About Testing: Ideas for Inquiry and Discussion on Standardized Testing
description: Students in New York City are currently taking standardized tests, and The Timess SchoolBook blog has been busy reporting on them  in posts on the outcry over a contested question about a pineapple without sleeves, on parents choosing to keep their children home during tests, and from a staff developer on how testing is hurting teaching.

title: Fed Outlook: No Big Steps, No Retreat
description: There are times when the Federal Reserve is on the verge of movement, when the latest economic data could easily produce a shift in the nations monetary policy.

title: In Charter Battle, Union Turns to School's Namesake for Help
Dining Out at Ethnic Supermarkets in Los Angeles
description: I can trace my interest in supermarkets as tourist attractions to time I spent in the Dominican Republic 17 years ago, when, shopping with local friends, I was downright shocked by the variety of shapes and sizes of the kitchen tool invented to smash a once-fried plantain slice before tossing it back into the oil to make a tostn.

title: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from France, England, North Korea and India.

title: To Encourage Good Habits, Test Early and Often in High School
Older Men Still Being Screened for Prostate Cancer
description: Many men 75 years and older, who are far more likely to be harmed than helped by prostate cancer screening, continue to be tested for the disease, despite federal guidelines strongly advising against the practice.

title: Kabul Toasts the Queen With a Cool Drink, and the Fizz of Diplomacy
description: Strains of God Save the Queen floated over Kabul on Sunday.

title: TimesCast | Questioning Austerity
description: April 24, 2012  As strict austerity measures take root across Europe, some wonder whether the cuts will harm more than they help.

title: Bomb at Train Station Kills 2 and Injures 27 in Pakistan
description: LAHORE, Pakistan  A bomb exploded inside the busiest railway station in this eastern Pakistani city late Tuesday afternoon, killing at least two people and injuring 27, police officials said.

title: JPMorgans New Asia Chief Sees Growth Opportunities
description: Over his four years at JPMorgan Chase, Jeff Urwin has taken an increasingly global role. Now, the next stop in his career involves moving halfway around the world.

title: Obama Calls Agents in Scandal Knuckleheads
description: BOULDER, Colo.  President Obama on Tuesday called the Secret Service agents caught in a prostitution scandal a couple of knuckleheads who did not reflect the overall professionalism of the agency.

title: Art Is Long; Copyrights Can Even Be Longer
description: It is there in the new 3-D version of Titanic, as it was in James Camerons original film: a modified version of Picassos painting Les Demoiselles dAvignon aboard the ship as it sinks.

title: The Culinary Definition of Neighborly
description: THERE are many different kinds of neighbors in Manhattan. There are those who bang on the ceiling at the slightest click of a high heel on hardwood. There are others who dart into a darkened doorway, threatened by a curious glance. And then there are Robyn and Jesse.

title: Nonprofit Group Highlights Privacy Issues in Mobile Payments
description: Some mobile payment methods are so convenient that you can walk into a store and buy something without even taking your smartphone out of your pocket. But at what cost?

title: Apple Profit Rises on Higher iPhone and iPad Sales
description: Not long after the iPhone came out, skeptics questioned how much appeal the costly device and related wireless service would have in countries like China with lower income levels. On Tuesday, Apple provided the answer: A lot.

title: Whats in Store | Maison Kitsun
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Facebook Fight in Germany Leads to Battle Over Privacy
description: BERLIN  Ariane Friedrich, a German Olympic high-jump hopeful, knows how to pull a tough face, a gun and, it seems, a fast one on a fan who sent her an obscene message over Facebook.

title: With Depleted Primary Field, Romney Looks to Win Big
description: Republicans in five states are voting Tuesday in primaries that party leaders hope will serve to accentuate Mitt Romneys status as the presumed nominee for the fall election against President Obama.

title: Empelln Cocina
description: Inside the chef Alex Stupaks Mexican restaurant in the East Village.

title: A Taste of Mexico, as in a Dream
description: THE danger in writing about the smart and often inspired cooking at Empelln Cocina, Alex Stupaks free-associating mash note to the food of Mexico, is that other chefs might get the idea that anybody can do what he has done.

title: Beaming Colors From Up North
description: I SHOULD admit upfront that I knew the thread was frayed. Before I walked out my front door, Id noticed how flimsily the button was held by the string, how uncertain it looked, almost shrugging in defeat.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Arrested in Russia and Nokias Problems
description: Here are some of the most interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Tuesday. There are more here.

title: As Demand Rises, Ohios Steel Mills Shake Off the Rust and Expand
description: CANTON, Ohio  The Ohio steel industry, led by a drilling boom in the gas and oil industry and a resuscitated demand for cars and light trucks, is growing again. Steel makers across the state are racing to keep pace with plans to add a total of two million square feet of production space at a cost of $1.5 billion.

title: The Arizona Show
description: Senator Charles Schumer of New York, chairman of the Judiciary Committees subcommittee on immigration, refugees and border security,called a hearing this morning on Arizonas immigration law.

title: A Mexican Restaurant Has to Give Up Tacos
description: Its not exactly a Mexican standoff, but it is a decidedly odd dining arrangement.

title: Lincoln Centers Out of Doors Returns for 42nd Year
description: A funk concert by Nile Rodgers, an experimental composition by Phil Kline and a recital by the Cleo Parker Robinson Dance Ensemble are among the highlights of Lincoln Centers 42nd Out of Doors festival, which will run from July 25 to Aug. 12.

title: Prima
description: 58 East First Street (First Avenue); (646) 559-4823; primanyc.net.

title: La Churreria
description: 284 Mulberry Street (Houston Street); (212) 219-0400; lachurrerianyc.com.

title: David W. Levinson
description: Mr. Levinson, 63, is the chairman and chief of the L & L Holding Company, which is based in New York and owns and operates five million square feet of office space in the Manhattan area. Its portfolio includes 200 Fifth Avenue, once called the International Toy Center, and 425 Park Avenue, which is about to be redeveloped.

title: Final for Chelsea; Creeping Doubts for Barcelona
description: BARCELONA, Spain  When it was over, and the balloons had shriveled and the whistles had faded away, Lionel Messi put his hands to his head. The slick, slippery forward stood still, rooted to his spot. It was as if he could not believe what he was seeing.

title: Slide Show: Prima
description: Prima is a small restaurant in the East Village that acts like a bar  its a coffee bar in the morning, a raw bar, wine bar and cocktail bar at night  but some of the most exciting dishes to come out of the kitchen are classic restaurant fare, namely fish entrees prepared according to traditional French technique: seared in butter on the stovetop and finished in the oven.

title: Knicks Give Grunwald a Promotion, and Woodson Gets a Boost
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The Knicks rewarded Glen Grunwald on Tuesday, removing the interim from his title of general manager after a wildly unpredictable season in which the team finished above .500 and is heading to the playoffs with considerable momentum.

title: Why the Debt That Burdens the Modern World Is About More Than Money
description: A glance at the headlines from Europe, the news from Washington or this months bills will confirm that we live in an age of debt. Debt, a concept at once straightforward and almost metaphysically complex, is a source of personal, national and global anxiety, and forms a link between the individual and the worldwide economic system.

title: Three Dishes at Empelln Cocina
description: At Empelln Cocina, Alex Stupak and his wife and partner, Lauren Resler, have given themselves permission to stick to Mexicos traditional cuisine when it suits them and to leave tradition behind when that seems like a more intriguing path. I spoke with them on the phone this week to learn the inspirations and innovations behind three of the restaurants best dishes.

title: Violence in Syrias Capital Even With a Cease-Fire
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Three members of the Syrian security services used to suppress antigovernment dissent were killed in and around Damascus on Tuesday, according to the official media and activists, one of several indications that the cease-fire arranged under United Nations auspices continued to wobble.

title: Refused, Reunited
description: The 1990s Swedish hardcore band performed at Terminal 5 on Monday night, its second New York City show after regrouping for the Coachella festival.

title: Swedes Who Know How to Stay Mad as Hell
description: Like any sensible punk-rockers, the 1990s Swedish band Refused was skeptical about reuniting. Why would these old guys play these old songs? Dennis Lyxzen, the bands lead singer (and screamer), asked onstage at the sold-out Terminal 5 on Monday night, in its second New York City show after Refused regrouped for the Coachella festival.

title: Pioneers Who Helped Fill More Than a Breadbasket
description: In 1910 a dozen young Eastern European Jews moved to the Jordan Valley, then under Ottoman rule, and began to build an agrarian community based on a utopian socialist vision. Men and women were treated equally, everyone shared all they had, and no one had more than anyone else.

title: Fraud Heightens Jeopardy of Investing in Chinese Companies
description: You might think that if you bought shares of a Chinese company that was listed on an American stock market, you would actually own a piece of that company.

title: Philadelphia Orchestra Settles Pension Dispute With Musicians
description: The Philadelphia Orchestra said on Tuesday that it had settled a dispute with its musicians national pension fund, calling the agreement a critical step in its effort to emerge from bankruptcy court. The orchestra agreed to pay $1.75 million to the American Federation of Musicians and Employers Pension Fund, it said, in exchange for the funds dropping its claims against the orchestra. The orchestra had withdrawn from the fund, prompting the fund to say that it was owed $35 million as a consequence. That was one of the demands dropped under the agreement, the orchestra said.

title: Principals Criticize Increased Costs of Test Scoring
Riverpark Adds an Outdoor Farm Table
description: Riverpark, the restaurant in the Alexandria Center, a group of office towers overlooking the East River at 29th Street, has had its own farm since last year. Nearly 200 different edible herbs, vegetables and berries are planted in soil in 4,000 milk crates set up in the plaza in front of the restaurant.

title: Big Ratings for Playoffs
description: More people are watching the Stanley Cup playoffs in the United States this year, partly because four national networks are covering them, up from two in recent seasons.

title: The End of the World of Video as We Know It
description: The idea of going to a store to pick out a movie that you would take home and watch on your own TV: some of us remember when this was a novelty. We think it was before cellphones, but were not quite sure, having long ago given up on keeping up with technology.

title: Patagonia Starts a Food Line
description: For years, Patagonia, the outdoor clothier, has been outfitting adventurers for forays into the wilderness. Now the company is exploring a frontier of its own: food. Its starting a new line called Patagonia Provisions, advertised as sustainable substance  portable, nutritious, shelf-stable snacks to tuck into the pocket of that polyester fleece garment.

title: A Louis Armstrong Performance, Recipes Included
description: On Jan. 29, 1971, five months before his death, Louis Armstrong performed for the last time, at the National Press Club in Washington, to celebrate the inauguration of Vernon Louviere, a journalist from New Orleans, as the clubs president. Served with the jazz were bayou dishes including shrimp mousse, jambalaya and a Jamaica rum pie prepared by Christopher Blake, a New Orleans writer and chef.

title: For Santorum, Its All Over but the Endorsement
description: This was supposed to have been Rick Santorums comeback night.

title: Next Up to Testify, Rupert Murdoch, Who Has Been Prepping
description: Even as testimony by James Murdoch on Tuesday was agitating the British political scene  over the extent of his knowledge of phone-hacking at News International papers and particularly over his contacts with the British government concerning business deals  his father, Rupert, was prepared to take his seat on Wednesday.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: Dining Calendar
description: Benefits

title: Wal-Mart Vows to Fix Its Controls
description: Allegations of widespread bribery at Wal-Marts Mexican subsidiary continued to reverberate on Tuesday, with the company beginning a campaign to limit the damage as its shares declined further.

title: Edwardss Former Aide Takes the Stand
description: April 24, 20112 - At John Edwards trial in North Carolina, his former campaign staffer Andrew Young is on the stand for his second day of testimony for the prosecution.

title: No Pressure: Just Make Obama Laugh
description: LOS ANGELES  A little over a week before Jimmy Kimmel would face the assembled Washington press corps, the nations political leaders and assorted celebrities, all decked out in formalwear in a noisy ballroom, he found himself waking suddenly in the middle of the night: He wasnt racked by nerves; he had simply thought of another joke in his sleep.

title: North Carolina, I Love You. I Really, Really Love You.
description: During his speech at the University of North Carolina today, President Obama mentioned North Carolina 10 times, mostly to say how much he loves it. Love North Carolina, he said. I love North Carolina. I do. Every time I come down to this state I just love it that much more.

title: Misconduct in Colombia Varied, an Inquiry Finds
description: WASHINGTON  After the Secret Service scandal erupted nearly two weeks ago, the accusations of egregious behavior by the men entrusted with protecting President Obama seemed clear-cut. Members of Congress and tabloids depicted a dozen agency employees meeting prostitutes in their hotel rooms and drunken revels at brothels or strip clubs involving up to 20 women.

title: The Soul of a New Ensemble: Musicians as Entrepreneurs
description: In a New York University lecture hall, business school students poked at iPads and iPhones to produce short melodic loops through speakers. A few feet away, a small group of musicians about the same age played along in a performance of Terry Rileys Minimalist masterpiece In C.

title: Wholehearted Songs for Lovelorn Joe Six-Packs
description: In 2009 Lee Brice released Love Like Crazy, the first single from the album of the same title, a pulpy croon that shuttled between two seemingly competing sides of Mr. Brices personality. Is he a wide-eyed celebrant of everlasting love or a kooky raconteur of lifes little offbeat surprises?

title: Fresh Pairings for Liszt, With Bird Imagery Hovering
description: It would have been unlike Pierre-Laurent Aimard to celebrate Liszts bicentenary with a straightforward recording and recitals to match. Mr. Aimard has, to a large extent, taken over the role of the keyboards deep thinker from Alfred Brendel, with Jeremy Denk and Jonathan Biss in hot pursuit (not that there must be only one). His programs are typically built to look beyond how striking a set of works is, or how thoughtfully and colorfully Mr. Aimard plays them, though those thoughts invariably come to mind as well.

title: Opening a Trove of City Snapshots, Not Quite a Million Deep
description: Call it Forward to the Future. The Bloomberg administration unveiled a trove of 870,000 digitized images and media from the city archives Tuesday, with photographs dating from 1858, color images from the 1980s of every building in the city, and farm maps dating to 160 years ago. The gallery is accessible free on the citys Web site (though opening-day traffic was so heavy that its been down most of the afternoon), and reprints and digital copies are available for purchase.

title: Tim Cook Spells Out the Rapid Growth of Apples iPad
description: Apple on Tuesday posted a blowout second quarter, nearly doubling its profit from the year-ago quarter. Thats notable because in years past, Apples second-quarter earnings had not been nearly as strong. The iPad, however, has helped change that.

title: At CinemaCon, Theater Owners Are the Stars
description: LAS VEGAS All week, movie executives will be arriving at Caesars Palace to kiss the rings of the big multiplex operators and learn about the latest advancements in popped corn. Its CinemaCon, the official convention of the National Association of Theater Owners.

title: Rising Demand in U.S. Helps 3M Beat Earnings Estimates
description: The 3M Company, maker of Post-it notes and fuel system tuneup kits, reported a 4.6 percent increase in its first-quarter profit on Tuesday, beating analysts forecasts, as industrial demand in the United States helped offset slowing markets abroad.

title: Etan, and the SoHo of Our Childhood
description: Another heartbreak. Each time Etan Patzs name comes back into the news, I hope for closure. I was his neighbor, and, like every other kid downtown, it could just as easily have been me. Only I didnt think that at the time.

title: The Caucus Click: Getting Ready for Romney
For AlixPartners, a Sale Provides Avenue for Expansion Abroad
description: The consulting firm AlixPartners  changed hands on Tuesday after it agreed to be sold to the private equity firm CVC Capital Partners, but its goal of expanding abroad remains the same.

title: Romney Adviser Takes Different Tack With Senate Race
description: Mitt Romney and Senator Scott P. Brown of Massachusetts may share a senior adviser, Eric Fehrnstrom, but theyre certainly getting different advice, at least when it comes to tax returns.

title: The Unconscious Impact of The Conflict
description: Motherlode has asked women at different stages of their family and career lives to respond to Elisabeth Badinters The Conflict by describing how reading it has affected their views or plans for work and motherhood. The following is a continuation of an ongoing conversation.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,931 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: U.S. Womens Soccer Team Draws Path Against Japan for Olympic Gold
description: One year after losing to Japan in a compelling World Cup final, the United States womens soccer team may have the rematch it has been seeking at this summers London Olympics.

title: Greenpeace Protests Apples Energy Practices By Releasing Balloons
description: The skies over the glass cube that serves as the entrance to the Apple store on Fifth Avenue turned a bit dark on Tuesday afternoon, at least for some shoppers inside. And a passing storm had nothing to do with it.

title: Rangers in Game 7: By the Numbers
description: The top-seeded Rangers face eighth-seeded Ottawa in Game 7 at Madison Square Garden on Thursday. The Rangers record in Game 7s is 3-5 but a perfect 3-0 at home, while the Senators are 0-4 in Game 7s. But other numbers suggest this Game 7 is a tossup.

title: Police Seeking Tips on Armed Robbery of McDonalds in Queens
description: The police are looking for a robber who forced workers at a McDonalds in Queens into a walk-in freezer at gunpoint on Thursday.

title: A Test for Arizonas Immigration Law
description: To the Editor:

title: For Bruins, Preparing for Game 7 Is Nothing New
description: WILMINGTON, Mass.  Another Stanley Cup playoff series, another Game 7 for the Boston Bruins. For the fifth time in their last six playoff series, the Bruins have been taken to the maximum, this time by the Washington Capitals. Game 7 of their first-round playoff series will be Wednesday night in Boston.

title: Stylish Hotels Sprouting in Brooklyn and Queens
description: The New York City hotel market managed to defy the slump most of the country experienced during and after the recession.

title: Level Global Founder Is Said to Have Been on Insider Trading Call
description: 8:18 p.m. | Updated

title: Alternatives to Stop-and-Frisk to Fight Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: Understanding Motives Behind Teens Distracted Driving
description: Many young drivers are in denial about their distracted driving tendencies. Girls are far more likely to engage in distracted behavior behind the wheel than boys. Parents often set bad examples.

title: Egyptian Actor Insulted Islam, a Court Finds
description: CAIRO  A court found Egypts most popular comic actor guilty on Tuesday of insulting Islam in roles in films mocking religious hypocrisy, alarming liberal-minded artists and intellectuals already anxious about the growing power of Islamists here after the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak.

title: Mixed Messages
description: To the Editor:

title: Curbing Executive Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: Marines Moving Women Toward the Front Lines
description: The Marine Corps, the most male of the armed services, is taking its first steps toward integrating women into war-fighting units, starting with its infantry officer school at Quantico, Va., and ground combat battalions that had once been closed to women.

title: Apple Chiefs Offhand Comment Spawns Internet Quip
description: Timothy D. Cook, Apples chief executive, made an easily overlooked comment in Apples conference call with Wall Street analysts on Tuesday evening, during all the discussion of impressive quarterly sales and profits. But, of course, the Internet overlooks nothing.

title: An Early Exit and Possible Shake-Up
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The Vancouver Canucks got revenge, but it did not help in the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: BTG Pactual Raises $1.93 Billion in I.P.O.
description: BTG Pactual, the Brazilian investment banking powerhouse, raised $3.625 billion reais ($1.93 billion) on Tuesday night in the largest Brazilian initial public offering of stock since Banco Santander Brasil went public in 2009.

title: Struggle Between Leaders of Players Union Creates Chaos
description: Five months after settling a damaging lockout, the N.B.A. players union is facing a more existential threat: an internal power struggle that has thrown the association into chaos.

title: Israel Retroactively Legalizes 3 West Bank Settlements
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli government on Tuesday retroactively legalized three Jewish settlement outposts in the West Bank, and moved to delay the scheduled evacuation of a fourth, in a provocative move that some critics said marked the first establishment of new settlements in two decades.

title: An MF Global Trustee Defends His Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  Louis J. Freeh, who gained prominence in Washington as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, delivered a broad defense on Tuesday of his latest role as bankruptcy trustee for MF Global.

title: Yankees Growing Concerned on Pineda
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  The Yankees have growing concern about Michael Pinedas right-shoulder injury, which has not healed as hoped and may be more serious than initially believed.

title: Case of Mad Cow Disease Is Found in U.S.
description: The Department of Agriculture announced that it had identified a case of mad cow disease, the first in six years, in a dairy cow in central California.

title: Romney Delivers Big Primary Wins, Assails Obama in Speech
description: Mitt Romney declared that he had accomplished a sweep of five states Tuesday night and laid claim to the Republican presidential nomination after what he said were 43 primaries and caucuses and many long nights.

title: Should the Privacy of a Stalker Be Protected?
description: One of Germanys Olympic hopefuls is facing a whole new challenge that raises questions about victims and perpetrators and the limits of privacy in the digital age.

title: Giving Away, and Then Seizing, Condoms
description: Last year, New York City health workers gave out 37.2 million condoms. That works out to an average of 70 condoms every minute of the year. The city got into mass-scale condom distribution to help prevent the spread of debilitating and deadly diseases.

title: For Quinn Wedding, Politics on the Side
description: She has joked about caterer tastings and trying on dresses. She has sent out hundreds of invitations, sprinkled with references to an early romantic getaway at the Pierre hotel and a shared affection for the Jersey Shore. In just a few weeks, she will walk down the aisle, with brooches from her mother fastened in her hair and surrounded by wildflowers meant to evoke those on the High Line.

title: A Cable Start-Up Lands 3 Big Brands
description: A START-UP cable channel led by Magic Johnson, the basketball star turned businessman, is getting an early vote of confidence from several large marketer clients of a major media agency.

title: Taking On Dementia With the Experiences of Normal Life
description: WEESP, the Netherlands  The sparkling-new 23-unit Hogewey complex here is virtually indistinguishable from other residential developments in the area. The apartments open onto a courtyard with benches, ponds and fountains, with beds of flowers in season (this is the Netherlands, after all). One kidney-shaped pond planted with reeds and other vegetation occasionally attracts wild ducks.

title: I Hunt, but the N.R.A. Isnt for Me
description: Bend, Ore.

title: Wendell Berry, American Hero
description: The sensibility of Wendell Berry, who is sometimes described as a modern day Thoreau but who Id call the soul of the real food movement, leads people like me on a path to the door of the hillside house he shares with his wife, Tanya, outside of Port Royal, Ky. Everything is as the pilgrim would have it: Wendell (hes a one-name icon, like Madonna, but probably in that respect only) is kind and welcoming, all smiles.

title: Disability Insurance Causes Pain
description: Every year, when the trustees of Social Security and Medicare publish their report on the programs finances they set off a round of partisan bickering about the solvency of the twin programs covering pensions and health care for retired Americans.

title: Muddy Waters
description: Washington

title: No Rest for the Weary Watson
description: AVONDALE, La.  Ten years before Bubba Watson won the Masters on the strength of a miracle shot, he made his PGA Tour debut at English Turn Golf and Country Club, on the west bank of the Mississippi River, roughly 18 miles from the Tour stops current location at the T.P.C. Louisiana.

title: Defendant No. 34 Has Her Say
description: Beirut, Lebanon

title: A Finishing School of Tough Love for Draftees
description: GAINESVILLE, Ga.  They share details with him about arrests and failed drug tests, substandard work habits and disciplinary infractions.

title: With 5 More Victories, Romney Focuses on the Fall
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Mitt Romney effectively assumed the helm of the Republican Party on Tuesday after five primary victories across the Northeast solidified his stature as the presidential nominee-in-waiting who is trying to unite conservatives and persuade independent voters that President Obama does not deserve a second term.

title: S.E.C. Asks if Hollywood Paid Bribes in China
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun an investigation into whether some of Hollywoods biggest movie studios have made illegal payments to officials in China to gain the right to film and show movies there, according to a person with knowledge of the investigation.

title: Subsidize Students, Not Tax Cuts
description: In 2007, President George W. Bush signed a bill that cut in half interest rates on subsidized student loans until 2012. Those low rates will expire on July 1  going back to 6.8 percent from 3.4 percent  and, to prevent college from becoming even more unaffordable for millions of students, the obvious move is to renew them. But nothing is that easy or sensible anymore in Washington, where House Republicans are far more interested in cutting taxes, largely for the rich, than they are in helping low- and middle-income students get a college education.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 24, 2012

title: A Changed South Central
description: The population of South Los Angeles has changed significantly in the two decades since the acquittal of white police officers in the beating of Rodney King inflamed racial tensions across the city.

title: Arizona and Interposition
description: An important verb appears on page 14 of the governments brief in Arizona v. the United States, the case about four provisions of that states immigration law that will be argued on Wednesday in the Supreme Court. The government says Arizona is trying to interpose its own judgments on national security, law enforcement, foreign policy, humanitarian considerations and the rights of law-abiding citizens and aliens. It says the Constitution and Congress, in the Immigration and Nationality Act, give the executive branch authority to handle those issues.

title: Battling Over Budget Cuts
description: The brief truce between the Air Force and the Air National Guard over proposed budget cuts may already be unraveling in the Senate.

title: Rangers and Senators Near End of Roiling Series
description: The day after the Rangers forced a Game 7 with the Ottawa Senators  Thursday at Madison Square Garden  the teams awaited disciplinary rulings from the N.H.L. on the outbursts that stained the Rangers 3-2 victory in Game 6.

title: Shifting Demographics in South Los Angeles
description: Since the Los Angeles riots 20 years ago, the once largely black South Central neighborhood is now two-thirds Hispanic.

title: In Years Since the Riots, a Changed Complexion in South Central
description: LOS ANGELES  When racially charged riots blazed here two decades ago, South Central became a national symbol of rage in a poor black neighborhood.

title: Consumers Need More Protection, Not Less
description: The new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is supposed to shield Americans from abusive banking and lending practices. And in its first nine months, it has been doing a good job. But consumer advocates are rightly alarmed that the bureau might now revoke a Federal Reserve rule that limited the fees credit card issuers can charge new customers.

title: A Dollop of Yogurt for  or, on  Obama
description: BOULDER, Colo.  Taking a bullet for the president is one thing. But fermented milk? It hasnt been a great week for the Secret Service.

title: Flamboyant Son of Fallen Chinese Leader Makes a Statement
description: HONG KONG  In the most sensational political drama in decades in China, the fall of the former Politburo member Bo Xilai has captivated the country for months with its cloak-and-dagger intrigue, charges of corruption and murder, and a compelling cast of personalities.

title: Does the V.A. Get It?
description: The Department of Veterans Affairs says it plans to hire 1,900 psychiatrists, psychologists, social workers, clinicians and clerical employees, a 10 percent increase in its mental health staff. Thats welcome progress for a system that is struggling to meet the needs of veterans. But there are questions about whether it will be enough  and whether the department is truly facing up to its problems.

title: Using U.S. Dollars, Zimbabwe Finds a Problem: No Change
description: HARARE, Zimbabwe  When Zimbabweans say they are waiting for change, they are usually talking about politics. After all, the country has had the same leader since 1980.

title: Group Says It Has Ceased Bomb Threats on Campus
description: As students headed to final exams at the University of Pittsburgh this week, with many exhausted and frustrated by more than 100 bomb threats that have disrupted classes and emptied dorms, they were hoping there would be no further evacuations now that a group has announced its bomb threat campaign is over.

title: Push to Give Midsize Farms a Hub at a Bronx Market
description: Decades after the slow-food movement began championing the benefits of locally grown fruits and vegetables, pressure is mounting for New York City to stand up to big vendors and make room for the regions midsize farms at the Hunts Point wholesale produce market in the South Bronx.

title: Nice Work If You Can Get It
description: Photos from the Broadway musical starring Matthew Broderick and Kelli OHara.

title: Fraud Trial for Espada Is Concluding After 6 Weeks
description: The six-week trial of Pedro Espada Jr., the former state senator whose audacious power grab brought the New York Legislature to a halt in 2009, approached its conclusion on Tuesday, with a federal prosecutor telling the jury during closing arguments that Mr. Espada used a nonprofit health care network that he ran as his own personal A.T.M.

title: Bid to Block Postal Service Bill Falls Short in Senate
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Tuesday defeated a Republican attempt to block a vote on a bill to save the struggling Postal Service. The vote was 62 to 37.

title: Are Family Values Outdated?
I See You
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Can you see the theme in todays puzzle? Or rather, can you C it?

title: Falling in Love, Footstep by Footstep
description: Every now and then, a bubble of pure, tickling charm rises from the artificial froth of Nice Work if You Can Get It, the pastiche of a 1920s musical featuring songs by George and Ira Gershwin. Most of this show, which opened on Tuesday night at the Imperial Theater, registers as a shiny, dutiful trickle of jokes and dance numbers performed by talented people who dont entirely connect with the whimsy of a bygone genre.

title: Ten-Term Democrat Holden Loses in Pennsylvania Primary
description: Ten-term Representative Tim Holden of Pennsylvania was defeated in a Democratic primary on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press, losing to Matt Cartwright, a lawyer, who made Mr. Holdens vote against President Obamas health care law a major issue in the newly redrawn 17th District.

title: Study of Fighters Shows Brain Changes Are Seen Before Symptoms
description: LAS VEGAS  One of the questions Dr. Charles Bernick and his colleagues ask boxers who come to the Cleveland Clinics Lou Ruvo Center for Brain Health here is, How many times have you been knocked out cold or gotten a concussion? Most say, never.

title: Genres Stretch, for Better and Worse, as YouTube Takes On TV
description: Standing in front of what looks like a frosted-blue shower stall, Hank Green, his nerd glasses riding low on his nose, puts his face up close to the tiny puppet on his finger.

title: Mitt Romney Speaks in New Hampshire
description: Mitt Romney spoke to supporters at a primary night rally in Manchester, N.H. Mr. Romney focused the majority of his remarks on the fall campaign.

title: Even Before the Game, the Mets Lose Two
description: Jose Reyes was back at Citi Field on Tuesday night as a Miami Marlin, a walking, smiling symbol of how ephemeral baseball can be. Meanwhile, the Mets, his old team, were reeling from a double shot of disheartening injury news, a reminder that some things never change.

title: Brutality of Servility
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.

title: Warmth of Campus Spotlight Beckons Obama Back
description: BOULDER, Colo.  The arenas are rocking, the students are whooping and President Obama is feeling the love.

title: Corrections: April 25
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Turkey Feels Sway of Reclusive Cleric in the U.S.
description: ISTANBUL  When Ahmet Sik was jailed last year on charges of plotting to overthrow the government, he had little doubt that a secretive movement linked to a reclusive imam living in the United States was behind his arrest.

title: Fierce Debate on Arizona Immigration Law on Eve of Supreme Court Hearing
description: WASHINGTON  A day before the Supreme Court was to hear arguments on an Arizona statute that expanded the immigration enforcement powers of local police, the author of the law defended it in a Senate hearing under sharp questioning from Democrats, saying it removes the political handcuffs from state and local law enforcement.

title: Devils Prevail and Force a Game 7
description: NEWARK  Early in overtime of a game the Devils had to win, Ilya Kovalchuk, their $100 million forward, collected a puck inside the Florida blue line, and instead of skating toward the goal, swerved to his right, then passed the puck instead of shooting it.

title: Ruling Extends Sex-Discrimination Protection to Transgender Woman Denied Federal Job
description: In a decision hailed by advocates for transgender people, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has ruled that a California woman who was denied a job at the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives after revealing that she was transitioning from her former life as a man can seek legal redress under sex-discrimination regulations.

title: Doris Betts, Novelist in Southern Tradition, Dies at 79
description: Doris Betts, an award-winning novelist and short-story writer whose characters grappled with religious faith, freedom, captivity and original sin in tales steeped in the Southern literary tradition, died on April 21 at her home in Pittsboro, N.C. She was 79.

title: Poll: New Yorkers Want New City School Policies from Next Mayor
Two Japanese Starters: One Good, One Great
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  One of the most highly anticipated pitching matchups in years, at least in Japan, was equal to the expectations Tuesday night.

title: Justice Department Submits Correction Letter to Supreme Court
description: The Justice Department told the Supreme Court on Tuesday evening that it had provided incorrect information to the justices in an immigration case. The department, in a seven-page letter, expressed regret for failing in its special obligation to provide this court with reliable and accurate information at all times.

title: George Cowan, Nuclear Scientist, Dies at 92
description: George Cowan, a chemist who helped build the first atomic bomb, detect the first Soviet nuclear explosion and test the first hydrogen bomb, died on Friday at his home in Los Alamos, N.M. He was 92.

title: Romney Wins Five Primaries
description: Mitt Romney won primary victories in New York, Pennsylvania, Connecticut, Rhode Island and Delaware on Tuesday, but he chose to be in New Hampshire instead to speak about general election themes.

title: Playing the Mormon Card
description: During the long Republican primary season, the highest-profile attack on Mitt Romneys Mormon faith came in October during the Values Voters Summit in Washington, when the pastor who introduced Rick Perry to the assembly, Robert Jeffress of Dallass First Baptist Church, told reporters that born-again followers of Christ should always prefer a competent Christian for the presidency and dismissed Mormonism as a pseudo-Christian cult.

title: The Evolution of the Runners High
description: Ferrets dont often figure in studies of exercise, perhaps because they dont exercise much. They slink like fog through tunnels, sprint briefly over open ground and spend much of their time sleeping. They are, in biological terms, whats called a noncursorial species, meaning that they are reluctant and lousy distance runners.

title: Salesforce Moves Into the Government Cloud and Social
description: Salesforce.com, best know for its sales, customer service and collaboration software for business, is now entering the government cloud business with a suite of new product offerings that could help thegovernmentadapt to todayssocial era.

title: Word of the Day | impale
description: impale \im-pal\ verb

title: Yemen: Defiant Commander Gives Up
description: The commander of the countrys air force agreed to give up his post on Tuesday, easing a political standoff that began weeks ago after some officials loyal to the former president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, refused orders from the new president, Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi, to step down. Mr. Hadi, who took office in February, has also faced several other crises in recent weeks, including clashes between militants and the army in the south and a spate of kidnappings. After several days of negotiations brokered by a United Nations envoy, Jamal Benomar, the air force chief, Gen. Mohammed Saleh al-Ahmar, who is the former presidents half brother, agreed to be replaced on Tuesday by Gen. Rashid Ali Nasser al-Jund.

title: U.S. Warns North Korea on Nuclear Test
description: Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta warned North Korea on Tuesday not to conduct another nuclear test, saying it would create greater instability in a dangerous part of the world. At a news conference in Brazil during a South American tour, Mr. Panetta said he had no information that North Korea was preparing for a test, although the South Korean government believes that is the case. This month, North Korea tried and failed to launch a rocket meant to put a satellite in orbit, which the United States condemned. I strongly urge North Korea not to engage in any further provocations, Mr. Panetta said. North Korea conducted nuclear tests in 2006 and 2009.

title: The Closer: Crawfords Replacements Doing Just Fine
description: The Boston Red Sox are undoubtedly eager to get the injured Carl Crawford back into their lineup, but according to at least one statistic, they may not want to rush.

title: Measles Deaths Drop in India
