description: The number of measles deaths worldwide has apparently dropped by about three-quarters over a decade, according to a new study by the World Health Organization and others, the Associated Press reports.

title: Son of Bo Xilai Reacts to News Media Coverage
description: The 24-year-old son of Bo Xilai, the ousted Communist Party official at the heart of a major political scandal in China, has made his first public statement to the news media.

title: The Medicine Baba Goes Door to Door
description: The Medicine Baba, Omkar Nath Sharma, 75, spends his days knocking on doors in Delhis upper and middle class neighborhoods, collecting their leftover medicines and giving them to the poor.

title: News Quiz | April 25, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Foreign Journalists Fall for Modi P.R. Machine
description: Narendra Modi, the leading figure of Indias right-wing Bharatiya Janata Party, didnt make Time magazines list of the 100 most powerful people in the world this year, Hartosh Singh Bal writes in the Latitude blog of The New York Times. Midway through the online polling, after Modis stock had started to surge, liberals in India organized a counter-campaign. In the end, 256,792 votes were cast for him and 266,684 votes against, Mr. Bal writes.

title: A Conversation With: USIBC Chairman Ajay Banga
description: Ajay Banga, the president and chief executive of electronic payment company MasterCard, was recently named the new chairman of the United States India Business Council, a trade group formed in 1975.

title: Credit Suisse Profit Falls 96% in First Quarter
description: LONDON  Credit Suisse said on Wednesday that its profit fell 96 percent in the first quarter, as the big Swiss bank continued to contend with the dual headwinds of a new regulatory environment and an economic slump.

title: April 25, 1945 | Conference to Form U.N. Meets as Allied Forces Near Victory Over Nazis
description: On April 25, 1945, in San Francisco, 46 nations met to discuss the creation of the United Nations, an international organization intended to maintain peace between nations. The conference began as troops from the United States and Soviet Union linked up on the Elbe River, in central Europe, a meeting that dramatized the collapse of Nazi Germany and the end of World War II in Europe.

title: Murdoch, Center Stage, Plays Powerless Broker
description: LONDON  By his own telling, Rupert Murdoch has portrayed himself as a man with Britains most power-packed Rolodex: gossiping with Margaret Thatcher about Ronald Reagan, drinking too much after his backing secured an improbable victory for John Major, joshing that he and Tony Blair were like two porcupines mating, fielding barbed threats from Gordon Brown and slipping in the back door of 10 Downing Street as David Camerons first visitor after his election.

title: Pakistan Says It Test-Fires Nuclear-Capable Missile
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistan successfully tested an improved intermediate-range ballistic missile early on Wednesday, according to a statement by the Pakistani military.

title: Test Yourself | Math, April 25, 2012
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article Luxury Stores Pull Out Mandarin Phrase Books to Make the Sale.

title: Updates on Rupert Murdochs Testimony in Britain
description: The Lede followed testimony by Rupert Murdoch and other developments in a judicial inquiry into the behavior of the British press that grew out of a widening phone hacking and corruption scandal at Murdoch-owned papers in Britain. Mr. Murdochs son James  testified for several hours on Tuesday.

title: Deck Me Out for the Ballgame
description: WHO is spending significant amounts of money on equipment for youth baseball?

title: Photos That Move and Flow  Underwater
description: The underwater photographer David Doubilet has had more than 70 photo stories in the National Geographic magazine, a dozen books and countless exhibits across the world.

title: What is the Ministry of Health Trying to Tell Doctors?
description: A top government minister, Ghulam Nabi Azad, this week delivered a jolt to Indias aspiring doctors that became front-page news on Tuesday: Any student wishing to continue their medical education in the United States would now have to sign a bond binding them to return to India once their studies were completed. Why? Mr. Azad said the tougher regulation was linked to a change in United States policy.

title: Violence in Syrias Capital Even With a Cease-Fire
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Three members of the Syrian security services used to suppress antigovernment dissent were killed in and around Damascus on Tuesday, according to the official media and activists, one of several indications that the cease-fire arranged under United Nations auspices continued to wobble. In addition, a small bomb exploded outside an Iranian culture and travel center in the center of Damascus, the Syrian capital, wounding four people but not causing much damage.

title: What Leader Would You Invite to Speak at Your School?
description: Seniors at Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan recently created a YouTube video to try to entice the Knicks star Jeremy Lin to speak at their graduation. And students in Chicago had the opportunity recently to be taught by Nobel Prize winners as well as other world leaders and celebrities. If you could invite any living leader  in politics, science, religion, entertainment, sports or anything else  to speak to your class, whom would you invite and why?

title: Ericsson Reports Strong First-Quarter Earnings
description: Ericsson, the biggest maker of mobile telecommunications network equipment, said Wednesday that net income had more  than doubled in the first quarter of 2012 on a gain from the sale of its stake in a cellphone business and demand from operators in Latin America, China and Southeast Asia.

title: Pakistan Says It Test Fires Nuclear-Capable Missile
description: Pakistan successfully tested an improved intermediate range nuclear capable ballistic missile early on Wednesday, according to a statement by the Pakistani military, Salman Masood writes in The New York Times.

title: Part 3: Answers to Readers Questions on Financial Aid
description: As families finalize their college choices before the May 1 deadline, finding the best fit for their students and their budgets, weve once again opened our virtual Guidance Office for some advice.

title: The Varying Impact of Austerity and Stimulus
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: The Early Word: Milestone
description: Todays Times

title: Hugo Chvez & The Supremes
description: MONTREAL  It happened every week. On Friday mornings, Venezuelas top prosecutor, the justice minister, the solicitor general, assorted Supreme Court justices, police chiefs and top officials would meet in the vice presidents office to review politically sensitive court cases and decide how they should be handled. In each instance, the vice president had the last word: dismissal, acquittal or conviction.

title: A Promising Brain Test for Football and Other Sports
description: A number of football players have been found to have chronic traumatic encephalopathy, but only after posthumous exams.

title: The Criminalization of Bad Mothers
description: On a rainy day just after Thanksgiving, Amanda Kimbrough played with her 2-year-old daughter in her raw-wood-paneled living room, petting her terriers and half-watching TV. Kimbrough, who is 32, lives a few miles outside Russellville, a town of fewer than 10,000 in rural northwestern Alabama, near the border of Franklin and Colbert Counties. Textiles were the economic engine of the area until the 1990s, when the industry went into decline and mills shut down. Now one of the regions leading employers is Pilgrims, a chicken supplier. The median household income is $31,213, and more than a third of children live below the poverty line.

title: The Water Fight That Inspired Chinatown
description: For many people, at least outside the far West, the mention of Californias water wars tends to conjure Roman Polanskis Chinatown. The 1974 film classic, starring Jack Nicholson, Faye Dunaway and John Huston, is loosely based on the success of the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power in siphoning off most of the Owens River, a stream fed by the snowmelt of the Eastern Sierra, and bringing it to the Los Angeles basin about a century ago.

title: Time to Revisit Food Deserts
description: In last weeks Fixes column I reported on a variety of initiatives that New York and other cities are engaged in to increase the availability of healthy food for sale, particularly fresh produce, in low-income neighborhoods that are believed to have insufficient access. The efforts include bringing in green carts and green markets to serve these areas, as well as offering financial, zoning and other incentives to attract new supermarkets and improve the quality and quantity of fresh food offerings in bodegas and corner stores. The work is explicitly designed to address what the government and many health experts have dubbed the problem of food deserts. It has catalyzed new retail food vendors in low-income areas, many of which have become successful businesses.

title: Is My Family Business Going to Be an Orphan?
description: As I promised I would in a recent post, I have held a family meeting to discuss the long-term fate of my business. I have no plans to retire anytime soon, but I have just turned 56, and I dont think it is too early  if it is ever too early  to plan for the future.

title: Playing the Holocaust Card
description: JERUSALEM  The seven days between Holocaust Memorial Day (last Thursday) and Independence Day (this Thursday) are packed with national symbolism. Seven days to remind the Jews of Israel of their trajectory from near annihilation to sovereign revival. Seven days for much sorrow and much pride.

title: Public Applies More Scrutiny to Exams That Are Supposed to Be Secret
Super PAC Ad Tries to Tie Romney to Oil Companies
description: Even as Mitt Romney continues to assail President Obama on the price of gas at the pump, Democrats are pushing back by trying to tie Mr. Romney to oil companies and the wealthy interests behind them.

title: 2012 N.F.L. Draft Big Board
description: Jonathan Bales, the founder ofTheDCTimes.com,has helped analyze draft prospects for The Fifth Down in his Scouting the Draft preview series.

title: Daily Report: Apples Profit Rises on iPhone Sales
description: Apple released its quarterly earnings on Tuesday, and as Nick Wingfield reports in Wednesdays New York Times, it was yet another blockbuster period. The company nearly doubled its profit from the quarter the year before, buoyed largely by sales of the iPhone, especially in China.

title: Republican National Committee Backs Romney
description: The Republican National Committee officially embraced Mitt Romney as the partys presumptive nominee on Wednesday morning after Mr. Romney claimed his new title in an energetic speech Tuesday night.

title: Opinion Report: Student Loans
description: From the editorial page

title: Murdoch on the Stand, Politicians in the Dock
description: LONDON  Much anticipation, not to say trepidation, as Rupert Murdoch took the stand on Wednesday at Britains judicial inquiry into media ethics.

title: The Big Wrong
description: Its Official: Keynes Was Right, says Henry Blodget. Recent election results in Europe seem to have raised consciousness in a way literally years of economic data couldnt: the austerity doctrine that has ruled European policy is a big fat failure.

title: Broadcasting a World of Whiteness
description: THOSE looking for hints of racial tone-deafness on the second episode of Girls, last Sunday on HBO, wouldnt have been let down. In an early scene Hannah, played by the shows creator, Lena Dunham, and her nonboyfriend Adam (Adam Driver) have sex; as theyre finishing, Adam promises to make the continent of Africa on Hannahs arm, a vexing intersection of eroticism and geography. Later Jessa (Jemima Kirke), nervously facing down an abortion, insists, I want to have children with many different men, of different races, as if they were trinkets to be collected, like key chains or snow globes.

title: Testing Concerns Keep Coming
Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: The Unbearable Slowness of Internal Devaluation
description: The euro areas economic strategy, such as it is, rests on two pillars: confidence through austerity, and internal devaluation. You know how the first is going; what about the second?

title: S.&P. Gives Negative Outlook for India
description: Standard & Poors lowered its outlook for India on Wednesday, citing the countrys struggle to rein in its relatively high debt and fiscal deficit amid a political impasse that is unlikely to ease before the next national elections in 2014, Bettina Wassener writes in The New York Times.

title: Leveraging, Deleveraging, and Fiscal Policy
description: Just a brief note.

title: National Loses Power as an Idea in India
description: This sentence has no meaning: Tea to be declared Indian national drink, Manu Joseph writes in The International Herald Tribune.

title: As a Top Banker Leaves Bank of America, Another Joins
description: One of the most senior bankers at Bank of America, Michael Rubinoff, has left the firm, months after a management shake-up in the investment bank.

title: Aide Tells of the Demise of His Friendship With Edwards
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  Lawyers for former Senator John Edwards have begun a slow, methodical dismantling of the leading witness against him in his federal corruption trial here.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Spotlight on Rupert Murdoch, and Surfing YouTubes Channels
description: Rupert Murdoch, this is your life. Testifying before a British inquiry on press ethics a day after his son James did, Mr. Murdoch is being painstakingly walked through his life as a politically minded media mogul, with questions about his relationships with prime ministers dating back to Margaret Thatcher. Ravi Somaiya is tweeting the proceedings, with choice quotes from Mr. Murdoch including:

title: Justices Seem Sympathetic to Central Part of Arizona Law
description: WASHINGTON  Justices across the ideological spectrum appeared inclined on Wednesday to uphold a controversial part of Arizonas aggressive 2010 immigration law, based on their questions at a Supreme Court argument.

title: N.F.L. Evolution: How Defenses Will Respond
description: The third in a three-part series. Part 1 examined how the evolution of the N.F.L. into a passing league is affecting the quarterback and wide receiver positions. Part 2 looked at the myth of the eminence of the left tackle and the coming resurgence at running back.

title: Bookshelf
description: All We Know (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $30), Lisa Cohens book about three magnificent failures, opens with a startling portrait of Esther Murphy (1897-1962), who was like a proto-Susan Sontag  she would pull great swaths of human history out of her memory, exhilarated by its ironies, its neglected crevices, and its meaning in the present  except that she never finished a book. Alex Katz: Maine / New York (Charta, $45) evokes the painters natural habitats, contrasting blacked-out cityscapes with languid nature tableaus (above, center). The book is tied to an exhibition that opens in July at the Colby College Museum of Art in Waterville, Me. (More of Katzs work, his prints, are on view at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston.) Following volumes on olives and Champagne, the Edible Series goes on a springtime spree with Vodka, Rum and Gin (Reaktion Books, $17 each). In the gin book, Lesley Jacobs Solmonson traces the spirits appearance in written English to an 18th-century tract that called it a fiery Lake that sets the Brain in Flame, burns up the Entrails, and scorches every Part within. Sounds about right.

title: A Candid Conversation With Alec Baldwin (Is There Any Other Kind?)
description: To hear Alec Baldwin tell it (or Tweet about it), you might think these were the final days at 30 Rock, and that he would soon be saying goodbye to Tina Fey and the band of misfit characters on that NBC comedy. While the network has not yet made an official announcement, 30 Rock is expected to be renewed for one last season, but in the meantime, Mr. Baldwin remains, shall we say, unsentimental about its long-term prospects and the broader state of affairs at NBC.

title: Netflix: Earnings Offer a Stream of Bad News
description: Sometimes when big juggernauts stumble, we cant help but murmur a bit of satisfaction. Ah, yes, all high and mighty werent you? But now look at you.

title: Morning Buzz, April 25: Bird Strike Forces Emergency Landing
description: Good morning. It will be partly cloudytoday, with highs in the mid 60s.

title: IPhone Attracts Customers, but Sprint Loses $863 Million
description: Sprint Nextel on Wednesday reported a loss of $863 million in its first quarter, twice the size of its loss in the same quarter last year, but the company was encouraged by the new customers the iPhone was bringing it.

title: Chasing, and Catching, a Purse Snatcher
description: Dear Diary:My New York apartment overlooked a crossing of two streets in the Village. You could hear and see a lot from there. One day I heard loud screams and ran to the corner window to look. Down the block a well-dressed middle-aged woman was doing the screaming. Apparently the womans purse had just been snatched, because a short person in white pants and shirt, hugging a large black handbag, was racing toward my building and the intersection. Meanwhile a stout professorial man, probably the victims companion, was pelting after the thief.

title: How to Try Terrorists
description: Next month, more than nine years after he was captured, then thrown into a secret prison, tortured, and finally moved to Guantanamo Bay, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed will finally go on trial under the military commission system.

title: Hungary Moves Closer to Getting New Aid
description: BRUSSELS  Hungary moved closer Wednesday to getting sorely needed financial support after the European Union accepted assurances that the government was not undermining the independence of the central bank, while referring to court two other laws that raised questions about the strength of Hungarys commitment to democracy.

title: Obamas Late-Night Slow Jam
description: Need any evidence of the effort by President Obama to woo young people, as reported by The Timess Peter Baker on Wednesday morning?

title: Image of the Day: April 25
Lone Ranger Lassoes Jack White
description: Walt Disney Pictures has hired the rock singer, guitarist and producer Jack White to write, produce and perform the score for the upcoming Lone Ranger, the company announced Monday at the CinemaCon theater owners convention in Las Vegas. The film, directed by Gore Verbinski (Pirates of the Caribbean, Rango), stars Johnny Depp as Tonto and Armie Hammer as John Reid and is set for release on May 31, 2013.

title: Arts Endowment Trims Support for PBS Shows
description: 2:48 p.m. | Updated The National Endowment for the Arts made sweeping cuts in its support of established PBS shows in the 2012 Arts in Media grants, which were announced Wednesday morning. Instead, the endowment awarded large grants to an array of gaming and Web-based projects.

title: Gingrich Tells Romney He Will Quit Race
description: 1:10 p.m. | Updated Newt Gingrich told Mitt Romney on Wednesday morning that he would suspend his presidential campaign next week and begin working to turn out conservative voters for Mr. Romney and Republican candidates in the fall election, Mr. Gingrichs spokesman said in an interview.

title: Strong Profits on Wall St., and Markets Move Higher
description: Stocks advanced on Wednesday, giving the Nasdaq 100 index its biggest gain this year, as Apples earnings almost doubled and the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said the Fed was prepared to do more to stimulate growth.

title: Wednesday Reading: A Child Changes His Familys Diet
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: What Were Reading
description: Bloomberg Businessweek: Rev up the Fryolator; its the semiannual French Fry Evaluation at McDonalds Corporation, where the companys three main spud suppliers  McCain foods, J.R. Simplot and Lamb Weston  competed before 15 tasters. Eyes were closed. There was sniffing. Munching, and, yes, spitting. The winner? Lamb Weston, from American Falls, Idaho.  Glenn Collins

title: Tribeca: Juliette Binoche on Acting From Insecurity
description: In Elles, Juliette Binoche stars as a work-obsessed, discontented journalist. Her bourgeois life, presented mostly in a pristine Paris apartment and cloaked in muted shades of whites and grays, contrasts sharply with those of the subjects of her latest article, two female students who also work as prostitutes. Ms. Binoches character, Anne, is at first dismissive and shocked by their choices, but over the course of the film, whichscreens at the Tribeca Film Festival on Wednesday afternoon and opens in select theaters on Friday, finds they have fears, and desires, in common.

title: Camerons Remarkable Achievement
description: From Britains Office of National Statistics (pdf):

title: Plaque Honoring Michael Landon Is Returned to Park
description: You dont have to share the Cartwright familys spirit of frontier justice to appreciate the return of a plaque honoring the Bonanza star Michael Landon to a park in Collingswood, N.J., where the actor grew up, months after it was removed under unclear circumstances.

title: On an Urban Heat Island, Zippy Red Oaks
description: Red oak seedlings in Central Park grow up to eight times faster than their cousins cultivated outside the city, probably because of the urban heat island effect, Columbia University researchers report.

title: Dow Corn, Resistant to a Weed Killer, Runs Into Opposition
description: To Jody Herr, it was a telltale sign that one of his tomato fields had been poisoned by 2,4-D, the powerful herbicide that was an ingredient in Agent Orange, the Vietnam War defoliant.

title: Childhood Obesity Leads to Unnecessary Surgeries
description: How does a 175-pound 10-year-old sound? Or a 200-pound 6-year-old? Or, far worse, a morbidly obese 6-year-old having his gallbladder removed because a high fat diet has caused it to malfunction and become a source of pain?

title: Leading Off: N.B.A. Dips Into Head Shot Outrage
description: When the N.B.A.s rather rusty wheels of justice finally kicked into gear and delivered a seven-game suspension to the Lakers Metta World Peace for his flying elbow K.O. of the Thunders James Harden, it was not a natural moment for the league. It could have simply borrowed a script from the N.H.L., handed down a pitifully light punishment, donned airport-strength ear protectors to drown out the outrage and moved on with its denial that concussions are any big deal. Instead, the N.B.A. took the time to explain all the complicating factors to its rusty wheel  hey, you try to make sense of the former Ron Artest with a piece of machinery  and came up with a suspension long enough to quell most outrage and yet wimpy enough to avoid truly upsetting the order of things.

title: For the Well Heeled, the $40,000 Rental
description: For travelers more accustomed to stratospheric thread counts than high fill-power sleeping bags, upscale options are still available. The travel service Lloyd and Townsend Rose rents high-end homes and, well, castles throughout Britain at rates starting at roughly 25,000 (about $39,500) a week.

title: Short of Cash? Rent a Lawn
description: ANY traveler to London this summer has no doubt scoured the listings of where to stay, where to eat and how to get around. But one resource that is probably overlooked is Londoners themselves, who during this time of high traffic will continue to rent out their resources to those on a budget strict enough that splurging for a night at a hotel  even if available  would be out of the question.

title: Want to Go to the Olympics? Act Now
description: THERE may be less than 100 days until the opening ceremony of the London Olympics, but procrastinators can still get to the Games, which run July 27 to Aug. 12, if theyre willing to spend a little more money, be flexible when it comes to flight times and crowds, and dont wait a moment longer.

title: Panetta Urges Brazil to Buy Fighter Jets From Boeing
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta pushed Brazil on Wednesday to buy $4 billion worth of Boeing-made Super Hornet fighter jets, saying the prospective sale reflected how important Brazil was to the United States.

title: Pixar Adds New Movie to Slate
description: LAS VEGAS  If the pressure is on Pixar to prove that its creative spark remains intact after the critical crash that was Cars 2, then the Disney-owned animation studio appears to be rising to the challenge. In a presentation to theater owners here on Monday, John Lasseter, Pixars chief creative officer (and the director of Cars 2), said the studio has added a movie about the Mexican holiday Da de los Muertos to its slate. The film, which does not yet have a title or a release date, will be directed by Lee Unkrich, who won an Oscar for Toy Story 3.

title: L.A. P.O.V. | The Quiet Allure of the Larder at Maple Drive
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Boombox Provides Fun in the Sun
description: The Etn Corporation, a company known for its emergency survival gadgets, is ready to party.

title: The Return of the Videophone (Again)
description: Ever since AT&T first demonstrated its Picturephone video telephone at the 1964 New York Worlds Fair, the public has been fascinated  at least in theory  with the idea of combining video and voice.

title: A Place for Old Chickens, Outside the Pot
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  Hindus regard the chicken as a vessel for evil spirits. The Chinese cook them to honor village deities. But here, chickens are a symbol of urban nirvana, their coops backyard shrines to a locavore movement that has city dwellers moving ever closer to their food. And the increasingly intimate relationships have led some bird owners to make plans for their chickens unproductive years. Hence a budding phenomenon: urban chicken retirement.

title: Business Day Live | April 25, 2012
description: Using tough tactics to collect medical debts; waiting and watching at the Federal Reserve; and Sam Grobart on Apple Inc., the profit machine.

title: Morning Walkabout: 4/25
description: Sleek Hotels Outside Manhattan Stylish hotels like Z NYC Hotel and Hotel Vetiver have migrated to Brooklyn and Queens. (The New York Times)

title: Tip of the Week: Getting Comfortable with New Microsoft Office Features
description: Upgrading to a new version of Microsoft Office  and then figuring out where all your favorite commands, menus and tools are in the new version  is something many users face every few years. To help ease Office workers into the latest edition, Microsoft provides several tutorials for the Mac OS X and Windows versions of the programs in the suite, which includes Word, Excel and PowerPoint.

title: Business Day Live: Apples Profit Soars on Sales in China
description: Using tough tactics to collect medical debts; waiting and watching at the Federal Reserve; and Sam Grobart on Apple Inc., the profit machine.

title: Car Models That Best Retain Their Value
description: Honda and Acura top the list of car brands that best retain their value over time, according to an annual ranking from the automotive site Edmunds.com.

title: British Police Say Madeleine McCann May Still Be Alive
description: LONDON  Investigators with Britains largest police force said on Wednesday that they believed that Madeleine McCann, the British toddler who vanished while on vacation with her parents in Portugal, could still be alive. Madelines story reverberated across the globe, and as the years have passed most have given up hope of ever finding her.

title: Champagne Headphones on a Beer Budget
description: After a steady diet of earbuds  good earbuds  I wasnt expecting to hear much improvement from a $100 pair of over-the-ear headphones. But I was in for sonic equivalent of a $14.95 all-you-can eat buffet  but one serving lobster, caviar and truffles. From the first note, the lush fidelity of the Grado SR80i headphones was a delightful shock.

title: Beach Boys Release New Single
description: The reunited Beach Boys released their first new single in decades on Wednesday, making it available for purchase on major digital services like iTunes and Amazon. The song, Thats Why God Made the Radio, sounds as if it could have been written in the 1960s. It is a slow romantic ode to pop radio, showing off the groups famous five-part harmonies and syrupy sentiments. The single is the first taste fans are getting of a new studio album by the same name, which is scheduled for release on June 5 by Capitol/EMI records. The album, which has 11 new songs, marks the first time in decades the two original leaders of the seminal band, Brian Wilson and Mike Love, have put aside their acrimony to work together. Three other early members  Al Jardine, David Marks and Bruce Johnston  are also onboard. The reconstituted band started a 50th Anniversary tour this week in Tucson and plans to play the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival this weekend. The Beach Boys also released an online video on Wednesday describing the making of the single.

title: Make Way for Ducks
description: They quack; they have feathers; they exude Robert McCloskey wholesomeness. They eat Wonder bread even though its evidently as bad for them as it is for young children. Whats not to like about ducklings?

title: The Private Equity P.R. Push Continues
description: A new promotional video from the Private Equity Growth Capital Council contains all the familiar cues that evoke the softer side of the buyout industry.

title: Disgraced Chinese Officials Son Tries to Defuse Sports Car Scandal
description: BEIJING  As the Chinese capital heaves with speculation over a British businessmans mysterious death, the downfall of a Machiavellian politician and the future of the ruling Communist Party, one incendiary question has been keeping the political classes awake at night: Did he or didnt he drive a red Ferrari?

title: Wheelies: The Underdog Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: On Our Radar: Urban Energy Patterns
description: Two students unveil an interactive Web-based map that allows people to visualize energy use in specific neighborhoods in more than 40 American cities. [urbmet.org]

title: A Web Retailer Buys the Perfect Domain Name. Then Comes a Letdown.
description: Founded in 1929 by Sol Braverman, the Newark Nut Company began selling bulk nuts and dried fruit in an open-air market on Newarks Mulberry Street. The business grew and then faded, and by 2002, it was being operated out of a mall in Newarks demoralized downtown by two of Mr. Bravermans sons. In 2003, as explained in last weeks Conversation column, a grandson, Jeffrey Braverman, joined the business and moved the companys focus to the Web.

title: Preparing to Look Good on Draft Night
description: The experts gathered around a conference table, sipped water and debated Dontari Poe, the oversize defensive tackle from Memphis and a likely first-round pick in the 2012 N.F.L. draft. In this room, early in draft week, his size was indeed an issue, but not his athleticism, smarts or speed.

title: Shopping Snapshots: April 26
description: The latest spring trend is baseball caps for women; a limited-edition line by Missoni and C.B. Made in Italy that benefits a good cause; and three new stores in Brooklyn for eclectic goods.

title: Was It a Mistake to Pay Lots of Money for a Clean Domain Name?
description: In a just-published case study, we recount a complicated decision facing the Newark Nut Company, a family-owned retailer based in Cranford, N.J.

title: London Politics for $500 | Who is Siobhan Benita?
description: On a cold, wet Thursday in a depressing part of southeast London a kindly man handed out flyers that read: Siobhan for mayor. Nearby, Siobhan Benita, going on four hours of sleep, stood a few feet away talking to a potential voter. Until someone from the team announced that they were going to miss their next appointment at a public library facing closure, and off they rushed to catch the train. Soon, it would absolutely pour with rain.

title: A Dancer Sees His Art Differently From a Russian Stage
description: In November, the last time we checked in with David Hallberg, he was emerging from the most celebrated  and scrutinized  performance of his life.

title: Mets Ring Machine Finishes the Spin Cycle
description: Attention! Ring alert from the Met! Now as Valhalla goes up in flames, the heads on white marble statues of the gods no longer go pop and explode. Instead, they crumble into pieces, and I think we can all agree that this is a more dignified way to suggest the twilight of the gods.

title: Should Your Dog Be Watching TV?
description: Plenty of things will grab a dogs attention: squirrels, tennis balls, funny smells, other dogs. But a TV channel?

title: P.S.A. Testing Continues in Older Men
description: Men over age 75 and their doctors are largely ignoring changing medical guidelines for prostate cancer screening, a study in the Journal of the American Medical Association has found.

title: Raising Glasses to Celebrate the Toast
description: Oscar Eustis was among the speakers Tuesday night at Brasserie Pushkin, the new Russian restaurant on West 57th Street, for a dinner celebrating the art of the toast. He didnt know the toast he would be giving; it would be handed to him some time before the spotlight hit. But he wasnt nervous. Hed had some practice at this sort of thing.

title: The Fall of New Orleans
description: New Orleans was the jewel of the Confederacy. In addition to being the Souths largest city, it boasted considerable industry that produced ironclads, munitions and uniforms, among other items. More important, it controlled access to the Mississippi River from the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Lloyd Live: Blankfein Takes to the Airwaves
description: Lloyd C. Blankfein can be an elusive public personality. The Goldman Sachs chief does not do many interviews, save for the odd P.S.A. and foray into his musical tastes.

title: Punch Brothers Talk About Music, the Lower East Side and Greg Maddux
description: It has always been hard to pigeonhole Punch Brothers. They are an all-star bluegrass band, five virtuosos led by Chris Thile, the mercurial mandolin player, but their songs smash the three-chord harmonies and blazing march rhythm of bluegrass.

title: Scouting Report
description: POP-UPS

title: A Broadway Baby With Experience
description: TELEVISION viewers may know Nicole Ari Parker as the lawyer Teri on the Showtime series Soul Food, which ran for five seasons in the early 2000s, or perhaps from the short-lived Deep End, which ABC broadcast briefly in 2010. But on Broadway Ms. Parker is a neophyte. And shes taken on quite a challenge, playing one of the most famous female characters in the theater  one that powerhouse actresses from Jessica Tandy to Cate Blanchett have performed  Tennessee Williamss fragile, fading Southern belle Blanche DuBois.

title: Occupy Student Debt Plans to Protest $1 Trillion Mark
description: Supporters of the Occupy Student Debt movement are planning several events on Wednesday to mark the moment when total student debt reaches $1 trillion, Inside Higher Ed reported.

title: What Do Springtime Polls Tell Us About the General Election?
description: Since Rick Santorum suspended his presidential campaign, essentially ending the Republican primary contest, the starting positions for the general election have taken shape. About 10 national polls have been released: President Obama leads Mitt Romney 47.7 percent to 43.7 percent, according to the RealClearPolitics average of recent surveys.

title: Whither the Ultrabook?
description: At Januarys Consumer Electronics Show, one of the largest tech conventions, computer makers were relentlessly showcasing their ultrabooks  thin and lightweight laptops similar to Apples MacBook Air. Intel had at least a dozen on display in its booth. Three months later, youd be lucky to even see an ultrabook in the wild.

title: Kids Draw the News | The Epic Brawl
description: Update, April 30 | This assignment is now closed. See the slideshow of the kids brawl art and check out the next assignment: the Pharaoh Bloomberg Incident.

title: V.C.U. Turns to Steven Holl Architects for New Arts Center
description: Virginia Commonwealth University has long been one of the leading public university graduate arts and design programs in the country. Now it also wants to be a cultural destination for audiences and performers. The university on Wednesday unveiled the design for a new $32 million Institute for Contemporary Art, designed by Steven Holl and Chris McVoy of Steven Holl Architects. Calling the 38,000-square-foot building part exhibition and performance space, part lab and incubator, the university said the institute will feature a series of flexible programming spaces for visual art, theater, music, dance and film.There will be an auditorium with more than 240 seats, a sculpture garden, classrooms and a cafe.

title: Excerpt: 'The Columnist'
description: John Lithgow and Margaret Colin in David Auburns new play, now on Broadway at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater.

title: Six Things I Learned From Reading Every Last Word of Vice
The Value of College
description: Gail Collins: David, I feel that I missed so much while I was on vacation in Turkey. Newt Gingrich was attacked by a penguin! John Edwards went on trial and according to the polls, we have finally found somebody with a lower approval rating than Congress.

title: Fed Cuts U.S. Growth Forecast for 2013 and 2014
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, on Wednesday dismissed proposals to escalate the Feds economic stimulus campaign as reckless, arguing that the costs would be high and the benefits uncertain.

title: Romneys Victory Speech
description: In his victory speech in New Hampshire last night, Mitt Romney mentioned the strains on working people who were hit hardest by the recession and have not seen anything like the recovery enjoyed by wealthy people  like Mitt Romney.

title: The Music Behind the Wine
description: It turns out that its not only chefs who are using music for inspiration: Whether its the polka beat of Mexican folk or the indie rock of Clap Your Hands Say Yeah, tunes are also employed by winemakers in creating their latest vintages. A few of them wrote about the connection in response to my e-mailed questions.

title: TimesCast | April 25, 2012
description: The Supreme Court takes on Arizonas immigration law | A Myanmar archipelago tempts tourists | Rupert Murdoch testifies.

title: On Outer Reaches of the Harlem Line, a Conductor Who Offers Full Service
description: You can travel the 82 miles from Grand Central Terminal to the remote, pastoral station in Wassaic, N.Y., with no more human engagement than the time it takes a conductor to punch your ticket and walk on.

title: Spring Staples | The Punchy Clutch
description: Seasons change and so must accessories.

title: Blue Note Jazz Festival Returns for a Second Year
description: The Blue Note Jazz Festival, which had its inaugural run last June, will return this year, June 10 through 30. Presented by the Blue Note Entertainment Group, which operates the Blue Note jazz club, the Highline Ballroom and B.B. King Blues Club, the festival chiefly involves those three rooms, with a few exceptions.

title: Champions League Semifinals: Bayern Munich (1) at Real Madrid (2). Aggregate, 3-3. Bayern Munich Wins Shootout, 3-1
The Baby Hawks Sure Are Looking Like Dinosaurs These Days
description: Boo and Scout, now 15 and 16 days old, paused for a between-meal snack around 11 a.m. Wednesday.

title: The Royals Are Reeling
description: Usually, every spring brings hope for fans that this will be the season that their struggling baseball team turns things around. Its a fresh slate, a new start, a nice wellspring of enthusiasm to revel in.

title: The Caucus Click: Up, Away and at Work
Israels Big Day, Under Sun and Cloud
description: JERUSALEM  The paradox that is Israel  wealthy, dynamic and safe, yet mistrusted, condemned and nervous  was on full display on Wednesday as the country mourned its fallen soldiers and began celebrating its 64th Independence Day.

title: Cuomo Applauds Intensified Campaign to Ticket Distracted Drivers
description: For a driver in New York State, its a good week to put away the cellphone. Thats the objective behind Operation Hang Up, a statewide enforcement campaign targeting distracted drivers that began Monday and is scheduled to continue through April 29.

title: An Advance Toward the Front Lines for Female Marines
description: In an article in The New York Times on Wednesday, James Dao wrote about the policy changes that will move female Marines closer to combat roles. He interviewed Gen. James F. Amos, the Marine Corps commandant, on the changes to policy, a subject first covered by The Marine Corps Times. Here are some of the new policies and initiatives:

title: Supreme Court Argument Transcript: Arizona v. United States
description: On April 25, 2012, the Supreme Court heard more than an hours worth of arguments over several provisions of Arizonas aggressive 2010 immigration law.

title: What Were You Thinking? For Couples, New Source of Online Friction
description: The more than 43,000 Twitter followers of Rosanne Cash, the singer and daughter of Johnny Cash, have come to expect her tart commentary on married life with her husband, John Leventhal, a Grammy-winning musician.

title: Study Points to Roles for Industry and Organics in Agriculture
description: A paper in this weeks issue of Nature reinforces the argument that a hybrid path in agriculture  incorporating both industrial-style production and organic practices where they make sense  gives the best chance of feeding some 9 billion people by midcentury with the fewest regrets.

title: Neuberger Museum Gets a New Director
description: Paola Morsiani, the curator of contemporary art at the Cleveland Museum of Art, has been appointed the director of the Neuberger Museum of Art of the State University of New York at Purchase, Thomas J. Schwartz, the president of the college, announced Wednesday. Ms. Morsiani, 50, will become the seventh director of the nations 10th largest university art museum, which has a collection of over 8,000 works in all media.

title: TimesCast | Myanmars Hidden Islands
description: Myanmars tropical islands could become a prime tourist destination, if the government allows.

title: A Curious Tooth Collection
description: Ken Angielczyk, an assistant curator at the Field Museum of Natural History, is searching for fossils of ancient mammal relatives in northeastern Brazil.

title: Consumer Agency Looking Into Mandatory Arbitration
description: You may not know it, but the fine print in the rules governing use of your credit card and your checking account probably limits your right to sue in court if you have a dispute with the company providing the service. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau said Tuesday that it is seeking information about that language in agreements for financial products and services.

title: Were Those Boos Really for Reyes?
description: Jose Reyess first game in Citi Field as a member of the Marlins on Tuesday night elicited a lot of emotions. Some fans serenaded him with Jose! Jose! Jose! Jose! chants, while others booed him over the course of the game.

title: New Diplomas Will Not Lower Standards, Regents Chancellor Says
Hedge Fund Managers See Tough Year for Industry
description: Hedge fund managers are predicting a tough year for the sector in 2012.

title: At Fort Defiance, Saluting a Drinks Pioneer
description: Todays history-minded mixologists follow various guiding lights from the past. Some bow at the altar of the 19th-century bartender Jerry Thomas, the so-called father of American mixology. Others look to Harry Johnson, a leading barman ofthe late 1800s.

title: In London, Films About Palestinians
description: Casting a wide net over the topic of Palestine, the 2012 London Palestine Film Festival kicked off last week, presenting contemporary comedic and dramatic films, a 1974 Susan Sontag documentary, and video installations.

title: Brother of Fallen Chinese Politician Resigns Lucrative Business Role
description: BEIJING  The elder brother of Bo Xilai, the Politburo member now at the center of a huge political scandal involving murder and a potential cover-up, resigned Wednesday as executive director and vice chairman at Everbright International, a division of a giant state-owned Chinese conglomerate.

title: Royal Bank of Scotland Said to Shed M.&A. Business
description: LONDON  The Royal Bank of Scotland will spin off its mergers and acquisitions business by early next year, as the nationalized British bank continues to cut back on its investment banking unit, according to people with direct knowledge of the matter.

title: A New Leader, and Maybe Direction, for Smash
description: In a signal that NBC and the shows producers may believe the future of Smash lies more in its soap opera elements than its inside look at the creation of a Broadway musical, the new guiding creative hand on the series is going to be Joshua Safran, an executive producer of the glossy CW soap Gossip Girl. NBC confirmed Wednesday that Mr. Safran is the choice to replace Theresa Rebeck as the hands-on executive producer  also known as show runner  of the second season of Smash.

title: Invoking Ricky Ricardo, NuvoTv Aims at the Bicultural Latino
description: A popular figure from the early days of television was conjured up Tuesday night for an upfront presentation to help a cable channel sell commercial time.

title: Kids Draw the News | Send Pictures
High Steaks | Beef Club in Paris
description: The name Beef Club may conjure images of bodybuilders or of a gay bar (or even a bar for bodybuilders), but in fact it should be taken at face value. Beef Club is an Anglo-style steakhouse, newly opened in Paris by Rome de Goriainoff, Pierre-Charles Cros and Olivier Bon, the trio behind the Experimental Cocktail Club and Nicolas Chevalier. (An Experimental Cocktail Club is set to open in New York, and they hope to expand to cities like Shanghai and Tokyo.)

title: How About a Little Smartness Training?
description: In last weekends special issue devoted to mental health, Dan Hurley wrote about a study that has rocked the world of intelligence research. Apparently, a certain kind of working-memory training  done 15 to 25 minutes a day, five days a week  can increase whats known as our fluid intelligence (reasoning, problem-solving, learning) in as few as four weeks. The regimen isnt easy (though neither is bodily exercise for those new to it), but its tantalizing to think that this sort of mental workout can actually make us smarter. Try it out yourself here, with a version of the trainingthat was used in the study.(You dont need to download anything, but you may be prompted to restart your browser in 32-bit mode.)

title: Amylin and Icahn Make Nice, Sending Shares Up
description: The activist investor Carl C. Icahn has withdrawn his lawsuit against Amylin Pharmaceuticals, helping propel the diabetes drug makers shares up more than 3.5 percent.

title: Photo Replay: April 25
description: Today in sports the 50-meter freestyle Olympic qualifier took place in Rio de Janeiro and Udinese fans showed their dedication in an Italian Serie A soccer match with Inter Milan.

title: Gates Joins 2 From Bush Administration in Consulting Firm
description: Together again. Former Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates, after a detour through the Obama administration, announced Wednesday that he was joining former Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and Stephen J. Hadley, a former national security adviser, in their strategic consulting firm. The move reunites the Bush-era foreign policy team.

title: An Eric Ripert Dinner Fetches $200,000
description: Nicholas D. Lowry, the president of Swann Auction Galleries, often starts the bidding with a bottle of Herradura Tequila that might cost $50. He uses it to get the crowd going, and the item fetches far more than its worth.

title: Petition Drive Challenges Standardized Testing
Double-Dip Recession in Britain
description: LONDON  Britain has fallen into its first double-dip recession since the 1970s, according to official figures released Wednesday, a development that raised more questions about whether government belt-tightening in Europe has gone too far.

title: These Days Are Numbered: Eight Summer Math Ideas
description: The school year is starting to wind down in many places in the country, and it brings worries about so-called summer slide  the documented decline in student skills during the long summer break.

title: Northwestern Women Fall to Florida
description: EVANSTON, Ill.  After a furious finish, the Northwestern womens lacrosse team fell short once again. The result was a loud Florida celebration on the Wildcats home field, a mob of blue jerseys under airborne lacrosse sticks in front of a silent crowd of more than 1,500.

title: At House Hearing, Schapiro Says Cost Analyses Are Slowing S.E.C.s Work
description: WASHINGTON  Republicans on a House Financial Services subcommittee questioned on Wednesday whether the Securities and Exchange Commission had strengthened the cost-benefit analyses it conducts on newly proposed regulations.

title: The Rangers Biggest Challenge? Face-Offs
description: 4:52 p.m. | Updated The Rangers took extra face-off practice Wednesday ahead of Thursdays Game 7 versus Ottawa, and for good reason  they are getting killed on draws.

title: For 2nd Week, Lionel Richie Tops the Charts
description: On the pop charts this week, Lionel Richie holds at No. 1, Maroon 5 has a fast-selling download, and two One Directions compete.

title: Companies Raise Concerns Over Google Drives Privacy Protections
description: 5:50 p.m. | Updated Added more explanation from Google about the terms of service agreement.

title: Banks Form Alliances to Buy A.I.G. Assets
description: Big banks, gearing up for a bidding war on assets tied to the collapse of the American International Group, have created unlikely alliances to mount offers for what was once viewed as the dregs of Wall Street.

title: The Tenderness of Simmered Chicken
description: As much as I like a good roast chicken, I have always had a soft spot for simmered and boiled chicken, from iconic meaty Mexican soups to down-home American chicken and dumplings, to the French poule-au-pot and beyond. What can I say? Its about tenderness, succulence and broth.

title: Give Lehman High a Chance, a Student Says
Boeing Lifts Forecast After a Strong Quarter
description: An increase in airplane deliveries helped the Boeing Company report stronger-than-expected earnings on Wednesday and signaled that the company was getting past the problems that slowed production of its new 787 Dreamliner and 747-8 jets.

title: Suiting Up for the N.F.L. Draft
description: Inside the Joseph Abboud showroom in Manhattan, where Rachel Johnson, a stylist, selected clothes for Dontari Poe, an oversize defensive tackle, to wear to the draft.

title: Some Rest for the Weary
description: As I lounged on the couch, all I could think was: If I dont do my hamstring exercises, they will be so sore when I start back up. And my quads  theyre going to kill me after I do a shooting session.

title: A Hearing and Rallies Over a Law in Arizona
description: WASHINGTON  Hundreds of chanting demonstrators filled the sidewalk in front of the Supreme Court on Wednesday, denouncing an Arizona immigration law that was under debate inside, saying it would spread fear among Latinos in the state.

title: A Low-Key Anchor With High Expectations
description: ITS an old question: what makes a real New Yorker? Pronouncing Houston Street correctly? Knowing who Dr. Zizmor is? Turning off Taxi TV as soon as the meter starts?

title: Did Blankfein Snub Paulson?
description: On Wednesday morning on CNBC, Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chief of Goldman Sachs, made a rare on-camera appearance to defend the embattled firm from its detractors.

title: Dogfights on Your iPhone
description: The invasion of apps on toys continues with this weeks release of Foam Fighters Pacific from WowWee ($9.99), a set of three-inch styrofoam gliders that you can suction cup under your iPhones outside camera. Align the wings with an on-screen template and the apps augmented reality features superimpose a WWII dogfight over your living room.

title: Celebrity Spats Thrive on Twitter
description: ITS not every mother who airs family grievances online. But when Courtney Love heard rumors that Dave Grohl, the Foo Fighters frontman, had made advances on her 19-year-old daughter, Frances Bean Cobain, which Ms. Cobain and Mr. Grohl denied, she blasted him on Twitter.

title: Times Reporters Discuss the N.F.L. Draft
description: Judy Battista, Mike Tanier and Connor Ennis of The Times join readers in a discussion about this year's college draft.

title: Bernanke Responds
description: Ben Bernanke responds to my magazine piece; as I see it, in effect he declared that he has been assimilated by the Fed Borg:

title: Talking About the N.F.L. Draft With Times Reporters
description: Judy Battista and Mike Tanier, who write about football for The New York Times, joined The Timess pro football editor, Connor Ennis, who served as host, and a handful of readers in a Google Plus video hangout to talk about this weeks N.F.L. draft.

title: TimesCast | Rupert Murdoch Testifies
description: April 25, 2012  In London, Rupert Murdoch played down his political influence on the British government during judicial hearings tied to the phone hacking scandal.

title: Women See Worrisome Shift in Turkey
description: ISTANBUL  Gokce, a soft-spoken 37-year-old mother of two, has lived on the run for 15 years, ever since her abusive husband tracked her down, broke down her door and shot her in the leg six times after she refused to return to him.

title: Homes for $625,000
description: Properties in Idaho, Boston and Key West.

title: What You Get for ... $625,000
description: BOISE, IDAHO

title: Surpassing the Great American Consumer
description: Once upon a time, the world vied primarily for the attention (and dollars) of American consumers. Just a decade ago, they were responsible for nearly a quarter of the worlds economy.

title: Fte Accompli | Chanels Tribeca Film Festival Dinner
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Leaving the Nest to Fly Solo
description: TWO years after the Council of Fashion Designers of America established an incubator program in the garment district, the first group of young designers to cohabit in its space has left the nest, so to speak. Some of them are bigger than when they started. Some are not. But most say they are a little wiser. Ten new designers will move in next month.

title: Watson to Buy Actavis for $5.9 Billion
description: LONDON  Watson Pharmaceuticals agreed on Wednesday to buy the Swiss drug maker Actavis Group for as much as 4.5 billion euros ($5.9 billion), as the American company looks to expand its presence in overseas markets.

title: Obama Sings for College Affordability
description: On Wednesday night, President Obama appeared on Late Night With Jimmy Fallon and participated in one of the shows funnier features: slow-jamming the news. The president sang about the rising interest rates on Stafford loans, using a similar refrain hed used earlier in the day at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill.

title: South Sudan to Get Aid From China; No Oil Deal
description: BEIJING  China has welcomed the president of South Sudan and agreed to provide bank loans and humanitarian aid, but it has stopped short of moving forward on an oil pipeline, a sign of the delicate position Beijing finds itself in as the biggest energy investor in both the new nation of South Sudan and its bitter foe, Sudan.

title: White House Returns Fire Over Claim About Big Tax Increases
description: The Obama administration on Wednesday fired back at an adviser to Mitt Romney who had asserted that the presidents economic plans would mean a huge tax increase for all Americans.

title: House Hunting in ... Prague
description: THREE-BEDROOM PENTHOUSE IN OLD TOWN PRAGUE

title: A Designer Penthouse in Pragues Old Town
description: A three-bedroom penthouse designed by the noted Czech architect Eva Jiricna is listed at $1.6 million.

title: Partners at Andreessen Horowitz Make Charity Pledge
description: The partners of venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz are not quite billionaires. But they are following the lead of Warren E. Buffett.

title: Cuomo Says Talk of White House Bid Is Premature
description: ALBANY  Even Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo acknowledged that there was something familiar about the situation.

title: Stone Links: The Sources of Ethical Authority
description: At the Religion and Ethics section of The Australian Broadcasting Corporations website, two philosophers use the quote, If there is no God, everything is permitted, commonly attributed to Dostoevsky, as a touchstone for considering whether there is an ultimate source of ethical authority.

title: Lawmakers Support Shifting Financial Oversight
description: Financial firms will face new regulatory scrutiny under legislation unveiled on Wednesday.

title: Scene City: Time Magazine Toasts Its Top 100 Influencers
description: Time magazine honored 100 people that it named the most influential, among them Hillary Rodham Clinton, Rihanna, Stephen Colbert and others.

title: American Austerity
description: With all the focus on Europes sudden discovery that austerity doesnt work, we shouldnt lose sight of just how much de facto austerity weve done on this side of the Atlantic. Heres a comparison of changes in government employment (federal, state, and local) during the first four years of three presidents who came to office amid a troubled economy:

title: A Lethal Beacon for Migrating Birds
description: On the morning of Sept. 11, 1948, a good number of dead, dying and exhausted birds were found at the base of the WBAL radio tower in Baltimore, in what was then viewed as a new and unusual phenomenon. Ever since communication towers began popping up in the United States in the 1940s and 50s, bird bodies have littered the fields below them, especially during migration season.

title: $18 Million Gift for Theater at Yale
description: The Yale School of Drama and Yale Repertory Theater announced on Wednesday that they had received an $18 million gift  the largest in their history  to finance the creation of new plays and musicals through commissions to writers, developmental workshops and productions at both Yale Rep and other theaters that stage the work.

title: Influential, and All in One Room
description: HALFWAY through the Time 100 party on Tuesday night, Stephen Colbert summed up the crowd.

title: Paul Rudd and Emma Stone to Star in Live Reading of The Apartment
description: Should Paul Rudd ever need a place to stay in New York, one imagines there would be numerous volunteers to offer him lodging. In the meantime, Mr. Rudd will be crashing the role originally played by Jack Lemmon in a reading of the script for the 1960 Billy Wilder comedy The Apartment, alongside Emma Stone, wholl be substituting for that films original co-star, Shirley MacLaine.

title: Shylocks Master Class on Rage
description: Just wait till they get angry.

title: 3 to Pay $32 Million to Settle S.E.C. Charges of Insider Trading
description: A deal lawyer, a trader and their middleman who carried out an insider trading scheme that lasted decades and included the use of code names and disposable cellphones settled charges Wednesday with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $32 million.

title: Humor Found Online, Posted Onstage
description: Usually its harder to be funny in writing than in speech. After all, with naked text you dont have the helpful tools of timing, vocal intonation, facial expression, gestures or props.

title: Google Makes Push Into E-Commerce With New Online Store
description: In a move it tried  and abandoned  once before, Google began selling a smartphone directly to consumers through a new online store on Tuesday.

title: Discord on the Hill Extends to Domestic Violence Law
description: The latest ugly (and seemingly needless) partisan fight on Capitol Hill concerns a measure designed to prevent domestic violence against women.

title: Its an Absurd World, So Send in the Clowns
description: IN a new video chronicling a day in their lives, the artists Anthony Aziz and Sammy Cucher  life partners and collaborators since 1992  emerge from the subway in Long Island City, Queens. They walk to their studio, where they review photographs tacked to a wall and video footage they shot in 2009 while traveling through Israel, Lebanon and the Balkans. The images are complemented by a relentless soundtrack of NPR reports on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and the controversy over a proposed Islamic community center in Lower Manhattan, blended with snatches of Middle Eastern folk music and military drumbeats.

title: Aziz + Cucher: Some People
description: A look at the new exhibition at the Indianapolis Museum of Art.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Fast-Forward TV and 3-D Printer Gallery
description: Here are some of the most interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Wednesday. There are more here.

title: Life, Interrupted | Visiting Hours
description: Suleika Jaouad is in the hospital for a bone marrow transplant and has been isolated in her room for 24 days.

title: Outfitting the Veep
description: WHEN Ernesto Martinez, the lead costume designer for the new HBO series Veep, started to think about how to dress the shows star, Julia Louis-Dreyfus, for her role as the countrys first female vice president, he quickly decided that inspiration would have to come from somewhere other than the current office holders in the nations capital.

title: TimesCast | Immigration at Highest Court
description: April 25, 2012  The Supreme Court hears arguments regarding Arizonas controversial immigration law.

title: Face Time | Olivia Wilde
description: For me, the highlight of the Tribeca Film Festival was making up the lovely Olivia Wilde for the premiere of the documentary she produced, Baseball in the Time of Cholera. It follows the effects of a cholera outbreak on a young Haitian athlete named Joseph and the scandal surrounding the United Nationss involvement in the affair. It was a special evening for her because its a film she is very proud of. You may have caught a glimpse of her looking gorgeous in Revlons latest ads. Between blush and mascara, Wilde and I chatted about what its like to be a global brand ambassador for Revlon and much more.

title: Viacom Signs a New Lease to Expand in Times Sq.
description: Viacom Inc., the entertainment conglomerate that owns MTV, Comedy Central, Nickelodeon and Paramount Pictures, is expanding its presence in Times Square with one of the largest leases signed in New York City.

title: For Dynamo, a Stunning Comeback
description: Dynamo Moscow beat Avangard Omsk, 1-0, Wednesday in Game 7 of the K.H.L.s Gagarin Cup final, completing a comeback from a 3-1 series deficit and winning the clubs ninth Russian or Soviet domestic championship.

title: Yankees Lose Pineda for Season, and Hughes Adds to Worries
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  It was a dreary day for the Yankees pitching rotation Wednesday, as news about Michael Pinedas season-ending injury was followed by a bad outing from one of the pitchers the Yankees hope can make up for Pinedas loss.

title: An All-Star Cast Makes One Big Happy Family
description: Understatement, restraint and an implicit trust that the shows virtues speak for themselves: those qualities describe the lavish concert performance of The Sound of Music, on Tuesday evening at Carnegie Hall. As the old slogan puts it, there was no muss, no fuss, no bother.

title: The Rise of Designer Childrens Lines
description: In the last year or two, Lanvin, Gucci, Stella McCartney and Marni have entered the childrens clothing market.

title: Glass Houses in the Countryside
description: In England, a modernist villa and a guest pavilion on a 23-acre estate.

title: In the British Countryside, a Well-Packaged Life
description: HORSMONDEN, England

title: Debt Unforgiveness
description: At the University of North Carolina yesterday, President Obama blasted a congresswoman who said she has very little tolerance for students who graduate with debt. He did not name her, but many people in North Carolina knew (or could have guessed) that he was talking about Virginia Foxx, the snarling Republican from the northwest corner of the state, whose lack of tolerance in many areas is not a secret.

title: On the Road With the Proper Gear
description: Last month, I was sitting in a club lounge in Newark Liberty International Airport when I noticed a man in the seat across from me with this technological array in front of him:

title: Sundance  Festival Moves to London
description: After more than three decades of showcasing independent film in Park City, Utah, the Sundance Film Festival will for the first time take place in London under the moniker Sundance London.

title: That Dress Is So Preschool
description: ONE morning in the fall of 1956, in a salon at 12 East 57th Street, the eminent American couturier Charles James presented his first childrens-wear line to a group of editors that included Diana Vreeland. Sherry and cookies were served, and with a sense of camp that preceded Marc Jacobs by 50 years, Mr. James had ladies in nurses uniforms bring out the tiny garments.

title: New Design From the Milan Furniture Fair
description: Highlights from the fair, where pieces made of industrial waste contrasted with deep-cushioned sofas that provide infantile comfort.

title: These Seven Sicknesses Returns to the Flea Theater
description: The Flea Theater will remount its production of These Seven Sicknesses, a five-hour, streamlined adaptation of seven Sophocles plays, from June 6 through July 1 at its TriBeCa space, the company announced on Wednesday.

title: In Court, Easterling Suicide Is the Focus
description: The suicide last week of Ray Easterling, a player with the Atlanta Falcons in the 1970s who was being treated for dementia, took center stage in court on Wednesday.

title: Even on a Retro Highway, Its Best to Watch the Road Ahead
description: The singer Maria Minerva  tall, imposing, underselling herself in a Boy London T-shirt and black leggings  stood behind, next to, around and in front of two laptops and a small keyboard. She seemed to have no fixed relationship to her gear, and her act didnt involve much articulated, worked-out body language; when she wasnt playing melodies on the keyboard, she sang and danced to hazy, anachronistic electro beats from her laptop, projecting absent-mindedness as if she were alone in her bedroom.

title: 10 Questions for Timothy F. Geithner
description: The attacks on Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner that marked the early part of the Obama administration have died down somewhat as the economy has recovered. But struggles in Europe have created new economic challenges as Mr. Geithner serves out the remaining months of Mr. Obamas first term, as the president implored him to. After touring a manufacturing plant in Clackamas, Ore., Mr. Geithner sat down Wednesday with John Harwood of The Times and CNBC to discuss the still fragile recovery and the quickening economic debate in the presidential campaign.

title: Dewey & LeBoeuf Crisis Mirrors Legal Industrys Woes
description: The crisis confronting the law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf has stunned the legal profession. About 70 of Deweys 300 partners have left since January after their salaries were slashed because of the firms weak financial performance.

title: For Marlboro Musicians, at Home or on Tour, Performance Is in the Details
description: Some composers write cheery music while their personal lives are in disarray. Others channel their suffering into angst-ridden compositions, as Bartok did in his String Quartet No. 6. Introducing the piece before a performance by Musicians From Marlboro on Tuesday evening the cellist Marcy Rosen detailed the genesis of the work, written in 1939, shortly before Bartok left his native Hungary and emigrated to America.

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Pakistan, the Philippines, Portugal and Washington.

title: Banged-Up Rangers Hope to Feel Better After Game 7
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  N.H.L. players often say the goal during the early rounds of the Stanley Cup playoffs is to survive and advance. Facing a Game 7 on Thursday night against the Ottawa Senators, the Rangers are looking to do the same  although not in that order.

title: Tranquillity Replaces Trash Talk and Heels
description: In the first episode of Leave It to Niecy, a reality show about the actress and comedian Niecy Nash, Ms. Nash is determined to prove to her children that she can orchestrate family fun. Dominic, the oldest child and only boy, tries to tell her that their family isnt like others that have lived with cameras.

title: Entwine
description: WITH its shabby-chic dcor and unassuming entrance, Entwine looks like any other neighborhood wine bar in the West Village (which it is). But on Wednesday nights, it has becomes an unlikely place to spot celebrities and listen to musicians like Courtney Love and Joseph Arthur try out new material.

title: Please, Dont Feed the Artist
description: ON most days, you can hear Dawn Kaspers installation at the Whitney Biennial before you see it. Bessie Smith or the Beatles or an episode of The Young Ones, a British sitcom from the 80s, might be playing scratchily on one of her many devices, spilling out into an adjacent gallery and accompanied by a throaty guffaw from the artist, whom you might then come upon sitting cross-legged on a mattress, wearing a Hawaiian shirt, eating a sandwich and entertaining a few strangers.

title: The Nobility, Behaving Not So Nobly
description: At first it seemed odd that the Cutting Edge Concerts New Music Festival would want to close its 2012 iteration with an evening of one-act operas that proudly luxuriate in the spirit of the Renaissance. But there are worse periods to explore when looking for innovative composition. Even a cursory listen to one of Gesualdos madrigals, say, can convince anyone that few works composed since then have been so thorny and searching.

title: Another Spanish Soccer Titan Is Toppled by Penalty Kicks
description: MADRID  Penalty kicks are supposed to be near certainties for professional soccer players, and to outsiders, the question is how could they not be? A motionless ball, only 12 yards from the goal with no one but the hapless goalkeeper to beat, and he must stay on his line until the ball is kicked. For players like Lionel Messi and Cristiano Ronaldo, wizards who score from impossible angles, success from the spot seems as if it should be virtually guaranteed.

title: Madeleine Albright: By the Book
description: What book is on your night stand now?

title: Serious About a New Language? Begin With Lesson 1
description: Ive tried learning Italian through books, CDs, DVDs, tapes, and apps with phrase books and translation technology. Nothing stuck.

title: The Antisocial Effects of Social Media
description: To the Editor:

title: The Inventor Who Put Frozen Peas on Our Tables
description: Mark Kurlanskys work includes Salt, a book about salt, and Cod: a Biography of the Fish that Changed the World. He specializes in the mix of showmanship and small-bore scrutiny that gives minor-sounding material the patina of great relevance. But his new book, Birdseye, asks what sounds, even for Mr. Kurlansky, like a feebly rhetorical question: Ever wonder how those frozen peas and carrots and dinner entrees in your freezer came to be there? The very probable answer: no, you have not.

title: Anti-Semitism in Hungary
description: To the Editor:

title: This Camera Doesnt Take Pictures. It Describes Them.
description: The Descriptive Camera doesnt work like your normal point-and-shoot camera. Instead, this contraption prints out a description of the photo you take, rather than an image itself.

title: Newly Released Books
description: New tellings of old standbys mark the month, as two debut novelists take on bridal shenanigans while another reimagines teenage werewolves. Then theres the story of an early feminist who fights the power in an antiquated setting.

title: Ousted Chinese Leader Is Said to Have Spied on Other Top Officials
description: BEIJING  When Hu Jintao, Chinas top leader, picked up the telephone last August to talk to a senior anticorruption official visiting Chongqing, special devices detected that he was being wiretapped  by local officials in that southwestern metropolis.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Music Film Is Delayed by Fees for Songs
description: In the 1960s many of the hits coming out of Los Angeles under the names of the Beach Boys, Sonny & Cher, the Mamas and the Papas, the Monkees and other top pop acts were actually recorded by an elite but largely anonymous corps of studio musicians nicknamed the Wrecking Crew. To gain them some belated public recognition Denny Tedesco, a son of one of the most prolific of those session players, spent more than 15 years making a documentary about the ensemble.

title: Jazz at Lincoln Center Names a New Executive Director
description: The trustees of Jazz at Lincoln Center have reached into the ranks of business leaders in the digital media sector for a new executive director, hiring Greg Scholl, a former NBC Universal executive with a background in digital music distribution, to manage the nonprofit arts institution.

title: Wal-Mart in Mexico
description: To the Editor:

title: 10 Questions for Timothy F. Geithner
description: Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner sat down for an interview with John Harwood of the New York Times and CNBC.
