description: To the Editor:

title: What Do Musics Corporate Bosses Make? All Eyes on Live Nation
description: When the Warner Music Group was sold last year for $3.3 billion, observers of the music industry lost an important resource: as the last stand-alone, publicly traded major record company, Warner offered valuable insight into the economics of the business through its detailed quarterly accounting statements.

title: Effects of Climate Change
description: To the Editor:

title: Defying Expectations With Dark Lyrics and a Dance Beat
description: Miike Snow, the Swedish band that started a three-night stand at Terminal 5 on Tuesday night, has given itself a tricky assignment: bringing angst and enigma into the artificial electronic paradise of electronic dance music. Its best-loved song, Animal  the crowd-pleasing finale on Tuesday  begins, There was a time when my world was filled with darkness, darkness, darkness, and doesnt find much comfort from there.

title: For Vevo, a NewFront to Rival the UpFronts
description: The annual spring upfronts, when television peddles its wares to Madison Avenue, has a new wrinkle ahead of the 2012-13 season: media companies that specialize in online video and other digital delights are adding themselves to the lineup of presentations by broadcast and cable TV outlets.

title: Federal Arts Endowment Sharply Cuts PBS Grants
description: The National Endowment for the Arts made sweeping cuts in its support of established PBS shows on Wednesday, and for the first time awarded significant grants to an array of gaming, mobile and Web-based projects.

title: Pull Up a Broken Chair
description: The objects and installations created by Alex Mustonen and Daniel Arsham of Snarkitecture, a Brooklyn art and design studio, are almost always perplexing, purposely challenging peoples expectations. Their Cast Light, for instance, is a light bulb encased in a solid block of gypsum concrete that allows illumination to escape only through rough cuts in the material. And for Dig, an installation in New York last year at the Storefront for Art and Architecture, they conceived a cavelike interior, which Mr. Arsham chiseled out of solid blocks of expanded polystyrene in a series of performances.

title: Senate Passes Plan to Give Postal Service Fiscal Relief
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Wednesday overcame opposition from several Republicans and passed legislation that would overhaul the financially ailing Postal Service, voting weeks before the agency plans to begin closing thousands of post offices and consolidating hundreds of processing centers to cut costs.

title: China Slows Down, and Grows Up
description: MORE than half of Americans think China is already the worlds leading economy  an astonishing misperception, given that Chinas gross domestic product is still less than half of Americas. As George Orwell once observed, Whoever is winning at the moment will always seem to be invincible. China has grown at a breakneck pace for so long that its aura of invincibility has grown to outsize proportions in the Western imagination.

title: Week After Pulitzer Controversy, City Gives Writers a New Award
description: The literary world still has not recovered from its Pulitzer snub last week, when the absence of an award for fiction incensed publishers, authors and booksellers.

title: Slumping Davis Dropped in Mets Order
description: Mets first baseman Ike Davis dragged a .131 batting average into their game Wednesday against the Miami Marlins, and after placing him seventh in the batting order, Manager Terry Collins said he would like to see Davis play his way out of his slump.

title: Bernanke on What the Fed Can Do
description: Its worth reading the entirety of this response from the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, to a question I raised at a news conference on Wednesday. Its a very clear statement of his views on what is probably the most important current question of economic policy: Why wont the Fed do everything in its power to reduce unemployment?

title: Devils Security Blanket, Brodeur Is Game 7 Veteran
description: NEWARK  Adam Henrique, the Devils superb rookie forward, was flipping through the channels Wednesday morning when hockey highlights compelled him to set down his remote control. Best he could tell, they were from a Game 7  but from when, he wondered. The Devils were playing the Rangers, and the deciding goal came in overtime, on a wraparound by Stephane Matteau.

title: Lionsgate Chief Marketing Officer Will Stay in Role Long Term
description: LOS ANGELES  Lionsgate said on Wednesday that Tim Palen would continue long term as chief marketing officer, ensuring continuity for that studios Hunger Games franchise and ending a power struggle over marketing duties resulting from its acquisition of Summit Entertainment.

title: Expand Minds, Not the N.Y.U. Campus
description: FOR much of the last decade, universities across the country have been spending many millions on construction projects, building grand new campuses to draw more students.

title: Ex-Morgan Stanley Executive Pleads Guilty to Violating Anticorruption Laws
description: One of Morgan Stanleys former real estate executives in China pleaded guilty on Wednesday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn to violating federal anticorruption laws, as the American government continues to crack down on citizens who commit fraud and bribery abroad.

title: A Move to Put Mustard in Food as Well as on It
description: COMMERCIALS for Frenchs mustard, the 108-year-old Reckitt Benckiser brand, have tended to feature backyard barbecues and ballparks where the mustard, unsurprisingly, is squirted on hot dogs, hamburgers and sandwiches.

title: G.O.P. Questions Obamas Travel Accounting
description: As President Obama returned to Washington on Wednesday after a two-day tour of crucial battleground states, the Republican National Committee requested an investigation into whether he was using taxpayer money for what amounted to campaign events.

title: For Women at Games, Messages Are Mixed
description: LONDON

title: Veterans and Brain Disease
description: He was a 27-year-old former Marine, struggling to adjust to civilian life after two tours in Iraq. Once an A student, he now found himself unable to remember conversations, dates and routine bits of daily life. He became irritable, snapped at his children and withdrew from his family. He and his wife began divorce proceedings.

title: Oregon: Study of Coal Transport Sought
description: Gov. John Kitzhaber asked the federal government on Wednesday to conduct an environmental study of proposals to export coal to Asia from Montana and Wyoming through ports in Oregon and Washington. Mr. Kitzhaber did not take a position on the proposals, but his request, made in a letter to several federal agencies, echoed calls from opponents who say the proposals would clog the Northwest with new rail traffic, spread coal dust and increase global and local pollution.

title: North Carolina: Budget Includes Money for Those Sterilized in Eugenics Effort
description: Gov. Bev Perdue called Wednesday for the state to spend $10.3 million to compensate victims of a eugenics program. Between 1929 and 1974, thousands of people were sterilized against their will under a state program intended to prevent poor, uneducated and sometimes mentally handicapped people from having children. The governor said the budget proposal would include $50,000 for each of the 132 verified victims of the program still living. The money would also support a state foundation that tries to find other former patients.

title: Gov. Scott Rounds Up the Usual Zealots
description: It is outrageous that some of Floridas most gun-friendly legislators are on a task force appointed by Gov. Rick Scott to examine the Stand Your Ground law at issue in the shooting death of Trayvon Martin. While Governor Scott has promised a full and fair review, his appointments raise serious doubts about that commitment.

title: Idaho Airmail
description: Ray Arnold has been delivering mail for 34 years to a remote patch of Idaho in the northern Rocky Mountains, at a cost of $46,000 a year to the Postal Service.

title: Neil Finds Three Ways to Torment Rangers
description: OTTAWA  Every facet of Chris Neil, the Ottawa right wing and Rangers nemesis, has been on display during the teams first-round playoff series.

title: Rallies Will Kick Off Obama Re-election Bid
description: President Obama and the first lady will hold two big campaign rallies next week in what Mr. Obamas political advisers are calling the official opening of his effort to win a second term in the White House.

title: Equal Opportunity Panel Updates Hiring Policy
description: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission on Wednesday approved an updated policy that makes it harder for employers to use background checks to systematically rule out hiring anyone with a criminal conviction.

title: In Milan, Plush Reality
description: SOME of the most thought-provoking ideas at the International Furniture Fair in Milan, which ended on Sunday, issued not from the thousands of exhibition booths and off-site venues or even from the lips of the designers, pundits and producers who bring this stalwart city to life every April. They were written on the walls.

title: Market Ready
description: Q. Is it worth spending money on flower arrangements for an open house?

title: Espadas Lawyer Calls Embezzlement Charges Rotten to the Core
description: A lawyer for former State Senator Pedro Espada Jr. placed a giant poster of a red apple in front of a federal jury on Wednesday and said that the prosecutions case claiming that her client embezzled money from a nonprofit health center was rotten to the core.

title: Egypts Chaotic Election
description: Egypts democratic transition is in turmoil again as the country heads into next months crucial election for its first president since the ouster of Hosni Mubarak. Egypts military-run government is running out of time to guarantee a fair and credible vote. Authorities need to finalize the list of candidates and decide where polling stations will be located, whether citizens must vote at specific stations, what rules the monitors must follow and how television airtime will be apportioned among candidates. And all this information needs to be widely publicized.

title: Future of Rose Bowl Is Hot Issue for B.C.S.
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla.  There are few more enduring symbols in college football than the Rose Bowl, which, at the Bowl Championship Series meetings, has become emblematic of a sport caught between traditional pageantry and a lucrative future.

title: Giant Rooftop Signs Move Closer to a Reality in Queens
description: The Manhattan skyline is world-renowned for the iconic profiles of the Empire State and Chrysler Buildings. But the Queens skyline has long been an unremarkable, low-slung silhouette.

title: A Database to Curb Abuse
description: The use and abuse in this country of powerful pain medications has spiraled upward in recent years. A report by New Yorks attorney general, Eric Schneiderman, showed prescriptions in the state for oxycodone, the active ingredient in OxyContin, rose a remarkable 82 percent from 2007 to 2010, and nearly 17 percent for hydrocodone, the main ingredient in Vicodin.

title: In Shift, Mexico to Review Wal-Mart Permits
description: MEXICO CITY  Two days after declaring it would not investigate bribery allegations tied to Wal-Marts rapid expansion in Mexico, the Mexican government said Wednesday that it would review permits related to the approval of stores and seek information from American authorities.

title: With Wal-Mart Claims, Greater Attention on a Law
description: WASHINGTON  A decade ago, the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, which bars American companies from bribing officials overseas, was rarely enforced or discussed. Today, it strikes fear throughout the executive offices of companies with overseas operations, generating huge fees for law firms and large fines for the federal government.

title: A Roof Over Your Head Isnt Enough
description: EVERY week for the last three summers, Ive kicked a footlong tube of curved white aluminum into a bush while hustling by with my lawn mower.

title: Sales at Dinosaur Designs and Others
description: Resin housewares and glassware items will be up to 80 percent off at Dinosaur Designs, April 27 to 30 (the Insects Beetle jug, regularly $90, will be $20); 211 Elizabeth Street (Prince Street), (212) 680-3523, dinosaurdesigns.com.

title: Paris Designers Compose Works
description: Ronan and Erwan Bouroullec, the Paris-based industrial designers, spent the last few years on their latest book, Works, which will be published by Phaidon next month to coincide with the International Contemporary Furniture Fair in New York.

title: MoMAs Latest Destination Is Mexico
description: The Museum of Modern Art Design Stores new destination collection, introduced Thursday, highlights products made in Mexico. For the next few months, or while stock lasts, the shop will offer more than 150 items by 60 Mexican or Mexico-based designers  from tableware and decorative accessories to furniture.

title: A Modernist Touch Outdoors
description: While you can furnish an entire home with modernist classics, that has not always been true for outdoor space. But Cassina, the Italian furniture manufacturer, has taken a step toward rectifying that situation with the introduction of pieces by Le Corbusier, Charlotte Perriand and Pierre Jeanneret, reworked for outdoor use.

title: Expanding the Concept of Lighting
description: IN-EI, a new line of lamps created by the fashion designer Issey Miyake for the Italian lighting company Artemide, includes table, floor, ceiling and pendant lights. The collection, which is made from recycled PET plastic bottles, can be stored flat and expanded into three-dimensional forms without the use of internal frames.

title: Lightly Seasoned Quarterback Is Still a Commodity
description: Andrew Luck has been hailed as a once-in-a-generation prospect because of his physical tools and mental dexterity. But Ryan Tannehill is perhaps the most intriguing player in this N.F.L. draft, in large part because of what he lacks: experience.

title: The End of Newt
description: Well, the results of the latest wave of primaries are in. The people have spoken, decisively. All 10 of them.

title: Chasing Fees, Banks Court Low-Income Customers
description: When David Wegner went looking for a checking account in January, he was peppered with offers for low-end financial products, including a prepaid debit card with numerous fees, a short-term emergency loan with steep charges, money wire services and check-cashing options.

title: Republicans Urge Romney to Promote Positive Vision
description: Republicans have a message for Mitt Romney: its time to go positive.

title: Mayor Vows to Go to Court to Fight Councils Wage Bills
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, warning that the City Councils efforts to raise the wages of some private-sector workers would drive away businesses, vowed on Wednesday to fight the Council in court.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 25, 2012

title: Laker Cites Passion, Not Anger, in Elbowing
description: EL SEGUNDO, Calif.  Peace? Not in the Lakers time.

title: At Disney, Its Tough to Find a Chief
description: LAS VEGAS  At a convention of movie theater owners here on Tuesday, Walt Disney Studios displayed plenty of fanfare, trotting out Johnny Depp to promote his 2013 remake of The Lone Ranger and hiring 11 bagpipe players to herald Brave, a film about a Scottish princess.

title: After Recalls and Missteps, J.&J.s New Chief Confronts Critical Challenges
description: Johnson & Johnson needs to rethink the way it brings drugs to market, expand its reach into global markets and rebuild consumer confidence by returning recalled brands to pharmacy shelves, the incoming chief executive, Alex Gorsky, said in an interview Wednesday.

title: Retirement Homes Beckon for City Chickens
description: Urban chicken retirement is becoming a new phenomenon, giving aging birds a place to live out their sunset years.

title: When Banks Compete With Check-Cashing Stores
description: An article in Thursdays paper tracks the growing interest among major banks in offering prepaid debit cards, check cashing and wire transfers. Reading it together with a Bucks post from a few months back about the rise of payday-loan-like cash advance services from major financial institutions, you begin to understand just how seriously the banks take the idea of competing with old-fashioned currency exchanges and other storefront money centers that are known for their high fees and exorbitant interest rates.

title: Things I Saw  No. 6
description: Suggestions for what youd like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

title: 2 House Democrats Defeated After Opposing Health Law
description: WASHINGTON  The defeat of two conservative House Democrats by more liberal opponents in Tuesdays Pennsylvania primary illustrates the strong hold the new health care law still has over committed Democratic voters and foreshadows an even more polarized Congress next year in the aftermath of the latest round of redistricting.

title: As Analyst, Polian Still Focuses on Draft
description: After decades of being central to draft decision making with the Buffalo Bills, the Carolina Panthers and the Indianapolis Colts, Bill Polians personnel assessments matter a little less than in the past.

title: We Are Not Stupid
description: Its still about Mitt Romney, and were not stupid.

title: Pakistani Premier Faces Verdict in Clash With Court
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  After months of standoffs and skirmishes in a courtroom clash between Pakistans top judges and civilian leaders, the Supreme Court is poised to deliver a verdict on Thursday that could land Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gilani in prison and cost him his job.

title: Arizona v. United States
description: Solicitor General Donald Verrilli Jr. had barely started his argument against Arizonas immigration law on Wednesday at the Supreme Court when Chief Justice John Roberts Jr. signaled where he stood  in sympathy with the states defense of the statute.

title: Appeals Panel Overturns Conviction of Lebovits in Sexual Abuse Case
description: Saying that a detectives handwritten notes had not been promptly turned over to defense lawyers before trial, a New York appeals court panel this week overturned the 2010 conviction of a cantor who had already served one year in prison for the repeated sexual assault of a teenager.

title: Revealing Naked Power Behind Mask
description: Nudity has been so commonplace for so long on Broadway that it is now shocking when it shocks you. So give credit to the creators of The Columnist, David Auburns scrupulously assembled historical drama, for delivering a truly troubling glimpse of exposed flesh in the plays opening minutes, a glimpse  it turns out  that is anything but gratuitous.

title: A Global Puzzle
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Rebus alert! This is a longish one, so write in tiny letters if youre solving on paper. It takes a lot of work to cram the whole WORLD into one small square. So its a small WORLD, get it? Is this thing on? Hey, wheres everyone going?

title: Whitewashing on the Small Screen
General Orders Review of Military Schools After Class Is Told U.S. Is at War With Islam
description: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff has ordered military schools to make sure they are not including anti-Islamic themes in training courses, the Defense Department said on Wednesday, after complaints surfaced about the curriculum in a course dealing with terrorism and radicalism.

title: After Mans Death, Scrutiny for a Police Chase
description: Tamon Robinsons sideline of digging up cobblestones and selling them to scrap dealers had gotten him arrested numerous times.

title: Winners at Southeasterns Regional
description: The Southeasterns Regional was held in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., from April 9 to 15. The winners of the most master points were Judith Bianco, Win Allegaert and Kevin Bathurst of New York City, and Justin Lall of Henderson, Nev. In five events they won twice, were second twice and fourth once.

title: Taking Their Dreams, but Not the Usual Ones, to Broadway
description: If the lights of Broadway were dimmed every time a dream died, it would be cast in eternal darkness. Yet hope continues, as reflected by the many people who are testing the worlds most unforgiving stage by investing in a new musical opening this week, the aptly named Leap of Faith.

title: Anger at Sarkozy Fuels Far-Right Party in France
description: PARIS  Lionel de Marcy seems an unlikely supporter of Frances far-right party, the National Front. He comes from the Caribbean island of Martinique, has a good job in Paris and is the son of a former leader of the Socialist Party.

title: Wright Gets Boost From Friendlier Dimensions
description: David Wright crushed yet another baseball that soared high and traveled far at Citi Field, sailing all the way to the wall at a spacious ballpark that tortured him for three years. But Citi Field has been shrunk, partly for Wrights benefit.

title: Grunwald Will Have Decision on Woodson
description: With his interim tag removed, and his status as the Knicks top basketball executive secure, Glen Grunwalds first major decision will be whether to remove another interim label: his coachs.

title: Suspending a Campaign
description: As Mitt Romney moves toward locking up the Republican nomination, take a look back at the campaigns that were.

title: Prostitutes Perplexed as Glare Falls on Citys Brothels
description: CARTAGENA, Colombia  Rubbing eyes drowsy from lack of sleep and still smudged with the previous nights mascara, the employees of the Angeles Bar Club trooped one by one on Tuesday afternoon into a tiny bedroom with stickers of Tinker Bell and Sleeping Beauty pasted on the mauve walls to sit down on a bed with a lime green comforter and be tested for sexually transmitted diseases.

title: Life Inside a Brothel in Cartagena
description: Though the recent scandal involving American Secret Service agents has cast new scrutiny on prostitution in Colombia, life in the brothels goes on as it always has.

title: Black Mans Killing in Georgia Eludes Spotlight
description: LYONS, Ga.  Norman Neesmith was sleeping in his home on a rural farm road here in onion country when a noise woke him up.

title: Yielding to the Real World, Gingrich Tells Romney Hell Quit the Race
description: WASHINGTON  Newt Gingrichs presidential campaign was always improbable: He was a Washington insider, twice divorced, with a lavish lifestyle and a penchant for off-the-cuff bluntness that is perfect for a pundit, not a politician.

title: French Front-Runner Says Hed Seek to Renegotiate Fiscal Treaty if Elected
description: PARIS  The front-runner for the French presidency, the Socialist candidate Franois Hollande, said on Wednesday that if elected he would ask other European leaders to renegotiate a fiscal treaty in order to promote growth.

title: In an Ideal World, Heres How the Draft Would Unfold
description: The N.F.L. draft can be a turning point in a teams history. It can also reaffirm the status quo, for better or worse. The three-day event, which begins Thursday night at Radio City Music Hall, is an opportunity for teams to fill immediate needs, add developmental players or, in a few cases, kick-start franchise-wide paradigm shifts. The Colts have stated that they will take Stanford quarterback Andrew Luck No. 1 over all; the Redskins are enamored of Baylor quarterback Robert Griffin III and will certainly take him second. After that, anything is possible. Here, in alphabetical order, is a peek at the likely shopping lists for all 32 teams.

title: Mobilizing Young Voters on Campus
description: President Obama wrapped up a barnstorming tour of college campuses in swing states on Wednesday.

title: Two Parties Find a Way to Agree, and Disagree, on Student Loan Rates
description: IOWA CITY  As President Obama wrapped up a barnstorming tour of college campuses in swing states on Wednesday, Democrats and Republicans agreed that they wanted to avoid a steep increase in the student loan interest rate this summer. But the chief issue remained unsettled: how to pay the cost of doing so.

title: Score One for the Helicopter Parents
description: Has a grandparent mocked your parenting today? Pointed out that you survived a childhood without a five-point-harness car seat, a bike helmet or laws requiring a gate around every pool?

title: British Governments Ties to Murdochs Scrutinized
description: LONDON  Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain and a senior member of his cabinet faced a growing scandal Wednesday over suggestions of intimate links between Rupert Murdochs business interests and the government presented by Mr. Murdoch and his son James this week as evidence in a judicial inquiry.

title: Capitals Edge Bruins in the Closest Series
description: BOSTON  They hung around for the traditional handshake. They stayed a little longer to raise their sticks and salute their fans. But those were the actions of the defeated Wednesday night. The Boston Bruins defense of the Stanley Cup ended before it ever really began.

title: U.S. to Step Up Drone Strikes Inside Yemen
description: WASHINGTON  The White House has given the Central Intelligence Agency and the Pentagon broader authority to carry out drone strikes in Yemen against terrorists who imperil the United States, reflecting rising concerns about the country as a safe haven for Al Qaeda, a senior administration official said Wednesday night.

title: 2 Abuse Victims Testify at Church Officials Trial
description: PHILADELPHIA  Two men testified Wednesday of abuse they suffered as youths at the hands of a now defrocked Philadelphia priest. The two victims of Edward Avery, a former priest who has pleaded guilty to sexual assault charges, appeared during the landmark trial of Msgr. William Lynn, the former secretary for clergy at the Archdiocese of Philadelphia, who is charged with child endangerment. Monsignor Lynn is suspected of allowing priests accused of abuse to remain in positions where they could continue to abuse children.

title: Finale Will Resolve Knicks Playoff Role
description: Before they could close out the Los Angeles Clippers, or bid a temporary farewell to their fans, before the Knicks could even be sure of their playoff destination, the chant started to boom:

title: Still Working His Way Back, Pettitte Takes Loss in Trenton
description: TRENTON  Just hours after the Yankees announced that pitcher Michael Pineda would miss the remainder of the season with a shoulder injury, Andy Pettitte pitched for Class AA Trenton on Wednesday.

title: Man Said to Be Acting Head of New England Mob Is Held
description: BOSTON  The man federal authorities say was the acting head of the New England mob was arrested here Wednesday morning, and in a federal court appearance in Providence, R.I., later in the day pleaded not guilty to multiple counts including racketeering and conspiracy.

title: Corrections: April 26
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Womens Soccer Pioneer to Be Honored by Jewish Hall of Fame
description: The hackneyed but long-running joke about Jews in sports was humorously summarized in the 1980 film Airplane, when the flight attendant Elaine, played by Julie Hagerty, said to a passenger:

title: A Close Reading of the Feds Statement
description: The Federal Reserves statement was unusually similar to its previous language about the countrys economic conditions.

title: With Pickup of Paul, Clippers Changed Style
description: The Los Angeles Clippers arrived in New York for their last regular-season game having completed the first part of their mission: they made the playoffs for the first time in seven years and for only the fifth time since the franchise moved from Buffalo to San Diego in 1978 and changed its name from the Braves.

title: Karzai Critic in Congress Is Asked to Cancel Afghanistan Visit
description: WASHINGTON  Acting at the behest of President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan, senior American officials told a California congressman last weekend that he was not welcome in Afghanistan because of concerns that his sharp criticism of Mr. Karzai would undermine Washingtons efforts to rebuild trust with the government and restart preliminary peace talks with the Taliban.

title: Word of the Day | felon
description: felon \fe-ln\ noun

title: White House Promotes a Bioeconomy
description: The Obama administration is expected to announce a broad plan on Thursday to foster development of the nations bioeconomy, including the use of renewable resources and biological manufacturing methods.

title: Of Mali, the Maldives and Crises Ecological and Political
description: PARIS  The Maldives and Mali, just a few letters apart on the United Nations roll call, are both poor Islamic states with few inhabitants scattered over wide, empty spaces. Yet they exemplify extremes that threaten a small, round planet.

title: Virginia Spencer Carr, Literary Biographer, Dies at 82
description: Virginia Spencer Carr, a literary scholar whose book The Lonely Hunter remains the standard biography of Carson McCullers, died on April 10 at her home in Lynn, Mass. She was 82.

title: Smartphone Patent Wars: The Coming Sequel
description: Billions of dollars are being spent to amass patent arsenals, and lawsuits are flying worldwide. Apple, Samsung, Microsoft and Motorola Mobility (or Google, after that patent-inspired acquisition is complete) are the heavyweights in the fray, seeking an edge in the fast-growing smartphone market, using intellectual property as a weapon.

title: A Man on a Wire Above Chinas Grand Canyon
description: HONG KONG  The best American rock climbers would already seem to have their hands full, from the Gunks and the granite crags in New Hampshire to the Hueco Tanks boulders in Texas, to the storied routes in Yosemite like Half Dome and El Capitan.

title: Israeli Army Chief Says He Believes Iran Wont Build Bomb
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli military chief described the Iranian government as rational in interviews published Wednesday and said he did not believe it would build a nuclear bomb, appearing to put some distance between himself and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Defense Minister Ehud Barak.

title: Japan Power Broker Acquitted in Scandal
description: TOKYO  A divisive power broker of Japans ruling party was acquitted Thursday of charges in a political financing scandal, freeing him to step up his opposition to Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda and a critical tax increase plan.

title: Did Blankfein Snub Paulson Over Emerging Markets?
description: On Wednesday morning on CNBC, Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chief of Goldman Sachs, made a rare on-camera appearance to defend the embattled firm from its detractors, Kevin Roose writes in DealBook blog of The New York Times.

title: Brazil: Panetta Pushes Boeing
description: Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta pushed Brazil on Wednesday to buy $4 billion worth of Boeing-made Super Hornet fighter jets, saying the prospective sale reflected how important Brazil was to the United States. During the first visit by an American defense secretary to the country in seven years, Mr. Panetta used a speech at Superior War College in Rio De Janeiro to focus on smoothing a sometimes thorny relationship and promoting American weapons sales. Brazil is deciding whether to buy 36 fighter jets worth about $4 billion in a competition between Boeing in the United States, Dassault Aviation in France and Saab in Sweden.

title: Pakistani Prime Minister Is Spared Jail but Faces More Battles
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Senior judges embroiled in a bitter confrontation with the government made a tactical retreat on Thursday when they convicted the prime minister, Yousaf Raza Gilani, on contempt charges, but imposed a symbolic sentence that allowed him to walk free minutes later.

title: Ireland: Law on Abuse Is Proposed
description: Ireland has introduced draft legislation that would make it a crime to withhold information on child abuse from the state authorities. The new law was introduced in response to last Julys Cloyne Report, which found that a Roman Catholic diocese had failed to report such abuse as recently as 2008. Under the legislation, any person who fails to report abuse would face at least five years in jail. Justice Minister Alan Shatter said that the law would extend to the confessional and that it was not acceptable that there can be a cloak of secrecy surrounding such offenses against children or other vulnerable people in society.

title: Deutsche Bank Earnings Fall 34%, Worse Than Expected
description: FRANKFURTDeutsche Bank, the largest German bank, said on Thursday that profit had fallen 34 percent in the first quarter, more than expected, as the European debt crisis continued to depress fees from trading and other investment banking activities.

title: News Quiz | April 26, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: In The Commuters, a Photographer Chronicles Mumbais Working Class
description: You stare out of the window, you fiddle with your phone, you nod your head along to music, you block out the sounds and presence of people pressed against you, and you try to pass the time during another dreary morning commute in Mumbais local trains. It was out of this boredom that photographer Chirodeep Chaudhuris latest show The Commuterswas born.

title: Ex-President of Liberia Aided War Crimes, Court Rules
description: THE HAGUE  Charles G. Taylor, the former president of Liberia and once a powerful warlord, was convicted by an international tribunal on Thursday of arming, supporting and guiding a brutal rebel movement that committed mass atrocities in Sierra Leone during its civil war in the 1990s. He is the first head of state to be convicted by an international court since the Nuremberg trials after World War II.

title: Santander Earnings Drop 24% in Quarter
description: 8:08 a.m. | Updated

title: At British Inquiry, Murdoch Apologizes Over Scandal
description: LONDON  After a day of testimony at a British judicial inquiry over his ties, friendships and disputes with British politicians, Rupert Murdoch returned to the witness stand on Thursday, saying he apologized for failing to take measures to avert the hacking scandal that has convulsed his media outpost here.

title: Test Yourself | English, April 26, 2012
description: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the India Ink blog post Keralas Cochini Jews Meld Into Israel.

title: April 26, 1986 | Explosion at Chernobyl Nuclear Plant
description: On April 26, 1986, the worlds worst nuclear accident happened at the Chernobyl plant near Pripyat, Ukraine, in the Soviet Union. An explosion and fire in the No. 4 reactor sent radioactivity into the atmosphere.

title: Doors Open for Female Marines
description: WHAT steps has the Marine Corps taken in integrating women in war-fighting units?WHAT are female Marines still not allowed to do?

title: Barclays Profit Rises as Investment Banking Shows Strength
description: LONDON  Barclays on Thursday reported a better-than-expected increase in first-quarter earnings, reflecting stronger investment banking results and improving credit quality.

title: Updates on Rupert Murdochs Second Day of Testimony in Britain
description: The Lede followed a second day of testimony by Rupert Murdoch on Thursday and other developments in a judicial inquiry into the behavior of the British press that grew out of a widening phone hacking and corruption scandal at Murdoch-owned papers in Britain. On Wednesday, Mr. Murdoch downplayed the political influence of his media empire in hours of testimony. His son James appeared before the same judicial panel on Tuesday.

title: Seeing Yourself as Others Do
description: While on spring break 10 years ago in Myrtle Beach, S.C., Jen Davis decided to turn the camera on herself. But at 5-foot-4 and 260 pounds, this was not an easy thing to do. Sitting on a sandy beach mat in a tank top and shorts, surrounded by friends in more revealing swimwear, she triggered a cable release hidden under her foot.

title: U.S. Assets at Work, Unsupervised
description: Simon Johnson is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You. From 2007 to 2008, he was the International Monetary Funds chief economist and director of research.

title: What Have You and Your Family Accomplished Together?
description: Marshall Reid was an overweight sixth grader who wanted to get healthy, so he and his family worked together on plan. It worked and eventually, they wrote a book about it. Have you and your family ever taken on a big project or set a shared goal? Did you succeed?

title: Exxon Mobil Earnings Disappoint
description: The global oil giant Exxon Mobil on Thursday reported disappointing first-quarter earnings, saying net income dropped 11 percent because of lower production volumes and weak chemical profit margins.

title: Social Media 1, Indian Government 0
description: The futility of the Indian governments attempts to control what is posted on Facebook, YouTube and other social media sites was thrown into high relief this week, after a video purportedly showing Congress spokesman Abhishek Manu Singvi having sex in his office resulted in his resignation.

title: Fresenius Group Bids $4.1 Billion for Hospital Operator
description: LONDON  The health care company Fresenius Group on Thursday offered 3.1 billion euros ($4.1 billion) to buy the German hospital operator Rhn-Klinikum, as it looked to increase its presence in the German market.

title: Japanese Soba and the Broth of Life
description: A bowl of soba is a beautiful, exotic and delicious centerpiece for a Japanese meal: the not-too-soft, nutty buckwheat noodles sitting in a mahogany broth  dashi  thats as clear and glossy as beef consomm, not only salty and umami-complex but sweet as well. My favorite variety, tamago toji, is egg-topped. When its made right, the egg is almost foamy, soft-scrambled and tender, deliciously flavored by the dashi, a bit of which it absorbs.

title: How Samuel L. Jackson Became His Own Genre
description: Before The Mountaintop opened on Broadway last fall, there were rumors that this fictional account of Martin Luther King Jr.s last night before his assassination would present him as a flawed man, one who drinks and flirts with a motel maid. Kenny Leon, the director, told me recently, however, that he never would have had anything to do with something that destroyed the iconic nature of Dr. King. In fact, he said, when he first read the play, he realized that its innocently childlike King could be played only by a sensitive actor bigger than life  his friend Sam Jackson.

title: The 15 Movies That Define Samuel L. Jacksons Career
description: In the April 29 issue of the magazine, Pat Jordan writes about how Samuel L. Jackson became his own genre. Below, fifteen of the 100-plus movies in his oeuvre.

title: How Do You Compete With FedEx and U.P.S.?
description: Recently, while wrapping up a meeting with a new client, Lone Star Overnight, the companys chief executive talked about what hes doing to shift his companys culture. Ive always been fascinated by company culture, but its especially interesting when someone is trying to transform a 20-year-old company with revenue of more than $50 million.

title: Why Andrew Luck Deserves to Be Drafts No. 1 Quarterback
description: Matt Waldman is the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, a testament to his obsession with film analysis, now available for download. Examples of his work can be found at his blog. This post concludes his ranking of the skill position draft prospects for the Fifth Down:

description: LONDON  The backlash against austerity is under way. Responding to the anguish of restless electorates hammered by the effects of budget cuts, European politicians are putting the focus back on economic growth.

description: Breaking down (some of) his (many, many) roles into constituent categories. With some overlap.

description: DETROIT  Chrysler, broken down, bankrupt and begging for a bailout just three years ago, is now a shiny new sports car zipping past the competition.

description: Every time I think we might be making progress against the prejudices and myths that pass for judicious thinking these days, something like this editorial in the FT comes along to renew my despair.

description: More on the bird conservation front:

title: Young and Restless Students Race Sophisticated Mini-Machines in Detroit
description: This week, elementary and middle-school students convened on the floor of the Cobo Center in Detroit, Michigan to build and race toy cars without any prior knowledge of the parts and materials at their disposal, Paul Stenquist  writes in Wheels blog of The New York Times.

description: Barclays Profit Rises as Deutsche Bank and Santander Report Lower Earnings | Europes debt crisis continued to weigh on the Continents largest banks, as three lenders reported first-quarter results on Thursday.

description: From the editorial page

title: Lest We Remember
description: ISTANBUL  The other day Taraf, a Turkish language newspaper for which I write, ran a quarter-page ad depicting a pomegranate with a deep slash and the legend: Some wounds do not heal with time. The pomegranate is a symbol of the Armenian people, and in fine print you could make out the endorsement of many prominent Turkish Armenians for a gathering in Istanbuls Taksim Square. The ad didnt bother to explain the purpose of the assembly, leaving the date and time  April 24, 19:15  to speak for itself.

title: Decision Looms for City Schools
The Caregivers Bookshelf: Essays on the End
description: Let me acknowledge that perhaps not everyone wants to settle down in a comfy chair with a glass of wine, a purring cat, and 22 very personal essays about death and dying. My daughter has taken to asking me whether I wouldnt rather read  or write  about puppies and kittens.

title: The Road to Naypyidaw
description: NAYPYIDAW, Myanmar  The 43 seats of Parliament that Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and the other newly elected members of her National League for Democracy (N.L.D.) were supposed to fill on Monday remain empty. After winning by-elections by a landslide earlier this month, the Lady and her party are refusing to show up for their first legislative session in protest over having to take a pledge to safeguard the 2008 Constitution.

title: Rice, a Private Equity Pioneer, to Step Down
description: Joseph L. Rice III, a pioneer of the private equity industry, plans to step down as chairman of Clayton, Dubilier & Rice, his firm announced in a letter to clients on Wednesday.

description: Sometimes even the small companies can reveal big lessons about success on the Internet.

description: LOS ANGELES

title: T Exclusive Video | A Polished Look by Chanel
description: When Peter Philips, Chanels creative director for makeup, wanted to showcase the latest collection of Chanel nail polish on film, he called upon Ruth Hogben, a London filmmaker known for her work with Gareth Pugh and Louis Vuitton. The inspiration to use sign language came shortly after.

title: How an iPhone Audition Got Benedict Cumberbatch Into the Star Trek Sequel
description: No, Benedict Cumberbatch is not going to tell us anything juicy about the top-secret role hes been filming in the coming sequel to Star Trek, the next adventure of the starship Enterprise crew from the director J. J. Abrams.

title: Thursday Reading: Should Your Dog Be Watching TV?
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Magic Fingers
description: The Dutch model Saskia De Brauw shows off an array of chic Chanel polishes.

title: A Bribery Case That Goes Beyond Corruption
description: If all goes as scheduled, former State Senator Carl Kruger will stand Thursday afternoon before a federal judge in Manhattan and get whats coming to him for having accepted hundreds of thousands of dollars in bribes.

title: Edwards Ex-Aide Admits Stealth Campaign Billing
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  The drama of former Senator John Edwardss trial took a few more twists on Thursday as Andrew Young, the eager aide whose fortunes and stature rose and fell with those of Mr. Edwards, admitted submitting misleading financial statements to a wealthy benefactor who thought he was helping the senator hide a mistress.

title: Heavy Casualties Reported in Syria Explosion
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A number of Syrian civilians died in a poor neighborhood of Hama after their houses crashed down on them, but the government and the opposition offered widely different accounts on Thursday of the cause.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Murdoch Says He Failed on Hacking, and a Missing Vogue Profile
description: Rupert Murdoch completed his second and final day of testimony before the Leveson inquiry on press ethics on Thursday, addressing the phone-hacking scandal at his companys News of The World that propelled the creation of the commission in the first place. I also have to say that I failed, Mr. Murdoch told the commission. I am very sorry about it. In addition, he suggested, Alan Cowell writes, that there had been what he called a cover-up by underlings at The News of the World to hide the extent of the phone hacking scandal.

title: Making Information Matter in a Noisy Age
description: I was invited to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology earlier this week to outline my notion that it is possible, amid the reverberating noise and distraction, to use the Web and other emerging communication tools and networks to make the world a better place.

title: Morning Buzz, April 26: A Protest Against Tuition
description: Good morning. Expect rain throughout the day with temperatures reaching the upper 50s, a surprisingly appropriate forecast to commemorate the anniversary of Shakespeares baptism.

title: Lockheed Chief to Retire and Hand Reins to an Insider
description: Lockheed Martin said Thursday that its chief executive, Robert J. Stevens, would retire in December after eight years in the job. His successor will be Christopher E. Kubasik, who is now Lockheeds president and chief operating officer.

title: A Daunting Emissions Quest for U.S. Cities
description: More than 1,000 American cities have voluntarily committed themselves to ambitious targets for reducing carbon dioxide emissions. A recent case study focusing on Allegheny County, Pa., home to Pittsburgh, highlights how hard it will be for some to meet those goals, however.

title: What Were Reading
description: Reuters: Despite assurances from the Agriculture Department, the blowback from the announcement of Americas first case of mad cow disease in six years (in a California dairy cow) has begun. Two major South Korean retailers and an English wholesaler have halted sales of United States beef, while Mexico, Korea and Japan say they will continue imports.  Glenn Collins

title: A Photographer Is Approached for an Assignment
description: Dear Diary: I was photographing dancers in Madison Square Park on April 14, a stunning Saturday morning, and a big, burly 30-something and ruggedly handsome Con Ed worker saunters over to me from the plaza in front of the Flatiron Building, where hed been working, and starts making small talk.

title: Mods and Bikers | Bobbin Bicycles Land Stateside
description: When you come across a smart new upright bicycle on the floor of the TriBeCa cycling boutique Adeline Adeline this spring, dont make the mistake of calling it Dutch. It very well may be a Bobbin, a line of British city bikes designed by Tom Morris and Sian Emmison, who until recently ran a bike shop of the same name in Islington, London. The line of bikes, which has been available in Britain since 2011, makes its New York City debut tonight, with a party at the TriBeCa store. (An earlier line of Britain-only Bobbin bikes has been popular for about five years among fashionable Londoners like Florence Welch, Lara Stone and the designer Erdem Moraglioglu.)

title: Tribeca: Maggie Gyllenhaal on Sex Scenes From a Womans Perspective
description: The plague of our times, a character declares in Hysteria, Tanya Wexlers new film, stems from an overactive uterus. The time is Victorian England and the focus is the invention of the vibrator. The romantic comedy, which plays at the Tribeca Film Festival on Thursday and opens commercially on May 18, stars Hugh Dancy as Mortimer, a forward-thinking doctor, and Maggie Gyllenhaal as Charlotte, a champion of womens rights and the rebellious daughter of Mr. Dancys mentor, as well as his romantic match.

title: Trouble With the Top Man
description: HOUSTON Aubrey K. McClendon, Chesapeake Energys audacious chairman and chief executive, has ridden the busts and booms in natural gas like a rodeo cowboy. He became a billionaire as the company he co-founded aggressively outbid competitors for land leases and drilled highly productive wells in virtually every major shale gas field in the country. And he acquired trophy assets like an N.B.A. team and a $12 million antique map collection.

title: Support for Same-Sex Marriage Is Up
description: Same-sex marriage opponents often cast themselves as the defenders of traditional, mainstream American values. Increasingly, however, it looks as though the traditional and the mainstream are coming apart.

title: With Panel Vote, Once-Venerable City Schools Will Close
Higher Prices Help PepsiCo Increase Earnings on Flat Sales
description: PepsiCo, the Hatfield of the countrys cola wars to Coca-Colas McCoy, used higher prices to eke out slightly better first-quarter earnings than analysts expected despite essentially flat revenue.

title: Image of the Day: April 26
Leaves Arrive, Transforming the Forest
description: See a larger version of the forest from this week. Compare with the enlarged version of last weeks image.

title: A Struggling Order Sees a Chance on Broadway
description: The Passionist priests and and brothers of the Province of St. Paul of the Cross are among the investors in the musical Leap of Faith, opening Thursday.

title: AstraZeneca C.E.O. to Step Down
description: David Brennan, the chief executive of AstraZeneca, will step down on June 1 as the big British pharmaceutical company struggles with competition from makers of generic drugs and the failure of several drug development projects.

title: Activist Group Alleges Widespread Corruption in Defense Deals
description: Hiring foreign call girls, intimidation, money laundering, fraud and bribes  those are just some of the activities government officials, defense executives and middle men were accused of Thursday by the activist group India Against Corruption.

title: Business Day Live | April 26, 2012
description: Banks aggressively court low-income customers; balancing education costs and job prospects in California; and a rise in malware targeting Mac users.

description: Banks aggressively court low-income customers; balancing education costs and job prospects in California; and a rise in malware targeting Mac users.

title: Ross Douthat Talks About the State of American Christianity
description: In his new book Bad Religion: How We Became a Nation of Heretics, Ross Douthat, an Op-Ed columnist for The Times, writes about how Christianity lost its central place in American life through a variety of factors, among them the religions failed attempts to accommodate secular trends; a strong identification of the church with strictly conservative politics; a lack of great religious-inspired art; and the appeal to a God within that tailors spirituality to the citizens of a self-help age. I recently spoke with Mr. Douthat about the book via e-mail. Below are excerpts of the conversation.

title: Lomography, an Analog Company Surviving in a Digital World
description: From the death rattle of companies like Kodak to the popularity of apps like Instagram that transform cellphone snaps into vintage-looking works of art, amateur film photography seems destined for the graveyard of obsolete technologies.

title: The Citys Verdant Heart
description: Theres no dearth of specious, gaseous political rhetoric in this fevered democracy of ours, but one bit of grandstanding that irks me in particular is the occasional portrayal of the city as a dark graveyard for civic virtue stalked by hedonists with no sense of community.

title: A $1,200 Dress for Your Little One?
description: From the Styles section: The high-fashion world, determined to leave no market untapped, is now turning out designer clothes for children. Just $1,200 for a Lanvin tulle dress, and dont forget the $1,570 taffeta coat. Makes the $30 dry cleaning bill to get out the chocolate-frosted birthday cake look like milk money, doesnt it? The vast majority of us, of course, still spend less on a t-shirt for a child than you could blow on a venti at Starbucks  but to see how the other 1 percent lives, check out the slide show.

title: Using Business to Help At-Risk Middle Schoolers
An Aging Japanese Town Bets on a Young Mayor for Its Revival
description: YUBARI,Japan Most young people have already fled this city of empty streets and shuttered schools, whose bankrupt local government collapsed under the twin burdens of debt and demographics that are slowly afflicting the rest ofJapan.

title: Dear Boy Scouts: Let a Gay Mom Lead the Pack
description: By now, you may have heard of Jennifer Tyrrell, especially if youre the parent of a child of scouting age. Shes the Bridgeport, Ohio, mother who (reluctantly) accepted the role of den mother for her 7-year-old son Cruzs Tiger Scout pack a year ago (not, as many reluctant volunteer parents know, a position that adults are clamoring to fill)  and was told by the regional, and then national Boy Scouts organization earlier this month that she would have to leave her troop, because her sexual orientation did not meet the high standards of conduct set by the Boy Scouts of America.

title: The Curious Case of the Telus Proxy Battle
description: The proxy battle involving the Telus Corporation, the $19 billion Canadian telecommunications company, is shaping up to be the most interesting of the year, involving allegations of empty voting, vote buying and secret share accumulations. What fun!

title: Lawmakers Push for a Final Volcker Rule by the Summer
description: The lawmakers who sponsored an effort to rein in risky trading on Wall Street are now urging regulators to finalize a forceful version of the Volcker Rule by the summer.

title: A Worrisome Rise in Jobless Claims
description: The odds that the economy has fallen into a spring slowdown  for the third straight year  rose this morning.

title: Q. and A. About Frontline Series on the Financial Crisis
description: 4:01 p.m. | Updated

title: In Hockey, Game 7 Is Different
description: This time there was no Champagne, no Stanley Cup paraded around the rink, not nearly as much delirium as on that manic night, the last time there was a Game 7 in Madison Square Garden.

title: Two Game 7s? Isnt There a Draft Going On?
description: It is a quirk of the modern sports schedule that pits the first night of the N.F.L. draft against two Game 7s in the N.H.L. playoffs, which is sort of like choosing between Audrey Hepburn or a Kardashian sister. Because yes, everyone will agree nothing rivals a Game 7 for drama and intensity, for players pouring their hopes and dreams onto the ice. And yes, it will get killed in the ratings by a parade of large men doing nothing but modeling specially tailored menswear. In todays world, the Kardashians it is.

title: TLC Is Said to Plan a Reunion Tour Using Projections of Lisa Lopes
description: Why let a little thing like death get in the way of a lucrative reunion?The two surviving members the girl group TLC are planning a reunion tour that will use video projections of Lisa Lopes, who died in a car crash a decade ago, according to the celebrity-watch Web site TMZ.

title: Under Public Pressure, City Retreats on Cleveland and Bushwick High School Closings
Massachusetts Stamps a Catch-All Plate for E.V.s, Plug-Ins and Hybrids
description: The Massachusetts Department of Transportation announced this week that it would make special license plates available for purely electric, plug-in hybrid and regular hybrid vehicles, becoming the second state, after Hawaii, to do so. The optional plates, which cost $20 with no annual fee, feature the letters EV, or EC for commercial vehicles, and a graphic of a car mated with a plug.

title: Morning Walkabout: 4/26
description: Hidden Myanmar The 800 islands of the Mergui Archipelago in southern Myanmar remain largely empty even as a tourism infrastructure takes root in the rest of the country. The few visitors who make it are closely monitored, because, locals suspect, a massacre took place on one of the islands and illegal fishing, logging and smuggling still occurs. (The New York Times)

title: European Union Protests Ukraines Treatment of Jailed Ex-Premier
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union pressed Ukraine on Thursday to allow independent medical specialists to visit the countrys jailed former prime minister, Yulia V. Tymoshenko, after she claimed to have been beaten by prison guards last week.

title: Does Medicine Discourage Gay Doctors?
description: During my surgical training, whenever the conversation turned to relationships, one of my colleagues would always joke about his inability to get a date, then abruptly change the subject. I thought he might be gay but never asked him outright, because it didnt seem important.

title: As Bison Return to Prairie, Some Rejoice, Others Worry
description: WOLF POINT, Mont.  Sioux and Assiniboine tribe members wailed a welcome song last month as around 60 bison from Yellowstone National Park stormed onto a prairie pasture that had not felt a bisons hoof for almost 140 years.

title: For One More Day at the Office
description: Every only child knows there is a difference between being lonely and being alone. Growing up in Manhattan, I was a master at entertaining myself; I had an older half sister, but she didnt live with me, so I was usually my own favorite company.

title: Look of the Moment | Gwyneth Paltrow
description: The Look: No fuss. Natural hair, gothic nails and stilettos take a ladylike knit sheath and bicolor top-handle tote to a modern place.

title: Teachers Aide on Upper West Side Charged With Sexually Abusing 8-Year-Old
description: Update | Mr. Abdalla was freed on April 26 after the district attorneys office decided to defer prosecution while it continues to investigate his case.

title: Crane Owner Is Cleared of All Charges in Fatal Collapse
description: The owner of a crane company was acquitted on Thursday of all charges in connection with the collapse of a tower crane in Manhattan nearly four years ago that killed two people.

title: A Mixed Legal Outcome for an Egyptian Comedian
description: CAIRO  A court on Thursday dismissed a case against Egypts most popular comedian that charged him with insulting Islam in his films, just days after another court fined him in a separate case dealing with very similar charges. Egyptian state media had initially reported that his first conviction had been overturned on appeal, and the opposite outcomes in similar cases underscored the confusion and irregularity in the application of Egypts laws against defaming religion.

title: Missing Curtain
description: The new Broadway musical Once forgoes the typical opening curtain to start the show on stage, audience invited.

title: Citizens Bank Is Latest to Settle Suit on Overdraft Fees
description: Citizens Bank is the latest institution to settle a class-action lawsuit alleging that banks changed the order of customer payments to increase the amount they could collect in overdraft fees. The fees are charged when customers, by writing checks or using debit cards, spend more than is available in their checking accounts.

title: Broadway Show Appetizers
description: THE orchestral overture has been a mainstay of Broadway musicals for decades, though in recent years some shows have dispensed with it. This season three Broadway productions  one of them a play  have added preshow components that have nothing to do with highlighting a composers score. They are meant to be mood setters and palate whetters for the audience  and fun to boot, or so the shows creators hope.

title: Sean Payton Returns to the Zurich Classic
description: AVONDALE, La.  Two nights before the N.F.L. draft, the banished Saints Coach Sean Payton pulled off a trade. In a swap that involved sleeves of golf balls among other items, Payton swapped his amateur trio, which drew Ricky Barnes at the pairings party, with Ryan Palmers for Wednesdays Zurich Classic pro-am.

title: Ann Romney Discusses Super Tuesday Multiple Sclerosis Scare
description: Ann Romney had a little bit of a scare involving her multiple sclerosis before Super Tuesday, she told Entertainment Tonight in an interview set to be broadcast Thursday evening.

title: Off-Broadway Companies Will Stage World Premieres by Shepard, Hwang and Guare
description: Signature Theater on Thursday announced world premiere productions of plays by Sam Shepard (True West) and David Henry Hwang (Chinglish) during the next 18 months, while another respected Off Broadway stalwart, the Atlantic Theater Company, announced its own world premieres by John Guare (The House of Blue Leaves) and Melissa James Gibson (This) for its 2012-13 season.

title: App Smart Extra: Press Here
description: Ive often written about childrens apps in a variety of contexts, including games, narratives and pure education (like the Barefoot World Atlas for iPad). Occasionally an app crosses over into two or more of those spheres, but too often that ambition muddies the final product.

title: Swashbumblers Roiling Madcap Seas
description: You cant always just say aarrr at the end of a sentence and think that makes everything all right. This is wise advice and not only for pirates and piratephiles of all ages. Its also the closest thing to a lesson  also: pigs are not fruit  in the delightful stop-motion animation The Pirates! Band of Misfits, a story of high-seas silliness from that British national treasure Aardman Animations (Wallace & Gromit). Exquisitely detailed  from its ocean breakers to the wavelike curlicues on a pirates luxurious beard  the movie is a curiosity cabinet of visual pleasures but so breezy and lightly funny that you may not realize at first how good it is. (Youre too busy grinning.)

title: E.P.A. Official Spoke of Crucifying Polluters
description: A high-ranking Environmental Protection Agency official has apologized for remarks he made to subordinates suggesting that the agency crucify some violators of pollution laws to deter others.

title: Now Toting | Hartmann Luggage
description: Lightweight luggage is an obsession for frequent travelers and overpackers alike. I confess: I am both. But I am also a design snob, and if Im going to consider grounding my gorgeous but relatively weighty T. Anthony pieces for whats widely considered some of the lightest luggage around  polycarbonate plastic  it had better look good. Historically, this has been a tall order. The most attractive pieces in this category are often empty boxes inside, while the most practical ones, with zippered pockets and the like, tend to come in colors or exterior patterns that Id rather leave on the baggage carousel.

title: Newt Gingrichs Debt
description: Newt Gingrich is preparing to make the transition from forgotten-but-not-gone to gone-and-hopefully-forgotten by dropping his presidential campaign next week. And hes doing it in good Reagan-and-Bush-era Republican fashion  carrying on about fiscal responsibility while piling up a nice fat budget deficit.

title: Business Day Live | Laura Tyson
description: April 26, 2012  Laura Tyson, former chair of the Presidents Council of Economic Advisers, discusses balancing education costs and job prospects in California.

title: G.R.E. Will Allow Test Takers to Customize Score Reports
description: Students interested in eventually going to graduate and business schools will soon have a chance to put their best G.R.E. scores forward, officials announced this week.

title: TimesCast | April 26, 2012
description: Rupert Murdoch apologizes for the hacking scandal | The Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof on the former Liberian presidents guilty verdict.

title: Banco Espirito Chief to Tender Resignation From NYSE Board
description: Ricardo Salgado, the chief executive of Banco Espirito Santo, Portugals biggest bank, is expected to offer his resignation as a director of NYSE Euronext after failing to garner a majority of shareholder votes.

title: Excerpt: 'Leap of Faith'
description: Raul Esparza and Talon Ackerman in Like Magic, a number from the new Broadway musical at the St. James Theater.

title: Will The Stars Align for Small Nuclear Reactors?
description: A company that wants to build a new kind of nuclear reactor, one small enough that it could be delivered by truck, has found a potential customer.

title: Farewell to Nova Iorque
description: Ken Angielczyk, an assistant curator at the Field Museum of Natural History, is searching for fossils of ancient mammal relatives in northeastern Brazil.

title: Excerpt: 'Don't Dress for Dinner'
description: A scene from the Roundabout Theater Company's production, on Broadway at the American Airlines Theater.

title: Theater Talkback: A Seat at the Table
description: On Monday night, my play The Lyons opened at the Cort Theater on Broadway. Now, Ive been writing plays for almost 30 years and been getting them produced Off-Broadway for 19. So, I guess I cant be shocked that people keep asking me how it feels to have a play on Broadway after all this time.

title: At the Oxygen Upfront, It Was Showtime
description: Most of the upfront presentations made to advertisers by television networks and channels follow the show-and-tell model. One cable channel decided to play up the show.

title: Biden Paints Romney as Out of Touch on Foreign Policy
description: Taking the battle with Mitt Romney to the foreign policy front, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. praised President Obama on Thursday as the man who got Osama bin Laden and painted Mr. Romney as a Cold War relic who would leave American troops stranded in Afghanistan.

title: Oils Dark Heart Pumps Strong
description: The cover of Private Empire, Steve Colls new book about the Exxon Mobil Corporation, is a forbidding black slab. Even the lettering looks dismal. Its the color of a chain smokers lung.

title: Previewing the Patriot League Mens Lacrosse Tournament
description: The automatic qualifier for the N.C.A.A. tournament from the Patriot League will be determined this weekend at Colgate University, with a tournament that is as wide open as ever. With one exception, Colgate, Lehigh, Army, and Bucknell played each other in one-goal games this season (Colgate defeated Army by two goals). The four schools represented are the same four schools that made the league tournament last year, which was won by host Bucknell.

title: Laura Tyson: The Public University Dilemma
description: Laura DAndrea Tyson, a contributor to this blog and an economist at the University of California, Berkeley, spoke with Catherine Rampell about the toll that state cutbacks have taken on public universities. Middle-class applicants are most seriously affected, as they may lack the assets or the financial aid to enroll. Its part of the broader polarization of the United States, she says. Part of the solution might be to raise the sticker price for those who can afford it, in order to subsidize others  but such plans run up against state restrictions designed to ensure the universitys public mission.

title: State Worker Drug Tests Struck Down in Florida
description: MIAMI  A federal court in Miami ruled Thursday that Gov. Rick Scotts order to randomly test a majority of state employees for drugs is unconstitutional, saying there is not a compelling enough reason to do so.

title: Federal Prosecutors Are Said to Be Examining Goldman Banker
description: Federal prosecutors in California are said to be investigating whether an investment banker at Goldman Sachs leaked confidential information about health care deals to the Galleon Group, the defunct hedge fund that was run by Raj Rajaratnam.

title: Study Indicates a Greater Threat of Extreme Weather
description: New research suggests that global warming is causing the cycle of evaporation and rainfall over the oceans to intensify more than scientists had expected, an ominous finding that may indicate a higher potential for extreme weather in coming decades.

title: Wheelies: The Displacement Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Study Sheds Light on How Birds Navigate by Magnetic Field
description: Birds are famously good navigators. Some migrate thousands of miles, flying day and night, even when the stars are obscured. And for decades, scientists have known that one navigational skill they employ is an ability to detect variations in the earths magnetic field.

title: Milan Report | The Wrap-Up, Part II
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Group Buys $6 Million Ad Targeting Obama in Swing States
description: The group Americans for Prosperity just went up with a $6.1 million ad buy in swing states that accuses the Obama administration of squandering American taxpayer dollars on green energy projects, asserting that some of the money actually went to foreign entities. The ad is going up in eight states: Colorado, Florida, Iowa, Michigan, Nevada, New Mexico, Ohio and Virginia.

title: Barclays Capital and Deutsche Bank Pick Up A.I.G. Assets
description: In the latest step toward unwinding the crisis-era bailout of the American International Group, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced Thursday that it had sold a chunk of the Maiden Lane III portfolio to a bidding group that included Barclays Capital and Deutsche Bank Securities.

title: Samuel L. Jackson Was Ready for Some Football
description: One of the sidebars that accompanies this weeks cover story on Samuel L. Jackson is Five Curios, a short list of surprising appearances by the actor. To this mix, lets add another, a curio among the curios: Jacksons promo for Monday Night Football back in 2003. Far as Im concerned, it belongs up there in the pantheon of sublime Jacksonian moments right between Wheres my super suit? (The Incredibles) and Every time my fingers touch brain, Im Superfly T.N.T., Im the Guns of the Navarone  (Pulp Fiction). Many of the Jackson hallmarks are on display: the crazy eyes, the grin of mischief, the escalating intensity, the quick-shift vocal impersonations. And if it lacks swear words  the promo aired on prime-time TV, remember  it compensates with what, when seen today, is a different sort of transgressive thrill, a celebration of footballs skull-crushing essence. Try not to enjoy it when Jackson starts soaring: You want to bury em in the turf. You want em lookin through their earhole! You want to say, I like your teeth  especially the ones scattered around the 20-yard line. You want their mamas to say say: Oh, no, thats not my child! My child has a face!'

title: Early Menopause Linked to Bone Fracture Risk
description: Women who reach menopause early are at significantly greater risk for osteoporosis and bone fracture later in life, a Swedish study has found.

title: On Our Radar: Invasive Tiger Shrimp
description: A rise in sightings of the invasive Asian tiger shrimp off the Atlantic and gulf coasts has government scientists scrambling to figure out the cause and the implications for native fish in those waters. We can confirm there was nearly a tenfold jump in reports of Asian tiger shrimp in 2011, a federal biologist says. [NOAA]

title: Move on Oil Company Draws Praise in Argentina, Where Growth Continues
description: BUENOS AIRES  President Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner of Argentina has incurred the wrath of the European Union by expropriating a controlling stake in YPF S.A., the oil and gas company owned by the Spanish energy giant Repsol, prompting retaliatory salvos in a budding trans-Atlantic trade war.

title: Politicians Find a Way to Agree, and Disagree, on Student Loan Rates
description: Republicans and Democrats agree: nobody wants to see the interest rates of student loans go up this summer. They disagree, however, about how to cover the costs that would keep that from happening, our colleagues Peter Baker and Jennifer Steinhauer report this week.

title: On the Other Hand, It Could Have Been Worse
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Liam Hendriks, a rookie right-handed pitcher for the Minnesota Twins who hails from Australia, faced the Boston Red Sox twice in spring training. He threw five scoreless innings altogether, three perfect ones in a March 16 start at Bostons home stadium, JetBlue Park in Fort Myers.

title: Judge Agrees to Release 2nd Man Held in Rape Case
description: A State Supreme Court judge on Thursday authorized the release, until his trial, of a Brooklyn man who had been jailed for almost a year on charges of rape and sex trafficking, saying that there appeared to be problems with the credibility of his accuser.

title: In Albany, a Bill for Mandatory Kindergarten

description: Units of Brazilian investment bank BTG Pactual rose sharply Thursday, their first day on the So Paulo stock exchange, even as other bank stocks fell.

title: Tone-Deaf Lawyers Jeopardize the Draw Something Game
description: As many Draw Something fans know, this delightful app has become the victim of a very upsetting corporate they ruined a great thing story. But today, Im delighted to be the bearer of good news. After doing a little sleuthing, Ive learned that a happy ending is on the way.

title: Medvedev, Unscripted, Admits Disappointments
description: MOSCOW  During a two-hour interview on Russian television on Thursday, President Dmitri A. Medvedev admitted disappointment over some of the goals of his four-year presidency, saying that his anticorruption drive was stymied because officials are a corporation, and they do not want anyone to meddle in their affairs.

title: Cissy Houston Plans a Book on Her Daughter, Whitney, a k a Nippy
description: Cissy Houston, the gospel singer and mother of Whitney Houston, met with publishers in New York this week to shop a book about her daughter, several people who were in the meetings said.

description: Julie Drizin, the director of the University of Marylands Journalism Center on Children and Families, will not be bringing her children into the office today.

title: Apprenticeship to Chef Meant Only Long Hours and Sub-Minimum Wages, Suit Says

title: For N.F.L. Seeking Specialists, an Army of Extras
description: This years N.F.L. draft is full of elite prospects who have been the topic of constant debate since the college bowl season ended.

title: Pregame Chatter: Kreider Is Relaxed; Callahan Is Healthy
description: Chris Kreider, who scored of the winning goal in the Rangers 3-2 victory in Ottawa in Game 6, showed no signs of rookie nervousness before Game 7. He said he slept great and was ready to go.

description: A former employee of Spitzers Corner, a gastropub on the Lower East Side, is suing the restaurant, which he says hired him for an apprenticeship that required him to work 90 hours or more a week for as little as $2.91 an hour.

title: Rebates for Some Who Buy Own Health Insurance
description: Almost a third of people who bought their own health insurance last year will get rebates averaging $127 because of a requirement in the federal health care law, according to a new report from the Kaiser Family Foundation.

description: While a roundup of all the different cuts of Blade Runner would be able to fill its own retrospective, the Film Society of Lincoln Center is taking a broader approach to a coming tribute to the director Ridley Scott, whose movies have visited the far-flung future, outer space, ancient Rome, not-so-merry olde England and points in between.

title: U.S. Escalates Google Case by Hiring Noted Outside Lawyer
description: Federal regulators escalated their antitrust investigation of Google on Thursday by hiring a prominent litigator, sending a strong signal that they are prepared to take the Internet giant to court.

title: Quandary Considered: Handling Siblings Who Hit
description: This quandary was mine, but far from mine alone: the day-to-day battles among my youngest kids have suddenly veered off into the physical. Nothing too violent; not the daily physical abuse at the hands of an older sibling one reader described in response, but a low-grade background of whacks, pinches and pushes.

There were the remains of room service delivered to her at the Beverly Hilton Hotel: a rolling table draped with a soiled tablecloth on which were a partially eaten hamburger and French fries, a Heineken can, a Champagne glass and a small white vase with purple flowers.

description: The documentary, screening as part of the Tribeca Film Festival, is about young Ethiopian runners.

description: Verizon and AT&T reported their quarterly earnings in the last week, and they told nearly identical stories: Both are making a lot of money just from mobile data  the fees customers pay to reach the Internet over their networks. Some numbers shared by AT&T make it clear why.

title: A Musical Son of the South Is Mourned in Woodstock
description: WOODSTOCK, N.Y.  He was that impossible rarity in modern music, a figure at once indelibly international and utterly local, whose shows in his hilltop barn drew fans and musicians from around the world, as well as the local carpenters, cops and firefighters who were part of his daily life.
