title: Up Front
description: This week, Mohsin Hamid reviews Nell Freudenbergers novel The Newlyweds, about an American man and a Bangladeshi woman who meet over the Internet and, despite the geographic and cultural gulfs between them, decide to marry. Hamid, the author of two novels, is himself a traverser of borders, having grown up mostly in Lahore, Pakistan, where he now lives, with stints in London and the United States. In addition to writing fiction, he is a prolific essayist on culture and politics for publications including The Guardian of London, Time magazine and The New York Review of Books. Im a political animal, he told us via e-mail. How the pack hunts, shares its food, tends its wounded  these things matter to me. So I write about them. Fiction and nonfiction are just two different ways of lying to try to get at truths. Fiction lies by fabricating what isnt there. Nonfiction lies by omitting what is. Doing both is useful: it keeps me aware of sentences, a novelists obsession, and the power of the void that surrounds them, a preoccupation of journalists.

title: Sierra Leone, 10 Years Later
description: Former Liberian President Charles G. Taylor was convicted on Thursday by an international tribunal of 11 counts of planning, aiding and abetting war crimes committed in Sierra Leone. Mr. Taylor, who was found guilty of crimes against humanity and war crimes, including murder, rape, slavery and the use of child soldiers, is the first head of state to be convicted by an international court since the Nuremberg trials.

title: The Conviction of Charles Taylor
description: The Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof on what the conviction of Charles Taylor means for Sierra Leone and for current brutal dictators and warlords.

title: TimesCast | Murdoch Apologizes
description: April 26, 2012  During a second day of questions, Rupert Murdoch described an internal cover-up at The News of the World aimed at hiding the use of phone hacking.

title: Amazons Earnings Decline 35% but Top Forecasts
description: SEATTLE  Investors in many other companies might panic upon hearing of a 35 percent drop in net income. When Amazon.com reported those results on Thursday, its shares went up almost 15 percent in after-hours trading.

title: Homegrown Lineup Strolls Home With a Win
description: Considering who the Mets are and all the nuttiness they have seen, perhaps it was inevitable that on a day they fielded their first homegrown lineup in 41 years they would earn a three-game sweep of the Miami Marlins in a delightful, but entirely dumbfounding, way.

title: Electric East London
description: From fashion and flora to designers and drinks, you can find it here.

title: 36 Hours in East London
description: KNOWN for its cutting-edge bars, offbeat galleries and ethnic restaurants, East London is by far the citys trendiest area (just ask Ralph Fiennes and Keira Knightley, who both live here), crowded with shoppers during the day and clubbers at night. Wear comfortable walking (and dancing) shoes to discover its neighborhoods east of the Tower of London, namely, Shoreditch, Bethnal Green, Hackney Wick and Dalston. Youll find some of Londons best fashion, craft and design businesses, mostly in renovated historic buildings and warehouses off leafy squares and winding streets. Though the current crop of creative merchants echo the areas 18th-century history as a center for silk weaving and furniture making, East Londons artists today hail from anywhere but the past.

title: Former State Senator Is Sentenced to 7 Years in Vast Bribery Case
description: Carl Kruger, the once-powerful New York State senator from Brooklyn who resigned his office in disgrace and pleaded guilty to corruption charges in December, was sentenced to seven years in prison on Thursday by a federal judge in Manhattan.

title: The Never-to-Be Bride
description: I MET Dan, my future husband, in college when I was 20. But we never married. In fact, we were never engaged. Not even close. I say he was my future husband only because he was that important to me.

title: Earnest Sailors Drop Anchor Among the Enemy
description: One of the hallmarks of Whale Wars, the Animal Planet reality series about conservationists doing battle with Japanese whalers on the high seas, is the anonymity of the animal lovers faceless and mostly silent enemy: crouched on the decks of its ships, seen at a distance through the mist and spray.

title: Exhibits From 2 Artists in Their 70s
description: Nothing rewards a provocateur quite like the art world, but not every enfant terrible turns minence grise. Two artists who have made that transition, however, currently have work on view in New York.

title: Senate Passes Reauthorization of Domestic Violence Law
description: The Senate voted overwhelmingly on Thursday to reauthorize the Violence Against Women Act and expand its reach to American Indians and gay, bisexual and transgender domestic abuse victims, after Republicans opted to sidestep an expected partisan brawl.

title: Drawings of Continental Drift
description: At first glance Storied Past: Four Centuries of French Drawings From the Blanton Museum of Art, at the Grey Art Gallery, looks like a dreary affair: a gathering of little-known draftsmen, almost all of them beholden to the Academy. Give it time, though, and like a dull professorial type after a few gin and tonics it may surprise you with sudden flights of vivacity.

title: Stop Fishing for Lunch Dates
description: People often e-mail me saying: Id like to have lunch. Please send me some dates when you are free. This drives me nuts. It assumes that I want to have lunch with them, and puts the responsibility on me to find a date. I miss the old days when people said, Lets have lunch next Thursday, which gave me an out if I wanted one, or the chance to suggest another day if I felt like it. Your thoughts? Susan, Grand Rapids

title: Elbow Surgery Is Likely for Pelfrey
description: Mike Pelfrey is almost assuredly headed for Tommy John surgery in the wake of a magnetic resonance imaging test that revealed a partial tear of the ulnar collateral ligament in his right elbow, a development that could end his career with the Mets.

description: Photographs from Ukraine, Russia, Sierra Leone and Afghanistan.

title: The Medal of Freedom: Civil Rights Activists, War Heroes, Thin Mints
description: The Presidential Medal of Freedom is the highest honor a grateful nation, or at least president, has to bestow on a civilian. And it is a big deal, even bigger than the annual pardoning of a Thanksgiving turkey or the Easter Egg Roll on the South Lawn.

title: Groups Seek Senate Review of Universal-EMI Deal
description: 6:34 p.m. | Updated Opponents of the Universal Music Groups $1.9 billion bid for EMIs record labels are asking the Senate Judiciary subcommittee on antitrust issues to examine the deal, raising the possibility of Senate hearings.

title: A Small-Town Murder by Just the Nicest Guy
description: Bernie, Richard Linklaters gaudily vibrant, at times morbidly funny true-crime story, takes place in the East Texas town of Carthage, which, at the time when sweet Bernie Tiede (Jack Black) murdered sour Mrs. Nugent (Shirley MacLaine), had a population of 6,500. To judge from the movie and the Texas Monthly article that inspired it, nearly everyone in Carthage loved Bernie, including the minister who after the shooting preached that Bernie needs to be with God, and he needs to know that we are with him. The preacher didnt say that Bernie needed to be in heaven to be with God. In the movie, at least, he seems to suggest that Carthage would do just fine.

title: Presidential Medals to Dylan, John Glenn and 11 Others
description: President Obama plans to award the Presidential Medal of Freedom to 13 people, including Bob Dylan, John Glenn, Toni Morrison and John Paul Stevens, the White House announced Thursday.

title: Where Dinosaurs Roar Back
description: SECAUCUS, N.J.

title: Better Chanted Than Read
description: IT starts with a mans voice: Ocean, he intones, stretching the final consonant. Theres an echo, another presence. A woman begins to talk-sing, her vocals growing high and furious, building to a wail; someone pants, more voices appear, everything is louder and more frenzied. A wild, sustained choral shriek. Then, six minutes after it began, the man again: Ocean.

title: Beaumarchais Revamped With Shades Of Revolution
description: The Manhattan School of Music has put on some demanding operas, but nothing as challenging to produce as John Coriglianos Ghosts of Versailles, with a libretto by the playwright William M. Hoffman, which opened on Wednesday night before a sold-out house.

title: Lovebirds in a Predictable Pickle: Silly but So What?
description: At the start of The Five-Year Engagement, Tom (Jason Segel) is about to propose to his girlfriend, Violet (Emily Blunt). He has an elaborate surprise planned, and when it is ruined (by his clumsy eagerness and Violets persistent curiosity), he goes through with it anyway. The romance of the evening is in no way diminished by Violets knowledge of whats coming, and something similar could be said about this movie, directed by Nicholas Stoller from a script he wrote with Mr. Segel.

title: Saving Spains Honor: Atltico and Bilbao Reach Europa League Final

Its 8:40 a.m. on a scruffy stretch of York Avenue between East 76th and East 77th Streets. Now, over porcelain mugs of coffee and plenty of hot milk, the talking can begin.

title: Dance Listings for April 27  May 3
description: Dance

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Silicon Valley Sexism, and Apple After Jobs
description: Here are some of the most interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Thursday. There are more here.

title: In Gramercy, Better Timing for Irish Developer
description: RESIDENTS of the Kips Bay and Gramercy neighborhoods may have thought the ghostly glass building wrapped in scaffolding at the corner of 23rd Street and Second Avenue was another casualty of the global real estate crisis.

title: Who Loses and Who Profits When Sex Is a Commodity?
description: In case you have forgotten, all women are prostitutes, and all men are johns. Strip away the trappings of upscale bourgeois life, and a wife  even an upscale professional wife  is a household slave, expected to cook, clean and take care of the children. Her husband might deign to make love to her after she cooks a fancy dinner for his boss. All it takes for her to keep the peace is some well-timed flirtatious role-playing. But he has to initiate the amorous reward. Sounds very 1970s, doesnt it?

title: Laying the Tracks Others Followed
description: The handsome show of Frank Stellas early paintings at L&M Arts could not be better timed. Abstract art, especially of a Minimalist mien, is on the uptick right now, with a few too many young artists acting as if they have invented the wheel, especially where brushy or severely simplified monochromes are concerned.

title: The $100 Million Question
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Bill Bollinger
description: A look at an exhibition of the artists work at the SculptureCenter.

title: Pirating for the Troops
description: One of the worlds most prolific bootleggers of Hollywood DVDs is a hero to overseas soldiers.

title: Terracotta Warriors
description: Photographs from a new exhibition at Discovery Times Square in New York City.

title: Grading the Graders: Human vs. Robot
description: To the Editor:

title: Sure Bets
description: ODDS are 3-to-1 that when Edvard Munchs Scream comes up for sale at Sothebys on Wednesday night, it will fetch $150 million to $200 million. And theres a 3-to-2 chance that pastel will become the most expensive artwork ever sold at auction, breaking the current record of $106.5 million set two years ago at Christies for Picassos Nude, Green Leaves and Bust. As for who will buy The Scream, bets are 5-to-2 that it will be a Russian, 3-to-1 an Asian or European and 4-to-1 an American. Thats the thinking, anyway, from Ladbrokes, the British bookmaking chain, which has been analyzing the fate of what Sothebys is billing as the most recognizable image in art history after the Mona Lisa.

title: Photo Replay: April 26
description: A view of the day in sports, with tennis in Germany, auto racing in Argentina and soccer in Spain.

title: On the Block
description: A look at some of the artworks up for auction this spring.

title: Spring Auctions
description: Several highly recognizable works up for sale at Sothebys, Christies and Phillips de Pury over the next two weeks.

title: A Murderer Tapping at His Chamber Door
description: Edgar Allan Poe died in Baltimore in October 1849, by most accounts in a state of dissipation and despair. The Raven, a new movie directed by James McTeigue (V for Vendetta; Ninja Assassin), differs from most accounts by imagining Poe in his final days as a heroic crime fighter, tracking down a diabolical serial killer with the tenacious ingenuity of the special agents on Criminal Minds.

title: Life of a Salesman
description: Gonna make a record in the month of May*  well, actually, gonna sell a book publishing Monday. That means a couple of weeks of frantic promotion, starting with All Things Considered tomorrow, This Week and the 92nd Street Y on Sunday, and much much more.

title: Mercedess Trash Talk at IHT Sports Summit
description: ISTANBUL  I was so disappointed when the Turkish Grand Prix was cut from the Formula One calendar this year that I wondered how I would get back to one of my favorite venues for a race: Istanbul. The answer came quickly when the International Herald Tribune decided to hold its inaugural Sports Business Summit in Istanbul.

title: The Guru in the Basement Promises a Journey to ... Something
description: Nobody is gutted in Sound of My Voice, a smart, effectively unsettling movie about the need to believe and the hard, cruel arts of persuasion. But over time the men and women who meet in a mysterious house in an anonymous Los Angeles neighborhood  where they shed their clothes and cleanse their bodies in a ritual  are opened up bit by bit, wound by wound, until theyre sobbing and laughing, their insides smeared across the carpet.

title: How to Apply for a Student Visa to Study in the United States
Machismo, Obtained via Machete
description: Fight until our blood runs out! The heavenly home of our ancestors, here we come! That battle cry prefaces a desperate, suicidal run across a fragile bridge by aboriginal warriors to confront the Japanese Army in the Taiwanese historical epic Warriors of the Rainbow: Seediq Bale. Its words embody the primitive philosophy of warfare glorified by this unabashedly nationalistic film.

title: Secret Service Agents Plea in Colombia Proved True
description: WASHINGTON  In the hours after a Secret Service employee got into a dispute with a prostitute at a hotel in Colombia two weeks ago, high-ranking officials with the agency pored over hotel records.

title: 3 Settings, 3 Countries and the World of Women Who Live by Their Bodies
description: I picked up a client. He was 20 or 21 years old. After he was done with me, I had a one-legged man. After him came an old grandpa with a white beard. Right after the old man, I got another customer. He mishandled me, and I got very angry. I told him, You may never come back to my room. More followed after that, about 10 clients all together.

title: For the Love of the Technology, the Bay Area Is Reinventing Baseball (Again)
description: A decade ago, as portrayed in the book and movie Moneyball, the Athletics put a new spin on the game of baseball through statistics and data. A new generation of baseball executives huddled around computers in Oakland and threw out century-old scouting traditions, relying instead on technology to select undervalued players in the 2002 Major League Baseball draft.

title: Images of a Ballet Company Moving Through History
description: All the words in all the books about any art form are but suggestions of what theyre trying to describe. Theyre useful, but you have to experience the stuff. And thats the worthy pull of Joffrey: Mavericks of American Dance: visions of a company moving through history.

title: His Wig May Be Askew, but This Singer Has Range
description: When Carletta Sue Kay takes the stage, it can take the unin-itiated by surprise. The singer is over six feet tall, with a figure more like a wrestlers than an ingnues, and is typically a mess: wig askew, vintage dress often missing a sleeve or other homemade alterations, red lipstick unevenly applied.

title: One Black Mans Actions as a Piece of Civil Rights History
description: Early in Raymond De Felittas documentary of the 1960s-era South, Bookers Place: A Mississippi Story, a couple of tales are quickly told about black men who were shot or beaten for their transgressions against whites: one for inadvertently brushing his mop against a womans foot, another for touching someones car. The anecdotes lay down the law as it stood shortly before the time Booker Wright, a black waiter, made the fateful decision to explain to a documentary crew for NBC News not only what he served white customers but also how he felt about their varied treatment of him.

title: The N.F.L. Draft
description: The 2012 N.F.L. draft took place at Radio City Music Hall in New York City.

title: The Netherlands: Budget Agreement Meets the European Unions Targets
description: The Netherlands defied expectations of a prolonged budget crisis on Thursday, rolling out an agreement to meet European Union mandates less than a week after a dispute over austerity measures led to the collapse of Prime Minister Mark Ruttes government. That collapse opened the door to elections in September that could help decide the future of the euro. Finance Minister Jan Kees de Jager said the budget deal brought the target for reducing the deficit next year to 3 percent of gross domestic product into sight. Parliament was expected to debate the measures late into the night Thursday, but with the backing of 77 votes in the 150-seat lower house, the budget put forth by Mr. Rutte, who will serve in a caretaker capacity until elections, appeared certain to go through essentially intact. NOS television, the Dutch state broadcaster, said the deal called for a lower mortgage-interest tax deduction, a freeze on public sector wages and increased sin taxes, among other things.

title: Martial Arts Fighter Tackles the Russian Mob
description: Poor Jason Statham. Could we ask for a better action star? More graceful than Steven Seagal, more droll than Jet Li, more charming than Bruce Willis. And, as Transporter 3 proved, more adept at sparring romantically than most. So how dispiriting to see him underserved once again, with a clattery vehicle like Boaz Yakins Safe.

title: City Council Is Set to Encourage Greener Buildings With Zoning Changes
description: New York City is about to update its zoning regulations to catch up with the Bloomberg administrations environmental image and to make it easier for buildings to insulate exterior walls, install solar panels and put gardens on rooftops.

title: Four Young People, One Crime and a Night Gone Wrong
description: Dre (Evan Ross) is a smart, by-the-bootstraps high school senior, someone on his way out of the hood into the bigger world. So when his girlfriend begs him not to hang out with his delinquent buddies, you know that he will and that there will be trouble. Actually, youve already seen the trouble.

title: Starbucks Sales in China Contribute to Earnings Rise
description: The Starbucks Corporation, the ubiquitous coffee company, grew strongly in the quarter that ended April 1, propelled by more traffic in its stores and big increases in sales of its products through channels like grocery and warehouse stores.

title: An Oakland V.A. Official to Address Claim Delays
description: Douglas Bragg, the director of the Department of Veterans Affairss Oakland Regional Office, will appear next month before members of the California Congressional delegation to answer questions about the performance of his office, which handles all disability claims filed by veterans from Bakersfield to the Oregon border.

title: Should Israel Act Alone for Peace?
description: To the Editor:

title: Trailing Torontos War Veteran Turned Bank Robber
description: From its opening shot of a quotation by the Argentine writer Jos Narosky  In war, there are no unwounded soldiers  Citizen Gangster announces its sympathies. Drawing on the exploits of Edwin Boyd, a Canadian World War II veteran who became that countrys most infamous bank robber, this unusually cerebral crime movie chooses psychic pain over public-enemy thrills.

title: N.Y.U.s Expansion Plan, as Seen by Its Leaders
description: To the Editor:

title: Tribeca: War Witch and Una Noche Take Top Prizes at Film Festival
description: War Witch, the director Kim Nguyens feature about a kidnapped African girl who becomes a child soldier, was named the best narrative feature at the 2012 Tribeca Film Festival, and its star, Rachel Mwanza, was named best actress, the festivals organizers announced at a ceremony on Thursday night.Una Noche, a film by Lucy Mulloy about Cuban teens who dream of fleeing Havana for Miami, won the best actor prize, which was split between two of its leads, Dariel Arrechada and Javier Nuez Florin; Ms. Mulloy was also named best new narrative director for the film, which additionally was cited for best cinematography in a narrative feature film. (As was reported earlier this week, Mr. Nuez and another star of the film, Anailn de la Ra de la Torre, disappeared as they were traveling from Cuba to the festival.)

title: A Visit to White House
description: To the Editor:

title: Family of Robert G. Morvillo to Start a Law Firm in His Honor
description: Robert G. Morvillo, the prominent white-collar defense lawyer who died late last year, left behind a legacy of fierce advocacy on behalf of his powerful clients and a family of lawyers to carry the mantle.

title: How to Evaluate Colleges
description: To the Editor:

title: A Beaten Teenager Seeks Solace in Another Species
description: In defiance of its rather twee title, the documentary Dolphin Boy is admirably opposed to mystical pronouncements about the man-beast connection it so carefully records. More grounded in simple observation than in fanciful theories, this effortlessly engaging story of sudden tragedy and halting recovery wisely focuses on the facts and leaves the wonder to the audience.

title: European Regulator Warns Silicon Valley About Privacy
description: The European data protection supervisor, Peter Hustinx, on Thursday urged technology companies to innovate in the area of consumer privacy, saying that lawmakers on the continent would press ahead on a contentious proposed law that would, in part, compel companies to pare down the personal data kept in their digital vaults.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: Attorney General in Mexico Will Investigate Wal-Mart
description: MEXICO CITY  The Mexican government on Thursday stepped up its response to the bribery allegations that have been tied to Wal-Marts breakneck growth here, announcing that the federal attorney generals office would begin an investigation into the companys actions.

title: Warlords Beware
description: It took a decade, but an international court on Thursday convicted the former Liberian president, Charles Taylor, for war crimes and crimes against humanity in Sierra Leones horrifying civil war. This is a historic victory for justice and accountability: the first time a former head of state has been convicted by an international court since the Nuremberg trials after World War II. Mr. Taylor, who will be sentenced in coming weeks, richly deserves this distinction.

title: Underachievers Stumble Into Romantic Bliss
description: Celebrating aimless adults who prefer to sponge off the hard work of others is a dispiritingly persistent trend in American entertainment. In HBOs much-yammered-about Girls, the lead character is stunned when her fed-up parents refuse to donate $1,100 a month to support her two-year quest for self-knowledge, and in The Giant Mechanical Man, underachieving paves the road to romantic bliss.

title: Bands and Pop Singers Join Fight Against  Backpage.com Ads
description: More than a dozen prominent pop singers and rock bands have joined a campaign aimed at forcing The Village Voice to stop running ads on Backpage.com for escorts, strip-clubs and other adult services, a publicist for the campaign said. The list of bands who have signed a petition against the ads includes the former members of R.E.M and the members of the Roots, Alabama Shakes, the Civil Wars and Drive-By Truckers. Among the singers who have lent their support are Alicia Keys, Rosanne Cash and Talib Kweli.

title: Running the World With Eyes Wide Open
description: Jesper Olsen, a 40-year-old from Denmark, runs the equivalent of a marathon most days. He eschews iPods and is on his 25th pair of running shoes as he strings the long runs together in his second run around the world. Call him a real-life Forrest Gump and he playfully rolls his eyes.

title: Making a New Life in a Seamy New York
description: Its almost a disappointment when anyone speaks in Andrew Dosunmus evocative debut feature, Restless City, which could nearly tell its simple story without words. Djbril (Sy Alassane), an aspiring singer and Canal Street peddler, may move through a gray-market immigrant world of pirated CDs and sketchy back rooms, but everyone and everywhere looks fashion-spread terrific, thanks to the serenely muted colors and elegant, wide-screen compositions by the cinematographer Bradford Young.

title: After Quiet Years, British Regulator Gets Tough on Abuses
description: LONDON  Britains securities regulator once had a reputation for taking a light-touch approach to regulation.

title: A Corporate Big Shot With a Sideline in Art Theft
description: Headhunters is the first screen adaptation of a book by Jo Nesbo, the Norwegian novelist best known for his crime series starring a loose-cannon detective. This relentless new film, which does not feature the detective Harry Hole, is ostensibly a stand-alone tale, unless you count the planned American remake. But its justifiably paranoid protagonist suffers enough punishing twists for two or three movies.

title: In Democratic Primary, Taking On a Dallas Institution
description: It takes a lot of nerve to run in a Democratic primary against a 20-year incumbent, especially a Dallas institution like Representative Eddie Bernice Johnson.

title: An Incomplete Justice
description: THE verdict delivered Thursday against Charles G. Taylor for crimes against humanity ends a saga that began on Christmas Eve 1989, when Mr. Taylor and a group of Libyan-trained followers invaded Liberia, igniting a regional conflagration that eventually engulfed parts of Sierra Leone, Guinea and Ivory Coast.

title: In Congress, a Move to Look Into a Medical Debt Collector
description: A California representative is calling for an investigation into Accretive Health, one of the nations largest collectors of medical debt, for potentially violating a federal law that requires hospitals to provide emergency care regardless of citizenship, legal status or the ability to pay.

title: Lousy but Not Lovable Bobcats
description: By every way you can measure, the Charlotte Bobcats are a spectacularly bad team. They spent the last part of their regular season compiling a staggering 23-game losing streak and clinching the N.B.A. record for worst winning percentage. They have lost to good teams by large margins and to mediocre teams by almost-as-large margins. After losing to the Knicks in their season finale, 104-84, on Thursday night, they have not won since March 17.

title: At 92, a Bandit to Hollywood but a Hero to Soldiers
description: MASSAPEQUA, N.Y.  One of the worlds most prolific bootleggers of Hollywood DVDs loves his morning farina. He has spent eight years churning out hundreds of thousands of copies of The Hangover, Gran Torino and other first-run movies from his small Long Island apartment to ship overseas.

title: S.&P. Cuts Its Rating on Spain, Citing Debt
description: Standard & Poors downgraded Spains credit rating on Thursday, saying that the countrys sovereign debt levels were too high and that its banks would need an infusion of aid as the countrys economy contracted.

title: The Reading Renaissance
description: SEATTLE  Satan in Seattle, as the walking wounded of the book business describe Amazon.com, continues to expand from the shores of Lake Union here, with nearly a dozen new office buildings housing the global nerve center of earths largest online retailer.

title: Out With the Old, in With the Inexperienced
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Small Screens, Big Dollars
description: THE annual spring upfronts, when television peddles its wares to Madison Avenue, has a new twist ahead of the 2012-13 season: Media companies that specialize in online video and other digital delights are adding themselves to the lineup of presentations by broadcast and cable TV outlets.

title: How Many Terrorists in This Cell?
description: The young man sat at the defense table behind a great cloud of a beard, an unblinking stone, as his lawyer argued that he was not guilty. Just the victim of desperate criminals, who needed to sell someone to save their own miserable skins, so they ratted out their high school buddy.

title: Hockey Loss Sets Off Slurs, and Boston Asks, Again?
description: BOSTON  The game-winning goal that Joel Ward of the Washington Capitals scored against the Boston Bruins in overtime on Wednesday did two things, both embarrassing to Boston. It knocked the reigning champion Bruins out of the N.H.L. playoffs, and it unleashed a flurry of Twitter slurs against Mr. Ward that summoned an old, familiar image of this city as a den of racist white sports fans.

title: Conference Leaders Agree to Pursue 4-Team Playoff
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla.  College football is on the cusp of a major shift, but for now, the changing language of the games power brokers offers hope to those clamoring for a better way to decide a national champion.

title: Testifying, Murdoch Cites a Cover-Up in Phone Hacking
description: LONDON  Rupert Murdoch criticized many different people for many different things in a morning of scrappy and often blunt testimony before a judicial panel here on Thursday. But in the most explosive criticism of all, he unexpectedly accused at least one former employee of presiding over a cover-up of phone hacking and other dubious practices at The News of the World tabloid.

title: Intrigue in Chongqing
description: St. Louis

title: City Decides to Spare School of Second Chances
description: The schools chancellor, Dennis M. Walcott, retreated on Thursday from a plan to shut down a last-chance high school for students who have dropped out or have failed at traditional schools.

title: Is Our Adults Learning?
description: In 2009, we had a big debate about whether to pass a stimulus package. Many esteemed and/or Nobel Prize-winning economists like Joseph Stiglitz, Larry Summers and Christina Romer argued that it would help lift the economy out of recession. Many other esteemed and/or Nobel Prize-winning economists like Robert Barro, Edward Prescott and James Buchanan argued that positive effects would be small and the package wouldnt be worth the long-term cost.

title: Jaguars Owner Is Subject of Environmental Protest
description: When Shahid R. Khan bought the Jacksonville Jaguars late last year for $760 million, he was portrayed as an American success story: an immigrant who worked at an auto parts plant, later bought it and eventually became a billionaire.

title: Woman, Fighter, Philosopher
description: I first met the renowned Yale professor Ruth Barcan Marcus in the ladies room at the Marlboro Music Festival during the summer of 1977. As a music major in Yale College I had taken only a few philosophy courses, and none with Marcus. But word of the arrival in 1973 of the formidable philosopher had reached even the musty practice rooms in the bowels of Harkness Hall; and I had seen her several times, from a safe distance, on campus. Perhaps because this initial encounter occurred on musical rather than philosophical terrain, I managed to ask the woman adjusting her collar in the mirror next to me whether she was Ruth Marcus, the famous logician. She laughed and said yes, and then asked what I planned to do with my Yale degree. I told her I wanted to go to graduate school in philosophy, but feared that a major in music, rather than philosophy, would be an obstacle. She replied, I dont see why that should stop you.

title: In China, a Fall From Grace May Aid a Rise to Power
description: BEIJING  When Xi Jinping, the vice president of China and its presumed next leader, returned from a crucial image-polishing tour of the United States in February, he faced an even more delicate matter at home.

title: Now Off Case, Judge Weighs In on Dams
description: SEATTLE  A federal judge who spent a decade presiding over one of the most contentious environmental court fights in the Northwest  the fate of endangered salmon in the Columbia River Basin and four hydroelectric dams that interrupt their migration  has said in a recorded interview that the dams should be removed to help the fish.

title: Gingrich Is Quitting the Race (Just Give Him a Little Time)
description: MOORESVILLE, N.C.  Newt Gingrich arrived at the Penske Racing plant here on Thursday accompanied by a large security detail protecting him from a big threat  of rain.

title: ESPN Radio Plans a Move to FM in New York
description: For 11 years, ESPN has built its New York radio outpost at 1050 AM, using local and national shows to challenge the power of the older, more established WFAN, which resides down the AM dial at 660.

title: A Fallen Politician, Sympathetic Unto Himself
description: Save for the fact that he pitied himself far more than you could hope to match, Carl Kruger almost presented a sympathetic portrait of a man consumed with remorse.

title: One Called Upon To Decide
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Not a bad way to work our way into the weekend puzzles. A fresh and crunchy Friday by Patrick Berry, with some lovely new entries, clues tightened up for an end-of-week solve, and enough wordplay to keep any solver happy. Life is good.

title: If You Cant Tell Your Cook From Your Mistress, What Do You Nibble?
description: Can I blame Mark Rylance?

title: Sneaky Preacher, Without a Prayer
description: Say amen, somebody. Or, better yet, just whimper the word. Weve finally come to the end of a hard-run overcrowded spring on Broadway. And here, to sound the final trumpet, is one last musical, a show that appropriately expresses how many a dedicated theatergoer must be feeling right now: plumb tuckered out.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 26, 2012

title: Culture Warriors Dont Win
description: Mitt Romneys apparent nomination proves that Republican voters are more pragmatic and centrist than their reputation suggests. The Republican candidates this year fought a classic political battle. Rick Santorum, Newt Gingrich and Ron Paul campaigned as purists, echoing Henry Clays famous expression from 1844, Id rather be right than president. The realist Romney updated the belief of nineteenth-century partisans that a candidates most important ability is what they called his availability, as in his ability to avail  and prevail.

title: 3 Troopers Are Suspended Amid Sex Inquiry
description: Three New York state troopers were suspended on Thursday without pay amid an investigation into whether one of them had organized parties that might have involved prostitution, according to a statement by the State Police.

title: Senate Votes to Reauthorize Domestic Violence Act
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate voted overwhelmingly on Thursday to reauthorize the Violence Against Women Act and expand its reach to American Indians and homosexuals, after Republicans opted to sidestep an expected partisan brawl.

title: Opening the Broadcasters Books
description: Television stations have been making a lot more money from campaign ads since the Supreme Court helped lift the limits on contributions to political groups. The public, though, has been kept in the dark about how much these groups and the so-called super PACs are spending, and where they are spending it, because the stations dont want to make it easy to find out how much they are being paid for those ads.

title: Death of a Fairy Tale
description: This was the month the confidence fairy died.

title: Student Loan Debate Becomes Election-Year Fight
description: WASHINGTON  The subject of interest rates onsubsidized collegeloans, once reserved for the deep weeds of Congressional committees, has touched off a blazing battle between Democrats and Republicans at a volume usually reserved for debates overtax cuts or immigration.

title: Defense Minister Adds to Israels Recent Mix of Messages on Iran
description: JERUSALEM  One day after Israeli newspapers reported that the nations top general had said economic and diplomatic pressures against Iran were beginning to succeed, his superior, Defense Minister Ehud Barak, said Thursday that the chances appear low that the Iranian government would bow to international pressure and halt its nuclear program.

title: A Year in the Life of Social Security
description: The trustees of Social Security reported this week that absent reforms, the system will be able to pay full benefits until 2033  versus 2036 in last years report  and three-fourths of benefits after that. One of the reasons for the grim new projection is the increase in oil prices, which the trustees assumed are here to stay and will exert a drag on the economy and worker pay for decades to come. Less pay means less tax revenue for the system.

title: Robert Bork, Romney Standard-Bearer
description: Robert Bork has been among the most divisive figures in American law and a right-wing standard-bearer in Republican politics for nearly 40 years. In 1973, when he was solicitor general, he fired Archibald Cox as special prosecutor on the order of Richard Nixon to aid the Watergate cover-up. When Ronald Reagan nominated him to the Supreme Court in 1987, the Senate rejected him by a vote of 58 to 42, the largest margin in American history.

title: Game 7 Worthy of Salute
description: Game 7 lived up to its billing Thursday night at a raucous Madison Square Garden. The Ottawa Senators desperately pressed for an equalizing goal in the third period. The Rangers frantically defended their goal, diving to block each shot. Henrik Lundqvist scrambled from post to post to make acrobatic saves. Each loose puck sparked pitched battles along the boards and behind the nets.

title: Taylors Rule in Liberia
description: Charles G. Taylor, the former president of Liberia and once a powerful warlord, was convicted of abetting rebels who committed war crimes in Sierra Leone in the 1990s.

title: A Glimpse of Nature, No Sunscreen Required
Tribeca: A Protest Over Festival Sponsor Involved in Clearing Occupy Wall Street
U.S. Agrees to Reduce Size of Force on Okinawa
description: WASHINGTON  The United States and Japan have reached agreement on a long-simmering dispute that calls for the American military to reduce the number of Marines on Okinawa by 9,000 and begin returning land to the government there, senior officials announced on Thursday.

title: Romney Uses Cold War Prism, Biden Says in Foreign Policy Attack
description: Shifting the battle with Mitt Romney from jobs and taxes to the safer realm of foreign policy, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. traveled to New York City on Thursday to praise President Obama as the man who got Osama bin Laden and to paint Mr. Romney as a cold war relic who would leave American troops stranded in Afghanistan.

title: After Restful Final Game, Knicks Head to Miami
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  After the tumult and the injuries, the dizzying changes and the wild swings of fate, the Knicks concluded their regular season with a 48-minute exhale, a final chance to breathe before the air gets heavy and the lungs grow tight.

title: With G.O.P.s Ear, Rubio Pushes Dream Act Proposal
description: MIAMI  When Senator Marco Rubio first floated his compromise version of the Dream Act  the bill, now stalled, that would grant some students in the United States illegally a path to citizenship  the chances of reviving the politically charged issue in Congress seemed as dim as the chances of snuffing out attack ads on the campaign trail.

title: All-Spanish Final in Europa League
description: A day after Real Madrid joined Barcelona on the exit ramp out of European competition, two Spanish clubs salvaged a bit of prestige for La Liga by advancing to the Europa League final.

title: House Votes to Approve Disputed Hacking Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Defying a veto threat from President Obama, the House on Thursday passed a bill that encourages intelligence agencies and businesses to share information about threats to computer systems, including attacks on American Web sites by hackers in China and other countries.

title: Pick-by-Pick Analysis: The 2012 N.F.L. Draft
description: Mike Tanier was at Radio City Music Hall covering the 2012 N.F.L. draft. He provided live updates and analysis of all the first-round picks. Add your reactions to the draft in the comments section below and continue reading to see how the draft unfolded.

title: U.S. Sees Positive Signs From China on Security Issues
description: WASHINGTON  When China suddenly began cutting back its purchases of oil from Iran in the last month, officials in the Obama administration were guardedly optimistic, seeing the move as the latest in a string of encouraging signs from Beijing on sensitive security issues like Syria and North Korea, as well as on politically fraught economic issues like Chinas exchange rate.

title: Luck. Griffin. Then It Gets Interesting.
description: The suspense went out of the very top of this years N.F.L. draft long ago, well before the enormous poster of Peyton Manning came crumbling down from Indianapoliss Lucas Oil Stadium this week.

title: Despite Budget Cuts and Base Expansion, Trying to Save Energy
description: EL PASO  Outside a building that provides medical care for wounded soldiers at Fort Bliss, two long, dark lines of hundreds of solar panels stand on supports over the parking lot, moving to follow the sun.

title: On Day of Reckoning, Recalling Horror That Swallowed Liberia
description: WASHINGTON  When I heard the news Thursday that Charles G. Taylor, the former president of Liberia, had been found guilty of war crimes in Sierra Leone, I immediately telephoned one of the people whose life had been ripped apart by his soldiers: my sister Eunice, back home in Liberia.

title: A List of War Crimes in Sierra Leone
description: Charles G. Taylor, from Liberia, was convicted of supporting rebel fighters who committed war crimes in Sierra Leone from 1996 to 2002.

title: Giants Wait Their Turn, Then Grab Running Back
description: The Giants waited through the first round of Thursday nights N.F.L. draft while their division rivals traded to acquire higher picks. When their turn finally arrived, they selected the Virginia Tech running back David Wilson with the 32d and final pick.

title: Irving Millman Dies at 88; Worked to Stop Hepatitis B
description: Irving Millman, a microbiologist whose work led to the creation of a vaccine against hepatitis B that is credited with saving millions of lives, died on April 17 in Washington. He was 88.

title: Corrections: April 27
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Pete Fornatale, a Pioneer of FM Rock, Dies at 66
description: Pete Fornatale, a disc jockey who helped usher in a musical alternative to Top 40 AM radio in New York in the late 1960s and early 1970s, presenting progressive rock and long album tracks that AM stations wouldnt touch and helping to give WNEW a major presence on the still-young FM dial, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 66.

title: Playoff Teams Finish Regular Season Cautiously
description: It took solving a labor dispute to get the N.B.A. regular season started. Then it took a march of survival, for most teams, including many injuries to top players.

title: New North Korean Missile Is Called Into Question

title: Jets Try to Bolster Rush With a Defensive End
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. About 45 minutes after the Jets made their first-round pick on Thursday night, Rex Ryan walked into an interview room wearing a smile as wide as his shirt collar. General Manager Mike Tannenbaum looked over and said, Can anybody tell by Rexs body language whether we drafted offense or defense?

title: Ernest Callenbach, Author of Ecotopia, Dies at 83
description: Ernest Callenbach, the author of the 1975 novel Ecotopia, the tale of an awakening paradise in the Pacific Northwest that developed a cult following as a harbinger of the environmental movement, died on April 16 at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 83.

title: Defenders Journey to Get Back in the Light
description: In the seventh game of the Rangers first-round series in the Stanley Cup playoffs, Marc Staal made his comeback from a severe concussion complete.

title: Hugo Fiorato, Conductor at City Ballet, Dies at 97
description: Hugo Fiorato, a former child prodigy who became the conductor of the New York City Ballet and one of its most enduring influences, died on Monday in Boston. He was 97.

title: A (Free) Cultural Festival Known for Its Hip Quotient Opens in Hong Kong
description: Liberatum has been organizing cultural festivals around the globe for 10 years, and its finally launching its first one in Hong Kong. From Friday through Sunday, the festival will feature panels with the international icons Pharrell Williams and V.S. Naipaul alongside Hong Kong filmmakers, musicians and designers. The program also includes short films by Mike Figgis and Guy Bourdin, as well as a musical performance by the Hong Kong New Ensemble.

title: Elise Testone Is Ousted From Idol on Queen Week
description: Only five contestants were left on American Idol, as Elise Testone, a 28-year-old vocal coach from South Carolina who excels at hard rock, was taken off the show after receiving the fewest votes among viewers of Foxs singing competition.

title: Georgia: One-Year Sentence in Killing
description: A white man who shot to death a 22-year-old black man who had sneaked into his home to party with the homeowners teenaged relative and her younger friend was sentenced to a year in a state detention center and nine years of probation on Thursday, said Hayward Altman, the district attorney for Georgias middle judicial circuit. Mr. Altman originally charged the man, Norman Neesmith, 62, with seven offenses, among them murder and false imprisonment. The charges were reduced in a plea bargain. The parents of the dead man, Justin Patterson, believed the shooting in January 2011 and the sentence were racially motivated. Mr. Altman said the case had elements of self-defense and was complicated by the fact that one of the girls was 14, although she told Mr. Patterson and his younger brother, who was also at the house that night, that she was 18.

title: At a Bronx Vigil Nearly a Year After a Killing, a Man Is Shot Dead
description: Nearly a year ago, Michael Ikoli emerged from his apartment building on Webster Avenue in the Bronx and was shot dead. Wednesday would have been his 25th birthday, and a couple dozen friends gathered in front of his building to pay their respects. They lighted candles, dozens of them.

title: Devils Outlast Panthers in Game 7
description: SUNRISE, Fla.  Put away the streamers and the cake. Martin Brodeurs retirement party is on hold.

title: Obama to Target Colleges That Prey on Veterans
description: They survived insurgents, terrorists and roadside bombs. But President Obama is worried that many military veterans who made it home from the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan are now being targeted by unscrupulous for-profit career colleges.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for April 27  May 3
description: Art

title: Rangers and Devils Replay: Game 7
description: The Rangers eliminated the eighth-seeded Senators from the playoffs with a 2-1 victory. In Sunrise, Fla., the Devils defeated the Panthers, 3-2, in double-overtime.

description: The top picks in this years N.F.L. draft, with analysis by Mike Tanier.

title: U.S. Assets at Work, Unsupervised
description: Most Americans paid no attention last weekend when the International Monetary Fund announced it was well on its way to roughly doubling the money that it can lend to troubled countries  what the organization calls a $430 billion increase in the global firewall, Simon Johnson writes in the Economix blog of The New York Times.

title: Fighting Deflation, Japan's Central Bank Expands Asset Purchases
description: TOKYO  In a closely watched decision, Japans central bank expanded its asset-purchase and loan program Friday by another 5 trillion in a bid to convince investors it remains committed to a recent inflation target and to kick-starting the countrys long-stagnant economy.

title: New York Businessman Alleges Corruption in Indian Defense Deals
description: C. Edmonds Allen, the New York businessman named in a trove of documents that activists India Against Corruption turned over to journalists last night, confirmed he was the source, and said that he worked with India defense dealmaker Abhishek Verma for a decade.

title: Challenge for U.S. After Escape by China Activist
description: BEIJING  The dramatic nighttime escape of a blind rights lawyer from extralegal house arrest in his village dealt a major embarrassment to the Chinese government and left the United States, which may be sheltering him, with a new diplomatic quandary as it seeks to improve its fraught relationship with Beijing.

title: News Quiz | April 27, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: April 27, 1947 | Babe Ruth Is Honored at Yankee Stadium
description: On April 27, 1947, the Yankees hosted Babe Ruth Day at Yankee Stadium. The event was held to honor the ailing baseball star, who was nearing the end of his life because of throat cancer. Ruth, the legendary Sultan of Swat, died a year later at age 53.

description: NEW YORK  If hes to have any hope of keeping his job, President Barack Obama needs to regain the love of young voters. But with 50 percent of Americans under 30 jobless or underemployed, the once cozy relationship is strained.

description: Update |  May 10

title: British Official to Hand Over Messages on Murdoch TV Bid
description: LONDON  A British cabinet minister who has been accused of being too cozy with Rupert Murdochs media empire said on Friday that he would turn over all text messages and e-mails relating to his role in Mr. Murdochs aborted $12 billion takeover bid for BSkyB, Britains main satellite broadcaster.

title: Is TV Too White?
description: Note: The article cited below contains references that may not be appropriate for all students.

description: As families finalize their college choices before the May 1 deadline, finding the best fit for their students and their budgets, weve once again opened our virtual Guidance Office for some advice.

title: Midcentury Ferrari Racecars Headline Sale in Monaco
description: As they did during the bull market of the late 80s, vintage Ferraris have helped lead the recent run-up in prices for collector cars. Models built before Enzo Ferrari, the marques charismatic founder, sold a stake to Fiat in 1969 have primarily driven the trend, especially competition cars with well-documented racing histories.

title: How Richer States Finance Poorer Ones
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

title: All About David Wilson, Giants New Back
description: A player with immense upside but clear deficiencies that might take time for him to address. Heres a one-play taste  (in the video above)  of that upside in terms of agility, balance and functional power. Matt Waldman, The Rookie Scouting Portfolio

title: Danish Police Arrest Three in Terrorism Plot
description: LONDON  The Danish authorities said on Friday that they had arrested three men accused of planning a terrorist operation and of illegal possession of firearms.

title: Hitching a Ride, a Shuttle Puts On an Air Show
description: For the first time, a space shuttle landed in New York City.

title: Giving My Business a Stress Test
description: This post is about cash flow. I have been thinking about it differently this year and trying something new. As I explained in a previous post, last year we slowly built cash through the year, then we had a gusher in December. We ended up with a lot of cash, I gave out big bonuses (mostly to myself), and we still made a healthy profit. That was great! (As Ive written previously, it hasnt always been this way.)

title: Watch out India, Here Comes Oprah (Again)
description: India, brace yourself. You will soon be served up and scrutinized by Americas Midwestern housewives (actually by almost all of Americas housewives). Theres no escape. Talk show queen Oprah Winfrey is again turning her attentions, and cameras, on the subcontinent.

title: Taylor Gone, but Blood Diamonds Are Forever
description: LONDON  Charles G. Taylor, the former president of Liberia convicted of war crimes by an international court on Thursday, fostered a murderous conflict in neighboring Sierra Leone in order to get his hands on blood diamonds mined there by slaves.

title: All About Quinton Coples, Jets New Defensive End

title: Ministers Wrap Up Clean Energy Meeting
description: Their work is not sexy and generates little controversy or media coverage, but a group of energy and environment ministers from 22 countries and the European Union is claiming substantial progress in spreading energy efficiency and more affordable energy around the globe.

title: Obama vs. Romney: Battle of the Fairness Doctrines
description: For months, President Obama has been making the case for what he calls the American values of fair play and accusing Republicans of pushing policies that unfairly benefit the rich over the middle class.

title: Higher Taxes and a Loss in Europe Hurt Ford Profit
description: DEARBORN, Mich.  The Ford Motor Company on Friday said that its profit fell by almost half in the first quarter, as higher taxes and a loss in Europe overshadowed improvements in its North American business.

title: Two Dozen Injured in Bombings in Eastern Ukraine
description: MOSCOW  Several explosions rocked an industrial city in eastern Ukraine on Friday, wounding more than two dozen people in what officials described as a coordinated terrorist attack.

title: The Tangled Tale of Aakash, the Worlds Cheapest Laptop
description: Last October, with much fanfare, the Ministry of Human Resources Development unveiled Aakash, a new, $35 computer built for Indian students. More than six months later, with tens of thousands of university students still waiting, the tale of the Aakash looks a bit like an Indian soap opera, complete with a convoluted storyline, multiple characters, and massive personality clashes.

title: Attacks on Coalition Forces by Afghan Counterparts Are on the Rise
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The toll in a wave of attacks against coalition forces by their Afghan counterparts rose this week, underscoring the increasing tempo of the so-called green-on-blue assaults this year.

title: Arizona Is (Probably) Not a Swing State
description: Two polls released this week show the presidential race essentially tied in Arizona, with one giving Barack Obama a lead of two percentage points and the other giving Mitt Romney a lead of two percentage points. The Obama campaign has suggested it will compete in Arizona, a state it largely ignored in 2008 because it was John McCains home.

title: K.K.R. Posts Slight Gain in Profit Despite Drop in Fees
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts reported that its first-quarter adjusted profit rose nearly 5 percent, as an increase in the value of the investment firms holdings helped offset a drop in deal-related fees.

title: Im Ready for My Close-Up, Mr. Puccini
description: WHEN you walk to your seat in a movie theater for one of the Live in HD broadcasts of the Metropolitan Opera, your experience begins with the sound: the instantly recognizable, immediately comforting hum of instruments tuning and the audience stirring, piped in live from the Met itself.

title: Join Us to Talk About the N.F.L. Draft
description: So the first two picks of the N.F.L. draft went as expected and then the wheeling and dealing got started. On Monday at Noon Eastern time, Judy Battista and Mike Tanier, two of the Timess football writers, will take stock of what happened over the next 220 selections during a Google Plus video hangout. And we would like to invite selected readers to join them in the discussion. If you are available for 30 minutes beginning at that time and would like to hang out with us, use the comment area below to let us know, and include a link to your Google-plus profile page. Please note that to participate in the hangout you will need a Google-plus profile, a video camera-enabled computer, and you will have to follow the Times in Google plus. If you cannot join us at that time, feel free to leave a question you would like answered and be sure to check back on The Fifth Down on Monday afternoon to watch a video of the hangout.

title: Western Conference Playoff Predictions
description: The Western Conference side of the Stanley Cup playoffs resumes on Friday when the Nashville Predators play at the Phoenix Coyotes. The Los Angeles Kings visit the St. Louis Blues for Game 1 on Saturday. After a first round full of tight games, upsets and on-ice mayhem, it would be reasonable to expect more of the same in the second round.

title: Analyzing the Unusual Items in Amazons Earnings
description: Amazon.com reported first quarter earnings Thursday evening that investors and analysts apparently thought a lot of, as the companys shares soared 14 percent after the close of regular stock market trading. But that happened despite some very big, but unexplained, movements in the companys income statement.

title: Daily Report: U.S. Escalates Google Antitrust Case
description: Federal regulators escalated their antitrust investigation of Google on Thursday by hiring a prominent litigator, sending a strong signal that they are prepared to take the Internet giant to court, report David Streitfeld and Edward Wyatt on Friday in The New York Times.

title: Opinion Report: Robert Bork
description: From the editorial page

title: Little Private Equity Firm Gets a Big Spotlight
description: Monomoy Capital Partners, the mid-market private equity firm whose work at Oneida, the flatware giant, was featured in DealBook in January, is quickly becoming the most popular private equity firm in town.

title: European Fiscal Crisis Could Shape Debate Over U.S. Economy
description: Mitt Romney effectively wrapped up the Republican presidential nomination. Newt Gingrich said he would drop out. President Obama stumped through key swing states. But theres a case to be made that the developments this week with the greatest long-term meaning for American politics took place across the Atlantic, not in Washington or New Hampshire or Iowa.

title: Daily Activity Tied to Lower Alzheimers Risk
description: Higher levels of daily physical activity are associated with a decreased risk of Alzheimers disease, new research suggests.

title: Zipping Through Airport Security
description: When I went through security at the Las Vegas airport last week, you could have knocked me over with a feather. The Transportation Security Administration guy told me not to take off my coat, my shoes, my belt, my watch. Huh? I said. I reached down to pull my laptop out of my bag. No, you can leave that in there, he said.

description: TOP STORIES

description: The economic recovery slowed more than expected early this year, raising fears of a spring slowdown for the third year in a row and giving Republicans a fresh opportunity to criticize President Obamas policies.

description: But only because some people want it to be confusing.

title: Lazard Revenue Rises, as Expenses Crimp Profit
description: Benefiting from an increase in advisory mandates, Lazard posted a 9 percent rise in revenue for the first quarter, while expenses weighed on profit.

title: Fox Renews Fringe, Defining Ratings Success Down
description: The Fox network announced Thursday night that it would renew the series Fringe for a final, shortened season of 13 episodes  thereby establishing a new precedent for what constitutes success in television.

description: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first several paragraphs of the Well blog post, Should Your Dog Be Watching TV?

description: Directed by: Haley Wollens; Produced by: Maya Rose & Jude Mc; DP & Editor: Jude Mc;Animation: Andreas Nout Schmidt

description: Update | Aug 19:  This contest is now over, but you can read the work of all our winners here.

title: Is Kim Kardashian the Equal of Paul McCartney? Only on 30 Rock
description: Among the traditions of the 30 Rock live episode, which that NBC comedy attempted for the second time in its history on Thursday, is to switch some of the celebrity cameos between performances of the show for East Coast and West Coast audiences.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Google in the Spotlight, and New Yorkers 2 Dots on Top
description: The Federal Trade Commission is hiring an experienced litigator as part of its antitrust investigation of Google and its search engine, David Streitfeld and Edward Wyatt report. The hiring of Beth A. Wilkinson, a former Justice Department prosecutor, is a strong indication that the government is considering taking the case to court, which would be the biggest government-tech industry showdown since the Microsoft case 14 years ago.

title: Taylors Trial and the Tribulations of Justice
description: On Thursday, a special panel of judges in The Hague found Charles Taylor, the former president of Liberia, guilty of aiding war crimes in Sierra Leone. Hailed by some as a victory against impunity, the historic verdict is also raising concerns about international criminal justice.

title: Morning Buzz, April 27: The Rise of 1 World Trade Center
description: Good morning. Today will be partly cloudy, with winds reaching 24 m.p.h. and a high of 56 degrees.

title: For Back Pain, Steroid Shots No More Effective Than Placebo
description: A randomized trial of steroid injections for back pain has shown that they are no more effective than a placebo.

title: Image of the Day: April 27
Nomuras Profit Jumps 86% in First Quarter
description: The Japanese bank Nomura Holdings reported an 86 percent rise in its net profit for the first three months of the year, as the Asian firm benefited from stronger trading commissions and the sale of mutual funds in its domestic market.

title: The Sun Shines Today for New Annie Star
description: Eleven-year-old actress Lilla Crawford will star as musical theaters most famous orphan in this falls Broadway revival of Annie, the producers said on Friday. Ms. Crawford, a Los Angeles native, made her Broadway debut last year playing Debbie in the cast of Billy Elliot before it closed this winter. She was selected to play Annie after a nine-month star search that included 5,000 auditions across the United States and via online video.

title: Markets Shrug Off a Disappointing G.D.P. Number
description: The Standard & Poors 500-stock index capped its best week in a month as retailers surged to a record and improving corporate earnings and consumer confidence tempered lower-than-forecast economic growth.

title: A Humble Letter
description: Dear Diary:I started a long teaching career at Grover Cleveland High School in Queens, more than a little awed by the fact it was bigger than my hometown. At that time, the federal government made money available for field trips and, upon discovering none of my 9th or 10th graders had ever been on a field trip or even traveled much in the city, I set about planning to take them to what I considered its most beautiful place, the Cloisters.

title: The Get | Mannins Monogram Pendant Necklace
description: Theres a lot of uncertainly surrounding Emily Blunts character, Violet, in the new romantic comedy The Five-Year Engagement, which opens in theaters today. Whats solid: the monogram necklace she wears in every scene, from her engagement to Tom (played by Jason Segel) to their wedding day. Designed by Suzanne Donegan, the Los Angeles-based jeweler behind the elegant and understated fine jewelry line Mannin, Blunts pretty gold pendant is as symbolic as it is stylish. (A newly affianced woman wearing a keepsake that bears what will soon be her maiden names initials? One doesnt need a psychologist to connect those dots.) The pendant has everlasting value, Donegan says. It feels good to wear, emotionally and physically. Till death do us part.

title: Looking for the English on London Menus
description: MOCK English food all you like. But the local food thing is almost as inbred in England as it is in France; it just sometimes hides behind poverty, war or a fatal attraction to (as they call it) America. Today there are literally dozens of restaurants featuring not only fish from the Channel, the North Atlantic and the North Sea, but local beef and pork. Meanwhile, there is lamb from Wales and Scotland, and produce from everywhere.

title: What Were Reading
description: The Los Angeles Times: Fascinating piece by Jonathan Gold suggesting that the 1992 riots in Los Angeles played a crucial role in shaping the citys strong, decisive restaurant culture.  Eric Asimov

title: New Bankruptcy Documents Reveal Outsize Pay at Lehman Before Collapse
description: It is no secret that Richard S. Fuld Jr., the former chief executive of Lehman Brothers, and his fellow officers earned hundreds of millions of dollars in the years leading up to the banks collapse.

title: A Few Good Spots for a Spot of Tea
description: WITH Queen Elizabeths Diamond Jubilee coming up in June and the Olympics just around the corner, what better way to celebrate all things English than to experience the most traditional of Britains rituals  afternoon tea?

title: My London, and Welcome to It
description: IF youve saved this article for your long-planned trip to London, and youre now reading it for the third time, circling Heathrow, well, Im sorry. Youre probably still up there because the queue at passport control has become mutinous. Theyre snaking out onto the runways  grim, silently furious visitors, unable to use their phones, forbidden from showing anything but abject acquiescence to the blunt instrument that is the immigration officer at the distant desk.

title: 11 Olympics, and Counting
description: GEORGE REED-DELLINGER watched his first Olympics on television in 1960 when he was 13. Sixteen years later he saw the Montreal Games live. To be there in person, theres nothing like it, he said. Im getting goose bumps just thinking about it.

title: A Buzz in Bermondsey
description: A 58,000-square-foot art space, a 95-story skyscraper and other attractions are sending a charge into this London neighborhood.

title: Choice Tables, London
description: Mark Bittman went hunting for English cooking in London. Heres a taste of what he found.

title: School Aide Accused of Abuse Is Freed, but Investigation Continues
description: 1:54 p.m. | Updated  A teachers aide accused of molesting an 8-year-old girl was freed on Thursday night after the Manhattan district attorneys office deferred prosecution of him, an official there said.

title: At Englands Edge
description: Top-shelf art and a dramatic seaside setting lure visitors to remote St. Ives.

title: Who Made That Mason Jar?
description: Before a New Jersey-born son of a Scottish farmer named John Landis Mason patented his jar in 1858, home-food preservation was a tricky affair. Modern heat-based canning, pioneered by a Frenchman in 1806, was too cumbersome for most home cooks, many of whom relied on cork-and-wax contraptions to seal food, often imperfectly, into vessels whose opaque walls rendered the contents invisible.

title: Why Afghan Women Risk Death to Write Poetry
description: In a private house in a quiet university neighborhood of Kabul, Ogai Amail waited for the phone to ring. Through a plate-glass window, she watched the sinking sun turn the courtyard the color of eggplant. The electricity wasnt working and the room was unheated, a few floor cushions the only furnishings. Amail tucked her bare feet underneath her and pulled up the collar of her puffy black coat. Her dark hair was tied in a ponytail, and her eyelids were coated in metallic blue powder. In the green glare of the mobile phones screen, her face looked wan and worried. When the phone finally bleeped, Amail shrieked with joy and put on the speakerphone. A teenage girls voice tumbled into the room. Im freezing, the girl said. Her voice was husky with cold. To make this call, shed sneaked out of her fathers mud house without her coat.

title: So Long, Farewell
description: After reading The Ethicist, I started a feature in my high-school newspaper called The Moralist. But I feel conflicted offering advice that I myself would be unable to follow. I feel even worse when others comment on this contradiction. Under the assumption that nobody is perfect, how do you reconcile your human faults with the guidance you dispense in your column? LARRY MILSTEIN, SCARSDALE, N.Y.

title: Gabriel Kahane Is a One-Man Cultural Cuisinart
description: The concert was over, and Gabriel Kahane was standing in his dressing room at Carnegie Hall, dripping with sweat. He had soaked through the T-shirt he performed in  a deep V-neck with Maybe I should call you when I get back from New York written on it in a loopy script  and his mop of curly hair was matted down.

title: After the Agony of Youth, the Ecstasy of Surfing
description: When I was 8, my parents divorced and my mother married a man whose career took us from Washington to Melbourne Beach, a town on the Space Coast of Central Florida, where I learned to surf.

title: St. Ives, Where Art Meets the Ocean
description: SPRING colors glowed: robins-egg blues, daffodil yellows and succulent greens balanced by far-off reflections from the sand and surf. Whenever I stopped for directions on the road leading out of St. Ives, about five and a half hours from London, another broad Cornish accent encouraged me to continue farther up the hill, until I finally reached the gates of the Leach Pottery, the historic ceramics studio founded there in 1920.

title: The Shark Jumper
description: What struck me most about your new memoir, My Happy Days in Hollywood, in which you recount creating shows like The Odd Couple and Happy Days, is that you still talk to your sister Penny. It sounds as if she made your life hell during Laverne and Shirley.  Yeah, that was my worst show experience. The 70s were druggy years on a lot of shows. It was just a mess, but of course I still talk to her. I dont think you can tell your family that you cant come in the house. Ive always tried to make people happy  the only one I totally didnt was my sister. Thats one of the reasons I did Beaches. Women say things to each other, and the next day they go shopping. Men say things to each other, and they dont talk for 30 years.

title: My Son Went to Heaven, and All I Got Was a No. 1 Best Seller
description: At 3 years 10 months, Colton Burpo was a sunny child, a preachers son certain of his faith and his eternal fate. Then his appendix burst, and as doctors failed to figure out what was wrong with him, he lay in a hospital bed until his father, Todd, saw the shadow of death cross his face. I recognized it instantly, Todd, a pastor, recalls. With Coltons face covered in death, Todd and his wife, Sonja, took the boy to another hospital, where he was wheeled into surgery. Hes not in good shape, the surgeon said. As Colton screamed for his father, Todd fled, locked himself in a room and railed at God.

title: The Steinway Way
description: Inside the piano factory.

title: The 4.15.12 Issue
description: The New York Times published a swell piece that, as such pieces must, made it clear that Caro is the most unusual and perhaps the best biographer of our age. If it is madness to spend nearly 40 years writing about L.B.J., then it is a special and useful madness. . . . The Years of Lyndon Johnson has become such an unusual quest that the obsession gains value independent of the finished product. Actually, that should be published product, not finished. Caro never finishes a book; he has it taken away from him. Eventually.

title: Amid Shouts of Hecklers, Barclays Board Apologizes to Shareholders
description: 10:36 a.m. | Updated

title: J. Crew Goes Hardcore
description: Surely somebody has noticed that the old 9:30 Club building in Washington, D.C., is soon to be a J. Crew store. Surely someone will claim this is somehow ironic, that the club that fostered the all-ages hardcore scene of Minor Threat, Government Issue and Fugazi will soon sell pairs of $140 Caf Capri pants in geranium lace. I dont see the big deal. But I worry about the smell.

title: Parental Quandary: A Daughter Who Is Overweight, and Unaware
description: This weeks parental quandary comes from a father whos intent on not becoming one of the parents Dr. Catherine Musemeche castigates for allowing their childrens weight and health to reach a point where gallbladder removal is the next obvious step. He wants to help his overweight 12-year-old daughter to change her lifestyle, and the numbers on the scale  but as far as he can tell, his daughter hasnt noticed that she has a problem.

title: An Introvert Steps Out
description: I awoke one January morning from uneasy dreams to find myself transformed. For seven blissful years I had spent my time reading, writing and researching a book about introversion. But the publication date had arrived, the idyll was over and my metamorphosis was complete. I was now that impossibly oxymoronic creature: the Public Introvert.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE COMPLETE POEMS,  by Philip Larkin. Edited by Archie Burnett. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $40.) The 90 pages of poems collected during Larkins lifetime, on which his reputation rests, are joined by others published and unpublished and by lengthy commentary.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE TRINITY SIX,  by Charles Cumming. (St. Martins Griffin, $14.99.) Cummings thriller posits a sixth double agent among the notorious spies from Trinity College, Cambridge, who infiltrated British intelligence and betrayed their country to the Soviet Union during the cold war. Convinced that the sixth spys death had been faked by MI6, Cummings hero, a rakish professor of Russian history, becomes enmeshed in a battle between Moscow and London.

title: Unreconciled
description: Not shy of stepping straight into demanding terrain, Patrick Flanery sets his first novel, Absolution, in post-apartheid South Africa, where the horrific injustices of the past leak unavoidably forward. The end of apartheid may have put an end to state-sanctioned violence, but it signaled the beginning of an epidemic of a more personal kind of violence  a reactive, frustrated, untargeted revenge.

title: Mythic Passions
description: To the long catalog of odd hybrids that inhabit Greek myth  the half-human, half-equine centaurs, the birdlike Harpies with their human faces, the man-eating Scylla with her doglike nether parts  we may now add Madeline Millers first novel, The Song of Achilles. In it, Miller has taken on an (appropriately) heroic task: to fashion a modern work of literature out of very ancient stories  specifically, the tale of the Greeks at Troy, one of the oldest and most seminal of all legends in the Western tradition. The idea of recasting the Greek classics began with the ancients themselves; Virgils Aeneid is, in many ways, both a rewriting of and a commentary on the Homeric epics. More recently, it has challenged ambitious writers like Mary Renault, whose 1958 novel The King Must Die brilliantly reimagined the Theseus legend as narrated by the hero himself, and David Malouf, whose terrific 2009 novel Ransom invents a moving episode toward the end of the Iliad. But in the case of Miller, who earned undergraduate and graduate degrees in classics at Brown, the epic reach exceeds her technical grasp. The result is a book that has the head of a young adult novel, the body of the Iliad and the hindquarters of Barbara Cartland.

title: Social Networks of Disease
description: In Partner to the Poor, the medical anthropologist Paul Farmer writes that the failure to contemplate social and economic aspects of epidemics stunts our understanding of them. To this one might add: And hinders our ability to contain and defeat them. Craig Timberg, a journalist for The Washington Post, and Daniel Halperin, an epidemiologist and medical anthropologist at the University of North Carolina, have collaborated on Tinderbox precisely to explore these very aspects of the AIDS epidemic in Africa. They set out to identify why AIDS emerged when it did; why Africans were so disproportionally affected; and why some countries have succeeded in reducing infection rates while others have not.

title: Mean Kids
description: Bully. Such a poisonous word for those of us who endured one. Tormentor feels more appropriate. What drives a person to torture another? To make life intolerable, until the bullied, dreading the thought of one more vicious homeroom encounter, can only wonder: Why is he doing it? When will it end? Will I make it through high school alive?

title: The Dispossessed
description: When Thomas Bayly was a little boy, snuggled in his housekeepers lap, he asked her why she was called Hatties Mary. She told him it was her slave name and shed chosen to keep it as a way of always having her mother with her. Then he asked her what happened to her mother, and she answered that there are some questions you should never ask. You should never ask a prisoner what he did to get put in jail, never ask a widow whether she gets lonely in bed, and never ask a freed slave what happened to her family. Thomas was perhaps 4 when she gave him these answers, and he retained them until he could make sense of them, one by one.

title: Breaking Faith
description: From Gods Controversy With New England, Michael Wigglesworths 1662 call to repentance, to the latest campaign autobiography by a presidential aspirant, the jeremiad has been one of the most durable literary forms throughout American history. Typically, the author identifies some golden age, one just now dissolving in the rearview mirror; recounts the slippery path of declension; and then prescribes an amendment of ways in order to avert further disaster.

title: The Secret of Our Non-success
