description: Disappointing GDP number  were not growing fast enough to make any significant headway on reducing the output gap  but hey, no need for further Fed action.

title: A Great Awakening
description: Secular Americans worst fears have come true: there is now scientific evidence that evangelical churches brainwash believers. They dont merely teach that Adam and Eve actually existed and that gay marriage is an abomination. They change the way their members brains work. But T. M. Luhrmann, a psychological anthropologist at Stanford, argues that this is not as insidious as it sounds. On the contrary, mental conditioning has a noble lineage in the history of religion, and even (or especially) in this modern age, it can help humans flourish. When God Talks Back explains how rational people living in the 21st century can believe that God speaks to them  and why the rest of us should take them seriously.

title: Playoff Preview: Eastern Conference
description: If the eight teams that qualified for postseason play out of the Eastern Conference seem familiar, that is because all eight also made it last season. The Indiana Pacers were the biggest movers, improving from No. 8 last season to No. 3 this season, but many of the story lines remain the same in a conference dominated by the Chicago Bulls and Miami Heat.

title: Drawn Together
description: If one is at first glance tempted to dismiss Alison Bechdels Are You My Mother? as a glorified comic strip, one would be wildly and woefully misguided: it is as complicated, brainy, inventive and satisfying as the finest prose memoirs.

title: Operation Anthropoid
description: The nameless narrator of HHhH has serious misgivings about the novel he is writing. Like Laurent Binet, the books French author, he has spent years examining the murder of the SS general Reinhard Heydrich in Prague in 1942 with a view to retelling the story as a thriller. But now he decides it is dishonest to invent descriptions, dialogue, thoughts and feelings on a subject as serious as this. The best he can do, he concludes, is to provide a running commentary on the truth (or otherwise) of what he is writing. I just hope that, however bright and blinding the veneer of fiction that covers this fabulous story, he writes, you will still be able to see through it to the historical reality that lies behind.

title: Inside the List
description: SONGSTRESS: Carole Kings rock n roll memoir, A Natural Woman, is at No. 11 in its second week on the hardcover nonfiction list. As famous singers go, King has always seemed exceedingly nice  more Janis Ian than Janis Joplin  and her books humble granola-and-chardonnay prose is about as earnest as youd expect from the songwriter behind Youve Got a Friend. But Kings best melodies often have a dark edge, and its detectable in her autobiography too, especially in stories about her four failed marriages. One husband lost his mind to hallucinogens, and another beat her repeatedly before dying of a cocaine overdose. In hindsight, King writes, I probably should have asked Rick these two questions: Why are you living in a van? and Are you by any chance psychotic?  The music gossips not bad, either. In 1976 King and a boyfriend were watching Taxi Driver on the Upper East Side when King ran into Yoko Ono in the movie theater restroom. Ono invited the pair to spend the rest of the evening at the palatial apartment she shared with John Lennon  who had spurned King at their only previous meeting, 11 years earlier. Now she finally had a chance to ask him why. Its because I was intimidated, he said. No hard feelings, right? This is Carole King were talking about: definitely, no hard feelings.

title: Wells Fargo to Buy Prime Brokerage Firm
description: Wells Fargo took its first step into prime brokerage on Friday, agreeing to buy the midsize Merlin Securities.

title: Agency Upgrades Investigation of 63,000 Ford Freestar Minivans for Rust Condition
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has intensified an investigation into corrosion on about 63,000 Ford Freestar minivans and its Mercury equivalent, the Monterey, from the 2004 model year. The agency suspects that the condition might prevent a third row of fold-down seats from being locked in the upright position.

title: Some Favorite Urban Oases
description: In a post yesterday about the community-minded priorities, adjustments and sacrifices of oft-derided urbanites, I mentioned Central Park, but I didnt really get into its greatness. And I wont here, because Ive neither the time nor the space. Id need weeks, months, years. And Id need hundreds of thousands of words, so infinite are the parks glories and so big is my love for it. A blog post cant accommodate that.

title: Higher Bail in Shooting Is Rejected, for Now
description: A Florida judge on Friday rejected a prosecutors motion to increase bail for George Zimmerman, the man charged in the shooting of Trayvon Martin, after his lawyer disclosed that Mr. Zimmerman had received more than $200,000 from a legal defense Web site he established.

title: The Temperatures Rising (No Sweat)
description: CHET WALKER is standing before a room full of dancers, adroitly tossing a black baton from hand to hand. His disciples arent having such an easy time. Were having our first day with canes, Melissa Spengler, Mr. Walkers stage manager, whispers. There may be some crashing.

title: London Underground | Mass Observation
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Crucial to Romney, Floridas Latino Voters Are Wary of Him, Too
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla.  If Mitt Romney is to overcome his problem with Hispanic voters, he is going to have to start by changing a lot of minds in central Florida.

title: Bribes Without Jail Time
description: As reported in a front-page article in The New York Times this week, the Wal-Mart Mexican bribery scheme has all the makings of a gripping criminal prosecution: millions of dollars in illegal payoffs to Mexican government officials and evidence of a cover-up scheme that went all the way to Wal-Mart headquarters in Bentonville, Ark.

title: S.&P. Downgrades Nokias Bonds to Junk
description: 12:27 p.m. | Updated Adding Nokias response and information on its earnings.

title: Collect Call | Gray Foy and Joel Kayes Eight Rooms of Wonder
description: Two friends and collectors, compulsive accumulators both, live among eclectic treasures in their 57th Street apartment.

title: With Prison Ministry, Colson Linked Religion and Reform
description: Since the 1960s, prison reform has been seen as a leftist cause, Robert Perkinson, a historian and the author of Texas Tough: The Rise of Americas Prison Empire, said this week. But it used to be a Christian cause, and Colson played a big role in bringing prison reform back to Christian conservatism.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Despite the chill in the air, spring is surely here as perennial food markets bloom again for the season: With its penchant for all things artisanal, the Hester Street Fair, at Essex and Hester Streets on the Lower East Side, reopens on Saturday, bringing together food vendors (from Lukes Lobsters and Prohibition Bakery to Pies n Thighs and Ample Hills Creamery), indie designers, yogis and more. The fair will continue through October on Saturdays from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Also making its debut for the year is the New Amsterdam Market, at the South Street Seaport on South Street near Peck Slip, on Sunday from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. A bread pavilion featuring more than a dozen bakers, all of whom use local flour, helps kick off the seasons first market. Its opening weekend for the food vendors parked at the Red Hook ballfields, located near the corner of Bay and Clinton Streets in Red Hook, Brooklyn. Much of the Latin American fare is sold from 9 a.m. to 9 p.m. on Saturdays and Sundays.

title: The Service-Sector Mystery
description: The G.D.P. figure for the first quarter  growth at an annual rate of 2.2 percent  is disappointing, even if it could reflect cautious estimates that will be revised in coming months as more data comes in.

title: Morning Walkabout: 4/27
description: Casino Company Gambles on Macau Galaxy Entertainment plans to spend more than $2 billion on the second phase of its resort in Macau, the worlds largest gambling destination. It is projected to open in 2015, making it the next casino to be completed there. (Reuters)

title: Deals and More Deals
description: You do have to hand it to the N.F.L. It could have simply sat back on its laurels, gloating in its were-the-most-popular-league superiority, basking in the prime time television spotlight on its draft, which is really a non-event once held in a smoke-filled room in a basement somewhere. But somehow, against all entertainment odds, the league managed to produce something that turned into a cross between reality TV and The Price is Right.

title: Book Review Podcast
description: This week, Nell Freudenberger discusses The Newlyweds, her new novel; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; T. M. Luhrmann talks about how evangelical Christians relate to God; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: Friday Reading: Student Loan Debate Becomes Election-Year Fight
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Business Day Live | April 27, 2012
description: Who is held responsible under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act? Google's Chade-Meng Tan on compassion in the corporate world and how equity research has evolved since the financial crisis.

title: Business Day Live: Bribes Without Jail Time
description: Who is held responsible under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act? And, Googles Chade-Meng Tan on compassion in the corporate world and how equity research has evolved since the financial crisis.

title: On Our Radar: A Hard Look at Exxon Mobil
description: In a review in The Times, Dwight Garner praises Private Empire, Steve Colls new book on Exxon Mobil, as meticulous, multi-angled and valuable as well as impartial, although he finds that it has few peaks and valleys emotionally. He says it is especially interesting on the subject of Exxons s relationship with the George W. Bush administration. [The New York Times]

title: Playoff Preview: Western Conference
description: All that was old was new again, with the San Antonio Spurs leading the way in the Western Conference along with stalwart playoff teams like the Los Angeles Lakers and Dallas Mavericks while Chris Paul proved that he can make any team a contender. The traditionally stronger conference may lack the star power of the East, but it more than makes up for it in overall quality.

title: A Consensus Begins to Emerge on Derivatives in Bankruptcy
description: Derivatives are contracts, but they are not treated like other contracts when one party enters an insolvency proceeding.

title: Collect Call | Gray Foy and Joel Kayes Eight Rooms of Wonder
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Bob Dylan and Toni Morrison to Receive Presidential Medal of Freedom
description: Nearly 50 years after he sounded Chimes of Freedom on one of his earliest folk-rock albums, Bob Dylan, the mercurial pop troubadour, will be rewarded with a Presidential Medal of Freedom, the highest civilian honor given by the United States, alongside such noteworthy figures as Toni Morrison, Madeleine Albright, John Glenn and John Paul Stevens.

title: John Thain, Grade A Dad
description: John A. Thain, the former chief executive of Merrill Lynch, did a less-than-ideal job parenting Merrill through its 2008 merger with Bank of America. (Remember the $35,000 commode on legs?)

title: A Battered City, Through Local Lenses
description: AFTER decades of decline and neglect and the exodus of more than half of its population, Detroit now owns a cityscape that is often described as post-apocalyptic. Abandoned prewar skyscrapers, immense dilapidated factories, downtown streets devoid of people, entire neighborhoods nearly vacant and returning to brush: all provide epic vistas of blight, warning about the fickle nature of capitalism.

title: Four Bowls of Pho
description: Diners who love pho (pronounced fuh) know the Vietnamese soup and noodle dish is all about the flavorful, meaty broth, served hot, hot, hot. But this week, the Recipes for Health columnist Martha Rose Shulman has found a way to capture the flavors of pho in a vegetarian broth. The recipe retains the traditional spices of pho without using meat. She writes:

title: When Is a Bad Mother a Criminal?
description: From the Times Magazine: In Alabama, exposing a fetus to a controlled substance, chemical substance or drug paraphernalia is a crime. Amanda Kimbrough tested positive for methamphetamine after her son was born prematurely and was sentenced to 10 years in prison following his death. Reasonable response to a mother who uses while pregnant, or pregnancy police taken to the farthest extremes?

title: For Runners, a Lift From Warren Buffett
description: Air Jordans have been around for decades for fans of the basketball legend. But for disciples of Warren E. Buffetts value investing, there has never been a shoe that captures their hero  until now.

title: The Munchkins Are a Problem: Technical Difficulties
Whos Paying for Those Ads?
description: Since the nations broadcasters refuse to fully disclose how much theyre making from campaign spending, the Federal Communications Commission hashad to force them into accepting digital-age standards for transparency. The commission voted 2-to-1 this morning to require television stations to post information about campaign ads on a national database.

title: Margaret & Tucker
description: In this user-generated video, Margaret and Tucker tell the story of how they met through a mutual friend and their first awkward date that they both agreed to put behind them.

title: A Forlorn Birdbath, Right in City Halls Backyard
description: This ones for the birds. The New York Times reported on Monday that standing water  in a puddle or even a birdbath  can subject the offending property owner to a fine of up to $2,000. Its a violation of the New York City health code aimed at combating mosquitoes that carry West Nile virus.

title: The South, the War and Christian Slavery
description: In the minds of many Southerners, the capture of New Orleans on April 25, 1862, by Union forces was more than simply a troubling military loss. It also raised the disturbing possibility that divine punishment was being inflicted on a spiritually wayward and sinful Confederacy.

title: A Few Good Lawyers
description: BILIN, West Bank  Earlier this month, I finally watched The Law in These Parts, a documentary by the Israeli film director Raanan Alexandrowicz, at the 7th International Conference for Popular Resistance. The film describes the legal system that Israel has applied in the Palestinian Occupied Territories since 1967, and it does so exclusively through interviews with members of the Israeli military legal corps who wrote and implemented the system.

title: Wedding Q. and A.
description: If in Doubt, Send an Invitation Anyway

title: Off the Charts: Working Off a Housing Oversupply
description: A major difference between the recovery from the 2007-9 recession and previous recoveries is that residential construction, usually a major contributor to recovery, has contributed very little. In part, that is because the homebuilding industry was a victim of past recessions but a major cause of the most recent one. Overbuilding, brought on by easy credit, left the economy vulnerable. Now, there are some signs that the overbuilding has been worked off.

title: Lemon Poppy-Seed Pancakes With Greek Yogurt and Jam
description: Time: 20 minutes

title: Pancakes That Are Not So Flat (Artistically)
description: CHANCES are, if you have a reliable pancake recipe, you rarely stray.

title: Engel Introduces Bill to Protect Student Privacy
description: 1:36 p.m. | Updated Federal legislation introduced Friday could curb efforts by universities and athletic departments to digitally track student athletes.

title: Romney Campaign Tries to Paint Obama as Too Cool
description: Mitt Romney wants you to believe he will face one cool cat in November  a Ray-Ban-wearing, slow-news-jamming, smooth-as-silk singing Oval Office incumbent who regularly fills up stadiums with swooning students chanting his name: O-bam-a! O-bam-a!

title: This Weeks Movies
description: The New York Times film critics on The Five Year Engagement, Bernie, and The Pirates! Band of Misfits.

title: Steps to a Cakewalk Closing
description: THERES no lack of information on the Internet about real estate closings. But according to Sandy Gadow, the author of The Complete Guide to Your Real Estate Closing and a Sothebys broker who has taken part in thousands of closings, both buyers and sellers should know certain basic things to make a closing go well.

title: Bang! Youre Closed
description: THE setting for the closing on an apartment in the East 50s was a lawyers office. Things seemed to be going well between the sellers until the wife found out the price her husband had received for the apartment. She clearly didnt think it was enough. When he asked her to turn over her keys, she hurled them at him and hit him in the forehead, drawing blood.

title: The Rail Hits the Fifth-Year Pole
description: It was April 8, 2008, when The Rail entered the world. The blog set out to provide an insightful look into the world of horse racing by seasoned reporters, grizzled handicappers and enthusiastic fans. Like proud parents, we were so thrilled with the adventure that was before us. We also had no idea what we had in store, which, in hindsight, was probably for the best. There were story lines galore, many heartwarming and some heartbreaking: Big Brown, Eight Belles, steroids, no steroids, Mine That Bird, Rachel Alexandra, Calvin Bo-Rail and Animal Kingdom to name a few.

title: Book Review Podcast: Nell Freudenbergers New Novel
description: In the New York Times Book Review, Mohsin Hamid reviews Nell Freudenbergers latest novel, The Newlyweds, in which a Bangladeshi woman and American man agree to marry after meeting online. Mr. Hamid writes:

title: A Flicker of Hope Appears in the Housing Market
description: THE boom in housing in the middle of the last decade created a huge oversupply of homes in the United States. But now that oversupply appears to be close to vanishing, at least in most parts of the country.

title: Past Perfect
description: Restoration Hardware, which has forged a successful new identity with retro-chic furnishings, has also become a collector of vintage architecture. Having closed a substantial number of its mall stores in the last 18 months, the company has moved into the Hollywood Regency structure in Los Angeles that formerly housed Williams-Sonoma Home, and set up shop in a 1908 mercantile building in East Hampton, N.Y. Later this year, it will open a new retail space in Bostons Back Bay neighborhood, restoring an elegant early-1860s building (right) that was constructed for the New England Museum of Natural History (and later housed the high-end retailers Bonwit Teller and Louis Boston). And more buildings will be added to the roster soon. Gary Friedman, Restoration Hardwares chairman and co-C.E.O., explained that the gracious proportions of older buildings are more in line with the companys identity: We think of ourselves not as retailers but as curators.

title: Fashion News Were Reading Now
description: Still waiting for your Costume Institute Gala invitation to arrive in the mail? Dont fret. This year, you can watch fashions royalty gather in front of your computer screen while its being  live streamed.

title: Former Campaign Treasurer for Comptroller Is Indicted
description: A federal grand jury has indicted the former campaign treasurer for John C. Liu, the city comptroller, on charges that she helped funnel illegal campaign money to Mr. Liu by using fictitious donors and then impeded investigators efforts to gather information about the fund-raising, the United States attorney in Manhattan announced on Friday.

title: Lights. Camera. Invest! Putting Filmmaking in the Portfolio.
description: FOR most people, investing has not been fun these last few years. At best, it has been stressful.

title: TimesCast | April 27, 2012
description: A blind activist escapes house arrest in China | Two former Virginia governors vie for a United States Senate seat | The space shuttle Enterprise arrives in New York.

title: F.C.C. Approves Plan for Online Database of Political TV Ads
description: The Federal Communications Commission on Friday approved a proposal to have local broadcasters publish information about political advertising sales on the Web in a government database.

title: Video: This Weeks Movies, April 27
description: In todays edition of This Weeks Movies, we hear critical takes on three films: Richard Linklaters dark comedy Bernie, Peter Lords stop-motion animated Pirates! Band of Misfits and Nicholas Stollers romantic comedy The Five-Year Engagement, with Jason Segel and Emily Blunt. Do you have plans to go to one of these films this weekend, or do have thoughts on them? Let us know in the comments area below.

title: A Tiger, Accused of Slurs, Is Arrested
description: Detroit Tigers outfielder Delmon Young was arrested outside a Manhattan hotel early Friday after an altercation in he screamed anti-Semitic epithets at a group of tourists and a panhandler, the police said.

title: One in Two New College Graduates Is Jobless or Underemployed
description: One in two new college graduates is jobless or underemployed, The Associated Press reported this week.

title: Robert Miles Parker, Artist and Preservationist, Dies at 72
description: Robert Miles Parker, an artist and preservationist whose pen-and-ink drawings of urban landscapes displayed a whimsical delight in storefronts, apartment buildings, houses and theaters, died on April 17 at his home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, a neighborhood where he could often be found working at a makeshift drawing board in a lawn chair on the sidewalk with a pet Norfolk terrier on a leash sitting patiently beside him. He was 72.

title: At Pratt, Seeking a Sophisticated Eye
description: A few years ago, on a visit to the McQueen studios in London, I poked my head into a room of interns beavering away at rows of desks. They could have been accountants, I thought, poring over their Victorian ledgers. That scene could be duplicated across the fashion world, as new design-school graduates take their place in studios, and hope for the best. Its exciting to land a job  a bonus if its with a halfway decent name  but hardly glamorous.

title: Space Shuttle Enterprise Arrives in New York
description: Space Shuttle Enterprise arrived in New York, riding piggyback on a modified jumbo jet. Its trip included flyovers over parts of the city and landmarks before it landed at its temporary home, Kennedy Airport.

title: 7 Series Reached New Ratings Lows on Thursday
description: On a night surely affected by sports events  guys on ice shooting pucks and other guys on stage reading out names of college football players  a live episode of NBCs comedy 30 Rock marginally improved the fortunes of the show, while American Idol solidified its position as it moves toward the end of another season.

title: Letting Fliers Have a Voice in Mergers
description: Every time a company goes through bankruptcy court or gets involved in merger talks, its disappointing to see who does not have a seat at the negotiating table.

title: Kurt Masur in Good Condition After Fall Off Podium
description: The conductor Kurt Masur, 84, is said to be in good condition in a Paris hospital after having fallen off the podium and into the audience last night while leading the Orchestre National de France at the Thtre des Champs-lyses. The fall occurred during the second and final work on the program, Tchaikovskys Symphony No. 6 (Pathtique), in the midst of the third movement, Allegro molto vivace. Mr. Masurs assistant, Stefana Atlas, said that the fall resulted from an accident rather than his increasingly frail physical condition, which has led him to cancel some performances in recent months.

title: Fair Share
description: At the I.C.F.F., the writer and designer Suzanne Trocm curates British Bone, a selection of china produced by 1882LTD, including Max Lambs hand-carved tableware. Now in its second edition, WantedDesign again takes over the Terminal Stores building (28th Street at 11th Avenue), where it will host an exhibition of contemporary Brazilian design and a three-day workshop where design students will make their own light fixtures. In the garment district, the recently opened Moss Bureau (256 West 36th Street, 10th floor) will present Midway, a giant, zoetropic Ferris wheel and carousel by the artist and metalsmith Cathy McClure; Mortal Stillness, an exhibition of taxidermy by Kelly McCallum, assorted artist-made vessels and Jennifer Trasks ivory, bone and gilded wood jewelry. And check out the new Standard Hotel East Village (25 Cooper Square), where the Sight Unseen founders (and T contributors), Monica Khemsurov and Jill Singer, will install the work of West Coast designers for the aptly named Hotel California. The British designer Tom Dixon will introduce his soon-to-be-available Etch Light Web at London Underground in the basement of the Bleecker Street Theater (45 Bleecker Street). Walk away with a Mirrorball or Jack Light, or order one for home delivery from Fab.com on special iPad stations. And finally, Jamie Gray will introduce the newest pieces of his MatterMade collection, including Meg Callahans digitally printed quilts at Matter (405 Broome Street) and at a secret location nearby. Happy hunting.

title: Your Agenda for an American Airlines Customers Committee
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I call for the creation of a customers committee to represent the interest of frequent fliers on American Airlines. After all, everybody seems to get a seat at the table when an airline like American goes bankrupt or is the object of unwanted merger affection like the kind that US Airways is currently bestowing on it. So why shouldnt customers try to get some leverage, too?

title: George E. Doty Sr., Former Guardian of Goldmans Finances, Is Dead at 94
description: George E. Doty Sr., a former partner at Goldman Sachs and longtime watcher of the investment banks finances, died on Tuesday at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 94.

title: In a Slump, Hopkins Lacrosse Faces Top-Ranked Loyola
description: The players on the Johns Hopkins mens lacrosse team are ticked off and eager for another opportunity to showcase their talents and end all this losing business.

title: Living In | Piermont, N.Y.
description: Piermont, a village draped down the Hudson River face of the Tallman Mountains, evokes a Mediterranean hillside, or maybe Sausalito, Calif.

title: Jennifer Wu and Andy Woo
description: JENNIFER WU was moving so fast through life that potential suitors couldnt keep up with her. Educated at Harvard and the New York University School of Law, she had been known to fly off to Africa or Europe on a moments notice, or scare up a party of 20 with a few phone calls.

title: Boons and Banes of the Picturesque
description: DRAPED as it is down the Hudson River face of the Tallman Mountains, Piermont evokes a Mediterranean hillside, or maybe Sausalito, Calif. Either way, it presents a sharp contrast to many of its neighbors in Rockland County.

title: Go Buy the 200th Issue of The Paris Review
description: This isnt another in the What I Learned From Reading  series, but a companion plug for a couple of literary journals that are well worth spending your money on.

title: Senate Candidates in Massachusetts Release Their Tax Returns
description: 2:41 p.m. | Updated BOSTON  The top two candidates in the Massachusetts Senate race, which has focused so far on who can best understand the needs of average voters, are much wealthier than most of those voters.

title: Trailer: 'Don't Stop Believin''
description: A trailer for the documentary about Arnel Pineda and how his YouTube videos aided in getting him a gig as the lead singer of Journey.

title: Babies on Parade
description: A timeline of celebrities and their babies in the news media.

title: Investing With Your Heart, as Well as Your Head
description: In his Wealth Matters column this week, Paul Sullivan looks at an investment that doesnt involve stocks or bonds or real estate. Instead, he talks to people who have invested in films.

title: Radio As It Once Was
description: One day not long ago I was in my car, flipping through satellite radio stations on my way to work, when I suddenly heard a very unusual thing: Someone actually talking about the music he was playing. After a while I realized it was a voice from my teenage years  Dennis Elsas. one of a team of D.J.s on New Yorks WNEW FM in the 1960s and 1970s.

title: The Baby Bump
description: JESSICA SIMPSON, the onetime pop star, had her first and last Top 10 hit more than a decade ago, with I Wanna Love You Forever. But that didnt stop Elle magazine from putting her on its April cover (naked and pregnant, in an echo of the often-imitated 1991 Vanity Fair cover photo of Demi Moore) nor People magazine from splashing pictures of her baby shower over several pages in its April 2 issue.

title: A Dinner Date That Presidents Wish They Could Skip
description: Just as they do every year, the famous officials, journalists and Hollywood stars will gather Saturday night at the White House Correspondents Association dinner for an odd mix of celebrity and wonkdom.

title: Marlins Park in Miami
description: The Miami Marlins colorful new stadium breaks from baseballs now-familiar retro style into the 21st century.

title: A Ballpark That May Be Louder Than the Fans
description: MIAMI  After 20 years of retro-style ballparks since the opening of Oriole Park at Camden Yards in Baltimore, nearly all decked out with brick facades and calculated quirks that came to seem as predictable and interchangeable as the old doughnut-shaped arenas, Major League Baseball has its first unapologetic 21st-century stadium.

title: Ahead of the Curve, Yet Again
description: INDIO, Calif.

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $19,397,662.50
description: A full-floor penthouse at 100 11th Avenue that sold for $19,397,662.50 was the biggest sale of the week, according to city records. The penthouse, which has a 4,500-square-foot terrace, was also the last sponsor unit to sell in the building, which was designed by Jean Nouvel.

title: Record Store Day Specials and Some Asian Vibes
description: Branford Marsalis Quartet

title: Recordings Rich With Slavic Sounds
description: LIKE many singers from Slavic cultures, the Russian baritone Dmitri Hvorostovsky and the Polish baritone Mariusz Kwiecien have had some of their finest successes performing in Italian. This spring at the Metropolitan Opera Mr. Hvorostovsky has been stealing the show as Germont in Willy Deckers production of Verdis Traviata. And after missing the first performances because of an injury, Mr. Kwiecien was impressive in the title role of Mozarts Don Giovanni in the Mets new production in the fall. He followed up recently with an acclaimed turn as Belcore in Donizettis Elisir dAmore.

title: In Watch Industry, a Feud Over What Makes a Timepiece Swiss-Made
description: BASEL  Lest anyone doubt that the watches it makes are Swiss, Swiss Mountaineer emblazons Switzerlands national flag on the dial of each timepiece. Does it matter that except for their Swiss movement, the watches components are made at a factory in Shenzhen, China? Or that Swiss Mountaineer is owned by a Hong Kong company called Golden Hawk?

title: Fledgling Ballerinas, Just Learning to Fly
description: BESS KARGMAN wasnt expecting anything life changing when she walked into the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts on her lunch break from an unpaid internship one April day three years ago. When banners advertising the New York City finals of the international ballet competition Youth America Grand Prix caught her eye, this aspiring documentary filmmaker in search of a subject popped into the theater and grabbed one of the last available seats.

title: Eastern Conference Playoff Predictions
description: In the Western Conference, the second round of the playoffs will be played all over the map (distance from St. Louis to Los Angeles: 1,800 miles). But in the East, the matchups are among bitter rivals on Amtraks Northeast Corridor (distance from Newark to Philadelphia: 90 miles). Best advice to bystanders: stay off the trains on game days.

title: Spain Is Still Awaiting the Payoff From Austerity
description: LONDON  Since the beginning of the debt crisis in Europe more than two years ago, defenders of the euro currency union have stuck to a basic argument: if the euro zones weaker economies would only keep pursuing policies of austerity, even as growth collapsed and job losses mounted, they would be rewarded by investors more willing to buy their bonds.

title: Ruggles: Complete Works, Reissued as a CD
description: Vocal soloists; John Kirkpatrick, pianist; Buffalo Philharmonic, conducted by Michael Tilson Thomas; other ensembles. Other Minds OM 1020/21-2; two CDs.

title: Obama Campaign Raises Money for Hillary Clinton
description: Four years ago, the Obama fund-raising machine worked to bury Hillary Rodham Clinton. Now his contributors are opening their wallets for her.

title: How to Make Rhubarb Compote
description: Rhubarb compote is one of the best things to have on hand in your refrigerator. Melissa Clark shows how to make it.

title: A Little Something Schiaparelli?
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: British Airways Menus  Try for a Retro Feel
description: In honor of the London Olympic and Paralympic Games, British Airways will be serving up special in-flight meals concocted by Michelin-starred chefs in its first-class cabins from July through September.

title: Lindsey & Steven
description: Lindsey and Steven met in film school in 2003 but became friends in 2005 when they worked on a movie together. Their relationship deepened, thanks in part to a shared love of building bed forts.

title: At Parris Island, Basic Training Pulls Lessons From Marines Real-World Lapses
description: PARRIS ISLAND, S.C.  The Marine Corps recruits sat cross-legged on the spotless floor of their barracks here, the blankets on their bunks pulled as tight as drumheads. Perched before them, catlike atop a pair of footlockers, Staff Sgt. Levar Woods launched into the days lesson.

title: No Laughing Matter: One Man, Two Guvnors Will Vie as New Play for Tonys
description: The eligibility committee for the Tony Awards on Friday denied a request by the producers of the Broadway comedy One Man, Two Guvnors to compete in the category of best play revival, where One Man would have faced less competition for a Tony nomination  and perhaps a stronger chance of winning  than in the category of best play. Instead One Man, which opened to excellent reviews this month, will compete for one of the four best-play nominations with other admired contenders like Other Desert Cities, Clybourne Park, The Lyons, Peter and the Starcatcher, and Venus in Fur.

title: Space Shuttle Arrives in New York
description: The space shuttle enterprise was delivered to New York and given a grand entrance.

title: Suicide Attack Kills 9 Near Damascus as Cease-Fire Erodes
description: A suicide bomber attacked a group of Syrian security service members near a mosque in a Damascus suburb on Friday, killing at least nine people and wounding dozens of others, said the state news media, which also reported at least two other bombings around the capital in the most recent signs of the erosion of the United Nations-monitored cease-fire.

title: Treat Petite: A Different Sort of Soft-Serve
description: A successful trial run in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, led Rovshan Danilov, who is originally from Azerbaijan, and Arthur Simonyan, from Russia, to open a Manhattan shop selling soft-serve kefir. A fermented milk product popular in Eastern Europe, kefir (pronounced keh-FEAR) is now sold in many supermarkets here. It is similar to yogurt, but thinner, and contains several types of beneficial bacteria and yeast.

title: April 29  May 5
description: THE Turkish director Nuri Bilge Ceylan, whose Once Upon a Time in Anatolia shared the 2011 grand prize at Cannes, has become an auteur hero. But beyond Mr. Ceylan most American moviegoers probably have little experience with Turkish movies. That makes the 29-film series THE SPACE BETWEEN: A PANORAMA OF CINEMA IN TURKEY  presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center with the Moon and Stars Project of the American Turkish Society  all the more valuable. With movies from the late 1950s to the present, the series concentrates on socially engaged works rather than on the countrys commercial cinema.

title: Breaking Down Knicks-Heat
description: In the summer of 2010, the New York Knicks and Miami Heat had similar ideas on constructing their rosters. Both teams freed up cap space in order to sign the leagues best free agents. The Heat achieved their goal, signing LeBron James and Chris Bosh, while retaining Dwayne Wade. As Miami grabbed three All Stars, New York was only able to land one, Amare Stoudemire.

title: Dutch Plan to Restrict Marijuana Passes Hurdle
description: PARIS  The Dutch governments plan to prohibit the purchase of marijuana by nonresidents cleared an important hurdle on Friday, when a court in The Hague dismissed a lawsuit brought by shop owners challenging the plan on the grounds that it was discriminatory.

title: Healthcare: What Might Have Been
description: Long before the sexting scandal that ended his career, Rep. Anthony Weiner advised the president on how to pass healthcare reform. Robert Draper reports in his new book, Do Not Ask What Good We Do, that in September of 2009 Mr. Weiner told the president, I think youre looking at this entirely the wrong way. You need to simplify it. Just say that what were doing is gradually expanding Medicare.

title: Romanias Government Collapses Amid Austerity Backlash
description: PARIS  Romanias government fell Friday in a no-confidence vote just two months after taking office, the latest government in Europe to crumble amid disputes over unpopular austerity measures and declining growth rates.

title: An Everyman Goes From YouTube to Journey
description: How many YouTube hits does it take to get to superstardom? For the musician and artist Arnel Pineda, it took only the right one. When Neal Schon, the guitarist for Journey, was looking for a new singer for the band, he searched on YouTube and found Mr. Pineda, a Filipino singer who was performing Journey songs with his group the Zoo Band. Mr. Schon asked to meet with Mr. Pineda and, eventually, Mr. Pineda, an artist who had logged so many hours impersonating the sounds of rock stars, became one. A new documentary playing this weekend at the Tribeca Film Festival, Dont Stop Believin': Everymans Journey looks deeper into the unlikely story of Arnel Pineda and how he became the frontman for one of Americas most popular rock acts. It follows Mr. Pineda on the bands 2008 tour and spends some time with him in more personal moments as well.

title: DealBooks Week in Review
description: The defense of Rajat K. Gupta got a boost from the disclosure of an insider inquiry targeting a Goldman banker in California. In China, big banks are starved for capital after a lending spree. And Andrew Ross Sorkin finds tainted executives sheltered on boards.

title: House Passes Student Loan Bill Despite Veto Threat
description: WASHINGTON  Moments after an unusual fiery appeal from Speaker John A. Boehner, the House ignored a veto threat from President Obama and voted 215 to 195 on Friday to prevent a doubling of student loan rates.

title: Homophobic? Maybe Youre Gay
description: WHY are political and religious figures who campaign against gay rights so often implicated in sexual encounters with same-sex partners?

title: Fantasy Football: Breaking Down the First Round of the N.F.L. Draft
description: Jason and Justin Sablich will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy). Andrew Luck, Quarterback, Indianapolis Colts  Peyton Mannings replacement brings size, accuracy and brains to offensive coordinator Bruce Arianss quarterback-friendly offense, but without Pierre Garcon, Jacob Tamme and Dallas Clark hell have to make do with a declining Reggie Wayne and a fragile Austin Collie as his main weapons. Rookie quarterbacks always carry considerable risk, but his upside and talent will make him an attractive mid- to low-end QB2 that will be coming off of the fantasy boards in the middle rounds.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A five-bedroom colonial in Edgemont, N.Y., and a three-bedroom ranch in Metuchen, N.J.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A Chelsea tri-level, a Boerum Hill house and a Washington Heights co-op.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: A New Volume of Batman: No Mans Land
description: New to the graphic books paperback best-seller list this week is Volume 2 of Batman: No Mans Land, which appears at No. 7. The story was originally published in serialized form in 1999. Those days were hard times for Gotham City and the caped crusader: after an outbreak of disease, the city was leveled by an earthquake. The government had enough and gave the order to evacuate the city. Batman, his allies, his enemies and many residents stayed. The story, which wove through several monthly titles and was handled by several writers and artists, was compelling. The city became divided by rival factions and familiar faces were cast into different roles. (The Penguin, for example, became a supplier of goods on the black market, while the Huntress, who felt ostracized by Batman, took on a new guise.) Most superhero stories require a good helping of suspension of disbelief, and this one is no different. When No Mans Land began, fans wondered why Batmans heroic allies did not help him or the city. Theres an adventure that addresses that (in a Justice League story, they are shown protecting Gothams perimeter, but are asked by Batman to otherwise keep out), which I hope will be featured in a future volume.

title: For Those Who Think ... (Yawn)
description: Toyotas Camry remains mostly unchanged for 2012, offering the predictably soothing experience that has made it the best-selling car in America for 13 of the last 14 years.

title: Spains King Has Surgery Amid Debate on His Reign
description: MADRID  In the latest twist in a drama now gripping Spain, King Juan Carlos underwent surgery for the second time on Thursday since fracturing his hip while elephant hunting in Botswana earlier this month.

title: The Value of James Harden
description: While James Harden has received much attention this week for taking an elbow to the face from Metta World Peace, he actually deserves recognition for his impressive play this season.

title: As Parents, Are Fathers the Second Sex?
description: Ten months ago, my wife and I had our first child, a boy. He was born in London, where weve been living for nearly four years.

title: Nebraska Coach Makes Public Stand Against Gay Rights
description: While much of the sports world seems to be making an effort to be move away from its entrenched homophobia and be more inclusive of gays and lesbians  professional teams filming videos for the It Gets Better project and hockeys new You Can Play initiative, for example  an assistant football coach at Nebraska believes that is going entirely in the wrong direction.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, April 27
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: 30 Rock Satire of Kraft Sponsorship Is Sponsored by Kraft
description: The episode of the sitcom 30 Rock that NBC broadcast live on Thursday night offered a fanciful tribute to live TV on the Peacock network. Not left out of that wacky history lesson were the sponsors, an integral part of television when it was live.

title: Should Cyberbullying Be a Crime?
Passengers Tell American Airlines What They Want
description: In this weeks Your Money column, Ron Lieber argues that theres a need for a committee to advocate for passengers when airlines restructure or merge. The issue has come up again as American Airlines makes its arguments on restructuring in bankruptcy court and US Airways signals that it hopes to merge with American.

title: Tardec FED Bravo: A Deeper Shade of Army Green
description: By its own admission, the Army tends not to fret over the fuel efficiency of its terrestrial vehicle fleet. But at the Society of Automotive Engineers World Congress in Detroit this week, the armed forces played against type, unveiling a new concept vehicle, the FED Bravo.

title: Shaved Asparagus With Arugula and Parmesan
description: Time: About 20 minutes

title: Asparagus With Mustard Vinaigrette
description: 1 1/2 pounds large or medium asparagus

title: Stir-Fried Spicy Asparagus
description: Time: About 15 minutes

title: A Romantic Cooks True Spring Love
description: AS far as asparagus is concerned, you could say Im a fanatic: a rabid, obsessive-compulsive perfectionist.

title: Federal Investigators Subpoena Union Documents
description: 5:02 p.m. | Updated Federal investigators have sent a subpoena to the National Basketball Players Association seeking documents about the business practices of the union, which have come under scrutiny because of claims of nepotism and conflicts of interest.

title: After a Tumultuous Season, Anthony May Have More on the Line
description: It is hardly a strain to argue that the compelling first-round matchup between the Knicks and the Miami Heat is largely about the baggage strapped onto the backs of LeBron James and Company as they begin the 2012 postseason.

title: Four Things I Learned From Reading Every Last Word of Real Simple
description: Full disclosure: Real Simple is not a magazine that I usually buy or read. This is not because its not a good magazine (Im not qualified to judge; see first sentence) but because its a magazine explicitly targeted at women. I am not generalizing here: the editors note from Kristin van Ogtrop (who, full disclosure Part 2, is the spouse of a Times Magazine staff member) includes a story about a husband buying his wife the wrong black cashmere turtleneck that concludes with: The womans friends clucked sympathetically. Havent we all been there? Personally, I have not been there.

title: Seacrests Role at NBCUniversal Will Span News, Sports and Entertainment
description: Look for Ryan Seacrest to be appearing soon on NBCs Today show and on the networks coverage of special events like the Olympics.

title: Vain Glorious | Virgins Code Red
description: Virgin Airlines recently unveiled a swank spa at its new Upper Class lounge at New Yorks Kennedy Airport, the first Clubhouse spa outside of London. A blowout and a massage before you climb on board a night flight has great appeal  plane bed head is not a good look. The spa within the 10,000-square-foot clubhouse, designed by Slade Architecture, has its own Bumble and Bumble salon, and offers facials using Dr. Hauschka products.

title: Peoples Choice Returns With Apps and Adele
description: AS a car-buying choice, the Toyota Camry is like the ask the audience lifeline on Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? The Camry, the best-selling car in America for 13 of the last 14 years, represents the wisdom of the crowd, a safe harbor for those who just arent that interested in cars.

title: TimesCast | Chinese Dissident Escapes
description: April 27, 2012  Chen Guangcheng, a blind lawyer known for taking on the case of thousands of women who had been forcibly sterilized, escapes from house arrest.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, April 27
description: More Photographs

title: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
description: Photos from New York, Kazakhstan, Spain and Syria.

title: The Few, the Proud, the Brutes: Special Ops for Jeep Wranglers
description: IN 1993, Dave Harriton decided to cut his Jeep in half to make it longer. Little did he know what the project would entail  or that it would stretch into an enterprise that supplies aftermarket equipment for Jeeps and modifies the off-road stalwarts for even more extreme use.

title: P.S. 29 Parents Grill Officials Over Construction
The Week in Pictures for April 27
description: Subjects include a womens bocce league in the Bronx, caretakers for the citys historic homes and mourners at Levon Helms wake in Woodstock, N.Y.

title: Inserting the Brand-New Alongside the Old Familiar
description: New-music fans who object when musical organizations present contemporary works in special concerts, where they wont intrude on the classics  the New York Philharmonics Contact! series, or the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Centers Kaplan Penthouse concerts, for example  would have approved of the way the society presented John Harbisons new Sonata No. 1 for Violin and Piano on Tuesday evening at Alice Tully Hall.

title: TV Puzzle: Watch Knicks or Rangers?
description: A quirk in playoff scheduling has created a problem for some New York sports fans.

title: Before Flying Car Can Take Off, Theres a Checklist
description: THE promise of an airplane parked in every driveway, for decades a fantasy of suburban commuters and a staple of mens magazines, resurfaced this month in Manhattan. On display at the New York auto show was the Terrafugia Transition, an airplane with folding wings and a drive system that enabled it to be used on the road.

title: Expect Some Delays
description: Flying cars like the Terrafugia Transition are ready to lift off, but theyll need to clear some regulatory hurdles first.

title: Makers Vie for Their Share of Chinas Cooling Market
description: IS the gold rush ending just as all the prospectors finally arrive?

title: 50 Berlin Galleries Host Shows and Events
description: From Friday through Sunday, 50 galleries will open their doors to visitors from around the world as part of Gallery Weekend Berlin. With notable exhibitions and see-and-be-seen parties, the three-day event has emerged as one of the most important art happenings in Europe.

title: Chic in Review | Miss Kardashian Goes to Washington
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Threat of a Close Shave in Mozarts Lechers Tale
description: Mozarts Don Giovanni usually concludes these days with a moralizing sextet: after the rogue Giovanni has descended to hell, his fed-up servant Leporello, the women he wronged and the fiances he enraged proclaim, Questo  il fin di chi fa mal (Such is the end of the evildoer). The sextet was usually omitted until the mid-20th century, and an artistic argument can certainly be made for its exclusion, since the opera ends on a note of heightened drama with Giovannis fiery death.

title: Android Is Failing to Get Into Businesses as iPhone and iPad Do
description: Googles Android is installed on more devices than any other mobile software system in the world. But beyond sheer quantity, it doesnt seem to have much going for it among American businesses. Its prominence is eroding in the smartphone market here.

title: If Carmen Had Made It to the Altar
description: So much bling, so little substance.

title: A Critique of the Broken-Record Message of Green Traditionalists
description: Keith Kloor, building ona post on his blog, Collide-a-Scape, has an essay posted on Discover, titled The Limits to Environmentalism, that is well worth reading.

title: Prosecutors Scrutinize Ex-Head of Dewey
description: The Manhattan district attorneys office is investigating accusations of wrongdoing at the troubled law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf, the firm said on Friday.

title: Untying the Knot, and Bonds, of Marriage
description: WHEN the performance artist Marina Abramovic separated from her longtime partner, Ulay, in 1988, they decided to honor the occasion with a ritual. She traveled to one end of the Great Wall of China, he to the other, and after a 90-day hike, they met in the middle, embraced and officially parted ways.

title: Bill Skowron, Slugger in Yankee Golden Era, Dies at 81
description: Bill Skowron, the slugging first baseman who played on seven pennant-winning teams with the Yankees in the 1950s and early 60s, died on Friday in Arlington Heights, Ill. He was 81.

title: Bill Cunningham | Wistful
description: The cascading blossoms remind me of what I saw in Paris last month: the elongated look of women in stripes.

title: Woman With a Lens, Restored
description: DANCER, bride, runaway wife, radical filmmaker and pioneer  Shirley Clarke is one of the great undertold stories of American independent cinema. A woman working in a predominantly male world, a white director who turned her camera on black subjects, she was a Park Avenue rich girl who willed herself to become a dancer and a filmmaker, ran away to bohemia, hung out with the Beats and held to her own vision in triumph and defeat. She helped inspire a new film movement and made urgently vibrant work that blurs fiction and nonfiction, only to be marginalized, written out of histories and dismissed as a dilettante. She died in 1997 at 77 and is long overdue for a reappraisal.

title: Door Between Galleries Lets in an Artists Vision
description: The big-money contemporary art world has grown so large that it often seems to have achieved nation-state status, while the galleries it comprises operate like feuding medieval principalities, constantly jousting for turf (Chelsea real estate), prestige (A-list artists) and money (from collectors pockets).

title: More Answers About the Baby Hawks
description: Boo and Scout, the baby hawks in the Hawk Cam nest high above Washington Square Park, are now 17 and 18 days old and have morphed from round-headed, snow-white fuzz balls to slightly fearsome grayish creatures somewhat resembling fluff-covered dinosaurs. Now that theyre too big for mother hawk Rosie to sit on top of them, the pair are getting more air time on the Hawk Cam.

title: Defying Expectations With Dark Lyrics and a Danceable Sound
description: Miike Snow, the Swedish band that started a three-night stand at Terminal 5 on Tuesday night, has given itself a tricky assignment: bringing angst and enigma into the artificial electronic paradise of electronic dance music. Its best-loved song, Animal  the crowd-pleasing finale on Tuesday  begins, There was a time when my world was filled with darkness, darkness, darkness, and doesnt find much comfort from there.

title: Video: Homemade Rhubarb Compote
description: In this weeks column, I mention a homemade rhubarb compote that I used as a topping for pancakes. I demonstrate the recipe in this video if you want a detailed look at how to make it, though it is simple as can be. Just cube 3/4 pound rhubarb and combine it with 3/4 cup sugar over low heat. When the rhubarb starts to soften, but before it falls apart (about 5 minutes), use a slotted spoon to transfer it to a bowl. Then, cook the liquid down in the pan until it thickens and turns syrupy (about 5 minutes longer). This condenses and intensifies the rhubarb flavor. Add the syrup to the bowl with the rhubarb and let cool. It will keep for at least a week in the fridge.

title: Another Chapter in a Personal Myth That Keeps Growing Darker
description: By now, just about everyone in the contemporary dance world is familiar with the provocative, involved question behind Twenty Looks or Paris Is Burning at the Judson Church, the series Trajal Harrell  began in 2009: What would have happened in 1963 if someone from the ball scene in Harlem had gone downtown to perform alongside the early postmoderns at Judson Church?

title: Signs of a Shift as G.M.A. Again Leads Today in Viewers
description: The early shift seems to be real: preliminary ratings this week indicate that ABCs Good Morning America has won another week over NBCs Today show, this time by a more substantial margin. The win came with Matt Lauer, the top morning anchor for Today, on the job.

title: Asparagus, at Last
description: It finally feels like spring when local asparagus starts showing up in New Yorks greenmarkets. And on a market visit the other day, fresh asparagus seemed to be popping out all over. There were tempting green spears in every size  fat, medium and pencil-thin, and even some purple-tinged varieties.

title: Table Talk: The New Family Dinner
description: GROWING up in the 70s, I sat down to a family dinner that was consistent with my parents child-rearing philosophy at the time, which my mother likes to call benign neglect. Over dinner, my father briefed my mother on the ins and outs of his day at the office, while my siblings and I zoned out or piped up or fought over why my older sister always got the corner seat. We sat down as a family to a good, healthy meal, but dinner was not what you would call child-centric  which was fine with us, and definitely fine with them.

title: Tonys Committee Decides One Man, Two Guvnors Isnt a Revival
description: The eligibility committee for the Tony Awards on Friday denied a request by the producers of the Broadway comedy One Man, Two Guvnors to compete in the category of best play revival. One Man would have faced less competition for a Tony nomination  and perhaps a stronger chance of winning  as a revival than in the category of best play.

title: Obama Trumpets Killing of Bin Laden, and Critics Pounce
description: WASHINGTON  Presidents running for re-election typically boast of programs they created, people they helped or laws they signed. They talk about rising test scores or falling deficits or expanding job rolls. President Obama is increasingly taking the unusual route of bragging about how he killed a man.

title: A Winding Trip Reverberates in Cinema
description: AT one point in a lovely 1990 documentary about the French filmmaker Jacques Rivette he muses on the importance of curiosity and time to storytellers  or, in his modest phrase, people who try to play with fiction. Seated between his interlocutor, the critic Serge Daney, and the documentarys director, Claire Denis, Mr. Rivette  a slight, thoughtful man who punctuates his answers with reflexive shrugs and bashful smiles  declares, It seems that Scheherazade is our patron saint.

title: Teachers, Principals and Money Unresolved for 24 Turnaround Schools
Reviewing the Toyota Camry
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Ezra Dyer reviews the Toyota Camry, which received a refresh for the 2012 model year  though Toyota would argue its volume-leading sedan was reinvented.

title: Deception Tells Its Tale, Again
description: WHO do you think you are?

title: A State Looks at Itself in a New Mirror
description: DENVER  An East Coast visitors first reaction, provincially enough, has to be skepticism: does Colorado even have that much history?

title: Secret Service Tightens Travel Rules for Its Staff
description: WASHINGTON  Two weeks after the Secret Service opened an investigation into whether a dozen of its agents and employees had spent the night with prostitutes in Colombia, the agency announced on Friday that it had tightened its rules for staff members traveling in foreign countries.

title: It Takes Two to Fight Over a Documentary
description: WHEN David Redmon and Ashley Sabin were first falling in love, they took a trip to Mexico. Not that kind of trip. They went to shoot a documentary about the squalid conditions of the workers who make Victorias Secret bags. The film never took shape, but the relationship flourished.

title: Fans of Flight Welcome the Space Shuttle
Photo Replay: April 27
description: A view of the day in sports, from a Canadian politician wearing a Rangers jersey to a spectator sporting a folding chair.

title: Media Conference Attendees, Pack Your Glow Sticks
description: The ____ lifestyle touches all corners of pop culture today, and by creating a smart and effective conference just ahead of the single largest ____ festival in North America, EDMbiz is uniquely positioned to be an essential crossroads for new ideas and opportunities.

title: Shes Playing Games With Your Lives
description: THESE days, games arent just for fun anymore.

title: After 53 Years of Mixing Drinks, a Beer for the Road
description: Tommy Rowles did not have a Tommy Rowles.

title: Its April, It Rains. Deal (and Sing).
description: The Happiest Sound in Town, the title of Marilyn Mayes new show at Feinsteins at Loews Regency, is not a misnomer. A woman of seemingly inexhaustible vocal stamina, show-business smarts and innate good will and optimism, Ms. Maye, now 84, spreads a kind of joy that is the opposite of the forced cheer affected by many performers to camouflage insecurity.

title: In Ohio, Romney Hails Two Entrepreneurs Named John
description: WESTERVILLE, Ohio  This is the story of two Johns  Jimmy Johns and Papa Johns.

title: How to Interpret the Derby Contenders Final Preparations
description: The 20-horse field for this years Kentucky Derby is taking shape, and the stars are now either at Churchill Downs or will arrive in the next few days. Union Rags, who arrived at Churchill Downs on Thursday after training at Keeneland for a couple of weeks, performed a routine gallop Friday.

title: Every Instrument Has the Spotlight
description: When Alan Gilbert commissioned the composer Marc Neikrug to write a piece for the New York Philharmonic, he couched the request simply: he wanted something that would show off the full orchestra. It could have been a symphony or a tone poem, but for Mr. Neikrug the solution was a concerto for orchestra: a score in the tradition of Bartoks and Lutoslawskis similarly titled works, in which every part of the ensemble would be treated equally. His goal, he said in a recent interview on YouTube, was to write music that would require the Philharmonic to play ferociously difficult music like ferocious animals.

title: Classics With a Spirit of Improvisation
description: At first glance, the program that the pianist Richard Goode played at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening seemed dispiritingly constricted. The two composers whose works he performed, Schumann and Chopin, were born in the same year, 1810, and the works he chose were all composed within a decade, from 1838 to 1847.

title: Week in Pictures for April 27
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a womens bocce league in the Bronx, caretakers for the citys historic homes and mourners at Levon Helms wake in Woodstock, N.Y.

title: Classic Greek Flavors, With a Modern Twist
description: THE vivid blue and white color scheme, the airy dining room and even the typography on the sign at Kyma Greek Cuisine, a six-month-old restaurant in Somerville, primed my palate for the classics of that cuisine: succulent grilled meats and seafood, lemon, oregano, feta, ouzo, rich coffee.

title: A Change in Name and Focus
description: The seven-year-old Long Island Merlot Alliance has changed its name to Merliance, after its collectively made wine, and expanded its program, now describing itself as a group of producers of quality merlot and merlot-based blends.

title: Guardiola Stepping Down as Barcelona Manager
description: Pep Guardiola will step down as Barcelonas manager after the season, the club announced Friday, and be replaced by his longtime friend and assistant Tito Vilanova.

title: Adventurous Choices for Nibblers and Grazers
description: THE small-plate restaurant trend shows no sign of waning. Such places are popular with good reason: diners looking for a light meal find the portions manageable, while those with big appetites enjoy trying a variety of dishes. One of the newest of the breed is the Phoenix, which opened in Seaford on Feb. 1 in a semicircular corner building that was previously a Pomodorino restaurant.

title: Authentic Feasts, Tequila Included, for Any Fiesta
description: CONTRARY to popular belief, Cinco de Mayo is not Mexicos independence day. It is, however, a fine occasion to salute that countrys culture and cuisine while getting a head start on summer. The three restaurants listed below serve authentic and innovative Mexican food in dcors that contribute to a celebratory sense of fiesta all year long.

title: The N.R.A. and Hunters: Its Complicated
description: To the Editor:

title: Trials Begin for World Mind Sports Games
description: The second quadrennial World Mind Sports Games will be held in Lille, France, in August. The trial to select the United States open team started on Friday and runs through May 6. Details are at usbf.org, and play can be watched live at bridgebase.com.

title: A History of the Expansion of Presidential Power
description: To the Editor:

title: The Feast of San Gennaro, Without the Stereotypes
description: To the Editor:

title: A Passport for Arizona?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Mannequin for a Beat, Buuel for Intermission
description: In Argentina, Charly Garca, 60, is the kind of nationally renowned rock superstar who performs in arenas and brings out multigenerational audiences who can sing dozens of his songs all the way through. He played a rare United States concert, his first New York City show since 2002, on Wednesday night at the Best Buy Theater, where the opening guitar lines of his songs immediately inspired shouts of recognition and la-la singalongs.

title: The Decision to Deport
description: To the Editor:

title: The Creationist and the Polar Bear
description: To the Editor:

title: A Nightingale Soaring Tranquilly Through Nocturnes
description: The soprano Sandrine Piau and the pianist Susan Manoff paused on Thursday evening, waiting for the low rumble of the subway that passes not too far from the subterranean Zankel Hall to subside. Then they eased into the first line, Calmes dans le demi-jour (Calm at twilight), from Faurs song En Sourdine (Muted), and as always with Ms. Piau, the calm seemed to permeate the very air.

title: The Rich Are Different From You And Me
description: Mitt Romney (emphasis added):

title: Reading and Acting Out a Letter (It Isnt Fan Mail)
description: As the artistic director of Chunky Move, the successful Australian company he founded and is about to leave, Gideon Obarzanek is known for creating high-tech multimedia experiments. So its something of a departure for this 45-year-old choreographer to put himself onstage, in gym clothes, with little more than a desk and a laptop for a solo performance.

title: St. Johns Introduces New Womens Basketball Coach
description: The news conference to introduce Joe Tartamella as the St. Johns womens basketball coach on Friday was attended by his parents, brother, sister, wife, son and in-laws, along with dignitaries from the university. But it was an absent party whose presence was felt most: Kim Barnes Arico.

title: Councilmans Spokesman Is Let Go After Past Prison Time Is Revealed
description: Updated, April 28 | After The New York Post revealed that the spokesman for  Councilman Ydanis Rodriguez had spent time in prison for attacking an Army recruitment center in the Bronx, Mr. Rodriguez released the spokesman from his staff on Friday.

title: Mighty Wind of British Laughs
description: It wasnt until the joke about passing gas that I realized that Richard Beans riotous crowd-pleaser One Man, Two Guvnors is an awfully smart show.

title: God and Man in Tennessee
description: Russellville, Tenn.

title: Obama Signs Order to Limit Aggressive College Recruiting of Veterans
description: At Georgias Fort Stewart on Friday, President Obama signed an executive order to help protect military families and veterans from aggressive and deceptive recruiting by higher education institutions  especially for-profit colleges  seeking their military benefits.

title: Friday Night Music: Dont Give Up
description: Ive actually posted this clip from Peter Gabriels 1993 Secret World tour once before, but it seems especially relevant given my new book  I even quote from the song in Chapter 1.

title: Indictment of Jia Hou
description: The federal indictment of Jia Hou, the former campaign treasurer for John C. Liu, the city comptroller, accuses her of discussing ways to circumvent the citys campaign finance laws.

title: Whats in a Name? A Crucial Ingredient
description: SHORTLY before Burrata opened in February, with brown paper still covering the windows, stylish block letters fixed to its handsome facade announced the coming of a restaurant named Hearth (smaller letters below promised wood-fired pizza). With all systems ready to go, the owner, Chas Anderson, met with a cease-and-desist letter from a Manhattan restaurateur who already had rights to the name Hearth  hence the mellifluous last-minute christening.

title: In Virginia, 2 Ex-Governors Vie for Senate and Balance of Power
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.  Seven months before Virginia voters elect their next United States senator, former Gov. Tim Kaine, the Democrats choice for the slot, was rallying a college crowd here, trying to impress upon them the magnitude of the decision to come.

title: An Evenly Matched Senate Race
description: With so many Senate seats up for grabs this November, no other race appears to be quite so evenly matched as the one in Virginia, which features two former governors with near-universal name recognition, local successes to stump on and rich campaign war chests.

title: In Brawl, Laws May Have Been Broken, but No Dress Codes
description: The call came in around midnight on Thursday, April 12, and the police officers of Manhattans Midtown North Precinct did a double take at the address.

title: Murdochs Denials of Political Favors Hard to Swallow in New York
description: Former Mayor Edward I. Koch said he was in his West Village apartment early one morning in 1977 when the phone rang and the man on the other end of the line said, Good morning, Congressman. Its Rupert.

title: F.D.A. Sends Warning Letters to 10 Marketers of Workout Boosters
description: The Food and Drug Administration warned marketers of dietary supplements this week that certain popular workout boosters could increase peoples blood pressure, potentially causing shortness of breath or heart attacks.

title: A Few for the Ages

title: TimesCast | Swing Seat in a Swing State
description: In Virginia, two former governors  Democrat Tim Kaine and Republican George Allen  are vying for a U.S. Senate seat armed with name recognition and rich campaign war chests.

title: In Search of Apps for Television
description: The same consumers who delight in navigating the iPad still click frustratingly through cable channels to find a basketball game. Their complaint: Why cant television be more like a tablet?

title: Updates to an Art Form That Once Caused Outrage
description: The history of modern art is often described as a history of outrage. Take, for instance, this episode involving found objects: in 1913, the poet Guillaume Apollinaire published four reproductions of Pablo Picassos sculptural constructions, made of scavenged materials, in a small Parisian journal  upon which 34 of the journals 40 subscribers immediately canceled their subscriptions. Apparently, even those avant-garde consumers werent ready to accept such objects as art.

title: City Crackdown on Hotels Affects Quaint B&Bs Too
description: The Eden House hotel in Washington Heights advertised free Wi-Fi and good subway access at bargain prices. The Loftstel in Brooklyn offered dorm-style beds for $25 a night, and three-bedrooms for just $195. In a city where a hotel room often costs a weeks pay, they seemed attractive options.

title: Some Things Considered, Anyway
description: Me on NPR.

title: Hunting for Votes in Virginia
description: Tim Kaine, a Democrat, and George Allen, a Republican, are battling for what is considered by both parties to be a crucial Senate seat.

title: Cuomo Says He Makes History, Then Repeats It
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is making history.

title: U.S. Antitrust Move Has Google Fighting on Two Fronts
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google may soon be fighting antitrust battles on two fronts.

title: My Faith-Based Retirement
description: My 60th birthday is less than a week and a half away, and if there is one thing I can say with certainty its that 60 is not the new 50.

title: Suburban Tales That Go to the Edge
description: THERE is plenty of mayhem for fans of dark fiction in the pages of Long Island Noir: shootings, killings, all manner of brutality. And Long Island, too, comes in for a beating.

title: Hollande and Sarkozy Trade Insults as Runoff Nears
description: PARIS  With accusations of fascism and lying, incompetence and imbecility, the French presidential campaign has been one of the nastiest in memory. One legislator from the governing party even compared the partner of the Socialist challenger to a Rottweiler.

title: Desperately Seeking Quarterback Stoppers
description: When the Baltimore Ravens finally plucked outside linebacker Courtney Upshaw from the green room Friday night  he slid from an expected first-round selection to the third pick in the second  it continued this drafts run on the people who chase after quarterbacks. And with the next pick, the Denver Broncos surprised analysts by taking defensive tackle Derek Wolfe, another pass rusher.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 27, 2012

title: Cars, Trains and Partisan Posturing
description: The transportation bill is vital, providing billions of dollars to states and communities to build and repair roads, ensure bridges are safe and improve mass transit for millions of commuters. It also sustains some 2.9 million jobs, many in the hard-pressed construction industry.

title: A Theater Class Where All Are Able
description: MILLBURN, N.J.   Im a little scared, confessed one of the children in the black-box theater at the Paper Mill Playhouse here on a recent Friday.

title: Bristol-Myers Subpoenaed in Inquiry Into Sales
description: Bristol-Myers Squibb has been subpoenaed by the Securities and Exchange Commission for information related to its sales and marketing practices in other countries, the company disclosed in a federal filing.

title: Prostitution Inquiry Is Latest Scandal for State Police
description: The State Police is an agency that is no stranger to scandal.

title: William Hammond and the End of the Medical Middle Ages
description: While other events of April 25, 1862, dominated the nations headlines  most notably the Confederate surrender of New Orleans  perhaps the most significant single event in the life of the average Union soldier was a presidential appointment that day that was hardly noticed outside Washington. Over the objection of Edwin Stanton, his secretary of war, President Lincoln named William Alexander Hammond as surgeon general of the Army.

title: Chevron Misses Forecasts Despite Higher Oil Prices
description: Chevron missed first-quarter profit and sales estimates as falling production blunted the impact of surging oil prices. Net income rose 4.2 percent to $6.47 billion, or $3.27 a share, from $6.21 billion, or $3.09 a share, a year earlier, the company said. Sales rose 0.8 percent to $58.9 billion, 7.8 percent lower than the average of three analysts estimates compiled by Bloomberg. Stock in Chevron, which is based in San Ramon, Calif., fell 2 cents, or 0.02 percent, to $106.20 a share.

title: Food Safety on Hold
description: While the first lady, Michelle Obama, champions the issue of healthy food, the rest of the administration does not seem to have gotten the message. There are now three important food issues on hold. And health and nutrition advocates worry that they are stalled for the election season, or longer, because of pushback from the food industry. Here is what needs to move along:

title: Newly Engaged and Out to Splurge
description: The neighborhood remains scruffy, but gentrification is in full bloom at the NoMad Hotel, at Broadway and 28th Street, where the vibe is European louche-luxe and the restaurant is the province of Daniel Humm and Will Guidara, the chef and general manager who own the Michelin three-star Eleven Madison Park. At NoMad, patrons have multiple backdrops for dining, each offering its own enticements: the central Atrium, with its stone floor and glass ceiling, guarantees high visibility; the romantic Parlour, decorated with framed, pressed herbs, is comfortably intimate; the Fireplace room, for large parties, resembles an antique jewelry box. A seductively lighted duplex library adjacent to the bar encourages patrons to tuck away their iPhones, settle in with a book, sip a cocktail, converse and envision themselves to the manner born. Or inside a game of Clue.

title: The Myth of Deterrence
description: One of the most frequently made claims about the death penalty is that it deters potential murderers. That was the claim when the Supreme Court reinstated capital punishment in 1976. It is the claim today after a revival of research about the topic in the last decade.

title: More Than a Breath of Fresh Air
description: Growing up in the Stanley M. Isaacs Houses on 92ndStreet and First Avenue in Manhattan, Yvette Vasquez was never allowed to play outside. But around the projects there was mostly just asphalt littered with crack vials, recalled Ms. Vasquez, who is now 30. There was nothing to look forward to, she said, until she was 9, when the Fresh Air Fund sent her to spend two glorious weeks with a host family in St. Catharines, Ontario.

title: A Very Pricey Pineapple
description: Lets talk about talking pineapples.

title: United States Talks Fail as Pakistanis Seek Apology
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The first concentrated high-level talks aimed at breaking a five-month diplomatic deadlock between the United States and Pakistan ended in failure on Friday over Pakistani demands for an unconditional apology from the Obama administration for an airstrike. The White House, angered by the recent spectacular Taliban attacks in Afghanistan, refuses to apologize.

title: A Year Older, but as Good as Ever
description: It is easy to bet that a players skills will erode with time. Inevitably, you will be right. Jamie Moyer aside, no player lasts forever.
