title: Big 3 Are Expected to Reunite for Game 1
description: MIAMI  Since the Heat beat the Knicks on April 15, their Big Three has been reduced to the Big Two, then the Big One and now the Big Question Mark.

title: Stuff Between Some Cake Layers
description: Administrivial Tournament/Will Shortz-Spotting Alert! If you live near Providence, Rhode Island and would like to enjoy some fresh puzzles constructed by the amazing minds of the Brown University Puzzle Club, constructors Natan Last, Aimee Lucido, Jonah Kagan, Joey Weissbrot, and Zoe Wheeler invite one and all to their Brown Annual Crossword Tournament, hosted by Will Shortz and being held tomorrow on campus in a building called LIST. The tournament runs from noon to 3:00 p.m., and the tournament puzzles will run at a later date here in The New York Times.

title: No Less Irreverent at Age 68
description: A lot of people come up to me and say, Peel, I thought you were dead, said David Peel, who is not only alive but basically living the same life he led 40 years ago, when he was a muse for the Yippie and hippie movements in New York City.

title: Persistence Has Yet to Pay Off in an Effort to Run a Newsstand
description: Mohammad Sikder, a baker turned cabby from Bangladesh who supports a family of six, had resolved to escape the stresses of a taxi drivers life.

title: Chandlers Illness Could Be Knicks First Postseason Test
description: MIAMI  On the eve of the eve of their first playoff run together, the revived, reconstituted Knicks gathered around the dinner table to talk history, hopes and the Miami Heat. In this last leisurely moment Thursday night, the only concern was the empty chair where a 7-foot defensive sentinel should have been sitting.

title: In Report, Details of Misconduct Accusations Against Former Finance Chief
description: A former Bloomberg official asked a real estate company to help her domestic partner find an apartment just weeks after her agency sharply reduced the firms tax burden, and she was romantically involved with two subordinates, according to the results of a city investigation released on Friday.

title: Jogs, Shows and Lots of Caffeine
description: If his Sunday is not frenetic, Vin Cipolla, the constantly caffeinated president of the Municipal Art Society, feels as if something is missing  or it means he has retreated to his country house in Pound Ridge, N.Y., for fresh air and a daylong hike. But mostly, Mr. Cipolla, 55, sticks close to the cityscape he has focused on preserving and reinvigorating since leaving his position as president of the National Park Foundation in 2009. Marathon walks and Central Park jogs are Sunday habits. He lives near Columbus Circle with his wife, Celine McDonald, 55, a landscape painter, and the youngest of their four daughters, Gabriella, 23. Their second-youngest, Olivia, 26, has an apartment in the same building.

title: For Goalie, Smooth Transition From Minors to Sports Biggest Stage
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  When the Washington Capitals season began, goaltender Braden Holtby was the odd man out. The team had signed the veteran Tomas Vokoun to battle Michal Neuvirth for the starting job. And despite an impressive finish to the 2010-11 season, Holtby found himself back with the Hershey Bears, the Capitals American Hockey League affiliate.

title: With Support Off as Events Begin, Komen Works to Revive Its Image
description: Susan G. Komen for the Cure may have popularized the color pink as a universal symbol of breast cancer fund-raising. But these days, many of the breast cancer foundations local affiliates are singing the blues.

title: Raid to Kill Bin Laden Helped United States, Panetta Says
description: WASHINGTON  Killing Osama bin Laden was not a silver bullet that destroyed Al Qaeda, Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta said on Friday, but he asserted that his death weakened the terrorist group and made the United States more safe.

title: The Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: Chesapeake Energys decision to end a controversial compensation plan for its chief executive and questions about aggressive debt-collection practices by Accretive Health were among the top stories this week.

title: Turning Unused Acres Green
description: THE city of New York owns thousands of slivers of unused land, and about a year ago, a group of Brooklyn gardeners had an idea: identify all the vacant lots in the borough, then help neighborhood residents take them over. They built an online map, then a mobile app, with information about the plots, including the names and phone numbers of the agencies that owned them. They called themselves 596 Acres, after the total area of unused public land in Brooklyn, according to city data.

title: Fewer Illegal Immigrants Stopped for Traffic Violations Will Face Deportation
description: Fewer illegal immigrants stopped by police for minor traffic violations would be held for deportation under changes announced Friday to a federal fingerprinting program, Department of Homeland Security officials said.

title: On East 84th Street
description: Lillian Jacobs has lived on East 84th Street in Yorkville for 100 years. The area has maintained its charm and is home to many longtimers.

title: A Lopsided Lacrosse Rivalry Receives a Jolt
description: BALTIMORE  The campuses of Loyola and Johns Hopkins sit a mile apart in this citys northern end, linked by tree-lined Charles Street as well as a feverish enthusiasm for lacrosse.

title: 100 Years of Staying Put
description: WHEN Lillian Jacobs was 2, in 1911 or 12, her family moved from the Lower East Side into a tenement building on East 84th Street, just off York Avenue, then known as Avenue A. Her parents ran a candy store on the buildings ground floor, catering to the newly arrived immigrants from Germany, Hungary, Austria and Ireland.

title: Giants Find Big-Play Potential and Smile With Pick
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When David Wilson met with the Giants during the scouting combine in Indianapolis, he wore a three-piece suit and congratulated team executives for winning the Super Bowl. A Giants official told Wilson, a running back, that he was one of the few prospects who had done so. It was a gesture that suited his personality.

title: Wife of Ex-Aide Testifies About Work for Edwards
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  Cheri Young, whose husband, Andrew, is the leading witness in the federal corruption trial against John Edwards, followed him onto the witness stand on Friday, recounting in a steely voice how much her husband had adored the former senator and vice-presidential nominee.

title: Death of Spy, Zipped Into Bag, Spawns Theories and Inquest
description: LONDON  Britain, home to the MI6 spy agency that inspired the James Bond stories and the billion-dollar film franchise, has been wrestling this week with one of the countrys strangest real-life spy mysteries in a generation, one that has become known popularly as the case of the spy in the bag.

title: A Different Intersection of Church and Politics
description: On Tuesday afternoon, on the steps of Federal Hall, in Lower Manhattan, where Occupy Wall Street protesters have been contained in recent weeks, Loren Hart, a conservatively dressed man of 33, sat reading a newspaper as he held a sign that gave quiet expression to pervasive grievances: The economy is failing us. Our climate is worsening every day. Perhaps we should make some serious changes. Mr. Hart arrived in New York from North Carolina in October to join the Occupy movement with the expectation that he would stay a few days, but he has felt unmotivated to leave.

title: Bad News for Pelfrey Is Break for Young Pitcher
description: DENVER  The fall of one player represents an opportunity for another. As the Mets on Friday began to handle the immediate repercussions of Mike Pelfreys season-ending elbow injury, there was a familiar echo to the situation for Dillon Gee, a pitcher who benefited from a similar situation almost exactly a year ago.

description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Before the Jets could want him, Quinton Coples had to be turned away. This was five years ago, when Coples and his mother, Gail, walked into the football office at Hargrave Military Academy in Chatham, Va. The coach, Robert Prunty, apologized and said that his roster was full.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,934 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Young Peoples Priorities
description: Judging by this weeks debate, you would think that student loans are young peoples only priority. Theyre not. In fact, a cleverly designed survey released this week by Harvard Universitys Institute of Politics asked respondents ages 18 to 29 to choose between pairings of issues to determine which ones they felt were more important. Among domestic issues, creating jobs almost always won, while combating climate change almost never did. Immigration is also a losing issue (except when paired with climate change), while access to affordable health care is a winner. I found the results so interesting that I wanted to share them. Enjoy.

title: One Passed Ball by Tigers Erases Night of Control Problems From Nova
description: The temperature at Yankee Stadium was a baseball-unfriendly 47 degrees at game time Friday, with a chilly breeze starching the pennants. It was so frosty that even Justin Verlander, the Detroit Tigers right-handed ace, was not as precise and diabolical as usual.

title: Uncertainty Hangs Over the Nets Brooklyn Lineup
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Four players and Coach Avery Johnson gave their parting words as members of the New Jersey Nets on Friday afternoon. Although the team will continue to practice a stones throw from the Meadowlands in the near future, they will be doing so as the Brooklyn Nets.

title: Bin Ladens Death Made U.S. Safe, Panetta Says, Recalling Nail-Biting Moments of Raid
description: It has almost been one year since Osama bin Laden was killed in his compound in Abbottabad, Pakistan, by a United States Navy SEAL team. Ahead of the May anniversary, Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta told reporters on Friday that bin Ladens death was not a silver bullet, but that it, along with the killings of other Qaeda leaders, had prevented them from having the command and control capability to be able to put together an attack similar to 9/11.

title: Enoch Williams, New York Councilman, Dies at 84
description: Enoch H. Williams, a former New York City councilman who used his leadership positions to pass a law banning smoking in most public spaces and to help stop the Giuliani administration from selling city-owned hospitals, but who also came under fire from gay rights groups, died on Tuesday at his home in Heathrow, Fla. He was 84.

title: Joe Muranyi, Clarinetist for Louis Armstrong, Dies at 84
description: Joe Muranyi, a clarinetist whose mastery of pre-World War II jazz led to a four-year stint with Louis Armstrongs last band  and to an improbable moment of pop stardom  died on April 20 in Manhattan. He was 84.

title: In a Single Half-Inning, the Mets Come Undone
description: DENVER  There was something cruel about the half-inning, how it stubbornly refused to end.

title: Phoenix Wins Game 1 in Overtime
description: Ray Whitney scored 14 minutes 4 seconds into overtime as the host Phoenix Coyotes defeated the Nashville Predators, 4-3, in the opening game of their Western Conference semifinal series.

title: Dont Just Sit There
description: ONE lesson Ive learned while writing about fitness is that few things impinge on an active life as much as writing about fitness  all that time spent hunched before a computer or puzzling over scientific journals, the countless hours of feckless, seated procrastination. While writing about the benefits of exercise, my muscles slackened. Fat seeped insidiously into my blood, liver and ventricles. Stupor infiltrated my brain.

title: Refinery Venture Reflects Easing of India-Pakistan Relations
description: The billionaire Lakshmi N. Mittal and an Indian oil company are formally opening a $4 billion refinery on the northern border with Pakistan, as India and Pakistan seek to stimulate trade, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Police Clash With Malaysia Protesters Seeking Electoral Reforms
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  The police fired tear gas and water cannons on Saturday at thousands of protesters here calling for free and fair elections, in one of the largest rallies in Malaysia in recent years.

title: Energy Meeting Hopes to Bring Light to Millions of Homes
description: Their work is not sexy and generates little controversy or media coverage, but a group of energy and environment ministers from 22 countries and the European Union is claiming substantial progress in spreading energy efficiency and more affordable energy around the globe, John M. Broder writes in Green blog of The New York Times.

title: Afghan Official Survives Attack by Insurgents
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  In an episode with worrisome significance for the security industry, two Taliban insurgents with pistols hidden in their shoes evaded an American-operated full-body scanner and nearly succeeded in assassinating the governor of Kandahar on Saturday.

title: Stranded on a Not-So-Strange Land
description: For five years, Jiri Makovec, 35, a Czech photographer, stranded himself on an island.

title: Following A Spirit Of Discovery
description: Since forming a dozen years ago the Wayne Shorter Quartet has held to a rigorously thorough standard of discovery, welcoming not only flashes of inspiration but also irresolute pauses, stubborn quandaries and heady longueurs.

title: Remarks by Former Official Fuel Israeli Discord on Iran
description: JERUSALEM  The recently retired chief of Israels internal security agency accused the government of misleading the public about the likely effectiveness of an aerial strike on Irans nuclear facilities, ratcheting up the criticism of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Defense Minister Ehud Barak from the countrys security establishment.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: Approximately 152 senior police officers from the state have been transferred following a state cabinet decision. This announcement comes ahead of the bi-annual formality of shifting the government offices to the summer capital of Srinagar from the winter capital, Jammu. (Kashmir Live)

title: The Horror of the Handshake
description: You could put together a good-sized mob of people who would probably rather step on John Terrys hand than shake it. Start with Wayne Bridge. And Alexis Snchez. And Tottenhams defense. And nightclub bouncers. And Americans.

title: Comparing Quinton Coples With Jason Pierre-Paul
description: Quinton Coples, the new Jets defensive end, has said that his game most resembles that of the Giants star Jason Pierre-Paul.

title: A Conversation With: Actor Prosenjit Chatterjee
description: Dibakar Banerjees film Shanghai, scheduled for a June 8 release, brings Bengali actor Prosenjit Chatterjee back to Bollywood after a 20-year hiatus. I needed a sexy leading man, Mr. Banerjee, famous for his National Award-winning Khosla Ka Ghosla and Oye Lucky! Lucky Oye!, told a news conference in Kolkata on Monday.

title: Giants Thrilled to Land Rueben Randle
description: The Giants seemed overjoyed Friday night to land L.S.U. receiver Rueben Randle. By the time the last pick of the second round rolled around, Randle was the highest player on their board  by far, the Giants said. Why didnt they trade up just to be sure they could grab him? General Manager Jerry Reese said the Giants hadnt had great experiences with that strategy. So they waited  We dont panic  and were rewarded. The Giants actually considered taking Randle at the end of the first round.

title: Nine Things I Learned From Reading Every Last Word of The New Yorker
description: Lets first dispense with the question of whether I really read every one of the 55,000 words in this weeks New Yorker. All I can say is I tried. One of my favorite discoveries was a quote from Walt Frazier. As a girl growing up in New York City, I was obsessed with the Knicks guard. Back then you could write him a worshipful letter, care of the Garden, and get back a signed black-and-white photo. Once before a home game, my friend Paul and I saw him on the street after he got out of his Rolls. We asked him for his autograph  two adoring 12-year-olds offering up a couple of pieces of lined paper  and he told us he was only signing copies of a book about him that recently had been published, and then he turned away. I still loved him. But it was hard not to harbor a grudge. And then came all those years of his jangling play-by-play commentary. But I couldnt help but feel a new sense of tenderness when he explained himself in Talk of the Town: When I was a player, I rarely read anything, unless it was about me. Now I get The Times Arts & Leisure section, where they critique the plays: Riveting! Mesmerizing! Provocative! Profound! Dazzling! All these different words. I like the way they sound, so I write them down and use them.

title: For Northwestern Football Deonte Gibson Is a Burgeoning Star
description: Ask Northwestern football players about Deonte Gibson, and they will all say the same thing.

title: Writers of the World
description: From April 30 to May 6, 100 writers from 25 countries will be in New York for a festival sponsored by the PEN American Center.

title: At Google, a Moment to Pause
description: In the driven, intensely competitive atmosphere that is Googles headquarters in Mountain View, Calif., a popular course teaches employees how to defuse emotions and tap their inner serenity and resilience.

description: Mountain View, Calif.

title: Euro Austerity, Continued
description: Martin Wolf does his own version of my austerity versus growth analysis; he uses a different measure of austerity and a different time period, but the results are basically the same. Martins graph, which would be unreadably small in this format, is here.

title: A Shakespeare Olympiad in Dozens of Languages
description: The plays of William Shakespeare have such universal appeal that they have been performed in various languages worldwide. Now audiences can enjoy the Bard in multiple languages in one fell swoop. Globe to Globe, a festival from Londons Globe Theater, showcases 37 of Shakespeares plays performed in different languages by 37 international companies.

title: Where The Productivity Went
description: Larry Mishel has a systematic breakdown of the reasons for worker income stagnation since 1973. He starts with the familiar divergence: productivity up 80 percent, the compensation (including benefits) of the median worker up only 11 percent. Where did the productivity go?

title: Bombs Add to Soccer Festival Woes
description: LONDON  The decision to invite Ukraine to co-host Europes most important soccer tournament this year was a controversial one  and that was before four bomb explosions rocked the countrys third largest city on Friday.

title: The Rail Bookshelf: Kentucky Derby Dreams
description: In the winter of 2009, I went to Taylor Made Farm in Nicholasville, Ky., to chronicle a thoroughbred breeding farm. Thirty-five thousand thoroughbred foals were born in North America that year, about 400 of them at Taylor Made. I stayed with the farms 2009 foals, focusing on about a dozen of them, through the seasons of their young life until they were sold at the nations premiere yearling sales at Saratoga and Keeneland in 2010.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Google Translation and a Robot Weaver
description: Here are some of the most interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Friday. There are more here.

title: Protests in Malaysia
description: Police unleashed tear gas and chemical-laced water Saturday at thousands of demonstrators who staged one of Malaysias largest street rallies in years, demanding fair rules for national elections expected soon.

title: Business Day Live | Chade-Meng Tan
description: April 27, 2012 - Google's Chade-Meng Tan on compassion in the corporate world.

title: Four Fiscal Charts
description: Heres an exercise I did for my own edification  and to prepare for questions on book tour  but others may be interested in the results. I wanted a simple answer to the people who always insist that we must be having massive fiscal stimulus because we have a big budget deficit; my answer is that the deficit is a result of the depressed economy, but how do we show that without getting too much into the weeds?

title: A Humbled Gap Tries a Fresh Coat of Pep
description: THIS cant be a Gap: the mannequins look kind of happy.

title: Telling Strength From Weakness
description: ARE the perils posed by too-big-to-fail banks a thing of the past?

title: The Calming Effect of Central Banks
description: EUROPE is hitting another rough patch. But this time, the troubles have barely rattled world financial markets. Thats a huge change.

title: Refocused, After a Staggering Loss
description: IVE always handled stress well. Any job would bore me if it didnt have an element of stress. Part of my coping secret is that I compartmentalize. So when Im at work, Im 100 percent at work. When Im mothering, Im 100 percent Mommy.

title: Hey, Not So Fast on European Austerity
description: EUROPEAN policy makers just dont get it. To hear them talk, youd think that Europe was on the right path. Troubled countries just need more of the same, they say  more fiscal austerity, more labor market flexibility, more price stability  and the European crisis will be licked.

title: Chicken Scratches vs. Electronic Prescriptions
description: AS e-mail and texting have become our favored means of written communication, handwriting has almost disappeared. Penmanship is becoming a modern form of hieroglyphics, intelligible only to literary scholars.

title: The Man Is a Coach. Period.
description: KENSINGTON, Conn.  The unofficial Chicago Bulls fan club of central Connecticut gathered around a 110-inch television one Thursday earlier this month. One family composed most of the club, four parents and two siblings who live here within half a mile of one another, the entire brood close by, always, except for one.

title: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Im sure that most of us have seen Mel Taubs Puns and Anagrams puzzles, but if you are just tuning in, PandA puzzles are crossword-style puzzles whose clues are precisely what the title implies: they are usually all puns or anagrams. Some of them require putting words together, and Ill talk about that in a bit.

title: International Bird Rescue
description: In 1971, two oil tankers collided near the Golden Gate Bridge. The spill of 800,000 gallons of oil contaminated the coastline and wildlife, including countless aquatic birds. Volunteers who treated 7,000 of the oil-coated birds later created International Bird Rescue in Berkeleys Aquatic Park. International Bird Rescue, which is now at the edge of the Suisun Marsh in Fairfield, gives baths, medical treatments and tender attention to scores of sick, injured or oil-coated birds at a state-of-the-art hospital. LOUISE RAFKIN

title: In Oakland, Officials Say Police Used Illegal Tactics
description: Last week, as Oakland prepared for what organizers expect to be the largest Occupy Oakland protest since November, the citys police department called a news conference to announce major reforms to its crowd-control policies.

title: Shanahan Defends Rulings and Says Theyve Made a Difference
description: As Brendan Shanahan approached his Midtown office building Thursday afternoon, a hockey fan was waiting for him. During Shanahans 20 years as an N.H.L. player, he embraced meeting fans. But Shanahan now wears a suit to work as the leagues disciplinarian, and people are rarely happy with him.

title: Canceled Muni Bus Runs Draw New Attention to Drivers Absenteeism Rates
description: Last Monday, Muni canceled 43 bus runs, leaving passengers with long waits, with no warning and no explanation for the delays.

title: For Jockey, Road to Belmont Runs Through the Derby
description: When Julien Leparoux traveled from his native France to the United States in 2003, his only goal was to master English. He had never ridden in a horse race.

title: Temple Makes Austin the Place to Find Peace and Joy
description: Each morning Lama Lobtsul, the lama in residence at the Buddhist center Palri Pema Od Ling in Austin, enters the temple and performs the important task of arranging offerings of water, candles and incense in front of the rare statue of Guru Rinpoche.

title: Cultivating Endorsements for That Rainy Day
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: On High-Speed Rails, a New Challenger in Italy
description: FLORENCE, Italy  It took over five years, a roughly $1.3 billion investment and a neck-and-neck race with Italys national rail lines to get Europes first private operator of high-speed, domestic trains on track.

title: The Dewhurst Legacy: Skilled Politician or Pushover?
description: If Lt. Gov. David Dewhurst wins his bid to replace Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison, who is retiring, he will leave a job he has had for nearly 10 years  longer than all but two other lieutenant governors in Texas history.

title: Firm Hand Guides Young Team in Aftermath of Tragedy
description: YAROSLAVL, Russia  After three decades coaching Russian hockey, Pyotr Vorobyov is not easily daunted.

title: Daring Circle, Now at Risk, Aided Activists Flight in China
description: BEIJING  For months, Chen Guangcheng, one of Chinas best-known dissidents, played a cat-and-mouse game with the phalanx of guards encircling his home. He dug a tunnel to try to escape, a friend says, but was found out. And he sneaked out a video that alerted his supporters to the smothering confinement he said he and his wife endured at the hands of the men who kept them virtual prisoners in their rural farmhouse.

title: White Sox Have First Base Covered
description: For decades, the premier positions for excellence through the decades were center field for the Yankees and left field for the Boston Red Sox. Maybe we should consider another: first base for the Chicago White Sox.

title: Reveling in a Tech Life
description: I GREW up outside London and attended a private French school, the Lyce Franais de Londres. My parents owned a printing company in London and would drop off my younger brother and me in the morning and pick us up after work. I attended that school from age 4 until I enrolled in the University of Oxford to study chemistry.

title: A Beating in the Stands, Followed by One on the Field
description: Ty Cobb ruled the baseball world in the era before Babe Ruth. Fiery, profane and bearing a long list of grudges, Cobb often dominated games while turning almost everyone else into an adversary. He baited pitchers, argued with umpires and slid into bases with sharpened spikes; on and off the field, he was involved in numerous, often violent, incidents. Even his teammates disliked him.

title: How to Adopt Mentors Without Really Asking
description: This interview with  Shellye Archambeau, chief executive of  MetricStream, a firm that helps companies meet compliance standards, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Fighting for Gold, Alongside Her Brother
description: The Lopez siblings earned three tae kwon do medals for the United States at the 2008 Beijing Olympics. Mark won a silver, and Diana and Steven each took home a bronze. Their oldest brother, Jean, coaches Team Lopez in Houston.

title: Lawmaker Sees New Crisis at Texas Youth Lockups
description: Five years after instituting a sweeping overhaul in the wake of sexual and physical abuse scandals at Texas youth lockups, a senior lawmaker is again calling the situation at the facilities a crisis that jeopardizes the safety of youths.

title: Trying to Draw Fans in a Baseball Town
description: CINCINNATI  The first voice many travelers hear at the Cincinnati/Northern Kentucky International Airport belongs to Marty Brennaman, who has broadcast the Reds on radio for nearly 40 years. Between announcements from the Transportation Security Administration, Brennaman beckons fans to Great American Ball Park to see Joey Votto, Brandon Phillips and Jay Bruce.

title: Taking a Ride on Italo
description: Locomotives dubbed Italo started speeding around 186 miles an per hour on Saturday, opening a new chapter in European rail travel.

title: Curtis Rises Again as Putts Begin to Fall
description: AVONDALE, La.  Ben Curtis knows how cruel sport can be. His favorite team, the Cleveland Browns, has had two winning seasons since returning to the N.F.L. in 1999. Even in their leanest years, the Browns have recorded at least two victories, which is perhaps why Curtis did not think twice before setting a goal of winning at least once a year on the PGA Tour.

title: Body Found After Bunker Is Stormed
description: Authorities in Washington State blew open a survivalist bunker on Saturday to find what they believe to be the body of a man suspected of killing his wife and daughter  the culmination of a lengthy manhunt that drove officers into the sludge-packed foothills of the Cascade Mountains.

title: Letters: Many Stakeholders in Executive Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: Following the Breadcrumbs on the Data-Sharing Trail
description: WOULD you like to donate to the Obama campaign? Sign up for a college course? Or maybe subscribe to Architectural Digest?

title: Apples Havens: A World of Subsidiaries
description: A collection of documents from the companys overseas units sheds light on how they fit together.

title: Shrinking Corporate Tax Rates
description: Corporate profits are far bigger now than they were in 1977, the year Apple was incorporated and corporate tax rates have fallen.

title: At This Atlanta Barbershop, the Conversation Goes on 24/7
description: ATLANTA  It is 1 a.m., but the night is young for Dre Rosenberg, a 22-year-old clothing stylist here. Later, he will grab drinks with friends and hit the nightclubs in Atlantas wealthiest neighborhood, Buckhead.

title: Apples Response on Its Tax Practices
description: In response to requests for comment on the companys tax practices, Apple provided this statement to The New York Times:

title: How Apple Sidesteps Billions in Taxes
description: RENO, Nev.  Apple, the worlds most profitable technology company, doesnt design iPhones here. It doesnt run AppleCare customer service from this city. And it doesnt manufacture MacBooks or iPads anywhere nearby.

title: Teenager Is Stabbed at a Bronx Subway Station
description: A 19-year-old man was stabbed on a Bronx subway platform early on Saturday after confronting a man whom he suspected of stealing a cellphone on a downtown No. 4 train, the police said.

title: Montague and Capulet as Shiite and Sunni
description: BAGHDAD  It is not poison or a dagger that takes the lives of the young lovers, but a suicide bomb. The Montagues and Capulets are divided not just by family, but also by religious sect. And the dialogue in the Iraqi adaptation of Romeo and Juliet is sprinkled with references to Blackwater, Iranians and the American reconstruction effort.

title: Double Irish With a Dutch Sandwich
description: Numerous companies take advantage of loopholes in international laws to move profits around the world, dodging taxes. Many of these techniques rely on transferring profits on patent royalties to places like Ireland. Here is one technique typical of what Apple and others pioneered.

title: Cease-Fire in Syria Exposes Heavy Price of Just Buying Time
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A United Nations-backed cease-fire has neither stopped the fighting in Syria nor forced the government to pull its troops from civilian neighborhoods. It has been called a failure by activists still dodging bullets on the streets of Syria and by senior Obama administration officials questioned in Congress last week.

title: Casilla Is the New Closer by the Bay
description: The San Francisco Giants drafted Brian Wilson in the 24th round in 2003, knowing his elbow was damaged. They suggested Wilson recover from reconstructive elbow surgery under their supervision, rather than return to Louisiana State, and he agreed.

title: Durants Modest Aspiration: To Just Relax and Play Ball
description: On July 7, 2010, amid the rolling of drums and the heralding of trumpets as the long-awaited moment neared, ESPN announced that in a one-hour special, LeBron James would reveal his choice from among his hometown team, Cleveland, and glamour-market suitors from New York, Los Angeles, Chicago and Miami.

title: This Week This Week
description: Ill be on Stephanopoulos tomorrow, panel discussion (in front of a live audience) of pancake recipes the economy (surprise).

title: Lin Is Back on the Court, Playing One-on-One
description: MIAMI  Jeremy Lin played one-on-one Saturday afternoon, an indication that he is ahead of schedule in his recovery from knee surgery. But his availability for the Knicks first-round playoff series against the Miami Heat remains uncertain.

title: In the Philippines, Haunted by History
description: THE Philippines is haunted by its relationship with the United States. I remember the day, in 1991, when the Military Bases Agreement between the two countries was rescinded. The headlines yelled, finally: Freedom! But worrywarts held on to their beads. Clark Air Force Base and Subic Naval Base were Americas largest overseas outposts  powerful vestiges of colonial rule decades after the American occupation, which lasted from 1899 to 1946, had ended. In American history books those decades have fallen into an Orwellian memory hole: lost or abridged.

title: For Jets, Harnessing Stephen Hills Speed
description: No, Matt Waldman of the Rookie Scouting Portfolio did not write a preview series on every single player who was drafted these past three days. But coincidentally in the past few months, his blog has featured several players who have been chosen by the Giants and the Jets. And coincidentally, Matt has helped the Fifth Down preview the draft. So here are some outtakes from his coverage of wide receiver Stephen Hill of Georgia Tech, chosen by the Jets with the 43rd pick after they surrendered two late-round picks to move up.

title: A Universal Language of Sports-Talk Radio
description: BARCELONA, Spain  Before the big game that night, the radio caller wanted to talk about his team. He wanted to rant and to plead, to rationalize and to predict. He wanted, perhaps most of all, to complain.

title: A World Title Match Without the Best Players
description: Viswanathan Anand and Boris Gelfand will have to forget their recent struggles when they begin their match for the world title in Moscow a week from Thursday.

title: Base Serves as Home for Children Caught at Border
description: SAN ANTONIO  At lunchtime, teenage boys in red and blue T-shirts stood in line as they entered a hushed cafeteria for hamburgers and hot dogs. Just days earlier, many of them risked their lives crossing the border from Mexico into the United States, but now they were spending their time in spotless, orderly rooms, with police officers ensuring their safety, registered nurses monitoring their health and a host of board games, movies and outdoor activities keeping them entertained.

title: If Peas Can Talk, Should We Eat Them?
description: Imagine a being capable of processing, remembering and sharing information  a being with potentialities proper to it and inhabiting a world of its own. Given this brief description, most of us will think of a human person, some will associate it with an animal, and virtually no ones imagination will conjure up a plant.

title: Griffin Will Help Introduce a New Dimension
description: Bill Polian was at the draft last week, wondering about the future of the N.F.L. Just a few months removed from his job as the president of the Indianapolis Colts, Polian is still familiar with the players who are entering the league, the ones he was scouting not long ago. He remembers the first time he saw in person Robert Griffin III, the second overall pick.

title: He Is 56, and Short, but Stars at 3 Positions
description: Onstage at the Longacre Theater, Peter Scolari is in Magic/Bird, slipping in and out of characters, changing in and out of blazers, pullovers, warm-up suits and sneakers, and moving in and out of accents.

title: For Sale Online: Yankees Cap (Used)
description: David Wells was in Detroit last Saturday, preparing for a broadcast the next day, when he watched the final inning of Philip Humbers perfect game on television. As Humber wobbled against the leadoff man in the ninth inning, Wells rooted him on.

title: Loyal Companion Helps a Veteran Regain Her Life After War Trauma
description: SAN DIEGO  The hovering aircraft was just a plain-vanilla traffic chopper, a benignly common species to Southern California skies. But its mere presence overhead was enough to make Tori Stitt stiffen.

title: Directors Heading Down New Paths
description: Something to Live For

title: A New Pawn in Chinas Two Tugs of War
description: BEIJING  The escape of a blind human rights lawyer from house arrest, and apparently into the hands of American officials here, came at an excruciatingly awkward time for the Chinese leadership as it struggles to preserve a cohesive front after the spectacular dismissal of Bo Xilai, a member of Chinas Politburo.

title: This Season, Celtics Are at Once Hobbling and Walking Tall
description: WALTHAM, Mass.  The Celtics played the first game of the lockout-shortened 2011-12 season, opening against the Knicks at Madison Square Garden on Dec. 25.

title: Questions of Bias and Balance
description: Re A Hard Look at the President (April 22): I like your push for The Times to avoid bias in covering the presidential election. It strikes me as admirable even though, as a liberal, I naturally think that charges of bias against The Times are often overheated.

title: The Post-Cash, Post-Credit-Card Economy
description: YOU walk into a cafe, order a macchiato, give your name to the barista and let him give you the once-over. Thats it. Payment made.

title: Weapons of Peculiar Destruction
description: The special actions of our revolutionary armed forces will start soon to meet the reckless challenge of the group of traitors, the North Korean military commands special operation action group said in a statement. ... They will reduce all the ratlike groups and the bases for provocations to ashes in three or four minutes, in much shorter time, by unprecedented peculiar means and methods of our own style.

title: Thomas P. Campbell
description: Thomas P. Campbell is the director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.

title: Dancap Leaves Prince of Broadway Production
description: Dancap Productions has pulled out as lead producer of Prince of Broadway, the musical retrospective of the career of the Tony Award-winning producer and director Harold Prince, which is aiming to open on Broadway in November.

title: A Romney Rambler Looks Back
description: ON Tuesday night, Mitt Romney stood at a lectern in New Hampshire, the state where he first announced his candidacy nearly 11 months ago, and unofficially assumed the mantle of the Republican Party.

title: Terrorist Plots, Hatched by the F.B.I.
description: THE United States has been narrowly saved from lethal terrorist plots in recent years  or so it has seemed. A would-be suicide bomber was intercepted on his way to the Capitol; a scheme to bomb synagogues and shoot Stinger missiles at military aircraft was developed by men in Newburgh, N.Y.; and a fanciful idea to fly explosive-laden model planes into the Pentagon and the Capitol was hatched in Massachusetts.

title: Warrior in Chief
description: THE president who won the Nobel Peace Prize less than nine months after his inauguration has turned out to be one of the most militarily aggressive American leaders in decades.

title: Playoff Teams Have Strength in Reserve
description: Every good team needs strong play from its bench. With the playoffs set to begin, the following bench players were the most productive reserves, ordered by player efficiency rating, among those averaging 15 to 20 minutes a game. They may not be famous, but they are often pivotal to their teams chances of advancing.

title: Needing to Get Faster, the Jets Act Quickly
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The two defining plays of the Jets disappointing 2011 season did more than produce anguish and heartbreak. They also informed the teams strategy for this years draft.

title: A Senator Fights Back
description: It is dangerous to challenge the funnel cloud of corporate and right-wing political advertising this year, but Senator Claire McCaskill, Democrat of Missouri, has decided to fight back. She is running commercials that talk directly about the ads trying to prevent her re-election.

title: Cozy Deal
description: Congress long ago shirked its responsibility to provide the Food and Drug Administration with sufficient money to do its job. So the companies that make drugs and medical devices  complaining that it took too long to win approval for their products  offered to pay user fees if the F.D.A. would hire more people to evaluate their applications. Critics charge that those cozy cash-fed agreements have given industry far too much influence over the regulatory process. Industry says that without the money, patients would have to wait far too long to get access to new treatments.

title: Truth and Atonement in North Carolina
description: North Carolina is about to provide a bittersweet postscript to the sad and brutal history of eugenics in America. Of the 32 states that once had laws for compulsory sterilization of people deemed feeble-minded, moronic and otherwise undesirable as parents, none was more aggressive. In North Carolina, the power to recommend sterilization was extended beyond physicians to welfare workers charged with cutting the cost of the public dole.

title: We Are All Nuns
description: CATHOLIC nuns are not the prissy traditionalists of caricature. No, nuns rock!

title: The Torrent of Spring
description: Spring is the torrential season. On a bright, blue-skied day in April or May, it can feel as if youre standing in a river of biological change, whether youre in Central Park or out in the country. Everything seems to be regenerating  every species of plant, animal and insect  all of them cued to the new light and the new warmth. Its as though were living in three kinds of time at once: geological time, which is too slow for us to grasp, human time, which is just right, and tulip time, which comes and goes in the blink of an eye.

title: Bishops Play Church Queens as Pawns
description: WASHINGTON

title: Words of the Prophets
description: Beirut, Lebanon

title: The Human Cost of Zero Tolerance
description: There is no proof that the zero-tolerance policing adopted by New York and other cities in the 1990s had anything to do with the decline in violent crime across the nation. Crime also dropped in jurisdictions that did not use the approach.

title: The Imperiled Promise of College
description: FOR a long time and for a lot of us, college was more or less a synonym for success. We had only to go. We had only to graduate. And if we did, according to parents and high-school guidance counselors and everything we heard and everything we read, we could pretty much count on a career, just about depend on a decent income and more or less expect security. A diploma wasnt a piece of paper. It was an amulet.

title: Sunday Dialogue: When to Hold Recall Votes
description: Readers debate what misdeeds justify an officials early exit.

title: Incredible Shrinking Country
description: THE Children of Men, P. D. Jamess 1992 novel, is set in a future where the worlds male population has become infertile, and an aging Britain is adapting to the human races gradual extinction. Women push dolls in baby carriages. Families baptize kittens. There are state-run national porn shops to stimulate the flagging male libido. Suicide flourishes. Immigrants are welcomed as guest laborers but expelled once they become too old to work. The last children born on earth  the so-called Omegas  have grown up to be bored, arrogant, antisocial and destructive.

title: A First Round Filled With Close Games and Surprises
description: The unpredictability of the Stanley Cup playoffs was evident in the competitiveness of the opening round, which included a dethroning of the champion Boston Bruins.

title: Amos Vogel, Champion of Films, Dies at 91
description: Amos Vogel, who exerted an influence on the history of film that few other non-filmmakers can claim, founding Cinema 16, which became the nations largest membership film society, and directing the first New York Film Festival, died on Tuesday at his home in Greenwich Village. He was 91.

title: Marty and Nick Jr. Go to America
description: I PAID my first visit to America in 1958, at the age of 9, and I liked it so much that I stayed for almost a year. Before we embarked on the Queen Elizabeth, my brother Philip (age 10) and I took the wise precaution of changing our names. For me it was quite straightforward: I would be known, stateside, as Marty. Philip was more imaginative, adapting one of his middle names and coming up with Nick Jr.  while boldly ignoring the fact that there was no Nick Sr. My middle name, I later realized, would have been perfect just as it was: Louis (my parents were admirers of Louis Armstrong). Anyway, when the great liner approached the glittering immensity of New York, Nick Jr. and Marty were fully prepared.

title: Unexceptionalism: A Primer
description: TO achieve unexceptionalism, the political ideal that would render the United States indistinguishable from the impoverished, traditionally undemocratic, brutal or catatonic countries of the world, do the following:

title: Hello, Martians. Let Moby-Dick Explain
description: LAST night the Martians touched down in the backyard. They were oval and bright pink, with two antlike antennae topped by eyes fringed with sea-anemone lashes. They said theyd come to study America.

title: Saudis Close Embassy in Egypt
description: CAIRO  Saudi Arabia closed its embassy here on Saturday and recalled its ambassador, setting off a diplomatic crisis that seemed to catch Egypts military rulers off guard and left them struggling to repair a rift with a financial benefactor and a long-time ally.

title: Infractions
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Im going to go out on a limb and confess that this is the second pass Im making at writing this post. I trashed the first draft, which is rare. And although she didnt know it until now, I owe Tracy Gray an apology.

title: Explaining a Slowdown in Health Care Spending
description: While the decline in the growth of national health care spending has largely been attributed to the recession, the changing behaviors of consumers and providers may also be a factor. As a share of the economy, health expenditures remained steady from 2009 to 2010.

title: In Hopeful Sign, Health Spending Is Flattening Out
description: WASHINGTON  The growth of health spending has slowed substantially in the last few years, surprising experts and offering some fuel for optimism about the federal governments long-term fiscal performance.

title: How One Hospital Bent the Cost Curve
description: In an article in The Times on Sunday, I look at whether there is more than meets the eye in the slowdown in health care costs.

title: Things I Saw  No. 7
description: Suggestions for what youd like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

title: Rookie Continues His Rise, Taking Rangers Along
description: The fans at Madison Square Garden were on their feet, roaring Chris Kreiders name. Kreider, a rookie forward who was still on his parents cellphone plan when he joined the Rangers from Boston College three weeks ago, had just taken a perfect stretch pass from Derek Stepan and blasted a 43-foot slap shot past Washington goalie Braden Holtby.

title: Just Like That, It All Goes Wrong for the Knicks
description: MIAMI  Tempers flared, jump shots faltered, a knee buckled, the mood darkened. And a Knicks postseason that had inspired so much promise turned quickly, shockingly gloomy Saturday afternoon.

title: Pope Vs. Nuns
description: My Sunday column is about the latest Papal crackdown on nuns, this time targeting the largest organization representing American nuns. I have so much admiration for the nuns Ive seen around the world; I have rather less for the Vatican. Please read the column and let me know if you agree.

title: Garcias Next Start in Question After Another Poor Showing
description: With a collection of bad starts and curious pitches, Freddy Garcia has not done much to help the Yankees this year. But by pitching so poorly, at least he has helped turn a potentially difficult decision into a rather obvious one.

title: Brain Drain Feared as German Jobs Lure Southern Europeans
description: SCHWBISCH HALL, Germany  While much of southern Europe is struggling with soaring unemployment rates, a robust Germany is desperate for educated workers, and it has begun to look south for the solution.

title: Knicks-Heat Replay: Game 1
description: A look at Game 1 of the first-round playoff series between the Knicks and the host Miami Heat, won by Miami, 100-67.

title: For Edwards and Aide, Another Lost Love Story
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  For hour after grueling hour, Andrew Young sat on the witness stand in a small federal courtroom here last week and stared straight ahead, never once facing the man he had once looked upon as a father.

title: One Killed and Dozens Hurt as Tent Collapses in St. Louis
description: At least one person died and 17 people were sent to the hospital when a gust of wind caused a large tent to collapse on baseball fans near Busch Stadium in St. Louis on Saturday, officials said. Five people were in critical condition.

title: F.C.C. Report on Googles Street View Project
description: Google on Saturday made available, with only names redacted, the report of the Federal Communications Commissions findings from a 17-month investigation into Googles collection of sensitive personal data. The F.C.C. had released a more heavily redacted version two weeks earlier.

title: Tigers Young, Accused of Slurs, Could Resume Play Early This Week
description: Delmon Young, the Detroit Tigers outfielder who was arrested and charged with second-degree aggravated harassment Friday, could be back on the field playing for the Tigers early this week.

title: Support From Islamists for Liberal Upends Race in Egypt
description: ABU HOMOS, Egypt  Egypts most conservative Islamists endorsed a liberal Islamist for president late Saturday night, upending the political landscape and confounding expectations about the internal dynamics of the Islamist movement.

title: Mets Get a Look at a Familiar Face
description: DENVER  Jamie Moyer, who is scheduled to start Sunday for the Colorado Rockies, made his big league debut in 1986, the year that the Mets won their last World Series.

title: Data Harvesting at Google Not a Rogue Act, Report Finds
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Googles harvesting of e-mails, passwords and other sensitive personal information from unsuspecting households in the United States and around the world was neither a mistake nor the work of a rogue engineer, as the company long maintained, but a program that supervisors knew about, according to new details from the full text of a regulatory report.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 29
description: Nearly one year after the killing of Osama bin Laden, analysts in Washington are questioning the politicization of his death, and assessing the current state of homeland security. The Obama administration has dispatched John O. Brennan, White House counterterrorism adviser, to discuss the nations overseas challenges on ABCs This Week, CNNs State of the Union and FOXs Fox News Sunday.

title: Rangers-Capitals Replay: Game 1
description: The rookie Chris Kreider broke a 1-1 tie, and the Rangers beat the Capitals, 3-1, in the opening game of their series.

title: For Knicks and Bulls, Differing but Demoralizing Losses
description: MIAMI

title: White House Correspondents Association Dinner Highlights
description: Just as they do every year, the famous officials, journalists and Hollywood stars will gather Saturday night at the White House Correspondents Association dinner for an odd mix of celebrity and wonkdom. Below is a selection of Twitter messages and photos from the event.

title: Recall Election Tests Strategies for November
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  Recall Walker bumper stickers dotted the workers parking lot at the Georgia Pacific paper mill on Day Street here one recent afternoon, proof of their unions role in the effort to oust Gov. Scott Walker from office early for his legislation limiting public employees bargaining rights.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 28, 2012

title: Kreider Speeds Into a Vital Role
description: When Chris Kreider scored to break a 1-1 tie in the third period on Saturday, he did not just electrify the crowd at Madison Square Garden. At a convention of collegiate hockey coaches in Naples, Fla., Jerry York pumped his fist and smiled.

title: Knicks Chandler Loses the Battles
description: MIAMI  Tyson Chandler came to the Knicks in the off-season and became the teams vocal leader, defensive catalyst and possibly the missing piece for a franchise that had not won a playoff series since 2000.

title: Gees Changeups Stifle Rockies, and This Time Mets Hold Lead
description: DENVER  For the second night in a row, the Mets offense hummed, but this time, the effort was not washed away by a deluge of foul pitching and defense.

title: Knee Injury Ends Shumperts Season
description: MIAMI  Iman Shumperts splendid rookie season came to a devastating end Saturday afternoon when he tore the anterior cruciate ligament and the lateral meniscus in his left knee during the Knicks 100-67 playoff loss to the Miami Heat.

title: Much Fodder for Obama at White House Journalists Event
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama poked fun at himself, Congress, the Secret Service, the media and particularly his rival Mitt Romney on Saturday night, mocking his Republican opponent as a fuddy-duddy rich guy who travels with his dog in a cage strapped to the roof of the family car.

title: The Caucus Click: The Week in Pictures
description: Mitt Romney decisively won contests held Tuesday, in Connecticut, Delaware, New York, Pennsylvania and Rhode Island. Newt Gingrich announced that he would suspend his presidential campaign.

title: Giants Stick to Script and Address Some Needs
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Year after year, Giants General Manager Jerry Reese has said that the teams blueprint for the N.F.L. draft revolves around taking the best players available.

title: The Caucus Click: The Week in Pictures
description: A look back at the week on the campaign trail, which included contests in Connecticut, Delaware, New York, Pennsylvania and Rhode Island.  Go to the slide show.

title: Devils Tinker With Lines for Game 1
description: NEWARK  Alexei Ponikarovsky, a 227-pound left wing who gives the Devils some heft, found a white mesh jersey, not a gray one, at his locker before practice Saturday. He has been in the N.H.L. long enough not to ask about the color of his jersey, just to put it on.

Wills II, a retired chief magistrate of Wake County, N.C., officiated.

Roeser and Donald B. Roeser of New Port Richey, Fla. The Rev. Dr. Stephen W. Gentle, a Disciples of Christ minister, officiated at the National City Christian Church in Washington, where he is the senior pastor.

description: David Ricardo Sotomayor and Robert Paul Anderson were married Saturday at the Episcopal Church of St. Mary-in-the-Highlands in Cold Spring, N.Y. Mayor Seth J. Gallagher of Cold Spring officiated, and the Rev. Shane Scott-Hamblen, the churchs rector, led an Episcopal ceremony.

description: Tania Zoriana Mandzy and Neil Kumar Inala were married Thursday in San Jose, Calif. Rich Kulish, a commissioner of civil marriages for Santa Clara County, officiated at the County Government Center. On Saturday, the Rev. Petro Dyachok performed a Ukrainian Catholic ceremony at St. Mary of the Assumption Catholic Mission, which was followed by a Hindu ceremony led by Pandit Padmanaban Chayulu at the Boulder Ridge golf club.

Harrison, a retired judge of the Ingham County Circuit Court in Lansing, Mich., and an uncle of the bride, received permission from the Marriage Bureau of the Family Court of the District of Columbia Superior Court to officiate.

title: Hopkins Beats Loyola
description: Rob Guidas goal with 2.3 seconds left in overtime gave 10th-ranked Johns Hopkins a 10-9 victory over top-ranked Loyola (Md.), which rallied from a 9-5 deficit early in the fourth quarter before dropping its first game of the season.

title: China Blocking All Mention of Chen and His Daring Escape
description: HONG KONG  The improbable late-night escape of the blind lawyer Chen Guangcheng from house arrest in his rural village has thrilled anti-abortion campaigners and human rights groups, while humiliating the security forces who were charged with sealing off Mr. Chen and his family.

title: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
description: Why has the promise of India remained unfulfilled? Basharat Peer enumerates the many reasons for Indias recent failures and uncertain future in an article in Foreign Affairs magazine. The piece argues that while Indias elite and growing middle class have become increasingly vociferous at expounding their aspiration for India to become a great power, the country has little to show for it. Mr. Peer analyzes two popular books from last year  Behind the Beautiful Forevers, by Katherine Boo, and The Beautiful and the Damned, by Siddhartha Deb  to show how increasing inequity hampers the promise of Indias growing international influence.

title: Years Roll By as Famed Tavern Struggles to Reopen
description: It is a question that has been asked before: Whatever happened to Chumleys?

title: Giants Say Adrien Robinson Is the Pierre-Paul of Tight Ends
description: A smile creased General Manager Jerry Reeses face Saturday when he began discussing Adrien Robinson, the Cincinnati tight end whom the Giants selected with the final pick in the fourth round, the 127th selection over all.

title: Were Doomed
description: Update: So you see what I mean. We have a terrible failure of demand  and Carly Fiorina thinks the key problem is excessive taxes on corporations (our effective rate is actually fairly low). Hey, if only we had low rates like Ireland, we could have 14.7 percent unemployment  oh well, never mind.

title: New Model Needed for Race-Day Treatment, a Veterinarian Says
description: The white horse emerged late last year representing promise to restore a limping game; a new age of clean racing, race-day-medication-free racing; but the white horse hung coming down the lane. Too much Lasix, it seems; resulting in an inability to hold sway.

title: Going to Heathrow? A Few Survival Tips
description: Heathrow Airport in London operates at 99 percent capacity, with 1,305 take-offs and landings each day  one every 45 seconds, except during the overnight ban. Since it cant add capacity to ease demand during the Olympic Games in July, the airport authority aims to boost organization on the ground.

title: Disruptions: With No Revenue, an Illusion of Value
description: The gears of Silicon Valley continue to mesh and turn because of money, not necessarily technological innovations. And there are certain things about that money machine that denizens of the Valley would rather keep quiet.

title: The Rail Bookshelf: The Kentucky Derby
description: An excerpt from The Kentucky Derby: How the Run for the Roses Became Americas Premier Sporting Event regarding the controversial 1968 race.

title: Obama Campaign Grapples With New Voter ID Laws
description: WASHINGTON  Field workers for President Obamas campaign fanned out across the country over the weekend in an effort to confront a barrage of new voter identification laws that strategists say threaten the campaigns hopes for registering new voters ahead of the November election.

title: Romney Calls for Protecting Chinese Dissident
description: Mitt Romney weighed in on the looming diplomat crisis between the United States and China, calling on Sunday for the Obama administration to take every measure to protect a blind dissident and his family after his daring escape from house arrest last week.

title: With a Steel Column, a Tower Will Reclaim the Manhattan Sky
description: If the winds are forgiving enough over Lower Manhattan  up where workers can see the whole outline of the islands tip  a steel column will be hoisted into place Monday afternoon atop the exoskeleton of 1 World Trade Center and New York will have a new tallest building.

title: Bill Clinton Deployed to Help Obama Raise Cash
description: WASHINGTON  Former President Bill Clinton is coming to the aid of President Obama on Sunday night in the first of a series of joint fund-raisers intended to tap his deep-pocketed network and marry two wings of a party that have lived together uneasily since their 2008 showdown.

title: The Avengers, a Week Away at Home, Leads Overseas
description: All of Hollywoods action over the weekend was overseas, where Walt Disney Studios released The Avengers in 39 markets and took in $178.4 million. This superhero movie, which arrives in the United States next weekend (kicking off moviedoms summer season), set records in 12 territories.

title: Yankees Send Struggling Garcia to the Bullpen
description: The Yankees starting rotation has been a question mark all season with injuries and ineffectiveness forcing the team to overuse its bullpen and often play from behind. The team made a move to change things Sunday, demoting the struggling Freddy Garcia to the bullpen.

title: Seven Killed as S.U.V. Plunges Into the Bronx Zoo
description: 10:27 p.m. | Updated  The revised version of this post is available here.

title: New Taxicabs Are Green, Literally
description: Call it how you see it: Lime. Mint. Wasabi. Or perhaps you might prefer a nonedible comparison.

title: The Coach, the Biographer and the Last Chapter
description: This wont be another book about Xs and Os, will it? Joe Paternos daughter Mary Kay asked.

title: Protesters in Malaysia Accuse Police of Brutality
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  Displaying bruises and scrapes, participants in a weekend protest said Sunday that the police used brutal tactics to shut down their rally for fair elections, prompting the organizers to demand an inquiry by the countrys Human Rights Commission.

title: A Mysterious Woman With a Past, 300 Years of It
description: As much as Puccinis Tosca, Verdis Aida or Bergs Lulu, Janaceks 1926 opera, The Makropulos Case, comes across as the stunning masterpiece it is only if a production has a soprano who can inhabit the lead role. Here that character is Emilia Marty, the mysterious prima donna at the center of this suspenseful thriller, set in Prague in 1922. On Friday night Karita Mattila sang Marty when the Metropolitan Opera brought back the sleekly modern and inspired 1996 production by Elijah Moshinsky, last seen in 2001.

title: This Revolution Was British, Fired by Libidos
description: Faramerz Dabhoiwala has endured some awkward moments since his new book, The Origins of Sex, an ambitious history of sexuality in 18th-century Britain, was published to rave reviews in that country in January.

title: A Symbiotic Relationship That Just Keeps Growing
description: With all the reports of financial struggles and labor clashes that have dogged the Philadelphia Orchestra this season, you can lose sight of the fact that on any given night this storied institution will probably prove anew that it remains one of the countrys premier ensembles. Certainly no other American orchestra has cemented as durable and fruitful a relationship with Simon Rattle, the chief conductor of the Berlin Philharmonic and one of the worlds more provocative conductors.

title: U.S. Drone Strike Underlines Clash of Interests in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  An American drone strike killed three suspected militants in Pakistans tribal belt on Sunday, an official said, in the first such attack since the countrys Parliament demanded an end to those missions just over two weeks ago.

title: Obesity-Linked Diabetes in Children Resists Treatment
description: Obesity and the form of diabetes linked to it are taking an even worse toll on Americas youths than medical experts had realized. As obesity rates in children have climbed, so has the incidence of Type 2 diabetes, and a new study adds another worry: the disease progresses more rapidly in children than in adults and is harder to treat.

title: Theatrical on the Shell, Intricate at the Core
description: A brainy, adventurous Irish songwriter lives within the flamboyant theatricality of Julie Feeney, whos playing a 10-night stand at the Irish Arts Center through May 6.

title: April 30/ May 1 Media
description: According to my master schedule,

title: Worth Watching: African Men, Hollywood Stereotypes
description: Thanks to a Facebook post by Cameron Sinclair, the executive director of Architecture for Humanity and co-editor of Design Like You Give a Damn,I found this fine effort to get beyond the Hollywood vision of the African man:

title: In Crisis Over Dissident, U.S. Sends Official to Beijing
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration rushed to contain a growing diplomatic crisis between the United States and China, sending a senior diplomat to Beijing to discuss the fate of a blind dissident who fled house arrest last week.

title: Diabetes in Obese Children Is Tough to Treat
description: The first large study of Type 2 diabetes in children has reached a troubling conclusion: Not only are more children developing the type of diabetes associated with obesity, but the disease develops more quickly and is less responsive to treatment, explains Denise Grady in todays New York Times:

title: A Nations Best and Worst, Forged in a Crucible
description: On Nov. 22, 1963, when he was told that John F. Kennedy was dead, and that he was now president, Lyndon B. Johnson later recalled, I was a man in trouble, in a world that is never more than minutes away from catastrophe.

title: When Dancing the Senses, Sometimes No Explanation Is Required
description: Perceptual Motion, the new work presented by Battery Dance Company, is about the five senses. During its course, were clearly told this  in writing. Typed definitions and scientific descriptions of sight, hearing, touch, taste and smell appear on a screen at the beginning of each section; theres a particular pleasure in finding that theres no dumbing down in the way information is stated. Words like somatosensory and mechanoreceptor are part of the script, and at the matinee I attended on Friday at 3LD Art & Technology Center the audience responded with complete attention throughout because of the works serious intelligence.

title: Top Prizes Awarded at Tribeca Film Festival
description: War Witch, the director Kim Nguyens feature about a kidnapped African girl who becomes a child soldier, was named the best narrative feature at the 2012 Tribeca Film Festival, and its star, Rachel Mwanza, below, was named best actress, the festivals organizers announced on Thursday night. Una Noche, a film by Lucy Mulloy about Cuban teenagers who dream of fleeing Havana for Miami, won the best-actor prize, which was split between two of its leads, Dariel Arrechada and Javier Nez Florin; Ms. Mulloy was also named best new narrative director for the film, which additionally was cited for best cinematography in a narrative feature film. (Mr. Nez and another star of the film, Anailn de la Ra de la Torre, disappeared as they were traveling from Cuba to the festival.) All In, Daniel Burmans film about the romantic life of a professional poker player, won for best screenplay, written by Mr. Burman and Sergio Dubcovsky, and The World Before Her, Nisha Pahujas film about competitors in the Miss India pageant, took best documentary feature. Two audience awards were announced on Saturday night: Any Day Now, the director Travis Fines feature inspired by a true story of a gay couple trying to adopt a teenager in Los Angeles during the 1970s, received the audience narrative award, and Burn, Tom Putnam and Brenna Sanchezs film that follows the fire commissioner of Detroit, won the audience documentary award.

title: Powerhouse Theater Summer Season
description: The playwright Itamar Moses (Completeness), the composer Michael Friedman (Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson) and the director Daniel Aukin (4000 Miles) will join together for a musical workshop based on Jonathan Lethems 2003 novel The Fortress of Solitude as part of the Powerhouse Theaters coming summer season. Produced by New York Stage and Film and Vassar College, this years plays and musicals in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., begin on June 22. The schedule also will feature Abigail/1702, a new work by Roberto Aguirre-Sacasa (Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark) that is set a decade after the events depicted in The Crucible by Arthur Miller, and The Power of Duff, a new play by Stephen Belber (Dusk Rings a Bell), in which a news anchor has a spiritual awakening on live television.

title: Footnotes
description: The Joyce Theater has announced that its fall-winter season will include the return of Soledad Barrio and her company Noche Flamenca after a sold-out run at the theater last year. Running Sept. 18 through Jan. 27, the season will also feature a new piece from the choreographer Wen Wei Wang and performances by the dancers Crystal Pite and Russell Maliphant. ... A public memorial tribute to the theater producer and director Theodore Mann, who died in February at 87, will be at 1 p.m. on Tuesday at Circle in the Square Theater, of which he was a founder.

title: Sabathia Controls Detroit as Rodriguez Moves Past Mays on R.B.I. List
description: Alex Rodriguez tied and later passed Willie Mays for eighth place on the career runs batted in list Sunday, but the story of the day for the Yankees was the continuation of C. C. Sabathias hot streak with Chris Stewart behind the plate.

title: Turkish Writer Opens Museum Based on Novel
description: ISTANBUL  The first thing you see are the cigarette butts. There are thousands of them  4,213 to be exact  mounted behind plexiglass on the ground floor of the Nobel laureate Orhan Pamuks new museum, named for and based on his 2008 novel, The Museum of Innocence.

title: Where Nations Debate, Harmony of a Jazzy Kind
description: From its earliest days, when the pianist Jelly Roll Morton spoke of a Spanish tinge, jazz has been extraordinarily open to international influences. Now its official. Last fall Unesco  the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization  designated jazz a universal music of freedom and creativity and decreed that henceforth every April 30 is to be celebrated around the world as International Jazz Day.

title: In Vast Jungle, U.S. Troops Aid in Search for Kony
description: OBO, Central African Republic  It has got to be one of the oddest matchups in United States military history.

title: Ballet Star Gazes Down and Rises Up
description: On Saturday at the David H. Koch Theater a dozen or so of the foremost ballet dancers in the world performed. And yet the star of the evening  there was never any doubt about this  did not appear onstage until after all the dancing was over.

title: Room at the Inn
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Before we get started with our solving week, Wordplay would like to extend congratulations to John Hammond, winner of the 2012 Brown University Crossword Tournament. Mr. Hammond finished the playoff puzzle in approximately 17.5 minutes. Stay tuned for some fun puzzles from this tournament, coming up starting tomorrow and appearing over the next week or two. Everybody, say congratulations to Mr. Hammond, pictured below with Will Shortz.

title: Trial for U.S. Team for World Mind Sports Games
description: The trial to select the United States open team for the World Mind Sports Games in August has reached the knockout stage in Schaumburg, Ill.

title: Report Shows Quarterly Decline in Video Rental Revenue; Digital Streaming Increases
description: LOS ANGELES  Powerful shifts in viewing habits continued to distort the market for movies and television shows in home entertainment formats, as video rentals from stores and subscription services collapsed in the first quarter of 2012, according to a report from the Digital Entertainment Group. Digital revenue grew just enough to lift overall home entertainment spending in the United States by 2.47 percent, to $4.45 billion compared with $4.3 billion over the same period in 2011.

title: Orhan Pamuks Novel Museum
description: Turkeys best-known writer opened a museum in Istanbul.

title: On Second Try, Flyers beat Devils in Game 1
description: PHILADELPHIA  Every series this postseason has been defined by unyielding defense and superb goaltending, every series except those played by the Philadelphia Flyers. They do not mind being the anomaly. They can deal with giving up a few goals as long as they score more.

description: MIAMI  Jeremy Lins left knee is sound, but it is not yet ready for the strain of playoff basketball and it may not be until the Knicks have run out of playoff games.

A state senator in California is pushing for a formal audit of a proposed Wal-Mart in San Diego. And in Boston and its suburbs, residents are pressuring politicians to disclose whether they have received contributions from the company.

description: DENVER  The Mets were forced to wait  for Jamie Moyers fastball to reach home plate, for their batters to capitalize in scoring situations, for their bullpen to preserve a lead  but after 4 hours 1 minute of baseball, their forbearance was finally rewarded.

description: If viewers are looking for telenovelas in Spanglish with a heavy dose of marketing, then Telemundos new Web series Mia Mundo will satisfy.

description: To the Editor:

title: Navigating a Tightrope With Amazon
description: Last Tuesday, Buzz Bissinger hopped the Amtrak train to Philadelphia from New York, where he had done a bit of publicity for After Friday Night Lights, a 12,000-word e-book that had been performing nicely since its release. But when he opened his laptop to check his ranking on Amazon, he found the book was no longer for sale there.

title: Nespresso Coffee Develops a Taste for TV
description: NESPRESSO, a division of Nestl that sells single-serve espresso machines and capsules of coffee worldwide, is introducing its first United States television advertising on Monday.
