News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Amid Rural Decay, Trees Take Root in Silos
description: EUDORA, Kan.  The sight is a familiar one along the dusty back roads of the Great Plains: an old roofless silo left to the elements along with decaying barns, chicken coops and stone homesteads.

title: Makeup, and Feminist Guilt, at 13
description: My 8th grader began lobbying for makeup  again  shortly before she turned 13. The year before, shed insisted that everyone in her 7th grade class wore makeup except three of them  her and two of her friends.

title: After Derby Win With Long Shot, Hoping That History Will Repeat
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Penny Chenery, Lucien Laurin and Ron Turcotte found the Kentucky Derby winners circle in 1972 with a runner named Riva Ridge. They liked the place so much they decided to come back, and the big red horse named Secretariat provided their second consecutive victory in 1973.

title: A Race Recast by YouTube and Twitter
description: MEXICO CITY  It sounds like the typical hardball, American-style campaign. The presidential candidate from the incumbents party calls the front-runner a liar in television and Internet advertisements. Supporters of the front-runner retaliate with a Web site and Twitter posts that say his top opponent lies. And the third-place candidate wraps the gaffes of both of them into a YouTube video cheekily titled Excuses Not to Debate.

title: Start-Ups Look to the Crowd
description: When Eric Migicovsky, an engineer, wanted to develop a line of wristwatches that could display information from an iPhone  like caller ID and text messages  he went the traditional route of asking venture capitalists to finance his company.

title: Richard Bellman, Lawyer Who Fought Discrimination, Dies at 74
description: Richard F. Bellman, a lawyer whose tenacity and legal ingenuity propelled him to victory in fights with local governments over racially discriminatory zoning, including in a landmark case against Mount Laurel, N.J., in 1975, died on April 18 on his way to work in Manhattan, where he also lived. He was 74.

title: In Terrorists Testimony, a Rare, Intimate Look Into a Secretive World
description: There was a British man who nearly became the second shoe bomber and took his orders directly from Osama bin Laden.

title: Hardly a Close Ally, Clinton Teams With Obama to Raise Cash and Votes
description: WASHINGTON  Four years ago, Barack Obama wrested control of the Democratic Party after portraying Bill Clinton as a symbol of small-ball ambition and outdated politics. Now, as president, Mr. Obama is turning to his Democratic predecessor for help as Republicans breathe down his neck.

title: Sudan Declares State of Emergency as Clashes Continue
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan  Sudan declared a state of emergency on Sunday along much of its border with South Sudan as the momentum toward all-out war continues to build after weeks of clashes over disputed areas and oil.

title: State Report Says Racing Association Knowingly Withheld Millions
description: The operator of the Saratoga, Aqueduct and Belmont racetracks knowingly withheld nearly $8.5 million that was due to bettors over a 15-month period, according to a new state report, and the Cuomo administration has asked the state inspector general to determine if executives broke civil or criminal laws.

title: On Report Cards for City Schools, Invisible Line Between A and F
description: Public School 30 and Public School 179 are about as alike as two schools can be. They are two blocks apart in the South Bronx. Both are 98 percent black and Latino. At P.S. 30, 97 percent of the children qualify for subsidized lunches; at P.S. 179, 93 percent.

title: The Day After
description: THE one thing everyone knows about North Korea is that we know very little about North Korea, except that it is miserable, totalitarian, nuclear and erratic. It is the hermit kingdom, the dark side of the moon.

title: Teetering, Dewey Ousts Ex-Head From Post
description: Dewey & LeBoeuf, the corporate law firm fighting for survival amid partner defections and heavy debt, ousted its former chairman from the firms management on Sunday and ended talks with a potential merger partner, according to an internal memo.

title: Bulls Stay Positive After Losing Rose
description: DEERFIELD, Ill.  A day after Derrick Rose crumpled to the floor with a torn anterior cruciate ligament in his left knee, the Chicago Bulls were still dealing with the aftershocks of the news that they would have to continue their postseason without Rose, their star point guard and the leagues reigning most valuable player.

title: Wasting Our Minds
description: In Spain, the unemployment rate among workers under 25 is more than 50 percent. In Ireland almost a third of the young are unemployed. Here in America, youth unemployment is only 16.5 percent, which is still terrible  but things could be worse.

title: The C.I.A.s Misuse of Secrecy
description: IN Yemen, Pakistan and elsewhere the C.I.A. has used drones to kill thousands of people  including several Americans. Officials have aggressively defended the controversial program, telling journalists that it is effective, lawful and closely supervised.

title: Whats in a Name? (Part 1)
description: This is the first in a three-part series.

title: The Civil Wars Rip Van Winkle
A Presence Still Felt if Not Heard
description: MIAMI

title: Final Farewells at a Legendary Radio Station
description: One worker went around collecting autographs on a T-shirt. Another solemnly handed thank-you notes sealed in stationery envelopes to some of the disc jockeys. Other employees smiled from behind the microphones, posing for cameras and cellphones.

title: Scandal and Scrutiny Hem In Murdochs Empire
description: In the months after a phone-hacking scandal erupted in Britain last summer, Rupert Murdoch told people within News Corporation that he wanted to revisit his media companys discontinued $12 billion bid for the pay television service British Sky Broadcasting.

title: Lakers Open With a Familiar Thrashing of the Nuggets
description: LOS ANGELES  For the Denver Nuggets, at least, the road to the N.B.A. finals still runs through here.

title: The Economy Downshifts
description: The slow start for the economy in 2012  an annual rate of 2.2 percent in the first three months of the year  is evidence that the recovery is too weak to push joblessness much lower than its current 8.2 percent, and too fragile to withstand the kinds of budget cuts Congressional Republicans are proposing.

title: Making Headway on a Plan to Lure Producers to China
description: LOS ANGELES  Bruno Wu, a Chinese media entrepreneur, is pushing ahead with his previously declared plan to expand the production of global films in China, despite a chill that ran through movie circles last week amid reports that the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating whether American studios had made illegal payments to officials in China.

title: United vs. City Reaches Far Beyond Manchester
description: MANCHESTER, England  Slanting rain and a vicious wind sent ripples and eddies across the puddles forming outside Manchester Citys Etihad Stadium on Sunday. Workers spilled out of two satellite television trucks, ferrying cables and cameras into the stadium to prepare for what could be the most anticipated match in Premier League history.

title: U.N. Chief Will Ask West to Lift Myanmar Sanctions
description: NAYPYIDAW, Myanmar  When he addresses Myanmars Parliament on Monday, Ban Ki-moon, the secretary general of the United Nations, plans to urge Western nations to lift or suspend their remaining sanctions against the country.

title: When Rivals Concede, but Are in No Rush to Endorse
description: Mitt Romney has vanquished virtually all of his rivals for the Republican presidential nomination. Only RepresentativeRon Paul of Texas remains in the race; the rest, evenNewt Gingrich, have bowed to the reality that Mr. Romney will be the nominee.

title: A Midsummer Nights Dream
description: Photos from the production at the Classic Stage Company.

title: For Some Parents, Leaving a Private School Is Harder Than Getting In
description: In February 2011, Nicole Smolowitzs son was admitted to the Mandell School on the Upper West Side. She signed a contract and paid the $7,500 deposit.

title: N.F.L. Draft More Closely Resembles Swap Meet, Only With Top-Quality Talent
description: No two N.F.L. drafts are alike.

title: Foolish Mortals, Naughty Fairies: The Usual Mischief
description: A shower of rose petals descending on a carpet of black wood shavings provides one of the many visual allurements in the Classic Stage Companys production of A Midsummer Nights Dream. The tilted mirrored wall rising at the back of the theater  like a humongous disco ball squashed flat  reflects the flurrying downfall back to the audience, amplifying the magical feeling of being caught up in the eye of a hot-pink hurricane.

title: In China, Foreign Films Meet a Powerful Gatekeeper
description: LOS ANGELES  Any foreign movie knocking on Chinas door must pass through powerful gatekeepers  the China Film Group and its chief executive, Han Sanping.

title: Bigotry on the Ballot
description: North Carolina already has a law barring same-sex marriage, but the states Republican-controlled Legislature is not satisfied. It devised a measure to enshrine this obvious discrimination in the State Constitution and placed it on the ballot of the states May 8 primary election  a test of tolerance versus bigotry that ought to be watched closely nationwide.

title: Knicks, in Rout, Beat Rangers for TV Viewers
description: New York sports viewers made a clear decision Saturday afternoon between playoff series that began at almost the same time. Game 1 of the first-round series between the Knicks and the Miami Heat and Game 1 of the Washington Capitals-Rangers Eastern Conference semifinals started a half-hour apart, and the N.B.A. game was the overwhelming favorite.

title: After They Check the Box
description: The federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has reaffirmed and updated a 25-year-old ruling that bars companies from automatically denying employment to people based on arrest or conviction records. It is must reading for all employers.

title: 2 Charged in Bronx Subway Stabbing
description: Two people have been charged with attempted murder in the stabbing of a 19-year-old man on a Bronx subway platform, the authorities said on Sunday.

title: 7 Relatives Die as S.U.V. Drops 60 Feet Off Bronx Highway
description: It could not have taken more than a few terrifying seconds from the moment the S.U.V.s driver lost control on an elevated highway on Sunday to the moment it came to a violent rest about 60 feet below, in a nonpublic area of the Bronx Zoo. The vehicles seven occupants, spanning three generations of a Bronx family, were killed on impact, their bodies still inside.

title: Dont Bargain With Rail Safety
description: There are worrying signs that Congress is getting ready to retreat from the lesson learned in 2008 when 25 passengers were killed and more than 130 injured in a horrific California rail collision. In the aftermath of that tragedy, Congress did the right thing and passed a law requiring the installation by 2015 of automated control systems on the nations passenger lines that can stop a train if an engineer is dozing, incapacitated or just not paying attention. The engineer in the California disaster was found to be text-messaging at the controls when he blew past a red warning signal and collided head-on with a freight train.

title: A Conversation With Paul Ryan
description: Representative Paul Ryan of Wisconsin may be the most influential policy maker in the Republican Party.

title: Book Takes Aim at Murdochs
description: British newspapers were flooded last week with coverage of a judicial inquiry that spent several days relentlessly questioning Rupert Murdoch and his son James.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 29, 2012

title: Ryans Rise From Follower to G.O.P. Trailblazer
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Paul D. Ryan strolls the halls of Capitol Hill with the anarchist band Rage Against the Machine pounding through his earbuds.

title: Swiss Police Arrest Canadian Tied to Africa Fraud Inquiry
description: OTTAWA  The Swiss police have arrested a former senior executive of SNC-Lavalin, a Canadian construction company that did considerable business with the regime of Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan dictator.

title: Photo Replay: April 29
description: The images of the day include a title fight in boxing, a judo tournament and baseball action.

title: Jordan the Owner Could Learn From Jordan the Player
description: From 1986, when he scored 63 points against Boston in a playoff game, until his final championship performance in 1998, Michael Jordan owned the N.B.A. spring. The period between April and June used to be called Jordans time.

title: From Mediaites Founder, a Site for Blanket Coverage of Celebrity Chefs
description: As Dan Abrams interviewed editor candidates for his next Web site start-up, one of his questions must have stood out. Whats your favorite celebrity chef feud?

title: Anthony Holds Key to All Hope for Knicks
description: MIAMI  To save the Knicks postseason, all Carmelo Anthony needs to do is score like himself, pass like Jeremy Lin, defend like Iman Shumpert and protect the rim like Tyson Chandler.

title: Rangers Are Putting Up Obstacles for Ovechkin
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  It may or may not wind up being a bulletin-board quotation, but Alex Ovechkin made a surprising assertion at the Washington Capitals practice on Sunday.

title: On the Highest Floors, Food Comes to the Workers
description: New York, the most vertical of cities, has become a tad blas about its skyscrapers, high-rise malls and multistory restaurant collections. At last, though, it has a fresh take on the perpendicular: the vertical food-truck court.

title: When Outdoor Ads Are Indoors
description: The industry that Madison Avenue usually refers to as outdoor advertising, or simply outdoor, is starting an effort to convince agencies and advertisers that it is more than outdoor.

title: Accretive Denies Accusations of Pressuring Patients to Pay
description: Accretive Health, one of the nations largest collectors of medical bills, took issue on Sunday with a report by the Minnesota attorney generals office that it puts bedside pressure on patients to pay their bills.

title: Report Says Pepsi in Deals With IHOP and Applebees
description: The cola wars are heating up again.

title: George Vujnovich is Dead at 96; Led War Rescue
description: George Vujnovich, an O.S.S. agent in World War II who oversaw the rescue of more than 500 downed Allied airmen from German-occupied Yugoslavia, his parents homeland, died Tuesday in Queens. He was 96.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include personal income and spending for March, and the Chicago purchasing managers index for April (Monday); the I.S.M. manufacturing index for April and construction spending for March (Tuesday); the ADP employment report for April and factory orders for March (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, first-quarter productivity and the I.S.M. nonmanufacturing report for April (Thursday); and unemployment figures for April (Friday).

title: Staying Hopeful, No Matter the View
description: MISSION VIEJO, Calif.  After taking a penalty stroke for an errant drive, Jim Abbott studied his approach from about 110 yards to Arroyo Trabuco Golf Clubs short, yet challenging, par-4 sixth hole.

title: A Radio Merger in New York Reflects a Shifting Industry
description: On its surface, the merger last week of WRKS and WBLS, longtime rivals in the R&B radio format in New York, was business as usual for the broadcast industry. Two struggling competitors combined operations, and a deep-pocketed third party  Disney  came along to lease the leftover frequency.

title: Moscelyne Larkin, a Founder of Tulsa Ballet, Is Dead at 87
description: Moscelyne Larkin, one of five dancers termed the American Indian ballerinas of Oklahoma and a co-founder of the Tulsa Ballet, died on Wednesday in a nursing home in Tulsa, Okla. She was 87.

title: Finding the Limits of Empathy
description: In any struggle, failure to understand the opposition is a weakness and a point of vulnerability. This is especially true in politics. Both the Democratic and the Republican parties have repeatedly fallen into the trap of overestimating popular support for their own policies and failing to anticipate hostile reactions to them.

title: Philippines Role May Expand as U.S. Adjusts Asia Strategy
description: FORT MAGSAYSAY, the Philippines  The squad from the United States Armys 196th Infantry Brigade was moving quietly through the hills of Luzon Island when the staccato bursts of machine gun fire sent them into action.

title: Making Progress Against Clutter
description: In a column last fall, I announced my intention to rid my home and myself of a half-century of accumulated stuff  everything from papers, books, clothing and shoes to packaging material and shopping bags. Im happy to report significant progress.

description: Regardless of what happens on Monday in Manchestergeddon, the Premier League title will not change hands and the engraver will continue to work on other projects for at least a week or so.

title: Former Israeli Premier Assails Netanyahu on Iran
description: Ehud Olmert, the former prime minister of Israel, plunged on Sunday into the countrys growing debate over Iran policy with harsh criticism of his successor, Benjamin Netanyahu.

title: Experts Believe Iran Conflict Is Less Likely
description: WASHINGTON  After a winter of alarm over the possibility that a military conflict over the Iranian nuclear program might be imminent, American officials and outside analysts now believe that the chances of war in the near future have significantly decreased.

title: In Melodeeman, One Horses Rise and Fall
description: Melodeeman, a thoroughbred, raced for six years, through surgery, six owners and 47 races. He broke down and was euthanized on the track on Jan. 21, 2010.

title: Good Wife Watch: Is This the End of Lockhart Gardner?
description: Where to begin? With the attempted sabotage of Lockhart Gardner, Kalindas troubled past and her rekindled friendship with Alicia, Jackies return and Peters bombshell, Sunday nights Season 3 finale of The Good Wife left me feeling like the series had returned to its roots: a savory and satisfying blend of legal sagacity, emotional gravitas and humor.

title: Lack of a U.S. Apology Is Sticking Point for Pakistan
description: HONG KONG  It was a difficult weekend in Pakistan. The body of a British Red Cross doctor was found, beheaded, dumped by the side of a road in Quetta. A C.I.A. drone strike killed three suspected militants in an old schoolhouse. And talks last week about a reset of the deeply troubled relationship with the United States went nowhere, partly because of Washingtons refusal to apologize for an earlier air attack that killed 24 Pakistani soldiers.

title: Three Years of Kickstarter Projects
description: Almost 50,000 projects have sought financing on Kickstarter since the site began on April 28, 2009. About half successfully reached their fund-raising goals. Each dot represents how much a project raised by its deadline.

title: One Horse, One Week of Injections
description: Coronado Heights, a 4-year-old thoroughbred who received a diagnosis of early degenerative joint disease, broke down and was euthanized on the track at Aqueduct on Feb. 25. Below, an illustration of the drugs and dosages given to Coronado Heights the week before he broke down.

title: How the Data Was Analyzed
description: To assess how often horses break down or are injured, The New York Times bought official data covering more than 150,000 race results from 2009 through 2011. The data are compiled by trained chart callers and used to put together result charts that bettors use to evaluate horses. The Times searched the data for terms indicating that a horse encountered a physical problem: broke down, vanned off, injured, lame, euthanized, died, collapsed, bleeding or went wrong.

title: Rise of the Racinos
description: As the popularity of horse racing has diminished, racetracks like Aqueduct in New York have turned to casinos for additional revenue.

title: As Casinos Enter the Game, Horses Lose
description: Casinos opening at a growing number of racetracks have recalibrated the age-old economic equations of the horse-racing game.

title: Big Purses, Sore Horses and Death
description: As he trained for his first race, at Aqueduct Racetrack in Queens, the 3-year-old thoroughbred Wes Vegas galloped on the track most mornings and had two timed workouts. But his handlers also prepared him in another way: In the month before the race, records show, he received 10 intravenous injections of potent drugs for pain, one the day before he ran; two injections of a drug for joint disease; corticosteroid injections in his two front ankles; a sedative; and an ulcer drug.

title: Breakdown
description: The new economics of horse racing are making an always-dangerous game even more so, as lax oversight puts animal and rider at risk.

title: Benzion Netanyahu, Hawkish Scholar, Dies at 102
description: Benzion Netanyahu, a scholar of Judaic history who lobbied in the United States for the creation of the Jewish state, wrote a revisionist account of the Spanish Inquisition and became a behind-the-scenes adviser to his son Benjamin Netanyahu, Israels prime minister, died on Monday at his home in Jerusalem. He was 102.

title: Ska Vengers Play Tihar
description: About 1,000 prisoners of Tihar Jail, the largest prison facility in South Asia, were serenaded last week by the Ska Vengers, a Delhi-based ska band, at an outdoor concert in one of the complexs jails.

title: News Quiz | April 30, 2012
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: April 30, 1975 | Saigon Falls
description: On April 30, 1975, Communist North Vietnamese and Viet Cong forces captured the South Vietnamese capital of Saigon, forcing South Vietnam to surrender and bringing about an end to the Vietnam War.

He has recently written for the magazine on the Phillies deceptive pitchers, haunted houses in South Carolina and the former N.B.A. referee Tim Donaghy.

description: Hilton Kramer once called Evelyn Hofer the most famous unknown photographer in America, a title she did not dispute. To her, the work was more important than the artist.

title: In Syria, Blame Cast by 2 Sides in Attacks
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrias official media reported a series of attacks against government buildings on Monday, including two bombings that targeted two security headquarters in the northern city of Idlib and a small rocket assault on the Central Bank in downtown Damascus.

description: NAYPYIDAW, Myanmar  The party of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi backed down on Monday in a dispute over Myanmars oath of office, agreeing to enter Parliament for the first time and reviving hopes for the countrys reconciliation program.

description: Attaining a college degree is a milestone many people dream about  and expect to achieve. But with the rising cost of tuition and high unemployment rates for recent graduates, is college a necessity or a luxury?

description: Jonathan Chait has an excellent piece on Paul Ryan, which shows not just that hes a fake deficit hawk now, but that he always was  he was an enthusiastic supporter of all of Bushs budget-busters, spending as well as taxes.

description: Dozens of flood alerts are issued as Britain is drenched by rain and buffeted by high winds after an unusually dry winter. [Sky News]

title: Invisible President
description: MOSCOW  Dmitri Medvedev has entered his last week as president of Russia: on May 7, he will hand back the office to Vladimir Putin. Having served just one four-year term, he will be remembered as one of the countrys shortest-lived rulers. He will also be remembered as one of countrys shortest rulers. At no more than 53, and with his propensity to wear huge Windsor knots, he often looks like a fourth-grader trying on daddys business suit.

title: Daily Report: Coming of Age for a Site to Finance Start-Ups
description: In Mondays New York Times, Jenna Wortham tells the story of Eric Migicovsky, a 25-year-old engineer who turned to Kickstarter, a site where ordinary people finance creative projects, to raise money for his idea: a line of wristwatches that could display information from an iPhone, like caller ID and text messages.

title: Eagles Looking Up; Umenyiora Unhappy
description: The Giants seemed pleased with themselves about their draft picks this past weekend, but managed to displease one of their current players. Its not a new story. Osi Umenyiora has been unhappy with General Manager Jerry Reese for a while. Giants fans have to hope that Umenyiora can set aside contract distractions and play with abandon, as he did last season during the teams Super Bowl run. But it seems too much to expect that hell be happy doing it.

title: After Criticism, Aviva Chief Forgoes Pay Increase
description: LONDON  Aviva said on Monday that its chief executive had decided to refuse a pay increase for this year after some shareholders raised concerns about the levels of executive pay at the British insurance giant.

description: Im often asked what gadget one should buy to make better coffee at home, and I always give the same answer: get a good grinder. Then I wait for the blank response.

description: After the global financial crisis, banks may not be viewed as the most trustworthy organizations, but generally they are considered a safer place to keep money than stowing it under a mattress.

title: Has the Correspondents Dinner Become a Nerd Unity Conference?
description: Late on Saturday evening at the Bloomberg-Vanity Fair party after the White House Correspondents Association annual dinner, Judd Apatow, a Hollywood director-producer who was a long way from home, asked who might be interesting to talk to. There were a lot of folks to pick from, including David Axelrod, President Obamas political strategist; the retired general and former Secretary of State Colin L. Powell; and New Yorks mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg. He was standing near Eric E. Schmidt, the executive chairman of Google, so an introduction was made.

title: At Film Festival, a Sponsorship Leads to a Protest
description: The 2012 Tribeca Film Festival ended on Sunday, not without a measure of discontent. This had nothing to do with who won awards. The issue was one of the festivals major sponsors, Brookfield Properties, the real estate company best known of late as the owner of Zuccotti Park, where Occupy Wall Street encamped for two months last fall.

title: Malaysian Police to Investigate Violence at Protest
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  The Malaysian police pledged on Monday to investigate violence at a rally supporting free elections that spiraled out of control when protesters broke through barricades and the police fired tear gas in central Kuala Lumpur.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Microsoft Buys Into the Nook, and Radios Shrinking Diversity
description: The e-book wars added a new alliance, the Microsoft-Barnes & Noble joint venture, DealBook reported on Monday. Microsoft has invested $300 million for a 17.6 percent stake in a new Barnes & Nobles subsidiary composed of its Nook digital-book business and college-texts units; intriguingly, the deal values the subsidiary at $1.7 billion, much more than Barnes & Noble is worth by itself, as The Wall Street Journal noted. Also, as part of the deal, Microsoft has settled its patent dispute with Barnes & Noble, and there will be a Nook application included in the new Windows 8, which is scheduled to have a release preview in early June.

title: An Unwelcome Subway Passenger
description: Dear Diary:On a recent unseasonably warm spring day, I was reminded that it wont be long until it is unbearably hot and humid at the subway stations, where this exciting encounter occurred last summer.

title: Image of the Day: April 30
Monday Reading: Act Now to Go to the London Olympics
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: 8th, 9th or 10th, Rodriguez Passes Mays
description: On a fairly brisk Sunday afternoon, Alex Rodriguez passed Willie Mays, driving in his 1,904th run in his amazing career in a fairly mundane way, with a fielders choice. Narrowing down just where he ranked on the career list proved a bit more complicated.

title: Morning Buzz, April 30: A Fight Over $150 Million in Tips
description: Good morning. It will be mostly sunny today, with highs in the low 60s and a good chance of showers tonight.

title: The New Pay Phone and What It Knows About You
description: The term pay phone has a new meaning today.

title: Profile in Style | Misha Nonoo
description: A self-described magpie, the New York-based fashion designer found her aesthetic match in fellow Briton Alexander Gilkes (a co-founder of Paddle 8, an online art market). We both have a knack for assembling clutter, she says. The couple (who will wed in Venice in May) spend countless hours scouring antiques markets around the world for offbeat and interesting furnishings that act as an Old World-y counterpoint to their contemporary-art-filled apartment in downtown Manhattan. Nonoos favorite find is an 18th-century birthing table she bought in LIsle Sur la Sorgue, in France. It now serves a far less serious, but equally important, purpose as our drinks table, she says with a laugh. The pair are consummate hosts who entertain often and effortlessly. According to Nonoo, the recipe for a good dinner party is simple. We give our guests a good dose of grape, then its time for after-dinner games  celebrity is a current favorite  and an obligatory wearing of our collection of fancy-dress costumes and hats. More

description: Details: As we gear up for the Kentucky Derby, heres Christopher Ross on the art of making a better mint julep.  Jeff Gordinier

title: Will Oil Extraction Harm Western Parks?
description: As the public comment period ends this week on a proposal to develop oil shale and oil sands in vast areas of the Rocky Mountain West, conservationists are making a stand on behalf of the areas national parks. The National Parks Conservation Association, a 90-year-old organization, is concerned that eight national parks and monuments are at risk from energy development of this type and scale.

description: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing confirmed on Monday that it was considering a bid for the London Metal Exchange, as the battle heated up for the worlds largest metal-trading platform.

description: Fans of Uggie, the adorable Jack Russell terrier who somehow failed to be nominated in the best supporting actor category for the Oscar-winning film The Artist, will be barking his own story in a coming memoir published by Gallery Books, The Associated Press reported.

description: Leading up to the Kentucky Derby, there is the $2 million question: Who handles the distance? But very few ask: Where did they come from?

title: The Danger of Too Much Comfort in Your Financial Life
description: Change can be a scary thing. So its no wonder that were drawn to things we recognize  to things that are familiar  and stick with them. Its why we go to a chain restaurant, buy clothes from the Gap and drive the same kind of car for big chunks of our lives.

title: From Fighter Jets to Finance: Topgun Lessons for Wall Street
description: Wall Street trading floors are home to many a military-style battle cry. But for Lt. Cmdr. Jeffery Lay, the connection between finance and F-14 fighter jets is more than metaphorical.

description: Charles Duhigg and David Kocieniewski answer questions and respond to reader comments about Apples efforts to minimize its taxes.

description: Charles Duhigg and David Kocieniewski answer questions and respond to reader comments about Apples efforts to minimize its taxes.

title: Wife of Aide to Edwards Testifies About Lies
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  By turns tearful, incredulous and angry, Cheri Young, the wife of a former top aide to John Edwards, testified at the former senators federal corruption trial on Monday that she was reluctantly drawn into an intricate web of deceit in an attempt to get him elected president.

title: On a Tightrope, President Prods China on Rights
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Monday gently prodded China to improve its human-rights record but pointedly declined to discuss the case of a prominent Chinese lawyer, Chen Guangcheng, now said to be under American protection in Beijing. His remarks highlighted the delicacy of an unfolding diplomatic dispute that analysts say may prove fiendishly difficult to resolve.

title: Edible Selby | Net Gains
description: Kirk Lombard, a Bay Area fisherman and self-described fish nerd, is not interested in marquee species. I fish for the things nobody wants, he says. Rock crab, surf smelt and monkeyface eel have long been his bread and butter, and he proudly holds the California record for the largest monkeyface ever caught (6.1 pounds). When the foraging trend took off  that is, when he started noticing young people in tight pants pulling wild asparagus from cracks in sidewalks  Lombard founded a company, Sea Forager, to show landlubbers how to find the citys little-known sea creatures. He conducts sold-out tours to some of his secret fishing holes, where he demonstrates poke-poling, a method to retrieve the elusive monkeyface. Its great in gumbo, Lombard says. More

title: Cutting a Deal With Big Tobacco
description: Last May, I wrote a post about whether a green company, like TerraCycle, should partner with companies that make tobacco, firearms or alcohol.

title: Monday Motorsports: Kyle Busch Sets Record at Richmond

title: In Southern Italy, Fake Euros That Even the Police Admire

Like some of his new peers, he is also a fugitive from the banking business.

description: Time for dessert. You whip up your favorite brownie recipe and pour into your new 93 inch baking dish. The brownies bake. The toothpick comes out clean. Now for the cutting.

description: Its no secret that Im obsessed with Rihanna and Beyonce. I devour their every post on Twitter, Facebook, Instagram and Tumblr.

title: Insights From the Youngest Minds
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Seated in a cheerfully cramped monitoring room at the Harvard University Laboratory for Developmental Studies, Elizabeth S. Spelke, a professor of psychology and a pre-eminent researcher of the basic ingredient list from which all human knowledge is constructed, looked on expectantly as her students prepared a boisterous 8-month-old girl with dark curly hair for the onerous task of watching cartoons.

title: Ignorance, Too, Can Be Viral
description: PARIS  Just before I returned to the real world from Arizona, a neighbor of respectable age stopped me at the mailbox. Hed heard I was some sort of reporter who worked abroad.

title: Public Gets to Vote on New York City Preservation Projects
description: Its the preservationists version of American Idol. American Express and the National Trust for Historic Preservation have chosen New York City to receive $3 million in preservation grants, and New Yorkers and New York lovers will get to vote for some of the winners.

title: Elizabeth S. Spelke
description: A video interview with the Harvard cognitive psychologist on babies and the nature of human knowledge.

title: Name Change
description: If you look at the top of the page, youll notice this blog has a new name. Readers responded to the original, Loyal Opposition, with a resounding, Huh?

title: Bahraini Court Orders Retrials for Activists
description: CAIRO  A Bahraini court on Monday ordered retrials for a political activist who has been on a hunger strike for nearly three months and 20 others who were convicted by a military tribunal for their participation in protests last year against Bahrains ruling monarchy.

title: Protesters Accuse Police of Improperly Using Barricades
description: Updated, 7:00 p.m. | A federal lawsuit filed on Monday accused the New York Police Department of improperly using barricades to corral protesters and asked a judge to issue an order forbidding certain uses of barricades.

title: Financial Regulator Hires Diversity Monitor
description: The nations consumer financial watchdog has set out to address another Wall Street problem: a lack of diversity.

title: The Mexican Is Answering Questions
description: Gustavo Arellano, the subject of my Dining article this week, was born and raised in Anaheim, Calif., and is the urbane editor and food critic of OC Weekly. But in 2004, he assumed another persona: As the protagonist of the column Ask a Mexican! he is fat, gold-toothed, and dons a sombrero to answer readers deepest questions about Mexican and Mexican-American life. (Examples: Are there different kinds of Mexican food? Why do Mexicans paint murals on their cars? Is Mitt Romney part Mexican?)

title: Food Trucks Get Vertical
description: When it isnt all that easy to get to the food in your workplace or neighborhood, there is an option: The food can come to you. And so, for the last few months, fancy-food trucks have been traveling up the freight elevator of the 19-story Starrett-Lehigh Building at 601 West 26th Street in West Chelsea, to offer dining options five days a week to some 6,000 office workers and visitors.

title: Borough Haul | Crossing Brooklyn Ferry Festival
description: If there are any doubts as to Brooklyns status as the coolest borough, Crossing Brooklyn Ferry, a three-day music and film festival named for a poem by the Brooklynite Walt Whitman and curated by the twin brothers Aaron and Bryce Dessner of the much-loved local band The National, should put them to rest. The independent music scene in Brooklyn is the world capital of that culture, Bryce says. And it has a massive visual arts scene. So when the Brooklyn Academy of Music approached the brothers about putting together a program of musicians and filmmakers who live in the borough, they jumped at the chance. Many of the names on the bill, like St Vincent and the Walkmen, are friends of the Dessners; others, like the Sierre Leone-born Janka Nabay, were chosen to represent Brooklyns musical diversity. But despite being organized by a pair of musicians, Crossing Brooklyn Ferry was initially conceived of as a film festival. BAM is singular in its commitment to commissioning new work, and we wanted the festival to reflect that, Bryce explains. Plus its exciting for musicians to work with filmmakers, so we decided to commission new films and have scores written for them. Among the filmmakers who will be screening work at BAMs Rose Cinemas are Tunde Adebimpe of TV on the Radio, Jonas Mekas, Joseph Gordon-Levitt and Poppy de Villeneuve, whose dreamy, black-and-white depiction of an afternoon on the bayou, And So, We Begin Again, an excerpt of which can be seen here, was hypnotically scored by Missy Mazzoli. Crossing Brooklyn Ferry, the poem, talks about leaving Manhattan and islands, de Villeneuve says. I took that as a very literal starting point  I went to the Everglades and then the Ten Thousand Islands.

title: Romney Says He Would Have Ordered Bin Laden Killing
description: 3:04 p.m. | Updated PORTSMOUTH, N.H.  Mitt Romney said on Monday that even Jimmy Carter would have given the order to kill Osama bin Laden in Pakistan a year ago, dismissing pointed questions by President Obamas re-election campaign about whether Mr. Romney would have issued the same command the president did.

title: E.P.A. Official Resigns Over Crucify Comments
description: Al Armendariz, the Environmental Protection Agency official who stirred controversy last week after a video circulated in which he declared that that the agency should crucify polluters as a deterrent, has resigned, saying he regrets his comments and does not want them to distract from the E.P.A.s work.

title: Milken Conference Kicks Off With Panel on Global Growth
description: LOS ANGELES  The first rule of the Milken Conference is: Dont call it the Milken Conference.

title: And So We Begin Again
description: A film by Poppy de Villeneuve for the Crossing Brooklyn Ferry Festival.

title: A Bunch of Things I Learned From Reading Every Last Word of Sports Illustrated
description: I took my game to the next level last week when I read Sports Illustrated cover to cover. I just took it one word at a time. Lets go to the highlight reel. (Italics mean Im shouting!)

title: In New Video, Obama Campaign Reminds Voters of 2008 Job Losses
description: For months, senior White House aides have been privately banking on a chart of monthly job losses and gains that shows steep declines during President George W. Bushs last year in office and sharp improvement under President Obama.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: The 2012 B2B Ace Awards, sponsored by the Business Marketing Association of New York, were presented on April 18. Digitas, part of the Publicis Groupe, won Best of Show for the Small Business Saturday campaign for American Express as well as the award for integrated marketing campaign with a budget of $1 million or more. The runner-up for Best of Show was the Corning Gorilla Glass campaign by Doremus, part of the Omnicom Group, which also won the award for a broadcast television campaign. The B2B in the name of the awards is for business-to-business.

title: Brooklyn Basketball Will Be Black and White
description: eset with a long, checkered past, the Nets wasted no time embracing new traditions.

title: Assumptions and Attitudes Dont Survive Cancer
description: MALIGNANT Medical Ethicists Confront Cancer.

title: A Ten-Volume Look at Jewish Culture
description: Yale University Press and the Posen Foundation are embarking on a 10-volume anthology that covers more than 3,000 years of Jewish cultural artifacts, texts and paintings. This monumental project includes the best of Jewish culture in its historical and global entirety, the editor in chief, James E. Young, a professor of English and Judaic Studies at the University of Massachusetts Amherst, said in a news release. It will provide future generations with a working legacy by which to recover and comprehend Jewish culture and civilization.

title: Chandler Says Hell Be in Knicks Lineup for Game 2
description: MIAMI  With bags under his eyes and hope in his voice, Tyson Chandler said he would be in the lineup Monday night to play the Miami Heat. Beyond that, even Chandler is not sure.

title: Collective Intelligence 2012 Conference at MIT
description: The Collective Intelligence conference at MIT was the first-ever interdisciplinary research conference on the subject. Its revealing that the event itself was a real exercise in collective intelligence.

title: Ford Show Truck Is Drafted Into Service After Texas Tornadoes
description: As multiple tornadoes blistered the Dallas area on April 3, a custom-built Ford F-550 Super Duty pickup suddenly went from show truck to fully engaged fire department support vehicle.

title: Sarkozy Threatens to Sue Over Accusations of Libyan Donations
description: As a close presidential race enters its final week in France, President Nicolas Sarkozy said on Monday that he would file suit against a muckraking French news site before the end of the campaign over articles claiming that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi illegally donated roughly $65 million to his 2007 presidential campaign.

title: 3 Children Killed in Cross-Fire Between Taliban and U.S.
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Three children were killed and three wounded in cross-fire on Monday when Taliban insurgents attacked a team of American soldiers in southern Afghanistan, Afghan officials said.

title: Celtics Rondo Loses His Cool Against the Hawks
description: Yes, the Boston Celtics have survived the lockout-shortened, injury-marred regular season to get to the N.B.A. playoffs. But judging by Sundays 83-74 loss to the Hawks in Atlanta, a long postseason run may not be in the cards for the veteran-laden Celtics.

title: Premier League: Manchester City (1) vs. Manchester United (0)
description: It seems like yesterday, make that a few weeks ago, when Manchester City Manager Roberto Mancini waved the blue flag and declared the race over in Englands Premier League. But now, with only two regular season games left, the Citizens find themselves in first place, on goal differential, after Mondays 1-0 win against rival United in the Manchester derby at the Etihad Stadium.

title: Springs False Start
description: Q. After a late-winter warm spell that was followed by early-spring cold, I noticed that the trees in my neighborhood did not fully blossom. Even crab apple blossoms perished in the cold. What can we expect by summer?

title: E! Adds Scripted Series and Reality Shows to Lineup
description: The E! network announced an ambitious lineup of original programming Monday, including a new singing competition from one of the producers of American Idol, a relationship show with a Jonas brother (and his wife), and a weekly talk show with the comedian Whitney Cummings, which could raise questions about the future of her NBC sitcom.

title: In Fight Over Obama Health Law, a Front in Minnesota
description: ST. PAUL  With zeal, excitement and a meticulous attention to detail, the administration of Gov. Mark Dayton is trying to expand health insurance coverage and remake Minnesotas insurance market along the lines envisioned by President Obama.

title: Peters and Jackman to Get Special Tonys
description: The Broadway darlings Bernadette Peters and Hugh Jackman will receive special Tony Awards at the June 10 awards ceremony, the Broadway League and the American Theater Wing announced on Monday. Ms. Peters, who appeared most recently on Broadway in Follies, will receive the Isabelle Stevenson Award for her volunteer work to benefit animal rescue groups and shelters. She has also worked on behalf of Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS, Standing Tall, and the Actors Fund of America.

title: E.R. Doctors Face Quandary on Painkillers
description: Dr. Bruce Lobitz, an attending physician in the emergency department at Upstate Carolina Medical Center in Gaffney, S.C., sees about 10 patients a week complaining of toothaches. The bane of our existence, he calls them.

title: Pro-Romney Super PAC Scrubs Negative Ads
description: As Republicans rally to unify behind the presumptive nominee Mitt Romney, the campaigns allies are working to heal old wounds from the bruising primary fight. In the latest example, the pro-Romney super PAC Restore Our Future has scrubbed its YouTube account of all negative ads against Newt Gingrich and Rick Santorum.

title: Cheese and Red Wine, Together Again
description: BACK in the old days, before the Internet or even electricity, red wine and cheese were thought to belong together as surely as pomp and circumstance. It was customary to serve the cheese course after the meal, to be consumed with the red that remained in the bottle after the roast had been finished. It seemed so obvious it did not warrant debate.

title: Kickstarter Surprises Tech Startup
description: Jenna Wortham, a technology reporter for The New York Times, interviews one of the creators of the Pebble e-paper watch, a device that has received a massive following on Kickstarter.

title: Farewell, Dr. Spock. Hello, Snooki.

But as Jacob Bernstein so excellently reported in the Styles section on Sunday, it has turned into a savvy career move for an increasing number of C-level celebrities for whom, as he puts it, motherhood pays.

Kreider Is Right Where He Wants to Be on 21st Birthday

But unlike members of Congress, they argued that the hors doeuvres were among the few things that were properly priced.

title: Barnes & Nobles Nook Unit Is Worth More Than Its Parent Company

title: Open to Conversation, or a Helicopter Ride

title: Tony Nominations Coming Tuesday: Let the Combat Begin
description: The starting bell for Broadways biggest horse race rings at 8:30 a.m. Tuesday when nominations for the 2012 Tony Awards will be announced. By 8:35 a.m. the shrieking and moaning from armchair critics and show queens should be underway as well, about which productions and performers were robbed of Tony nominations and about which of the lucky ones were  how shall we put it?  undeserving.

title: "Forward" Excerpt
description: An excerpt from the Obama campaign's "Forward" web video.

title: The Sakura Matsuri Festival
description: Hosted by the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, the weekend-long festival celebrated traditional and contemporary Japanese culture.

title: Americans Best Customers Want It to Stay Independent
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I proposed that American Airlines customers form a committee to try to influence the outcome of the airlines bankruptcy and the outcome of any potential merger between the airline and US Airways or another carrier. Members of the FlyerTalk Web community are already pondering putting something like that together in the wake of the column  if you want to check it out and weigh in.

title: Campaign Finance Watchdogs File Complaint Against Illinois Congressman
description: 4:46 p.m. | Updated  Two campaign finance watchdogs filed a complaint Monday against a Republican congressman who asked Representative Eric Cantor of Virginia, the House majority leader, for a $25,000 contribution to an anti-incumbent super PAC aiming to oust a veteran Republican from the House.

title: Fur, Feathers, Ivory and Bone: The U.S. Military and Endangered Species Souvenirs
description: The links between conflict and contraband are as old as war, and have been the subject of extensive research. The reasons are easy to grasp, if sometimes hard to trace. Wars disrupt economies and can create acute shortages, often while encouraging lawlessness and the breakdown of borders and institutions. In these circumstances, smugglers are both in demand and can thrive.

title: A Word Heard Often, Except at the Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON  The most versatile of the classic Anglo-Saxon swear words has, diligent research reveals, made just one appearance in oral arguments before the Supreme Court. The cursing, in 1971, probably won the case, which concerned the prosecution of a vulgar protest against the draft during the Vietnam War. By repeating the word in court, the protesters lawyer showed that it could have a role in public discourse. Over the next two decades or so, the word was used in nine Supreme Court decisions, typically in quotations of something a criminal had said. Its last appearance was in 1993.

title: Signs of Volcanoes In Mars Topography
description: A new study suggests that the Athabasca Valles, a group of valleys near the Martian equator, were not formed by ice, as some scientists have theorized.

title: Masur Sidelined Through September With Broken Shoulder Blade
description: After falling from the podium during a concert in Paris on Thursday the conductor Kurt Masur, 84, has withdrawn from all his engagements through September.

title: Five Things I Learned From Reading Every Last Word of Spin
description: My first New York publishing job was an internship with Spin in the summer of 1987. It wasnt glamorous. Most of my time was spent in a stockroom stuffing envelopes with T-shirts to be sent to new subscribers. (Perhaps a nonsubscribing friend or two of mine received a Spin T-shirt as well.) I can remember exactly two highlights that summer. First, John Leland, who was a terrific Spin columnist (and who now works here at The Times), took pity on my musical ignorance and gave me a couple of preview cassettes (cassettes!) that would change my worldview: Sister, by Sonic Youth, and Youre Living All Over Me, by Dinosaur Jr.

title: One More Reason to Love Mussels: Curry-Laced Moules  la Marinire With Fresh Peas
description: If youre looking for a great, sustainable source of omega-3s, think about mussels.

title: Iran Denounces Florida Pastor Over Koran Burning
description: TEHRAN  A Koran burning conducted by Terry Jones, the controversial pastor from Florida, has angered Iranian politicians, with one calling for Joness execution.

title: Principal Fined for Canceling Class So Son Could Be Tutored
description: A Queens school principal who had a math class watch a movie, The Karate Kid, so the teacher could tutor the principals college-age son has been fined $2,000 and reprimanded, the citys Conflicts of Interest Board announced on Monday.

title: Is the Toyota Camry Unfairly Vilified?
description: Ezra Dyers review of the 2012 Toyota Camry, which appeared in Sundays Automobiles section, touched a nerve among some Wheels readers.

title: Denial of Anthony Gives Knicks All Types of Problems
description: The Knicks playoff-opening catastrophe was marked by general failures more than any specific flaw, but much attention has rightly been paid to the Miami Heats denial defense against Carmelo Anthony. That strategic decision alone did not and could not have produced Game 1s 33-point final margin, but the approach and its aftermath communicated plenty about the dynamics of both teams.

title: Look of The Moment | Elizabeth Banks
description: The Look: Red State. A pleated peplum turns an exacting column dress into a look thats anything but conservative.

title: Coke Denies It Is in Talks to Buy Monster Beverage
description: 7:58 p.m. | Updated

title: Quinn Quits Wage Rally After Bloomberg Is Insulted
description: Saying she would not tolerate name-calling in political debates, Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, walked out of a rally on Monday after a participant derided New Yorks mayor as Pharaoh Bloomberg.

title: Abuse of Opiates Soars in Pregnant Women
description: The fast-growing abuse of prescription drugs has reached maternity wards in hospitals across the country, with the number of pregnant women addicted to opiate drugs  and the number of babies born experiencing withdrawal symptoms  rising sharply over the last decade.

title: Delta Buys Refinery to Get Control of Fuel Costs
description: Delta Air Lines said on Monday that it had agreed to buy a refinery near Philadelphia from ConocoPhillips to offset the risk of higher jet fuel prices.

title: Fashion News Were Reading Now
description: Here are the highlights from the White House Correspondents Association dinner, including the red carpet.

title: Disregard These Predictions
description: John Boehner said last week that his party faces a real challenge in holding its Congressional majority. I would say that there is a two-in-three chance that we win control of the House again, he said on Fox News. Then he added, presumably for the benefit of those who struggle with math, but theres a one-in-three chance that we could lose.

title: Note to Self About China: Pick a Fight, Any Fight
description: Christopher Buckleys satirical novels do not normally prompt cognitive dissonance. But theres something jolting at work in his latest, They Eat Puppies, Dont They? This book means to be funny, but its about China, currently one of the least funny places on earth. Its not a period piece, but it is badly dated. Much of its charm is derived from a heroine who seems modeled on Ann Coulter. Much of its hilarity comes from contemplating how to kill off the Dalai Lama and what to do with his corpse.

title: HBO Quickly Renews Girls and Veep
description: HBO never hesitates when a show breaks through the clutter and starts making noise: this spring it has added two noisy comedies to its schedule, Girls and Veep, and on Monday it jumped to renew both of them for second seasons.

title: Scraping a Little More Sky Downtown
description: A small steel tendril poked up atop 1 World Trade Center at 2:08 p.m. on Monday. About 17 minutes later, it was joined by another. Nineteen minutes after that, the first beam joined them, making a fencelike H. Shortly before 3 oclock, the whole center of gravity on the skyline shifted from Midtown back down to Lower Manhattan  at least symbolically.

title: Should Young Athletes Be Screened for Heart Risk?
description: Should high school athletes be screened for heart trouble before taking to the practice field?

description: After a string of accounting missteps, Groupon is adding some financial muscle to its board.

title: T Summer Design | Must Haves
description: On our design list this summer: a bar trolley, illustrative wallpaper, timely clocks. More

title: Kids Draw the News | Epic Brawl Depicted
description: Thanks to all the children who took us up on our first (and somewhat controversial) Kids Draw the News assignment: the big fight in the Tap Room of the New York Athletic Club. Behold their handiwork, in the slide show above.

title: Seacrest Assembles TV Empire
description: Three months ago, when the news, sports and entertainment worlds converged on Indianapolis for the Super Bowl, Ryan Seacrest was at home in Hollywood  and feeling uncharacteristically jealous.

title: Simple Device Helps Delay Birth to Lift Babies Chances of Survival
description: In wealthy countries, some very premature babies are saved in intensive care units. In poor countries, they often die or develop blindness, retardation, lung problems or cerebral palsy.

title: What a Dearth of Small Donations May Mean for Romney
description: The fund-raising apparatus powering President Obamas re-election effort has struggled to attract the big-money donors who contributed to Mr. Obamas record fund-raising haul in 2008.

title: In Birds Pursuit of Love, New Plant Life Blooms
description: Male bowerbirds cultivate plants, a new study reports, though their gardening work appears to be unintentional.

title: Best-Case Scenario: Two Chances to Mate
description: Male orb-web spiders have an unenviable lot. Most of the time, their mates eat them immediately after copulating. Even if that doesnt happen, males can mate at most twice in one lifetime.

title: United States Tops 50 Best Restaurants List With 8 Spots
description: The annual list of the 50 best restaurants in the world, compiled by Restaurant, a British magazine, and sponsored by S. Pellegrino and Acqua Panna, is out. The top three restaurants remain the same: Noma in Copenhagen and Can Roca and Mugaritz in Spain.

title: Bob Smith, Inventor of Fog-Free Ski Goggles, Dies at 78
description: As an orthodontist, Bob Smith knew how to correct a problem. And as an avid skier who tackled the mountains near his home in Alta, Utah, he recognized something in 1964 that needed fixing: ski goggles.

title: Piano Works Both Powerful and Poetic
description: PAUL LEWIS

title: Reliving Days (and Lyrics) When No One Got Along
description: Twenty years ago Los Angeles was burning, a conflagration that began with a videotape. Four police officers who had been captured on camera beating Rodney King were acquitted on April 29, 1992, and for days the city seethed.

title: Academia Occupied by Occupy
description: If surveys of Occupy Wall Street supporters conducted last fall still hold true, the crowds of protesters expected to turn out Tuesday for May Day events across the country will most likely skew male, young, white, college educated, underpaid, and thoroughly disgusted with the American political system.

title: Dutch Troupes Long Road to the Joyce
description: In many ways, Roel Voorintholt and Ton Wiggers seem like an old married couple. The two men spend a great deal of each day together. They also live in the same house. They argue with withering humor over who will buy cigarettes. But Mr. Voorintholt and Mr. Wiggers arent a couple (well, at least not right now, but more on that later).

title: Playing a Dogmatic Leaders Power Games
description: On Friday evening Bloom! Dance Collective, a group of five dancer-choreographers with roots in Hungary, Italy and Spain, made its American debut at Abrons Arts Center. If the piece it presented, City, is an indication, this group isnt coy when it comes to addressing social issues. Even though these artists, based in London and Budapest, welcome humor and convey a decidedly casual vibe, City is political dance. End of story.

title: Clip: First Position
description: A scene from the documentary First Position, about young contestants in a ballet competition.

title: Life in the Sea Found Its Fate in a Paroxysm of Extinction
description: It may never be as well known as the Cretaceous extinction, the one that killed off the dinosaurs. Yet the much earlier Permian extinction  252 million years ago  was by far the most catastrophic of the planets five known paroxysms of species loss.

title: Looking to Make a Profit on Lawsuits, Firms Invest in Them
description: When it comes to legal spats, companies often loathe having to spend millions of dollars on legal fees while waiting months for a case to drag through courts. But to Wall Street, lengthy litigation is a growing investment opportunity.

title: An Underground Fossil Forest Offers Clues on Climate Change
description: In the clammy depths of a southern Illinois coal mine lies the largest fossil forest ever discovered, at least 50 times as extensive as the previous contender.

title: Cuomo Forms Panel to Make 'Action Plan' for  Education
An Olympic Champion, a Symbol and an Awkward Partner With Fame
description: If all you know about Jesse Owens is Hitler, four gold medals and, oh yeah, didnt he run against a horse?, then the American Experience documentary Jesse Owens (Tuesday night on PBS stations) will fill some gaps in brisk and entertaining fashion.

title: As Brooklyn Rents Rise, She Stalks the $625 Apartment
description: If you live in New York and happen to have about $625 in your pocket, you could go out and buy yourself a plane ticket to Los Angeles, a 32-gigabyte iPad, or perhaps a shiny pair of Christian Louboutin pumps. Or you could make that your monthly rent in a city apartment, by sticking with Sophia Cosmadopoulos.

title: Breathing Fire With Ballads
description: Blown Away, the new album by Carrie Underwood, the shiny but tough country star, starts out loud, sassy, rollicking and wise. Good Girl is the first song  a little Pat Benatar, a little Tanya Tucker  and it plays out like a sequel to Ms. Underwoods 2006 smash Before He Cheats, except, instead of taking out her rightfully stoked dissatisfaction on her ex, she opts for unity and warns the next woman instead.

description: The songs were devotional, and the mood was euphoric when Arif Lohar, a Pakistani singer who is a major star in Punjabi music, performed at Asia Society on Friday night, the first of two sold-out concerts.

title: Apple Green Is a Hard Sell With Livery Drivers
description: Jos Trivino leaned against his shiny, black Lincoln Town Car in Jamaica, Queens on Monday, gawking at a newspaper photo of the new Boro Taxi.

title: Devils Seek Answers With Kovalchuk
description: NEWARK  One day after a playoff game in which he was virtually invisible, Ilya Kovalchuk, the Devils $100 million forward, was not available to speak with the news media Monday because he was visiting a therapist, a team spokesman said.

title: High Turnover for Charter School Principals, Report Says
Where China Is a Hot Topic, Even at Lunch
description: LOS ANGELES  The Milken Institute Global Conference has a reputation for being dominated by financiers in suits. But although a dress code of business attire is unofficially enforced, DealBook has met many attendees who dont work on Wall Street. (We particularly liked our conversation with the founder of a technology firm who had strong feelings about United States maritime laws.)

title: With App, Groups Seek Better Way to Report Complaints of Profiling by Airport Security
description: WASHINGTON  Civil rights groups are going digital to combat what they say are instances of racial profiling by security screeners at the nations airports.

title: Loyalists of Malis Overthrown Leader Appear to Be Attempting Countercoup
description: BAMAKO, Mali  Gunfire rang out over this West African capital Monday night as soldiers loyal to the president, who was deposed in a coup in March, appeared to be attempting a countercoup against the ruling military junta.

title: Dont Know Much About (Ancient) History
description: The things I do for book sales. I debated, sort of, Ron Paul on Bloomberg.Video here. I thought we might have a discussion of why the runaway inflation he and his allies keep predicting keeps not happening. But no, he insisted (if I understood him correctly) that currency debasement and price controls destroyed the Roman Empire. I responded that I am not a defender of the economic policies of the Emperor Diocletian.

title: Yankees Have Unfamiliar Alignment in Outfield
description: The Yankees outfield has taken on a shape-shifting quality recently because of injuries to the starters at both corners. That showed in the lineup Monday night against Baltimore, which featured infielder Eduardo Nunez in left field and the defensively challenged Raul Ibanez right.

title: Tigers Young Is Suspended for 7 Days After His Arrest
description: Delmon Young of the Detroit Tigers was suspended for seven days without pay by Major League Baseball on Monday, nearly four days after his arrest in Manhattan on a second-degree aggravated harassment charge.

title: Names of the Dead

title: India: Crowded Ferry Capsizes
description: At least 35 people are dead and more than 160 are missing after a ferry carrying as many as 350 passengers capsized Monday on the swollen Brahmaputra River in eastern India during a severe storm, according to media reports and government officials. Other accounts in the Indian media put the death toll at more than 100. The accident occurred in the remote Indian state of Assam. The state police chief, J. N. Choudhury, told The Associated Press that about 150 people managed to swim to safety or were rescued. Ferry accidents happen with a grim frequency in eastern India and Bangladesh, where many people depend on boats to travel through the region.

title: With Green Beret Tactics, Combating Gang Warfare
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass.  At first glance, the Brightwood neighborhood in this central New England city would seem to have little in common with war-torn villages in Iraq or Afghanistan.
